// Workshop 3 - Copy and Move Semantics
// w3.cpp

#include <iostream>
#include <iomanip>
#include <utility>
#include <ctime>
#include "Text.cpp"

#define TIME(start, end) double((end) - (start)) / CLOCKS_PER_SEC

int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
    if (argc == 1) {
        std::cerr << argv[0] << ": missing file operand\n";
        return 1;
    }
    else if (argc != 2) {
        std::cerr << argv[0] << ": too many arguments\n";
        return 2;
    }
    std::clock_t cs, ce;
    {
        std::cout << std::fixed << std::setprecision(3);
        cs = std::clock();
        w3::Text a;
        ce = std::clock();
        std::cout << "Constructor      " << TIME(cs, ce) << " seconds";
        std::cout << " - a.size = " << a.size() << std::endl;

        cs = std::clock();
        w3::Text b(argv[1]);
        ce = std::clock();
        std::cout << "Constructor      " << TIME(cs, ce) << " seconds";
        std::cout << " - b.size = " << b.size() << std::endl;

        cs = std::clock();
        a = b;
        ce = std::clock();
        std::cout << "Copy Assignment  " << TIME(cs, ce) << " seconds";
        std::cout << " - a.size = " << a.size() << std::endl;

        cs = std::clock();
        a = std::move(b);
        ce = std::clock();
        std::cout << "Move Assignment  " << TIME(cs, ce) << " seconds";
        std::cout << " - a.size = " << a.size() << std::endl;

        cs = std::clock();
        w3::Text c = a;
        ce = std::clock();
        std::cout << "Copy Constructor " << TIME(cs, ce) << " seconds";
        std::cout << " - c.size = " << c.size() << std::endl;

        cs = std::clock();
        w3::Text d = std::move(a);
        ce = std::clock();
        std::cout << "Move Constructor " << TIME(cs, ce) << " seconds";
        std::cout << " - d.size = " << d.size() << std::endl;

        cs = std::clock();
    }
    ce = std::clock();
    std::cout << "Destructor       " << TIME(cs, ce) << " seconds\n";
}

//#pragma once
#include "Text.h"
#define DEBUG

#include <fstream>
#include <iostream>
#include <string>


using namespace std;

namespace w3 {

    class Text {
        string* lineTable;
        size_t lineCount;
    public:
        ~ Text() { if (lineTable) delete[] lineTable; };

        Text() : lineCount(0), lineTable(nullptr) { };

        Text(const char* filename) : lineCount(0), lineTable(nullptr) {

            fstream fs(filename);
            string s;
            if (fs.is_open()) {
                while (getline(fs, s)) {
                    lineCount++;
                }
#ifdef DEBUG
                cout << "file" << filename << " containts" << lineCount << " lines\n";
                lineTable = new string[lineCount];
#endif

                fs.clear();             // reset error state
                fs.seekp(0, ios::beg);  // postiton file offet 0 from the beginning (which is beginning)
                for (size_t l = 0; l < lineCount; l++) {
                    getline(fs, lineTable[l]);
                }
#ifdef DEBUG
                for(size_t l = 0; l < lineCount; l++){
                    cout << "line " << l << "-->" << lineTable[l] << "\n";
                }
#endif
            }
            else {
                cerr << "Cannot open file -->" << filename << "<--\n";
            }
        }

        // assignment operator
        Text &operator=(const Text &rhs) {
            if (this != &rhs) {
                if (lineTable) delete[] lineTable;

                //deep copy
                lineCount = rhs.lineCount;
                lineTable = new string[lineCount];

                for (size_t l = 0; l < lineCount; l++) {
                    lineTable[l] = rhs.lineTable[l];
                }


            }
            return *this;
        }

        // copy constructor
        Text(const Text &rhs) {
            lineTable = nullptr;
            *this = rhs;
        }

        // move assignment operator
        Text& operator=(Text &&rhs) {
            if (this != &rhs) {
                if (lineTable) { delete[] lineTable; };

                lineCount = rhs.lineCount;
                lineTable = new string[lineCount];

                for (size_t l = 0; l < lineCount; l++) {
                    lineTable[l] = rhs.lineTable[l];
                }


            }
            return *this;
        }

        // move constructor
        Text(Text&& rhs) {
            lineTable = nullptr;
            *this = rhs;
        }


        size_t size() const { return lineCount; }
    };
} //namespace w3vzaguzin@matrix:~/oop/oop345/labs/lab3> g++ -o w3 -std=c++0x w3.cpp Text.cpp

line 244-->1609
line 245-->
line 246-->THE SONNETS
line 247-->
line 248-->by William Shakespeare
line 249-->
line 250-->
line 251-->
line 252-->                     1
line 253-->  From fairest creatures we desire increase,
line 254-->  That thereby beauty's rose might never die,
line 255-->  But as the riper should by time decease,
line 256-->  His tender heir might bear his memory:
line 257-->  But thou contracted to thine own bright eyes,
line 258-->  Feed'st thy light's flame with self-substantial fuel,
line 259-->  Making a famine where abundance lies,
line 260-->  Thy self thy foe, to thy sweet self too cruel:
line 261-->  Thou that art now the world's fresh ornament,
line 262-->  And only herald to the gaudy spring,
line 263-->  Within thine own bud buriest thy content,
line 264-->  And tender churl mak'st waste in niggarding:
line 265-->    Pity the world, or else this glutton be,
line 266-->    To eat the world's due, by the grave and thee.
line 267-->
line 268-->
line 269-->                     2
line 270-->  When forty winters shall besiege thy brow,
line 271-->  And dig deep trenches in thy beauty's field,
line 272-->  Thy youth's proud livery so gazed on now,
line 273-->  Will be a tattered weed of small worth held:  
line 274-->  Then being asked, where all thy beauty lies,
line 275-->  Where all the treasure of thy lusty days;
line 276-->  To say within thine own deep sunken eyes,
line 277-->  Were an all-eating shame, and thriftless praise.
line 278-->  How much more praise deserved thy beauty's use,
line 279-->  If thou couldst answer 'This fair child of mine
line 280-->  Shall sum my count, and make my old excuse'
line 281-->  Proving his beauty by succession thine.
line 282-->    This were to be new made when thou art old,
line 283-->    And see thy blood warm when thou feel'st it cold.
line 284-->
line 285-->
line 286-->                     3
line 287-->  Look in thy glass and tell the face thou viewest,
line 288-->  Now is the time that face should form another,
line 289-->  Whose fresh repair if now thou not renewest,
line 290-->  Thou dost beguile the world, unbless some mother.
line 291-->  For where is she so fair whose uneared womb
line 292-->  Disdains the tillage of thy husbandry?
line 293-->  Or who is he so fond will be the tomb,
line 294-->  Of his self-love to stop posterity?  
line 295-->  Thou art thy mother's glass and she in thee
line 296-->  Calls back the lovely April of her prime,
line 297-->  So thou through windows of thine age shalt see,
line 298-->  Despite of wrinkles this thy golden time.
line 299-->    But if thou live remembered not to be,
line 300-->    Die single and thine image dies with thee.
line 301-->
line 302-->
line 303-->                     4
line 304-->  Unthrifty loveliness why dost thou spend,
line 305-->  Upon thy self thy beauty's legacy?
line 306-->  Nature's bequest gives nothing but doth lend,
line 307-->  And being frank she lends to those are free:
line 308-->  Then beauteous niggard why dost thou abuse,
line 309-->  The bounteous largess given thee to give?
line 310-->  Profitless usurer why dost thou use
line 311-->  So great a sum of sums yet canst not live?
line 312-->  For having traffic with thy self alone,
line 313-->  Thou of thy self thy sweet self dost deceive,
line 314-->  Then how when nature calls thee to be gone,
line 315-->  What acceptable audit canst thou leave?  
line 316-->    Thy unused beauty must be tombed with thee,
line 317-->    Which used lives th' executor to be.
line 318-->
line 319-->
line 320-->                     5
line 321-->  Those hours that with gentle work did frame
line 322-->  The lovely gaze where every eye doth dwell
line 323-->  Will play the tyrants to the very same,
line 324-->  And that unfair which fairly doth excel:
line 325-->  For never-resting time leads summer on
line 326-->  To hideous winter and confounds him there,
line 327-->  Sap checked with frost and lusty leaves quite gone,
line 328-->  Beauty o'er-snowed and bareness every where:
line 329-->  Then were not summer's distillation left
line 330-->  A liquid prisoner pent in walls of glass,
line 331-->  Beauty's effect with beauty were bereft,
line 332-->  Nor it nor no remembrance what it was.
line 333-->    But flowers distilled though they with winter meet,
line 334-->    Leese but their show, their substance still lives sweet.
line 335-->
line 336-->
line 337-->                     6  
line 338-->  Then let not winter's ragged hand deface,
line 339-->  In thee thy summer ere thou be distilled:
line 340-->  Make sweet some vial; treasure thou some place,
line 341-->  With beauty's treasure ere it be self-killed:
line 342-->  That use is not forbidden usury,
line 343-->  Which happies those that pay the willing loan;
line 344-->  That's for thy self to breed another thee,
line 345-->  Or ten times happier be it ten for one,
line 346-->  Ten times thy self were happier than thou art,
line 347-->  If ten of thine ten times refigured thee:
line 348-->  Then what could death do if thou shouldst depart,
line 349-->  Leaving thee living in posterity?
line 350-->    Be not self-willed for thou art much too fair,
line 351-->    To be death's conquest and make worms thine heir.
line 352-->
line 353-->
line 354-->                     7
line 355-->  Lo in the orient when the gracious light
line 356-->  Lifts up his burning head, each under eye
line 357-->  Doth homage to his new-appearing sight,
line 358-->  Serving with looks his sacred majesty,  
line 359-->  And having climbed the steep-up heavenly hill,
line 360-->  Resembling strong youth in his middle age,
line 361-->  Yet mortal looks adore his beauty still,
line 362-->  Attending on his golden pilgrimage:
line 363-->  But when from highmost pitch with weary car,
line 364-->  Like feeble age he reeleth from the day,
line 365-->  The eyes (fore duteous) now converted are
line 366-->  From his low tract and look another way:
line 367-->    So thou, thy self out-going in thy noon:
line 368-->    Unlooked on diest unless thou get a son.
line 369-->
line 370-->
line 371-->                     8
line 372-->  Music to hear, why hear'st thou music sadly?
line 373-->  Sweets with sweets war not, joy delights in joy:
line 374-->  Why lov'st thou that which thou receiv'st not gladly,
line 375-->  Or else receiv'st with pleasure thine annoy?
line 376-->  If the true concord of well-tuned sounds,
line 377-->  By unions married do offend thine ear,
line 378-->  They do but sweetly chide thee, who confounds
line 379-->  In singleness the parts that thou shouldst bear:  
line 380-->  Mark how one string sweet husband to another,
line 381-->  Strikes each in each by mutual ordering;
line 382-->  Resembling sire, and child, and happy mother,
line 383-->  Who all in one, one pleasing note do sing:
line 384-->    Whose speechless song being many, seeming one,
line 385-->    Sings this to thee, 'Thou single wilt prove none'.
line 386-->
line 387-->
line 388-->                     9
line 389-->  Is it for fear to wet a widow's eye,
line 390-->  That thou consum'st thy self in single life?
line 391-->  Ah, if thou issueless shalt hap to die,
line 392-->  The world will wail thee like a makeless wife,
line 393-->  The world will be thy widow and still weep,
line 394-->  That thou no form of thee hast left behind,
line 395-->  When every private widow well may keep,
line 396-->  By children's eyes, her husband's shape in mind:
line 397-->  Look what an unthrift in the world doth spend
line 398-->  Shifts but his place, for still the world enjoys it;
line 399-->  But beauty's waste hath in the world an end,
line 400-->  And kept unused the user so destroys it:  
line 401-->    No love toward others in that bosom sits
line 402-->    That on himself such murd'rous shame commits.
line 403-->
line 404-->
line 405-->                     10
line 406-->  For shame deny that thou bear'st love to any
line 407-->  Who for thy self art so unprovident.
line 408-->  Grant if thou wilt, thou art beloved of many,
line 409-->  But that thou none lov'st is most evident:
line 410-->  For thou art so possessed with murd'rous hate,
line 411-->  That 'gainst thy self thou stick'st not to conspire,
line 412-->  Seeking that beauteous roof to ruinate
line 413-->  Which to repair should be thy chief desire:
line 414-->  O change thy thought, that I may change my mind,
line 415-->  Shall hate be fairer lodged than gentle love?
line 416-->  Be as thy presence is gracious and kind,
line 417-->  Or to thy self at least kind-hearted prove,
line 418-->    Make thee another self for love of me,
line 419-->    That beauty still may live in thine or thee.
line 420-->
line 421-->
line 422-->                     11  
line 423-->  As fast as thou shalt wane so fast thou grow'st,
line 424-->  In one of thine, from that which thou departest,
line 425-->  And that fresh blood which youngly thou bestow'st,
line 426-->  Thou mayst call thine, when thou from youth convertest,
line 427-->  Herein lives wisdom, beauty, and increase,
line 428-->  Without this folly, age, and cold decay,
line 429-->  If all were minded so, the times should cease,
line 430-->  And threescore year would make the world away:
line 431-->  Let those whom nature hath not made for store,
line 432-->  Harsh, featureless, and rude, barrenly perish:
line 433-->  Look whom she best endowed, she gave thee more;
line 434-->  Which bounteous gift thou shouldst in bounty cherish:
line 435-->    She carved thee for her seal, and meant thereby,
line 436-->    Thou shouldst print more, not let that copy die.
line 437-->
line 438-->
line 439-->                     12
line 440-->  When I do count the clock that tells the time,
line 441-->  And see the brave day sunk in hideous night,
line 442-->  When I behold the violet past prime,
line 443-->  And sable curls all silvered o'er with white:  
line 444-->  When lofty trees I see barren of leaves,
line 445-->  Which erst from heat did canopy the herd
line 446-->  And summer's green all girded up in sheaves
line 447-->  Borne on the bier with white and bristly beard:
line 448-->  Then of thy beauty do I question make
line 449-->  That thou among the wastes of time must go,
line 450-->  Since sweets and beauties do themselves forsake,
line 451-->  And die as fast as they see others grow,
line 452-->    And nothing 'gainst Time's scythe can make defence
line 453-->    Save breed to brave him, when he takes thee hence.
line 454-->
line 455-->
line 456-->                     13
line 457-->  O that you were your self, but love you are
line 458-->  No longer yours, than you your self here live,
line 459-->  Against this coming end you should prepare,
line 460-->  And your sweet semblance to some other give.
line 461-->  So should that beauty which you hold in lease
line 462-->  Find no determination, then you were
line 463-->  Your self again after your self's decease,
line 464-->  When your sweet issue your sweet form should bear.  
line 465-->  Who lets so fair a house fall to decay,
line 466-->  Which husbandry in honour might uphold,
line 467-->  Against the stormy gusts of winter's day
line 468-->  And barren rage of death's eternal cold?
line 469-->    O none but unthrifts, dear my love you know,
line 470-->    You had a father, let your son say so.
line 471-->
line 472-->
line 473-->                     14
line 474-->  Not from the stars do I my judgement pluck,
line 475-->  And yet methinks I have astronomy,
line 476-->  But not to tell of good, or evil luck,
line 477-->  Of plagues, of dearths, or seasons' quality,
line 478-->  Nor can I fortune to brief minutes tell;
line 479-->  Pointing to each his thunder, rain and wind,
line 480-->  Or say with princes if it shall go well
line 481-->  By oft predict that I in heaven find.
line 482-->  But from thine eyes my knowledge I derive,
line 483-->  And constant stars in them I read such art
line 484-->  As truth and beauty shall together thrive
line 485-->  If from thy self, to store thou wouldst convert:  
line 486-->    Or else of thee this I prognosticate,
line 487-->    Thy end is truth's and beauty's doom and date.
line 488-->
line 489-->
line 490-->                     15
line 491-->  When I consider every thing that grows
line 492-->  Holds in perfection but a little moment.
line 493-->  That this huge stage presenteth nought but shows
line 494-->  Whereon the stars in secret influence comment.
line 495-->  When I perceive that men as plants increase,
line 496-->  Cheered and checked even by the self-same sky:
line 497-->  Vaunt in their youthful sap, at height decrease,
line 498-->  And wear their brave state out of memory.
line 499-->  Then the conceit of this inconstant stay,
line 500-->  Sets you most rich in youth before my sight,
line 501-->  Where wasteful time debateth with decay
line 502-->  To change your day of youth to sullied night,
line 503-->    And all in war with Time for love of you,
line 504-->    As he takes from you, I engraft you new.
line 505-->
line 506-->
line 507-->                     16  
line 508-->  But wherefore do not you a mightier way
line 509-->  Make war upon this bloody tyrant Time?
line 510-->  And fortify your self in your decay
line 511-->  With means more blessed than my barren rhyme?
line 512-->  Now stand you on the top of happy hours,
line 513-->  And many maiden gardens yet unset,
line 514-->  With virtuous wish would bear you living flowers,
line 515-->  Much liker than your painted counterfeit:
line 516-->  So should the lines of life that life repair
line 517-->  Which this (Time's pencil) or my pupil pen
line 518-->  Neither in inward worth nor outward fair
line 519-->  Can make you live your self in eyes of men.
line 520-->    To give away your self, keeps your self still,
line 521-->    And you must live drawn by your own sweet skill.
line 522-->
line 523-->
line 524-->                     17
line 525-->  Who will believe my verse in time to come
line 526-->  If it were filled with your most high deserts?
line 527-->  Though yet heaven knows it is but as a tomb
line 528-->  Which hides your life, and shows not half your parts:  
line 529-->  If I could write the beauty of your eyes,
line 530-->  And in fresh numbers number all your graces,
line 531-->  The age to come would say this poet lies,
line 532-->  Such heavenly touches ne'er touched earthly faces.
line 533-->  So should my papers (yellowed with their age)
line 534-->  Be scorned, like old men of less truth than tongue,
line 535-->  And your true rights be termed a poet's rage,
line 536-->  And stretched metre of an antique song.
line 537-->    But were some child of yours alive that time,
line 538-->    You should live twice in it, and in my rhyme.
line 539-->
line 540-->
line 541-->                     18
line 542-->  Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?
line 543-->  Thou art more lovely and more temperate:
line 544-->  Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,
line 545-->  And summer's lease hath all too short a date:
line 546-->  Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines,
line 547-->  And often is his gold complexion dimmed,
line 548-->  And every fair from fair sometime declines,
line 549-->  By chance, or nature's changing course untrimmed:  
line 550-->  But thy eternal summer shall not fade,
line 551-->  Nor lose possession of that fair thou ow'st,
line 552-->  Nor shall death brag thou wand'rest in his shade,
line 553-->  When in eternal lines to time thou grow'st,
line 554-->    So long as men can breathe or eyes can see,
line 555-->    So long lives this, and this gives life to thee.
line 556-->
line 557-->
line 558-->                     19
line 559-->  Devouring Time blunt thou the lion's paws,
line 560-->  And make the earth devour her own sweet brood,
line 561-->  Pluck the keen teeth from the fierce tiger's jaws,
line 562-->  And burn the long-lived phoenix, in her blood,
line 563-->  Make glad and sorry seasons as thou fleet'st,
line 564-->  And do whate'er thou wilt swift-footed Time
line 565-->  To the wide world and all her fading sweets:
line 566-->  But I forbid thee one most heinous crime,
line 567-->  O carve not with thy hours my love's fair brow,
line 568-->  Nor draw no lines there with thine antique pen,
line 569-->  Him in thy course untainted do allow,
line 570-->  For beauty's pattern to succeeding men.  
line 571-->    Yet do thy worst old Time: despite thy wrong,
line 572-->    My love shall in my verse ever live young.
line 573-->
line 574-->
line 575-->                     20
line 576-->  A woman's face with nature's own hand painted,
line 577-->  Hast thou the master mistress of my passion,
line 578-->  A woman's gentle heart but not acquainted
line 579-->  With shifting change as is false women's fashion,
line 580-->  An eye more bright than theirs, less false in rolling:
line 581-->  Gilding the object whereupon it gazeth,
line 582-->  A man in hue all hues in his controlling,
line 583-->  Which steals men's eyes and women's souls amazeth.
line 584-->  And for a woman wert thou first created,
line 585-->  Till nature as she wrought thee fell a-doting,
line 586-->  And by addition me of thee defeated,
line 587-->  By adding one thing to my purpose nothing.
line 588-->    But since she pricked thee out for women's pleasure,
line 589-->    Mine be thy love and thy love's use their treasure.
line 590-->
line 591-->
line 592-->                     21  
line 593-->  So is it not with me as with that muse,
line 594-->  Stirred by a painted beauty to his verse,
line 595-->  Who heaven it self for ornament doth use,
line 596-->  And every fair with his fair doth rehearse,
line 597-->  Making a couplement of proud compare
line 598-->  With sun and moon, with earth and sea's rich gems:
line 599-->  With April's first-born flowers and all things rare,
line 600-->  That heaven's air in this huge rondure hems.
line 601-->  O let me true in love but truly write,
line 602-->  And then believe me, my love is as fair,
line 603-->  As any mother's child, though not so bright
line 604-->  As those gold candles fixed in heaven's air:
line 605-->    Let them say more that like of hearsay well,
line 606-->    I will not praise that purpose not to sell.
line 607-->
line 608-->
line 609-->                     22
line 610-->  My glass shall not persuade me I am old,
line 611-->  So long as youth and thou are of one date,
line 612-->  But when in thee time's furrows I behold,
line 613-->  Then look I death my days should expiate.  
line 614-->  For all that beauty that doth cover thee,
line 615-->  Is but the seemly raiment of my heart,
line 616-->  Which in thy breast doth live, as thine in me,
line 617-->  How can I then be elder than thou art?
line 618-->  O therefore love be of thyself so wary,
line 619-->  As I not for my self, but for thee will,
line 620-->  Bearing thy heart which I will keep so chary
line 621-->  As tender nurse her babe from faring ill.
line 622-->    Presume not on thy heart when mine is slain,
line 623-->    Thou gav'st me thine not to give back again.
line 624-->
line 625-->
line 626-->                     23
line 627-->  As an unperfect actor on the stage,
line 628-->  Who with his fear is put beside his part,
line 629-->  Or some fierce thing replete with too much rage,
line 630-->  Whose strength's abundance weakens his own heart;
line 631-->  So I for fear of trust, forget to say,
line 632-->  The perfect ceremony of love's rite,
line 633-->  And in mine own love's strength seem to decay,
line 634-->  O'ercharged with burthen of mine own love's might:  
line 635-->  O let my looks be then the eloquence,
line 636-->  And dumb presagers of my speaking breast,
line 637-->  Who plead for love, and look for recompense,
line 638-->  More than that tongue that more hath more expressed.
line 639-->    O learn to read what silent love hath writ,
line 640-->    To hear with eyes belongs to love's fine wit.
line 641-->
line 642-->
line 643-->                     24
line 644-->  Mine eye hath played the painter and hath stelled,
line 645-->  Thy beauty's form in table of my heart,
line 646-->  My body is the frame wherein 'tis held,
line 647-->  And perspective it is best painter's art.
line 648-->  For through the painter must you see his skill,
line 649-->  To find where your true image pictured lies,
line 650-->  Which in my bosom's shop is hanging still,
line 651-->  That hath his windows glazed with thine eyes:
line 652-->  Now see what good turns eyes for eyes have done,
line 653-->  Mine eyes have drawn thy shape, and thine for me
line 654-->  Are windows to my breast, where-through the sun
line 655-->  Delights to peep, to gaze therein on thee;  
line 656-->    Yet eyes this cunning want to grace their art,
line 657-->    They draw but what they see, know not the heart.
line 658-->
line 659-->
line 660-->                     25
line 661-->  Let those who are in favour with their stars,
line 662-->  Of public honour and proud titles boast,
line 663-->  Whilst I whom fortune of such triumph bars
line 664-->  Unlooked for joy in that I honour most;
line 665-->  Great princes' favourites their fair leaves spread,
line 666-->  But as the marigold at the sun's eye,
line 667-->  And in themselves their pride lies buried,
line 668-->  For at a frown they in their glory die.
line 669-->  The painful warrior famoused for fight,
line 670-->  After a thousand victories once foiled,
line 671-->  Is from the book of honour razed quite,
line 672-->  And all the rest forgot for which he toiled:
line 673-->    Then happy I that love and am beloved
line 674-->    Where I may not remove nor be removed.
line 675-->
line 676-->
line 677-->                     26  
line 678-->  Lord of my love, to whom in vassalage
line 679-->  Thy merit hath my duty strongly knit;
line 680-->  To thee I send this written embassage
line 681-->  To witness duty, not to show my wit.
line 682-->  Duty so great, which wit so poor as mine
line 683-->  May make seem bare, in wanting words to show it;
line 684-->  But that I hope some good conceit of thine
line 685-->  In thy soul's thought (all naked) will bestow it:
line 686-->  Till whatsoever star that guides my moving,
line 687-->  Points on me graciously with fair aspect,
line 688-->  And puts apparel on my tattered loving,
line 689-->  To show me worthy of thy sweet respect,
line 690-->    Then may I dare to boast how I do love thee,
line 691-->    Till then, not show my head where thou mayst prove me.
line 692-->
line 693-->
line 694-->                     27
line 695-->  Weary with toil, I haste me to my bed,
line 696-->  The dear respose for limbs with travel tired,
line 697-->  But then begins a journey in my head
line 698-->  To work my mind, when body's work's expired.  
line 699-->  For then my thoughts (from far where I abide)
line 700-->  Intend a zealous pilgrimage to thee,
line 701-->  And keep my drooping eyelids open wide,
line 702-->  Looking on darkness which the blind do see.
line 703-->  Save that my soul's imaginary sight
line 704-->  Presents thy shadow to my sightless view,
line 705-->  Which like a jewel (hung in ghastly night)
line 706-->  Makes black night beauteous, and her old face new.
line 707-->    Lo thus by day my limbs, by night my mind,
line 708-->    For thee, and for my self, no quiet find.
line 709-->
line 710-->
line 711-->                     28
line 712-->  How can I then return in happy plight
line 713-->  That am debarred the benefit of rest?
line 714-->  When day's oppression is not eased by night,
line 715-->  But day by night and night by day oppressed.
line 716-->  And each (though enemies to either's reign)
line 717-->  Do in consent shake hands to torture me,
line 718-->  The one by toil, the other to complain
line 719-->  How far I toil, still farther off from thee.  
line 720-->  I tell the day to please him thou art bright,
line 721-->  And dost him grace when clouds do blot the heaven:
line 722-->  So flatter I the swart-complexioned night,
line 723-->  When sparkling stars twire not thou gild'st the even.
line 724-->    But day doth daily draw my sorrows longer,
line 725-->    And night doth nightly make grief's length seem stronger
line 726-->
line 727-->
line 728-->                     29
line 729-->  When in disgrace with Fortune and men's eyes,
line 730-->  I all alone beweep my outcast state,
line 731-->  And trouble deaf heaven with my bootless cries,
line 732-->  And look upon my self and curse my fate,
line 733-->  Wishing me like to one more rich in hope,
line 734-->  Featured like him, like him with friends possessed,
line 735-->  Desiring this man's art, and that man's scope,
line 736-->  With what I most enjoy contented least,
line 737-->  Yet in these thoughts my self almost despising,
line 738-->  Haply I think on thee, and then my state,
line 739-->  (Like to the lark at break of day arising
line 740-->  From sullen earth) sings hymns at heaven's gate,  
line 741-->    For thy sweet love remembered such wealth brings,
line 742-->    That then I scorn to change my state with kings.
line 743-->
line 744-->
line 745-->                     30
line 746-->  When to the sessions of sweet silent thought,
line 747-->  I summon up remembrance of things past,
line 748-->  I sigh the lack of many a thing I sought,
line 749-->  And with old woes new wail my dear time's waste:
line 750-->  Then can I drown an eye (unused to flow)
line 751-->  For precious friends hid in death's dateless night,
line 752-->  And weep afresh love's long since cancelled woe,
line 753-->  And moan th' expense of many a vanished sight.
line 754-->  Then can I grieve at grievances foregone,
line 755-->  And heavily from woe to woe tell o'er
line 756-->  The sad account of fore-bemoaned moan,
line 757-->  Which I new pay as if not paid before.
line 758-->    But if the while I think on thee (dear friend)
line 759-->    All losses are restored, and sorrows end.
line 760-->
line 761-->
line 762-->                     31  
line 763-->  Thy bosom is endeared with all hearts,
line 764-->  Which I by lacking have supposed dead,
line 765-->  And there reigns love and all love's loving parts,
line 766-->  And all those friends which I thought buried.
line 767-->  How many a holy and obsequious tear
line 768-->  Hath dear religious love stol'n from mine eye,
line 769-->  As interest of the dead, which now appear,
line 770-->  But things removed that hidden in thee lie.
line 771-->  Thou art the grave where buried love doth live,
line 772-->  Hung with the trophies of my lovers gone,
line 773-->  Who all their parts of me to thee did give,
line 774-->  That due of many, now is thine alone.
line 775-->    Their images I loved, I view in thee,
line 776-->    And thou (all they) hast all the all of me.
line 777-->
line 778-->
line 779-->                     32
line 780-->  If thou survive my well-contented day,
line 781-->  When that churl death my bones with dust shall cover
line 782-->  And shalt by fortune once more re-survey
line 783-->  These poor rude lines of thy deceased lover:  
line 784-->  Compare them with the bett'ring of the time,
line 785-->  And though they be outstripped by every pen,
line 786-->  Reserve them for my love, not for their rhyme,
line 787-->  Exceeded by the height of happier men.
line 788-->  O then vouchsafe me but this loving thought,
line 789-->  'Had my friend's Muse grown with this growing age,
line 790-->  A dearer birth than this his love had brought
line 791-->  To march in ranks of better equipage:
line 792-->    But since he died and poets better prove,
line 793-->    Theirs for their style I'll read, his for his love'.
line 794-->
line 795-->
line 796-->                     33
line 797-->  Full many a glorious morning have I seen,
line 798-->  Flatter the mountain tops with sovereign eye,
line 799-->  Kissing with golden face the meadows green;
line 800-->  Gilding pale streams with heavenly alchemy:
line 801-->  Anon permit the basest clouds to ride,
line 802-->  With ugly rack on his celestial face,
line 803-->  And from the forlorn world his visage hide
line 804-->  Stealing unseen to west with this disgrace:  
line 805-->  Even so my sun one early morn did shine,
line 806-->  With all triumphant splendour on my brow,
line 807-->  But out alack, he was but one hour mine,
line 808-->  The region cloud hath masked him from me now.
line 809-->    Yet him for this, my love no whit disdaineth,
line 810-->    Suns of the world may stain, when heaven's sun staineth.
line 811-->
line 812-->
line 813-->                     34
line 814-->  Why didst thou promise such a beauteous day,
line 815-->  And make me travel forth without my cloak,
line 816-->  To let base clouds o'ertake me in my way,
line 817-->  Hiding thy brav'ry in their rotten smoke?
line 818-->  'Tis not enough that through the cloud thou break,
line 819-->  To dry the rain on my storm-beaten face,
line 820-->  For no man well of such a salve can speak,
line 821-->  That heals the wound, and cures not the disgrace:
line 822-->  Nor can thy shame give physic to my grief,
line 823-->  Though thou repent, yet I have still the loss,
line 824-->  Th' offender's sorrow lends but weak relief
line 825-->  To him that bears the strong offence's cross.  
line 826-->    Ah but those tears are pearl which thy love sheds,
line 827-->    And they are rich, and ransom all ill deeds.
line 828-->
line 829-->
line 830-->                     35
line 831-->  No more be grieved at that which thou hast done,
line 832-->  Roses have thorns, and silver fountains mud,
line 833-->  Clouds and eclipses stain both moon and sun,
line 834-->  And loathsome canker lives in sweetest bud.
line 835-->  All men make faults, and even I in this,
line 836-->  Authorizing thy trespass with compare,
line 837-->  My self corrupting salving thy amiss,
line 838-->  Excusing thy sins more than thy sins are:
line 839-->  For to thy sensual fault I bring in sense,
line 840-->  Thy adverse party is thy advocate,
line 841-->  And 'gainst my self a lawful plea commence:
line 842-->  Such civil war is in my love and hate,
line 843-->    That I an accessary needs must be,
line 844-->    To that sweet thief which sourly robs from me.
line 845-->
line 846-->
line 847-->                     36  
line 848-->  Let me confess that we two must be twain,
line 849-->  Although our undivided loves are one:
line 850-->  So shall those blots that do with me remain,
line 851-->  Without thy help, by me be borne alone.
line 852-->  In our two loves there is but one respect,
line 853-->  Though in our lives a separable spite,
line 854-->  Which though it alter not love's sole effect,
line 855-->  Yet doth it steal sweet hours from love's delight.
line 856-->  I may not evermore acknowledge thee,
line 857-->  Lest my bewailed guilt should do thee shame,
line 858-->  Nor thou with public kindness honour me,
line 859-->  Unless thou take that honour from thy name:
line 860-->    But do not so, I love thee in such sort,
line 861-->    As thou being mine, mine is thy good report.
line 862-->
line 863-->
line 864-->                     37
line 865-->  As a decrepit father takes delight,
line 866-->  To see his active child do deeds of youth,
line 867-->  So I, made lame by Fortune's dearest spite
line 868-->  Take all my comfort of thy worth and truth.  
line 869-->  For whether beauty, birth, or wealth, or wit,
line 870-->  Or any of these all, or all, or more
line 871-->  Entitled in thy parts, do crowned sit,
line 872-->  I make my love engrafted to this store:
line 873-->  So then I am not lame, poor, nor despised,
line 874-->  Whilst that this shadow doth such substance give,
line 875-->  That I in thy abundance am sufficed,
line 876-->  And by a part of all thy glory live:
line 877-->    Look what is best, that best I wish in thee,
line 878-->    This wish I have, then ten times happy me.
line 879-->
line 880-->
line 881-->                     38
line 882-->  How can my muse want subject to invent
line 883-->  While thou dost breathe that pour'st into my verse,
line 884-->  Thine own sweet argument, too excellent,
line 885-->  For every vulgar paper to rehearse?
line 886-->  O give thy self the thanks if aught in me,
line 887-->  Worthy perusal stand against thy sight,
line 888-->  For who's so dumb that cannot write to thee,
line 889-->  When thou thy self dost give invention light?  
line 890-->  Be thou the tenth Muse, ten times more in worth
line 891-->  Than those old nine which rhymers invocate,
line 892-->  And he that calls on thee, let him bring forth
line 893-->  Eternal numbers to outlive long date.
line 894-->    If my slight muse do please these curious days,
line 895-->    The pain be mine, but thine shall be the praise.
line 896-->
line 897-->
line 898-->                     39
line 899-->  O how thy worth with manners may I sing,
line 900-->  When thou art all the better part of me?
line 901-->  What can mine own praise to mine own self bring:
line 902-->  And what is't but mine own when I praise thee?
line 903-->  Even for this, let us divided live,
line 904-->  And our dear love lose name of single one,
line 905-->  That by this separation I may give:
line 906-->  That due to thee which thou deserv'st alone:
line 907-->  O absence what a torment wouldst thou prove,
line 908-->  Were it not thy sour leisure gave sweet leave,
line 909-->  To entertain the time with thoughts of love,
line 910-->  Which time and thoughts so sweetly doth deceive.  
line 911-->    And that thou teachest how to make one twain,
line 912-->    By praising him here who doth hence remain.
line 913-->
line 914-->
line 915-->                     40
line 916-->  Take all my loves, my love, yea take them all,
line 917-->  What hast thou then more than thou hadst before?
line 918-->  No love, my love, that thou mayst true love call,
line 919-->  All mine was thine, before thou hadst this more:
line 920-->  Then if for my love, thou my love receivest,
line 921-->  I cannot blame thee, for my love thou usest,
line 922-->  But yet be blamed, if thou thy self deceivest
line 923-->  By wilful taste of what thy self refusest.
line 924-->  I do forgive thy robbery gentle thief
line 925-->  Although thou steal thee all my poverty:
line 926-->  And yet love knows it is a greater grief
line 927-->  To bear greater wrong, than hate's known injury.
line 928-->    Lascivious grace, in whom all ill well shows,
line 929-->    Kill me with spites yet we must not be foes.
line 930-->
line 931-->
line 932-->                     41  
line 933-->  Those pretty wrongs that liberty commits,
line 934-->  When I am sometime absent from thy heart,
line 935-->  Thy beauty, and thy years full well befits,
line 936-->  For still temptation follows where thou art.
line 937-->  Gentle thou art, and therefore to be won,
line 938-->  Beauteous thou art, therefore to be assailed.
line 939-->  And when a woman woos, what woman's son,
line 940-->  Will sourly leave her till he have prevailed?
line 941-->  Ay me, but yet thou mightst my seat forbear,
line 942-->  And chide thy beauty, and thy straying youth,
line 943-->  Who lead thee in their riot even there
line 944-->  Where thou art forced to break a twofold truth:
line 945-->    Hers by thy beauty tempting her to thee,
line 946-->    Thine by thy beauty being false to me.
line 947-->
line 948-->
line 949-->                     42
line 950-->  That thou hast her it is not all my grief,
line 951-->  And yet it may be said I loved her dearly,
line 952-->  That she hath thee is of my wailing chief,
line 953-->  A loss in love that touches me more nearly.  
line 954-->  Loving offenders thus I will excuse ye,
line 955-->  Thou dost love her, because thou know'st I love her,
line 956-->  And for my sake even so doth she abuse me,
line 957-->  Suff'ring my friend for my sake to approve her.
line 958-->  If I lose thee, my loss is my love's gain,
line 959-->  And losing her, my friend hath found that loss,
line 960-->  Both find each other, and I lose both twain,
line 961-->  And both for my sake lay on me this cross,
line 962-->    But here's the joy, my friend and I are one,
line 963-->    Sweet flattery, then she loves but me alone.
line 964-->
line 965-->
line 966-->                     43
line 967-->  When most I wink then do mine eyes best see,
line 968-->  For all the day they view things unrespected,
line 969-->  But when I sleep, in dreams they look on thee,
line 970-->  And darkly bright, are bright in dark directed.
line 971-->  Then thou whose shadow shadows doth make bright
line 972-->  How would thy shadow's form, form happy show,
line 973-->  To the clear day with thy much clearer light,
line 974-->  When to unseeing eyes thy shade shines so!  
line 975-->  How would (I say) mine eyes be blessed made,
line 976-->  By looking on thee in the living day,
line 977-->  When in dead night thy fair imperfect shade,
line 978-->  Through heavy sleep on sightless eyes doth stay!
line 979-->    All days are nights to see till I see thee,
line 980-->    And nights bright days when dreams do show thee me.
line 981-->
line 982-->
line 983-->                     44
line 984-->  If the dull substance of my flesh were thought,
line 985-->  Injurious distance should not stop my way,
line 986-->  For then despite of space I would be brought,
line 987-->  From limits far remote, where thou dost stay,
line 988-->  No matter then although my foot did stand
line 989-->  Upon the farthest earth removed from thee,
line 990-->  For nimble thought can jump both sea and land,
line 991-->  As soon as think the place where he would be.
line 992-->  But ah, thought kills me that I am not thought
line 993-->  To leap large lengths of miles when thou art gone,
line 994-->  But that so much of earth and water wrought,
line 995-->  I must attend, time's leisure with my moan.  
line 996-->    Receiving nought by elements so slow,
line 997-->    But heavy tears, badges of either's woe.
line 998-->
line 999-->
line 1000-->                     45
line 1001-->  The other two, slight air, and purging fire,
line 1002-->  Are both with thee, wherever I abide,
line 1003-->  The first my thought, the other my desire,
line 1004-->  These present-absent with swift motion slide.
line 1005-->  For when these quicker elements are gone
line 1006-->  In tender embassy of love to thee,
line 1007-->  My life being made of four, with two alone,
line 1008-->  Sinks down to death, oppressed with melancholy.
line 1009-->  Until life's composition be recured,
line 1010-->  By those swift messengers returned from thee,
line 1011-->  Who even but now come back again assured,
line 1012-->  Of thy fair health, recounting it to me.
line 1013-->    This told, I joy, but then no longer glad,
line 1014-->    I send them back again and straight grow sad.
line 1015-->
line 1016-->
line 1017-->                     46  
line 1018-->  Mine eye and heart are at a mortal war,
line 1019-->  How to divide the conquest of thy sight,
line 1020-->  Mine eye, my heart thy picture's sight would bar,
line 1021-->  My heart, mine eye the freedom of that right,
line 1022-->  My heart doth plead that thou in him dost lie,
line 1023-->  (A closet never pierced with crystal eyes)
line 1024-->  But the defendant doth that plea deny,
line 1025-->  And says in him thy fair appearance lies.
line 1026-->  To side this title is impanelled
line 1027-->  A quest of thoughts, all tenants to the heart,
line 1028-->  And by their verdict is determined
line 1029-->  The clear eye's moiety, and the dear heart's part.
line 1030-->    As thus, mine eye's due is thy outward part,
line 1031-->    And my heart's right, thy inward love of heart.
line 1032-->
line 1033-->
line 1034-->                     47
line 1035-->  Betwixt mine eye and heart a league is took,
line 1036-->  And each doth good turns now unto the other,
line 1037-->  When that mine eye is famished for a look,
line 1038-->  Or heart in love with sighs himself doth smother;  
line 1039-->  With my love's picture then my eye doth feast,
line 1040-->  And to the painted banquet bids my heart:
line 1041-->  Another time mine eye is my heart's guest,
line 1042-->  And in his thoughts of love doth share a part.
line 1043-->  So either by thy picture or my love,
line 1044-->  Thy self away, art present still with me,
line 1045-->  For thou not farther than my thoughts canst move,
line 1046-->  And I am still with them, and they with thee.
line 1047-->    Or if they sleep, thy picture in my sight
line 1048-->    Awakes my heart, to heart's and eye's delight.
line 1049-->
line 1050-->
line 1051-->                     48
line 1052-->  How careful was I when I took my way,
line 1053-->  Each trifle under truest bars to thrust,
line 1054-->  That to my use it might unused stay
line 1055-->  From hands of falsehood, in sure wards of trust!
line 1056-->  But thou, to whom my jewels trifles are,
line 1057-->  Most worthy comfort, now my greatest grief,
line 1058-->  Thou best of dearest, and mine only care,
line 1059-->  Art left the prey of every vulgar thief.  
line 1060-->  Thee have I not locked up in any chest,
line 1061-->  Save where thou art not, though I feel thou art,
line 1062-->  Within the gentle closure of my breast,
line 1063-->  From whence at pleasure thou mayst come and part,
line 1064-->    And even thence thou wilt be stol'n I fear,
line 1065-->    For truth proves thievish for a prize so dear.
line 1066-->
line 1067-->
line 1068-->                     49
line 1069-->  Against that time (if ever that time come)
line 1070-->  When I shall see thee frown on my defects,
line 1071-->  When as thy love hath cast his utmost sum,
line 1072-->  Called to that audit by advised respects,
line 1073-->  Against that time when thou shalt strangely pass,
line 1074-->  And scarcely greet me with that sun thine eye,
line 1075-->  When love converted from the thing it was
line 1076-->  Shall reasons find of settled gravity;
line 1077-->  Against that time do I ensconce me here
line 1078-->  Within the knowledge of mine own desert,
line 1079-->  And this my hand, against my self uprear,
line 1080-->  To guard the lawful reasons on thy part,  
line 1081-->    To leave poor me, thou hast the strength of laws,
line 1082-->    Since why to love, I can allege no cause.
line 1083-->
line 1084-->
line 1085-->                     50
line 1086-->  How heavy do I journey on the way,
line 1087-->  When what I seek (my weary travel's end)
line 1088-->  Doth teach that case and that repose to say
line 1089-->  'Thus far the miles are measured from thy friend.'
line 1090-->  The beast that bears me, tired with my woe,
line 1091-->  Plods dully on, to bear that weight in me,
line 1092-->  As if by some instinct the wretch did know
line 1093-->  His rider loved not speed being made from thee:
line 1094-->  The bloody spur cannot provoke him on,
line 1095-->  That sometimes anger thrusts into his hide,
line 1096-->  Which heavily he answers with a groan,
line 1097-->  More sharp to me than spurring to his side,
line 1098-->    For that same groan doth put this in my mind,
line 1099-->    My grief lies onward and my joy behind.
line 1100-->
line 1101-->
line 1102-->                     51  
line 1103-->  Thus can my love excuse the slow offence,
line 1104-->  Of my dull bearer, when from thee I speed,
line 1105-->  From where thou art, why should I haste me thence?
line 1106-->  Till I return of posting is no need.
line 1107-->  O what excuse will my poor beast then find,
line 1108-->  When swift extremity can seem but slow?
line 1109-->  Then should I spur though mounted on the wind,
line 1110-->  In winged speed no motion shall I know,
line 1111-->  Then can no horse with my desire keep pace,
line 1112-->  Therefore desire (of perfect'st love being made)
line 1113-->  Shall neigh (no dull flesh) in his fiery race,
line 1114-->  But love, for love, thus shall excuse my jade,
line 1115-->    Since from thee going, he went wilful-slow,
line 1116-->    Towards thee I'll run, and give him leave to go.
line 1117-->
line 1118-->
line 1119-->                     52
line 1120-->  So am I as the rich whose blessed key,
line 1121-->  Can bring him to his sweet up-locked treasure,
line 1122-->  The which he will not every hour survey,
line 1123-->  For blunting the fine point of seldom pleasure.  
line 1124-->  Therefore are feasts so solemn and so rare,
line 1125-->  Since seldom coming in that long year set,
line 1126-->  Like stones of worth they thinly placed are,
line 1127-->  Or captain jewels in the carcanet.
line 1128-->  So is the time that keeps you as my chest
line 1129-->  Or as the wardrobe which the robe doth hide,
line 1130-->  To make some special instant special-blest,
line 1131-->  By new unfolding his imprisoned pride.
line 1132-->    Blessed are you whose worthiness gives scope,
line 1133-->    Being had to triumph, being lacked to hope.
line 1134-->
line 1135-->
line 1136-->                     53
line 1137-->  What is your substance, whereof are you made,
line 1138-->  That millions of strange shadows on you tend?
line 1139-->  Since every one, hath every one, one shade,
line 1140-->  And you but one, can every shadow lend:
line 1141-->  Describe Adonis and the counterfeit,
line 1142-->  Is poorly imitated after you,
line 1143-->  On Helen's cheek all art of beauty set,
line 1144-->  And you in Grecian tires are painted new:  
line 1145-->  Speak of the spring, and foison of the year,
line 1146-->  The one doth shadow of your beauty show,
line 1147-->  The other as your bounty doth appear,
line 1148-->  And you in every blessed shape we know.
line 1149-->    In all external grace you have some part,
line 1150-->    But you like none, none you for constant heart.
line 1151-->
line 1152-->
line 1153-->                     54
line 1154-->  O how much more doth beauty beauteous seem,
line 1155-->  By that sweet ornament which truth doth give!
line 1156-->  The rose looks fair, but fairer we it deem
line 1157-->  For that sweet odour, which doth in it live:
line 1158-->  The canker blooms have full as deep a dye,
line 1159-->  As the perfumed tincture of the roses,
line 1160-->  Hang on such thorns, and play as wantonly,
line 1161-->  When summer's breath their masked buds discloses:
line 1162-->  But for their virtue only is their show,
line 1163-->  They live unwooed, and unrespected fade,
line 1164-->  Die to themselves. Sweet roses do not so,
line 1165-->  Of their sweet deaths, are sweetest odours made:  
line 1166-->    And so of you, beauteous and lovely youth,
line 1167-->    When that shall vade, by verse distills your truth.
line 1168-->
line 1169-->
line 1170-->                     55
line 1171-->  Not marble, nor the gilded monuments
line 1172-->  Of princes shall outlive this powerful rhyme,
line 1173-->  But you shall shine more bright in these contents
line 1174-->  Than unswept stone, besmeared with sluttish time.
line 1175-->  When wasteful war shall statues overturn,
line 1176-->  And broils root out the work of masonry,
line 1177-->  Nor Mars his sword, nor war's quick fire shall burn:
line 1178-->  The living record of your memory.
line 1179-->  'Gainst death, and all-oblivious enmity
line 1180-->  Shall you pace forth, your praise shall still find room,
line 1181-->  Even in the eyes of all posterity
line 1182-->  That wear this world out to the ending doom.
line 1183-->    So till the judgment that your self arise,
line 1184-->    You live in this, and dwell in lovers' eyes.
line 1185-->
line 1186-->
line 1187-->                     56  
line 1188-->  Sweet love renew thy force, be it not said
line 1189-->  Thy edge should blunter be than appetite,
line 1190-->  Which but to-day by feeding is allayed,
line 1191-->  To-morrow sharpened in his former might.
line 1192-->  So love be thou, although to-day thou fill
line 1193-->  Thy hungry eyes, even till they wink with fulness,
line 1194-->  To-morrow see again, and do not kill
line 1195-->  The spirit of love, with a perpetual dulness:
line 1196-->  Let this sad interim like the ocean be
line 1197-->  Which parts the shore, where two contracted new,
line 1198-->  Come daily to the banks, that when they see:
line 1199-->  Return of love, more blest may be the view.
line 1200-->    Or call it winter, which being full of care,
line 1201-->    Makes summer's welcome, thrice more wished, more rare.
line 1202-->
line 1203-->
line 1204-->                     57
line 1205-->  Being your slave what should I do but tend,
line 1206-->  Upon the hours, and times of your desire?
line 1207-->  I have no precious time at all to spend;
line 1208-->  Nor services to do till you require.  
line 1209-->  Nor dare I chide the world-without-end hour,
line 1210-->  Whilst I (my sovereign) watch the clock for you,
line 1211-->  Nor think the bitterness of absence sour,
line 1212-->  When you have bid your servant once adieu.
line 1213-->  Nor dare I question with my jealous thought,
line 1214-->  Where you may be, or your affairs suppose,
line 1215-->  But like a sad slave stay and think of nought
line 1216-->  Save where you are, how happy you make those.
line 1217-->    So true a fool is love, that in your will,
line 1218-->    (Though you do any thing) he thinks no ill.
line 1219-->
line 1220-->
line 1221-->                     58
line 1222-->  That god forbid, that made me first your slave,
line 1223-->  I should in thought control your times of pleasure,
line 1224-->  Or at your hand th' account of hours to crave,
line 1225-->  Being your vassal bound to stay your leisure.
line 1226-->  O let me suffer (being at your beck)
line 1227-->  Th' imprisoned absence of your liberty,
line 1228-->  And patience tame to sufferance bide each check,
line 1229-->  Without accusing you of injury.  
line 1230-->  Be where you list, your charter is so strong,
line 1231-->  That you your self may privilage your time
line 1232-->  To what you will, to you it doth belong,
line 1233-->  Your self to pardon of self-doing crime.
line 1234-->    I am to wait, though waiting so be hell,
line 1235-->    Not blame your pleasure be it ill or well.
line 1236-->
line 1237-->
line 1238-->                     59
line 1239-->  If there be nothing new, but that which is,
line 1240-->  Hath been before, how are our brains beguiled,
line 1241-->  Which labouring for invention bear amis
line 1242-->  The second burthen of a former child!
line 1243-->  O that record could with a backward look,
line 1244-->  Even of five hundred courses of the sun,
line 1245-->  Show me your image in some antique book,
line 1246-->  Since mind at first in character was done.
line 1247-->  That I might see what the old world could say,
line 1248-->  To this composed wonder of your frame,
line 1249-->  Whether we are mended, or whether better they,
line 1250-->  Or whether revolution be the same.  
line 1251-->    O sure I am the wits of former days,
line 1252-->    To subjects worse have given admiring praise.
line 1253-->
line 1254-->
line 1255-->                     60
line 1256-->  Like as the waves make towards the pebbled shore,
line 1257-->  So do our minutes hasten to their end,
line 1258-->  Each changing place with that which goes before,
line 1259-->  In sequent toil all forwards do contend.
line 1260-->  Nativity once in the main of light,
line 1261-->  Crawls to maturity, wherewith being crowned,
line 1262-->  Crooked eclipses 'gainst his glory fight,
line 1263-->  And Time that gave, doth now his gift confound.
line 1264-->  Time doth transfix the flourish set on youth,
line 1265-->  And delves the parallels in beauty's brow,
line 1266-->  Feeds on the rarities of nature's truth,
line 1267-->  And nothing stands but for his scythe to mow.
line 1268-->    And yet to times in hope, my verse shall stand
line 1269-->    Praising thy worth, despite his cruel hand.
line 1270-->
line 1271-->
line 1272-->                     61  
line 1273-->  Is it thy will, thy image should keep open
line 1274-->  My heavy eyelids to the weary night?
line 1275-->  Dost thou desire my slumbers should be broken,
line 1276-->  While shadows like to thee do mock my sight?
line 1277-->  Is it thy spirit that thou send'st from thee
line 1278-->  So far from home into my deeds to pry,
line 1279-->  To find out shames and idle hours in me,
line 1280-->  The scope and tenure of thy jealousy?
line 1281-->  O no, thy love though much, is not so great,
line 1282-->  It is my love that keeps mine eye awake,
line 1283-->  Mine own true love that doth my rest defeat,
line 1284-->  To play the watchman ever for thy sake.
line 1285-->    For thee watch I, whilst thou dost wake elsewhere,
line 1286-->    From me far off, with others all too near.
line 1287-->
line 1288-->
line 1289-->                     62
line 1290-->  Sin of self-love possesseth all mine eye,
line 1291-->  And all my soul, and all my every part;
line 1292-->  And for this sin there is no remedy,
line 1293-->  It is so grounded inward in my heart.  
line 1294-->  Methinks no face so gracious is as mine,
line 1295-->  No shape so true, no truth of such account,
line 1296-->  And for my self mine own worth do define,
line 1297-->  As I all other in all worths surmount.
line 1298-->  But when my glass shows me my self indeed
line 1299-->  beated and chopt with tanned antiquity,
line 1300-->  Mine own self-love quite contrary I read:
line 1301-->  Self, so self-loving were iniquity.
line 1302-->    'Tis thee (my self) that for my self I praise,
line 1303-->    Painting my age with beauty of thy days.
line 1304-->
line 1305-->
line 1306-->                     63
line 1307-->  Against my love shall be as I am now
line 1308-->  With Time's injurious hand crushed and o'erworn,
line 1309-->  When hours have drained his blood and filled his brow
line 1310-->  With lines and wrinkles, when his youthful morn
line 1311-->  Hath travelled on to age's steepy night,
line 1312-->  And all those beauties whereof now he's king
line 1313-->  Are vanishing, or vanished out of sight,
line 1314-->  Stealing away the treasure of his spring:  
line 1315-->  For such a time do I now fortify
line 1316-->  Against confounding age's cruel knife,
line 1317-->  That he shall never cut from memory
line 1318-->  My sweet love's beauty, though my lover's life.
line 1319-->    His beauty shall in these black lines be seen,
line 1320-->    And they shall live, and he in them still green.
line 1321-->
line 1322-->
line 1323-->                     64
line 1324-->  When I have seen by Time's fell hand defaced
line 1325-->  The rich-proud cost of outworn buried age,
line 1326-->  When sometime lofty towers I see down-rased,
line 1327-->  And brass eternal slave to mortal rage.
line 1328-->  When I have seen the hungry ocean gain
line 1329-->  Advantage on the kingdom of the shore,
line 1330-->  And the firm soil win of the watery main,
line 1331-->  Increasing store with loss, and loss with store.
line 1332-->  When I have seen such interchange of State,
line 1333-->  Or state it self confounded, to decay,
line 1334-->  Ruin hath taught me thus to ruminate
line 1335-->  That Time will come and take my love away.  
line 1336-->    This thought is as a death which cannot choose
line 1337-->    But weep to have, that which it fears to lose.
line 1338-->
line 1339-->
line 1340-->                     65
line 1341-->  Since brass, nor stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea,
line 1342-->  But sad mortality o'ersways their power,
line 1343-->  How with this rage shall beauty hold a plea,
line 1344-->  Whose action is no stronger than a flower?
line 1345-->  O how shall summer's honey breath hold out,
line 1346-->  Against the wrackful siege of batt'ring days,
line 1347-->  When rocks impregnable are not so stout,
line 1348-->  Nor gates of steel so strong but time decays?
line 1349-->  O fearful meditation, where alack,
line 1350-->  Shall Time's best jewel from Time's chest lie hid?
line 1351-->  Or what strong hand can hold his swift foot back,
line 1352-->  Or who his spoil of beauty can forbid?
line 1353-->    O none, unless this miracle have might,
line 1354-->    That in black ink my love may still shine bright.
line 1355-->
line 1356-->
line 1357-->                     66  
line 1358-->  Tired with all these for restful death I cry,
line 1359-->  As to behold desert a beggar born,
line 1360-->  And needy nothing trimmed in jollity,
line 1361-->  And purest faith unhappily forsworn,
line 1362-->  And gilded honour shamefully misplaced,
line 1363-->  And maiden virtue rudely strumpeted,
line 1364-->  And right perfection wrongfully disgraced,
line 1365-->  And strength by limping sway disabled
line 1366-->  And art made tongue-tied by authority,
line 1367-->  And folly (doctor-like) controlling skill,
line 1368-->  And simple truth miscalled simplicity,
line 1369-->  And captive good attending captain ill.
line 1370-->    Tired with all these, from these would I be gone,
line 1371-->    Save that to die, I leave my love alone.
line 1372-->
line 1373-->
line 1374-->                     67
line 1375-->  Ah wherefore with infection should he live,
line 1376-->  And with his presence grace impiety,
line 1377-->  That sin by him advantage should achieve,
line 1378-->  And lace it self with his society?  
line 1379-->  Why should false painting imitate his cheek,
line 1380-->  And steal dead seeming of his living hue?
line 1381-->  Why should poor beauty indirectly seek,
line 1382-->  Roses of shadow, since his rose is true?
line 1383-->  Why should he live, now nature bankrupt is,
line 1384-->  Beggared of blood to blush through lively veins,
line 1385-->  For she hath no exchequer now but his,
line 1386-->  And proud of many, lives upon his gains?
line 1387-->    O him she stores, to show what wealth she had,
line 1388-->    In days long since, before these last so bad.
line 1389-->
line 1390-->
line 1391-->                     68
line 1392-->  Thus is his cheek the map of days outworn,
line 1393-->  When beauty lived and died as flowers do now,
line 1394-->  Before these bastard signs of fair were born,
line 1395-->  Or durst inhabit on a living brow:
line 1396-->  Before the golden tresses of the dead,
line 1397-->  The right of sepulchres, were shorn away,
line 1398-->  To live a second life on second head,
line 1399-->  Ere beauty's dead fleece made another gay:  
line 1400-->  In him those holy antique hours are seen,
line 1401-->  Without all ornament, it self and true,
line 1402-->  Making no summer of another's green,
line 1403-->  Robbing no old to dress his beauty new,
line 1404-->    And him as for a map doth Nature store,
line 1405-->    To show false Art what beauty was of yore.
line 1406-->
line 1407-->
line 1408-->                     69
line 1409-->  Those parts of thee that the world's eye doth view,
line 1410-->  Want nothing that the thought of hearts can mend:
line 1411-->  All tongues (the voice of souls) give thee that due,
line 1412-->  Uttering bare truth, even so as foes commend.
line 1413-->  Thy outward thus with outward praise is crowned,
line 1414-->  But those same tongues that give thee so thine own,
line 1415-->  In other accents do this praise confound
line 1416-->  By seeing farther than the eye hath shown.
line 1417-->  They look into the beauty of thy mind,
line 1418-->  And that in guess they measure by thy deeds,
line 1419-->  Then churls their thoughts (although their eyes were kind)
line 1420-->  To thy fair flower add the rank smell of weeds:  
line 1421-->    But why thy odour matcheth not thy show,
line 1422-->    The soil is this, that thou dost common grow.
line 1423-->
line 1424-->
line 1425-->                     70
line 1426-->  That thou art blamed shall not be thy defect,
line 1427-->  For slander's mark was ever yet the fair,
line 1428-->  The ornament of beauty is suspect,
line 1429-->  A crow that flies in heaven's sweetest air.
line 1430-->  So thou be good, slander doth but approve,
line 1431-->  Thy worth the greater being wooed of time,
line 1432-->  For canker vice the sweetest buds doth love,
line 1433-->  And thou present'st a pure unstained prime.
line 1434-->  Thou hast passed by the ambush of young days,
line 1435-->  Either not assailed, or victor being charged,
line 1436-->  Yet this thy praise cannot be so thy praise,
line 1437-->  To tie up envy, evermore enlarged,
line 1438-->    If some suspect of ill masked not thy show,
line 1439-->    Then thou alone kingdoms of hearts shouldst owe.
line 1440-->
line 1441-->
line 1442-->                     71  
line 1443-->  No longer mourn for me when I am dead,
line 1444-->  Than you shall hear the surly sullen bell
line 1445-->  Give warning to the world that I am fled
line 1446-->  From this vile world with vilest worms to dwell:
line 1447-->  Nay if you read this line, remember not,
line 1448-->  The hand that writ it, for I love you so,
line 1449-->  That I in your sweet thoughts would be forgot,
line 1450-->  If thinking on me then should make you woe.
line 1451-->  O if (I say) you look upon this verse,
line 1452-->  When I (perhaps) compounded am with clay,
line 1453-->  Do not so much as my poor name rehearse;
line 1454-->  But let your love even with my life decay.
line 1455-->    Lest the wise world should look into your moan,
line 1456-->    And mock you with me after I am gone.
line 1457-->
line 1458-->
line 1459-->                     72
line 1460-->  O lest the world should task you to recite,
line 1461-->  What merit lived in me that you should love
line 1462-->  After my death (dear love) forget me quite,
line 1463-->  For you in me can nothing worthy prove.  
line 1464-->  Unless you would devise some virtuous lie,
line 1465-->  To do more for me than mine own desert,
line 1466-->  And hang more praise upon deceased I,
line 1467-->  Than niggard truth would willingly impart:
line 1468-->  O lest your true love may seem false in this,
line 1469-->  That you for love speak well of me untrue,
line 1470-->  My name be buried where my body is,
line 1471-->  And live no more to shame nor me, nor you.
line 1472-->    For I am shamed by that which I bring forth,
line 1473-->    And so should you, to love things nothing worth.
line 1474-->
line 1475-->
line 1476-->                     73
line 1477-->  That time of year thou mayst in me behold,
line 1478-->  When yellow leaves, or none, or few do hang
line 1479-->  Upon those boughs which shake against the cold,
line 1480-->  Bare ruined choirs, where late the sweet birds sang.
line 1481-->  In me thou seest the twilight of such day,
line 1482-->  As after sunset fadeth in the west,
line 1483-->  Which by and by black night doth take away,
line 1484-->  Death's second self that seals up all in rest.  
line 1485-->  In me thou seest the glowing of such fire,
line 1486-->  That on the ashes of his youth doth lie,
line 1487-->  As the death-bed, whereon it must expire,
line 1488-->  Consumed with that which it was nourished by.
line 1489-->    This thou perceiv'st, which makes thy love more strong,
line 1490-->    To love that well, which thou must leave ere long.
line 1491-->
line 1492-->
line 1493-->                     74
line 1494-->  But be contented when that fell arrest,
line 1495-->  Without all bail shall carry me away,
line 1496-->  My life hath in this line some interest,
line 1497-->  Which for memorial still with thee shall stay.
line 1498-->  When thou reviewest this, thou dost review,
line 1499-->  The very part was consecrate to thee,
line 1500-->  The earth can have but earth, which is his due,
line 1501-->  My spirit is thine the better part of me,
line 1502-->  So then thou hast but lost the dregs of life,
line 1503-->  The prey of worms, my body being dead,
line 1504-->  The coward conquest of a wretch's knife,
line 1505-->  Too base of thee to be remembered,  
line 1506-->    The worth of that, is that which it contains,
line 1507-->    And that is this, and this with thee remains.
line 1508-->
line 1509-->
line 1510-->                     75
line 1511-->  So are you to my thoughts as food to life,
line 1512-->  Or as sweet-seasoned showers are to the ground;
line 1513-->  And for the peace of you I hold such strife
line 1514-->  As 'twixt a miser and his wealth is found.
line 1515-->  Now proud as an enjoyer, and anon
line 1516-->  Doubting the filching age will steal his treasure,
line 1517-->  Now counting best to be with you alone,
line 1518-->  Then bettered that the world may see my pleasure,
line 1519-->  Sometime all full with feasting on your sight,
line 1520-->  And by and by clean starved for a look,
line 1521-->  Possessing or pursuing no delight
line 1522-->  Save what is had, or must from you be took.
line 1523-->    Thus do I pine and surfeit day by day,
line 1524-->    Or gluttoning on all, or all away.
line 1525-->
line 1526-->
line 1527-->                     76  
line 1528-->  Why is my verse so barren of new pride?
line 1529-->  So far from variation or quick change?
line 1530-->  Why with the time do I not glance aside
line 1531-->  To new-found methods, and to compounds strange?
line 1532-->  Why write I still all one, ever the same,
line 1533-->  And keep invention in a noted weed,
line 1534-->  That every word doth almost tell my name,
line 1535-->  Showing their birth, and where they did proceed?
line 1536-->  O know sweet love I always write of you,
line 1537-->  And you and love are still my argument:
line 1538-->  So all my best is dressing old words new,
line 1539-->  Spending again what is already spent:
line 1540-->    For as the sun is daily new and old,
line 1541-->    So is my love still telling what is told.
line 1542-->
line 1543-->
line 1544-->                     77
line 1545-->  Thy glass will show thee how thy beauties wear,
line 1546-->  Thy dial how thy precious minutes waste,
line 1547-->  These vacant leaves thy mind's imprint will bear,
line 1548-->  And of this book, this learning mayst thou taste.  
line 1549-->  The wrinkles which thy glass will truly show,
line 1550-->  Of mouthed graves will give thee memory,
line 1551-->  Thou by thy dial's shady stealth mayst know,
line 1552-->  Time's thievish progress to eternity.
line 1553-->  Look what thy memory cannot contain,
line 1554-->  Commit to these waste blanks, and thou shalt find
line 1555-->  Those children nursed, delivered from thy brain,
line 1556-->  To take a new acquaintance of thy mind.
line 1557-->    These offices, so oft as thou wilt look,
line 1558-->    Shall profit thee, and much enrich thy book.
line 1559-->
line 1560-->
line 1561-->                     78
line 1562-->  So oft have I invoked thee for my muse,
line 1563-->  And found such fair assistance in my verse,
line 1564-->  As every alien pen hath got my use,
line 1565-->  And under thee their poesy disperse.
line 1566-->  Thine eyes, that taught the dumb on high to sing,
line 1567-->  And heavy ignorance aloft to fly,
line 1568-->  Have added feathers to the learned's wing,
line 1569-->  And given grace a double majesty.
line 1570-->  Yet be most proud of that which I compile,
line 1571-->  Whose influence is thine, and born of thee,
line 1572-->  In others' works thou dost but mend the style,
line 1573-->  And arts with thy sweet graces graced be.
line 1574-->    But thou art all my art, and dost advance
line 1575-->    As high as learning, my rude ignorance.
line 1576-->
line 1577-->
line 1578-->                     79
line 1579-->  Whilst I alone did call upon thy aid,
line 1580-->  My verse alone had all thy gentle grace,
line 1581-->  But now my gracious numbers are decayed,
line 1582-->  And my sick muse doth give an other place.
line 1583-->  I grant (sweet love) thy lovely argument
line 1584-->  Deserves the travail of a worthier pen,
line 1585-->  Yet what of thee thy poet doth invent,
line 1586-->  He robs thee of, and pays it thee again,
line 1587-->  He lends thee virtue, and he stole that word,
line 1588-->  From thy behaviour, beauty doth he give
line 1589-->  And found it in thy cheek: he can afford
line 1590-->  No praise to thee, but what in thee doth live.  
line 1591-->    Then thank him not for that which he doth say,
line 1592-->    Since what he owes thee, thou thy self dost pay.
line 1593-->
line 1594-->
line 1595-->                     80
line 1596-->  O how I faint when I of you do write,
line 1597-->  Knowing a better spirit doth use your name,
line 1598-->  And in the praise thereof spends all his might,
line 1599-->  To make me tongue-tied speaking of your fame.
line 1600-->  But since your worth (wide as the ocean is)
line 1601-->  The humble as the proudest sail doth bear,
line 1602-->  My saucy bark (inferior far to his)
line 1603-->  On your broad main doth wilfully appear.
line 1604-->  Your shallowest help will hold me up afloat,
line 1605-->  Whilst he upon your soundless deep doth ride,
line 1606-->  Or (being wrecked) I am a worthless boat,
line 1607-->  He of tall building, and of goodly pride.
line 1608-->    Then if he thrive and I be cast away,
line 1609-->    The worst was this, my love was my decay.
line 1610-->
line 1611-->
line 1612-->                     81  
line 1613-->  Or I shall live your epitaph to make,
line 1614-->  Or you survive when I in earth am rotten,
line 1615-->  From hence your memory death cannot take,
line 1616-->  Although in me each part will be forgotten.
line 1617-->  Your name from hence immortal life shall have,
line 1618-->  Though I (once gone) to all the world must die,
line 1619-->  The earth can yield me but a common grave,
line 1620-->  When you entombed in men's eyes shall lie,
line 1621-->  Your monument shall be my gentle verse,
line 1622-->  Which eyes not yet created shall o'er-read,
line 1623-->  And tongues to be, your being shall rehearse,
line 1624-->  When all the breathers of this world are dead,
line 1625-->    You still shall live (such virtue hath my pen)
line 1626-->    Where breath most breathes, even in the mouths of men.
line 1627-->
line 1628-->
line 1629-->                     82
line 1630-->  I grant thou wert not married to my muse,
line 1631-->  And therefore mayst without attaint o'erlook
line 1632-->  The dedicated words which writers use
line 1633-->  Of their fair subject, blessing every book.  
line 1634-->  Thou art as fair in knowledge as in hue,
line 1635-->  Finding thy worth a limit past my praise,
line 1636-->  And therefore art enforced to seek anew,
line 1637-->  Some fresher stamp of the time-bettering days.
line 1638-->  And do so love, yet when they have devised,
line 1639-->  What strained touches rhetoric can lend,
line 1640-->  Thou truly fair, wert truly sympathized,
line 1641-->  In true plain words, by thy true-telling friend.
line 1642-->    And their gross painting might be better used,
line 1643-->    Where cheeks need blood, in thee it is abused.
line 1644-->
line 1645-->
line 1646-->                     83
line 1647-->  I never saw that you did painting need,
line 1648-->  And therefore to your fair no painting set,
line 1649-->  I found (or thought I found) you did exceed,
line 1650-->  That barren tender of a poet's debt:
line 1651-->  And therefore have I slept in your report,
line 1652-->  That you your self being extant well might show,
line 1653-->  How far a modern quill doth come too short,
line 1654-->  Speaking of worth, what worth in you doth grow.  
line 1655-->  This silence for my sin you did impute,
line 1656-->  Which shall be most my glory being dumb,
line 1657-->  For I impair not beauty being mute,
line 1658-->  When others would give life, and bring a tomb.
line 1659-->    There lives more life in one of your fair eyes,
line 1660-->    Than both your poets can in praise devise.
line 1661-->
line 1662-->
line 1663-->                     84
line 1664-->  Who is it that says most, which can say more,
line 1665-->  Than this rich praise, that you alone, are you?
line 1666-->  In whose confine immured is the store,
line 1667-->  Which should example where your equal grew.
line 1668-->  Lean penury within that pen doth dwell,
line 1669-->  That to his subject lends not some small glory,
line 1670-->  But he that writes of you, if he can tell,
line 1671-->  That you are you, so dignifies his story.
line 1672-->  Let him but copy what in you is writ,
line 1673-->  Not making worse what nature made so clear,
line 1674-->  And such a counterpart shall fame his wit,
line 1675-->  Making his style admired every where.  
line 1676-->    You to your beauteous blessings add a curse,
line 1677-->    Being fond on praise, which makes your praises worse.
line 1678-->
line 1679-->
line 1680-->                     85
line 1681-->  My tongue-tied muse in manners holds her still,
line 1682-->  While comments of your praise richly compiled,
line 1683-->  Reserve their character with golden quill,
line 1684-->  And precious phrase by all the Muses filed.
line 1685-->  I think good thoughts, whilst other write good words,
line 1686-->  And like unlettered clerk still cry Amen,
line 1687-->  To every hymn that able spirit affords,
line 1688-->  In polished form of well refined pen.
line 1689-->  Hearing you praised, I say 'tis so, 'tis true,
line 1690-->  And to the most of praise add something more,
line 1691-->  But that is in my thought, whose love to you
line 1692-->  (Though words come hindmost) holds his rank before,
line 1693-->    Then others, for the breath of words respect,
line 1694-->    Me for my dumb thoughts, speaking in effect.
line 1695-->
line 1696-->
line 1697-->                     86  
line 1698-->  Was it the proud full sail of his great verse,
line 1699-->  Bound for the prize of (all too precious) you,
line 1700-->  That did my ripe thoughts in my brain inhearse,
line 1701-->  Making their tomb the womb wherein they grew?
line 1702-->  Was it his spirit, by spirits taught to write,
line 1703-->  Above a mortal pitch, that struck me dead?
line 1704-->  No, neither he, nor his compeers by night
line 1705-->  Giving him aid, my verse astonished.
line 1706-->  He nor that affable familiar ghost
line 1707-->  Which nightly gulls him with intelligence,
line 1708-->  As victors of my silence cannot boast,
line 1709-->  I was not sick of any fear from thence.
line 1710-->    But when your countenance filled up his line,
line 1711-->    Then lacked I matter, that enfeebled mine.
line 1712-->
line 1713-->
line 1714-->                     87
line 1715-->  Farewell! thou art too dear for my possessing,
line 1716-->  And like enough thou know'st thy estimate,
line 1717-->  The charter of thy worth gives thee releasing:
line 1718-->  My bonds in thee are all determinate.  
line 1719-->  For how do I hold thee but by thy granting,
line 1720-->  And for that riches where is my deserving?
line 1721-->  The cause of this fair gift in me is wanting,
line 1722-->  And so my patent back again is swerving.
line 1723-->  Thy self thou gav'st, thy own worth then not knowing,
line 1724-->  Or me to whom thou gav'st it, else mistaking,
line 1725-->  So thy great gift upon misprision growing,
line 1726-->  Comes home again, on better judgement making.
line 1727-->    Thus have I had thee as a dream doth flatter,
line 1728-->    In sleep a king, but waking no such matter.
