line 1729-->
line 1730-->
line 1731-->                     88
line 1732-->  When thou shalt be disposed to set me light,
line 1733-->  And place my merit in the eye of scorn,
line 1734-->  Upon thy side, against my self I'll fight,
line 1735-->  And prove thee virtuous, though thou art forsworn:
line 1736-->  With mine own weakness being best acquainted,
line 1737-->  Upon thy part I can set down a story
line 1738-->  Of faults concealed, wherein I am attainted:
line 1739-->  That thou in losing me, shalt win much glory:  
line 1740-->  And I by this will be a gainer too,
line 1741-->  For bending all my loving thoughts on thee,
line 1742-->  The injuries that to my self I do,
line 1743-->  Doing thee vantage, double-vantage me.
line 1744-->    Such is my love, to thee I so belong,
line 1745-->    That for thy right, my self will bear all wrong.
line 1746-->
line 1747-->
line 1748-->                     89
line 1749-->  Say that thou didst forsake me for some fault,
line 1750-->  And I will comment upon that offence,
line 1751-->  Speak of my lameness, and I straight will halt:
line 1752-->  Against thy reasons making no defence.
line 1753-->  Thou canst not (love) disgrace me half so ill,
line 1754-->  To set a form upon desired change,
line 1755-->  As I'll my self disgrace, knowing thy will,
line 1756-->  I will acquaintance strangle and look strange:
line 1757-->  Be absent from thy walks and in my tongue,
line 1758-->  Thy sweet beloved name no more shall dwell,
line 1759-->  Lest I (too much profane) should do it wronk:
line 1760-->  And haply of our old acquaintance tell.  
line 1761-->    For thee, against my self I'll vow debate,
line 1762-->    For I must ne'er love him whom thou dost hate.
line 1763-->
line 1764-->
line 1765-->                     90
line 1766-->  Then hate me when thou wilt, if ever, now,
line 1767-->  Now while the world is bent my deeds to cross,
line 1768-->  join with the spite of fortune, make me bow,
line 1769-->  And do not drop in for an after-loss:
line 1770-->  Ah do not, when my heart hath 'scaped this sorrow,
line 1771-->  Come in the rearward of a conquered woe,
line 1772-->  Give not a windy night a rainy morrow,
line 1773-->  To linger out a purposed overthrow.
line 1774-->  If thou wilt leave me, do not leave me last,
line 1775-->  When other petty griefs have done their spite,
line 1776-->  But in the onset come, so shall I taste
line 1777-->  At first the very worst of fortune's might.
line 1778-->    And other strains of woe, which now seem woe,
line 1779-->    Compared with loss of thee, will not seem so.
line 1780-->
line 1781-->
line 1782-->                     91  
line 1783-->  Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,
line 1784-->  Some in their wealth, some in their body's force,
line 1785-->  Some in their garments though new-fangled ill:
line 1786-->  Some in their hawks and hounds, some in their horse.
line 1787-->  And every humour hath his adjunct pleasure,
line 1788-->  Wherein it finds a joy above the rest,
line 1789-->  But these particulars are not my measure,
line 1790-->  All these I better in one general best.
line 1791-->  Thy love is better than high birth to me,
line 1792-->  Richer than wealth, prouder than garments' costs,
line 1793-->  Of more delight than hawks and horses be:
line 1794-->  And having thee, of all men's pride I boast.
line 1795-->    Wretched in this alone, that thou mayst take,
line 1796-->    All this away, and me most wretchcd make.
line 1797-->
line 1798-->
line 1799-->                     92
line 1800-->  But do thy worst to steal thy self away,
line 1801-->  For term of life thou art assured mine,
line 1802-->  And life no longer than thy love will stay,
line 1803-->  For it depends upon that love of thine.  
line 1804-->  Then need I not to fear the worst of wrongs,
line 1805-->  When in the least of them my life hath end,
line 1806-->  I see, a better state to me belongs
line 1807-->  Than that, which on thy humour doth depend.
line 1808-->  Thou canst not vex me with inconstant mind,
line 1809-->  Since that my life on thy revolt doth lie,
line 1810-->  O what a happy title do I find,
line 1811-->  Happy to have thy love, happy to die!
line 1812-->    But what's so blessed-fair that fears no blot?
line 1813-->    Thou mayst be false, and yet I know it not.
line 1814-->
line 1815-->
line 1816-->                     93
line 1817-->  So shall I live, supposing thou art true,
line 1818-->  Like a deceived husband, so love's face,
line 1819-->  May still seem love to me, though altered new:
line 1820-->  Thy looks with me, thy heart in other place.
line 1821-->  For there can live no hatred in thine eye,
line 1822-->  Therefore in that I cannot know thy change,
line 1823-->  In many's looks, the false heart's history
line 1824-->  Is writ in moods and frowns and wrinkles strange.  
line 1825-->  But heaven in thy creation did decree,
line 1826-->  That in thy face sweet love should ever dwell,
line 1827-->  Whate'er thy thoughts, or thy heart's workings be,
line 1828-->  Thy looks should nothing thence, but sweetness tell.
line 1829-->    How like Eve's apple doth thy beauty grow,
line 1830-->    If thy sweet virtue answer not thy show.
line 1831-->
line 1832-->
line 1833-->                     94
line 1834-->  They that have power to hurt, and will do none,
line 1835-->  That do not do the thing, they most do show,
line 1836-->  Who moving others, are themselves as stone,
line 1837-->  Unmoved, cold, and to temptation slow:
line 1838-->  They rightly do inherit heaven's graces,
line 1839-->  And husband nature's riches from expense,
line 1840-->  Tibey are the lords and owners of their faces,
line 1841-->  Others, but stewards of their excellence:
line 1842-->  The summer's flower is to the summer sweet,
line 1843-->  Though to it self, it only live and die,
line 1844-->  But if that flower with base infection meet,
line 1845-->  The basest weed outbraves his dignity:  
line 1846-->    For sweetest things turn sourest by their deeds,
line 1847-->    Lilies that fester, smell far worse than weeds.
line 1848-->
line 1849-->
line 1850-->                     95
line 1851-->  How sweet and lovely dost thou make the shame,
line 1852-->  Which like a canker in the fragrant rose,
line 1853-->  Doth spot the beauty of thy budding name!
line 1854-->  O in what sweets dost thou thy sins enclose!
line 1855-->  That tongue that tells the story of thy days,
line 1856-->  (Making lascivious comments on thy sport)
line 1857-->  Cannot dispraise, but in a kind of praise,
line 1858-->  Naming thy name, blesses an ill report.
line 1859-->  O what a mansion have those vices got,
line 1860-->  Which for their habitation chose out thee,
line 1861-->  Where beauty's veil doth cover every blot,
line 1862-->  And all things turns to fair, that eyes can see!
line 1863-->    Take heed (dear heart) of this large privilege,
line 1864-->    The hardest knife ill-used doth lose his edge.
line 1865-->
line 1866-->
line 1867-->                     96  
line 1868-->  Some say thy fault is youth, some wantonness,
line 1869-->  Some say thy grace is youth and gentle sport,
line 1870-->  Both grace and faults are loved of more and less:
line 1871-->  Thou mak'st faults graces, that to thee resort:
line 1872-->  As on the finger of a throned queen,
line 1873-->  The basest jewel will be well esteemed:
line 1874-->  So are those errors that in thee are seen,
line 1875-->  To truths translated, and for true things deemed.
line 1876-->  How many lambs might the stern wolf betray,
line 1877-->  If like a lamb he could his looks translate!
line 1878-->  How many gazers mightst thou lead away,
line 1879-->  if thou wouldst use the strength of all thy state!
line 1880-->    But do not so, I love thee in such sort,
line 1881-->    As thou being mine, mine is thy good report.
line 1882-->
line 1883-->
line 1884-->                     97
line 1885-->  How like a winter hath my absence been
line 1886-->  From thee, the pleasure of the fleeting year!
line 1887-->  What freezings have I felt, what dark days seen!
line 1888-->  What old December's bareness everywhere!  
line 1889-->  And yet this time removed was summer's time,
line 1890-->  The teeming autumn big with rich increase,
line 1891-->  Bearing the wanton burden of the prime,
line 1892-->  Like widowed wombs after their lords' decease:
line 1893-->  Yet this abundant issue seemed to me
line 1894-->  But hope of orphans, and unfathered fruit,
line 1895-->  For summer and his pleasures wait on thee,
line 1896-->  And thou away, the very birds are mute.
line 1897-->    Or if they sing, 'tis with so dull a cheer,
line 1898-->    That leaves look pale, dreading the winter's near.
line 1899-->
line 1900-->
line 1901-->                     98
line 1902-->  From you have I been absent in the spring,
line 1903-->  When proud-pied April (dressed in all his trim)
line 1904-->  Hath put a spirit of youth in every thing:
line 1905-->  That heavy Saturn laughed and leaped with him.
line 1906-->  Yet nor the lays of birds, nor the sweet smell
line 1907-->  Of different flowers in odour and in hue,
line 1908-->  Could make me any summer's story tell:
line 1909-->  Or from their proud lap pluck them where they grew:  
line 1910-->  Nor did I wonder at the lily's white,
line 1911-->  Nor praise the deep vermilion in the rose,
line 1912-->  They were but sweet, but figures of delight:
line 1913-->  Drawn after you, you pattern of all those.
line 1914-->    Yet seemed it winter still, and you away,
line 1915-->    As with your shadow I with these did play.
line 1916-->
line 1917-->
line 1918-->                     99
line 1919-->  The forward violet thus did I chide,
line 1920-->  Sweet thief, whence didst thou steal thy sweet that smells,
line 1921-->  If not from my love's breath? The purple pride
line 1922-->  Which on thy soft check for complexion dwells,
line 1923-->  In my love's veins thou hast too grossly dyed.
line 1924-->  The lily I condemned for thy hand,
line 1925-->  And buds of marjoram had stol'n thy hair,
line 1926-->  The roses fearfully on thorns did stand,
line 1927-->  One blushing shame, another white despair:
line 1928-->  A third nor red, nor white, had stol'n of both,
line 1929-->  And to his robbery had annexed thy breath,
line 1930-->  But for his theft in pride of all his growth  
line 1931-->  A vengeful canker eat him up to death.
line 1932-->    More flowers I noted, yet I none could see,
line 1933-->    But sweet, or colour it had stol'n from thee.
line 1934-->
line 1935-->
line 1936-->                     100
line 1937-->  Where art thou Muse that thou forget'st so long,
line 1938-->  To speak of that which gives thee all thy might?
line 1939-->  Spend'st thou thy fury on some worthless song,
line 1940-->  Darkening thy power to lend base subjects light?
line 1941-->  Return forgetful Muse, and straight redeem,
line 1942-->  In gentle numbers time so idly spent,
line 1943-->  Sing to the ear that doth thy lays esteem,
line 1944-->  And gives thy pen both skill and argument.
line 1945-->  Rise resty Muse, my love's sweet face survey,
line 1946-->  If time have any wrinkle graven there,
line 1947-->  If any, be a satire to decay,
line 1948-->  And make time's spoils despised everywhere.
line 1949-->    Give my love fame faster than Time wastes life,
line 1950-->    So thou prevent'st his scythe, and crooked knife.
line 1951-->
line 1952-->  
line 1953-->                     101
line 1954-->  O truant Muse what shall be thy amends,
line 1955-->  For thy neglect of truth in beauty dyed?
line 1956-->  Both truth and beauty on my love depends:
line 1957-->  So dost thou too, and therein dignified:
line 1958-->  Make answer Muse, wilt thou not haply say,
line 1959-->  'Truth needs no colour with his colour fixed,
line 1960-->  Beauty no pencil, beauty's truth to lay:
line 1961-->  But best is best, if never intermixed'?
line 1962-->  Because he needs no praise, wilt thou be dumb?
line 1963-->  Excuse not silence so, for't lies in thee,
line 1964-->  To make him much outlive a gilded tomb:
line 1965-->  And to be praised of ages yet to be.
line 1966-->    Then do thy office Muse, I teach thee how,
line 1967-->    To make him seem long hence, as he shows now.
line 1968-->
line 1969-->
line 1970-->                     102
line 1971-->  My love is strengthened though more weak in seeming,
line 1972-->  I love not less, though less the show appear,
line 1973-->  That love is merchandized, whose rich esteeming,  
line 1974-->  The owner's tongue doth publish every where.
line 1975-->  Our love was new, and then but in the spring,
line 1976-->  When I was wont to greet it with my lays,
line 1977-->  As Philomel in summer's front doth sing,
line 1978-->  And stops her pipe in growth of riper days:
line 1979-->  Not that the summer is less pleasant now
line 1980-->  Than when her mournful hymns did hush the night,
line 1981-->  But that wild music burthens every bough,
line 1982-->  And sweets grown common lose their dear delight.
line 1983-->    Therefore like her, I sometime hold my tongue:
line 1984-->    Because I would not dull you with my song.
line 1985-->
line 1986-->
line 1987-->                     103
line 1988-->  Alack what poverty my muse brings forth,
line 1989-->  That having such a scope to show her pride,
line 1990-->  The argument all bare is of more worth
line 1991-->  Than when it hath my added praise beside.
line 1992-->  O blame me not if I no more can write!
line 1993-->  Look in your glass and there appears a face,
line 1994-->  That over-goes my blunt invention quite,  
line 1995-->  Dulling my lines, and doing me disgrace.
line 1996-->  Were it not sinful then striving to mend,
line 1997-->  To mar the subject that before was well?
line 1998-->  For to no other pass my verses tend,
line 1999-->  Than of your graces and your gifts to tell.
line 2000-->    And more, much more than in my verse can sit,
line 2001-->    Your own glass shows you, when you look in it.
line 2002-->
line 2003-->
line 2004-->                     104
line 2005-->  To me fair friend you never can be old,
line 2006-->  For as you were when first your eye I eyed,
line 2007-->  Such seems your beauty still: three winters cold,
line 2008-->  Have from the forests shook three summers' pride,
line 2009-->  Three beauteous springs to yellow autumn turned,
line 2010-->  In process of the seasons have I seen,
line 2011-->  Three April perfumes in three hot Junes burned,
line 2012-->  Since first I saw you fresh which yet are green.
line 2013-->  Ah yet doth beauty like a dial hand,
line 2014-->  Steal from his figure, and no pace perceived,
line 2015-->  So your sweet hue, which methinks still doth stand  
line 2016-->  Hath motion, and mine eye may be deceived.
line 2017-->    For fear of which, hear this thou age unbred,
line 2018-->    Ere you were born was beauty's summer dead.
line 2019-->
line 2020-->
line 2021-->                     105
line 2022-->  Let not my love be called idolatry,
line 2023-->  Nor my beloved as an idol show,
line 2024-->  Since all alike my songs and praises be
line 2025-->  To one, of one, still such, and ever so.
line 2026-->  Kind is my love to-day, to-morrow kind,
line 2027-->  Still constant in a wondrous excellence,
line 2028-->  Therefore my verse to constancy confined,
line 2029-->  One thing expressing, leaves out difference.
line 2030-->  Fair, kind, and true, is all my argument,
line 2031-->  Fair, kind, and true, varying to other words,
line 2032-->  And in this change is my invention spent,
line 2033-->  Three themes in one, which wondrous scope affords.
line 2034-->    Fair, kind, and true, have often lived alone.
line 2035-->    Which three till now, never kept seat in one.
line 2036-->
line 2037-->  
line 2038-->                     106
line 2039-->  When in the chronicle of wasted time,
line 2040-->  I see descriptions of the fairest wights,
line 2041-->  And beauty making beautiful old rhyme,
line 2042-->  In praise of ladies dead, and lovely knights,
line 2043-->  Then in the blazon of sweet beauty's best,
line 2044-->  Of hand, of foot, of lip, of eye, of brow,
line 2045-->  I see their antique pen would have expressed,
line 2046-->  Even such a beauty as you master now.
line 2047-->  So all their praises are but prophecies
line 2048-->  Of this our time, all you prefiguring,
line 2049-->  And for they looked but with divining eyes,
line 2050-->  They had not skill enough your worth to sing:
line 2051-->    For we which now behold these present days,
line 2052-->    Have eyes to wonder, but lack tongues to praise.
line 2053-->
line 2054-->
line 2055-->                     107
line 2056-->  Not mine own fears, nor the prophetic soul,
line 2057-->  Of the wide world, dreaming on things to come,
line 2058-->  Can yet the lease of my true love control,  
line 2059-->  Supposed as forfeit to a confined doom.
line 2060-->  The mortal moon hath her eclipse endured,
line 2061-->  And the sad augurs mock their own presage,
line 2062-->  Incertainties now crown themselves assured,
line 2063-->  And peace proclaims olives of endless age.
line 2064-->  Now with the drops of this most balmy time,
line 2065-->  My love looks fresh, and death to me subscribes,
line 2066-->  Since spite of him I'll live in this poor rhyme,
line 2067-->  While he insults o'er dull and speechless tribes.
line 2068-->    And thou in this shalt find thy monument,
line 2069-->    When tyrants' crests and tombs of brass are spent.
line 2070-->
line 2071-->
line 2072-->                     108
line 2073-->  What's in the brain that ink may character,
line 2074-->  Which hath not figured to thee my true spirit,
line 2075-->  What's new to speak, what now to register,
line 2076-->  That may express my love, or thy dear merit?
line 2077-->  Nothing sweet boy, but yet like prayers divine,
line 2078-->  I must each day say o'er the very same,
line 2079-->  Counting no old thing old, thou mine, I thine,  
line 2080-->  Even as when first I hallowed thy fair name.
line 2081-->  So that eternal love in love's fresh case,
line 2082-->  Weighs not the dust and injury of age,
line 2083-->  Nor gives to necessary wrinkles place,
line 2084-->  But makes antiquity for aye his page,
line 2085-->    Finding the first conceit of love there bred,
line 2086-->    Where time and outward form would show it dead.
line 2087-->
line 2088-->
line 2089-->                     109
line 2090-->  O never say that I was false of heart,
line 2091-->  Though absence seemed my flame to qualify,
line 2092-->  As easy might I from my self depart,
line 2093-->  As from my soul which in thy breast doth lie:
line 2094-->  That is my home of love, if I have ranged,
line 2095-->  Like him that travels I return again,
line 2096-->  Just to the time, not with the time exchanged,
line 2097-->  So that my self bring water for my stain,
line 2098-->  Never believe though in my nature reigned,
line 2099-->  All frailties that besiege all kinds of blood,
line 2100-->  That it could so preposterously be stained,  
line 2101-->  To leave for nothing all thy sum of good:
line 2102-->    For nothing this wide universe I call,
line 2103-->    Save thou my rose, in it thou art my all.
line 2104-->
line 2105-->
line 2106-->                     110
line 2107-->  Alas 'tis true, I have gone here and there,
line 2108-->  And made my self a motley to the view,
line 2109-->  Gored mine own thoughts, sold cheap what is most dear,
line 2110-->  Made old offences of affections new.
line 2111-->  Most true it is, that I have looked on truth
line 2112-->  Askance and strangely: but by all above,
line 2113-->  These blenches gave my heart another youth,
line 2114-->  And worse essays proved thee my best of love.
line 2115-->  Now all is done, have what shall have no end,
line 2116-->  Mine appetite I never more will grind
line 2117-->  On newer proof, to try an older friend,
line 2118-->  A god in love, to whom I am confined.
line 2119-->    Then give me welcome, next my heaven the best,
line 2120-->    Even to thy pure and most most loving breast.
line 2121-->
line 2122-->  
line 2123-->                     111
line 2124-->  O for my sake do you with Fortune chide,
line 2125-->  The guilty goddess of my harmful deeds,
line 2126-->  That did not better for my life provide,
line 2127-->  Than public means which public manners breeds.
line 2128-->  Thence comes it that my name receives a brand,
line 2129-->  And almost thence my nature is subdued
line 2130-->  To what it works in, like the dyer's hand:
line 2131-->  Pity me then, and wish I were renewed,
line 2132-->  Whilst like a willing patient I will drink,
line 2133-->  Potions of eisel 'gainst my strong infection,
line 2134-->  No bitterness that I will bitter think,
line 2135-->  Nor double penance to correct correction.
line 2136-->    Pity me then dear friend, and I assure ye,
line 2137-->    Even that your pity is enough to cure me.
line 2138-->
line 2139-->
line 2140-->                     112
line 2141-->  Your love and pity doth th' impression fill,
line 2142-->  Which vulgar scandal stamped upon my brow,
line 2143-->  For what care I who calls me well or ill,  
line 2144-->  So you o'er-green my bad, my good allow?
line 2145-->  You are my all the world, and I must strive,
line 2146-->  To know my shames and praises from your tongue,
line 2147-->  None else to me, nor I to none alive,
line 2148-->  That my steeled sense or changes right or wrong.
line 2149-->  In so profound abysm I throw all care
line 2150-->  Of others' voices, that my adder's sense,
line 2151-->  To critic and to flatterer stopped are:
line 2152-->  Mark how with my neglect I do dispense.
line 2153-->    You are so strongly in my purpose bred,
line 2154-->    That all the world besides methinks are dead.
line 2155-->
line 2156-->
line 2157-->                     113
line 2158-->  Since I left you, mine eye is in my mind,
line 2159-->  And that which governs me to go about,
line 2160-->  Doth part his function, and is partly blind,
line 2161-->  Seems seeing, but effectually is out:
line 2162-->  For it no form delivers to the heart
line 2163-->  Of bird, of flower, or shape which it doth latch,
line 2164-->  Of his quick objects hath the mind no part,  
line 2165-->  Nor his own vision holds what it doth catch:
line 2166-->  For if it see the rud'st or gentlest sight,
line 2167-->  The most sweet favour or deformed'st creature,
line 2168-->  The mountain, or the sea, the day, or night:
line 2169-->  The crow, or dove, it shapes them to your feature.
line 2170-->    Incapable of more, replete with you,
line 2171-->    My most true mind thus maketh mine untrue.
line 2172-->
line 2173-->
line 2174-->                     114
line 2175-->  Or whether doth my mind being crowned with you
line 2176-->  Drink up the monarch's plague this flattery?
line 2177-->  Or whether shall I say mine eye saith true,
line 2178-->  And that your love taught it this alchemy?
line 2179-->  To make of monsters, and things indigest,
line 2180-->  Such cherubins as your sweet self resemble,
line 2181-->  Creating every bad a perfect best
line 2182-->  As fast as objects to his beams assemble:
line 2183-->  O 'tis the first, 'tis flattery in my seeing,
line 2184-->  And my great mind most kingly drinks it up,
line 2185-->  Mine eye well knows what with his gust is 'greeing,  
line 2186-->  And to his palate doth prepare the cup.
line 2187-->    If it be poisoned, 'tis the lesser sin,
line 2188-->    That mine eye loves it and doth first begin.
line 2189-->
line 2190-->
line 2191-->                     115
line 2192-->  Those lines that I before have writ do lie,
line 2193-->  Even those that said I could not love you dearer,
line 2194-->  Yet then my judgment knew no reason why,
line 2195-->  My most full flame should afterwards burn clearer,
line 2196-->  But reckoning time, whose millioned accidents
line 2197-->  Creep in 'twixt vows, and change decrees of kings,
line 2198-->  Tan sacred beauty, blunt the sharp'st intents,
line 2199-->  Divert strong minds to the course of alt'ring things:
line 2200-->  Alas why fearing of time's tyranny,
line 2201-->  Might I not then say 'Now I love you best,'
line 2202-->  When I was certain o'er incertainty,
line 2203-->  Crowning the present, doubting of the rest?
line 2204-->    Love is a babe, then might I not say so
line 2205-->    To give full growth to that which still doth grow.
line 2206-->
line 2207-->  
line 2208-->                     116
line 2209-->  Let me not to the marriage of true minds
line 2210-->  Admit impediments, love is not love
line 2211-->  Which alters when it alteration finds,
line 2212-->  Or bends with the remover to remove.
line 2213-->  O no, it is an ever-fixed mark
line 2214-->  That looks on tempests and is never shaken;
line 2215-->  It is the star to every wand'ring bark,
line 2216-->  Whose worth's unknown, although his height be taken.
line 2217-->  Love's not Time's fool, though rosy lips and cheeks
line 2218-->  Within his bending sickle's compass come,
line 2219-->  Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks,
line 2220-->  But bears it out even to the edge of doom:
line 2221-->    If this be error and upon me proved,
line 2222-->    I never writ, nor no man ever loved.
line 2223-->
line 2224-->
line 2225-->                     117
line 2226-->  Accuse me thus, that I have scanted all,
line 2227-->  Wherein I should your great deserts repay,
line 2228-->  Forgot upon your dearest love to call,  
line 2229-->  Whereto all bonds do tie me day by day,
line 2230-->  That I have frequent been with unknown minds,
line 2231-->  And given to time your own dear-purchased right,
line 2232-->  That I have hoisted sail to all the winds
line 2233-->  Which should transport me farthest from your sight.
line 2234-->  Book both my wilfulness and errors down,
line 2235-->  And on just proof surmise, accumulate,
line 2236-->  Bring me within the level of your frown,
line 2237-->  But shoot not at me in your wakened hate:
line 2238-->    Since my appeal says I did strive to prove
line 2239-->    The constancy and virtue of your love.
line 2240-->
line 2241-->
line 2242-->                     118
line 2243-->  Like as to make our appetite more keen
line 2244-->  With eager compounds we our palate urge,
line 2245-->  As to prevent our maladies unseen,
line 2246-->  We sicken to shun sickness when we purge.
line 2247-->  Even so being full of your ne'er-cloying sweetness,
line 2248-->  To bitter sauces did I frame my feeding;
line 2249-->  And sick of welfare found a kind of meetness,  
line 2250-->  To be diseased ere that there was true needing.
line 2251-->  Thus policy in love t' anticipate
line 2252-->  The ills that were not, grew to faults assured,
line 2253-->  And brought to medicine a healthful state
line 2254-->  Which rank of goodness would by ill be cured.
line 2255-->    But thence I learn and find the lesson true,
line 2256-->    Drugs poison him that so feil sick of you.
line 2257-->
line 2258-->
line 2259-->                     119
line 2260-->  What potions have I drunk of Siren tears
line 2261-->  Distilled from limbecks foul as hell within,
line 2262-->  Applying fears to hopes, and hopes to fears,
line 2263-->  Still losing when I saw my self to win!
line 2264-->  What wretched errors hath my heart committed,
line 2265-->  Whilst it hath thought it self so blessed never!
line 2266-->  How have mine eyes out of their spheres been fitted
line 2267-->  In the distraction of this madding fever!
line 2268-->  O benefit of ill, now I find true
line 2269-->  That better is, by evil still made better.
line 2270-->  And ruined love when it is built anew  
line 2271-->  Grows fairer than at first, more strong, far greater.
line 2272-->    So I return rebuked to my content,
line 2273-->    And gain by ills thrice more than I have spent.
line 2274-->
line 2275-->
line 2276-->                     120
line 2277-->  That you were once unkind befriends me now,
line 2278-->  And for that sorrow, which I then did feel,
line 2279-->  Needs must I under my transgression bow,
line 2280-->  Unless my nerves were brass or hammered steel.
line 2281-->  For if you were by my unkindness shaken
line 2282-->  As I by yours, y'have passed a hell of time,
line 2283-->  And I a tyrant have no leisure taken
line 2284-->  To weigh how once I suffered in your crime.
line 2285-->  O that our night of woe might have remembered
line 2286-->  My deepest sense, how hard true sorrow hits,
line 2287-->  And soon to you, as you to me then tendered
line 2288-->  The humble salve, which wounded bosoms fits!
line 2289-->    But that your trespass now becomes a fee,
line 2290-->    Mine ransoms yours, and yours must ransom me.
line 2291-->
line 2292-->  
line 2293-->                     121
line 2294-->  'Tis better to be vile than vile esteemed,
line 2295-->  When not to be, receives reproach of being,
line 2296-->  And the just pleasure lost, which is so deemed,
line 2297-->  Not by our feeling, but by others' seeing.
line 2298-->  For why should others' false adulterate eyes
line 2299-->  Give salutation to my sportive blood?
line 2300-->  Or on my frailties why are frailer spies,
line 2301-->  Which in their wills count bad what I think good?
line 2302-->  No, I am that I am, and they that level
line 2303-->  At my abuses, reckon up their own,
line 2304-->  I may be straight though they themselves be bevel;
line 2305-->  By their rank thoughts, my deeds must not be shown
line 2306-->    Unless this general evil they maintain,
line 2307-->    All men are bad and in their badness reign.
line 2308-->
line 2309-->
line 2310-->                     122
line 2311-->  Thy gift, thy tables, are within my brain
line 2312-->  Full charactered with lasting memory,
line 2313-->  Which shall above that idle rank remain  
line 2314-->  Beyond all date even to eternity.
line 2315-->  Or at the least, so long as brain and heart
line 2316-->  Have faculty by nature to subsist,
line 2317-->  Till each to razed oblivion yield his part
line 2318-->  Of thee, thy record never can be missed:
line 2319-->  That poor retention could not so much hold,
line 2320-->  Nor need I tallies thy dear love to score,
line 2321-->  Therefore to give them from me was I bold,
line 2322-->  To trust those tables that receive thee more:
line 2323-->    To keep an adjunct to remember thee
line 2324-->    Were to import forgetfulness in me.
line 2325-->
line 2326-->
line 2327-->                     123
line 2328-->  No! Time, thou shalt not boast that I do change,
line 2329-->  Thy pyramids built up with newer might
line 2330-->  To me are nothing novel, nothing strange,
line 2331-->  They are but dressings Of a former sight:
line 2332-->  Our dates are brief, and therefore we admire,
line 2333-->  What thou dost foist upon us that is old,
line 2334-->  And rather make them born to our desire,  
line 2335-->  Than think that we before have heard them told:
line 2336-->  Thy registers and thee I both defy,
line 2337-->  Not wond'ring at the present, nor the past,
line 2338-->  For thy records, and what we see doth lie,
line 2339-->  Made more or less by thy continual haste:
line 2340-->    This I do vow and this shall ever be,
line 2341-->    I will be true despite thy scythe and thee.
line 2342-->
line 2343-->
line 2344-->                     124
line 2345-->  If my dear love were but the child of state,
line 2346-->  It might for Fortune's bastard be unfathered,
line 2347-->  As subject to time's love or to time's hate,
line 2348-->  Weeds among weeds, or flowers with flowers gathered.
line 2349-->  No it was builded far from accident,
line 2350-->  It suffers not in smiling pomp, nor falls
line 2351-->  Under the blow of thralled discontent,
line 2352-->  Whereto th' inviting time our fashion calls:
line 2353-->  It fears not policy that heretic,
line 2354-->  Which works on leases of short-numbered hours,
line 2355-->  But all alone stands hugely politic,  
line 2356-->  That it nor grows with heat, nor drowns with showers.
line 2357-->    To this I witness call the fools of time,
line 2358-->    Which die for goodness, who have lived for crime.
line 2359-->
line 2360-->
line 2361-->                     125
line 2362-->  Were't aught to me I bore the canopy,
line 2363-->  With my extern the outward honouring,
line 2364-->  Or laid great bases for eternity,
line 2365-->  Which proves more short than waste or ruining?
line 2366-->  Have I not seen dwellers on form and favour
line 2367-->  Lose all, and more by paying too much rent
line 2368-->  For compound sweet; forgoing simple savour,
line 2369-->  Pitiful thrivers in their gazing spent?
line 2370-->  No, let me be obsequious in thy heart,
line 2371-->  And take thou my oblation, poor but free,
line 2372-->  Which is not mixed with seconds, knows no art,
line 2373-->  But mutual render, only me for thee.
line 2374-->    Hence, thou suborned informer, a true soul
line 2375-->    When most impeached, stands least in thy control.
line 2376-->
line 2377-->  
line 2378-->                     126
line 2379-->  O thou my lovely boy who in thy power,
line 2380-->  Dost hold Time's fickle glass his fickle hour:
line 2381-->  Who hast by waning grown, and therein show'st,
line 2382-->  Thy lovers withering, as thy sweet self grow'st.
line 2383-->  If Nature (sovereign mistress over wrack)
line 2384-->  As thou goest onwards still will pluck thee back,
line 2385-->  She keeps thee to this purpose, that her skill
line 2386-->  May time disgrace, and wretched minutes kill.
line 2387-->  Yet fear her O thou minion of her pleasure,
line 2388-->  She may detain, but not still keep her treasure!
line 2389-->    Her audit (though delayed) answered must be,
line 2390-->    And her quietus is to render thee.
line 2391-->
line 2392-->
line 2393-->                     127
line 2394-->  In the old age black was not counted fair,
line 2395-->  Or if it were it bore not beauty's name:
line 2396-->  But now is black beauty's successive heir,
line 2397-->  And beauty slandered with a bastard shame,
line 2398-->  For since each hand hath put on nature's power,  
line 2399-->  Fairing the foul with art's false borrowed face,
line 2400-->  Sweet beauty hath no name no holy bower,
line 2401-->  But is profaned, if not lives in disgrace.
line 2402-->  Therefore my mistress' eyes are raven black,
line 2403-->  Her eyes so suited, and they mourners seem,
line 2404-->  At such who not born fair no beauty lack,
line 2405-->  Slandering creation with a false esteem,
line 2406-->    Yet so they mourn becoming of their woe,
line 2407-->    That every tongue says beauty should look so.
line 2408-->
line 2409-->
line 2410-->                     128
line 2411-->  How oft when thou, my music, music play'st,
line 2412-->  Upon that blessed wood whose motion sounds
line 2413-->  With thy sweet fingers when thou gently sway'st
line 2414-->  The wiry concord that mine ear confounds,
line 2415-->  Do I envy those jacks that nimble leap,
line 2416-->  To kiss the tender inward of thy hand,
line 2417-->  Whilst my poor lips which should that harvest reap,
line 2418-->  At the wood's boldness by thee blushing stand.
line 2419-->  To be so tickled they would change their state  
line 2420-->  And situation with those dancing chips,
line 2421-->  O'er whom thy fingers walk with gentle gait,
line 2422-->  Making dead wood more blest than living lips,
line 2423-->    Since saucy jacks so happy are in this,
line 2424-->    Give them thy fingers, me thy lips to kiss.
line 2425-->
line 2426-->
line 2427-->                     129
line 2428-->  Th' expense of spirit in a waste of shame
line 2429-->  Is lust in action, and till action, lust
line 2430-->  Is perjured, murd'rous, bloody full of blame,
line 2431-->  Savage, extreme, rude, cruel, not to trust,
line 2432-->  Enjoyed no sooner but despised straight,
line 2433-->  Past reason hunted, and no sooner had
line 2434-->  Past reason hated as a swallowed bait,
line 2435-->  On purpose laid to make the taker mad.
line 2436-->  Mad in pursuit and in possession so,
line 2437-->  Had, having, and in quest, to have extreme,
line 2438-->  A bliss in proof and proved, a very woe,
line 2439-->  Before a joy proposed behind a dream.
line 2440-->    All this the world well knows yet none knows well,  
line 2441-->    To shun the heaven that leads men to this hell.
line 2442-->
line 2443-->
line 2444-->                     130
line 2445-->  My mistress' eyes are nothing like the sun,
line 2446-->  Coral is far more red, than her lips red,
line 2447-->  If snow be white, why then her breasts are dun:
line 2448-->  If hairs be wires, black wires grow on her head:
line 2449-->  I have seen roses damasked, red and white,
line 2450-->  But no such roses see I in her cheeks,
line 2451-->  And in some perfumes is there more delight,
line 2452-->  Than in the breath that from my mistress reeks.
line 2453-->  I love to hear her speak, yet well I know,
line 2454-->  That music hath a far more pleasing sound:
line 2455-->  I grant I never saw a goddess go,
line 2456-->  My mistress when she walks treads on the ground.
line 2457-->    And yet by heaven I think my love as rare,
line 2458-->    As any she belied with false compare.
line 2459-->
line 2460-->
line 2461-->                     131
line 2462-->  Thou art as tyrannous, so as thou art,  
line 2463-->  As those whose beauties proudly make them cruel;
line 2464-->  For well thou know'st to my dear doting heart
line 2465-->  Thou art the fairest and most precious jewel.
line 2466-->  Yet in good faith some say that thee behold,
line 2467-->  Thy face hath not the power to make love groan;
line 2468-->  To say they err, I dare not be so bold,
line 2469-->  Although I swear it to my self alone.
line 2470-->  And to be sure that is not false I swear,
line 2471-->  A thousand groans but thinking on thy face,
line 2472-->  One on another's neck do witness bear
line 2473-->  Thy black is fairest in my judgment's place.
line 2474-->    In nothing art thou black save in thy deeds,
line 2475-->    And thence this slander as I think proceeds.
line 2476-->
line 2477-->
line 2478-->                     132
line 2479-->  Thine eyes I love, and they as pitying me,
line 2480-->  Knowing thy heart torment me with disdain,
line 2481-->  Have put on black, and loving mourners be,
line 2482-->  Looking with pretty ruth upon my pain.
line 2483-->  And truly not the morning sun of heaven  
line 2484-->  Better becomes the grey cheeks of the east,
line 2485-->  Nor that full star that ushers in the even
line 2486-->  Doth half that glory to the sober west
line 2487-->  As those two mourning eyes become thy face:
line 2488-->  O let it then as well beseem thy heart
line 2489-->  To mourn for me since mourning doth thee grace,
line 2490-->  And suit thy pity like in every part.
line 2491-->    Then will I swear beauty herself is black,
line 2492-->    And all they foul that thy complexion lack.
line 2493-->
line 2494-->
line 2495-->                     133
line 2496-->  Beshrew that heart that makes my heart to groan
line 2497-->  For that deep wound it gives my friend and me;
line 2498-->  Is't not enough to torture me alone,
line 2499-->  But slave to slavery my sweet'st friend must be?
line 2500-->  Me from my self thy cruel eye hath taken,
line 2501-->  And my next self thou harder hast engrossed,
line 2502-->  Of him, my self, and thee I am forsaken,
line 2503-->  A torment thrice three-fold thus to be crossed:
line 2504-->  Prison my heart in thy steel bosom's ward,  
line 2505-->  But then my friend's heart let my poor heart bail,
line 2506-->  Whoe'er keeps me, let my heart be his guard,
line 2507-->  Thou canst not then use rigour in my gaol.
line 2508-->    And yet thou wilt, for I being pent in thee,
line 2509-->    Perforce am thine and all that is in me.
line 2510-->
line 2511-->
line 2512-->                     134
line 2513-->  So now I have confessed that he is thine,
line 2514-->  And I my self am mortgaged to thy will,
line 2515-->  My self I'll forfeit, so that other mine,
line 2516-->  Thou wilt restore to be my comfort still:
line 2517-->  But thou wilt not, nor he will not be free,
line 2518-->  For thou art covetous, and he is kind,
line 2519-->  He learned but surety-like to write for me,
line 2520-->  Under that bond that him as fist doth bind.
line 2521-->  The statute of thy beauty thou wilt take,
line 2522-->  Thou usurer that put'st forth all to use,
line 2523-->  And sue a friend, came debtor for my sake,
line 2524-->  So him I lose through my unkind abuse.
line 2525-->    Him have I lost, thou hast both him and me,  
line 2526-->    He pays the whole, and yet am I not free.
line 2527-->
line 2528-->
line 2529-->                     135
line 2530-->  Whoever hath her wish, thou hast thy will,
line 2531-->  And 'Will' to boot, and 'Will' in over-plus,
line 2532-->  More than enough am I that vex thee still,
line 2533-->  To thy sweet will making addition thus.
line 2534-->  Wilt thou whose will is large and spacious,
line 2535-->  Not once vouchsafe to hide my will in thine?
line 2536-->  Shall will in others seem right gracious,
line 2537-->  And in my will no fair acceptance shine?
line 2538-->  The sea all water, yet receives rain still,
line 2539-->  And in abundance addeth to his store,
line 2540-->  So thou being rich in will add to thy will
line 2541-->  One will of mine to make thy large will more.
line 2542-->    Let no unkind, no fair beseechers kill,
line 2543-->    Think all but one, and me in that one 'Will.'
line 2544-->
line 2545-->
line 2546-->                     136
line 2547-->  If thy soul check thee that I come so near,  
line 2548-->  Swear to thy blind soul that I was thy 'Will',
line 2549-->  And will thy soul knows is admitted there,
line 2550-->  Thus far for love, my love-suit sweet fulfil.
line 2551-->  'Will', will fulfil the treasure of thy love,
line 2552-->  Ay, fill it full with wills, and my will one,
line 2553-->  In things of great receipt with case we prove,
line 2554-->  Among a number one is reckoned none.
line 2555-->  Then in the number let me pass untold,
line 2556-->  Though in thy store's account I one must be,
line 2557-->  For nothing hold me, so it please thee hold,
line 2558-->  That nothing me, a something sweet to thee.
line 2559-->    Make but my name thy love, and love that still,
line 2560-->    And then thou lov'st me for my name is Will.
line 2561-->
line 2562-->
line 2563-->                     137
line 2564-->  Thou blind fool Love, what dost thou to mine eyes,
line 2565-->  That they behold and see not what they see?
line 2566-->  They know what beauty is, see where it lies,
line 2567-->  Yet what the best is, take the worst to be.
line 2568-->  If eyes corrupt by over-partial looks,  
line 2569-->  Be anchored in the bay where all men ride,
line 2570-->  Why of eyes' falsehood hast thou forged hooks,
line 2571-->  Whereto the judgment of my heart is tied?
line 2572-->  Why should my heart think that a several plot,
line 2573-->  Which my heart knows the wide world's common place?
line 2574-->  Or mine eyes seeing this, say this is not
line 2575-->  To put fair truth upon so foul a face?
line 2576-->    In things right true my heart and eyes have erred,
line 2577-->    And to this false plague are they now transferred.
line 2578-->
line 2579-->
line 2580-->                     138
line 2581-->  When my love swears that she is made of truth,
line 2582-->  I do believe her though I know she lies,
line 2583-->  That she might think me some untutored youth,
line 2584-->  Unlearned in the world's false subtleties.
line 2585-->  Thus vainly thinking that she thinks me young,
line 2586-->  Although she knows my days are past the best,
line 2587-->  Simply I credit her false-speaking tongue,
line 2588-->  On both sides thus is simple truth suppressed:
line 2589-->  But wherefore says she not she is unjust?  
line 2590-->  And wherefore say not I that I am old?
line 2591-->  O love's best habit is in seeming trust,
line 2592-->  And age in love, loves not to have years told.
line 2593-->    Therefore I lie with her, and she with me,
line 2594-->    And in our faults by lies we flattered be.
line 2595-->
line 2596-->
line 2597-->                     139
line 2598-->  O call not me to justify the wrong,
line 2599-->  That thy unkindness lays upon my heart,
line 2600-->  Wound me not with thine eye but with thy tongue,
line 2601-->  Use power with power, and slay me not by art,
line 2602-->  Tell me thou lov'st elsewhere; but in my sight,
line 2603-->  Dear heart forbear to glance thine eye aside,
line 2604-->  What need'st thou wound with cunning when thy might
line 2605-->  Is more than my o'erpressed defence can bide?
line 2606-->  Let me excuse thee, ah my love well knows,
line 2607-->  Her pretty looks have been mine enemies,
line 2608-->  And therefore from my face she turns my foes,
line 2609-->  That they elsewhere might dart their injuries:
line 2610-->    Yet do not so, but since I am near slain,  
line 2611-->    Kill me outright with looks, and rid my pain.
line 2612-->
line 2613-->
line 2614-->                     140
line 2615-->  Be wise as thou art cruel, do not press
line 2616-->  My tongue-tied patience with too much disdain:
line 2617-->  Lest sorrow lend me words and words express,
line 2618-->  The manner of my pity-wanting pain.
line 2619-->  If I might teach thee wit better it were,
line 2620-->  Though not to love, yet love to tell me so,
line 2621-->  As testy sick men when their deaths be near,
line 2622-->  No news but health from their physicians know.
line 2623-->  For if I should despair I should grow mad,
line 2624-->  And in my madness might speak ill of thee,
line 2625-->  Now this ill-wresting world is grown so bad,
line 2626-->  Mad slanderers by mad ears believed be.
line 2627-->    That I may not be so, nor thou belied,
line 2628-->    Bear thine eyes straight, though thy proud heart go wide.
line 2629-->
line 2630-->
line 2631-->                     141
line 2632-->  In faith I do not love thee with mine eyes,  
line 2633-->  For they in thee a thousand errors note,
line 2634-->  But 'tis my heart that loves what they despise,
line 2635-->  Who in despite of view is pleased to dote.
line 2636-->  Nor are mine cars with thy tongue's tune delighted,
line 2637-->  Nor tender feeling to base touches prone,
line 2638-->  Nor taste, nor smell, desire to be invited
line 2639-->  To any sensual feast with thee alone:
line 2640-->  But my five wits, nor my five senses can
line 2641-->  Dissuade one foolish heart from serving thee,
line 2642-->  Who leaves unswayed the likeness of a man,
line 2643-->  Thy proud heart's slave and vassal wretch to be:
line 2644-->    Only my plague thus far I count my gain,
line 2645-->    That she that makes me sin, awards me pain.
line 2646-->
line 2647-->
line 2648-->                     142
line 2649-->  Love is my sin, and thy dear virtue hate,
line 2650-->  Hate of my sin, grounded on sinful loving,
line 2651-->  O but with mine, compare thou thine own state,
line 2652-->  And thou shalt find it merits not reproving,
line 2653-->  Or if it do, not from those lips of thine,  
line 2654-->  That have profaned their scarlet ornaments,
line 2655-->  And sealed false bonds of love as oft as mine,
line 2656-->  Robbed others' beds' revenues of their rents.
line 2657-->  Be it lawful I love thee as thou lov'st those,
line 2658-->  Whom thine eyes woo as mine importune thee,
line 2659-->  Root pity in thy heart that when it grows,
line 2660-->  Thy pity may deserve to pitied be.
line 2661-->    If thou dost seek to have what thou dost hide,
line 2662-->    By self-example mayst thou be denied.
line 2663-->
line 2664-->
line 2665-->                     143
line 2666-->  Lo as a careful huswife runs to catch,
line 2667-->  One of her feathered creatures broke away,
line 2668-->  Sets down her babe and makes all swift dispatch
line 2669-->  In pursuit of the thing she would have stay:
line 2670-->  Whilst her neglected child holds her in chase,
line 2671-->  Cries to catch her whose busy care is bent,
line 2672-->  To follow that which flies before her face:
line 2673-->  Not prizing her poor infant's discontent;
line 2674-->  So run'st thou after that which flies from thee,  
line 2675-->  Whilst I thy babe chase thee afar behind,
line 2676-->  But if thou catch thy hope turn back to me:
line 2677-->  And play the mother's part, kiss me, be kind.
line 2678-->    So will I pray that thou mayst have thy Will,
line 2679-->    If thou turn back and my loud crying still.
line 2680-->
line 2681-->
line 2682-->                     144
line 2683-->  Two loves I have of comfort and despair,
line 2684-->  Which like two spirits do suggest me still,
line 2685-->  The better angel is a man right fair:
line 2686-->  The worser spirit a woman coloured ill.
line 2687-->  To win me soon to hell my female evil,
line 2688-->  Tempteth my better angel from my side,
line 2689-->  And would corrupt my saint to be a devil:
line 2690-->  Wooing his purity with her foul pride.
line 2691-->  And whether that my angel be turned fiend,
line 2692-->  Suspect I may, yet not directly tell,
line 2693-->  But being both from me both to each friend,
line 2694-->  I guess one angel in another's hell.
line 2695-->    Yet this shall I ne'er know but live in doubt,  
line 2696-->    Till my bad angel fire my good one out.
line 2697-->
line 2698-->
line 2699-->                     145
line 2700-->  Those lips that Love's own hand did make,
line 2701-->  Breathed forth the sound that said 'I hate',
line 2702-->  To me that languished for her sake:
line 2703-->  But when she saw my woeful state,
line 2704-->  Straight in her heart did mercy come,
line 2705-->  Chiding that tongue that ever sweet,
line 2706-->  Was used in giving gentle doom:
line 2707-->  And taught it thus anew to greet:
line 2708-->  'I hate' she altered with an end,
line 2709-->  That followed it as gentle day,
line 2710-->  Doth follow night who like a fiend
line 2711-->  From heaven to hell is flown away.
line 2712-->    'I hate', from hate away she threw,
line 2713-->    And saved my life saying 'not you'.
line 2714-->
line 2715-->
line 2716-->                     146
line 2717-->  Poor soul the centre of my sinful earth,  
line 2718-->  My sinful earth these rebel powers array,
line 2719-->  Why dost thou pine within and suffer dearth
line 2720-->  Painting thy outward walls so costly gay?
line 2721-->  Why so large cost having so short a lease,
line 2722-->  Dost thou upon thy fading mansion spend?
line 2723-->  Shall worms inheritors of this excess
line 2724-->  Eat up thy charge? is this thy body's end?
line 2725-->  Then soul live thou upon thy servant's loss,
line 2726-->  And let that pine to aggravate thy store;
line 2727-->  Buy terms divine in selling hours of dross;
line 2728-->  Within be fed, without be rich no more,
line 2729-->    So shall thou feed on death, that feeds on men,
line 2730-->    And death once dead, there's no more dying then.
line 2731-->
line 2732-->
line 2733-->                     147
line 2734-->  My love is as a fever longing still,
line 2735-->  For that which longer nurseth the disease,
line 2736-->  Feeding on that which doth preserve the ill,
line 2737-->  Th' uncertain sickly appetite to please:
line 2738-->  My reason the physician to my love,  
line 2739-->  Angry that his prescriptions are not kept
line 2740-->  Hath left me, and I desperate now approve,
line 2741-->  Desire is death, which physic did except.
line 2742-->  Past cure I am, now reason is past care,
line 2743-->  And frantic-mad with evermore unrest,
line 2744-->  My thoughts and my discourse as mad men's are,
line 2745-->  At random from the truth vainly expressed.
line 2746-->    For I have sworn thee fair, and thought thee bright,
line 2747-->    Who art as black as hell, as dark as night.
line 2748-->
line 2749-->
line 2750-->                     148
line 2751-->  O me! what eyes hath love put in my head,
line 2752-->  Which have no correspondence with true sight,
line 2753-->  Or if they have, where is my judgment fled,
line 2754-->  That censures falsely what they see aright?
line 2755-->  If that be fair whereon my false eyes dote,
line 2756-->  What means the world to say it is not so?
line 2757-->  If it be not, then love doth well denote,
line 2758-->  Love's eye is not so true as all men's: no,
line 2759-->  How can it? O how can love's eye be true,  
line 2760-->  That is so vexed with watching and with tears?
line 2761-->  No marvel then though I mistake my view,
line 2762-->  The sun it self sees not, till heaven clears.
line 2763-->    O cunning love, with tears thou keep'st me blind,
line 2764-->    Lest eyes well-seeing thy foul faults should find.
line 2765-->
line 2766-->
line 2767-->                     149
line 2768-->  Canst thou O cruel, say I love thee not,
line 2769-->  When I against my self with thee partake?
line 2770-->  Do I not think on thee when I forgot
line 2771-->  Am of my self, all-tyrant, for thy sake?
line 2772-->  Who hateth thee that I do call my friend,
line 2773-->  On whom frown'st thou that I do fawn upon,
line 2774-->  Nay if thou lour'st on me do I not spend
line 2775-->  Revenge upon my self with present moan?
line 2776-->  What merit do I in my self respect,
line 2777-->  That is so proud thy service to despise,
line 2778-->  When all my best doth worship thy defect,
line 2779-->  Commanded by the motion of thine eyes?
line 2780-->    But love hate on for now I know thy mind,  
line 2781-->    Those that can see thou lov'st, and I am blind.
line 2782-->
line 2783-->
line 2784-->                     150
line 2785-->  O from what power hast thou this powerful might,
line 2786-->  With insufficiency my heart to sway,
line 2787-->  To make me give the lie to my true sight,
line 2788-->  And swear that brightness doth not grace the day?
line 2789-->  Whence hast thou this becoming of things ill,
line 2790-->  That in the very refuse of thy deeds,
line 2791-->  There is such strength and warrantise of skill,
line 2792-->  That in my mind thy worst all best exceeds?
line 2793-->  Who taught thee how to make me love thee more,
line 2794-->  The more I hear and see just cause of hate?
line 2795-->  O though I love what others do abhor,
line 2796-->  With others thou shouldst not abhor my state.
line 2797-->    If thy unworthiness raised love in me,
line 2798-->    More worthy I to be beloved of thee.
line 2799-->
line 2800-->
line 2801-->                     151
line 2802-->  Love is too young to know what conscience is,  
line 2803-->  Yet who knows not conscience is born of love?
line 2804-->  Then gentle cheater urge not my amiss,
line 2805-->  Lest guilty of my faults thy sweet self prove.
line 2806-->  For thou betraying me, I do betray
line 2807-->  My nobler part to my gross body's treason,
line 2808-->  My soul doth tell my body that he may,
line 2809-->  Triumph in love, flesh stays no farther reason,
line 2810-->  But rising at thy name doth point out thee,
line 2811-->  As his triumphant prize, proud of this pride,
line 2812-->  He is contented thy poor drudge to be,
line 2813-->  To stand in thy affairs, fall by thy side.
line 2814-->    No want of conscience hold it that I call,
line 2815-->    Her love, for whose dear love I rise and fall.
line 2816-->
line 2817-->
line 2818-->                     152
line 2819-->  In loving thee thou know'st I am forsworn,
line 2820-->  But thou art twice forsworn to me love swearing,
line 2821-->  In act thy bed-vow broke and new faith torn,
line 2822-->  In vowing new hate after new love bearing:
line 2823-->  But why of two oaths' breach do I accuse thee,  
line 2824-->  When I break twenty? I am perjured most,
line 2825-->  For all my vows are oaths but to misuse thee:
line 2826-->  And all my honest faith in thee is lost.
line 2827-->  For I have sworn deep oaths of thy deep kindness:
line 2828-->  Oaths of thy love, thy truth, thy constancy,
line 2829-->  And to enlighten thee gave eyes to blindness,
line 2830-->  Or made them swear against the thing they see.
line 2831-->    For I have sworn thee fair: more perjured I,
line 2832-->    To swear against the truth so foul a be.
line 2833-->
line 2834-->
line 2835-->                     153
line 2836-->  Cupid laid by his brand and fell asleep,
line 2837-->  A maid of Dian's this advantage found,
line 2838-->  And his love-kindling fire did quickly steep
line 2839-->  In a cold valley-fountain of that ground:
line 2840-->  Which borrowed from this holy fire of Love,
line 2841-->  A dateless lively heat still to endure,
line 2842-->  And grew a seeting bath which yet men prove,
line 2843-->  Against strange maladies a sovereign cure:
line 2844-->  But at my mistress' eye Love's brand new-fired,  
line 2845-->  The boy for trial needs would touch my breast,
line 2846-->  I sick withal the help of bath desired,
line 2847-->  And thither hied a sad distempered guest.
line 2848-->    But found no cure, the bath for my help lies,
line 2849-->    Where Cupid got new fire; my mistress' eyes.
line 2850-->
line 2851-->
line 2852-->                     154
line 2853-->  The little Love-god lying once asleep,
line 2854-->  Laid by his side his heart-inflaming brand,
line 2855-->  Whilst many nymphs that vowed chaste life to keep,
line 2856-->  Came tripping by, but in her maiden hand,
line 2857-->  The fairest votary took up that fire,
line 2858-->  Which many legions of true hearts had warmed,
line 2859-->  And so the general of hot desire,
line 2860-->  Was sleeping by a virgin hand disarmed.
line 2861-->  This brand she quenched in a cool well by,
line 2862-->  Which from Love's fire took heat perpetual,
line 2863-->  Growing a bath and healthful remedy,
line 2864-->  For men discased, but I my mistress' thrall,
line 2865-->    Came there for cure and this by that I prove,  
line 2866-->    Love's fire heats water, water cools not love.
line 2867-->
line 2868-->
line 2869-->THE END

line 2890-->by William Shakespeare

line 2893-->Dramatis Personae
line 2894-->

line 2896-->  THE DUKE OF FLORENCE
