line 2929-->
line 2930-->
line 2931-->SCENE:
line 2932-->Rousillon; Paris; Florence; Marseilles
line 2933-->
line 2934-->
line 2935-->ACT I. SCENE 1.
line 2936-->Rousillon. The COUNT'S palace
line 2937-->
line 2938-->Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS OF ROUSILLON, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
line 2939-->
line 2940-->  COUNTESS. In delivering my son from me, I bury a second husband.
line 2941-->  BERTRAM. And I in going, madam, weep o'er my father's death anew;
line 2942-->    but I must attend his Majesty's command, to whom I am now in
line 2943-->    ward, evermore in subjection.
line 2944-->  LAFEU. You shall find of the King a husband, madam; you, sir, a
line 2945-->    father. He that so generally is at all times good must of
line 2946-->    necessity hold his virtue to you, whose worthiness would stir it
line 2947-->    up where it wanted, rather than lack it where there is such
line 2948-->    abundance.
line 2949-->  COUNTESS. What hope is there of his Majesty's amendment?
line 2950-->  LAFEU. He hath abandon'd his physicians, madam; under whose
line 2951-->    practices he hath persecuted time with hope, and finds no other
line 2952-->    advantage in the process but only the losing of hope by time.
line 2953-->  COUNTESS. This young gentlewoman had a father- O, that 'had,' how
line 2954-->    sad a passage 'tis!-whose skill was almost as great as his
line 2955-->    honesty; had it stretch'd so far, would have made nature  
line 2956-->    immortal, and death should have play for lack of work. Would, for
line 2957-->    the King's sake, he were living! I think it would be the death of
line 2958-->    the King's disease.
line 2959-->  LAFEU. How call'd you the man you speak of, madam?
line 2960-->  COUNTESS. He was famous, sir, in his profession, and it was his
line 2961-->    great right to be so- Gerard de Narbon.
line 2962-->  LAFEU. He was excellent indeed, madam; the King very lately spoke
line 2963-->    of him admiringly and mourningly; he was skilful enough to have
line 2964-->    liv'd still, if knowledge could be set up against mortality.
line 2965-->  BERTRAM. What is it, my good lord, the King languishes of?
line 2966-->  LAFEU. A fistula, my lord.
line 2967-->  BERTRAM. I heard not of it before.
line 2968-->  LAFEU. I would it were not notorious. Was this gentlewoman the
line 2969-->    daughter of Gerard de Narbon?
line 2970-->  COUNTESS. His sole child, my lord, and bequeathed to my
line 2971-->    overlooking. I have those hopes of her good that her education
line 2972-->    promises; her dispositions she inherits, which makes fair gifts
line 2973-->    fairer; for where an unclean mind carries virtuous qualities,
line 2974-->    there commendations go with pity-they are virtues and traitors
line 2975-->    too. In her they are the better for their simpleness; she derives  
line 2976-->    her honesty, and achieves her goodness.
line 2977-->  LAFEU. Your commendations, madam, get from her tears.
line 2978-->  COUNTESS. 'Tis the best brine a maiden can season her praise in.
line 2979-->    The remembrance of her father never approaches her heart but the
line 2980-->    tyranny of her sorrows takes all livelihood from her cheek. No
line 2981-->    more of this, Helena; go to, no more, lest it be rather thought
line 2982-->    you affect a sorrow than to have-
line 2983-->  HELENA. I do affect a sorrow indeed, but I have it too.
line 2984-->  LAFEU. Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead: excessive
line 2985-->    grief the enemy to the living.
line 2986-->  COUNTESS. If the living be enemy to the grief, the excess makes it
line 2987-->    soon mortal.
line 2988-->  BERTRAM. Madam, I desire your holy wishes.
line 2989-->  LAFEU. How understand we that?
line 2990-->  COUNTESS. Be thou blest, Bertram, and succeed thy father
line 2991-->    In manners, as in shape! Thy blood and virtue
line 2992-->    Contend for empire in thee, and thy goodness
line 2993-->    Share with thy birthright! Love all, trust a few,
line 2994-->    Do wrong to none; be able for thine enemy
line 2995-->    Rather in power than use, and keep thy friend  
line 2996-->    Under thy own life's key; be check'd for silence,
line 2997-->    But never tax'd for speech. What heaven more will,
line 2998-->    That thee may furnish, and my prayers pluck down,
line 2999-->    Fall on thy head! Farewell. My lord,
line 3000-->    'Tis an unseason'd courtier; good my lord,
line 3001-->    Advise him.
line 3002-->  LAFEU. He cannot want the best
line 3003-->    That shall attend his love.
line 3004-->  COUNTESS. Heaven bless him! Farewell, Bertram.            Exit
line 3005-->  BERTRAM. The best wishes that can be forg'd in your thoughts be
line 3006-->    servants to you!  [To HELENA]  Be comfortable to my mother, your
line 3007-->    mistress, and make much of her.
line 3008-->  LAFEU. Farewell, pretty lady; you must hold the credit of your
line 3009-->    father.                             Exeunt BERTRAM and LAFEU
line 3010-->  HELENA. O, were that all! I think not on my father;
line 3011-->    And these great tears grace his remembrance more
line 3012-->    Than those I shed for him. What was he like?
line 3013-->    I have forgot him; my imagination
line 3014-->    Carries no favour in't but Bertram's.
line 3015-->    I am undone; there is no living, none,  
line 3016-->    If Bertram be away. 'Twere all one
line 3017-->    That I should love a bright particular star
line 3018-->    And think to wed it, he is so above me.
line 3019-->    In his bright radiance and collateral light
line 3020-->    Must I be comforted, not in his sphere.
line 3021-->    Th' ambition in my love thus plagues itself:
line 3022-->    The hind that would be mated by the lion
line 3023-->    Must die for love. 'Twas pretty, though a plague,
line 3024-->    To see him every hour; to sit and draw
line 3025-->    His arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls,
line 3026-->    In our heart's table-heart too capable
line 3027-->    Of every line and trick of his sweet favour.
line 3028-->    But now he's gone, and my idolatrous fancy
line 3029-->    Must sanctify his relics. Who comes here?
line 3030-->
line 3031-->                       Enter PAROLLES
line 3032-->
line 3033-->    [Aside]  One that goes with him. I love him for his sake;
line 3034-->    And yet I know him a notorious liar,
line 3035-->    Think him a great way fool, solely a coward;  
line 3036-->    Yet these fix'd evils sit so fit in him
line 3037-->    That they take place when virtue's steely bones
line 3038-->    Looks bleak i' th' cold wind; withal, full oft we see
line 3039-->    Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.
line 3040-->  PAROLLES. Save you, fair queen!
line 3041-->  HELENA. And you, monarch!
line 3042-->  PAROLLES. No.
line 3043-->  HELENA. And no.
line 3044-->  PAROLLES. Are you meditating on virginity?
line 3045-->  HELENA. Ay. You have some stain of soldier in you; let me ask you a
line 3046-->    question. Man is enemy to virginity; how may we barricado it
line 3047-->    against him?
line 3048-->  PAROLLES. Keep him out.
line 3049-->  HELENA. But he assails; and our virginity, though valiant in the
line 3050-->    defence, yet is weak. Unfold to us some warlike resistance.
line 3051-->  PAROLLES. There is none. Man, setting down before you, will
line 3052-->    undermine you and blow you up.
line 3053-->  HELENA. Bless our poor virginity from underminers and blowers-up!
line 3054-->    Is there no military policy how virgins might blow up men?
line 3055-->  PAROLLES. Virginity being blown down, man will quicklier be blown  
line 3056-->    up; marry, in blowing him down again, with the breach yourselves
line 3057-->     made, you lose your city. It is not politic in the commonwealth
line 3058-->    of nature to preserve virginity. Loss of virginity is rational
line 3059-->    increase; and there was never virgin got till virginity was first
line 3060-->    lost. That you were made of is metal to make virgins. Virginity
line 3061-->    by being once lost may be ten times found; by being ever kept, it
line 3062-->    is ever lost. 'Tis too cold a companion; away with't.
line 3063-->  HELENA. I will stand for 't a little, though therefore I die a
line 3064-->    virgin.
line 3065-->  PAROLLES. There's little can be said in 't; 'tis against the rule
line 3066-->    of nature. To speak on the part of virginity is to accuse your
line 3067-->    mothers; which is most infallible disobedience. He that hangs
line 3068-->    himself is a virgin; virginity murders itself, and should be
line 3069-->    buried in highways, out of all sanctified limit, as a desperate
line 3070-->    offendress against nature. Virginity breeds mites, much like a
line 3071-->    cheese; consumes itself to the very paring, and so dies with
line 3072-->    feeding his own stomach. Besides, virginity is peevish, proud,
line 3073-->    idle, made of self-love, which is the most inhibited sin in the
line 3074-->    canon. Keep it not; you cannot choose but lose by't. Out with't.
line 3075-->    Within ten year it will make itself ten, which is a goodly  
line 3076-->    increase; and the principal itself not much the worse. Away
line 3077-->    with't.
line 3078-->  HELENA. How might one do, sir, to lose it to her own liking?
line 3079-->  PAROLLES. Let me see. Marry, ill to like him that ne'er it likes.
line 3080-->    'Tis a commodity will lose the gloss with lying; the longer kept,
line 3081-->    the less worth. Off with't while 'tis vendible; answer the time
line 3082-->    of request. Virginity, like an old courtier, wears her cap out of
line 3083-->    fashion, richly suited but unsuitable; just like the brooch and
line 3084-->    the toothpick, which wear not now. Your date is better in your
line 3085-->    pie and your porridge than in your cheek. And your virginity,
line 3086-->    your old virginity, is like one of our French wither'd pears: it
line 3087-->    looks ill, it eats drily; marry, 'tis a wither'd pear; it was
line 3088-->    formerly better; marry, yet 'tis a wither'd pear. Will you
line 3089-->    anything with it?
line 3090-->  HELENA. Not my virginity yet.
line 3091-->    There shall your master have a thousand loves,
line 3092-->    A mother, and a mistress, and a friend,
line 3093-->    A phoenix, captain, and an enemy,
line 3094-->    A guide, a goddess, and a sovereign,
line 3095-->    A counsellor, a traitress, and a dear;  
line 3096-->    His humble ambition, proud humility,
line 3097-->    His jarring concord, and his discord dulcet,
line 3098-->    His faith, his sweet disaster; with a world
line 3099-->    Of pretty, fond, adoptious christendoms
line 3100-->    That blinking Cupid gossips. Now shall he-
line 3101-->    I know not what he shall. God send him well!
line 3102-->    The court's a learning-place, and he is one-
line 3103-->  PAROLLES. What one, i' faith?
line 3104-->  HELENA. That I wish well. 'Tis pity-
line 3105-->  PAROLLES. What's pity?
line 3106-->  HELENA. That wishing well had not a body in't
line 3107-->    Which might be felt; that we, the poorer born,
line 3108-->    Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes,
line 3109-->    Might with effects of them follow our friends
line 3110-->    And show what we alone must think, which never
line 3111-->    Returns us thanks.
line 3112-->
line 3113-->                      Enter PAGE
line 3114-->
line 3115-->  PAGE. Monsieur Parolles, my lord calls for you.      Exit PAGE  
line 3116-->  PAROLLES. Little Helen, farewell; if I can remember thee, I will
line 3117-->    think of thee at court.
line 3118-->  HELENA. Monsieur Parolles, you were born under a charitable star.
line 3119-->  PAROLLES. Under Mars, I.
line 3120-->  HELENA. I especially think, under Mars.
line 3121-->  PAROLLES. Why under Man?
line 3122-->  HELENA. The wars hath so kept you under that you must needs be born
line 3123-->    under Mars.
line 3124-->  PAROLLES. When he was predominant.
line 3125-->  HELENA. When he was retrograde, I think, rather.
line 3126-->  PAROLLES. Why think you so?
line 3127-->  HELENA. You go so much backward when you fight.
line 3128-->  PAROLLES. That's for advantage.
line 3129-->  HELENA. So is running away, when fear proposes the safety: but the
line 3130-->    composition that your valour and fear makes in you is a virtue of
line 3131-->    a good wing, and I like the wear well.
line 3132-->  PAROLLES. I am so full of business I cannot answer thee acutely. I
line 3133-->    will return perfect courtier; in the which my instruction shall
line 3134-->    serve to naturalize thee, so thou wilt be capable of a courtier's
line 3135-->    counsel, and understand what advice shall thrust upon thee; else  
line 3136-->    thou diest in thine unthankfulness, and thine ignorance makes
line 3137-->    thee away. Farewell. When thou hast leisure, say thy prayers;
line 3138-->    when thou hast none, remember thy friends. Get thee a good
line 3139-->    husband and use him as he uses thee. So, farewell.
line 3140--> Exit
line 3141-->  HELENA. Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie,
line 3142-->    Which we ascribe to heaven. The fated sky
line 3143-->    Gives us free scope; only doth backward pull
line 3144-->    Our slow designs when we ourselves are dull.
line 3145-->    What power is it which mounts my love so high,
line 3146-->    That makes me see, and cannot feed mine eye?
line 3147-->    The mightiest space in fortune nature brings
line 3148-->    To join like likes, and kiss like native things.
line 3149-->    Impossible be strange attempts to those
line 3150-->    That weigh their pains in sense, and do suppose
line 3151-->    What hath been cannot be. Who ever strove
line 3152-->    To show her merit that did miss her love?
line 3153-->    The King's disease-my project may deceive me,
line 3154-->    But my intents are fix'd, and will not leave me.        Exit
line 3155-->
line 3156-->
line 3157-->
line 3158-->
line 3159-->ACT I. SCENE 2.
line 3160-->Paris. The KING'S palace
line 3161-->
line 3162-->Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING OF FRANCE, with letters,
line 3163-->and divers ATTENDANTS
line 3164-->
line 3165-->  KING. The Florentines and Senoys are by th' ears;
line 3166-->    Have fought with equal fortune, and continue
line 3167-->    A braving war.
line 3168-->  FIRST LORD. So 'tis reported, sir.
line 3169-->  KING. Nay, 'tis most credible. We here receive it,
line 3170-->    A certainty, vouch'd from our cousin Austria,
line 3171-->    With caution, that the Florentine will move us
line 3172-->    For speedy aid; wherein our dearest friend
line 3173-->    Prejudicates the business, and would seem
line 3174-->    To have us make denial.
line 3175-->  FIRST LORD. His love and wisdom,
line 3176-->    Approv'd so to your Majesty, may plead
line 3177-->    For amplest credence.
line 3178-->  KING. He hath arm'd our answer,
line 3179-->    And Florence is denied before he comes;
line 3180-->    Yet, for our gentlemen that mean to see  
line 3181-->    The Tuscan service, freely have they leave
line 3182-->    To stand on either part.
line 3183-->  SECOND LORD. It well may serve
line 3184-->    A nursery to our gentry, who are sick
line 3185-->    For breathing and exploit.
line 3186-->  KING. What's he comes here?
line 3187-->
line 3188-->              Enter BERTRAM, LAFEU, and PAROLLES
line 3189-->
line 3190-->  FIRST LORD. It is the Count Rousillon, my good lord,
line 3191-->    Young Bertram.
line 3192-->  KING. Youth, thou bear'st thy father's face;
line 3193-->    Frank nature, rather curious than in haste,
line 3194-->    Hath well compos'd thee. Thy father's moral parts
line 3195-->    Mayst thou inherit too! Welcome to Paris.
line 3196-->  BERTRAM. My thanks and duty are your Majesty's.
line 3197-->  KING. I would I had that corporal soundness now,
line 3198-->    As when thy father and myself in friendship
line 3199-->    First tried our soldiership. He did look far
line 3200-->    Into the service of the time, and was  
line 3201-->    Discipled of the bravest. He lasted long;
line 3202-->    But on us both did haggish age steal on,
line 3203-->    And wore us out of act. It much repairs me
line 3204-->    To talk of your good father. In his youth
line 3205-->    He had the wit which I can well observe
line 3206-->    To-day in our young lords; but they may jest
line 3207-->    Till their own scorn return to them unnoted
line 3208-->    Ere they can hide their levity in honour.
line 3209-->    So like a courtier, contempt nor bitterness
line 3210-->    Were in his pride or sharpness; if they were,
line 3211-->    His equal had awak'd them; and his honour,
line 3212-->    Clock to itself, knew the true minute when
line 3213-->    Exception bid him speak, and at this time
line 3214-->    His tongue obey'd his hand. Who were below him
line 3215-->    He us'd as creatures of another place;
line 3216-->    And bow'd his eminent top to their low ranks,
line 3217-->    Making them proud of his humility
line 3218-->    In their poor praise he humbled. Such a man
line 3219-->    Might be a copy to these younger times;
line 3220-->    Which, followed well, would demonstrate them now  
line 3221-->    But goers backward.
line 3222-->  BERTRAM. His good remembrance, sir,
line 3223-->    Lies richer in your thoughts than on his tomb;
line 3224-->    So in approof lives not his epitaph
line 3225-->    As in your royal speech.
line 3226-->  KING. Would I were with him! He would always say-
line 3227-->    Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words
line 3228-->    He scatter'd not in ears, but grafted them
line 3229-->    To grow there, and to bear- 'Let me not live'-
line 3230-->    This his good melancholy oft began,
line 3231-->    On the catastrophe and heel of pastime,
line 3232-->    When it was out-'Let me not live' quoth he
line 3233-->    'After my flame lacks oil, to be the snuff
line 3234-->    Of younger spirits, whose apprehensive senses
line 3235-->    All but new things disdain; whose judgments are
line 3236-->    Mere fathers of their garments; whose constancies
line 3237-->    Expire before their fashions.' This he wish'd.
line 3238-->    I, after him, do after him wish too,
line 3239-->    Since I nor wax nor honey can bring home,
line 3240-->    I quickly were dissolved from my hive,  
line 3241-->    To give some labourers room.
line 3242-->  SECOND LORD. You're loved, sir;
line 3243-->    They that least lend it you shall lack you first.
line 3244-->  KING. I fill a place, I know't. How long is't, Count,
line 3245-->    Since the physician at your father's died?
line 3246-->    He was much fam'd.
line 3247-->  BERTRAM. Some six months since, my lord.
line 3248-->  KING. If he were living, I would try him yet-
line 3249-->    Lend me an arm-the rest have worn me out
line 3250-->    With several applications. Nature and sickness
line 3251-->    Debate it at their leisure. Welcome, Count;
line 3252-->    My son's no dearer.
line 3253-->  BERTRAM. Thank your Majesty.                 Exeunt [Flourish]
line 3254-->
line 3255-->
line 3256-->
line 3257-->
line 3258-->ACT I. SCENE 3.
line 3259-->Rousillon. The COUNT'S palace
line 3260-->
line 3261-->Enter COUNTESS, STEWARD, and CLOWN
line 3262-->
line 3263-->  COUNTESS. I will now hear; what say you of this gentlewoman?
line 3264-->  STEWARD. Madam, the care I have had to even your content I wish
line 3265-->    might be found in the calendar of my past endeavours; for then we
line 3266-->    wound our modesty, and make foul the clearness of our deservings,
line 3267-->    when of ourselves we publish them.
line 3268-->  COUNTESS. What does this knave here? Get you gone, sirrah. The
line 3269-->    complaints I have heard of you I do not all believe; 'tis my
line 3270-->    slowness that I do not, for I know you lack not folly to commit
line 3271-->    them and have ability enough to make such knaveries yours.
line 3272-->  CLOWN. 'Tis not unknown to you, madam, I am a poor fellow.
line 3273-->  COUNTESS. Well, sir.
line 3274-->  CLOWN. No, madam, 'tis not so well that I am poor, though many of
line 3275-->    the rich are damn'd; but if I may have your ladyship's good will
line 3276-->    to go to the world, Isbel the woman and I will do as we may.
line 3277-->  COUNTESS. Wilt thou needs be a beggar?
line 3278-->  CLOWN. I do beg your good will in this case.
line 3279-->  COUNTESS. In what case?  
line 3280-->  CLOWN. In Isbel's case and mine own. Service is no heritage; and I
line 3281-->    think I shall never have the blessing of God till I have issue o'
line 3282-->    my body; for they say bames are blessings.
line 3283-->  COUNTESS. Tell me thy reason why thou wilt marry.
line 3284-->  CLOWN. My poor body, madam, requires it. I am driven on by the
line 3285-->    flesh; and he must needs go that the devil drives.
line 3286-->  COUNTESS. Is this all your worship's reason?
line 3287-->  CLOWN. Faith, madam, I have other holy reasons, such as they are.
line 3288-->  COUNTESS. May the world know them?
line 3289-->  CLOWN. I have been, madam, a wicked creature, as you and all flesh
line 3290-->    and blood are; and, indeed, I do marry that I may repent.
line 3291-->  COUNTESS. Thy marriage, sooner than thy wickedness.
line 3292-->  CLOWN. I am out o' friends, madam, and I hope to have friends for
line 3293-->    my wife's sake.
line 3294-->  COUNTESS. Such friends are thine enemies, knave.
line 3295-->  CLOWN. Y'are shallow, madam-in great friends; for the knaves come
line 3296-->    to do that for me which I am aweary of. He that ears my land
line 3297-->    spares my team, and gives me leave to in the crop. If I be his
line 3298-->    cuckold, he's my drudge. He that comforts my wife is the
line 3299-->    cherisher of my flesh and blood; he that cherishes my flesh and  
line 3300-->    blood loves my flesh and blood; he that loves my flesh and blood
line 3301-->    is my friend; ergo, he that kisses my wife is my friend. If men
line 3302-->    could be contented to be what they are, there were no fear in
line 3303-->    marriage; for young Charbon the puritan and old Poysam the
line 3304-->    papist, howsome'er their hearts are sever'd in religion, their
line 3305-->    heads are both one; they may jowl horns together like any deer
line 3306-->    i' th' herd.
line 3307-->  COUNTESS. Wilt thou ever be a foul-mouth'd and calumnious knave?
line 3308-->  CLOWN. A prophet I, madam; and I speak the truth the next way:
line 3309-->
line 3310-->              For I the ballad will repeat,
line 3311-->                Which men full true shall find:
line 3312-->              Your marriage comes by destiny,
line 3313-->                Your cuckoo sings by kind.
line 3314-->
line 3315-->  COUNTESS. Get you gone, sir; I'll talk with you more anon.
line 3316-->  STEWARD. May it please you, madam, that he bid Helen come to you.
line 3317-->    Of her I am to speak.
line 3318-->  COUNTESS. Sirrah, tell my gentlewoman I would speak with her; Helen
line 3319-->    I mean.  
line 3320-->  CLOWN.  [Sings]
line 3321-->
line 3322-->               'Was this fair face the cause' quoth she
line 3323-->                 'Why the Grecians sacked Troy?
line 3324-->               Fond done, done fond,
line 3325-->                 Was this King Priam's joy?'
line 3326-->               With that she sighed as she stood,
line 3327-->               With that she sighed as she stood,
line 3328-->                 And gave this sentence then:
line 3329-->               'Among nine bad if one be good,
line 3330-->               Among nine bad if one be good,
line 3331-->                 There's yet one good in ten.'
line 3332-->
line 3333-->  COUNTESS. What, one good in ten? You corrupt the song, sirrah.
line 3334-->  CLOWN. One good woman in ten, madam, which is a purifying o' th'
line 3335-->    song. Would God would serve the world so all the year! We'd find
line 3336-->    no fault with the tithe-woman, if I were the parson. One in ten,
line 3337-->    quoth 'a! An we might have a good woman born before every blazing
line 3338-->    star, or at an earthquake, 'twould mend the lottery well: a man
line 3339-->    may draw his heart out ere 'a pluck one.
line 3340-->  COUNTESS. You'll be gone, sir knave, and do as I command you.  
line 3341-->  CLOWN. That man should be at woman's command, and yet no hurt done!
line 3342-->    Though honesty be no puritan, yet it will do no hurt; it will
line 3343-->    wear the surplice of humility over the black gown of a big heart.
line 3344-->    I am going, forsooth. The business is for Helen to come hither.
line 3345--> Exit
line 3346-->  COUNTESS. Well, now.
line 3347-->  STEWARD. I know, madam, you love your gentlewoman entirely.
line 3348-->  COUNTESS. Faith I do. Her father bequeath'd her to me; and she
line 3349-->    herself, without other advantage, may lawfully make title to as
line 3350-->    much love as she finds. There is more owing her than is paid; and
line 3351-->    more shall be paid her than she'll demand.
line 3352-->  STEWARD. Madam, I was very late more near her than I think she
line 3353-->    wish'd me. Alone she was, and did communicate to herself her own
line 3354-->    words to her own ears; she thought, I dare vow for her, they
line 3355-->    touch'd not any stranger sense. Her matter was, she loved your
line 3356-->    son. Fortune, she said, was no goddess, that had put such
line 3357-->    difference betwixt their two estates; Love no god, that would not
line 3358-->    extend his might only where qualities were level; Diana no queen
line 3359-->    of virgins, that would suffer her poor knight surpris'd without
line 3360-->    rescue in the first assault, or ransom afterward. This she  
line 3361-->    deliver'd in the most bitter touch of sorrow that e'er I heard
line 3362-->    virgin exclaim in; which I held my duty speedily to acquaint you
line 3363-->    withal; sithence, in the loss that may happen, it concerns you
line 3364-->    something to know it.
line 3365-->  COUNTESS. YOU have discharg'd this honestly; keep it to yourself.
line 3366-->    Many likelihoods inform'd me of this before, which hung so
line 3367-->    tott'ring in the balance that I could neither believe nor
line 3368-->    misdoubt. Pray you leave me. Stall this in your bosom; and I
line 3369-->    thank you for your honest care. I will speak with you further
line 3370-->    anon.                                           Exit STEWARD
line 3371-->
line 3372-->                            Enter HELENA
line 3373-->
line 3374-->    Even so it was with me when I was young.
line 3375-->    If ever we are nature's, these are ours; this thorn
line 3376-->    Doth to our rose of youth rightly belong;
line 3377-->    Our blood to us, this to our blood is born.
line 3378-->    It is the show and seal of nature's truth,
line 3379-->    Where love's strong passion is impress'd in youth.
line 3380-->    By our remembrances of days foregone,  
line 3381-->    Such were our faults, or then we thought them none.
line 3382-->    Her eye is sick on't; I observe her now.
line 3383-->  HELENA. What is your pleasure, madam?
line 3384-->  COUNTESS. You know, Helen,
line 3385-->    I am a mother to you.
line 3386-->  HELENA. Mine honourable mistress.
line 3387-->  COUNTESS. Nay, a mother.
line 3388-->    Why not a mother? When I said 'a mother,'
line 3389-->    Methought you saw a serpent. What's in 'mother'
line 3390-->    That you start at it? I say I am your mother,
line 3391-->    And put you in the catalogue of those
line 3392-->    That were enwombed mine. 'Tis often seen
line 3393-->    Adoption strives with nature, and choice breeds
line 3394-->    A native slip to us from foreign seeds.
line 3395-->    You ne'er oppress'd me with a mother's groan,
line 3396-->    Yet I express to you a mother's care.
line 3397-->    God's mercy, maiden! does it curd thy blood
line 3398-->    To say I am thy mother? What's the matter,
line 3399-->    That this distempered messenger of wet,
line 3400-->    The many-colour'd Iris, rounds thine eye?  
line 3401-->    Why, that you are my daughter?
line 3402-->  HELENA. That I am not.
line 3403-->  COUNTESS. I say I am your mother.
line 3404-->  HELENA. Pardon, madam.
line 3405-->    The Count Rousillon cannot be my brother:
line 3406-->    I am from humble, he from honoured name;
line 3407-->    No note upon my parents, his all noble.
line 3408-->    My master, my dear lord he is; and I
line 3409-->    His servant live, and will his vassal die.
line 3410-->    He must not be my brother.
line 3411-->  COUNTESS. Nor I your mother?
line 3412-->  HELENA. You are my mother, madam; would you were-
line 3413-->    So that my lord your son were not my brother-
line 3414-->    Indeed my mother! Or were you both our mothers,
line 3415-->    I care no more for than I do for heaven,
line 3416-->    So I were not his sister. Can't no other,
line 3417-->    But, I your daughter, he must be my brother?
line 3418-->  COUNTESS. Yes, Helen, you might be my daughter-in-law.
line 3419-->    God shield you mean it not! 'daughter' and 'mother'
line 3420-->    So strive upon your pulse. What! pale again?  
line 3421-->    My fear hath catch'd your fondness. Now I see
line 3422-->    The myst'ry of your loneliness, and find
line 3423-->    Your salt tears' head. Now to all sense 'tis gross
line 3424-->    You love my son; invention is asham'd,
line 3425-->    Against the proclamation of thy passion,
line 3426-->    To say thou dost not. Therefore tell me true;
line 3427-->    But tell me then, 'tis so; for, look, thy cheeks
line 3428-->    Confess it, th' one to th' other; and thine eyes
line 3429-->    See it so grossly shown in thy behaviours
line 3430-->    That in their kind they speak it; only sin
line 3431-->    And hellish obstinacy tie thy tongue,
line 3432-->    That truth should be suspected. Speak, is't so?
line 3433-->    If it be so, you have wound a goodly clew;
line 3434-->    If it be not, forswear't; howe'er, I charge thee,
line 3435-->    As heaven shall work in me for thine avail,
line 3436-->    To tell me truly.
line 3437-->  HELENA. Good madam, pardon me.
line 3438-->  COUNTESS. Do you love my son?
line 3439-->  HELENA. Your pardon, noble mistress.
line 3440-->  COUNTESS. Love you my son?  
line 3441-->  HELENA. Do not you love him, madam?
line 3442-->  COUNTESS. Go not about; my love hath in't a bond
line 3443-->    Whereof the world takes note. Come, come, disclose
line 3444-->    The state of your affection; for your passions
line 3445-->    Have to the full appeach'd.
line 3446-->  HELENA. Then I confess,
line 3447-->    Here on my knee, before high heaven and you,
line 3448-->    That before you, and next unto high heaven,
line 3449-->    I love your son.
line 3450-->    My friends were poor, but honest; so's my love.
line 3451-->    Be not offended, for it hurts not him
line 3452-->    That he is lov'd of me; I follow him not
line 3453-->    By any token of presumptuous suit,
line 3454-->    Nor would I have him till I do deserve him;
line 3455-->    Yet never know how that desert should be.
line 3456-->    I know I love in vain, strive against hope;
line 3457-->    Yet in this captious and intenible sieve
line 3458-->    I still pour in the waters of my love,
line 3459-->    And lack not to lose still. Thus, Indian-like,
line 3460-->    Religious in mine error, I adore  
line 3461-->    The sun that looks upon his worshipper
line 3462-->    But knows of him no more. My dearest madam,
line 3463-->    Let not your hate encounter with my love,
line 3464-->    For loving where you do; but if yourself,
line 3465-->    Whose aged honour cites a virtuous youth,
line 3466-->    Did ever in so true a flame of liking
line 3467-->    Wish chastely and love dearly that your Dian
line 3468-->    Was both herself and Love; O, then, give pity
line 3469-->    To her whose state is such that cannot choose
line 3470-->    But lend and give where she is sure to lose;
line 3471-->    That seeks not to find that her search implies,
line 3472-->    But, riddle-like, lives sweetly where she dies!
line 3473-->  COUNTESS. Had you not lately an intent-speak truly-
line 3474-->    To go to Paris?
line 3475-->  HELENA. Madam, I had.
line 3476-->  COUNTESS. Wherefore? Tell true.
line 3477-->  HELENA. I will tell truth; by grace itself I swear.
line 3478-->    You know my father left me some prescriptions
line 3479-->    Of rare and prov'd effects, such as his reading
line 3480-->    And manifest experience had collected  
line 3481-->    For general sovereignty; and that he will'd me
line 3482-->    In heedfull'st reservation to bestow them,
line 3483-->    As notes whose faculties inclusive were
line 3484-->    More than they were in note. Amongst the rest
line 3485-->    There is a remedy, approv'd, set down,
line 3486-->    To cure the desperate languishings whereof
line 3487-->    The King is render'd lost.
line 3488-->  COUNTESS. This was your motive
line 3489-->    For Paris, was it? Speak.
line 3490-->  HELENA. My lord your son made me to think of this,
line 3491-->    Else Paris, and the medicine, and the King,
line 3492-->    Had from the conversation of my thoughts
line 3493-->    Haply been absent then.
line 3494-->  COUNTESS. But think you, Helen,
line 3495-->    If you should tender your supposed aid,
line 3496-->    He would receive it? He and his physicians
line 3497-->    Are of a mind: he, that they cannot help him;
line 3498-->    They, that they cannot help. How shall they credit
line 3499-->    A poor unlearned virgin, when the schools,
line 3500-->    Embowell'd of their doctrine, have let off  
line 3501-->    The danger to itself?
line 3502-->  HELENA. There's something in't
line 3503-->    More than my father's skill, which was the great'st
line 3504-->    Of his profession, that his good receipt
line 3505-->    Shall for my legacy be sanctified
line 3506-->    By th' luckiest stars in heaven; and, would your honour
line 3507-->    But give me leave to try success, I'd venture
line 3508-->    The well-lost life of mine on his Grace's cure.
line 3509-->    By such a day and hour.
line 3510-->  COUNTESS. Dost thou believe't?
line 3511-->  HELENA. Ay, madam, knowingly.
line 3512-->  COUNTESS. Why, Helen, thou shalt have my leave and love,
line 3513-->    Means and attendants, and my loving greetings
line 3514-->    To those of mine in court. I'll stay at home,
line 3515-->    And pray God's blessing into thy attempt.
line 3516-->    Be gone to-morrow; and be sure of this,
line 3517-->    What I can help thee to thou shalt not miss.          Exeunt
line 3518-->
line 3519-->
line 3520-->
