line 3531-->
line 3532-->
line 3533-->ACT II. SCENE 1.
line 3534-->Paris. The KING'S palace
line 3535-->
line 3536-->Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING with divers young LORDS taking leave
line 3537-->for the Florentine war; BERTRAM and PAROLLES; ATTENDANTS
line 3538-->
line 3539-->  KING. Farewell, young lords; these war-like principles
line 3540-->    Do not throw from you. And you, my lords, farewell;
line 3541-->    Share the advice betwixt you; if both gain all,
line 3542-->    The gift doth stretch itself as 'tis receiv'd,
line 3543-->    And is enough for both.
line 3544-->  FIRST LORD. 'Tis our hope, sir,
line 3545-->    After well-ent'red soldiers, to return
line 3546-->    And find your Grace in health.
line 3547-->  KING. No, no, it cannot be; and yet my heart
line 3548-->    Will not confess he owes the malady
line 3549-->    That doth my life besiege. Farewell, young lords;
line 3550-->    Whether I live or die, be you the sons
line 3551-->    Of worthy Frenchmen; let higher Italy-
line 3552-->    Those bated that inherit but the fall
line 3553-->    Of the last monarchy-see that you come  
line 3554-->    Not to woo honour, but to wed it; when
line 3555-->    The bravest questant shrinks, find what you seek,
line 3556-->    That fame may cry you aloud. I say farewell.
line 3557-->  SECOND LORD. Health, at your bidding, serve your Majesty!
line 3558-->  KING. Those girls of Italy, take heed of them;
line 3559-->    They say our French lack language to deny,
line 3560-->    If they demand; beware of being captives
line 3561-->    Before you serve.
line 3562-->    BOTH. Our hearts receive your warnings.
line 3563-->  KING. Farewell.  [To ATTENDANTS]  Come hither to me.
line 3564-->                                       The KING retires attended
line 3565-->  FIRST LORD. O my sweet lord, that you will stay behind us!
line 3566-->  PAROLLES. 'Tis not his fault, the spark.
line 3567-->    SECOND LORD. O, 'tis brave wars!
line 3568-->  PAROLLES. Most admirable! I have seen those wars.
line 3569-->  BERTRAM. I am commanded here and kept a coil with
line 3570-->    'Too young' and next year' and "Tis too early.'
line 3571-->  PAROLLES. An thy mind stand to 't, boy, steal away bravely.
line 3572-->  BERTRAM. I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock,
line 3573-->    Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry,  
line 3574-->    Till honour be bought up, and no sword worn
line 3575-->    But one to dance with. By heaven, I'll steal away.
line 3576-->  FIRST LORD. There's honour in the theft.
line 3577-->  PAROLLES. Commit it, Count.
line 3578-->  SECOND LORD. I am your accessary; and so farewell.
line 3579-->  BERTRAM. I grow to you, and our parting is a tortur'd body.
line 3580-->  FIRST LORD. Farewell, Captain.
line 3581-->  SECOND LORD. Sweet Monsieur Parolles!
line 3582-->  PAROLLES. Noble heroes, my sword and yours are kin. Good sparks and
line 3583-->    lustrous, a word, good metals: you shall find in the regiment of
line 3584-->    the Spinii one Captain Spurio, with his cicatrice, an emblem of
line 3585-->    war, here on his sinister cheek; it was this very sword
line 3586-->    entrench'd it. Say to him I live; and observe his reports for me.
line 3587-->  FIRST LORD. We shall, noble Captain.
line 3588-->  PAROLLES. Mars dote on you for his novices!       Exeunt LORDS
line 3589-->    What will ye do?
line 3590-->
line 3591-->                            Re-enter the KING
line 3592-->
line 3593-->  BERTRAM. Stay; the King!  
line 3594-->  PAROLLES. Use a more spacious ceremony to the noble lords; you have
line 3595-->    restrain'd yourself within the list of too cold an adieu. Be more
line 3596-->    expressive to them; for they wear themselves in the cap of the
line 3597-->    time; there do muster true gait; eat, speak, and move, under the
line 3598-->    influence of the most receiv'd star; and though the devil lead
line 3599-->    the measure, such are to be followed. After them, and take a more
line 3600-->    dilated farewell.
line 3601-->  BERTRAM. And I will do so.
line 3602-->  PAROLLES. Worthy fellows; and like to prove most sinewy sword-men.
line 3603-->                                     Exeunt BERTRAM and PAROLLES
line 3604-->
line 3605-->                              Enter LAFEU
line 3606-->
line 3607-->  LAFEU.  [Kneeling]  Pardon, my lord, for me and for my tidings.
line 3608-->  KING. I'll fee thee to stand up.
line 3609-->  LAFEU. Then here's a man stands that has brought his pardon.
line 3610-->    I would you had kneel'd, my lord, to ask me mercy;
line 3611-->    And that at my bidding you could so stand up.
line 3612-->  KING. I would I had; so I had broke thy pate,
line 3613-->    And ask'd thee mercy for't.  
line 3614-->  LAFEU. Good faith, across!
line 3615-->    But, my good lord, 'tis thus: will you be cur'd
line 3616-->    Of your infirmity?
line 3617-->  KING. No.
line 3618-->  LAFEU. O, will you eat
line 3619-->    No grapes, my royal fox? Yes, but you will
line 3620-->    My noble grapes, an if my royal fox
line 3621-->    Could reach them: I have seen a medicine
line 3622-->    That's able to breathe life into a stone,
line 3623-->    Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary
line 3624-->    With spritely fire and motion; whose simple touch
line 3625-->    Is powerful to araise King Pepin, nay,
line 3626-->    To give great Charlemain a pen in's hand
line 3627-->    And write to her a love-line.
line 3628-->  KING. What her is this?
line 3629-->  LAFEU. Why, Doctor She! My lord, there's one arriv'd,
line 3630-->    If you will see her. Now, by my faith and honour,
line 3631-->    If seriously I may convey my thoughts
line 3632-->    In this my light deliverance, I have spoke
line 3633-->    With one that in her sex, her years, profession,  
line 3634-->    Wisdom, and constancy, hath amaz'd me more
line 3635-->    Than I dare blame my weakness. Will you see her,
line 3636-->    For that is her demand, and know her business?
line 3637-->    That done, laugh well at me.
line 3638-->  KING. Now, good Lafeu,
line 3639-->    Bring in the admiration, that we with the
line 3640-->    May spend our wonder too, or take off thine
line 3641-->    By wond'ring how thou took'st it.
line 3642-->  LAFEU. Nay, I'll fit you,
line 3643-->    And not be all day neither.                       Exit LAFEU
line 3644-->  KING. Thus he his special nothing ever prologues.
line 3645-->
line 3646-->                   Re-enter LAFEU with HELENA
line 3647-->
line 3648-->  LAFEU. Nay, come your ways.
line 3649-->  KING. This haste hath wings indeed.
line 3650-->  LAFEU. Nay, come your ways;
line 3651-->    This is his Majesty; say your mind to him.
line 3652-->    A traitor you do look like; but such traitors
line 3653-->    His Majesty seldom fears. I am Cressid's uncle,  
line 3654-->    That dare leave two together. Fare you well.            Exit
line 3655-->  KING. Now, fair one, does your business follow us?
line 3656-->  HELENA. Ay, my good lord.
line 3657-->    Gerard de Narbon was my father,
line 3658-->    In what he did profess, well found.
line 3659-->  KING. I knew him.
line 3660-->  HELENA. The rather will I spare my praises towards him;
line 3661-->    Knowing him is enough. On's bed of death
line 3662-->    Many receipts he gave me; chiefly one,
line 3663-->    Which, as the dearest issue of his practice,
line 3664-->    And of his old experience th' only darling,
line 3665-->    He bade me store up as a triple eye,
line 3666-->    Safer than mine own two, more dear. I have so:
line 3667-->    And, hearing your high Majesty is touch'd
line 3668-->    With that malignant cause wherein the honour
line 3669-->    Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power,
line 3670-->    I come to tender it, and my appliance,
line 3671-->    With all bound humbleness.
line 3672-->  KING. We thank you, maiden;
line 3673-->    But may not be so credulous of cure,  
line 3674-->    When our most learned doctors leave us, and
line 3675-->    The congregated college have concluded
line 3676-->    That labouring art can never ransom nature
line 3677-->    From her inaidable estate-I say we must not
line 3678-->    So stain our judgment, or corrupt our hope,
line 3679-->    To prostitute our past-cure malady
line 3680-->    To empirics; or to dissever so
line 3681-->    Our great self and our credit to esteem
line 3682-->    A senseless help, when help past sense we deem.
line 3683-->  HELENA. My duty then shall pay me for my pains.
line 3684-->    I will no more enforce mine office on you;
line 3685-->    Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts
line 3686-->    A modest one to bear me back again.
line 3687-->  KING. I cannot give thee less, to be call'd grateful.
line 3688-->    Thou thought'st to help me; and such thanks I give
line 3689-->    As one near death to those that wish him live.
line 3690-->    But what at full I know, thou know'st no part;
line 3691-->    I knowing all my peril, thou no art.
line 3692-->  HELENA. What I can do can do no hurt to try,
line 3693-->    Since you set up your rest 'gainst remedy.  
line 3694-->    He that of greatest works is finisher
line 3695-->    Oft does them by the weakest minister.
line 3696-->    So holy writ in babes hath judgment shown,
line 3697-->    When judges have been babes. Great floods have flown
line 3698-->    From simple sources, and great seas have dried
line 3699-->    When miracles have by the greatest been denied.
line 3700-->    Oft expectation fails, and most oft there
line 3701-->    Where most it promises; and oft it hits
line 3702-->    Where hope is coldest, and despair most fits.
line 3703-->  KING. I must not hear thee. Fare thee well, kind maid;
line 3704-->    Thy pains, not us'd, must by thyself be paid;
line 3705-->    Proffers not took reap thanks for their reward.
line 3706-->  HELENA. Inspired merit so by breath is barr'd.
line 3707-->    It is not so with Him that all things knows,
line 3708-->    As 'tis with us that square our guess by shows;
line 3709-->    But most it is presumption in us when
line 3710-->    The help of heaven we count the act of men.
line 3711-->    Dear sir, to my endeavours give consent;
line 3712-->    Of heaven, not me, make an experiment.
line 3713-->    I am not an impostor, that proclaim  
line 3714-->    Myself against the level of mine aim;
line 3715-->    But know I think, and think I know most sure,
line 3716-->    My art is not past power nor you past cure.
line 3717-->  KING. Art thou so confident? Within what space
line 3718-->    Hop'st thou my cure?
line 3719-->  HELENA. The greatest Grace lending grace.
line 3720-->    Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring
line 3721-->    Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring,
line 3722-->    Ere twice in murk and occidental damp
line 3723-->    Moist Hesperus hath quench'd his sleepy lamp,
line 3724-->    Or four and twenty times the pilot's glass
line 3725-->    Hath told the thievish minutes how they pass,
line 3726-->    What is infirm from your sound parts shall fly,
line 3727-->    Health shall live free, and sickness freely die.
line 3728-->  KING. Upon thy certainty and confidence
line 3729-->    What dar'st thou venture?
line 3730-->  HELENA. Tax of impudence,
line 3731-->    A strumpet's boldness, a divulged shame,
line 3732-->    Traduc'd by odious ballads; my maiden's name
line 3733-->    Sear'd otherwise; ne worse of worst-extended  
line 3734-->    With vilest torture let my life be ended.
line 3735-->  KING. Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak
line 3736-->    His powerful sound within an organ weak;
line 3737-->    And what impossibility would slay
line 3738-->    In common sense, sense saves another way.
line 3739-->    Thy life is dear; for all that life can rate
line 3740-->    Worth name of life in thee hath estimate:
line 3741-->    Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all
line 3742-->    That happiness and prime can happy call.
line 3743-->    Thou this to hazard needs must intimate
line 3744-->    Skill infinite or monstrous desperate.
line 3745-->    Sweet practiser, thy physic I will try,
line 3746-->    That ministers thine own death if I die.
line 3747-->  HELENA. If I break time, or flinch in property
line 3748-->    Of what I spoke, unpitied let me die;
line 3749-->    And well deserv'd. Not helping, death's my fee;
line 3750-->    But, if I help, what do you promise me?
line 3751-->  KING. Make thy demand.
line 3752-->  HELENA. But will you make it even?
line 3753-->  KING. Ay, by my sceptre and my hopes of heaven.  
line 3754-->  HELENA. Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand
line 3755-->    What husband in thy power I will command.
line 3756-->    Exempted be from me the arrogance
line 3757-->    To choose from forth the royal blood of France,
line 3758-->    My low and humble name to propagate
line 3759-->    With any branch or image of thy state;
line 3760-->    But such a one, thy vassal, whom I know
line 3761-->    Is free for me to ask, thee to bestow.
line 3762-->  KING. Here is my hand; the premises observ'd,
line 3763-->    Thy will by my performance shall be serv'd.
line 3764-->    So make the choice of thy own time, for I,
line 3765-->    Thy resolv'd patient, on thee still rely.
line 3766-->    More should I question thee, and more I must,
line 3767-->    Though more to know could not be more to trust,
line 3768-->    From whence thou cam'st, how tended on. But rest
line 3769-->    Unquestion'd welcome and undoubted blest.
line 3770-->    Give me some help here, ho! If thou proceed
line 3771-->    As high as word, my deed shall match thy deed.
line 3772-->                                              [Flourish. Exeunt]
line 3773-->
line 3774-->
line 3775-->
line 3776-->
line 3777-->ACT II. SCENE 2.
line 3778-->Rousillon. The COUNT'S palace
line 3779-->
line 3780-->Enter COUNTESS and CLOWN
line 3781-->
line 3782-->  COUNTESS. Come on, sir; I shall now put you to the height of your
line 3783-->    breeding.
line 3784-->  CLOWN. I will show myself highly fed and lowly taught. I know my
line 3785-->    business is but to the court.
line 3786-->  COUNTESS. To the court! Why, what place make you special, when you
line 3787-->    put off that with such contempt? But to the court!
line 3788-->  CLOWN. Truly, madam, if God have lent a man any manners, he may
line 3789-->    easily put it off at court. He that cannot make a leg, put off's
line 3790-->    cap, kiss his hand, and say nothing, has neither leg, hands, lip,
line 3791-->    nor cap; and indeed such a fellow, to say precisely, were not for
line 3792-->    the court; but for me, I have an answer will serve all men.
line 3793-->  COUNTESS. Marry, that's a bountiful answer that fits all questions.
line 3794-->  CLOWN. It is like a barber's chair, that fits all buttocks-the pin
line 3795-->    buttock, the quatch buttock, the brawn buttock, or any buttock.
line 3796-->  COUNTESS. Will your answer serve fit to all questions?
line 3797-->  CLOWN. As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an attorney, as your
line 3798-->    French crown for your taffety punk, as Tib's rush for Tom's
line 3799-->    forefinger, as a pancake for Shrove Tuesday, a morris for Mayday,
line 3800-->    as the nail to his hole, the cuckold to his horn, as a scolding
line 3801-->    quean to a wrangling knave, as the nun's lip to the friar's
line 3802-->    mouth; nay, as the pudding to his skin.
line 3803-->  COUNTESS. Have you, I, say, an answer of such fitness for all
line 3804-->    questions?
line 3805-->  CLOWN. From below your duke to beneath your constable, it will fit
line 3806-->    any question.
line 3807-->  COUNTESS. It must be an answer of most monstrous size that must fit
line 3808-->    all demands.
line 3809-->  CLOWN. But a trifle neither, in good faith, if the learned should
line 3810-->    speak truth of it. Here it is, and all that belongs to't. Ask me
line 3811-->    if I am a courtier: it shall do you no harm to learn.
line 3812-->  COUNTESS. To be young again, if we could, I will be a fool in
line 3813-->    question, hoping to be the wiser by your answer. I pray you, sir,
line 3814-->    are you a courtier?
line 3815-->  CLOWN. O Lord, sir!-There's a simple putting off. More, more, a
line 3816-->    hundred of them.
line 3817-->  COUNTESS. Sir, I am a poor friend of yours, that loves you.
line 3818-->  CLOWN. O Lord, sir!-Thick, thick; spare not me.  
line 3819-->  COUNTESS. I think, sir, you can eat none of this homely meat.
line 3820-->  CLOWN. O Lord, sir!-Nay, put me to't, I warrant you.
line 3821-->  COUNTESS. You were lately whipp'd, sir, as I think.
line 3822-->  CLOWN. O Lord, sir!-Spare not me.
line 3823-->  COUNTESS. Do you cry 'O Lord, sir!' at your whipping, and 'spare
line 3824-->    not me'? Indeed your 'O Lord, sir!' is very sequent to your
line 3825-->    whipping. You would answer very well to a whipping, if you were
line 3826-->    but bound to't.
line 3827-->  CLOWN. I ne'er had worse luck in my life in my 'O Lord, sir!' I see
line 3828-->    thing's may serve long, but not serve ever.
line 3829-->  COUNTESS. I play the noble housewife with the time,
line 3830-->    To entertain it so merrily with a fool.
line 3831-->  CLOWN. O Lord, sir!-Why, there't serves well again.
line 3832-->  COUNTESS. An end, sir! To your business: give Helen this,
line 3833-->    And urge her to a present answer back;
line 3834-->    Commend me to my kinsmen and my son. This is not much.
line 3835-->  CLOWN. Not much commendation to them?
line 3836-->  COUNTESS. Not much employment for you. You understand me?
line 3837-->  CLOWN. Most fruitfully; I am there before my legs.
line 3838-->  COUNTESS. Haste you again.                              Exeunt
line 3839-->
line 3840-->
line 3841-->
line 3842-->
line 3843-->ACT II. SCENE 3.
line 3844-->Paris. The KING'S palace
line 3845-->
line 3846-->Enter BERTRAM, LAFEU, and PAROLLES
line 3847-->
line 3848-->  LAFEU. They say miracles are past; and we have our philosophical
line 3849-->    persons to make modern and familiar things supernatural and
line 3850-->    causeless. Hence is it that we make trifles of terrors,
line 3851-->    ensconcing ourselves into seeming knowledge when we should submit
line 3852-->    ourselves to an unknown fear.
line 3853-->  PAROLLES. Why, 'tis the rarest argument of wonder that hath shot
line 3854-->    out in our latter times.
line 3855-->  BERTRAM. And so 'tis.
line 3856-->  LAFEU. To be relinquish'd of the artists-
line 3857-->  PAROLLES. So I say-both of Galen and Paracelsus.
line 3858-->  LAFEU. Of all the learned and authentic fellows-
line 3859-->  PAROLLES. Right; so I say.
line 3860-->  LAFEU. That gave him out incurable-
line 3861-->  PAROLLES. Why, there 'tis; so say I too.
line 3862-->  LAFEU. Not to be help'd-
line 3863-->  PAROLLES. Right; as 'twere a man assur'd of a-
line 3864-->  LAFEU. Uncertain life and sure death.  
line 3865-->  PAROLLES. Just; you say well; so would I have said.
line 3866-->  LAFEU. I may truly say it is a novelty to the world.
line 3867-->  PAROLLES. It is indeed. If you will have it in showing, you shall
line 3868-->    read it in what-do-ye-call't here.
line 3869-->  LAFEU.  [Reading the ballad title]  'A Showing of a Heavenly
line 3870-->    Effect in an Earthly Actor.'
line 3871-->  PAROLLES. That's it; I would have said the very same.
line 3872-->  LAFEU. Why, your dolphin is not lustier. 'Fore me, I speak in
line 3873-->    respect-
line 3874-->  PAROLLES. Nay, 'tis strange, 'tis very strange; that is the brief
line 3875-->    and the tedious of it; and he's of a most facinerious spirit that
line 3876-->    will not acknowledge it to be the-
line 3877-->  LAFEU. Very hand of heaven.
line 3878-->  PAROLLES. Ay; so I say.
line 3879-->  LAFEU. In a most weak-
line 3880-->  PAROLLES. And debile minister, great power, great transcendence;
line 3881-->    which should, indeed, give us a further use to be made than alone
line 3882-->    the recov'ry of the King, as to be-
line 3883-->  LAFEU. Generally thankful.
line 3884-->  
line 3885-->                 Enter KING, HELENA, and ATTENDANTS
line 3886-->
line 3887-->  PAROLLES. I would have said it; you say well. Here comes the King.
line 3888-->  LAFEU. Lustig, as the Dutchman says. I'll like a maid the better,
line 3889-->    whilst I have a tooth in my head. Why, he's able to lead her a
line 3890-->    coranto.
line 3891-->  PAROLLES. Mort du vinaigre! Is not this Helen?
line 3892-->  LAFEU. 'Fore God, I think so.
line 3893-->  KING. Go, call before me all the lords in court.
line 3894-->                                               Exit an ATTENDANT
line 3895-->    Sit, my preserver, by thy patient's side;
line 3896-->    And with this healthful hand, whose banish'd sense
line 3897-->    Thou has repeal'd, a second time receive
line 3898-->    The confirmation of my promis'd gift,
line 3899-->    Which but attends thy naming.
line 3900-->
line 3901-->                     Enter three or four LORDS
line 3902-->
line 3903-->    Fair maid, send forth thine eye. This youthful parcel
line 3904-->    Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing,  
line 3905-->    O'er whom both sovereign power and father's voice
line 3906-->    I have to use. Thy frank election make;
line 3907-->    Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.
line 3908-->  HELENA. To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress
line 3909-->    Fall, when love please. Marry, to each but one!
line 3910-->  LAFEU. I'd give bay Curtal and his furniture
line 3911-->    My mouth no more were broken than these boys',
line 3912-->    And writ as little beard.
line 3913-->  KING. Peruse them well.
line 3914-->    Not one of those but had a noble father.
line 3915-->  HELENA. Gentlemen,
line 3916-->    Heaven hath through me restor'd the King to health.
line 3917-->  ALL. We understand it, and thank heaven for you.
line 3918-->  HELENA. I am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest
line 3919-->    That I protest I simply am a maid.
line 3920-->    Please it your Majesty, I have done already.
line 3921-->    The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me:
line 3922-->    'We blush that thou shouldst choose; but, be refused,
line 3923-->    Let the white death sit on thy cheek for ever,
line 3924-->    We'll ne'er come there again.'  
line 3925-->  KING. Make choice and see:
line 3926-->    Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.
line 3927-->  HELENA. Now, Dian, from thy altar do I fly,
line 3928-->    And to imperial Love, that god most high,
line 3929-->    Do my sighs stream. Sir, will you hear my suit?
line 3930-->  FIRST LORD. And grant it.
line 3931-->  HELENA. Thanks, sir; all the rest is mute.
line 3932-->  LAFEU. I had rather be in this choice than throw ames-ace for my
line 3933-->    life.
line 3934-->  HELENA. The honour, sir, that flames in your fair eyes,
line 3935-->    Before I speak, too threat'ningly replies.
line 3936-->    Love make your fortunes twenty times above
line 3937-->    Her that so wishes, and her humble love!
line 3938-->  SECOND LORD. No better, if you please.
line 3939-->  HELENA. My wish receive,
line 3940-->    Which great Love grant; and so I take my leave.
line 3941-->  LAFEU. Do all they deny her? An they were sons of mine I'd have
line 3942-->    them whipt; or I would send them to th' Turk to make eunuchs of.
line 3943-->  HELENA. Be not afraid that I your hand should take;
line 3944-->    I'll never do you wrong for your own sake.  
line 3945-->    Blessing upon your vows; and in your bed
line 3946-->    Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed!
line 3947-->  LAFEU. These boys are boys of ice; they'll none have her.
line 3948-->    Sure, they are bastards to the English; the French ne'er got 'em.
line 3949-->  HELENA. You are too young, too happy, and too good,
line 3950-->    To make yourself a son out of my blood.
line 3951-->  FOURTH LORD. Fair one, I think not so.
line 3952-->  LAFEU. There's one grape yet; I am sure thy father drunk wine-but
line 3953-->    if thou be'st not an ass, I am a youth of fourteen; I have known
line 3954-->    thee already.
line 3955-->  HELENA.  [To BERTRAM]  I dare not say I take you; but I give
line 3956-->    Me and my service, ever whilst I live,
line 3957-->    Into your guiding power. This is the man.
line 3958-->  KING. Why, then, young Bertram, take her; she's thy wife.
line 3959-->  BERTRAM. My wife, my liege! I shall beseech your Highness,
line 3960-->    In such a business give me leave to use
line 3961-->    The help of mine own eyes.
line 3962-->  KING. Know'st thou not, Bertram,
line 3963-->    What she has done for me?
line 3964-->  BERTRAM. Yes, my good lord;  
line 3965-->    But never hope to know why I should marry her.
line 3966-->  KING. Thou know'st she has rais'd me from my sickly bed.
line 3967-->  BERTRAM. But follows it, my lord, to bring me down
line 3968-->    Must answer for your raising? I know her well:
line 3969-->    She had her breeding at my father's charge.
line 3970-->    A poor physician's daughter my wife! Disdain
line 3971-->    Rather corrupt me ever!
line 3972-->  KING. 'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her, the which
line 3973-->    I can build up. Strange is it that our bloods,
line 3974-->    Of colour, weight, and heat, pour'd all together,
line 3975-->    Would quite confound distinction, yet stand off
line 3976-->    In differences so mighty. If she be
line 3977-->    All that is virtuous-save what thou dislik'st,
line 3978-->    A poor physician's daughter-thou dislik'st
line 3979-->    Of virtue for the name; but do not so.
line 3980-->    From lowest place when virtuous things proceed,
line 3981-->    The place is dignified by the doer's deed;
line 3982-->    Where great additions swell's, and virtue none,
line 3983-->    It is a dropsied honour. Good alone
line 3984-->    Is good without a name. Vileness is so:  
line 3985-->    The property by what it is should go,
line 3986-->    Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair;
line 3987-->    In these to nature she's immediate heir;
line 3988-->    And these breed honour. That is honour's scorn
line 3989-->    Which challenges itself as honour's born
line 3990-->    And is not like the sire. Honours thrive
line 3991-->    When rather from our acts we them derive
line 3992-->    Than our fore-goers. The mere word's a slave,
line 3993-->    Debauch'd on every tomb, on every grave
line 3994-->    A lying trophy; and as oft is dumb
line 3995-->    Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb
line 3996-->    Of honour'd bones indeed. What should be said?
line 3997-->    If thou canst like this creature as a maid,
line 3998-->    I can create the rest. Virtue and she
line 3999-->    Is her own dower; honour and wealth from me.
line 4000-->  BERTRAM. I cannot love her, nor will strive to do 't.
line 4001-->  KING. Thou wrong'st thyself, if thou shouldst strive to choose.
line 4002-->  HELENA. That you are well restor'd, my lord, I'm glad.
line 4003-->    Let the rest go.
line 4004-->  KING. My honour's at the stake; which to defeat,  
line 4005-->    I must produce my power. Here, take her hand,
line 4006-->    Proud scornful boy, unworthy this good gift,
line 4007-->    That dost in vile misprision shackle up
line 4008-->    My love and her desert; that canst not dream
line 4009-->    We, poising us in her defective scale,
line 4010-->    Shall weigh thee to the beam; that wilt not know
line 4011-->    It is in us to plant thine honour where
line 4012-->    We please to have it grow. Check thy contempt;
line 4013-->    Obey our will, which travails in thy good;
line 4014-->    Believe not thy disdain, but presently
line 4015-->    Do thine own fortunes that obedient right
line 4016-->    Which both thy duty owes and our power claims;
line 4017-->    Or I will throw thee from my care for ever
line 4018-->    Into the staggers and the careless lapse
line 4019-->    Of youth and ignorance; both my revenge and hate
line 4020-->    Loosing upon thee in the name of justice,
line 4021-->    Without all terms of pity. Speak; thine answer.
line 4022-->  BERTRAM. Pardon, my gracious lord; for I submit
line 4023-->    My fancy to your eyes. When I consider
line 4024-->    What great creation and what dole of honour  
line 4025-->    Flies where you bid it, I find that she which late
line 4026-->    Was in my nobler thoughts most base is now
line 4027-->    The praised of the King; who, so ennobled,
line 4028-->    Is as 'twere born so.
line 4029-->  KING. Take her by the hand,
line 4030-->    And tell her she is thine; to whom I promise
line 4031-->    A counterpoise, if not to thy estate
line 4032-->    A balance more replete.
line 4033-->  BERTRAM. I take her hand.
line 4034-->  KING. Good fortune and the favour of the King
line 4035-->    Smile upon this contract; whose ceremony
line 4036-->    Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief,
line 4037-->    And be perform'd to-night. The solemn feast
line 4038-->    Shall more attend upon the coming space,
line 4039-->    Expecting absent friends. As thou lov'st her,
line 4040-->    Thy love's to me religious; else, does err.
line 4041-->              Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES who stay behind,
line 4042-->                                      commenting of this wedding
line 4043-->  LAFEU. Do you hear, monsieur? A word with you.
line 4044-->  PAROLLES. Your pleasure, sir?  
line 4045-->  LAFEU. Your lord and master did well to make his recantation.
line 4046-->  PAROLLES. Recantation! My Lord! my master!
line 4047-->  LAFEU. Ay; is it not a language I speak?
line 4048-->  PAROLLES. A most harsh one, and not to be understood without bloody
line 4049-->    succeeding. My master!
line 4050-->  LAFEU. Are you companion to the Count Rousillon?
line 4051-->  PAROLLES. To any count; to all counts; to what is man.
line 4052-->  LAFEU. To what is count's man: count's master is of another style.
line 4053-->  PAROLLES. You are too old, sir; let it satisfy you, you are too
line 4054-->    old.
line 4055-->  LAFEU. I must tell thee, sirrah, I write man; to which title age
line 4056-->    cannot bring thee.
line 4057-->  PAROLLES. What I dare too well do, I dare not do.
line 4058-->  LAFEU. I did think thee, for two ordinaries, to be a pretty wise
line 4059-->    fellow; thou didst make tolerable vent of thy travel; it might
line 4060-->    pass. Yet the scarfs and the bannerets about thee did manifoldly
line 4061-->    dissuade me from believing thee a vessel of too great a burden. I
line 4062-->    have now found thee; when I lose thee again I care not; yet art
line 4063-->    thou good for nothing but taking up; and that thou'rt scarce
line 4064-->    worth.  
line 4065-->  PAROLLES. Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity upon thee-
line 4066-->  LAFEU. Do not plunge thyself too far in anger, lest thou hasten thy
line 4067-->    trial; which if-Lord have mercy on thee for a hen! So, my good
line 4068-->    window of lattice, fare thee well; thy casement I need not open,
line 4069-->    for I look through thee. Give me thy hand.
line 4070-->  PAROLLES. My lord, you give me most egregious indignity.
line 4071-->  LAFEU. Ay, with all my heart; and thou art worthy of it.
line 4072-->  PAROLLES. I have not, my lord, deserv'd it.
line 4073-->  LAFEU. Yes, good faith, ev'ry dram of it; and I will not bate thee
line 4074-->    a scruple.
line 4075-->  PAROLLES. Well, I shall be wiser.
line 4076-->  LAFEU. Ev'n as soon as thou canst, for thou hast to pull at a smack
line 4077-->    o' th' contrary. If ever thou be'st bound in thy scarf and
line 4078-->    beaten, thou shalt find what it is to be proud of thy bondage. I
line 4079-->    have a desire to hold my acquaintance with thee, or rather my
line 4080-->    knowledge, that I may say in the default 'He is a man I know.'
line 4081-->  PAROLLES. My lord, you do me most insupportable vexation.
line 4082-->  LAFEU. I would it were hell pains for thy sake, and my poor doing
line 4083-->    eternal; for doing I am past, as I will by thee, in what motion
line 4084-->    age will give me leave.                                 Exit  
line 4085-->  PAROLLES. Well, thou hast a son shall take this disgrace off me:
line 4086-->    scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy lord! Well, I must be patient; there
line 4087-->    is no fettering of authority. I'll beat him, by my life, if I can
line 4088-->    meet him with any convenience, an he were double and double a
line 4089-->    lord. I'll have no more pity of his age than I would have of-
line 4090-->    I'll beat him, and if I could but meet him again.
line 4091-->
line 4092-->                         Re-enter LAFEU
line 4093-->
line 4094-->  LAFEU. Sirrah, your lord and master's married; there's news for
line 4095-->    you; you have a new mistress.
line 4096-->  PAROLLES. I most unfeignedly beseech your lordship to make some
line 4097-->    reservation of your wrongs. He is my good lord: whom I serve
line 4098-->    above is my master.
line 4099-->  LAFEU. Who? God?
line 4100-->  PAROLLES. Ay, sir.
line 4101-->  LAFEU. The devil it is that's thy master. Why dost thou garter up
line 4102-->    thy arms o' this fashion? Dost make hose of thy sleeves? Do other
line 4103-->    servants so? Thou wert best set thy lower part where thy nose
line 4104-->    stands. By mine honour, if I were but two hours younger, I'd beat  
line 4105-->    thee. Methink'st thou art a general offence, and every man should
line 4106-->    beat thee. I think thou wast created for men to breathe
line 4107-->    themselves upon thee.
line 4108-->  PAROLLES. This is hard and undeserved measure, my lord.
line 4109-->  LAFEU. Go to, sir; you were beaten in Italy for picking a kernel
line 4110-->    out of a pomegranate; you are a vagabond, and no true traveller;
line 4111-->    you are more saucy with lords and honourable personages than the
line 4112-->    commission of your birth and virtue gives you heraldry. You are
line 4113-->    not worth another word, else I'd call you knave. I leave you.
line 4114--> Exit
line 4115-->
line 4116-->                           Enter BERTRAM
line 4117-->
line 4118-->  PAROLLES. Good, very, good, it is so then. Good, very good; let it
line 4119-->    be conceal'd awhile.
line 4120-->  BERTRAM. Undone, and forfeited to cares for ever!
line 4121-->  PAROLLES. What's the matter, sweetheart?
line 4122-->  BERTRAM. Although before the solemn priest I have sworn,
line 4123-->    I will not bed her.
line 4124-->  PAROLLES. What, what, sweetheart?  
line 4125-->  BERTRAM. O my Parolles, they have married me!
line 4126-->    I'll to the Tuscan wars, and never bed her.
line 4127-->  PAROLLES. France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits
line 4128-->    The tread of a man's foot. To th' wars!
line 4129-->  BERTRAM. There's letters from my mother; what th' import is I know
line 4130-->    not yet.
line 4131-->  PAROLLES. Ay, that would be known. To th' wars, my boy, to th'
line 4132-->      wars!
line 4133-->    He wears his honour in a box unseen
line 4134-->    That hugs his kicky-wicky here at home,
line 4135-->    Spending his manly marrow in her arms,
line 4136-->    Which should sustain the bound and high curvet
line 4137-->    Of Mars's fiery steed. To other regions!
line 4138-->    France is a stable; we that dwell in't jades;
line 4139-->    Therefore, to th' war!
line 4140-->  BERTRAM. It shall be so; I'll send her to my house,
line 4141-->    Acquaint my mother with my hate to her,
line 4142-->    And wherefore I am fled; write to the King
line 4143-->    That which I durst not speak. His present gift
line 4144-->    Shall furnish me to those Italian fields  
line 4145-->    Where noble fellows strike. War is no strife
line 4146-->    To the dark house and the detested wife.
line 4147-->  PAROLLES. Will this capriccio hold in thee, art sure?
line 4148-->  BERTRAM. Go with me to my chamber and advise me.
line 4149-->    I'll send her straight away. To-morrow
line 4150-->    I'll to the wars, she to her single sorrow.
line 4151-->  PAROLLES. Why, these balls bound; there's noise in it. 'Tis hard:
line 4152-->    A young man married is a man that's marr'd.
line 4153-->    Therefore away, and leave her bravely; go.
line 4154-->    The King has done you wrong; but, hush, 'tis so.      Exeunt
line 4155-->
line 4156-->
line 4157-->
line 4158-->
line 4159-->ACT II. SCENE 4.
line 4160-->Paris. The KING'S palace
line 4161-->
line 4162-->Enter HELENA and CLOWN
line 4163-->
line 4164-->  HELENA. My mother greets me kindly; is she well?
line 4165-->  CLOWN. She is not well, but yet she has her health; she's very
line 4166-->    merry, but yet she is not well. But thanks be given, she's very
line 4167-->    well, and wants nothing i' th' world; but yet she is not well.
line 4168-->  HELENA. If she be very well, what does she ail that she's not very
line 4169-->    well?
line 4170-->  CLOWN. Truly, she's very well indeed, but for two things.
line 4171-->  HELENA. What two things?
line 4172-->  CLOWN. One, that she's not in heaven, whither God send her quickly!
line 4173-->    The other, that she's in earth, from whence God send her quickly!
line 4174-->
line 4175-->                        Enter PAROLLES
line 4176-->
line 4177-->  PAROLLES. Bless you, my fortunate lady!
line 4178-->  HELENA. I hope, sir, I have your good will to have mine own good
line 4179-->    fortunes.
line 4180-->  PAROLLES. You had my prayers to lead them on; and to keep them on,  
line 4181-->    have them still. O, my knave, how does my old lady?
line 4182-->  CLOWN. So that you had her wrinkles and I her money, I would she
line 4183-->    did as you say.
line 4184-->  PAROLLES. Why, I say nothing.
line 4185-->  CLOWN. Marry, you are the wiser man; for many a man's tongue shakes
line 4186-->    out his master's undoing. To say nothing, to do nothing, to know
line 4187-->    nothing, and to have nothing, is to be a great part of your
line 4188-->    title, which is within a very little of nothing.
line 4189-->  PAROLLES. Away! th'art a knave.
line 4190-->  CLOWN. You should have said, sir, 'Before a knave th'art a knave';
line 4191-->    that's 'Before me th'art a knave.' This had been truth, sir.
line 4192-->  PAROLLES. Go to, thou art a witty fool; I have found thee.
line 4193-->  CLOWN. Did you find me in yourself, sir, or were you taught to find
line 4194-->    me? The search, sir, was profitable; and much fool may you find
line 4195-->    in you, even to the world's pleasure and the increase of
line 4196-->    laughter.
line 4197-->  PAROLLES. A good knave, i' faith, and well fed.
line 4198-->    Madam, my lord will go away to-night:
line 4199-->    A very serious business calls on him.
line 4200-->    The great prerogative and rite of love,  
line 4201-->    Which, as your due, time claims, he does acknowledge;
line 4202-->    But puts it off to a compell'd restraint;
line 4203-->    Whose want, and whose delay, is strew'd with sweets,
line 4204-->    Which they distil now in the curbed time,
line 4205-->    To make the coming hour o'erflow with joy
line 4206-->    And pleasure drown the brim.
line 4207-->  HELENA. What's his else?
line 4208-->  PAROLLES. That you will take your instant leave o' th' King,
line 4209-->    And make this haste as your own good proceeding,
line 4210-->    Strength'ned with what apology you think
line 4211-->    May make it probable need.
line 4212-->  HELENA. What more commands he?
line 4213-->  PAROLLES. That, having this obtain'd, you presently
line 4214-->    Attend his further pleasure.
line 4215-->  HELENA. In everything I wait upon his will.
line 4216-->  PAROLLES. I shall report it so.
line 4217-->  HELENA. I pray you.                              Exit PAROLLES
line 4218-->    Come, sirrah.                                         Exeunt
line 4219-->
line 4220-->
line 4221-->
line 4222-->
line 4223-->ACT II. SCENE 5.
line 4224-->Paris. The KING'S palace
line 4225-->
line 4226-->Enter LAFEU and BERTRAM
line 4227-->
line 4228-->  LAFEU. But I hope your lordship thinks not him a soldier.
line 4229-->  BERTRAM. Yes, my lord, and of very valiant approof.
line 4230-->  LAFEU. You have it from his own deliverance.
line 4231-->  BERTRAM. And by other warranted testimony.
line 4232-->  LAFEU. Then my dial goes not true; I took this lark for a bunting.
line 4233-->  BERTRAM. I do assure you, my lord, he is very great in knowledge,
line 4234-->    and accordingly valiant.
line 4235-->  LAFEU. I have then sinn'd against his experience and transgress'd
line 4236-->    against his valour; and my state that way is dangerous, since I
line 4237-->    cannot yet find in my heart to repent. Here he comes; I pray you
line 4238-->    make us friends; I will pursue the amity
line 4239-->
line 4240-->                         Enter PAROLLES
line 4241-->
line 4242-->  PAROLLES.  [To BERTRAM]  These things shall be done, sir.
line 4243-->  LAFEU. Pray you, sir, who's his tailor?
line 4244-->  PAROLLES. Sir!  
line 4245-->  LAFEU. O, I know him well. Ay, sir; he, sir, 's a good workman, a
line 4246-->    very good tailor.
line 4247-->  BERTRAM.  [Aside to PAROLLES]  Is she gone to the King?
line 4248-->  PAROLLES. She is.
line 4249-->  BERTRAM. Will she away to-night?
line 4250-->  PAROLLES. As you'll have her.
line 4251-->  BERTRAM. I have writ my letters, casketed my treasure,
line 4252-->    Given order for our horses; and to-night,
line 4253-->    When I should take possession of the bride,
line 4254-->    End ere I do begin.
line 4255-->  LAFEU. A good traveller is something at the latter end of a dinner;
line 4256-->    but one that lies three-thirds and uses a known truth to pass a
line 4257-->    thousand nothings with, should be once heard and thrice beaten.
line 4258-->    God save you, Captain.
line 4259-->  BERTRAM. Is there any unkindness between my lord and you, monsieur?
line 4260-->  PAROLLES. I know not how I have deserved to run into my lord's
line 4261-->    displeasure.
line 4262-->  LAFEU. You have made shift to run into 't, boots and spurs and all,
line 4263-->    like him that leapt into the custard; and out of it you'll run
line 4264-->    again, rather than suffer question for your residence.  
line 4265-->  BERTRAM. It may be you have mistaken him, my lord.
line 4266-->  LAFEU. And shall do so ever, though I took him at's prayers.
line 4267-->    Fare you well, my lord; and believe this of me: there can be no
line 4268-->    kernal in this light nut; the soul of this man is his clothes;
line 4269-->    trust him not in matter of heavy consequence; I have kept of them
line 4270-->    tame, and know their natures. Farewell, monsieur; I have spoken
line 4271-->    better of you than you have or will to deserve at my hand; but we
line 4272-->    must do good against evil.                              Exit
line 4273-->  PAROLLES. An idle lord, I swear.
line 4274-->  BERTRAM. I think so.
line 4275-->  PAROLLES. Why, do you not know him?
line 4276-->  BERTRAM. Yes, I do know him well; and common speech
line 4277-->    Gives him a worthy pass. Here comes my clog.
line 4278-->
line 4279-->                          Enter HELENA
line 4280-->
line 4281-->  HELENA. I have, sir, as I was commanded from you,
line 4282-->    Spoke with the King, and have procur'd his leave
line 4283-->    For present parting; only he desires
line 4284-->    Some private speech with you.  
line 4285-->  BERTRAM. I shall obey his will.
line 4286-->    You must not marvel, Helen, at my course,
line 4287-->    Which holds not colour with the time, nor does
line 4288-->    The ministration and required office
line 4289-->    On my particular. Prepar'd I was not
line 4290-->    For such a business; therefore am I found
line 4291-->    So much unsettled. This drives me to entreat you
line 4292-->    That presently you take your way for home,
line 4293-->    And rather muse than ask why I entreat you;
line 4294-->    For my respects are better than they seem,
line 4295-->    And my appointments have in them a need
line 4296-->    Greater than shows itself at the first view
line 4297-->    To you that know them not. This to my mother.
line 4298-->                                               [Giving a letter]
line 4299-->    'Twill be two days ere I shall see you; so
line 4300-->    I leave you to your wisdom.
line 4301-->  HELENA. Sir, I can nothing say
line 4302-->    But that I am your most obedient servant.
line 4303-->  BERTRAM. Come, come, no more of that.
line 4304-->  HELENA. And ever shall  
line 4305-->    With true observance seek to eke out that
line 4306-->    Wherein toward me my homely stars have fail'd
line 4307-->    To equal my great fortune.
line 4308-->  BERTRAM. Let that go.
line 4309-->    My haste is very great. Farewell; hie home.
line 4310-->  HELENA. Pray, sir, your pardon.
line 4311-->  BERTRAM. Well, what would you say?
line 4312-->  HELENA. I am not worthy of the wealth I owe,
line 4313-->    Nor dare I say 'tis mine, and yet it is;
line 4314-->    But, like a timorous thief, most fain would steal
line 4315-->    What law does vouch mine own.
line 4316-->  BERTRAM. What would you have?
line 4317-->  HELENA. Something; and scarce so much; nothing, indeed.
line 4318-->    I would not tell you what I would, my lord.
line 4319-->    Faith, yes:
line 4320-->    Strangers and foes do sunder and not kiss.
line 4321-->  BERTRAM. I pray you, stay not, but in haste to horse.
line 4322-->  HELENA. I shall not break your bidding, good my lord.
line 4323-->  BERTRAM. Where are my other men, monsieur?
line 4324-->    Farewell!                                        Exit HELENA  
line 4325-->    Go thou toward home, where I will never come
line 4326-->    Whilst I can shake my sword or hear the drum.
line 4327-->    Away, and for our flight.
line 4328-->  PAROLLES. Bravely, coragio!                             Exeunt
line 4329-->

line 4342-->
line 4343-->
line 4344-->ACT III. SCENE 1.
line 4345-->Florence. The DUKE's palace
line 4346-->
line 4347-->        Flourish. Enter the DUKE OF FLORENCE, attended; two
line 4348-->               FRENCH LORDS, with a TROOP OF SOLDIERS
line 4349-->
line 4350-->  DUKE. So that, from point to point, now have you hear
line 4351-->    The fundamental reasons of this war;
line 4352-->    Whose great decision hath much blood let forth
line 4353-->    And more thirsts after.
line 4354-->  FIRST LORD. Holy seems the quarrel
line 4355-->    Upon your Grace's part; black and fearful
line 4356-->    On the opposer.
line 4357-->  DUKE. Therefore we marvel much our cousin France
line 4358-->    Would in so just a business shut his bosom
line 4359-->    Against our borrowing prayers.
line 4360-->  SECOND LORD. Good my lord,
line 4361-->    The reasons of our state I cannot yield,
line 4362-->    But like a common and an outward man
line 4363-->    That the great figure of a council frames
line 4364-->    By self-unable motion; therefore dare not
line 4365-->    Say what I think of it, since I have found  
line 4366-->    Myself in my incertain grounds to fail
line 4367-->    As often as I guess'd.
line 4368-->  DUKE. Be it his pleasure.
line 4369-->  FIRST LORD. But I am sure the younger of our nature,
line 4370-->    That surfeit on their ease, will day by day
line 4371-->    Come here for physic.
line 4372-->  DUKE. Welcome shall they be
line 4373-->    And all the honours that can fly from us
line 4374-->    Shall on them settle. You know your places well;
line 4375-->    When better fall, for your avails they fell.
line 4376-->    To-morrow to th' field. Flourish.                     Exeunt
line 4377-->
line 4378-->
line 4379-->
line 4380-->
line 4381-->ACT III. SCENE 2.
line 4382-->Rousillon. The COUNT'S palace
line 4383-->
line 4384-->Enter COUNTESS and CLOWN
line 4385-->
line 4386-->  COUNTESS. It hath happen'd all as I would have had it, save that he
line 4387-->    comes not along with her.
line 4388-->  CLOWN. By my troth, I take my young lord to be a very melancholy
line 4389-->    man.
line 4390-->  COUNTESS. By what observance, I pray you?
line 4391-->  CLOWN. Why, he will look upon his boot and sing; mend the ruff and
line 4392-->    sing; ask questions and sing; pick his teeth and sing. I know a
line 4393-->    man that had this trick of melancholy sold a goodly manor for a
line 4394-->    song.
line 4395-->  COUNTESS. Let me see what he writes, and when he means to come.
line 4396-->                                              [Opening a letter]
line 4397-->  CLOWN. I have no mind to Isbel since I was at court. Our old ling
line 4398-->    and our Isbels o' th' country are nothing like your old ling and
line 4399-->    your Isbels o' th' court. The brains of my Cupid's knock'd out;
line 4400-->    and I begin to love, as an old man loves money, with no stomach.
line 4401-->  COUNTESS. What have we here?
line 4402-->  CLOWN. E'en that you have there.                          Exit  
line 4403-->  COUNTESS.  [Reads]  'I have sent you a daughter-in-law; she hath
line 4404-->    recovered the King and undone me. I have wedded her, not bedded
line 4405-->    her; and sworn to make the "not" eternal. You shall hear I am run
line 4406-->    away; know it before the report come. If there be breadth enough
line 4407-->    in the world, I will hold a long distance. My duty to you.
line 4408-->                                           Your unfortunate son,
line 4409-->                                                       BERTRAM.'
line 4410-->    This is not well, rash and unbridled boy,
line 4411-->    To fly the favours of so good a king,
line 4412-->    To pluck his indignation on thy head
line 4413-->    By the misprizing of a maid too virtuous
line 4414-->    For the contempt of empire.
line 4415-->
line 4416-->                           Re-enter CLOWN
line 4417-->
line 4418-->  CLOWN. O madam, yonder is heavy news within between two soldiers
line 4419-->    and my young lady.
line 4420-->  COUNTESS. What is the -matter?
line 4421-->  CLOWN. Nay, there is some comfort in the news, some comfort; your
line 4422-->    son will not be kill'd so soon as I thought he would.  
line 4423-->  COUNTESS. Why should he be kill'd?
line 4424-->  CLOWN. So say I, madam, if he run away, as I hear he does the
line 4425-->    danger is in standing to 't; that's the loss of men, though it be
line 4426-->    the getting of children. Here they come will tell you more. For my
line 4427-->    part, I only hear your son was run away.                Exit
line 4428-->
line 4429-->              Enter HELENA and the two FRENCH GENTLEMEN
line 4430-->
line 4431-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. Save you, good madam.
line 4432-->  HELENA. Madam, my lord is gone, for ever gone.
line 4433-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. Do not say so.
line 4434-->  COUNTESS. Think upon patience. Pray you, gentlemen-
line 4435-->    I have felt so many quirks of joy and grief
line 4436-->    That the first face of neither, on the start,
line 4437-->    Can woman me unto 't. Where is my son, I pray you?
line 4438-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. Madam, he's gone to serve the Duke of Florence.
line 4439-->    We met him thitherward; for thence we came,
line 4440-->    And, after some dispatch in hand at court,
line 4441-->    Thither we bend again.
line 4442-->  HELENA. Look on this letter, madam; here's my passport.  
line 4443-->    [Reads]  'When thou canst get the ring upon my finger, which
line 4444-->    never shall come off, and show me a child begotten of thy body
line 4445-->    that I am father to, then call me husband; but in such a "then" I
line 4446-->    write a "never."
line 4447-->    This is a dreadful sentence.
line 4448-->  COUNTESS. Brought you this letter, gentlemen?
line 4449-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. Ay, madam;
line 4450-->    And for the contents' sake are sorry for our pains.
line 4451-->  COUNTESS. I prithee, lady, have a better cheer;
line 4452-->    If thou engrossest all the griefs are thine,
line 4453-->    Thou robb'st me of a moiety. He was my son;
line 4454-->    But I do wash his name out of my blood,
line 4455-->    And thou art all my child. Towards Florence is he?
line 4456-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. Ay, madam.
line 4457-->  COUNTESS. And to be a soldier?
line 4458-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. Such is his noble purpose; and, believe 't,
line 4459-->    The Duke will lay upon him all the honour
line 4460-->    That good convenience claims.
line 4461-->  COUNTESS. Return you thither?
line 4462-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. Ay, madam, with the swiftest wing of speed.  
line 4463-->  HELENA.  [Reads]  'Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France.'
line 4464-->    'Tis bitter.
line 4465-->  COUNTESS. Find you that there?
line 4466-->  HELENA. Ay, madam.
line 4467-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. 'Tis but the boldness of his hand haply, which
line 4468-->    his heart was not consenting to.
line 4469-->  COUNTESS. Nothing in France until he have no wife!
line 4470-->    There's nothing here that is too good for him
line 4471-->    But only she; and she deserves a lord
line 4472-->    That twenty such rude boys might tend upon,
line 4473-->    And call her hourly mistress. Who was with him?
line 4474-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. A servant only, and a gentleman
line 4475-->    Which I have sometime known.
line 4476-->  COUNTESS. Parolles, was it not?
line 4477-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. Ay, my good lady, he.
line 4478-->  COUNTESS. A very tainted fellow, and full of wickedness.
line 4479-->    My son corrupts a well-derived nature
line 4480-->    With his inducement.
line 4481-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. Indeed, good lady,
line 4482-->    The fellow has a deal of that too much  
line 4483-->    Which holds him much to have.
line 4484-->  COUNTESS. Y'are welcome, gentlemen.
line 4485-->    I will entreat you, when you see my son,
line 4486-->    To tell him that his sword can never win
line 4487-->    The honour that he loses. More I'll entreat you
line 4488-->    Written to bear along.
line 4489-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. We serve you, madam,
line 4490-->    In that and all your worthiest affairs.
line 4491-->  COUNTESS. Not so, but as we change our courtesies.
line 4492-->    Will you draw near?            Exeunt COUNTESS and GENTLEMEN
line 4493-->  HELENA. 'Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France.'
line 4494-->    Nothing in France until he has no wife!
line 4495-->    Thou shalt have none, Rousillon, none in France
line 4496-->    Then hast thou all again. Poor lord! is't
line 4497-->    That chase thee from thy country, and expose
line 4498-->    Those tender limbs of thine to the event
line 4499-->    Of the non-sparing war? And is it I
line 4500-->    That drive thee from the sportive court, where thou
line 4501-->    Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark
line 4502-->    Of smoky muskets? O you leaden messengers,  
line 4503-->    That ride upon the violent speed of fire,
line 4504-->    Fly with false aim; move the still-piecing air,
line 4505-->    That sings with piercing; do not touch my lord.
line 4506-->    Whoever shoots at him, I set him there;
line 4507-->    Whoever charges on his forward breast,
line 4508-->    I am the caitiff that do hold him to't;
line 4509-->    And though I kill him not, I am the cause
line 4510-->    His death was so effected. Better 'twere
line 4511-->    I met the ravin lion when he roar'd
line 4512-->    With sharp constraint of hunger; better 'twere
line 4513-->    That all the miseries which nature owes
line 4514-->    Were mine at once. No; come thou home, Rousillon,
line 4515-->    Whence honour but of danger wins a scar,
line 4516-->    As oft it loses all. I will be gone.
line 4517-->    My being here it is that holds thee hence.
line 4518-->    Shall I stay here to do 't? No, no, although
line 4519-->    The air of paradise did fan the house,
line 4520-->    And angels offic'd all. I will be gone,
line 4521-->    That pitiful rumour may report my flight
line 4522-->    To consolate thine ear. Come, night; end, day.  
line 4523-->    For with the dark, poor thief, I'll steal away.         Exit
line 4524-->
line 4525-->
line 4526-->
line 4527-->
line 4528-->ACT III. SCENE 3.
line 4529-->Florence. Before the DUKE's palace
line 4530-->
line 4531-->Flourish. Enter the DUKE OF FLORENCE, BERTRAM, PAROLLES, SOLDIERS,
line 4532-->drum and trumpets
line 4533-->
line 4534-->  DUKE. The General of our Horse thou art; and we,
line 4535-->    Great in our hope, lay our best love and credence
line 4536-->    Upon thy promising fortune.
line 4537-->  BERTRAM. Sir, it is
line 4538-->    A charge too heavy for my strength; but yet
line 4539-->    We'll strive to bear it for your worthy sake
line 4540-->    To th' extreme edge of hazard.
line 4541-->  DUKE. Then go thou forth;
line 4542-->    And Fortune play upon thy prosperous helm,
line 4543-->    As thy auspicious mistress!
line 4544-->  BERTRAM. This very day,
line 4545-->    Great Mars, I put myself into thy file;
line 4546-->    Make me but like my thoughts, and I shall prove
line 4547-->    A lover of thy drum, hater of love.                   Exeunt
line 4548-->
line 4549-->
line 4550-->
line 4551-->
line 4552-->ACT III. SCENE 4.
line 4553-->Rousillon. The COUNT'S palace
line 4554-->
line 4555-->Enter COUNTESS and STEWARD
line 4556-->
line 4557-->  COUNTESS. Alas! and would you take the letter of her?
line 4558-->    Might you not know she would do as she has done
line 4559-->    By sending me a letter? Read it again.
line 4560-->  STEWARD.  [Reads]  'I am Saint Jaques' pilgrim, thither gone.
line 4561-->    Ambitious love hath so in me offended
line 4562-->    That barefoot plod I the cold ground upon,
line 4563-->    With sainted vow my faults to have amended.
line 4564-->    Write, write, that from the bloody course of war
line 4565-->    My dearest master, your dear son, may hie.
line 4566-->    Bless him at home in peace, whilst I from far
line 4567-->    His name with zealous fervour sanctify.
line 4568-->    His taken labours bid him me forgive;
line 4569-->    I, his despiteful Juno, sent him forth
line 4570-->    From courtly friends, with camping foes to live,
line 4571-->    Where death and danger dogs the heels of worth.
line 4572-->    He is too good and fair for death and me;
line 4573-->    Whom I myself embrace to set him free.'  
line 4574-->  COUNTESS. Ah, what sharp stings are in her mildest words!
line 4575-->    Rinaldo, you did never lack advice so much
line 4576-->    As letting her pass so; had I spoke with her,
line 4577-->    I could have well diverted her intents,
line 4578-->    Which thus she hath prevented.
line 4579-->  STEWARD. Pardon me, madam;
line 4580-->    If I had given you this at over-night,
line 4581-->    She might have been o'er ta'en; and yet she writes
line 4582-->    Pursuit would be but vain.
line 4583-->  COUNTESS. What angel shall
line 4584-->    Bless this unworthy husband? He cannot thrive,
line 4585-->    Unless her prayers, whom heaven delights to hear
line 4586-->    And loves to grant, reprieve him from the wrath
line 4587-->    Of greatest justice. Write, write, Rinaldo,
line 4588-->    To this unworthy husband of his wife;
line 4589-->    Let every word weigh heavy of her worth
line 4590-->    That he does weigh too light. My greatest grief,
line 4591-->    Though little he do feel it, set down sharply.
line 4592-->    Dispatch the most convenient messenger.
line 4593-->    When haply he shall hear that she is gone  
line 4594-->    He will return; and hope I may that she,
line 4595-->    Hearing so much, will speed her foot again,
line 4596-->    Led hither by pure love. Which of them both
line 4597-->    Is dearest to me I have no skill in sense
line 4598-->    To make distinction. Provide this messenger.
line 4599-->    My heart is heavy, and mine age is weak;
line 4600-->    Grief would have tears, and sorrow bids me speak.     Exeunt
line 4601-->
line 4602-->
line 4603-->
line 4604-->
line 4605-->ACT III. SCENE 5.
line 4606-->
line 4607-->Without the walls of Florence
line 4608-->A tucket afar off. Enter an old WIDOW OF FLORENCE, her daughter DIANA,
line 4609-->VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other CITIZENS
line 4610-->
line 4611-->  WIDOW. Nay, come; for if they do approach the city we shall lose
line 4612-->    all the sight.
line 4613-->  DIANA. They say the French count has done most honourable service.
line 4614-->  WIDOW. It is reported that he has taken their great'st commander;
line 4615-->    and that with his own hand he slew the Duke's brother.  [Tucket]
line 4616-->    We have lost our labour; they are gone a contrary way. Hark! you
line 4617-->    may know by their trumpets.
line 4618-->  MARIANA. Come, let's return again, and suffice ourselves with the
line 4619-->    report of it. Well, Diana, take heed of this French earl; the
line 4620-->    honour of a maid is her name, and no legacy is so rich as
line 4621-->    honesty.
line 4622-->  WIDOW. I have told my neighbour how you have been solicited by a
line 4623-->    gentleman his companion.
line 4624-->  MARIANA. I know that knave, hang him! one Parolles; a filthy
line 4625-->    officer he is in those suggestions for the young earl. Beware of  
line 4626-->    them, Diana: their promises, enticements, oaths, tokens, and all
line 4627-->    these engines of lust, are not the things they go under; many a
line 4628-->    maid hath been seduced by them; and the misery is, example, that
line 4629-->    so terrible shows in the wreck of maidenhood, cannot for all that
line 4630-->    dissuade succession, but that they are limed with the twigs that
line 4631-->    threatens them. I hope I need not to advise you further; but I
line 4632-->    hope your own grace will keep you where you are, though there
line 4633-->    were no further danger known but the modesty which is so lost.
line 4634-->  DIANA. You shall not need to fear me.
line 4635-->
line 4636-->            Enter HELENA in the dress of a pilgrim
line 4637-->
line 4638-->  WIDOW. I hope so. Look, here comes a pilgrim. I know she will lie
line 4639-->    at my house: thither they send one another. I'll question her.
line 4640-->    God save you, pilgrim! Whither are bound?
line 4641-->  HELENA. To Saint Jaques le Grand.
line 4642-->    Where do the palmers lodge, I do beseech you?
line 4643-->  WIDOW. At the Saint Francis here, beside the port.
line 4644-->  HELENA. Is this the way?
line 4645-->                                                  [A march afar]  
line 4646-->  WIDOW. Ay, marry, is't. Hark you! They come this way.
line 4647-->    If you will tarry, holy pilgrim,
line 4648-->    But till the troops come by,
line 4649-->    I will conduct you where you shall be lodg'd;
line 4650-->    The rather for I think I know your hostess
line 4651-->    As ample as myself.
line 4652-->  HELENA. Is it yourself?
line 4653-->  WIDOW. If you shall please so, pilgrim.
line 4654-->  HELENA. I thank you, and will stay upon your leisure.
line 4655-->  WIDOW. You came, I think, from France?
line 4656-->  HELENA. I did so.
line 4657-->  WIDOW. Here you shall see a countryman of yours
line 4658-->    That has done worthy service.
line 4659-->  HELENA. His name, I pray you.
line 4660-->  DIANA. The Count Rousillon. Know you such a one?
line 4661-->  HELENA. But by the ear, that hears most nobly of him;
line 4662-->    His face I know not.
line 4663-->  DIANA. What some'er he is,
line 4664-->    He's bravely taken here. He stole from France,
line 4665-->    As 'tis reported, for the King had married him  
line 4666-->    Against his liking. Think you it is so?
line 4667-->  HELENA. Ay, surely, mere the truth; I know his lady.
line 4668-->  DIANA. There is a gentleman that serves the Count
line 4669-->    Reports but coarsely of her.
line 4670-->  HELENA. What's his name?
line 4671-->  DIANA. Monsieur Parolles.
line 4672-->  HELENA. O, I believe with him,
line 4673-->    In argument of praise, or to the worth
line 4674-->    Of the great Count himself, she is too mean
line 4675-->    To have her name repeated; all her deserving
line 4676-->    Is a reserved honesty, and that
line 4677-->    I have not heard examin'd.
line 4678-->  DIANA. Alas, poor lady!
line 4679-->    'Tis a hard bondage to become the wife
line 4680-->    Of a detesting lord.
line 4681-->  WIDOW. I sweet, good creature, wheresoe'er she is
line 4682-->    Her heart weighs sadly. This young maid might do her
line 4683-->    A shrewd turn, if she pleas'd.
line 4684-->  HELENA. How do you mean?
line 4685-->    May be the amorous Count solicits her  
line 4686-->    In the unlawful purpose.
line 4687-->  WIDOW. He does, indeed;
line 4688-->    And brokes with all that can in such a suit
line 4689-->    Corrupt the tender honour of a maid;
line 4690-->    But she is arm'd for him, and keeps her guard
line 4691-->    In honestest defence.
line 4692-->
line 4693-->    Enter, with drum and colours, BERTRAM, PAROLLES, and the
line 4694-->                          whole ARMY
line 4695-->
line 4696-->  MARIANA. The gods forbid else!
line 4697-->  WIDOW. So, now they come.
line 4698-->    That is Antonio, the Duke's eldest son;
line 4699-->    That, Escalus.
line 4700-->  HELENA. Which is the Frenchman?
line 4701-->  DIANA. He-
line 4702-->    That with the plume; 'tis a most gallant fellow.
line 4703-->    I would he lov'd his wife; if he were honester
line 4704-->    He were much goodlier. Is't not a handsome gentleman?
line 4705-->  HELENA. I like him well.  
line 4706-->  DIANA. 'Tis pity he is not honest. Yond's that same knave
line 4707-->    That leads him to these places; were I his lady
line 4708-->    I would poison that vile rascal.
line 4709-->  HELENA. Which is he?
line 4710-->  DIANA. That jack-an-apes with scarfs. Why is he melancholy?
line 4711-->  HELENA. Perchance he's hurt i' th' battle.
line 4712-->  PAROLLES. Lose our drum! well.
line 4713-->  MARIANA. He's shrewdly vex'd at something.
line 4714-->    Look, he has spied us.
line 4715-->  WIDOW. Marry, hang you!
line 4716-->  MARIANA. And your courtesy, for a ring-carrier!
line 4717-->                              Exeunt BERTRAM, PAROLLES, and ARMY
line 4718-->  WIDOW. The troop is past. Come, pilgrim, I will bring you
line 4719-->    Where you shall host. Of enjoin'd penitents
line 4720-->    There's four or five, to great Saint Jaques bound,
line 4721-->    Already at my house.
line 4722-->  HELENA. I humbly thank you.
line 4723-->    Please it this matron and this gentle maid
line 4724-->    To eat with us to-night; the charge and thanking
line 4725-->    Shall be for me, and, to requite you further,  
line 4726-->    I will bestow some precepts of this virgin,
line 4727-->    Worthy the note.
line 4728-->    BOTH. We'll take your offer kindly.                   Exeunt
line 4729-->
line 4730-->
line 4731-->
line 4732-->
line 4733-->ACT III. SCENE 6.
line 4734-->Camp before Florence
line 4735-->
line 4736-->Enter BERTRAM, and the two FRENCH LORDS
line 4737-->
line 4738-->  SECOND LORD. Nay, good my lord, put him to't; let him have his way.
line 4739-->  FIRST LORD. If your lordship find him not a hiding, hold me no more
line 4740-->    in your respect.
line 4741-->  SECOND LORD. On my life, my lord, a bubble.
line 4742-->  BERTRAM. Do you think I am so far deceived in him?
line 4743-->  SECOND LORD. Believe it, my lord, in mine own direct knowledge,
line 4744-->    without any malice, but to speak of him as my kinsman, he's a
line 4745-->    most notable coward, an infinite and endless liar, an hourly
line 4746-->    promise-breaker, the owner of no one good quality worthy your
line 4747-->    lordship's entertainment.
line 4748-->  FIRST LORD. It were fit you knew him; lest, reposing too far in his
line 4749-->    virtue, which he hath not, he might at some great and trusty
line 4750-->    business in a main danger fail you.
line 4751-->  BERTRAM. I would I knew in what particular action to try him.
line 4752-->  FIRST LORD. None better than to let him fetch off his drum, which
line 4753-->    you hear him so confidently undertake to do.
line 4754-->  SECOND LORD. I with a troop of Florentines will suddenly surprise  
line 4755-->    him; such I will have whom I am sure he knows not from the enemy.
line 4756-->    We will bind and hoodwink him so that he shall suppose no other
line 4757-->    but that he is carried into the leaguer of the adversaries when
line 4758-->    we bring him to our own tents. Be but your lordship present at
line 4759-->    his examination; if he do not, for the promise of his life and in
line 4760-->    the highest compulsion of base fear, offer to betray you and
line 4761-->    deliver all the intelligence in his power against you, and that
line 4762-->    with the divine forfeit of his soul upon oath, never trust my
line 4763-->    judgment in anything.
line 4764-->  FIRST LORD. O, for the love of laughter, let him fetch his drum; he
line 4765-->    says he has a stratagem for't. When your lordship sees the bottom
line 4766-->    of his success in't, and to what metal this counterfeit lump of
line 4767-->    ore will be melted, if you give him not John Drum's
line 4768-->    entertainment, your inclining cannot be removed. Here he comes.
line 4769-->
line 4770-->                      Enter PAROLLES
line 4771-->
line 4772-->  SECOND LORD. O, for the love of laughter, hinder not the honour of
line 4773-->    his design; let him fetch off his drum in any hand.
line 4774-->  BERTRAM. How now, monsieur! This drum sticks sorely in your  
line 4775-->    disposition.
line 4776-->  FIRST LORD. A pox on 't; let it go; 'tis but a drum.
line 4777-->  PAROLLES. But a drum! Is't but a drum? A drum so lost! There was
line 4778-->    excellent command: to charge in with our horse upon our own
line 4779-->    wings, and to rend our own soldiers!
line 4780-->  FIRST LORD. That was not to be blam'd in the command of the
line 4781-->    service; it was a disaster of war that Caesar himself could not
line 4782-->    have prevented, if he had been there to command.
line 4783-->  BERTRAM. Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success.
line 4784-->    Some dishonour we had in the loss of that drum; but it is not to
line 4785-->    be recovered.
line 4786-->  PAROLLES. It might have been recovered.
line 4787-->  BERTRAM. It might, but it is not now.
line 4788-->  PAROLLES. It is to be recovered. But that the merit of service is
line 4789-->    seldom attributed to the true and exact performer, I would have
line 4790-->    that drum or another, or 'hic jacet.'
line 4791-->  BERTRAM. Why, if you have a stomach, to't, monsieur. If you think
line 4792-->    your mystery in stratagem can bring this instrument of honour
line 4793-->    again into his native quarter, be magnanimous in the enterprise,
line 4794-->    and go on; I will grace the attempt for a worthy exploit. If you  
line 4795-->    speed well in it, the Duke shall both speak of it and extend to
line 4796-->    you what further becomes his greatness, even to the utmost
line 4797-->    syllable of our worthiness.
line 4798-->  PAROLLES. By the hand of a soldier, I will undertake it.
line 4799-->  BERTRAM. But you must not now slumber in it.
line 4800-->  PAROLLES. I'll about it this evening; and I will presently pen
line 4801-->    down my dilemmas, encourage myself in my certainty, put myself
line 4802-->    into my mortal preparation; and by midnight look to hear further
line 4803-->    from me.
line 4804-->  BERTRAM. May I be bold to acquaint his Grace you are gone about it?
line 4805-->  PAROLLES. I know not what the success will be, my lord, but the
line 4806-->    attempt I vow.
line 4807-->  BERTRAM. I know th' art valiant; and, to the of thy soldiership,
line 4808-->    will subscribe for thee. Farewell.
line 4809-->  PAROLLES. I love not many words.                          Exit
line 4810-->  SECOND LORD. No more than a fish loves water. Is not this a strange
line 4811-->    fellow, my lord, that so confidently seems to undertake this
line 4812-->    business, which he knows is not to be done; damns himself to do,
line 4813-->    and dares better be damn'd than to do 't.
line 4814-->  FIRST LORD. You do not know him, my lord, as we do. Certain it is  
line 4815-->    that he will steal himself into a man's favour, and for a week
line 4816-->    escape a great deal of discoveries; but when you find him out,
line 4817-->    you have him ever after.
line 4818-->  BERTRAM. Why, do you think he will make no deed at all of this that
line 4819-->    so seriously he does address himself unto?
line 4820-->  SECOND LORD. None in the world; but return with an invention, and
line 4821-->    clap upon you two or three probable lies. But we have almost
line 4822-->    emboss'd him. You shall see his fall to-night; for indeed he is
line 4823-->    not for your lordship's respect.
line 4824-->  FIRST LORD. We'll make you some sport with the fox ere we case him.
line 4825-->    He was first smok'd by the old Lord Lafeu. When his disguise and
line 4826-->    he is parted, tell me what a sprat you shall find him; which you
line 4827-->    shall see this very night.
line 4828-->  SECOND LORD. I must go look my twigs; he shall be caught.
line 4829-->  BERTRAM. Your brother, he shall go along with me.
line 4830-->  SECOND LORD. As't please your lordship. I'll leave you.   Exit
line 4831-->  BERTRAM. Now will I lead you to the house, and show you
line 4832-->    The lass I spoke of.
line 4833-->  FIRST LORD. But you say she's honest.
line 4834-->  BERTRAM. That's all the fault. I spoke with her but once,  
line 4835-->    And found her wondrous cold; but I sent to her,
line 4836-->    By this same coxcomb that we have i' th' wind,
line 4837-->    Tokens and letters which she did re-send;
line 4838-->    And this is all I have done. She's a fair creature;
line 4839-->    Will you go see her?
line 4840-->  FIRST LORD. With all my heart, my lord.                 Exeunt
line 4841-->
line 4842-->
line 4843-->
line 4844-->
line 4845-->ACT III. SCENE 7.
line 4846-->Florence. The WIDOW'S house
line 4847-->
line 4848-->Enter HELENA and WIDOW
line 4849-->
line 4850-->  HELENA. If you misdoubt me that I am not she,
line 4851-->    I know not how I shall assure you further
line 4852-->    But I shall lose the grounds I work upon.
line 4853-->  WIDOW. Though my estate be fall'n, I was well born,
line 4854-->    Nothing acquainted with these businesses;
line 4855-->    And would not put my reputation now
line 4856-->    In any staining act.
line 4857-->  HELENA. Nor would I wish you.
line 4858-->  FIRST give me trust the Count he is my husband,
line 4859-->    And what to your sworn counsel I have spoken
line 4860-->    Is so from word to word; and then you cannot,
line 4861-->    By the good aid that I of you shall borrow,
line 4862-->    Err in bestowing it.
line 4863-->  WIDOW. I should believe you;
line 4864-->    For you have show'd me that which well approves
line 4865-->    Y'are great in fortune.
line 4866-->  HELENA. Take this purse of gold,  
line 4867-->    And let me buy your friendly help thus far,
line 4868-->    Which I will over-pay and pay again
line 4869-->    When I have found it. The Count he woos your daughter
line 4870-->    Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty,
line 4871-->    Resolv'd to carry her. Let her in fine consent,
line 4872-->    As we'll direct her how 'tis best to bear it.
line 4873-->    Now his important blood will nought deny
line 4874-->    That she'll demand. A ring the County wears
line 4875-->    That downward hath succeeded in his house
line 4876-->    From son to son some four or five descents
line 4877-->    Since the first father wore it. This ring he holds
line 4878-->    In most rich choice; yet, in his idle fire,
line 4879-->    To buy his will, it would not seem too dear,
line 4880-->    Howe'er repented after.
line 4881-->  WIDOW. Now I see
line 4882-->    The bottom of your purpose.
line 4883-->  HELENA. You see it lawful then. It is no more
line 4884-->    But that your daughter, ere she seems as won,
line 4885-->    Desires this ring; appoints him an encounter;
line 4886-->    In fine, delivers me to fill the time,  
line 4887-->    Herself most chastely absent. After this,
line 4888-->    To marry her, I'll add three thousand crowns
line 4889-->    To what is pass'd already.
line 4890-->  WIDOW. I have yielded.
line 4891-->    Instruct my daughter how she shall persever,
line 4892-->    That time and place with this deceit so lawful
line 4893-->    May prove coherent. Every night he comes
line 4894-->    With musics of all sorts, and songs compos'd
line 4895-->    To her unworthiness. It nothing steads us
line 4896-->    To chide him from our eaves, for he persists
line 4897-->    As if his life lay on 't.
line 4898-->  HELENA. Why then to-night
line 4899-->    Let us assay our plot; which, if it speed,
line 4900-->    Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed,
line 4901-->    And lawful meaning in a lawful act;
line 4902-->    Where both not sin, and yet a sinful fact.
line 4903-->    But let's about it.                                   Exeunt
line 4904-->
