line 4918-->
line 4919-->ACT IV. SCENE 1.
line 4920-->Without the Florentine camp
line 4921-->
line 4922-->Enter SECOND FRENCH LORD with five or six other SOLDIERS in ambush
line 4923-->
line 4924-->  SECOND LORD. He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner.
line 4925-->    When you sally upon him, speak what terrible language you will;
line 4926-->    though you understand it not yourselves, no matter; for we must
line 4927-->    not seem to understand him, unless some one among us, whom we
line 4928-->    must produce for an interpreter.
line 4929-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Good captain, let me be th' interpreter.
line 4930-->  SECOND LORD. Art not acquainted with him? Knows he not thy voice?
line 4931-->  FIRST SOLDIER. No, sir, I warrant you.
line 4932-->  SECOND LORD. But what linsey-woolsey has thou to speak to us again?
line 4933-->  FIRST SOLDIER. E'en such as you speak to me.
line 4934-->  SECOND LORD. He must think us some band of strangers i' th'
line 4935-->    adversary's entertainment. Now he hath a smack of all
line 4936-->    neighbouring languages, therefore we must every one be a man of
line 4937-->    his own fancy; not to know what we speak one to another, so we
line 4938-->    seem to know, is to know straight our purpose: choughs' language,
line 4939-->    gabble enough, and good enough. As for you, interpreter, you must  
line 4940-->    seem very politic. But couch, ho! here he comes; to beguile two
line 4941-->    hours in a sleep, and then to return and swear the lies he forges.
line 4942-->
line 4943-->                         Enter PAROLLES
line 4944-->
line 4945-->  PAROLLES. Ten o'clock. Within these three hours 'twill be time
line 4946-->    enough to go home. What shall I say I have done? It must be a
line 4947-->    very plausive invention that carries it. They begin to smoke me;
line 4948-->    and disgraces have of late knock'd to often at my door. I find my
line 4949-->    tongue is too foolhardy; but my heart hath the fear of Mars
line 4950-->    before it, and of his creatures, not daring the reports of my
line 4951-->    tongue.
line 4952-->  SECOND LORD. This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue was
line 4953-->    guilty of.
line 4954-->  PAROLLES. What the devil should move me to undertake the recovery
line 4955-->    of this drum, being not ignorant of the impossibility, and
line 4956-->    knowing I had no such purpose? I must give myself some hurts, and
line 4957-->    say I got them in exploit. Yet slight ones will not carry it.
line 4958-->    They will say 'Came you off with so little?' And great ones I
line 4959-->    dare not give. Wherefore, what's the instance? Tongue, I must put  
line 4960-->    you into a butterwoman's mouth, and buy myself another of
line 4961-->    Bajazet's mule, if you prattle me into these perils.
line 4962-->  SECOND LORD. Is it possible he should know what he is, and be that
line 4963-->    he is?
line 4964-->  PAROLLES. I would the cutting of my garments would serve the turn,
line 4965-->    or the breaking of my Spanish sword.
line 4966-->  SECOND LORD. We cannot afford you so.
line 4967-->  PAROLLES. Or the baring of my beard; and to say it was in
line 4968-->    stratagem.
line 4969-->  SECOND LORD. 'Twould not do.
line 4970-->  PAROLLES. Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripp'd.
line 4971-->  SECOND LORD. Hardly serve.
line 4972-->  PAROLLES. Though I swore I leap'd from the window of the citadel-
line 4973-->  SECOND LORD. How deep?
line 4974-->  PAROLLES. Thirty fathom.
line 4975-->  SECOND LORD. Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed.
line 4976-->  PAROLLES. I would I had any drum of the enemy's; I would swear I
line 4977-->    recover'd it.
line 4978-->  SECOND LORD. You shall hear one anon.          [Alarum within]
line 4979-->  PAROLLES. A drum now of the enemy's!  
line 4980-->  SECOND LORD. Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.
line 4981-->  ALL. Cargo, cargo, cargo, villianda par corbo, cargo.
line 4982-->  PAROLLES. O, ransom, ransom! Do not hide mine eyes.
line 4983-->                                            [They blindfold him]
line 4984-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Boskos thromuldo boskos.
line 4985-->  PAROLLES. I know you are the Muskos' regiment,
line 4986-->    And I shall lose my life for want of language.
line 4987-->    If there be here German, or Dane, Low Dutch,
line 4988-->    Italian, or French, let him speak to me;
line 4989-->    I'll discover that which shall undo the Florentine.
line 4990-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Boskos vauvado. I understand thee, and can speak thy
line 4991-->    tongue. Kerely-bonto, sir, betake thee to thy faith, for
line 4992-->    seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.
line 4993-->  PAROLLES. O!
line 4994-->  FIRST SOLDIER. O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.
line 4995-->  SECOND LORD. Oscorbidulchos volivorco.
line 4996-->  FIRST SOLDIER. The General is content to spare thee yet;
line 4997-->    And, hoodwink'd as thou art, will lead thee on
line 4998-->    To gather from thee. Haply thou mayst inform
line 4999-->    Something to save thy life.  
line 5000-->  PAROLLES. O, let me live,
line 5001-->    And all the secrets of our camp I'll show,
line 5002-->    Their force, their purposes. Nay, I'll speak that
line 5003-->    Which you will wonder at.
line 5004-->  FIRST SOLDIER. But wilt thou faithfully?
line 5005-->  PAROLLES. If I do not, damn me.
line 5006-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Acordo linta.
line 5007-->    Come on; thou art granted space.
line 5008-->                   Exit, PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within
line 5009-->  SECOND LORD. Go, tell the Count Rousillon and my brother
line 5010-->    We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled
line 5011-->    Till we do hear from them.
line 5012-->  SECOND SOLDIER. Captain, I will.
line 5013-->  SECOND LORD. 'A will betray us all unto ourselves-
line 5014-->    Inform on that.
line 5015-->  SECOND SOLDIER. So I will, sir.
line 5016-->  SECOND LORD. Till then I'll keep him dark and safely lock'd.
line 5017-->                                                          Exeunt
line 5018-->
line 5019-->
line 5020-->
line 5021-->
line 5022-->ACT IV. SCENE 2.
line 5023-->Florence. The WIDOW'S house
line 5024-->
line 5025-->Enter BERTRAM and DIANA
line 5026-->
line 5027-->  BERTRAM. They told me that your name was Fontibell.
line 5028-->  DIANA. No, my good lord, Diana.
line 5029-->  BERTRAM. Titled goddess;
line 5030-->    And worth it, with addition! But, fair soul,
line 5031-->    In your fine frame hath love no quality?
line 5032-->    If the quick fire of youth light not your mind,
line 5033-->    You are no maiden, but a monument;
line 5034-->    When you are dead, you should be such a one
line 5035-->    As you are now, for you are cold and stern;
line 5036-->    And now you should be as your mother was
line 5037-->    When your sweet self was got.
line 5038-->  DIANA. She then was honest.
line 5039-->  BERTRAM. So should you be.
line 5040-->  DIANA. No.
line 5041-->    My mother did but duty; such, my lord,
line 5042-->    As you owe to your wife.
line 5043-->  BERTRAM. No more o'that!  
line 5044-->    I prithee do not strive against my vows.
line 5045-->    I was compell'd to her; but I love the
line 5046-->    By love's own sweet constraint, and will for ever
line 5047-->    Do thee all rights of service.
line 5048-->  DIANA. Ay, so you serve us
line 5049-->    Till we serve you; but when you have our roses
line 5050-->    You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves,
line 5051-->    And mock us with our bareness.
line 5052-->  BERTRAM. How have I sworn!
line 5053-->  DIANA. 'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth,
line 5054-->    But the plain single vow that is vow'd true.
line 5055-->    What is not holy, that we swear not by,
line 5056-->    But take the High'st to witness. Then, pray you, tell me:
line 5057-->    If I should swear by Jove's great attributes
line 5058-->    I lov'd you dearly, would you believe my oaths
line 5059-->    When I did love you ill? This has no holding,
line 5060-->    To swear by him whom I protest to love
line 5061-->    That I will work against him. Therefore your oaths
line 5062-->    Are words and poor conditions, but unseal'd-
line 5063-->    At least in my opinion.  
line 5064-->  BERTRAM. Change it, change it;
line 5065-->    Be not so holy-cruel. Love is holy;
line 5066-->    And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts
line 5067-->    That you do charge men with. Stand no more off,
line 5068-->    But give thyself unto my sick desires,
line 5069-->    Who then recovers. Say thou art mine, and ever
line 5070-->    My love as it begins shall so persever.
line 5071-->  DIANA. I see that men make ropes in such a scarre
line 5072-->    That we'll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.
line 5073-->  BERTRAM. I'll lend it thee, my dear, but have no power
line 5074-->    To give it from me.
line 5075-->  DIANA. Will you not, my lord?
line 5076-->  BERTRAM. It is an honour 'longing to our house,
line 5077-->    Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
line 5078-->    Which were the greatest obloquy i' th' world
line 5079-->    In me to lose.
line 5080-->  DIANA. Mine honour's such a ring:
line 5081-->    My chastity's the jewel of our house,
line 5082-->    Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
line 5083-->    Which were the greatest obloquy i' th' world  
line 5084-->    In me to lose. Thus your own proper wisdom
line 5085-->    Brings in the champion Honour on my part
line 5086-->    Against your vain assault.
line 5087-->  BERTRAM. Here, take my ring;
line 5088-->    My house, mine honour, yea, my life, be thine,
line 5089-->    And I'll be bid by thee.
line 5090-->  DIANA. When midnight comes, knock at my chamber window;
line 5091-->    I'll order take my mother shall not hear.
line 5092-->    Now will I charge you in the band of truth,
line 5093-->    When you have conquer'd my yet maiden bed,
line 5094-->    Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me:
line 5095-->    My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them
line 5096-->    When back again this ring shall be deliver'd.
line 5097-->    And on your finger in the night I'll put
line 5098-->    Another ring, that what in time proceeds
line 5099-->    May token to the future our past deeds.
line 5100-->    Adieu till then; then fail not. You have won
line 5101-->    A wife of me, though there my hope be done.
line 5102-->  BERTRAM. A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.
line 5103--> Exit  
line 5104-->  DIANA. For which live long to thank both heaven and me!
line 5105-->    You may so in the end.
line 5106-->    My mother told me just how he would woo,
line 5107-->    As if she sat in's heart; she says all men
line 5108-->    Have the like oaths. He had sworn to marry me
line 5109-->    When his wife's dead; therefore I'll lie with him
line 5110-->    When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid,
line 5111-->    Marry that will, I live and die a maid.
line 5112-->    Only, in this disguise, I think't no sin
line 5113-->    To cozen him that would unjustly win.                   Exit
line 5114-->
line 5115-->
line 5116-->
line 5117-->
line 5118-->ACT IV. SCENE 3.
line 5119-->The Florentine camp
line 5120-->
line 5121-->Enter the two FRENCH LORDS, and two or three SOLDIERS
line 5122-->
line 5123-->  SECOND LORD. You have not given him his mother's letter?
line 5124-->  FIRST LORD. I have deliv'red it an hour since. There is something
line 5125-->    in't that stings his nature; for on the reading it he chang'd
line 5126-->    almost into another man.
line 5127-->  SECOND LORD. He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking off
line 5128-->    so good a wife and so sweet a lady.
line 5129-->  FIRST LORD. Especially he hath incurred the everlasting displeasure
line 5130-->    of the King, who had even tun'd his bounty to sing happiness to
line 5131-->    him. I will tell you a thing, but you shall let it dwell darkly
line 5132-->    with you.
line 5133-->  SECOND LORD. When you have spoken it, 'tis dead, and I am the grave
line 5134-->    of it.
line 5135-->  FIRST LORD. He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in Florence,
line 5136-->    of a most chaste renown; and this night he fleshes his will in
line 5137-->    the spoil of her honour. He hath given her his monumental ring,
line 5138-->    and thinks himself made in the unchaste composition.
line 5139-->  SECOND LORD. Now, God delay our rebellion! As we are ourselves,  
line 5140-->    what things are we!
line 5141-->  FIRST LORD. Merely our own traitors. And as in the common course of
line 5142-->    all treasons we still see them reveal themselves till they attain
line 5143-->    to their abhorr'd ends; so he that in this action contrives
line 5144-->    against his own nobility, in his proper stream, o'erflows
line 5145-->    himself.
line 5146-->  SECOND LORD. Is it not meant damnable in us to be trumpeters of our
line 5147-->    unlawful intents? We shall not then have his company to-night?
line 5148-->  FIRST LORD. Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.
line 5149-->  SECOND LORD. That approaches apace. I would gladly have him see his
line 5150-->    company anatomiz'd, that he might take a measure of his own
line 5151-->    judgments, wherein so curiously he had set this counterfeit.
line 5152-->  FIRST LORD. We will not meddle with him till he come; for his
line 5153-->    presence must be the whip of the other.
line 5154-->  SECOND LORD. In the meantime, what hear you of these wars?
line 5155-->  FIRST LORD. I hear there is an overture of peace.
line 5156-->  SECOND LORD. Nay, I assure you, a peace concluded.
line 5157-->  FIRST LORD. What will Count Rousillon do then? Will he travel
line 5158-->    higher, or return again into France?
line 5159-->  SECOND LORD. I perceive, by this demand, you are not altogether  
line 5160-->    of his counsel.
line 5161-->  FIRST LORD. Let it be forbid, sir! So should I be a great deal
line 5162-->    of his act.
line 5163-->  SECOND LORD. Sir, his wife, some two months since, fled from his
line 5164-->    house. Her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques le Grand;
line 5165-->    which holy undertaking with most austere sanctimony she
line 5166-->    accomplish'd; and, there residing, the tenderness of her nature
line 5167-->    became as a prey to her grief; in fine, made a groan of her last
line 5168-->    breath, and now she sings in heaven.
line 5169-->  FIRST LORD. How is this justified?
line 5170-->  SECOND LORD. The stronger part of it by her own letters, which
line 5171-->    makes her story true even to the point of her death. Her death
line 5172-->    itself, which could not be her office to say is come, was
line 5173-->    faithfully confirm'd by the rector of the place.
line 5174-->  FIRST LORD. Hath the Count all this intelligence?
line 5175-->  SECOND LORD. Ay, and the particular confirmations, point from
line 5176-->    point, to the full arming of the verity.
line 5177-->  FIRST LORD. I am heartily sorry that he'll be glad of this.
line 5178-->  SECOND LORD. How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our
line 5179-->    losses!  
line 5180-->  FIRST LORD. And how mightily some other times we drown our gain in
line 5181-->    tears! The great dignity that his valour hath here acquir'd for
line 5182-->    him shall at home be encount'red with a shame as ample.
line 5183-->  SECOND LORD. The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and ill
line 5184-->    together. Our virtues would be proud if our faults whipt them
line 5185-->    not; and our crimes would despair if they were not cherish'd by
line 5186-->    our virtues.
line 5187-->
line 5188-->                      Enter a MESSENGER
line 5189-->
line 5190-->    How now? Where's your master?
line 5191-->  SERVANT. He met the Duke in the street, sir; of whom he hath taken
line 5192-->    a solemn leave. His lordship will next morning for France. The
line 5193-->    Duke hath offered him letters of commendations to the King.
line 5194-->  SECOND LORD. They shall be no more than needful there, if they were
line 5195-->    more than they can commend.
line 5196-->  FIRST LORD. They cannot be too sweet for the King's tartness.
line 5197-->    Here's his lordship now.
line 5198-->
line 5199-->                        Enter BERTRAM  
line 5200-->
line 5201-->    How now, my lord, is't not after midnight?
line 5202-->  BERTRAM. I have to-night dispatch'd sixteen businesses, a month's
line 5203-->    length apiece; by an abstract of success: I have congied with the
line 5204-->    Duke, done my adieu with his nearest; buried a wife, mourn'd for
line 5205-->    her; writ to my lady mother I am returning; entertain'd my
line 5206-->    convoy; and between these main parcels of dispatch effected many
line 5207-->    nicer needs. The last was the greatest, but that I have not ended
line 5208-->    yet.
line 5209-->  SECOND LORD. If the business be of any difficulty and this morning
line 5210-->    your departure hence, it requires haste of your lordship.
line 5211-->  BERTRAM. I mean the business is not ended, as fearing to hear of it
line 5212-->    hereafter. But shall we have this dialogue between the Fool and
line 5213-->    the Soldier? Come, bring forth this counterfeit module has
line 5214-->    deceiv'd me like a double-meaning prophesier.
line 5215-->  SECOND LORD. Bring him forth.  [Exeunt SOLDIERS]  Has sat i' th'
line 5216-->    stocks all night, poor gallant knave.
line 5217-->  BERTRAM. No matter; his heels have deserv'd it, in usurping his
line 5218-->    spurs so long. How does he carry himself?
line 5219-->  SECOND LORD. I have told your lordship already the stocks carry  
line 5220-->    him. But to answer you as you would be understood: he weeps like
line 5221-->    a wench that had shed her milk; he hath confess'd himself to
line 5222-->    Morgan, whom he supposes to be a friar, from the time of his
line 5223-->    remembrance to this very instant disaster of his setting i' th'
line 5224-->    stocks. And what think you he hath confess'd?
line 5225-->  BERTRAM. Nothing of me, has 'a?
line 5226-->  SECOND LORD. His confession is taken, and it shall be read to his
line 5227-->    face; if your lordship be in't, as I believe you are, you must
line 5228-->    have the patience to hear it.
line 5229-->
line 5230-->                   Enter PAROLLES guarded, and
line 5231-->                  FIRST SOLDIER as interpreter
line 5232-->
line 5233-->  BERTRAM. A plague upon him! muffled! He can say nothing of me.
line 5234-->  SECOND LORD. Hush, hush! Hoodman comes. Portotartarossa.
line 5235-->  FIRST SOLDIER. He calls for the tortures. What will you say without
line 5236-->    'em?
line 5237-->  PAROLLES. I will confess what I know without constraint; if ye
line 5238-->    pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more.
line 5239-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Bosko chimurcho.  
line 5240-->  SECOND LORD. Boblibindo chicurmurco.
line 5241-->  FIRST SOLDIER. YOU are a merciful general. Our General bids you
line 5242-->    answer to what I shall ask you out of a note.
line 5243-->  PAROLLES. And truly, as I hope to live.
line 5244-->  FIRST SOLDIER. 'First demand of him how many horse the Duke is
line 5245-->    strong.' What say you to that?
line 5246-->  PAROLLES. Five or six thousand; but very weak and unserviceable.
line 5247-->    The troops are all scattered, and the commanders very poor
line 5248-->    rogues, upon my reputation and credit, and as I hope to live.
line 5249-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Shall I set down your answer so?
line 5250-->  PAROLLES. Do; I'll take the sacrament on 't, how and which way you
line 5251-->    will.
line 5252-->  BERTRAM. All's one to him. What a past-saving slave is this!
line 5253-->  SECOND LORD. Y'are deceiv'd, my lord; this is Monsieur Parolles,
line 5254-->    the gallant militarist-that was his own phrase-that had the whole
line 5255-->    theoric of war in the knot of his scarf, and the practice in the
line 5256-->    chape of his dagger.
line 5257-->  FIRST LORD. I will never trust a man again for keeping his sword
line 5258-->    clean; nor believe he can have everything in him by wearing his
line 5259-->    apparel neatly.  
line 5260-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Well, that's set down.
line 5261-->  PAROLLES. 'Five or six thousand horse' I said-I will say true- 'or
line 5262-->    thereabouts' set down, for I'll speak truth.
line 5263-->  SECOND LORD. He's very near the truth in this.
line 5264-->  BERTRAM. But I con him no thanks for't in the nature he delivers it.
line 5265-->  PAROLLES. 'Poor rogues' I pray you say.
line 5266-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Well, that's set down.
line 5267-->  PAROLLES. I humbly thank you, sir. A truth's a truth-the rogues are
line 5268-->    marvellous poor.
line 5269-->  FIRST SOLDIER. 'Demand of him of what strength they are a-foot.'
line 5270-->    What say you to that?
line 5271-->  PAROLLES. By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present hour, I
line 5272-->    will tell true. Let me see: Spurio, a hundred and fifty;
line 5273-->    Sebastian, so many; Corambus, so many; Jaques, so many; Guiltian,
line 5274-->    Cosmo, Lodowick, and Gratii, two hundred fifty each; mine own
line 5275-->    company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii, two hundred fifty each; so
line 5276-->    that the muster-file, rotten and sound, upon my life, amounts not
line 5277-->    to fifteen thousand poll; half of the which dare not shake the
line 5278-->    snow from off their cassocks lest they shake themselves to
line 5279-->    pieces.  
line 5280-->  BERTRAM. What shall be done to him?
line 5281-->  SECOND LORD. Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him my
line 5282-->    condition, and what credit I have with the Duke.
line 5283-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Well, that's set down. 'You shall demand of him
line 5284-->    whether one Captain Dumain be i' th' camp, a Frenchman; what his
line 5285-->    reputation is with the Duke, what his valour, honesty, expertness
line 5286-->    in wars; or whether he thinks it were not possible, with
line 5287-->    well-weighing sums of gold, to corrupt him to a revolt.' What say
line 5288-->    you to this? What do you know of it?
line 5289-->  PAROLLES. I beseech you, let me answer to the particular of the
line 5290-->    inter'gatories. Demand them singly.
line 5291-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Do you know this Captain Dumain?
line 5292-->  PAROLLES. I know him: 'a was a botcher's prentice in Paris, from
line 5293-->    whence he was whipt for getting the shrieve's fool with child-a
line 5294-->    dumb innocent that could not say him nay.
line 5295-->  BERTRAM. Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I know his
line 5296-->    brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.
line 5297-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Well, is this captain in the Duke of Florence's
line 5298-->    camp?
line 5299-->  PAROLLES. Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy.  
line 5300-->  SECOND LORD. Nay, look not so upon me; we shall hear of your
line 5301-->    lordship anon.
line 5302-->  FIRST SOLDIER. What is his reputation with the Duke?
line 5303-->  PAROLLES. The Duke knows him for no other but a poor officer of
line 5304-->    mine; and writ to me this other day to turn him out o' th' band.
line 5305-->    I think I have his letter in my pocket.
line 5306-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Marry, we'll search.
line 5307-->  PAROLLES. In good sadness, I do not know; either it is there or it
line 5308-->    is upon a file with the Duke's other letters in my tent.
line 5309-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Here 'tis; here's a paper. Shall I read it to you?
line 5310-->  PAROLLES. I do not know if it be it or no.
line 5311-->  BERTRAM. Our interpreter does it well.
line 5312-->  SECOND LORD. Excellently.
line 5313-->  FIRST SOLDIER.  [Reads]  'Dian, the Count's a fool, and full of
line 5314-->    gold.'
line 5315-->  PAROLLES. That is not the Duke's letter, sir; that is an
line 5316-->    advertisement to a proper maid in Florence, one Diana, to take
line 5317-->    heed of the allurement of one Count Rousillon, a foolish idle
line 5318-->    boy, but for all that very ruttish. I pray you, sir, put it up
line 5319-->    again.  
line 5320-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Nay, I'll read it first by your favour.
line 5321-->  PAROLLES. My meaning in't, I protest, was very honest in the behalf
line 5322-->    of the maid; for I knew the young Count to be a dangerous and
line 5323-->    lascivious boy, who is a whale to virginity, and devours up all
line 5324-->    the fry it finds.
line 5325-->  BERTRAM. Damnable both-sides rogue!
line 5326-->  FIRST SOLDIER.                                         [Reads]
line 5327-->    'When he swears oaths, bid him drop gold, and take it;
line 5328-->    After he scores, he never pays the score.
line 5329-->    Half won is match well made; match, and well make it;
line 5330-->    He ne'er pays after-debts, take it before.
line 5331-->    And say a soldier, Dian, told thee this:
line 5332-->    Men are to mell with, boys are not to kiss;
line 5333-->    For count of this, the Count's a fool, I know it,
line 5334-->    Who pays before, but not when he does owe it.
line 5335-->    Thine, as he vow'd to thee in thine ear,
line 5336-->                                                   PAROLLES.'
line 5337-->  BERTRAM. He shall be whipt through the army with this rhyme in's
line 5338-->    forehead.
line 5339-->  FIRST LORD. This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifold  
line 5340-->    linguist, and the amnipotent soldier.
line 5341-->  BERTRAM. I could endure anything before but a cat, and now he's a
line 5342-->    cat to me.
line 5343-->  FIRST SOLDIER. I perceive, sir, by our General's looks we shall be
line 5344-->    fain to hang you.
line 5345-->  PAROLLES. My life, sir, in any case! Not that I am afraid to die,
line 5346-->    but that, my offences being many, I would repent out the
line 5347-->    remainder of nature. Let me live, sir, in a dungeon, i' th'
line 5348-->    stocks, or anywhere, so I may live.
line 5349-->  FIRST SOLDIER. We'll see what may be done, so you confess freely;
line 5350-->    therefore, once more to this Captain Dumain: you have answer'd to
line 5351-->    his reputation with the Duke, and to his valour; what is his
line 5352-->    honesty?
line 5353-->  PAROLLES. He will steal, sir, an egg out of a cloister; for rapes
line 5354-->    and ravishments he parallels Nessus. He professes not keeping of
line 5355-->    oaths; in breaking 'em he is stronger than Hercules. He will lie,
line 5356-->    sir, with such volubility that you would think truth were a fool.
line 5357-->    Drunkenness is his best virtue, for he will be swine-drunk; and
line 5358-->    in his sleep he does little harm, save to his bedclothes about
line 5359-->    him; but they know his conditions and lay him in straw. I have  
line 5360-->    but little more to say, sir, of his honesty. He has everything
line 5361-->    that an honest man should not have; what an honest man should
line 5362-->    have he has nothing.
line 5363-->  SECOND LORD. I begin to love him for this.
line 5364-->  BERTRAM. For this description of thine honesty? A pox upon him! For
line 5365-->    me, he's more and more a cat.
line 5366-->  FIRST SOLDIER. What say you to his expertness in war?
line 5367-->  PAROLLES. Faith, sir, has led the drum before the English
line 5368-->    tragedians-to belie him I will not-and more of his soldier-ship
line 5369-->    I know not, except in that country he had the honour to be the
line 5370-->    officer at a place there called Mile-end to instruct for the
line 5371-->    doubling of files-I would do the man what honour I can-but of
line 5372-->    this I am not certain.
line 5373-->  SECOND LORD. He hath out-villain'd villainy so far that the rarity
line 5374-->    redeems him.
line 5375-->  BERTRAM. A pox on him! he's a cat still.
line 5376-->  FIRST SOLDIER. His qualities being at this poor price, I need not
line 5377-->    to ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt.
line 5378-->  PAROLLES. Sir, for a cardecue he will sell the fee-simple of his
line 5379-->    salvation, the inheritance of it; and cut th' entail from all  
line 5380-->    remainders and a perpetual succession for it perpetually.
line 5381-->  FIRST SOLDIER. What's his brother, the other Captain Dumain?
line 5382-->  FIRST LORD. Why does he ask him of me?
line 5383-->  FIRST SOLDIER. What's he?
line 5384-->  PAROLLES. E'en a crow o' th' same nest; not altogether so great as
line 5385-->    the first in goodness, but greater a great deal in evil. He
line 5386-->    excels his brother for a coward; yet his brother is reputed one
line 5387-->    of the best that is. In a retreat he outruns any lackey: marry,
line 5388-->    in coming on he has the cramp.
line 5389-->  FIRST SOLDIER. If your life be saved, will you undertake to betray
line 5390-->    the Florentine?
line 5391-->  PAROLLES. Ay, and the Captain of his Horse, Count Rousillon.
line 5392-->  FIRST SOLDIER. I'll whisper with the General, and know his
line 5393-->    pleasure.
line 5394-->  PAROLLES.  [Aside]  I'll no more drumming. A plague of all drums!
line 5395-->    Only to seem to deserve well, and to beguile the supposition of
line 5396-->    that lascivious young boy the Count, have I run into this danger.
line 5397-->    Yet who would have suspected an ambush where I was taken?
line 5398-->  FIRST SOLDIER. There is no remedy, sir, but you must die.
line 5399-->    The General says you that have so traitorously discover'd the  
line 5400-->    secrets of your army, and made such pestiferous reports of men
line 5401-->    very nobly held, can serve the world for no honest use; therefore
line 5402-->    you must die. Come, headsman, of with his head.
line 5403-->  PAROLLES. O Lord, sir, let me live, or let me see my death!
line 5404-->  FIRST SOLDIER. That shall you, and take your leave of all your
line 5405-->    friends.  [Unmuffling him]  So look about you; know you any here?
line 5406-->  BERTRAM. Good morrow, noble Captain.
line 5407-->  FIRST LORD. God bless you, Captain Parolles.
line 5408-->  SECOND LORD. God save you, noble Captain.
line 5409-->  FIRST LORD. Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord Lafeu? I am
line 5410-->    for France.
line 5411-->  SECOND LORD. Good Captain, will you give me a copy of the sonnet
line 5412-->    you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count Rousillon? An I were not
line 5413-->    a very coward I'd compel it of you; but fare you well.
line 5414-->                                        Exeunt BERTRAM and LORDS
line 5415-->  FIRST SOLDIER. You are undone, Captain, all but your scarf; that
line 5416-->    has a knot on 't yet.
line 5417-->  PAROLLES. Who cannot be crush'd with a plot?
line 5418-->  FIRST SOLDIER. If you could find out a country where but women were
line 5419-->    that had received so much shame, you might begin an impudent  
line 5420-->    nation. Fare ye well, sir; I am for France too; we shall speak of
line 5421-->    you there.                                Exit with SOLDIERS
line 5422-->  PAROLLES. Yet am I thankful. If my heart were great,
line 5423-->    'Twould burst at this. Captain I'll be no more;
line 5424-->    But I will eat, and drink, and sleep as soft
line 5425-->    As captain shall. Simply the thing I am
line 5426-->    Shall make me live. Who knows himself a braggart,
line 5427-->    Let him fear this; for it will come to pass
line 5428-->    That every braggart shall be found an ass.
line 5429-->    Rust, sword; cool, blushes; and, Parolles, live
line 5430-->    Safest in shame. Being fool'd, by fool'ry thrive.
line 5431-->    There's place and means for every man alive.
line 5432-->    I'll after them.                                        Exit
line 5433-->
line 5434-->
line 5435-->
line 5436-->
line 5437-->ACT IV SCENE 4.
line 5438-->The WIDOW'S house
line 5439-->
line 5440-->Enter HELENA, WIDOW, and DIANA
line 5441-->
line 5442-->  HELENA. That you may well perceive I have not wrong'd you!
line 5443-->    One of the greatest in the Christian world
line 5444-->    Shall be my surety; fore whose throne 'tis needful,
line 5445-->    Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel.
line 5446-->    Time was I did him a desired office,
line 5447-->    Dear almost as his life; which gratitude
line 5448-->    Through flinty Tartar's bosom would peep forth,
line 5449-->    And answer 'Thanks.' I duly am inform'd
line 5450-->    His Grace is at Marseilles, to which place
line 5451-->    We have convenient convoy. You must know
line 5452-->    I am supposed dead. The army breaking,
line 5453-->    My husband hies him home; where, heaven aiding,
line 5454-->    And by the leave of my good lord the King,
line 5455-->    We'll be before our welcome.
line 5456-->  WIDOW. Gentle madam,
line 5457-->    You never had a servant to whose trust
line 5458-->    Your business was more welcome.  
line 5459-->  HELENA. Nor you, mistress,
line 5460-->    Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour
line 5461-->    To recompense your love. Doubt not but heaven
line 5462-->    Hath brought me up to be your daughter's dower,
line 5463-->    As it hath fated her to be my motive
line 5464-->    And helper to a husband. But, O strange men!
line 5465-->    That can such sweet use make of what they hate,
line 5466-->    When saucy trusting of the cozen'd thoughts
line 5467-->    Defiles the pitchy night. So lust doth play
line 5468-->    With what it loathes, for that which is away.
line 5469-->    But more of this hereafter. You, Diana,
line 5470-->    Under my poor instructions yet must suffer
line 5471-->    Something in my behalf.
line 5472-->  DIANA. Let death and honesty
line 5473-->    Go with your impositions, I am yours
line 5474-->    Upon your will to suffer.
line 5475-->  HELENA. Yet, I pray you:
line 5476-->    But with the word the time will bring on summer,
line 5477-->    When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns
line 5478-->    And be as sweet as sharp. We must away;  
line 5479-->    Our waggon is prepar'd, and time revives us.
line 5480-->    All's Well that Ends Well. Still the fine's the crown.
line 5481-->    Whate'er the course, the end is the renown.           Exeunt
line 5482-->
line 5483-->
line 5484-->
line 5485-->
line 5486-->ACT IV SCENE 5.
line 5487-->Rousillon. The COUNT'S palace
line 5488-->
line 5489-->Enter COUNTESS, LAFEU, and CLOWN
line 5490-->
line 5491-->  LAFEU. No, no, no, son was misled with a snipt-taffeta fellow
line 5492-->    there, whose villainous saffron would have made all the unbak'd
line 5493-->    and doughy youth of a nation in his colour. Your daughter-in-law
line 5494-->    had been alive at this hour, and your son here at home, more
line 5495-->    advanc'd by the King than by that red-tail'd humble-bee I speak
line 5496-->    of.
line 5497-->  COUNTESS. I would I had not known him. It was the death of the most
line 5498-->    virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature had praise for creating. If
line 5499-->    she had partaken of my flesh, and cost me the dearest groans of a
line 5500-->    mother. I could not have owed her a more rooted love.
line 5501-->  LAFEU. 'Twas a good lady, 'twas a good lady. We may pick a thousand
line 5502-->    sallets ere we light on such another herb.
line 5503-->  CLOWN. Indeed, sir, she was the sweet-marjoram of the sallet, or,
line 5504-->    rather, the herb of grace.
line 5505-->  LAFEU. They are not sallet-herbs, you knave; they are nose-herbs.
line 5506-->  CLOWN. I am no great Nebuchadnezzar, sir; I have not much skill in
line 5507-->    grass.  
line 5508-->  LAFEU. Whether dost thou profess thyself-a knave or a fool?
line 5509-->  CLOWN. A fool, sir, at a woman's service, and a knave at a man's.
line 5510-->  LAFEU. Your distinction?
line 5511-->  CLOWN. I would cozen the man of his wife, and do his service.
line 5512-->  LAFEU. So you were a knave at his service, indeed.
line 5513-->  CLOWN. And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her service.
line 5514-->  LAFEU. I will subscribe for thee; thou art both knave and fool.
line 5515-->  CLOWN. At your service.
line 5516-->  LAFEU. No, no, no.
line 5517-->  CLOWN. Why, sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve as great a
line 5518-->    prince as you are.
line 5519-->  LAFEU. Who's that? A Frenchman?
line 5520-->  CLOWN. Faith, sir, 'a has an English name; but his fisnomy is more
line 5521-->    hotter in France than there.
line 5522-->  LAFEU. What prince is that?
line 5523-->  CLOWN. The Black Prince, sir; alias, the Prince of Darkness; alias,
line 5524-->    the devil.
line 5525-->  LAFEU. Hold thee, there's my purse. I give thee not this to suggest
line 5526-->    thee from thy master thou talk'st of; serve him still.
line 5527-->  CLOWN. I am a woodland fellow, sir, that always loved a great fire;  
line 5528-->    and the master I speak of ever keeps a good fire. But, sure, he
line 5529-->    is the prince of the world; let his nobility remain in's court. I
line 5530-->    am for the house with the narrow gate, which I take to be too
line 5531-->    little for pomp to enter. Some that humble themselves may; but
line 5532-->    the many will be too chill and tender: and they'll be for the
line 5533-->    flow'ry way that leads to the broad gate and the great fire.
line 5534-->  LAFEU. Go thy ways, I begin to be aweary of thee; and I tell thee
line 5535-->    so before, because I would not fall out with thee. Go thy ways;
line 5536-->    let my horses be well look'd to, without any tricks.
line 5537-->  CLOWN. If I put any tricks upon 'em, sir, they shall be jades'
line 5538-->    tricks, which are their own right by the law of nature.
line 5539--> Exit
line 5540-->  LAFEU. A shrewd knave, and an unhappy.
line 5541-->  COUNTESS. So 'a is. My lord that's gone made himself much  sport
line 5542-->    out of him. By his authority he remains here, which he thinks is
line 5543-->    a patent for his sauciness; and indeed he has no pace, but runs
line 5544-->    where he will.
line 5545-->  LAFEU. I like him well; 'tis not amiss. And I was about to tell
line 5546-->    you, since I heard of the good lady's death, and that my lord
line 5547-->    your son was upon his return home, I moved the King my master to  
line 5548-->    speak in the behalf of my daughter; which, in the minority of
line 5549-->    them both, his Majesty out of a self-gracious remembrance did
line 5550-->    first propose. His Highness hath promis'd me to do it; and, to
line 5551-->    stop up the displeasure he hath conceived against your son, there
line 5552-->    is no fitter matter. How does your ladyship like it?
line 5553-->  COUNTESS. With very much content, my lord; and I wish it happily
line 5554-->    effected.
line 5555-->  LAFEU. His Highness comes post from Marseilles, of as able body as
line 5556-->    when he number'd thirty; 'a will be here to-morrow, or I am
line 5557-->    deceiv'd by him that in such intelligence hath seldom fail'd.
line 5558-->  COUNTESS. It rejoices me that I hope I shall see him ere I die.
line 5559-->    I have letters that my son will be here to-night. I shall beseech
line 5560-->    your lordship to remain with me tal they meet together.
line 5561-->  LAFEU. Madam, I was thinking with what manners I might safely be
line 5562-->    admitted.
line 5563-->  COUNTESS. You need but plead your honourable privilege.
line 5564-->  LAFEU. Lady, of that I have made a bold charter; but, I thank my
line 5565-->    God, it holds yet.
line 5566-->
line 5567-->                         Re-enter CLOWN  
line 5568-->
line 5569-->  CLOWN. O madam, yonder's my lord your son with a patch of velvet
line 5570-->    on's face; whether there be a scar under 't or no, the velvet
line 5571-->    knows; but 'tis a goodly patch of velvet. His left cheek is a
line 5572-->    cheek of two pile and a half, but his right cheek is worn bare.
line 5573-->  LAFEU. A scar nobly got, or a noble scar, is a good liv'ry of
line 5574-->    honour; so belike is that.
line 5575-->  CLOWN. But it is your carbonado'd face.
line 5576-->  LAFEU. Let us go see your son, I pray you;
line 5577-->    I long to talk with the young noble soldier.
line 5578-->  CLOWN. Faith, there's a dozen of 'em, with delicate fine hats, and
line 5579-->    most courteous feathers, which bow the head and nod at every man.
line 5580-->                                                          Exeunt
line 5581-->

line 5593-->
line 5594-->
line 5595-->
line 5596-->ACT V. SCENE 1.
line 5597-->Marseilles. A street
line 5598-->
line 5599-->Enter HELENA, WIDOW, and DIANA, with two ATTENDANTS
line 5600-->
line 5601-->  HELENA. But this exceeding posting day and night
line 5602-->    Must wear your spirits low; we cannot help it.
line 5603-->    But since you have made the days and nights as one,
line 5604-->    To wear your gentle limbs in my affairs,
line 5605-->    Be bold you do so grow in my requital
line 5606-->    As nothing can unroot you.
line 5607-->
line 5608-->                      Enter a GENTLEMAN
line 5609-->
line 5610-->    In happy time!
line 5611-->    This man may help me to his Majesty's ear,
line 5612-->    If he would spend his power. God save you, sir.
line 5613-->  GENTLEMAN. And you.
line 5614-->  HELENA. Sir, I have seen you in the court of France.
line 5615-->  GENTLEMAN. I have been sometimes there.
line 5616-->  HELENA. I do presume, sir, that you are not fall'n
line 5617-->    From the report that goes upon your goodness;  
line 5618-->    And therefore, goaded with most sharp occasions,
line 5619-->    Which lay nice manners by, I put you to
line 5620-->    The use of your own virtues, for the which
line 5621-->    I shall continue thankful.
line 5622-->  GENTLEMAN. What's your will?
line 5623-->  HELENA. That it will please you
line 5624-->    To give this poor petition to the King;
line 5625-->    And aid me with that store of power you have
line 5626-->    To come into his presence.
line 5627-->  GENTLEMAN. The King's not here.
line 5628-->  HELENA. Not here, sir?
line 5629-->  GENTLEMAN. Not indeed.
line 5630-->    He hence remov'd last night, and with more haste
line 5631-->    Than is his use.
line 5632-->  WIDOW. Lord, how we lose our pains!
line 5633-->  HELENA. All's Well That Ends Well yet,
line 5634-->    Though time seem so adverse and means unfit.
line 5635-->    I do beseech you, whither is he gone?
line 5636-->  GENTLEMAN. Marry, as I take it, to Rousillon;
line 5637-->    Whither I am going.  
line 5638-->  HELENA. I do beseech you, sir,
line 5639-->    Since you are like to see the King before me,
line 5640-->    Commend the paper to his gracious hand;
line 5641-->    Which I presume shall render you no blame,
line 5642-->    But rather make you thank your pains for it.
line 5643-->    I will come after you with what good speed
line 5644-->    Our means will make us means.
line 5645-->  GENTLEMAN. This I'll do for you.
line 5646-->  HELENA. And you shall find yourself to be well thank'd,
line 5647-->    Whate'er falls more. We must to horse again;
line 5648-->    Go, go, provide.                                      Exeunt
line 5649-->
line 5650-->
line 5651-->
line 5652-->
line 5653-->ACT V SCENE 2.
line 5654-->Rousillon. The inner court of the COUNT'S palace
line 5655-->
line 5656-->Enter CLOWN and PAROLLES
line 5657-->
line 5658-->  PAROLLES. Good Monsieur Lavache, give my Lord Lafeu this letter. I
line 5659-->    have ere now, sir, been better known to you, when I have held
line 5660-->    familiarity with fresher clothes; but I am now, sir, muddied in
line 5661-->    Fortune's mood, and smell somewhat strong of her strong
line 5662-->    displeasure.
line 5663-->  CLOWN. Truly, Fortune's displeasure is but sluttish, if it smell
line 5664-->    so strongly as thou speak'st of. I will henceforth eat no fish
line 5665-->    of Fortune's butt'ring. Prithee, allow the wind.
line 5666-->  PAROLLES. Nay, you need not to stop your nose, sir; I spake but by
line 5667-->    a metaphor.
line 5668-->  CLOWN. Indeed, sir, if your metaphor stink, I will stop my nose; or
line 5669-->    against any man's metaphor. Prithee, get thee further.
line 5670-->  PAROLLES. Pray you, sir, deliver me this paper.
line 5671-->  CLOWN. Foh! prithee stand away. A paper from Fortune's close-stool
line 5672-->    to give to a nobleman! Look here he comes himself.
line 5673-->
line 5674-->                           Enter LAFEU  
line 5675-->
line 5676-->    Here is a pur of Fortune's, sir, or of Fortune's cat, but not
line 5677-->    a musk-cat, that has fall'n into the unclean fishpond of her
line 5678-->    displeasure, and, as he says, is muddied withal. Pray you, sir,
line 5679-->    use the carp as you may; for he looks like a poor, decayed,
line 5680-->    ingenious, foolish, rascally knave. I do pity his distress
line 5681-->    in my similes of comfort, and leave him to your lordship.
line 5682--> Exit
line 5683-->  PAROLLES. My lord, I am a man whom Fortune hath cruelly scratch'd.
line 5684-->  LAFEU. And what would you have me to do? 'Tis too late to pare her
line 5685-->    nails now. Wherein have you played the knave with Fortune, that
line 5686-->    she should scratch you, who of herself is a good lady and would
line 5687-->    not have knaves thrive long under her? There's a cardecue for
line 5688-->    you. Let the justices make you and Fortune friends; I am for
line 5689-->    other business.
line 5690-->  PAROLLES. I beseech your honour to hear me one single word.
line 5691-->  LAFEU. You beg a single penny more; come, you shall ha't; save your
line 5692-->    word.
line 5693-->  PAROLLES. My name, my good lord, is Parolles.
line 5694-->  LAFEU. You beg more than word then. Cox my passion! give me your  
line 5695-->    hand. How does your drum?
line 5696-->  PAROLLES. O my good lord, you were the first that found me.
line 5697-->  LAFEU. Was I, in sooth? And I was the first that lost thee.
line 5698-->  PAROLLES. It lies in you, my lord, to bring me in some grace, for
line 5699-->    you did bring me out.
line 5700-->  LAFEU. Out upon thee, knave! Dost thou put upon me at once both the
line 5701-->    office of God and the devil? One brings the in grace, and the
line 5702-->    other brings thee out.    [Trumpets sound]  The King's coming; I
line 5703-->    know by his trumpets. Sirrah, inquire further after me; I had
line 5704-->    talk of you last night. Though you are a fool and a knave, you
line 5705-->    shall eat. Go to; follow.
line 5706-->  PAROLLES. I praise God for you.                         Exeunt
line 5707-->
line 5708-->
line 5709-->
line 5710-->
line 5711-->ACT V SCENE 3.
line 5712-->Rousillon. The COUNT'S palace
line 5713-->
line 5714-->Flourish. Enter KING, COUNTESS, LAFEU, the two FRENCH LORDS, with ATTENDANTS
line 5715-->
line 5716-->  KING. We lost a jewel of her, and our esteem
line 5717-->    Was made much poorer by it; but your son,
line 5718-->    As mad in folly, lack'd the sense to know
line 5719-->    Her estimation home.
line 5720-->  COUNTESS. 'Tis past, my liege;
line 5721-->    And I beseech your Majesty to make it
line 5722-->    Natural rebellion, done i' th' blaze of youth,
line 5723-->    When oil and fire, too strong for reason's force,
line 5724-->    O'erbears it and burns on.
line 5725-->  KING. My honour'd lady,
line 5726-->    I have forgiven and forgotten all;
line 5727-->    Though my revenges were high bent upon him
line 5728-->    And watch'd the time to shoot.
line 5729-->  LAFEU. This I must say-
line 5730-->    But first, I beg my pardon: the young lord
line 5731-->    Did to his Majesty, his mother, and his lady,  
line 5732-->    Offence of mighty note; but to himself
line 5733-->    The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife
line 5734-->    Whose beauty did astonish the survey
line 5735-->    Of richest eyes; whose words all ears took captive;
line 5736-->    Whose dear perfection hearts that scorn'd to serve
line 5737-->    Humbly call'd mistress.
line 5738-->  KING. Praising what is lost
line 5739-->    Makes the remembrance dear. Well, call him hither;
line 5740-->    We are reconcil'd, and the first view shall kill
line 5741-->    All repetition. Let him not ask our pardon;
line 5742-->    The nature of his great offence is dead,
line 5743-->    And deeper than oblivion do we bury
line 5744-->    Th' incensing relics of it; let him approach,
line 5745-->    A stranger, no offender; and inform him
line 5746-->    So 'tis our will he should.
line 5747-->  GENTLEMAN. I shall, my liege.                 Exit GENTLEMAN
line 5748-->  KING. What says he to your daughter? Have you spoke?
line 5749-->  LAFEU. All that he is hath reference to your Highness.
line 5750-->  KING. Then shall we have a match. I have letters sent me
line 5751-->    That sets him high in fame.  
line 5752-->
line 5753-->                          Enter BERTRAM
line 5754-->
line 5755-->  LAFEU. He looks well on 't.
line 5756-->  KING. I am not a day of season,
line 5757-->    For thou mayst see a sunshine and a hail
line 5758-->    In me at once. But to the brightest beams
line 5759-->    Distracted clouds give way; so stand thou forth;
line 5760-->    The time is fair again.
line 5761-->  BERTRAM. My high-repented blames,
line 5762-->    Dear sovereign, pardon to me.
line 5763-->  KING. All is whole;
line 5764-->    Not one word more of the consumed time.
line 5765-->    Let's take the instant by the forward top;
line 5766-->    For we are old, and on our quick'st decrees
line 5767-->    Th' inaudible and noiseless foot of Time
line 5768-->    Steals ere we can effect them. You remember
line 5769-->    The daughter of this lord?
line 5770-->  BERTRAM. Admiringly, my liege. At first
line 5771-->    I stuck my choice upon her, ere my heart  
line 5772-->    Durst make too bold herald of my tongue;
line 5773-->    Where the impression of mine eye infixing,
line 5774-->    Contempt his scornful perspective did lend me,
line 5775-->    Which warp'd the line of every other favour,
line 5776-->    Scorn'd a fair colour or express'd it stol'n,
line 5777-->    Extended or contracted all proportions
line 5778-->    To a most hideous object. Thence it came
line 5779-->    That she whom all men prais'd, and whom myself,
line 5780-->    Since I have lost, have lov'd, was in mine eye
line 5781-->    The dust that did offend it.
line 5782-->  KING. Well excus'd.
line 5783-->    That thou didst love her, strikes some scores away
line 5784-->    From the great compt; but love that comes too late,
line 5785-->    Like a remorseful pardon slowly carried,
line 5786-->    To the great sender turns a sour offence,
line 5787-->    Crying 'That's good that's gone.' Our rash faults
line 5788-->    Make trivial price of serious things we have,
line 5789-->    Not knowing them until we know their grave.
line 5790-->    Oft our displeasures, to ourselves unjust,
line 5791-->    Destroy our friends, and after weep their dust;  
line 5792-->    Our own love waking cries to see what's done,
line 5793-->    While shameful hate sleeps out the afternoon.
line 5794-->    Be this sweet Helen's knell. And now forget her.
line 5795-->    Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin.
line 5796-->    The main consents are had; and here we'll stay
line 5797-->    To see our widower's second marriage-day.
line 5798-->  COUNTESS. Which better than the first, O dear heaven, bless!
line 5799-->    Or, ere they meet, in me, O nature, cesse!
line 5800-->  LAFEU. Come on, my son, in whom my house's name
line 5801-->    Must be digested; give a favour from you,
line 5802-->    To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter,
line 5803-->    That she may quickly come.
line 5804-->                                          [BERTRAM gives a ring]
line 5805-->    By my old beard,
line 5806-->    And ev'ry hair that's on 't, Helen, that's dead,
line 5807-->    Was a sweet creature; such a ring as this,
line 5808-->    The last that e'er I took her leave at court,
line 5809-->    I saw upon her finger.
line 5810-->  BERTRAM. Hers it was not.
line 5811-->  KING. Now, pray you, let me see it; for mine eye,  
line 5812-->    While I was speaking, oft was fasten'd to't.
line 5813-->    This ring was mine; and when I gave it Helen
line 5814-->    I bade her, if her fortunes ever stood
line 5815-->    Necessitied to help, that by this token
line 5816-->    I would relieve her. Had you that craft to reave her
line 5817-->    Of what should stead her most?
line 5818-->  BERTRAM. My gracious sovereign,
line 5819-->    Howe'er it pleases you to take it so,
line 5820-->    The ring was never hers.
line 5821-->  COUNTESS. Son, on my life,
line 5822-->    I have seen her wear it; and she reckon'd it
line 5823-->    At her life's rate.
line 5824-->  LAFEU. I am sure I saw her wear it.
line 5825-->  BERTRAM. You are deceiv'd, my lord; she never saw it.
line 5826-->    In Florence was it from a casement thrown me,
line 5827-->    Wrapp'd in a paper, which contain'd the name
line 5828-->    Of her that threw it. Noble she was, and thought
line 5829-->    I stood engag'd; but when I had subscrib'd
line 5830-->    To mine own fortune, and inform'd her fully
line 5831-->    I could not answer in that course of honour  
line 5832-->    As she had made the overture, she ceas'd,
line 5833-->    In heavy satisfaction, and would never
line 5834-->    Receive the ring again.
line 5835-->  KING. Plutus himself,
line 5836-->    That knows the tinct and multiplying med'cine,
line 5837-->    Hath not in nature's mystery more science
line 5838-->    Than I have in this ring. 'Twas mine, 'twas Helen's,
line 5839-->    Whoever gave it you. Then, if you know
line 5840-->    That you are well acquainted with yourself,
line 5841-->    Confess 'twas hers, and by what rough enforcement
line 5842-->    You got it from her. She call'd the saints to surety
line 5843-->    That she would never put it from her finger
line 5844-->    Unless she gave it to yourself in bed-
line 5845-->    Where you have never come- or sent it us
line 5846-->    Upon her great disaster.
line 5847-->  BERTRAM. She never saw it.
line 5848-->  KING. Thou speak'st it falsely, as I love mine honour;
line 5849-->    And mak'st conjectural fears to come into me
line 5850-->    Which I would fain shut out. If it should prove
line 5851-->    That thou art so inhuman- 'twill not prove so.  
line 5852-->    And yet I know not- thou didst hate her deadly,
line 5853-->    And she is dead; which nothing, but to close
line 5854-->    Her eyes myself, could win me to believe
line 5855-->    More than to see this ring. Take him away.
line 5856-->                                          [GUARDS seize BERTRAM]
line 5857-->    My fore-past proofs, howe'er the matter fall,
line 5858-->    Shall tax my fears of little vanity,
line 5859-->    Having vainly fear'd too little. Away with him.
line 5860-->    We'll sift this matter further.
line 5861-->  BERTRAM. If you shall prove
line 5862-->    This ring was ever hers, you shall as easy
line 5863-->    Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence,
line 5864-->    Where she yet never was.                       Exit, guarded
line 5865-->  KING. I am wrapp'd in dismal thinkings.
line 5866-->
line 5867-->                        Enter a GENTLEMAN
line 5868-->
line 5869-->  GENTLEMAN. Gracious sovereign,
line 5870-->    Whether I have been to blame or no, I know not:
line 5871-->    Here's a petition from a Florentine,  
line 5872-->    Who hath, for four or five removes, come short
line 5873-->    To tender it herself. I undertook it,
line 5874-->    Vanquish'd thereto by the fair grace and speech
line 5875-->    Of the poor suppliant, who by this, I know,
line 5876-->    Is here attending; her business looks in her
line 5877-->    With an importing visage; and she told me
line 5878-->    In a sweet verbal brief it did concern
line 5879-->    Your Highness with herself.
line 5880-->  KING.  [Reads the letter]  'Upon his many protestations to marry me
line 5881-->    when his wife was dead, I blush to say it, he won me. Now is the
line 5882-->    Count Rousillon a widower; his vows are forfeited to me, and my
line 5883-->    honour's paid to him. He stole from Florence, taking no leave,
line 5884-->    and I follow him to his country for justice. Grant it me, O King!
line 5885-->    in you it best lies; otherwise a seducer flourishes, and a poor
line 5886-->    maid is undone.
line 5887-->                                                DIANA CAPILET.'
line 5888-->  LAFEU. I will buy me a son-in-law in a fair, and toll for this.
line 5889-->    I'll none of him.
line 5890-->  KING. The heavens have thought well on thee, Lafeu,
line 5891-->    To bring forth this discov'ry. Seek these suitors.  
line 5892-->    Go speedily, and bring again the Count.
line 5893-->                                               Exeunt ATTENDANTS
line 5894-->    I am afeard the life of Helen, lady,
line 5895-->    Was foully snatch'd.
line 5896-->  COUNTESS. Now, justice on the doers!
line 5897-->
line 5898-->                       Enter BERTRAM, guarded
line 5899-->
line 5900-->  KING. I wonder, sir, sith wives are monsters to you.
line 5901-->    And that you fly them as you swear them lordship,
line 5902-->    Yet you desire to marry.
line 5903-->                                           Enter WIDOW and DIANA
line 5904-->    What woman's that?
line 5905-->  DIANA. I am, my lord, a wretched Florentine,
line 5906-->    Derived from the ancient Capilet.
line 5907-->    My suit, as I do understand, you know,
line 5908-->    And therefore know how far I may be pitied.
line 5909-->  WIDOW. I am her mother, sir, whose age and honour
line 5910-->    Both suffer under this complaint we bring,
line 5911-->    And both shall cease, without your remedy.  
line 5912-->  KING. Come hither, Count; do you know these women?
line 5913-->  BERTRAM. My lord, I neither can nor will deny
line 5914-->    But that I know them. Do they charge me further?
line 5915-->  DIANA. Why do you look so strange upon your wife?
line 5916-->  BERTRAM. She's none of mine, my lord.
line 5917-->  DIANA. If you shall marry,
line 5918-->    You give away this hand, and that is mine;
line 5919-->    You give away heaven's vows, and those are mine;
line 5920-->    You give away myself, which is known mine;
line 5921-->    For I by vow am so embodied yours
line 5922-->    That she which marries you must marry me,
line 5923-->    Either both or none.
line 5924-->  LAFEU.  [To BERTRAM]  Your reputation comes too short for
line 5925-->    my daughter; you are no husband for her.
line 5926-->  BERTRAM. My lord, this is a fond and desp'rate creature
line 5927-->    Whom sometime I have laugh'd with. Let your Highness
line 5928-->    Lay a more noble thought upon mine honour
line 5929-->    Than for to think that I would sink it here.
line 5930-->  KING. Sir, for my thoughts, you have them ill to friend
line 5931-->    Till your deeds gain them. Fairer prove your honour  
line 5932-->    Than in my thought it lies!
line 5933-->  DIANA. Good my lord,
line 5934-->    Ask him upon his oath if he does think
line 5935-->    He had not my virginity.
line 5936-->  KING. What say'st thou to her?
line 5937-->  BERTRAM. She's impudent, my lord,
line 5938-->    And was a common gamester to the camp.
line 5939-->  DIANA. He does me wrong, my lord; if I were so
line 5940-->    He might have bought me at a common price.
line 5941-->    Do not believe him. o, behold this ring,
line 5942-->    Whose high respect and rich validity
line 5943-->    Did lack a parallel; yet, for all that,
line 5944-->    He gave it to a commoner o' th' camp,
line 5945-->    If I be one.
line 5946-->  COUNTESS. He blushes, and 'tis it.
line 5947-->    Of six preceding ancestors, that gem
line 5948-->    Conferr'd by testament to th' sequent issue,
line 5949-->    Hath it been ow'd and worn. This is his wife:
line 5950-->    That ring's a thousand proofs.
line 5951-->  KING. Methought you said  
line 5952-->    You saw one here in court could witness it.
line 5953-->  DIANA. I did, my lord, but loath am to produce
line 5954-->    So bad an instrument; his name's Parolles.
line 5955-->  LAFEU. I saw the man to-day, if man he be.
line 5956-->  KING. Find him, and bring him hither.        Exit an ATTENDANT
line 5957-->  BERTRAM. What of him?
line 5958-->    He's quoted for a most perfidious slave,
line 5959-->    With all the spots o' th' world tax'd and debauch'd,
line 5960-->    Whose nature sickens but to speak a truth.
line 5961-->    Am I or that or this for what he'll utter
line 5962-->    That will speak anything?
line 5963-->  KING. She hath that ring of yours.
line 5964-->  BERTRAM. I think she has. Certain it is I lik'd her,
line 5965-->    And boarded her i' th' wanton way of youth.
line 5966-->    She knew her distance, and did angle for me,
line 5967-->    Madding my eagerness with her restraint,
line 5968-->    As all impediments in fancy's course
line 5969-->    Are motives of more fancy; and, in fine,
line 5970-->    Her infinite cunning with her modern grace
line 5971-->    Subdu'd me to her rate. She got the ring;  
line 5972-->    And I had that which any inferior might
line 5973-->    At market-price have bought.
line 5974-->  DIANA. I must be patient.
line 5975-->    You that have turn'd off a first so noble wife
line 5976-->    May justly diet me. I pray you yet-
line 5977-->    Since you lack virtue, I will lose a husband-
line 5978-->    Send for your ring, I will return it home,
line 5979-->    And give me mine again.
line 5980-->  BERTRAM. I have it not.
line 5981-->  KING. What ring was yours, I pray you?
line 5982-->  DIANA. Sir, much like
line 5983-->    The same upon your finger.
line 5984-->  KING. Know you this ring? This ring was his of late.
line 5985-->  DIANA. And this was it I gave him, being abed.
line 5986-->  KING. The story, then, goes false you threw it him
line 5987-->    Out of a casement.
line 5988-->  DIANA. I have spoke the truth.
line 5989-->
line 5990-->                       Enter PAROLLES
line 5991-->  
line 5992-->  BERTRAM. My lord, I do confess the ring was hers.
line 5993-->  KING. You boggle shrewdly; every feather starts you.
line 5994-->    Is this the man you speak of?
line 5995-->  DIANA. Ay, my lord.
line 5996-->  KING. Tell me, sirrah-but tell me true I charge you,
line 5997-->    Not fearing the displeasure of your master,
line 5998-->    Which, on your just proceeding, I'll keep off-
line 5999-->    By him and by this woman here what know you?
line 6000-->  PAROLLES. So please your Majesty, my master hath been an honourable
line 6001-->    gentleman; tricks he hath had in him, which gentlemen have.
line 6002-->  KING. Come, come, to th' purpose. Did he love this woman?
line 6003-->  PAROLLES. Faith, sir, he did love her; but how?
line 6004-->  KING. How, I pray you?
line 6005-->  PAROLLES. He did love her, sir, as a gentleman loves a woman.
line 6006-->  KING. How is that?
line 6007-->  PAROLLES. He lov'd her, sir, and lov'd her not.
line 6008-->  KING. As thou art a knave and no knave.
line 6009-->    What an equivocal companion is this!
line 6010-->  PAROLLES. I am a poor man, and at your Majesty's command.
line 6011-->  LAFEU. He's a good drum, my lord, but a naughty orator.  
line 6012-->  DIANA. Do you know he promis'd me marriage?
line 6013-->  PAROLLES. Faith, I know more than I'll speak.
line 6014-->  KING. But wilt thou not speak all thou know'st?
line 6015-->  PAROLLES. Yes, so please your Majesty. I did go between them, as I
line 6016-->    said; but more than that, he loved her-for indeed he was mad for
line 6017-->    her, and talk'd of Satan, and of Limbo, and of Furies, and I know
line 6018-->    not what. Yet I was in that credit with them at that time that I
line 6019-->    knew of their going to bed; and of other motions, as promising
line 6020-->    her marriage, and things which would derive me ill will to speak
line 6021-->    of; therefore I will not speak what I know.
line 6022-->  KING. Thou hast spoken all already, unless thou canst say they are
line 6023-->    married; but thou art too fine in thy evidence; therefore stand
line 6024-->    aside.
line 6025-->    This ring, you say, was yours?
line 6026-->  DIANA. Ay, my good lord.
line 6027-->  KING. Where did you buy it? Or who gave it you?
line 6028-->  DIANA. It was not given me, nor I did not buy it.
line 6029-->  KING. Who lent it you?
line 6030-->  DIANA. It was not lent me neither.
line 6031-->  KING. Where did you find it then?  
line 6032-->  DIANA. I found it not.
line 6033-->  KING. If it were yours by none of all these ways,
line 6034-->    How could you give it him?
line 6035-->  DIANA. I never gave it him.
line 6036-->  LAFEU. This woman's an easy glove, my lord; she goes of and on at
line 6037-->    pleasure.
line 6038-->  KING. This ring was mine, I gave it his first wife.
line 6039-->  DIANA. It might be yours or hers, for aught I know.
line 6040-->  KING. Take her away, I do not like her now;
line 6041-->    To prison with her. And away with him.
line 6042-->    Unless thou tell'st me where thou hadst this ring,
line 6043-->    Thou diest within this hour.
line 6044-->  DIANA. I'll never tell you.
line 6045-->  KING. Take her away.
line 6046-->  DIANA. I'll put in bail, my liege.
line 6047-->  KING. I think thee now some common customer.
line 6048-->  DIANA. By Jove, if ever I knew man, 'twas you.
line 6049-->  KING. Wherefore hast thou accus'd him all this while?
line 6050-->  DIANA. Because he's guilty, and he is not guilty.
line 6051-->    He knows I am no maid, and he'll swear to't:  
line 6052-->    I'll swear I am a maid, and he knows not.
line 6053-->    Great King, I am no strumpet, by my life;
line 6054-->    I am either maid, or else this old man's wife.
line 6055-->                                             [Pointing to LAFEU]
line 6056-->  KING. She does abuse our ears; to prison with her.
line 6057-->  DIANA. Good mother, fetch my bail. Stay, royal sir;
line 6058-->                                                      Exit WIDOW
line 6059-->    The jeweller that owes the ring is sent for,
line 6060-->    And he shall surety me. But for this lord
line 6061-->    Who hath abus'd me as he knows himself,
line 6062-->    Though yet he never harm'd me, here I quit him.
line 6063-->    He knows himself my bed he hath defil'd;
line 6064-->    And at that time he got his wife with child.
line 6065-->    Dead though she be, she feels her young one kick;
line 6066-->    So there's my riddle: one that's dead is quick-
line 6067-->    And now behold the meaning.
line 6068-->
line 6069-->                     Re-enter WIDOW with HELENA
line 6070-->
line 6071-->  KING. Is there no exorcist  
line 6072-->    Beguiles the truer office of mine eyes?
line 6073-->    Is't real that I see?
line 6074-->  HELENA. No, my good lord;
line 6075-->    'Tis but the shadow of a wife you see,
line 6076-->    The name and not the thing.
line 6077-->  BERTRAM. Both, both; o, pardon!
line 6078-->  HELENA. O, my good lord, when I was like this maid,
line 6079-->    I found you wondrous kind. There is your ring,
line 6080-->    And, look you, here's your letter. This it says:
line 6081-->    'When from my finger you can get this ring,
line 6082-->    And are by me with child,' etc. This is done.
line 6083-->    Will you be mine now you are doubly won?
line 6084-->  BERTRAM. If she, my liege, can make me know this clearly,
line 6085-->    I'll love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.
line 6086-->  HELENA. If it appear not plain, and prove untrue,
line 6087-->    Deadly divorce step between me and you!
line 6088-->    O my dear mother, do I see you living?
line 6089-->  LAFEU. Mine eyes smell onions; I shall weep anon. [To PAROLLES]
line 6090-->    Good Tom Drum, lend me a handkercher. So, I
line 6091-->    thank thee. Wait on me home, I'll make sport with thee;  
line 6092-->    let thy curtsies alone, they are scurvy ones.
line 6093-->  KING. Let us from point to point this story know,
line 6094-->    To make the even truth in pleasure flow.
line 6095-->    [To DIANA]  If thou beest yet a fresh uncropped flower,
line 6096-->    Choose thou thy husband, and I'll pay thy dower;
line 6097-->    For I can guess that by thy honest aid
line 6098-->    Thou kept'st a wife herself, thyself a maid.-
line 6099-->    Of that and all the progress, more and less,
line 6100-->    Resolvedly more leisure shall express.
line 6101-->    All yet seems well; and if it end so meet,
line 6102-->    The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet.       [Flourish]
line 6103-->
line 6104-->EPILOGUE
line 6105-->                             EPILOGUE.
line 6106-->
line 6107-->  KING. The King's a beggar, now the play is done.
line 6108-->    All is well ended if this suit be won,
line 6109-->    That you express content; which we will pay
line 6110-->    With strife to please you, day exceeding day.
line 6111-->    Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts;
line 6112-->    Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts.
line 6113-->                                                    Exeunt omnes
line 6114-->
line 6115-->
line 6116-->THE END
