line 6197-->SCENE:
line 6198-->The Roman Empire
line 6199-->
line 6200-->ACT I. SCENE I.
line 6201-->Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palace
line 6202-->
line 6203-->Enter DEMETRIUS and PHILO
line 6204-->
line 6205-->  PHILO. Nay, but this dotage of our general's
line 6206-->    O'erflows the measure. Those his goodly eyes,
line 6207-->    That o'er the files and musters of the war
line 6208-->    Have glow'd like plated Mars, now bend, now turn,
line 6209-->    The office and devotion of their view
line 6210-->    Upon a tawny front. His captain's heart,
line 6211-->    Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst
line 6212-->    The buckles on his breast, reneges all temper,
line 6213-->    And is become the bellows and the fan
line 6214-->    To cool a gipsy's lust.
line 6215-->
line 6216-->     Flourish. Enter ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, her LADIES, the train,
line 6217-->                    with eunuchs fanning her
line 6218-->
line 6219-->    Look where they come!
line 6220-->    Take but good note, and you shall see in him
line 6221-->    The triple pillar of the world transform'd  
line 6222-->    Into a strumpet's fool. Behold and see.
line 6223-->  CLEOPATRA. If it be love indeed, tell me how much.
line 6224-->  ANTONY. There's beggary in the love that can be reckon'd.
line 6225-->  CLEOPATRA. I'll set a bourn how far to be belov'd.
line 6226-->  ANTONY. Then must thou needs find out new heaven, new earth.
line 6227-->
line 6228-->                       Enter a MESSENGER
line 6229-->
line 6230-->  MESSENGER. News, my good lord, from Rome.
line 6231-->  ANTONY. Grates me the sum.
line 6232-->  CLEOPATRA. Nay, hear them, Antony.
line 6233-->    Fulvia perchance is angry; or who knows
line 6234-->    If the scarce-bearded Caesar have not sent
line 6235-->    His pow'rful mandate to you: 'Do this or this;
line 6236-->    Take in that kingdom and enfranchise that;
line 6237-->    Perform't, or else we damn thee.'
line 6238-->  ANTONY. How, my love?
line 6239-->  CLEOPATRA. Perchance? Nay, and most like,
line 6240-->    You must not stay here longer; your dismission
line 6241-->    Is come from Caesar; therefore hear it, Antony.  
line 6242-->    Where's Fulvia's process? Caesar's I would say? Both?
line 6243-->    Call in the messengers. As I am Egypt's Queen,
line 6244-->    Thou blushest, Antony, and that blood of thine
line 6245-->    Is Caesar's homager. Else so thy cheek pays shame
line 6246-->    When shrill-tongu'd Fulvia scolds. The messengers!
line 6247-->  ANTONY. Let Rome in Tiber melt, and the wide arch
line 6248-->    Of the rang'd empire fall! Here is my space.
line 6249-->    Kingdoms are clay; our dungy earth alike
line 6250-->    Feeds beast as man. The nobleness of life
line 6251-->    Is to do thus [emhracing], when such a mutual pair
line 6252-->    And such a twain can do't, in which I bind,
line 6253-->    On pain of punishment, the world to weet
line 6254-->    We stand up peerless.
line 6255-->  CLEOPATRA. Excellent falsehood!
line 6256-->    Why did he marry Fulvia, and not love her?
line 6257-->    I'll seem the fool I am not. Antony
line 6258-->    Will be himself.
line 6259-->  ANTONY. But stirr'd by Cleopatra.
line 6260-->    Now for the love of Love and her soft hours,
line 6261-->    Let's not confound the time with conference harsh;  
line 6262-->    There's not a minute of our lives should stretch
line 6263-->    Without some pleasure now. What sport to-night?
line 6264-->  CLEOPATRA. Hear the ambassadors.
line 6265-->  ANTONY. Fie, wrangling queen!
line 6266-->    Whom everything becomes- to chide, to laugh,
line 6267-->    To weep; whose every passion fully strives
line 6268-->    To make itself in thee fair and admir'd.
line 6269-->    No messenger but thine, and all alone
line 6270-->    To-night we'll wander through the streets and note
line 6271-->    The qualities of people. Come, my queen;
line 6272-->    Last night you did desire it. Speak not to us.
line 6273-->                     Exeunt ANTONY and CLEOPATRA, with the train
line 6274-->  DEMETRIUS. Is Caesar with Antonius priz'd so slight?
line 6275-->  PHILO. Sir, sometimes when he is not Antony,
line 6276-->    He comes too short of that great property
line 6277-->    Which still should go with Antony.
line 6278-->  DEMETRIUS. I am full sorry
line 6279-->    That he approves the common liar, who
line 6280-->    Thus speaks of him at Rome; but I will hope
line 6281-->    Of better deeds to-morrow. Rest you happy!            Exeunt
line 6282-->
line 6283-->
line 6284-->
line 6285-->
line 6286-->SCENE II.
line 6287-->Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palace
line 6288-->
line 6289-->Enter CHARMIAN, IRAS, ALEXAS, and a SOOTHSAYER
line 6290-->
line 6291-->  CHARMIAN. Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most anything Alexas, almost
line 6292-->    most absolute Alexas, where's the soothsayer that you prais'd so
line 6293-->    to th' Queen? O that I knew this husband, which you say must
line 6294-->    charge his horns with garlands!
line 6295-->  ALEXAS. Soothsayer!
line 6296-->  SOOTHSAYER. Your will?
line 6297-->  CHARMIAN. Is this the man? Is't you, sir, that know things?
line 6298-->  SOOTHSAYER. In nature's infinite book of secrecy
line 6299-->    A little I can read.
line 6300-->  ALEXAS. Show him your hand.
line 6301-->
line 6302-->                       Enter ENOBARBUS
line 6303-->
line 6304-->  ENOBARBUS. Bring in the banquet quickly; wine enough
line 6305-->    Cleopatra's health to drink.
line 6306-->  CHARMIAN. Good, sir, give me good fortune.
line 6307-->  SOOTHSAYER. I make not, but foresee.  
line 6308-->  CHARMIAN. Pray, then, foresee me one.
line 6309-->  SOOTHSAYER. You shall be yet far fairer than you are.
line 6310-->  CHARMIAN. He means in flesh.
line 6311-->  IRAS. No, you shall paint when you are old.
line 6312-->  CHARMIAN. Wrinkles forbid!
line 6313-->  ALEXAS. Vex not his prescience; be attentive.
line 6314-->  CHARMIAN. Hush!
line 6315-->  SOOTHSAYER. You shall be more beloving than beloved.
line 6316-->  CHARMIAN. I had rather heat my liver with drinking.
line 6317-->  ALEXAS. Nay, hear him.
line 6318-->  CHARMIAN. Good now, some excellent fortune! Let me be married to
line 6319-->    three kings in a forenoon, and widow them all. Let me have a
line 6320-->    child at fifty, to whom Herod of Jewry may do homage. Find me to
line 6321-->    marry me with Octavius Caesar, and companion me with my mistress.
line 6322-->  SOOTHSAYER. You shall outlive the lady whom you serve.
line 6323-->  CHARMIAN. O, excellent! I love long life better than figs.
line 6324-->  SOOTHSAYER. You have seen and prov'd a fairer former fortune
line 6325-->    Than that which is to approach.
line 6326-->  CHARMIAN. Then belike my children shall have no names.
line 6327-->    Prithee, how many boys and wenches must I have?  
line 6328-->  SOOTHSAYER. If every of your wishes had a womb,
line 6329-->    And fertile every wish, a million.
line 6330-->  CHARMIAN. Out, fool! I forgive thee for a witch.
line 6331-->  ALEXAS. You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes.
line 6332-->  CHARMIAN. Nay, come, tell Iras hers.
line 6333-->  ALEXAS. We'll know all our fortunes.
line 6334-->  ENOBARBUS. Mine, and most of our fortunes, to-night, shall be-
line 6335-->    drunk to bed.
line 6336-->  IRAS. There's a palm presages chastity, if nothing else.
line 6337-->  CHARMIAN. E'en as the o'erflowing Nilus presageth famine.
line 6338-->  IRAS. Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot soothsay.
line 6339-->  CHARMIAN. Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful prognostication, I
line 6340-->    cannot scratch mine ear. Prithee, tell her but worky-day fortune.
line 6341-->  SOOTHSAYER. Your fortunes are alike.
line 6342-->  IRAS. But how, but how? Give me particulars.
line 6343-->  SOOTHSAYER. I have said.
line 6344-->  IRAS. Am I not an inch of fortune better than she?
line 6345-->  CHARMIAN. Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better than I,
line 6346-->    where would you choose it?
line 6347-->  IRAS. Not in my husband's nose.  
line 6348-->  CHARMIAN. Our worser thoughts heavens mend! Alexas- come, his
line 6349-->    fortune, his fortune! O, let him marry a woman that cannot go,
line 6350-->    sweet Isis, I beseech thee! And let her die too, and give him a
line 6351-->    worse! And let worse follow worse, till the worst of all follow
line 6352-->    him laughing to his grave, fiftyfold a cuckold! Good Isis, hear
line 6353-->    me this prayer, though thou deny me a matter of more weight; good
line 6354-->    Isis, I beseech thee!
line 6355-->  IRAS. Amen. Dear goddess, hear that prayer of the people! For, as
line 6356-->    it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome man loose-wiv'd, so it is
line 6357-->    a deadly sorrow to behold a foul knave uncuckolded. Therefore,
line 6358-->    dear Isis, keep decorum, and fortune him accordingly!
line 6359-->  CHARMIAN. Amen.
line 6360-->  ALEXAS. Lo now, if it lay in their hands to make me a cuckold, they
line 6361-->    would make themselves whores but they'ld do't!
line 6362-->
line 6363-->                          Enter CLEOPATRA
line 6364-->
line 6365-->  ENOBARBUS. Hush! Here comes Antony.
line 6366-->  CHARMIAN. Not he; the Queen.
line 6367-->  CLEOPATRA. Saw you my lord?  
line 6368-->  ENOBARBUS. No, lady.
line 6369-->  CLEOPATRA. Was he not here?
line 6370-->  CHARMIAN. No, madam.
line 6371-->  CLEOPATRA. He was dispos'd to mirth; but on the sudden
line 6372-->    A Roman thought hath struck him. Enobarbus!
line 6373-->  ENOBARBUS. Madam?
line 6374-->  CLEOPATRA. Seek him, and bring him hither. Where's Alexas?
line 6375-->  ALEXAS. Here, at your service. My lord approaches.
line 6376-->
line 6377-->          Enter ANTONY, with a MESSENGER and attendants
line 6378-->
line 6379-->  CLEOPATRA. We will not look upon him. Go with us.
line 6380-->                       Exeunt CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, and the rest
line 6381-->  MESSENGER. Fulvia thy wife first came into the field.
line 6382-->  ANTONY. Against my brother Lucius?
line 6383-->  MESSENGER. Ay.
line 6384-->    But soon that war had end, and the time's state
line 6385-->    Made friends of them, jointing their force 'gainst Caesar,
line 6386-->    Whose better issue in the war from Italy
line 6387-->    Upon the first encounter drave them.  
line 6388-->  ANTONY. Well, what worst?
line 6389-->  MESSENGER. The nature of bad news infects the teller.
line 6390-->  ANTONY. When it concerns the fool or coward. On!
line 6391-->    Things that are past are done with me. 'Tis thus:
line 6392-->    Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death,
line 6393-->    I hear him as he flatter'd.
line 6394-->  MESSENGER. Labienus-
line 6395-->    This is stiff news- hath with his Parthian force
line 6396-->    Extended Asia from Euphrates,
line 6397-->    His conquering banner shook from Syria
line 6398-->    To Lydia and to Ionia,
line 6399-->    Whilst-
line 6400-->  ANTONY. Antony, thou wouldst say.
line 6401-->  MESSENGER. O, my lord!
line 6402-->  ANTONY. Speak to me home; mince not the general tongue;
line 6403-->    Name Cleopatra as she is call'd in Rome.
line 6404-->    Rail thou in Fulvia's phrase, and taunt my faults
line 6405-->    With such full licence as both truth and malice
line 6406-->    Have power to utter. O, then we bring forth weeds
line 6407-->    When our quick minds lie still, and our ills told us  
line 6408-->    Is as our earing. Fare thee well awhile.
line 6409-->  MESSENGER. At your noble pleasure.                        Exit
line 6410-->  ANTONY. From Sicyon, ho, the news! Speak there!
line 6411-->  FIRST ATTENDANT. The man from Sicyon- is there such an one?
line 6412-->  SECOND ATTENDANT. He stays upon your will.
line 6413-->  ANTONY. Let him appear.
line 6414-->    These strong Egyptian fetters I must break,
line 6415-->    Or lose myself in dotage.
line 6416-->
line 6417-->                 Enter another MESSENGER with a letter
line 6418-->
line 6419-->    What are you?
line 6420-->  SECOND MESSENGER. Fulvia thy wife is dead.
line 6421-->  ANTONY. Where died she?
line 6422-->  SECOND MESSENGER. In Sicyon.
line 6423-->    Her length of sickness, with what else more serious
line 6424-->    Importeth thee to know, this bears.       [Gives the letter]
line 6425-->  ANTONY. Forbear me.                             Exit MESSENGER
line 6426-->    There's a great spirit gone! Thus did I desire it.
line 6427-->    What our contempts doth often hurl from us  
line 6428-->    We wish it ours again; the present pleasure,
line 6429-->    By revolution low'ring, does become
line 6430-->    The opposite of itself. She's good, being gone;
line 6431-->    The hand could pluck her back that shov'd her on.
line 6432-->    I must from this enchanting queen break off.
line 6433-->    Ten thousand harms, more than the ills I know,
line 6434-->    My idleness doth hatch. How now, Enobarbus!
line 6435-->
line 6436-->                    Re-enter ENOBARBUS
line 6437-->
line 6438-->  ENOBARBUS. What's your pleasure, sir?
line 6439-->  ANTONY. I must with haste from hence.
line 6440-->  ENOBARBUS. Why, then we kill all our women. We see how mortal an
line 6441-->    unkindness is to them; if they suffer our departure, death's the
line 6442-->    word.
line 6443-->  ANTONY. I must be gone.
line 6444-->  ENOBARBUS. Under a compelling occasion, let women die. It were pity
line 6445-->    to cast them away for nothing, though between them and a great
line 6446-->    cause they should be esteemed nothing. Cleopatra, catching but
line 6447-->    the least noise of this, dies instantly; I have seen her die  
line 6448-->    twenty times upon far poorer moment. I do think there is mettle
line 6449-->    in death, which commits some loving act upon her, she hath such a
line 6450-->    celerity in dying.
line 6451-->  ANTONY. She is cunning past man's thought.
line 6452-->  ENOBARBUS. Alack, sir, no! Her passions are made of nothing but the
line 6453-->    finest part of pure love. We cannot call her winds and waters
line 6454-->    sighs and tears; they are greater storms and tempests than
line 6455-->    almanacs can report. This cannot be cunning in her; if it be, she
line 6456-->    makes a show'r of rain as well as Jove.
line 6457-->  ANTONY. Would I had never seen her!
line 6458-->  ENOBARBUS. O Sir, you had then left unseen a wonderful piece of
line 6459-->    work, which not to have been blest withal would have discredited
line 6460-->    your travel.
line 6461-->  ANTONY. Fulvia is dead.
line 6462-->  ENOBARBUS. Sir?
line 6463-->  ANTONY. Fulvia is dead.
line 6464-->  ENOBARBUS. Fulvia?
line 6465-->  ANTONY. Dead.
line 6466-->  ENOBARBUS. Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice. When it
line 6467-->    pleaseth their deities to take the wife of a man from him, it  
line 6468-->    shows to man the tailors of the earth; comforting therein that
line 6469-->    when old robes are worn out there are members to make new. If
line 6470-->    there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut,
line 6471-->    and the case to be lamented. This grief is crown'd with
line 6472-->    consolation: your old smock brings forth a new petticoat; and
line 6473-->    indeed the tears live in an onion that should water this sorrow.
line 6474-->  ANTONY. The business she hath broached in the state
line 6475-->    Cannot endure my absence.
line 6476-->  ENOBARBUS. And the business you have broach'd here cannot be
line 6477-->    without you; especially that of Cleopatra's, which wholly depends
line 6478-->    on your abode.
line 6479-->  ANTONY. No more light answers. Let our officers
line 6480-->    Have notice what we purpose. I shall break
line 6481-->    The cause of our expedience to the Queen,
line 6482-->    And get her leave to part. For not alone
line 6483-->    The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches,
line 6484-->    Do strongly speak to us; but the letters to
line 6485-->    Of many our contriving friends in Rome
line 6486-->    Petition us at home. Sextus Pompeius
line 6487-->    Hath given the dare to Caesar, and commands  
line 6488-->    The empire of the sea; our slippery people,
line 6489-->    Whose love is never link'd to the deserver
line 6490-->    Till his deserts are past, begin to throw
line 6491-->    Pompey the Great and all his dignities
line 6492-->    Upon his son; who, high in name and power,
line 6493-->    Higher than both in blood and life, stands up
line 6494-->    For the main soldier; whose quality, going on,
line 6495-->    The sides o' th' world may danger. Much is breeding
line 6496-->    Which, like the courser's hair, hath yet but life
line 6497-->    And not a serpent's poison. Say our pleasure,
line 6498-->    To such whose place is under us, requires
line 6499-->    Our quick remove from hence.
line 6500-->  ENOBARBUS. I shall do't.                                Exeunt
line 6501-->
line 6502-->
line 6503-->
line 6504-->
line 6505-->SCENE III.
line 6506-->Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palace
line 6507-->
line 6508-->Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS
line 6509-->
line 6510-->  CLEOPATRA. Where is he?
line 6511-->  CHARMIAN. I did not see him since.
line 6512-->  CLEOPATRA. See where he is, who's with him, what he does.
line 6513-->    I did not send you. If you find him sad,
line 6514-->    Say I am dancing; if in mirth, report
line 6515-->    That I am sudden sick. Quick, and return.        Exit ALEXAS
line 6516-->  CHARMIAN. Madam, methinks, if you did love him dearly,
line 6517-->    You do not hold the method to enforce
line 6518-->    The like from him.
line 6519-->  CLEOPATRA. What should I do I do not?
line 6520-->  CHARMIAN. In each thing give him way; cross him in nothing.
line 6521-->  CLEOPATRA. Thou teachest like a fool- the way to lose him.
line 6522-->  CHARMIAN. Tempt him not so too far; I wish, forbear;
line 6523-->    In time we hate that which we often fear.
line 6524-->
line 6525-->                            Enter ANTONY
line 6526-->  
line 6527-->    But here comes Antony.
line 6528-->  CLEOPATRA. I am sick and sullen.
line 6529-->  ANTONY. I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose-
line 6530-->  CLEOPATRA. Help me away, dear Charmian; I shall fall.
line 6531-->    It cannot be thus long; the sides of nature
line 6532-->    Will not sustain it.
line 6533-->  ANTONY. Now, my dearest queen-
line 6534-->  CLEOPATRA. Pray you, stand farther from me.
line 6535-->  ANTONY. What's the matter?
line 6536-->  CLEOPATRA. I know by that same eye there's some good news.
line 6537-->    What says the married woman? You may go.
line 6538-->    Would she had never given you leave to come!
line 6539-->    Let her not say 'tis I that keep you here-
line 6540-->    I have no power upon you; hers you are.
line 6541-->  ANTONY. The gods best know-
line 6542-->  CLEOPATRA. O, never was there queen
line 6543-->    So mightily betray'd! Yet at the first
line 6544-->    I saw the treasons planted.
line 6545-->  ANTONY. Cleopatra-
line 6546-->  CLEOPATRA. Why should I think you can be mine and true,  
line 6547-->    Though you in swearing shake the throned gods,
line 6548-->    Who have been false to Fulvia? Riotous madness,
line 6549-->    To be entangled with those mouth-made vows,
line 6550-->    Which break themselves in swearing!
line 6551-->  ANTONY. Most sweet queen-
line 6552-->  CLEOPATRA. Nay, pray you seek no colour for your going,
line 6553-->    But bid farewell, and go. When you sued staying,
line 6554-->    Then was the time for words. No going then!
line 6555-->    Eternity was in our lips and eyes,
line 6556-->    Bliss in our brows' bent, none our parts so poor
line 6557-->    But was a race of heaven. They are so still,
line 6558-->    Or thou, the greatest soldier of the world,
line 6559-->    Art turn'd the greatest liar.
line 6560-->  ANTONY. How now, lady!
line 6561-->  CLEOPATRA. I would I had thy inches. Thou shouldst know
line 6562-->    There were a heart in Egypt.
line 6563-->  ANTONY. Hear me, queen:
line 6564-->    The strong necessity of time commands
line 6565-->    Our services awhile; but my full heart
line 6566-->    Remains in use with you. Our Italy  
line 6567-->    Shines o'er with civil swords: Sextus Pompeius
line 6568-->    Makes his approaches to the port of Rome;
line 6569-->    Equality of two domestic powers
line 6570-->    Breed scrupulous faction; the hated, grown to strength,
line 6571-->    Are newly grown to love. The condemn'd Pompey,
line 6572-->    Rich in his father's honour, creeps apace
line 6573-->    Into the hearts of such as have not thrived
line 6574-->    Upon the present state, whose numbers threaten;
line 6575-->    And quietness, grown sick of rest, would purge
line 6576-->    By any desperate change. My more particular,
line 6577-->    And that which most with you should safe my going,
line 6578-->    Is Fulvia's death.
line 6579-->  CLEOPATRA. Though age from folly could not give me freedom,
line 6580-->     It does from childishness. Can Fulvia die?
line 6581-->  ANTONY. She's dead, my Queen.
line 6582-->    Look here, and at thy sovereign leisure read
line 6583-->    The garboils she awak'd. At the last, best.
line 6584-->    See when and where she died.
line 6585-->  CLEOPATRA. O most false love!
line 6586-->    Where be the sacred vials thou shouldst fill  
line 6587-->    With sorrowful water? Now I see, I see,
line 6588-->    In Fulvia's death how mine receiv'd shall be.
line 6589-->  ANTONY. Quarrel no more, but be prepar'd to know
line 6590-->    The purposes I bear; which are, or cease,
line 6591-->    As you shall give th' advice. By the fire
line 6592-->    That quickens Nilus' slime, I go from hence
line 6593-->    Thy soldier, servant, making peace or war
line 6594-->    As thou affects.
line 6595-->  CLEOPATRA. Cut my lace, Charmian, come!
line 6596-->    But let it be; I am quickly ill and well-
line 6597-->    So Antony loves.
line 6598-->  ANTONY. My precious queen, forbear,
line 6599-->    And give true evidence to his love, which stands
line 6600-->    An honourable trial.
line 6601-->  CLEOPATRA. So Fulvia told me.
line 6602-->    I prithee turn aside and weep for her;
line 6603-->    Then bid adieu to me, and say the tears
line 6604-->    Belong to Egypt. Good now, play one scene
line 6605-->    Of excellent dissembling, and let it look
line 6606-->    Like perfect honour.  
line 6607-->  ANTONY. You'll heat my blood; no more.
line 6608-->  CLEOPATRA. You can do better yet; but this is meetly.
line 6609-->  ANTONY. Now, by my sword-
line 6610-->  CLEOPATRA. And target. Still he mends;
line 6611-->    But this is not the best. Look, prithee, Charmian,
line 6612-->    How this Herculean Roman does become
line 6613-->    The carriage of his chafe.
line 6614-->  ANTONY. I'll leave you, lady.
line 6615-->  CLEOPATRA. Courteous lord, one word.
line 6616-->    Sir, you and I must part- but that's not it.
line 6617-->    Sir, you and I have lov'd- but there's not it.
line 6618-->    That you know well. Something it is I would-
line 6619-->    O, my oblivion is a very Antony,
line 6620-->    And I am all forgotten!
line 6621-->  ANTONY. But that your royalty
line 6622-->    Holds idleness your subject, I should take you
line 6623-->    For idleness itself.
line 6624-->  CLEOPATRA. 'Tis sweating labour
line 6625-->    To bear such idleness so near the heart
line 6626-->    As Cleopatra this. But, sir, forgive me;  
line 6627-->    Since my becomings kill me when they do not
line 6628-->    Eye well to you. Your honour calls you hence;
line 6629-->    Therefore be deaf to my unpitied folly,
line 6630-->    And all the gods go with you! Upon your sword
line 6631-->    Sit laurel victory, and smooth success
line 6632-->    Be strew'd before your feet!
line 6633-->  ANTONY. Let us go. Come.
line 6634-->    Our separation so abides and flies
line 6635-->    That thou, residing here, goes yet with me,
line 6636-->    And I, hence fleeting, here remain with thee.
line 6637-->    Away!                                                 Exeunt
line 6638-->
line 6639-->
line 6640-->
line 6641-->
line 6642-->SCENE IV.
line 6643-->Rome. CAESAR'S house
line 6644-->
line 6645-->Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, reading a letter; LEPIDUS, and their train
line 6646-->
line 6647-->  CAESAR. You may see, Lepidus, and henceforth know,
line 6648-->    It is not Caesar's natural vice to hate
line 6649-->    Our great competitor. From Alexandria
line 6650-->    This is the news: he fishes, drinks, and wastes
line 6651-->    The lamps of night in revel; is not more manlike
line 6652-->    Than Cleopatra, nor the queen of Ptolemy
line 6653-->    More womanly than he; hardly gave audience, or
line 6654-->    Vouchsaf'd to think he had partners. You shall find there
line 6655-->    A man who is the abstract of all faults
line 6656-->    That all men follow.
line 6657-->  LEPIDUS. I must not think there are
line 6658-->    Evils enow to darken all his goodness.
line 6659-->    His faults, in him, seem as the spots of heaven,
line 6660-->    More fiery by night's blackness; hereditary
line 6661-->    Rather than purchas'd; what he cannot change
line 6662-->    Than what he chooses.  
line 6663-->  CAESAR. You are too indulgent. Let's grant it is not
line 6664-->    Amiss to tumble on the bed of Ptolemy,
line 6665-->    To give a kingdom for a mirth, to sit
line 6666-->    And keep the turn of tippling with a slave,
line 6667-->    To reel the streets at noon, and stand the buffet
line 6668-->    With knaves that smell of sweat. Say this becomes him-
line 6669-->    As his composure must be rare indeed
line 6670-->    Whom these things cannot blemish- yet must Antony
line 6671-->    No way excuse his foils when we do bear
line 6672-->    So great weight in his lightness. If he fill'd
line 6673-->    His vacancy with his voluptuousness,
line 6674-->    Full surfeits and the dryness of his bones
line 6675-->    Call on him for't! But to confound such time
line 6676-->    That drums him from his sport and speaks as loud
line 6677-->    As his own state and ours- 'tis to be chid
line 6678-->    As we rate boys who, being mature in knowledge,
line 6679-->    Pawn their experience to their present pleasure,
line 6680-->    And so rebel to judgment.
line 6681-->
line 6682-->                   Enter a MESSENGER  
line 6683-->
line 6684-->  LEPIDUS. Here's more news.
line 6685-->  MESSENGER. Thy biddings have been done; and every hour,
line 6686-->    Most noble Caesar, shalt thou have report
line 6687-->    How 'tis abroad. Pompey is strong at sea,
line 6688-->    And it appears he is belov'd of those
line 6689-->    That only have fear'd Caesar. To the ports
line 6690-->    The discontents repair, and men's reports
line 6691-->    Give him much wrong'd.
line 6692-->  CAESAR. I should have known no less.
line 6693-->    It hath been taught us from the primal state
line 6694-->    That he which is was wish'd until he were;
line 6695-->    And the ebb'd man, ne'er lov'd till ne'er worth love,
line 6696-->    Comes dear'd by being lack'd. This common body,
line 6697-->    Like to a vagabond flag upon the stream,
line 6698-->    Goes to and back, lackeying the varying tide,
line 6699-->    To rot itself with motion.
line 6700-->  MESSENGER. Caesar, I bring thee word
line 6701-->    Menecrates and Menas, famous pirates,
line 6702-->    Make the sea serve them, which they ear and wound  
line 6703-->    With keels of every kind. Many hot inroads
line 6704-->    They make in Italy; the borders maritime
line 6705-->    Lack blood to think on't, and flush youth revolt.
line 6706-->    No vessel can peep forth but 'tis as soon
line 6707-->    Taken as seen; for Pompey's name strikes more
line 6708-->    Than could his war resisted.
line 6709-->  CAESAR. Antony,
line 6710-->    Leave thy lascivious wassails. When thou once
line 6711-->    Was beaten from Modena, where thou slew'st
line 6712-->    Hirtius and Pansa, consuls, at thy heel
line 6713-->    Did famine follow; whom thou fought'st against,
line 6714-->    Though daintily brought up, with patience more
line 6715-->    Than savages could suffer. Thou didst drink
line 6716-->    The stale of horses and the gilded puddle
line 6717-->    Which beasts would cough at. Thy palate then did deign
line 6718-->    The roughest berry on the rudest hedge;
line 6719-->    Yea, like the stag when snow the pasture sheets,
line 6720-->    The barks of trees thou brows'd. On the Alps
line 6721-->    It is reported thou didst eat strange flesh,
line 6722-->    Which some did die to look on. And all this-  
line 6723-->    It wounds thine honour that I speak it now-
line 6724-->    Was borne so like a soldier that thy cheek
line 6725-->    So much as lank'd not.
line 6726-->  LEPIDUS. 'Tis pity of him.
line 6727-->  CAESAR. Let his shames quickly
line 6728-->    Drive him to Rome. 'Tis time we twain
line 6729-->    Did show ourselves i' th' field; and to that end
line 6730-->    Assemble we immediate council. Pompey
line 6731-->    Thrives in our idleness.
line 6732-->  LEPIDUS. To-morrow, Caesar,
line 6733-->    I shall be furnish'd to inform you rightly
line 6734-->    Both what by sea and land I can be able
line 6735-->    To front this present time.
line 6736-->  CAESAR. Till which encounter
line 6737-->    It is my business too. Farewell.
line 6738-->  LEPIDUS. Farewell, my lord. What you shall know meantime
line 6739-->    Of stirs abroad, I shall beseech you, sir,
line 6740-->    To let me be partaker.
line 6741-->  CAESAR. Doubt not, sir;
line 6742-->    I knew it for my bond.                                Exeunt
line 6743-->
line 6744-->
line 6745-->
line 6746-->
line 6747-->SCENE V.
line 6748-->Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palace
line 6749-->
line 6750-->Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN
line 6751-->
line 6752-->  CLEOPATRA. Charmian!
line 6753-->  CHARMIAN. Madam?
line 6754-->  CLEOPATRA. Ha, ha!
line 6755-->    Give me to drink mandragora.
line 6756-->  CHARMIAN. Why, madam?
line 6757-->  CLEOPATRA. That I might sleep out this great gap of time
line 6758-->    My Antony is away.
line 6759-->  CHARMIAN. You think of him too much.
line 6760-->  CLEOPATRA. O, 'tis treason!
line 6761-->  CHARMIAN. Madam, I trust, not so.
line 6762-->  CLEOPATRA. Thou, eunuch Mardian!
line 6763-->  MARDIAN. What's your Highness' pleasure?
line 6764-->  CLEOPATRA. Not now to hear thee sing; I take no pleasure
line 6765-->    In aught an eunuch has. 'Tis well for thee
line 6766-->    That, being unseminar'd, thy freer thoughts
line 6767-->    May not fly forth of Egypt. Hast thou affections?
line 6768-->  MARDIAN. Yes, gracious madam.  
line 6769-->  CLEOPATRA. Indeed?
line 6770-->  MARDIAN. Not in deed, madam; for I can do nothing
line 6771-->    But what indeed is honest to be done.
line 6772-->    Yet have I fierce affections, and think
line 6773-->    What Venus did with Mars.
line 6774-->  CLEOPATRA. O Charmian,
line 6775-->    Where think'st thou he is now? Stands he or sits he?
line 6776-->    Or does he walk? or is he on his horse?
line 6777-->    O happy horse, to bear the weight of Antony!
line 6778-->    Do bravely, horse; for wot'st thou whom thou mov'st?
line 6779-->    The demi-Atlas of this earth, the arm
line 6780-->    And burgonet of men. He's speaking now,
line 6781-->    Or murmuring 'Where's my serpent of old Nile?'
line 6782-->    For so he calls me. Now I feed myself
line 6783-->    With most delicious poison. Think on me,
line 6784-->    That am with Phoebus' amorous pinches black,
line 6785-->    And wrinkled deep in time? Broad-fronted Caesar,
line 6786-->    When thou wast here above the ground, I was
line 6787-->    A morsel for a monarch; and great Pompey
line 6788-->    Would stand and make his eyes grow in my brow;  
line 6789-->    There would he anchor his aspect and die
line 6790-->    With looking on his life.
line 6791-->
line 6792-->                         Enter ALEXAS
line 6793-->
line 6794-->  ALEXAS. Sovereign of Egypt, hail!
line 6795-->  CLEOPATRA. How much unlike art thou Mark Antony!
line 6796-->    Yet, coming from him, that great med'cine hath
line 6797-->    With his tinct gilded thee.
line 6798-->    How goes it with my brave Mark Antony?
line 6799-->  ALEXAS. Last thing he did, dear Queen,
line 6800-->    He kiss'd- the last of many doubled kisses-
line 6801-->    This orient pearl. His speech sticks in my heart.
line 6802-->  CLEOPATRA. Mine ear must pluck it thence.
line 6803-->  ALEXAS. 'Good friend,' quoth he
line 6804-->    'Say the firm Roman to great Egypt sends
line 6805-->    This treasure of an oyster; at whose foot,
line 6806-->    To mend the petty present, I will piece
line 6807-->    Her opulent throne with kingdoms. All the East,
line 6808-->    Say thou, shall call her mistress.' So he nodded,  
line 6809-->    And soberly did mount an arm-gaunt steed,
line 6810-->    Who neigh'd so high that what I would have spoke
line 6811-->    Was beastly dumb'd by him.
line 6812-->  CLEOPATRA. What, was he sad or merry?
line 6813-->  ALEXAS. Like to the time o' th' year between the extremes
line 6814-->    Of hot and cold; he was nor sad nor merry.
line 6815-->  CLEOPATRA. O well-divided disposition! Note him,
line 6816-->    Note him, good Charmian; 'tis the man; but note him!
line 6817-->    He was not sad, for he would shine on those
line 6818-->    That make their looks by his; he was not merry,
line 6819-->    Which seem'd to tell them his remembrance lay
line 6820-->    In Egypt with his joy; but between both.
line 6821-->    O heavenly mingle! Be'st thou sad or merry,
line 6822-->    The violence of either thee becomes,
line 6823-->    So does it no man else. Met'st thou my posts?
line 6824-->  ALEXAS. Ay, madam, twenty several messengers.
line 6825-->    Why do you send so thick?
line 6826-->  CLEOPATRA. Who's born that day
line 6827-->    When I forget to send to Antony
line 6828-->    Shall die a beggar. Ink and paper, Charmian.  
line 6829-->    Welcome, my good Alexas. Did I, Charmian,
line 6830-->    Ever love Caesar so?
line 6831-->  CHARMIAN. O that brave Caesar!
line 6832-->  CLEOPATRA. Be chok'd with such another emphasis!
line 6833-->    Say 'the brave Antony.'
line 6834-->  CHARMIAN. The valiant Caesar!
line 6835-->  CLEOPATRA. By Isis, I will give thee bloody teeth
line 6836-->    If thou with Caesar paragon again
line 6837-->    My man of men.
line 6838-->  CHARMIAN. By your most gracious pardon,
line 6839-->    I sing but after you.
line 6840-->  CLEOPATRA. My salad days,
line 6841-->    When I was green in judgment, cold in blood,
line 6842-->    To say as I said then. But come, away!
line 6843-->    Get me ink and paper.
line 6844-->    He shall have every day a several greeting,
line 6845-->    Or I'll unpeople Egypt.                               Exeunt
line 6846-->
line 6847-->

line 6859-->
line 6860-->
line 6861-->ACT II. SCENE I.
line 6862-->Messina. POMPEY'S house
line 6863-->
line 6864-->Enter POMPEY, MENECRATES, and MENAS, in warlike manner
line 6865-->
line 6866-->  POMPEY. If the great gods be just, they shall assist
line 6867-->    The deeds of justest men.
line 6868-->  MENECRATES. Know, worthy Pompey,
line 6869-->    That what they do delay they not deny.
line 6870-->  POMPEY. Whiles we are suitors to their throne, decays
line 6871-->    The thing we sue for.
line 6872-->  MENECRATES. We, ignorant of ourselves,
line 6873-->    Beg often our own harms, which the wise pow'rs
line 6874-->    Deny us for our good; so find we profit
line 6875-->    By losing of our prayers.
line 6876-->  POMPEY. I shall do well.
line 6877-->    The people love me, and the sea is mine;
line 6878-->    My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope
line 6879-->    Says it will come to th' full. Mark Antony
line 6880-->    In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make
line 6881-->    No wars without doors. Caesar gets money where  
line 6882-->    He loses hearts. Lepidus flatters both,
line 6883-->    Of both is flatter'd; but he neither loves,
line 6884-->    Nor either cares for him.
line 6885-->  MENAS. Caesar and Lepidus
line 6886-->    Are in the field. A mighty strength they carry.
line 6887-->  POMPEY. Where have you this? 'Tis false.
line 6888-->  MENAS. From Silvius, sir.
line 6889-->  POMPEY. He dreams. I know they are in Rome together,
line 6890-->    Looking for Antony. But all the charms of love,
line 6891-->    Salt Cleopatra, soften thy wan'd lip!
line 6892-->    Let witchcraft join with beauty, lust with both;
line 6893-->    Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts,
line 6894-->    Keep his brain fuming. Epicurean cooks
line 6895-->    Sharpen with cloyless sauce his appetite,
line 6896-->    That sleep and feeding may prorogue his honour
line 6897-->    Even till a Lethe'd dullness-
line 6898-->
line 6899-->                       Enter VARRIUS
line 6900-->
line 6901-->    How now, Varrius!  
line 6902-->  VARRIUS. This is most certain that I shall deliver:
line 6903-->    Mark Antony is every hour in Rome
line 6904-->    Expected. Since he went from Egypt 'tis
line 6905-->    A space for farther travel.
line 6906-->  POMPEY. I could have given less matter
line 6907-->    A better ear. Menas, I did not think
line 6908-->    This amorous surfeiter would have donn'd his helm
line 6909-->    For such a petty war; his soldiership
line 6910-->    Is twice the other twain. But let us rear
line 6911-->    The higher our opinion, that our stirring
line 6912-->    Can from the lap of Egypt's widow pluck
line 6913-->    The ne'er-lust-wearied Antony.
line 6914-->  MENAS. I cannot hope
line 6915-->    Caesar and Antony shall well greet together.
line 6916-->    His wife that's dead did trespasses to Caesar;
line 6917-->    His brother warr'd upon him; although, I think,
line 6918-->    Not mov'd by Antony.
line 6919-->  POMPEY. I know not, Menas,
line 6920-->    How lesser enmities may give way to greater.
line 6921-->    Were't not that we stand up against them all,  
line 6922-->    'Twere pregnant they should square between themselves;
line 6923-->    For they have entertained cause enough
line 6924-->    To draw their swords. But how the fear of us
line 6925-->    May cement their divisions, and bind up
line 6926-->    The petty difference we yet not know.
line 6927-->    Be't as our gods will have't! It only stands
line 6928-->    Our lives upon to use our strongest hands.
line 6929-->    Come, Menas.                                          Exeunt
line 6930-->
line 6931-->
line 6932-->
line 6933-->
line 6934-->SCENE II.
line 6935-->Rome. The house of LEPIDUS
line 6936-->
line 6937-->Enter ENOBARBUS and LEPIDUS
line 6938-->
line 6939-->  LEPIDUS. Good Enobarbus, 'tis a worthy deed,
line 6940-->    And shall become you well, to entreat your captain
line 6941-->    To soft and gentle speech.
line 6942-->  ENOBARBUS. I shall entreat him
line 6943-->    To answer like himself. If Caesar move him,
line 6944-->    Let Antony look over Caesar's head
line 6945-->    And speak as loud as Mars. By Jupiter,
line 6946-->    Were I the wearer of Antonius' beard,
line 6947-->    I would not shave't to-day.
line 6948-->  LEPIDUS. 'Tis not a time
line 6949-->    For private stomaching.
line 6950-->  ENOBARBUS. Every time
line 6951-->    Serves for the matter that is then born in't.
line 6952-->  LEPIDUS. But small to greater matters must give way.
line 6953-->  ENOBARBUS. Not if the small come first.
line 6954-->  LEPIDUS. Your speech is passion;
line 6955-->    But pray you stir no embers up. Here comes  
line 6956-->    The noble Antony.
line 6957-->
line 6958-->                Enter ANTONY and VENTIDIUS
line 6959-->
line 6960-->  ENOBARBUS. And yonder, Caesar.
line 6961-->
line 6962-->            Enter CAESAR, MAECENAS, and AGRIPPA
line 6963-->
line 6964-->  ANTONY. If we compose well here, to Parthia.
line 6965-->    Hark, Ventidius.
line 6966-->  CAESAR. I do not know, Maecenas. Ask Agrippa.
line 6967-->  LEPIDUS. Noble friends,
line 6968-->    That which combin'd us was most great, and let not
line 6969-->    A leaner action rend us. What's amiss,
line 6970-->    May it be gently heard. When we debate
line 6971-->    Our trivial difference loud, we do commit
line 6972-->    Murder in healing wounds. Then, noble partners,
line 6973-->    The rather for I earnestly beseech,
line 6974-->    Touch you the sourest points with sweetest terms,
line 6975-->    Nor curstness grow to th' matter.  
line 6976-->  ANTONY. 'Tis spoken well.
line 6977-->    Were we before our arinies, and to fight,
line 6978-->    I should do thus.                                 [Flourish]
line 6979-->  CAESAR. Welcome to Rome.
line 6980-->  ANTONY. Thank you.
line 6981-->  CAESAR. Sit.
line 6982-->  ANTONY. Sit, sir.
line 6983-->  CAESAR. Nay, then.                                  [They sit]
line 6984-->  ANTONY. I learn you take things ill which are not so,
line 6985-->    Or being, concern you not.
line 6986-->  CAESAR. I must be laugh'd at
line 6987-->    If, or for nothing or a little,
line 6988-->    Should say myself offended, and with you
line 6989-->    Chiefly i' the world; more laugh'd at that I should
line 6990-->    Once name you derogately when to sound your name
line 6991-->    It not concern'd me.
line 6992-->  ANTONY. My being in Egypt, Caesar,
line 6993-->    What was't to you?
line 6994-->  CAESAR. No more than my residing here at Rome
line 6995-->    Might be to you in Egypt. Yet, if you there  
line 6996-->    Did practise on my state, your being in Egypt
line 6997-->    Might be my question.
line 6998-->  ANTONY. How intend you- practis'd?
line 6999-->  CAESAR. You may be pleas'd to catch at mine intent
line 7000-->    By what did here befall me. Your wife and brother
line 7001-->    Made wars upon me, and their contestation
line 7002-->    Was theme for you; you were the word of war.
line 7003-->  ANTONY. You do mistake your business; my brother never
line 7004-->    Did urge me in his act. I did inquire it,
line 7005-->    And have my learning from some true reports
line 7006-->    That drew their swords with you. Did he not rather
line 7007-->    Discredit my authority with yours,
line 7008-->    And make the wars alike against my stomach,
line 7009-->    Having alike your cause? Of this my letters
line 7010-->    Before did satisfy you. If you'll patch a quarrel,
line 7011-->    As matter whole you have not to make it with,
line 7012-->    It must not be with this.
line 7013-->  CAESAR. You praise yourself
line 7014-->    By laying defects of judgment to me; but
line 7015-->    You patch'd up your excuses.  
line 7016-->  ANTONY. Not so, not so;
line 7017-->    I know you could not lack, I am certain on't,
line 7018-->    Very necessity of this thought, that I,
line 7019-->    Your partner in the cause 'gainst which he fought,
line 7020-->    Could not with graceful eyes attend those wars
line 7021-->    Which fronted mine own peace. As for my wife,
line 7022-->    I would you had her spirit in such another!
line 7023-->    The third o' th' world is yours, which with a snaffle
line 7024-->    You may pace easy, but not such a wife.
line 7025-->  ENOBARBUS. Would we had all such wives, that the men might go to
line 7026-->    wars with the women!
line 7027-->  ANTONY. So much uncurbable, her garboils, Caesar,
line 7028-->    Made out of her impatience- which not wanted
line 7029-->    Shrewdness of policy too- I grieving grant
line 7030-->    Did you too much disquiet. For that you must
line 7031-->    But say I could not help it.
line 7032-->  CAESAR. I wrote to you
line 7033-->    When rioting in Alexandria; you
line 7034-->    Did pocket up my letters, and with taunts
line 7035-->    Did gibe my missive out of audience.  
line 7036-->  ANTONY. Sir,
line 7037-->    He fell upon me ere admitted. Then
line 7038-->    Three kings I had newly feasted, and did want
line 7039-->    Of what I was i' th' morning; but next day
line 7040-->    I told him of myself, which was as much
line 7041-->    As to have ask'd him pardon. Let this fellow
line 7042-->    Be nothing of our strife; if we contend,
line 7043-->    Out of our question wipe him.
line 7044-->  CAESAR. You have broken
line 7045-->    The article of your oath, which you shall never
line 7046-->    Have tongue to charge me with.
line 7047-->  LEPIDUS. Soft, Caesar!
line 7048-->  ANTONY. No;
line 7049-->    Lepidus, let him speak.
line 7050-->    The honour is sacred which he talks on now,
line 7051-->    Supposing that I lack'd it. But on, Caesar:
line 7052-->    The article of my oath-
line 7053-->  CAESAR. To lend me arms and aid when I requir'd them,
line 7054-->    The which you both denied.
line 7055-->  ANTONY. Neglected, rather;  
line 7056-->    And then when poisoned hours had bound me up
line 7057-->    From mine own knowledge. As nearly as I may,
line 7058-->    I'll play the penitent to you; but mine honesty
line 7059-->    Shall not make poor my greatness, nor my power
line 7060-->    Work without it. Truth is, that Fulvia,
line 7061-->    To have me out of Egypt, made wars here;
line 7062-->    For which myself, the ignorant motive, do
line 7063-->    So far ask pardon as befits mine honour
line 7064-->    To stoop in such a case.
line 7065-->  LEPIDUS. 'Tis noble spoken.
line 7066-->  MAECENAS. If it might please you to enforce no further
line 7067-->    The griefs between ye- to forget them quite
line 7068-->    Were to remember that the present need
line 7069-->    Speaks to atone you.
line 7070-->  LEPIDUS. Worthily spoken, Maecenas.
line 7071-->  ENOBARBUS. Or, if you borrow one another's love for the instant,
line 7072-->    you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again.
line 7073-->    You shall have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to
line 7074-->    do.
line 7075-->  ANTONY. Thou art a soldier only. Speak no more.  
line 7076-->  ENOBARBUS. That truth should be silent I had almost forgot.
line 7077-->  ANTONY. You wrong this presence; therefore speak no more.
line 7078-->  ENOBARBUS. Go to, then- your considerate stone!
line 7079-->  CAESAR. I do not much dislike the matter, but
line 7080-->    The manner of his speech; for't cannot be
line 7081-->    We shall remain in friendship, our conditions
line 7082-->    So diff'ring in their acts. Yet if I knew
line 7083-->    What hoop should hold us stanch, from edge to edge
line 7084-->    O' th' world, I would pursue it.
line 7085-->  AGRIPPA. Give me leave, Caesar.
line 7086-->  CAESAR. Speak, Agrippa.
line 7087-->  AGRIPPA. Thou hast a sister by the mother's side,
line 7088-->    Admir'd Octavia. Great Mark Antony
line 7089-->    Is now a widower.
line 7090-->  CAESAR. Say not so, Agrippa.
line 7091-->    If Cleopatra heard you, your reproof
line 7092-->    Were well deserv'd of rashness.
line 7093-->  ANTONY. I am not married, Caesar. Let me hear
line 7094-->    Agrippa further speak.
line 7095-->  AGRIPPA. To hold you in perpetual amity,  
line 7096-->    To make you brothers, and to knit your hearts
line 7097-->    With an unslipping knot, take Antony
line 7098-->    Octavia to his wife; whose beauty claims
line 7099-->    No worse a husband than the best of men;
line 7100-->    Whose virtue and whose general graces speak
line 7101-->    That which none else can utter. By this marriage
line 7102-->    All little jealousies, which now seem great,
line 7103-->    And all great fears, which now import their dangers,
line 7104-->    Would then be nothing. Truths would be tales,
line 7105-->    Where now half tales be truths. Her love to both
line 7106-->    Would each to other, and all loves to both,
line 7107-->    Draw after her. Pardon what I have spoke;
line 7108-->    For 'tis a studied, not a present thought,
line 7109-->    By duty ruminated.
line 7110-->  ANTONY. Will Caesar speak?
line 7111-->  CAESAR. Not till he hears how Antony is touch'd
line 7112-->    With what is spoke already.
line 7113-->  ANTONY. What power is in Agrippa,
line 7114-->    If I would say 'Agrippa, be it so,'
line 7115-->    To make this good?  
line 7116-->  CAESAR. The power of Caesar, and
line 7117-->    His power unto Octavia.
line 7118-->  ANTONY. May I never
line 7119-->    To this good purpose, that so fairly shows,
line 7120-->    Dream of impediment! Let me have thy hand.
line 7121-->    Further this act of grace; and from this hour
line 7122-->    The heart of brothers govern in our loves
line 7123-->    And sway our great designs!
line 7124-->  CAESAR. There is my hand.
line 7125-->    A sister I bequeath you, whom no brother
line 7126-->    Did ever love so dearly. Let her live
line 7127-->    To join our kingdoms and our hearts; and never
line 7128-->    Fly off our loves again!
line 7129-->  LEPIDUS. Happily, amen!
line 7130-->  ANTONY. I did not think to draw my sword 'gainst Pompey;
line 7131-->    For he hath laid strange courtesies and great
line 7132-->    Of late upon me. I must thank him only,
line 7133-->    Lest my remembrance suffer ill report;
line 7134-->    At heel of that, defy him.
line 7135-->  LEPIDUS. Time calls upon's.  
line 7136-->    Of us must Pompey presently be sought,
line 7137-->    Or else he seeks out us.
line 7138-->  ANTONY. Where lies he?
line 7139-->  CAESAR. About the Mount Misenum.
line 7140-->  ANTONY. What is his strength by land?
line 7141-->  CAESAR. Great and increasing; but by sea
line 7142-->    He is an absolute master.
line 7143-->  ANTONY. So is the fame.
line 7144-->    Would we had spoke together! Haste we for it.
line 7145-->    Yet, ere we put ourselves in arms, dispatch we
line 7146-->    The business we have talk'd of.
line 7147-->  CAESAR. With most gladness;
line 7148-->    And do invite you to my sister's view,
line 7149-->    Whither straight I'll lead you.
line 7150-->  ANTONY. Let us, Lepidus,
line 7151-->    Not lack your company.
line 7152-->  LEPIDUS. Noble Antony,
line 7153-->    Not sickness should detain me.                    [Flourish]
line 7154-->                     Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS, AGRIPPA, MAECENAS
line 7155-->  MAECENAS. Welcome from Egypt, sir.  
line 7156-->  ENOBARBUS. Half the heart of Caesar, worthy Maecenas! My honourable
line 7157-->    friend, Agrippa!
line 7158-->  AGRIPPA. Good Enobarbus!
line 7159-->  MAECENAS. We have cause to be glad that matters are so well
line 7160-->    digested. You stay'd well by't in Egypt.
line 7161-->  ENOBARBUS. Ay, sir; we did sleep day out of countenance and made
line 7162-->    the night light with drinking.
line 7163-->  MAECENAS. Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast, and but
line 7164-->    twelve persons there. Is this true?
line 7165-->  ENOBARBUS. This was but as a fly by an eagle. We had much more
line 7166-->    monstrous matter of feast, which worthily deserved noting.
line 7167-->  MAECENAS. She's a most triumphant lady, if report be square to her.
line 7168-->  ENOBARBUS. When she first met Mark Antony she purs'd up his heart,
line 7169-->    upon the river of Cydnus.
line 7170-->  AGRIPPA. There she appear'd indeed! Or my reporter devis'd well for
line 7171-->    her.
line 7172-->  ENOBARBUS. I will tell you.
line 7173-->    The barge she sat in, like a burnish'd throne,
line 7174-->    Burn'd on the water. The poop was beaten gold;
line 7175-->    Purple the sails, and so perfumed that  
line 7176-->    The winds were love-sick with them; the oars were silver,
line 7177-->    Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke, and made
line 7178-->    The water which they beat to follow faster,
line 7179-->    As amorous of their strokes. For her own person,
line 7180-->    It beggar'd all description. She did lie
line 7181-->    In her pavilion, cloth-of-gold, of tissue,
line 7182-->    O'erpicturing that Venus where we see
line 7183-->    The fancy out-work nature. On each side her
line 7184-->    Stood pretty dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids,
line 7185-->    With divers-colour'd fans, whose wind did seem
line 7186-->    To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool,
line 7187-->    And what they undid did.
line 7188-->  AGRIPPA. O, rare for Antony!
line 7189-->  ENOBARBUS. Her gentlewomen, like the Nereides,
line 7190-->    So many mermaids, tended her i' th' eyes,
line 7191-->    And made their bends adornings. At the helm
line 7192-->    A seeming mermaid steers. The silken tackle
line 7193-->    Swell with the touches of those flower-soft hands
line 7194-->    That yarely frame the office. From the barge
line 7195-->    A strange invisible perfume hits the sense  
line 7196-->    Of the adjacent wharfs. The city cast
line 7197-->    Her people out upon her; and Antony,
line 7198-->    Enthron'd i' th' market-place, did sit alone,
line 7199-->    Whistling to th' air; which, but for vacancy,
line 7200-->    Had gone to gaze on Cleopatra too,
line 7201-->    And made a gap in nature.
line 7202-->  AGRIPPA. Rare Egyptian!
line 7203-->  ENOBARBUS. Upon her landing, Antony sent to her,
line 7204-->    Invited her to supper. She replied
line 7205-->    It should be better he became her guest;
line 7206-->    Which she entreated. Our courteous Antony,
line 7207-->    Whom ne'er the word of 'No' woman heard speak,
line 7208-->    Being barber'd ten times o'er, goes to the feast,
line 7209-->    And for his ordinary pays his heart
line 7210-->    For what his eyes eat only.
line 7211-->  AGRIPPA. Royal wench!
line 7212-->    She made great Caesar lay his sword to bed.
line 7213-->    He ploughed her, and she cropp'd.
line 7214-->  ENOBARBUS. I saw her once
line 7215-->    Hop forty paces through the public street;  
line 7216-->    And, having lost her breath, she spoke, and panted,
line 7217-->    That she did make defect perfection,
line 7218-->    And, breathless, pow'r breathe forth.
line 7219-->  MAECENAS. Now Antony must leave her utterly.
line 7220-->  ENOBARBUS. Never! He will not.
line 7221-->    Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale
line 7222-->    Her infinite variety. Other women cloy
line 7223-->    The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry
line 7224-->    Where most she satisfies; for vilest things
line 7225-->    Become themselves in her, that the holy priests
line 7226-->    Bless her when she is riggish.
line 7227-->  MAECENAS. If beauty, wisdom, modesty, can settle
line 7228-->    The heart of Antony, Octavia is
line 7229-->    A blessed lottery to him.
line 7230-->  AGRIPPA. Let us go.
line 7231-->    Good Enobarbus, make yourself my guest
line 7232-->    Whilst you abide here.
line 7233-->  ENOBARBUS. Humbly, sir, I thank you.                    Exeunt
line 7234-->
line 7235-->
line 7236-->
line 7237-->
line 7238-->SCENE III.
line 7239-->Rome. CAESAR'S house
line 7240-->
line 7241-->Enter ANTONY, CAESAR, OCTAVIA between them
line 7242-->
line 7243-->  ANTONY. The world and my great office will sometimes
line 7244-->    Divide me from your bosom.
line 7245-->  OCTAVIA. All which time
line 7246-->    Before the gods my knee shall bow my prayers
line 7247-->    To them for you.
line 7248-->  ANTONY. Good night, sir. My Octavia,
line 7249-->    Read not my blemishes in the world's report.
line 7250-->    I have not kept my square; but that to come
line 7251-->    Shall all be done by th' rule. Good night, dear lady.
line 7252-->  OCTAVIA. Good night, sir.
line 7253-->  CAESAR. Good night.                  Exeunt CAESAR and OCTAVIA
line 7254-->
line 7255-->                        Enter SOOTHSAYER
line 7256-->
line 7257-->  ANTONY. Now, sirrah, you do wish yourself in Egypt?
line 7258-->  SOOTHSAYER. Would I had never come from thence, nor you thither!
line 7259-->  ANTONY. If you can- your reason.  
line 7260-->  SOOTHSAYER. I see it in my motion, have it not in my tongue; but
line 7261-->    yet hie you to Egypt again.
line 7262-->  ANTONY. Say to me,
line 7263-->    Whose fortunes shall rise higher, Caesar's or mine?
line 7264-->  SOOTHSAYER. Caesar's.
line 7265-->    Therefore, O Antony, stay not by his side.
line 7266-->    Thy daemon, that thy spirit which keeps thee, is
line 7267-->    Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable,
line 7268-->    Where Caesar's is not; but near him thy angel
line 7269-->    Becomes a fear, as being o'erpow'r'd. Therefore
line 7270-->    Make space enough between you.
line 7271-->  ANTONY. Speak this no more.
line 7272-->  SOOTHSAYER. To none but thee; no more but when to thee.
line 7273-->    If thou dost play with him at any game,
line 7274-->    Thou art sure to lose; and of that natural luck
line 7275-->    He beats thee 'gainst the odds. Thy lustre thickens
line 7276-->    When he shines by. I say again, thy spirit
line 7277-->    Is all afraid to govern thee near him;
line 7278-->    But, he away, 'tis noble.
line 7279-->  ANTONY. Get thee gone.  
line 7280-->    Say to Ventidius I would speak with him.
line 7281-->                                                 Exit SOOTHSAYER
line 7282-->    He shall to Parthia.- Be it art or hap,
line 7283-->    He hath spoken true. The very dice obey him;
line 7284-->    And in our sports my better cunning faints
line 7285-->    Under his chance. If we draw lots, he speeds;
line 7286-->    His cocks do win the battle still of mine,
line 7287-->    When it is all to nought, and his quails ever
line 7288-->    Beat mine, inhoop'd, at odds. I will to Egypt;
line 7289-->    And though I make this marriage for my peace,
line 7290-->    I' th' East my pleasure lies.
line 7291-->
line 7292-->                       Enter VENTIDIUS
line 7293-->
line 7294-->    O, come, Ventidius,
line 7295-->    You must to Parthia. Your commission's ready;
line 7296-->    Follow me and receive't.                              Exeunt
line 7297-->
line 7298-->
line 7299-->
line 7300-->
line 7301-->SCENE IV.
line 7302-->Rome. A street
line 7303-->
line 7304-->Enter LEPIDUS, MAECENAS, and AGRIPPA
line 7305-->
line 7306-->  LEPIDUS. Trouble yourselves no further. Pray you hasten
line 7307-->    Your generals after.
line 7308-->  AGRIPPA. Sir, Mark Antony
line 7309-->    Will e'en but kiss Octavia, and we'll follow.
line 7310-->  LEPIDUS. Till I shall see you in your soldier's dress,
line 7311-->    Which will become you both, farewell.
line 7312-->  MAECENAS. We shall,
line 7313-->    As I conceive the journey, be at th' Mount
line 7314-->    Before you, Lepidus.
line 7315-->  LEPIDUS. Your way is shorter;
line 7316-->    My purposes do draw me much about.
line 7317-->    You'll win two days upon me.
line 7318-->  BOTH. Sir, good success!
line 7319-->  LEPIDUS. Farewell.                                      Exeunt
line 7320-->
line 7321-->
line 7322-->
line 7323-->
line 7324-->SCENE V.
line 7325-->Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palace
line 7326-->
line 7327-->Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS
line 7328-->
line 7329-->  CLEOPATRA. Give me some music- music, moody food
line 7330-->    Of us that trade in love.
line 7331-->  ALL. The music, ho!
line 7332-->
line 7333-->                    Enter MARDIAN the eunuch
line 7334-->
line 7335-->  CLEOPATRA. Let it alone! Let's to billiards. Come, Charmian.
line 7336-->  CHARMIAN. My arm is sore; best play with Mardian.
line 7337-->  CLEOPATRA. As well a woman with an eunuch play'd
line 7338-->    As with a woman. Come, you'll play with me, sir?
line 7339-->  MARDIAN. As well as I can, madam.
line 7340-->  CLEOPATRA. And when good will is show'd, though't come too short,
line 7341-->    The actor may plead pardon. I'll none now.
line 7342-->    Give me mine angle- we'll to th' river. There,
line 7343-->    My music playing far off, I will betray
line 7344-->    Tawny-finn'd fishes; my bended hook shall pierce
line 7345-->    Their slimy jaws; and as I draw them up
line 7346-->    I'll think them every one an Antony,
line 7347-->    And say 'Ah ha! Y'are caught.'
line 7348-->  CHARMIAN. 'Twas merry when
line 7349-->    You wager'd on your angling; when your diver
line 7350-->    Did hang a salt fish on his hook, which he
line 7351-->    With fervency drew up.
line 7352-->  CLEOPATRA. That time? O times
line 7353-->    I laughed him out of patience; and that night
line 7354-->    I laugh'd him into patience; and next morn,
line 7355-->    Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed,
line 7356-->    Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst
line 7357-->    I wore his sword Philippan.
line 7358-->
line 7359-->                    Enter a MESSENGER
line 7360-->
line 7361-->    O! from Italy?
line 7362-->    Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears,
line 7363-->    That long time have been barren.
line 7364-->  MESSENGER. Madam, madam-
line 7365-->  CLEOPATRA. Antony's dead! If thou say so, villain,  
line 7366-->    Thou kill'st thy mistress; but well and free,
line 7367-->    If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here
line 7368-->    My bluest veins to kiss- a hand that kings
line 7369-->    Have lipp'd, and trembled kissing.
line 7370-->  MESSENGER. First, madam, he is well.
line 7371-->  CLEOPATRA. Why, there's more gold.
line 7372-->    But, sirrah, mark, we use
line 7373-->    To say the dead are well. Bring it to that,
line 7374-->    The gold I give thee will I melt and pour
line 7375-->    Down thy ill-uttering throat.
line 7376-->  MESSENGER. Good madam, hear me.
line 7377-->  CLEOPATRA. Well, go to, I will.
line 7378-->    But there's no goodness in thy face. If Antony
line 7379-->    Be free and healthful- why so tart a favour
line 7380-->    To trumpet such good tidings? If not well,
line 7381-->    Thou shouldst come like a Fury crown'd with snakes,
line 7382-->    Not like a formal man.
line 7383-->  MESSENGER. Will't please you hear me?
line 7384-->  CLEOPATRA. I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak'st.
line 7385-->    Yet, if thou say Antony lives, is well,  
line 7386-->    Or friends with Caesar, or not captive to him,
line 7387-->    I'll set thee in a shower of gold, and hail
line 7388-->    Rich pearls upon thee.
line 7389-->  MESSENGER. Madam, he's well.
line 7390-->  CLEOPATRA. Well said.
line 7391-->  MESSENGER. And friends with Caesar.
line 7392-->  CLEOPATRA. Th'art an honest man.
line 7393-->  MESSENGER. Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.
line 7394-->  CLEOPATRA. Make thee a fortune from me.
line 7395-->  MESSENGER. But yet, madam-
line 7396-->  CLEOPATRA. I do not like 'but yet.' It does allay
line 7397-->    The good precedence; fie upon 'but yet'!
line 7398-->    'But yet' is as a gaoler to bring forth
line 7399-->    Some monstrous malefactor. Prithee, friend,
line 7400-->    Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear,
line 7401-->    The good and bad together. He's friends with Caesar;
line 7402-->    In state of health, thou say'st; and, thou say'st, free.
line 7403-->  MESSENGER. Free, madam! No; I made no such report.
line 7404-->    He's bound unto Octavia.
line 7405-->  CLEOPATRA. For what good turn?  
line 7406-->  MESSENGER. For the best turn i' th' bed.
line 7407-->  CLEOPATRA. I am pale, Charmian.
line 7408-->  MESSENGER. Madam, he's married to Octavia.
line 7409-->  CLEOPATRA. The most infectious pestilence upon thee!
line 7410-->                                              [Strikes him down]
line 7411-->  MESSENGER. Good madam, patience.
line 7412-->  CLEOPATRA. What say you? Hence,                  [Strikes him]
line 7413-->    Horrible villain! or I'll spurn thine eyes
line 7414-->    Like balls before me; I'll unhair thy head;
line 7415-->                                     [She hales him up and down]
line 7416-->    Thou shalt be whipp'd with wire and stew'd in brine,
line 7417-->    Smarting in ling'ring pickle.
line 7418-->  MESSENGER. Gracious madam,
line 7419-->    I that do bring the news made not the match.
line 7420-->  CLEOPATRA. Say 'tis not so, a province I will give thee,
line 7421-->    And make thy fortunes proud. The blow thou hadst
line 7422-->    Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage;
line 7423-->    And I will boot thee with what gift beside
line 7424-->    Thy modesty can beg.
line 7425-->  MESSENGER. He's married, madam.  
line 7426-->  CLEOPATRA. Rogue, thou hast liv'd too long.    [Draws a knife]
line 7427-->  MESSENGER. Nay, then I'll run.
line 7428-->    What mean you, madam? I have made no fault.             Exit
line 7429-->  CHARMIAN. Good madam, keep yourself within yourself:
line 7430-->    The man is innocent.
line 7431-->  CLEOPATRA. Some innocents scape not the thunderbolt.
line 7432-->    Melt Egypt into Nile! and kindly creatures
line 7433-->    Turn all to serpents! Call the slave again.
line 7434-->    Though I am mad, I will not bite him. Call!
line 7435-->  CHARMIAN. He is afear'd to come.
line 7436-->  CLEOPATRA. I will not hurt him.
line 7437-->    These hands do lack nobility, that they strike
line 7438-->    A meaner than myself; since I myself
line 7439-->    Have given myself the cause.
line 7440-->
line 7441-->                    Enter the MESSENGER again
line 7442-->
line 7443-->    Come hither, sir.
line 7444-->    Though it be honest, it is never good
line 7445-->    To bring bad news. Give to a gracious message  
line 7446-->    An host of tongues; but let ill tidings tell
line 7447-->    Themselves when they be felt.
line 7448-->  MESSENGER. I have done my duty.
line 7449-->  CLEOPATRA. Is he married?
line 7450-->    I cannot hate thee worser than I do
line 7451-->    If thou again say 'Yes.'
line 7452-->  MESSENGER. He's married, madam.
line 7453-->  CLEOPATRA. The gods confound thee! Dost thou hold there still?
line 7454-->  MESSENGER. Should I lie, madam?
line 7455-->  CLEOPATRA. O, I would thou didst,
line 7456-->    So half my Egypt were submerg'd and made
line 7457-->    A cistern for scal'd snakes! Go, get thee hence.
line 7458-->    Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me
line 7459-->    Thou wouldst appear most ugly. He is married?
line 7460-->  MESSENGER. I crave your Highness' pardon.
line 7461-->  CLEOPATRA. He is married?
line 7462-->  MESSENGER. Take no offence that I would not offend you;
line 7463-->    To punish me for what you make me do
line 7464-->    Seems much unequal. He's married to Octavia.
line 7465-->  CLEOPATRA. O, that his fault should make a knave of thee  
line 7466-->    That art not what th'art sure of! Get thee hence.
line 7467-->    The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome
line 7468-->    Are all too dear for me. Lie they upon thy hand,
line 7469-->    And be undone by 'em!                         Exit MESSENGER
line 7470-->  CHARMIAN. Good your Highness, patience.
line 7471-->  CLEOPATRA. In praising Antony I have disprais'd Caesar.
line 7472-->  CHARMIAN. Many times, madam.
line 7473-->  CLEOPATRA. I am paid for't now. Lead me from hence,
line 7474-->    I faint. O Iras, Charmian! 'Tis no matter.
line 7475-->    Go to the fellow, good Alexas; bid him
line 7476-->    Report the feature of Octavia, her years,
line 7477-->    Her inclination; let him not leave out
line 7478-->    The colour of her hair. Bring me word quickly.
line 7479-->                                                     Exit ALEXAS
line 7480-->    Let him for ever go- let him not, Charmian-
line 7481-->    Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon,
line 7482-->    The other way's a Mars.                         [To MARDIAN]
line 7483-->    Bid you Alexas
line 7484-->    Bring me word how tall she is.- Pity me, Charmian,
line 7485-->    But do not speak to me. Lead me to my chamber.        Exeunt
line 7486-->
line 7487-->
line 7488-->
line 7489-->
line 7490-->SCENE VI.
line 7491-->Near Misenum
line 7492-->
line 7493-->Flourish. Enter POMPEY and MENAS at one door, with drum and trumpet;
line 7494-->at another, CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, ENOBARBUS, MAECENAS, AGRIPPA,
line 7495-->with soldiers marching
line 7496-->
line 7497-->  POMPEY. Your hostages I have, so have you mine;
line 7498-->    And we shall talk before we fight.
line 7499-->  CAESAR. Most meet
line 7500-->    That first we come to words; and therefore have we
line 7501-->    Our written purposes before us sent;
line 7502-->    Which if thou hast considered, let us know
line 7503-->    If 'twill tie up thy discontented sword
line 7504-->    And carry back to Sicily much tall youth
line 7505-->    That else must perish here.
line 7506-->  POMPEY. To you all three,
line 7507-->    The senators alone of this great world,
line 7508-->    Chief factors for the gods: I do not know
line 7509-->    Wherefore my father should revengers want,
line 7510-->    Having a son and friends, since Julius Caesar,  
line 7511-->    Who at Philippi the good Brutus ghosted,
line 7512-->    There saw you labouring for him. What was't
line 7513-->    That mov'd pale Cassius to conspire? and what
line 7514-->    Made the all-honour'd honest Roman, Brutus,
line 7515-->    With the arm'd rest, courtiers of beauteous freedom,
line 7516-->    To drench the Capitol, but that they would
line 7517-->    Have one man but a man? And that is it
line 7518-->    Hath made me rig my navy, at whose burden
line 7519-->    The anger'd ocean foams; with which I meant
line 7520-->    To scourge th' ingratitude that despiteful Rome
line 7521-->    Cast on my noble father.
line 7522-->  CAESAR. Take your time.
line 7523-->  ANTONY. Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails;
line 7524-->    We'll speak with thee at sea; at land thou know'st
line 7525-->    How much we do o'er-count thee.
line 7526-->  POMPEY. At land, indeed,
line 7527-->    Thou dost o'er-count me of my father's house.
line 7528-->    But since the cuckoo builds not for himself,
line 7529-->    Remain in't as thou mayst.
line 7530-->  LEPIDUS. Be pleas'd to tell us-  
line 7531-->    For this is from the present- how you take
line 7532-->    The offers we have sent you.
line 7533-->  CAESAR. There's the point.
line 7534-->  ANTONY. Which do not be entreated to, but weigh
line 7535-->    What it is worth embrac'd.
line 7536-->  CAESAR. And what may follow,
line 7537-->    To try a larger fortune.
line 7538-->  POMPEY. You have made me offer
line 7539-->    Of Sicily, Sardinia; and I must
line 7540-->    Rid all the sea of pirates; then to send
line 7541-->    Measures of wheat to Rome; this 'greed upon,
line 7542-->    To part with unhack'd edges and bear back
line 7543-->    Our targes undinted.
line 7544-->  ALL. That's our offer.
line 7545-->  POMPEY. Know, then,
line 7546-->    I came before you here a man prepar'd
line 7547-->    To take this offer; but Mark Antony
line 7548-->    Put me to some impatience. Though I lose
line 7549-->    The praise of it by telling, you must know,
line 7550-->    When Caesar and your brother were at blows,  
line 7551-->    Your mother came to Sicily and did find
line 7552-->    Her welcome friendly.
line 7553-->  ANTONY. I have heard it, Pompey,
line 7554-->    And am well studied for a liberal thanks
line 7555-->    Which I do owe you.
line 7556-->  POMPEY. Let me have your hand.
line 7557-->    I did not think, sir, to have met you here.
line 7558-->  ANTONY. The beds i' th' East are soft; and thanks to you,
line 7559-->    That call'd me timelier than my purpose hither;
line 7560-->    For I have gained by't.
line 7561-->  CAESAR. Since I saw you last
line 7562-->    There is a change upon you.
line 7563-->  POMPEY. Well, I know not
line 7564-->    What counts harsh fortune casts upon my face;
line 7565-->    But in my bosom shall she never come
line 7566-->    To make my heart her vassal.
line 7567-->  LEPIDUS. Well met here.
line 7568-->  POMPEY. I hope so, Lepidus. Thus we are agreed.
line 7569-->    I crave our composition may be written,
line 7570-->    And seal'd between us.  
line 7571-->  CAESAR. That's the next to do.
line 7572-->  POMPEY. We'll feast each other ere we part, and let's
line 7573-->    Draw lots who shall begin.
line 7574-->  ANTONY. That will I, Pompey.
line 7575-->  POMPEY. No, Antony, take the lot;
line 7576-->    But, first or last, your fine Egyptian cookery
line 7577-->    Shall have the fame. I have heard that Julius Caesar
line 7578-->    Grew fat with feasting there.
line 7579-->  ANTONY. You have heard much.
line 7580-->  POMPEY. I have fair meanings, sir.
line 7581-->  ANTONY. And fair words to them.
line 7582-->  POMPEY. Then so much have I heard;
line 7583-->    And I have heard Apollodorus carried-
line 7584-->  ENOBARBUS. No more of that! He did so.
line 7585-->  POMPEY. What, I pray you?
line 7586-->  ENOBARBUS. A certain queen to Caesar in a mattress.
line 7587-->  POMPEY. I know thee now. How far'st thou, soldier?
line 7588-->  ENOBARBUS. Well;
line 7589-->    And well am like to do, for I perceive
line 7590-->    Four feasts are toward.  
line 7591-->  POMPEY. Let me shake thy hand.
line 7592-->    I never hated thee; I have seen thee fight,
line 7593-->    When I have envied thy behaviour.
line 7594-->  ENOBARBUS. Sir,
line 7595-->    I never lov'd you much; but I ha' prais'd ye
line 7596-->    When you have well deserv'd ten times as much
line 7597-->    As I have said you did.
line 7598-->  POMPEY. Enjoy thy plainness;
line 7599-->    It nothing ill becomes thee.
line 7600-->    Aboard my galley I invite you all.
line 7601-->    Will you lead, lords?
line 7602-->  ALL. Show's the way, sir.
line 7603-->  POMPEY. Come.               Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS and MENAS
line 7604-->  MENAS. [Aside] Thy father, Pompey, would ne'er have made this
line 7605-->    treaty.- You and I have known, sir.
line 7606-->  ENOBARBUS. At sea, I think.
line 7607-->  MENAS. We have, sir.
line 7608-->  ENOBARBUS. You have done well by water.
line 7609-->  MENAS. And you by land.
line 7610-->  ENOBARBUS. I Will praise any man that will praise me; though it  
line 7611-->    cannot be denied what I have done by land.
line 7612-->  MENAS. Nor what I have done by water.
line 7613-->  ENOBARBUS. Yes, something you can deny for your own safety: you
line 7614-->    have been a great thief by sea.
line 7615-->  MENAS. And you by land.
line 7616-->  ENOBARBUS. There I deny my land service. But give me your hand,
line 7617-->    Menas; if our eyes had authority, here they might take two
line 7618-->    thieves kissing.
line 7619-->  MENAS. All men's faces are true, whatsome'er their hands are.
line 7620-->  ENOBARBUS. But there is never a fair woman has a true face.
line 7621-->  MENAS. No slander: they steal hearts.
line 7622-->  ENOBARBUS. We came hither to fight with you.
line 7623-->  MENAS. For my part, I am sorry it is turn'd to a drinking.
line 7624-->    Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.
line 7625-->  ENOBARBUS. If he do, sure he cannot weep't back again.
line 7626-->  MENAS. Y'have said, sir. We look'd not for Mark Antony here. Pray
line 7627-->    you, is he married to Cleopatra?
line 7628-->  ENOBARBUS. Caesar' sister is call'd Octavia.
line 7629-->  MENAS. True, sir; she was the wife of Caius Marcellus.
line 7630-->  ENOBARBUS. But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.  
line 7631-->  MENAS. Pray ye, sir?
line 7632-->  ENOBARBUS. 'Tis true.
line 7633-->  MENAS. Then is Caesar and he for ever knit together.
line 7634-->  ENOBARBUS. If I were bound to divine of this unity, I would not
line 7635-->    prophesy so.
line 7636-->  MENAS. I think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage
line 7637-->    than the love of the parties.
line 7638-->  ENOBARBUS. I think so too. But you shall find the band that seems
line 7639-->    to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of
line 7640-->    their amity: Octavia is of a holy, cold, and still conversation.
line 7641-->  MENAS. Who would not have his wife so?
line 7642-->  ENOBARBUS. Not he that himself is not so; which is Mark Antony. He
line 7643-->    will to his Egyptian dish again; then shall the sighs of Octavia
line 7644-->    blow the fire up in Caesar, and, as I said before, that which is
line 7645-->    the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of
line 7646-->    their variance. Antony will use his affection where it is; he
line 7647-->    married but his occasion here.
line 7648-->  MENAS. And thus it may be. Come, sir, will you aboard? I have a
line 7649-->    health for you.
line 7650-->  ENOBARBUS. I shall take it, sir. We have us'd our throats in Egypt.  
line 7651-->  MENAS. Come, let's away.                                Exeunt
line 7652-->
line 7653-->ACT_2|SC_7
line 7654-->                           SCENE VII.
line 7655-->             On board POMPEY'S galley, off Misenum
line 7656-->
line 7657-->     Music plays. Enter two or three SERVANTS with a banquet
line 7658-->
line 7659-->  FIRST SERVANT. Here they'll be, man. Some o' their plants are
line 7660-->    ill-rooted already; the least wind i' th' world will blow them
line 7661-->    down.
line 7662-->  SECOND SERVANT. Lepidus is high-colour'd.
line 7663-->  FIRST SERVANT. They have made him drink alms-drink.
line 7664-->  SECOND SERVANT. As they pinch one another by the disposition, he
line 7665-->    cries out 'No more!'; reconciles them to his entreaty and himself
line 7666-->    to th' drink.
line 7667-->  FIRST SERVANT. But it raises the greater war between him and his
line 7668-->    discretion.
line 7669-->  SECOND SERVANT. Why, this it is to have a name in great men's
line 7670-->    fellowship. I had as lief have a reed that will do me no service
line 7671-->    as a partizan I could not heave.
line 7672-->  FIRST SERVANT. To be call'd into a huge sphere, and not to be seen
line 7673-->    to move in't, are the holes where eyes should be, which pitifully
line 7674-->    disaster the cheeks.
line 7675-->  
line 7676-->           A sennet sounded. Enter CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS,
line 7677-->            POMPEY, AGRIPPA, MAECENAS, ENOBARBUS, MENAS,
line 7678-->                         with other CAPTAINS
line 7679-->
line 7680-->  ANTONY. [To CAESAR] Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o' th'
line 7681-->      Nile
line 7682-->    By certain scales i' th' pyramid; they know
line 7683-->    By th' height, the lowness, or the mean, if dearth
line 7684-->    Or foison follow. The higher Nilus swells
line 7685-->    The more it promises; as it ebbs, the seedsman
line 7686-->    Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain,
line 7687-->    And shortly comes to harvest.
line 7688-->  LEPIDUS. Y'have strange serpents there.
line 7689-->  ANTONY. Ay, Lepidus.
line 7690-->  LEPIDUS. Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the
line 7691-->    operation of your sun; so is your crocodile.
line 7692-->  ANTONY. They are so.
line 7693-->  POMPEY. Sit- and some wine! A health to Lepidus!
line 7694-->  LEPIDUS. I am not so well as I should be, but I'll ne'er out.
line 7695-->  ENOBARBUS. Not till you have slept. I fear me you'll be in till  
line 7696-->    then.
line 7697-->  LEPIDUS. Nay, certainly, I have heard the Ptolemies' pyramises are
line 7698-->    very goodly things. Without contradiction I have heard that.
line 7699-->  MENAS. [Aside to POMPEY] Pompey, a word.
line 7700-->  POMPEY. [Aside to MENAS] Say in mine ear; what is't?
line 7701-->  MENAS. [Aside to POMPEY] Forsake thy seat, I do beseech thee,
line 7702-->      Captain,
line 7703-->    And hear me speak a word.
line 7704-->  POMPEY. [ Whispers in's ear ] Forbear me till anon-
line 7705-->    This wine for Lepidus!
line 7706-->  LEPIDUS. What manner o' thing is your crocodile?
line 7707-->  ANTONY. It is shap'd, sir, like itself, and it is as broad as it
line 7708-->    hath breadth; it is just so high as it is, and moves with it own
line 7709-->    organs. It lives by that which nourisheth it, and the elements
line 7710-->    once out of it, it transmigrates.
line 7711-->  LEPIDUS. What colour is it of?
line 7712-->  ANTONY. Of it own colour too.
line 7713-->  LEPIDUS. 'Tis a strange serpent.
line 7714-->  ANTONY. 'Tis so. And the tears of it are wet.
line 7715-->  CAESAR. Will this description satisfy him?  
line 7716-->  ANTONY. With the health that Pompey gives him, else he is a very
line 7717-->    epicure.
