line 7718-->  POMPEY. [Aside to MENAS] Go, hang, sir, hang! Tell me of that!
line 7719-->      Away!
line 7720-->    Do as I bid you.- Where's this cup I call'd for?
line 7721-->  MENAS. [Aside to POMPEY] If for the sake of merit thou wilt hear
line 7722-->      me,
line 7723-->    Rise from thy stool.
line 7724-->  POMPEY. [Aside to MENAS] I think th'art mad. [Rises and walks
line 7725-->    aside] The matter?
line 7726-->  MENAS. I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.
line 7727-->  POMPEY. Thou hast serv'd me with much faith. What's else to say?-
line 7728-->    Be jolly, lords.
line 7729-->  ANTONY. These quicksands, Lepidus,
line 7730-->    Keep off them, for you sink.
line 7731-->  MENAS. Wilt thou be lord of all the world?
line 7732-->  POMPEY. What say'st thou?
line 7733-->  MENAS. Wilt thou be lord of the whole world? That's twice.
line 7734-->  POMPEY. How should that be?
line 7735-->  MENAS. But entertain it,  
line 7736-->    And though you think me poor, I am the man
line 7737-->    Will give thee all the world.
line 7738-->  POMPEY. Hast thou drunk well?
line 7739-->  MENAS. No, Pompey, I have kept me from the cup.
line 7740-->    Thou art, if thou dar'st be, the earthly Jove;
line 7741-->    Whate'er the ocean pales or sky inclips
line 7742-->    Is thine, if thou wilt ha't.
line 7743-->  POMPEY. Show me which way.
line 7744-->  MENAS. These three world-sharers, these competitors,
line 7745-->    Are in thy vessel. Let me cut the cable;
line 7746-->    And when we are put off, fall to their throats.
line 7747-->    All there is thine.
line 7748-->  POMPEY. Ah, this thou shouldst have done,
line 7749-->    And not have spoke on't. In me 'tis villainy:
line 7750-->    In thee't had been good service. Thou must know
line 7751-->    'Tis not my profit that does lead mine honour:
line 7752-->    Mine honour, it. Repent that e'er thy tongue
line 7753-->    Hath so betray'd thine act. Being done unknown,
line 7754-->    I should have found it afterwards well done,
line 7755-->    But must condemn it now. Desist, and drink.  
line 7756-->  MENAS. [Aside] For this,
line 7757-->    I'll never follow thy pall'd fortunes more.
line 7758-->    Who seeks, and will not take when once 'tis offer'd,
line 7759-->    Shall never find it more.
line 7760-->  POMPEY. This health to Lepidus!
line 7761-->  ANTONY. Bear him ashore. I'll pledge it for him, Pompey.
line 7762-->  ENOBARBUS. Here's to thee, Menas!
line 7763-->  MENAS. Enobarbus, welcome!
line 7764-->  POMPEY. Fill till the cup be hid.
line 7765-->  ENOBARBUS. There's a strong fellow, Menas.
line 7766-->               [Pointing to the servant who carries off LEPIDUS]
line 7767-->  MENAS. Why?
line 7768-->  ENOBARBUS. 'A bears the third part of the world, man; see'st not?
line 7769-->  MENAS. The third part, then, is drunk. Would it were all,
line 7770-->    That it might go on wheels!
line 7771-->  ENOBARBUS. Drink thou; increase the reels.
line 7772-->  MENAS. Come.
line 7773-->  POMPEY. This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.
line 7774-->  ANTONY. It ripens towards it. Strike the vessels, ho!
line 7775-->    Here's to Caesar!  
line 7776-->  CAESAR. I could well forbear't.
line 7777-->    It's monstrous labour when I wash my brain
line 7778-->    And it grows fouler.
line 7779-->  ANTONY. Be a child o' th' time.
line 7780-->  CAESAR. Possess it, I'll make answer.
line 7781-->    But I had rather fast from all four days
line 7782-->    Than drink so much in one.
line 7783-->  ENOBARBUS. [To ANTONY] Ha, my brave emperor!
line 7784-->    Shall we dance now the Egyptian Bacchanals
line 7785-->    And celebrate our drink?
line 7786-->  POMPEY. Let's ha't, good soldier.
line 7787-->  ANTONY. Come, let's all take hands,
line 7788-->    Till that the conquering wine hath steep'd our sense
line 7789-->    In soft and delicate Lethe.
line 7790-->  ENOBARBUS. All take hands.
line 7791-->    Make battery to our ears with the loud music,
line 7792-->    The while I'll place you; then the boy shall sing;
line 7793-->    The holding every man shall bear as loud
line 7794-->    As his strong sides can volley.
line 7795-->               [Music plays. ENOBARBUS places them hand in hand]  
line 7796-->
line 7797-->                        THE SONG
line 7798-->            Come, thou monarch of the vine,
line 7799-->            Plumpy Bacchus with pink eyne!
line 7800-->            In thy fats our cares be drown'd,
line 7801-->            With thy grapes our hairs be crown'd.
line 7802-->            Cup us till the world go round,
line 7803-->            Cup us till the world go round!
line 7804-->
line 7805-->  CAESAR. What would you more? Pompey, good night. Good brother,
line 7806-->    Let me request you off; our graver business
line 7807-->    Frowns at this levity. Gentle lords, let's part;
line 7808-->    You see we have burnt our cheeks. Strong Enobarb
line 7809-->    Is weaker than the wine, and mine own tongue
line 7810-->    Splits what it speaks. The wild disguise hath almost
line 7811-->    Antick'd us all. What needs more words? Good night.
line 7812-->    Good Antony, your hand.
line 7813-->  POMPEY. I'll try you on the shore.
line 7814-->  ANTONY. And shall, sir. Give's your hand.
line 7815-->  POMPEY. O Antony,  
line 7816-->    You have my father's house- but what? We are friends.
line 7817-->    Come, down into the boat.
line 7818-->  ENOBARBUS. Take heed you fall not.
line 7819-->                              Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS and MENAS
line 7820-->    Menas, I'll not on shore.
line 7821-->  MENAS. No, to my cabin.
line 7822-->    These drums! these trumpets, flutes! what!
line 7823-->    Let Neptune hear we bid a loud farewell
line 7824-->    To these great fellows. Sound and be hang'd, sound out!
line 7825-->                                  [Sound a flourish, with drums]
line 7826-->  ENOBARBUS. Hoo! says 'a. There's my cap.
line 7827-->  MENAS. Hoo! Noble Captain, come.                        Exeunt
line 7828-->ACT_3|SC_1
line 7829-->                     ACT III. SCENE I.
line 7830-->                     A plain in Syria
line 7831-->
line 7832-->       Enter VENTIDIUS, as it were in triumph, with SILIUS
line 7833-->      and other Romans, OFFICERS and soldiers; the dead body
line 7834-->                of PACORUS borne before him
line 7835-->
line 7836-->  VENTIDIUS. Now, darting Parthia, art thou struck, and now
line 7837-->    Pleas'd fortune does of Marcus Crassus' death
line 7838-->    Make me revenger. Bear the King's son's body
line 7839-->    Before our army. Thy Pacorus, Orodes,
line 7840-->    Pays this for Marcus Crassus.
line 7841-->  SILIUS. Noble Ventidius,
line 7842-->    Whilst yet with Parthian blood thy sword is warm
line 7843-->    The fugitive Parthians follow; spur through Media,
line 7844-->    Mesopotamia, and the shelters whither
line 7845-->    The routed fly. So thy grand captain, Antony,
line 7846-->    Shall set thee on triumphant chariots and
line 7847-->    Put garlands on thy head.
line 7848-->  VENTIDIUS. O Silius, Silius,
line 7849-->    I have done enough. A lower place, note well,
line 7850-->    May make too great an act; for learn this, Silius:  
line 7851-->    Better to leave undone than by our deed
line 7852-->    Acquire too high a fame when him we serve's away.
line 7853-->    Caesar and Antony have ever won
line 7854-->    More in their officer, than person. Sossius,
line 7855-->    One of my place in Syria, his lieutenant,
line 7856-->    For quick accumulation of renown,
line 7857-->    Which he achiev'd by th' minute, lost his favour.
line 7858-->    Who does i' th' wars more than his captain can
line 7859-->    Becomes his captain's captain; and ambition,
line 7860-->    The soldier's virtue, rather makes choice of loss
line 7861-->    Than gain which darkens him.
line 7862-->    I could do more to do Antonius good,
line 7863-->    But 'twould offend him; and in his offence
line 7864-->    Should my performance perish.
line 7865-->  SILIUS. Thou hast, Ventidius, that
line 7866-->    Without the which a soldier and his sword
line 7867-->    Grants scarce distinction. Thou wilt write to Antony?
line 7868-->  VENTIDIUS. I'll humbly signify what in his name,
line 7869-->    That magical word of war, we have effected;
line 7870-->    How, with his banners, and his well-paid ranks,  
line 7871-->    The ne'er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia
line 7872-->    We have jaded out o' th' field.
line 7873-->  SILIUS. Where is he now?
line 7874-->  VENTIDIUS. He purposeth to Athens; whither, with what haste
line 7875-->    The weight we must convey with's will permit,
line 7876-->    We shall appear before him.- On, there; pass along.
line 7877-->                                                          Exeunt
line 7878-->
line 7879-->ACT_3|SC_2
line 7880-->                            SCENE II. Rome. CAESAR'S house
line 7881-->
line 7882-->        Enter AGRIPPA at one door, ENOBARBUS at another
line 7883-->
line 7884-->  AGRIPPA. What, are the brothers parted?
line 7885-->  ENOBARBUS. They have dispatch'd with Pompey; he is gone;
line 7886-->    The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps
line 7887-->    To part from Rome; Caesar is sad; and Lepidus,
line 7888-->    Since Pompey's feast, as Menas says, is troubled
line 7889-->    With the green sickness.
line 7890-->  AGRIPPA. 'Tis a noble Lepidus.
line 7891-->  ENOBARBUS. A very fine one. O, how he loves Caesar!
line 7892-->  AGRIPPA. Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!
line 7893-->  ENOBARBUS. Caesar? Why he's the Jupiter of men.
line 7894-->  AGRIPPA. What's Antony? The god of Jupiter.
line 7895-->  ENOBARBUS. Spake you of Caesar? How! the nonpareil!
line 7896-->  AGRIPPA. O, Antony! O thou Arabian bird!
line 7897-->  ENOBARBUS. Would you praise Caesar, say 'Caesar'- go no further.
line 7898-->  AGRIPPA. Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.
line 7899-->  ENOBARBUS. But he loves Caesar best. Yet he loves Antony.
line 7900-->    Hoo! hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot  
line 7901-->    Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number- hoo!-
line 7902-->    His love to Antony. But as for Caesar,
line 7903-->    Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.
line 7904-->  AGRIPPA. Both he loves.
line 7905-->  ENOBARBUS. They are his shards, and he their beetle. [Trumpets
line 7906-->      within] So-
line 7907-->    This is to horse. Adieu, noble Agrippa.
line 7908-->  AGRIPPA. Good fortune, worthy soldier, and farewell.
line 7909-->
line 7910-->           Enter CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, and OCTAVIA
line 7911-->
line 7912-->  ANTONY. No further, sir.
line 7913-->  CAESAR. You take from me a great part of myself;
line 7914-->    Use me well in't. Sister, prove such a wife
line 7915-->    As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest band
line 7916-->    Shall pass on thy approof. Most noble Antony,
line 7917-->    Let not the piece of virtue which is set
line 7918-->    Betwixt us as the cement of our love
line 7919-->    To keep it builded be the ram to batter
line 7920-->    The fortress of it; for better might we  
line 7921-->    Have lov'd without this mean, if on both parts
line 7922-->    This be not cherish'd.
line 7923-->  ANTONY. Make me not offended
line 7924-->    In your distrust.
line 7925-->  CAESAR. I have said.
line 7926-->  ANTONY. You shall not find,
line 7927-->    Though you be therein curious, the least cause
line 7928-->    For what you seem to fear. So the gods keep you,
line 7929-->    And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends!
line 7930-->    We will here part.
line 7931-->  CAESAR. Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well.
line 7932-->    The elements be kind to thee and make
line 7933-->    Thy spirits all of comfort! Fare thee well.
line 7934-->  OCTAVIA. My noble brother!
line 7935-->  ANTONY. The April's in her eyes. It is love's spring,
line 7936-->    And these the showers to bring it on. Be cheerful.
line 7937-->  OCTAVIA. Sir, look well to my husband's house; and-
line 7938-->  CAESAR. What, Octavia?
line 7939-->  OCTAVIA. I'll tell you in your ear.
line 7940-->  ANTONY. Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can  
line 7941-->    Her heart inform her tongue- the swan's down feather,
line 7942-->    That stands upon the swell at the full of tide,
line 7943-->    And neither way inclines.
line 7944-->  ENOBARBUS. [Aside to AGRIPPA] Will Caesar weep?
line 7945-->  AGRIPPA. [Aside to ENOBARBUS] He has a cloud in's face.
line 7946-->  ENOBARBUS. [Aside to AGRIPPA] He were the worse for that, were he a
line 7947-->      horse;
line 7948-->    So is he, being a man.
line 7949-->  AGRIPPA. [Aside to ENOBARBUS] Why, Enobarbus,
line 7950-->    When Antony found Julius Caesar dead,
line 7951-->    He cried almost to roaring; and he wept
line 7952-->    When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.
line 7953-->  ENOBARBUS. [Aside to AGRIPPA] That year, indeed, he was troubled
line 7954-->      with a rheum;
line 7955-->    What willingly he did confound he wail'd,
line 7956-->    Believe't- till I weep too.
line 7957-->  CAESAR. No, sweet Octavia,
line 7958-->    You shall hear from me still; the time shall not
line 7959-->    Out-go my thinking on you.
line 7960-->  ANTONY. Come, sir, come;  
line 7961-->    I'll wrestle with you in my strength of love.
line 7962-->    Look, here I have you; thus I let you go,
line 7963-->    And give you to the gods.
line 7964-->  CAESAR. Adieu; be happy!
line 7965-->  LEPIDUS. Let all the number of the stars give light
line 7966-->    To thy fair way!
line 7967-->  CAESAR. Farewell, farewell!                   [Kisses OCTAVIA]
line 7968-->  ANTONY. Farewell!                       Trumpets sound. Exeunt
line 7969-->
line 7970-->ACT_3|SC_3
line 7971-->                          SCENE III.
line 7972-->              Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palace
line 7973-->
line 7974-->         Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS
line 7975-->
line 7976-->  CLEOPATRA. Where is the fellow?
line 7977-->  ALEXAS. Half afeard to come.
line 7978-->  CLEOPATRA. Go to, go to.
line 7979-->
line 7980-->                Enter the MESSENGER as before
line 7981-->
line 7982-->    Come hither, sir.
line 7983-->  ALEXAS. Good Majesty,
line 7984-->    Herod of Jewry dare not look upon you
line 7985-->    But when you are well pleas'd.
line 7986-->  CLEOPATRA. That Herod's head
line 7987-->    I'll have. But how, when Antony is gone,
line 7988-->    Through whom I might command it? Come thou near.
line 7989-->  MESSENGER. Most gracious Majesty!
line 7990-->  CLEOPATRA. Didst thou behold Octavia?
line 7991-->  MESSENGER. Ay, dread Queen.
line 7992-->  CLEOPATRA. Where?  
line 7993-->  MESSENGER. Madam, in Rome
line 7994-->    I look'd her in the face, and saw her led
line 7995-->    Between her brother and Mark Antony.
line 7996-->  CLEOPATRA. Is she as tall as me?
line 7997-->  MESSENGER. She is not, madam.
line 7998-->  CLEOPATRA. Didst hear her speak? Is she shrill-tongu'd or low?
line 7999-->  MESSENGER. Madam, I heard her speak: she is low-voic'd.
line 8000-->  CLEOPATRA. That's not so good. He cannot like her long.
line 8001-->  CHARMIAN. Like her? O Isis! 'tis impossible.
line 8002-->  CLEOPATRA. I think so, Charmian. Dull of tongue and dwarfish!
line 8003-->    What majesty is in her gait? Remember,
line 8004-->    If e'er thou look'dst on majesty.
line 8005-->  MESSENGER. She creeps.
line 8006-->    Her motion and her station are as one;
line 8007-->    She shows a body rather than a life,
line 8008-->    A statue than a breather.
line 8009-->  CLEOPATRA. Is this certain?
line 8010-->  MESSENGER. Or I have no observance.
line 8011-->  CHARMIAN. Three in Egypt
line 8012-->    Cannot make better note.  
line 8013-->  CLEOPATRA. He's very knowing;
line 8014-->    I do perceive't. There's nothing in her yet.
line 8015-->    The fellow has good judgment.
line 8016-->  CHARMIAN. Excellent.
line 8017-->  CLEOPATRA. Guess at her years, I prithee.
line 8018-->  MESSENGER. Madam,
line 8019-->    She was a widow.
line 8020-->  CLEOPATRA. Widow? Charmian, hark!
line 8021-->  MESSENGER. And I do think she's thirty.
line 8022-->  CLEOPATRA. Bear'st thou her face in mind? Is't long or round?
line 8023-->  MESSENGER. Round even to faultiness.
line 8024-->  CLEOPATRA. For the most part, too, they are foolish that are so.
line 8025-->    Her hair, what colour?
line 8026-->  MESSENGER. Brown, madam; and her forehead
line 8027-->    As low as she would wish it.
line 8028-->  CLEOPATRA. There's gold for thee.
line 8029-->    Thou must not take my former sharpness ill.
line 8030-->    I will employ thee back again; I find thee
line 8031-->    Most fit for business. Go make thee ready;
line 8032-->    Our letters are prepar'd.                   Exeunt MESSENGER  
line 8033-->  CHARMIAN. A proper man.
line 8034-->  CLEOPATRA. Indeed, he is so. I repent me much
line 8035-->    That so I harried him. Why, methinks, by him,
line 8036-->    This creature's no such thing.
line 8037-->  CHARMIAN. Nothing, madam.
line 8038-->  CLEOPATRA. The man hath seen some majesty, and should know.
line 8039-->  CHARMIAN. Hath he seen majesty? Isis else defend,
line 8040-->    And serving you so long!
line 8041-->  CLEOPATRA. I have one thing more to ask him yet, good Charmian.
line 8042-->    But 'tis no matter; thou shalt bring him to me
line 8043-->    Where I will write. All may be well enough.
line 8044-->  CHARMIAN. I warrant you, madam.                         Exeunt
line 8045-->
line 8046-->ACT_3|SC_4
line 8047-->                          SCENE IV.
line 8048-->                  Athens. ANTONY'S house
line 8049-->
line 8050-->                 Enter ANTONY and OCTAVIA
line 8051-->
line 8052-->  ANTONY. Nay, nay, Octavia, not only that-
line 8053-->    That were excusable, that and thousands more
line 8054-->    Of semblable import- but he hath wag'd
line 8055-->    New wars 'gainst Pompey; made his will, and read it
line 8056-->    To public ear;
line 8057-->    Spoke scandy of me; when perforce he could not
line 8058-->    But pay me terms of honour, cold and sickly
line 8059-->    He vented them, most narrow measure lent me;
line 8060-->    When the best hint was given him, he not took't,
line 8061-->    Or did it from his teeth.
line 8062-->  OCTAVIA. O my good lord,
line 8063-->    Believe not all; or if you must believe,
line 8064-->    Stomach not all. A more unhappy lady,
line 8065-->    If this division chance, ne'er stood between,
line 8066-->    Praying for both parts.
line 8067-->    The good gods will mock me presently
line 8068-->    When I shall pray 'O, bless my lord and husband!'  
line 8069-->    Undo that prayer by crying out as loud
line 8070-->    'O, bless my brother!' Husband win, win brother,
line 8071-->    Prays, and destroys the prayer; no mid-way
line 8072-->    'Twixt these extremes at all.
line 8073-->  ANTONY. Gentle Octavia,
line 8074-->    Let your best love draw to that point which seeks
line 8075-->    Best to preserve it. If I lose mine honour,
line 8076-->    I lose myself; better I were not yours
line 8077-->    Than yours so branchless. But, as you requested,
line 8078-->    Yourself shall go between's. The meantime, lady,
line 8079-->    I'll raise the preparation of a war
line 8080-->    Shall stain your brother. Make your soonest haste;
line 8081-->    So your desires are yours.
line 8082-->  OCTAVIA. Thanks to my lord.
line 8083-->    The Jove of power make me, most weak, most weak,
line 8084-->    Your reconciler! Wars 'twixt you twain would be
line 8085-->    As if the world should cleave, and that slain men
line 8086-->    Should solder up the rift.
line 8087-->  ANTONY. When it appears to you where this begins,
line 8088-->    Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults  
line 8089-->    Can never be so equal that your love
line 8090-->    Can equally move with them. Provide your going;
line 8091-->    Choose your own company, and command what cost
line 8092-->    Your heart has mind to.                               Exeunt
line 8093-->
line 8094-->ACT_3|SC_5
line 8095-->                           SCENE V.
line 8096-->                   Athens. ANTONY'S house
line 8097-->
line 8098-->             Enter ENOBARBUS and EROS, meeting
line 8099-->
line 8100-->  ENOBARBUS. How now, friend Eros!
line 8101-->  EROS. There's strange news come, sir.
line 8102-->  ENOBARBUS. What, man?
line 8103-->  EROS. Caesar and Lepidus have made wars upon Pompey.
line 8104-->  ENOBARBUS. This is old. What is the success?
line 8105-->  EROS. Caesar, having made use of him in the wars 'gainst Pompey,
line 8106-->    presently denied him rivality, would not let him partake in the
line 8107-->    glory of the action; and not resting here, accuses him of letters
line 8108-->    he had formerly wrote to Pompey; upon his own appeal, seizes him.
line 8109-->    So the poor third is up, till death enlarge his confine.
line 8110-->  ENOBARBUS. Then, world, thou hast a pair of chaps- no more;
line 8111-->    And throw between them all the food thou hast,
line 8112-->    They'll grind the one the other. Where's Antony?
line 8113-->  EROS. He's walking in the garden- thus, and spurns
line 8114-->    The rush that lies before him; cries 'Fool Lepidus!'
line 8115-->    And threats the throat of that his officer
line 8116-->    That murd'red Pompey.  
line 8117-->  ENOBARBUS. Our great navy's rigg'd.
line 8118-->  EROS. For Italy and Caesar. More, Domitius:
line 8119-->    My lord desires you presently; my news
line 8120-->    I might have told hereafter.
line 8121-->  ENOBARBUS. 'Twill be naught;
line 8122-->    But let it be. Bring me to Antony.
line 8123-->  EROS. Come, sir.                                        Exeunt
line 8124-->
line 8125-->ACT_3|SC_6
line 8126-->                          SCENE VI.
line 8127-->                   Rome. CAESAR'S house
line 8128-->
line 8129-->             Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, and MAECENAS
line 8130-->
line 8131-->  CAESAR. Contemning Rome, he has done all this and more
line 8132-->    In Alexandria. Here's the manner of't:
line 8133-->    I' th' market-place, on a tribunal silver'd,
line 8134-->    Cleopatra and himself in chairs of gold
line 8135-->    Were publicly enthron'd; at the feet sat
line 8136-->    Caesarion, whom they call my father's son,
line 8137-->    And all the unlawful issue that their lust
line 8138-->    Since then hath made between them. Unto her
line 8139-->    He gave the stablishment of Egypt; made her
line 8140-->    Of lower Syria, Cyprus, Lydia,
line 8141-->    Absolute queen.
line 8142-->  MAECENAS. This in the public eye?
line 8143-->  CAESAR. I' th' common show-place, where they exercise.
line 8144-->    His sons he there proclaim'd the kings of kings:
line 8145-->    Great Media, Parthia, and Armenia,
line 8146-->    He gave to Alexander; to Ptolemy he assign'd
line 8147-->    Syria, Cilicia, and Phoenicia. She  
line 8148-->    In th' habiliments of the goddess Isis
line 8149-->    That day appear'd; and oft before gave audience,
line 8150-->    As 'tis reported, so.
line 8151-->  MAECENAS. Let Rome be thus
line 8152-->    Inform'd.
line 8153-->  AGRIPPA. Who, queasy with his insolence
line 8154-->    Already, will their good thoughts call from him.
line 8155-->  CAESAR. The people knows it, and have now receiv'd
line 8156-->    His accusations.
line 8157-->  AGRIPPA. Who does he accuse?
line 8158-->  CAESAR. Caesar; and that, having in Sicily
line 8159-->    Sextus Pompeius spoil'd, we had not rated him
line 8160-->    His part o' th' isle. Then does he say he lent me
line 8161-->    Some shipping, unrestor'd. Lastly, he frets
line 8162-->    That Lepidus of the triumvirate
line 8163-->    Should be depos'd; and, being, that we detain
line 8164-->    All his revenue.
line 8165-->  AGRIPPA. Sir, this should be answer'd.
line 8166-->  CAESAR. 'Tis done already, and messenger gone.
line 8167-->    I have told him Lepidus was grown too cruel,  
line 8168-->    That he his high authority abus'd,
line 8169-->    And did deserve his change. For what I have conquer'd
line 8170-->    I grant him part; but then, in his Armenia
line 8171-->    And other of his conquer'd kingdoms,
line 8172-->    Demand the like.
line 8173-->  MAECENAS. He'll never yield to that.
line 8174-->  CAESAR. Nor must not then be yielded to in this.
line 8175-->
line 8176-->                Enter OCTAVIA, with her train
line 8177-->
line 8178-->  OCTAVIA. Hail, Caesar, and my lord! hail, most dear Caesar!
line 8179-->  CAESAR. That ever I should call thee cast-away!
line 8180-->  OCTAVIA. You have not call'd me so, nor have you cause.
line 8181-->  CAESAR. Why have you stol'n upon us thus? You come not
line 8182-->    Like Caesar's sister. The wife of Antony
line 8183-->    Should have an army for an usher, and
line 8184-->    The neighs of horse to tell of her approach
line 8185-->    Long ere she did appear. The trees by th' way
line 8186-->    Should have borne men, and expectation fainted,
line 8187-->    Longing for what it had not. Nay, the dust  
line 8188-->    Should have ascended to the roof of heaven,
line 8189-->    Rais'd by your populous troops. But you are come
line 8190-->    A market-maid to Rome, and have prevented
line 8191-->    The ostentation of our love, which left unshown
line 8192-->    Is often left unlov'd. We should have met you
line 8193-->    By sea and land, supplying every stage
line 8194-->    With an augmented greeting.
line 8195-->  OCTAVIA. Good my lord,
line 8196-->    To come thus was I not constrain'd, but did it
line 8197-->    On my free will. My lord, Mark Antony,
line 8198-->    Hearing that you prepar'd for war, acquainted
line 8199-->    My grieved ear withal; whereon I begg'd
line 8200-->    His pardon for return.
line 8201-->  CAESAR. Which soon he granted,
line 8202-->    Being an obstruct 'tween his lust and him.
line 8203-->  OCTAVIA. Do not say so, my lord.
line 8204-->  CAESAR. I have eyes upon him,
line 8205-->    And his affairs come to me on the wind.
line 8206-->    Where is he now?
line 8207-->  OCTAVIA. My lord, in Athens.  
line 8208-->  CAESAR. No, my most wronged sister: Cleopatra
line 8209-->    Hath nodded him to her. He hath given his empire
line 8210-->    Up to a whore, who now are levying
line 8211-->    The kings o' th' earth for war. He hath assembled
line 8212-->    Bocchus, the king of Libya; Archelaus
line 8213-->    Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, king
line 8214-->    Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas;
line 8215-->    King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont;
line 8216-->    Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, king
line 8217-->    Of Comagene; Polemon and Amyntas,
line 8218-->    The kings of Mede and Lycaonia, with
line 8219-->    More larger list of sceptres.
line 8220-->  OCTAVIA. Ay me most wretched,
line 8221-->    That have my heart parted betwixt two friends,
line 8222-->    That does afflict each other!
line 8223-->  CAESAR. Welcome hither.
line 8224-->    Your letters did withhold our breaking forth,
line 8225-->    Till we perceiv'd both how you were wrong led
line 8226-->    And we in negligent danger. Cheer your heart;
line 8227-->    Be you not troubled with the time, which drives  
line 8228-->    O'er your content these strong necessities,
line 8229-->    But let determin'd things to destiny
line 8230-->    Hold unbewail'd their way. Welcome to Rome;
line 8231-->    Nothing more dear to me. You are abus'd
line 8232-->    Beyond the mark of thought, and the high gods,
line 8233-->    To do you justice, make their ministers
line 8234-->    Of us and those that love you. Best of comfort,
line 8235-->    And ever welcome to us.
line 8236-->  AGRIPPA. Welcome, lady.
line 8237-->  MAECENAS. Welcome, dear madam.
line 8238-->    Each heart in Rome does love and pity you;
line 8239-->    Only th' adulterous Antony, most large
line 8240-->    In his abominations, turns you off,
line 8241-->    And gives his potent regiment to a trull
line 8242-->    That noises it against us.
line 8243-->  OCTAVIA. Is it so, sir?
line 8244-->  CAESAR. Most certain. Sister, welcome. Pray you
line 8245-->    Be ever known to patience. My dear'st sister!         Exeunt
line 8246-->
line 8247-->ACT_3|SC_7
line 8248-->                          SCENE VII.
line 8249-->                  ANTONY'S camp near Actium
line 8250-->
line 8251-->                Enter CLEOPATRA and ENOBARBUS
line 8252-->
line 8253-->  CLEOPATRA. I will be even with thee, doubt it not.
line 8254-->  ENOBARBUS. But why, why,
line 8255-->  CLEOPATRA. Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars,
line 8256-->    And say'st it is not fit.
line 8257-->  ENOBARBUS. Well, is it, is it?
line 8258-->  CLEOPATRA. Is't not denounc'd against us? Why should not we
line 8259-->    Be there in person?
line 8260-->  ENOBARBUS. [Aside] Well, I could reply:
line 8261-->    If we should serve with horse and mares together
line 8262-->    The horse were merely lost; the mares would bear
line 8263-->    A soldier and his horse.
line 8264-->  CLEOPATRA. What is't you say?
line 8265-->  ENOBARBUS. Your presence needs must puzzle Antony;
line 8266-->    Take from his heart, take from his brain, from's time,
line 8267-->    What should not then be spar'd. He is already
line 8268-->    Traduc'd for levity; and 'tis said in Rome
line 8269-->    That Photinus an eunuch and your maids  
line 8270-->    Manage this war.
line 8271-->  CLEOPATRA. Sink Rome, and their tongues rot
line 8272-->    That speak against us! A charge we bear i' th' war,
line 8273-->    And, as the president of my kingdom, will
line 8274-->    Appear there for a man. Speak not against it;
line 8275-->    I will not stay behind.
line 8276-->
line 8277-->                   Enter ANTONY and CANIDIUS
line 8278-->
line 8279-->  ENOBARBUS. Nay, I have done.
line 8280-->    Here comes the Emperor.
line 8281-->  ANTONY. Is it not strange, Canidius,
line 8282-->    That from Tarentum and Brundusium
line 8283-->    He could so quickly cut the Ionian sea,
line 8284-->    And take in Toryne?- You have heard on't, sweet?
line 8285-->  CLEOPATRA. Celerity is never more admir'd
line 8286-->    Than by the negligent.
line 8287-->  ANTONY. A good rebuke,
line 8288-->    Which might have well becom'd the best of men
line 8289-->    To taunt at slackness. Canidius, we  
line 8290-->    Will fight with him by sea.
line 8291-->  CLEOPATRA. By sea! What else?
line 8292-->  CANIDIUS. Why will my lord do so?
line 8293-->  ANTONY. For that he dares us to't.
line 8294-->  ENOBARBUS. So hath my lord dar'd him to single fight.
line 8295-->  CANIDIUS. Ay, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia,
line 8296-->    Where Caesar fought with Pompey. But these offers,
line 8297-->    Which serve not for his vantage, he shakes off;
line 8298-->    And so should you.
line 8299-->  ENOBARBUS. Your ships are not well mann'd;
line 8300-->    Your mariners are muleteers, reapers, people
line 8301-->    Ingross'd by swift impress. In Caesar's fleet
line 8302-->    Are those that often have 'gainst Pompey fought;
line 8303-->    Their ships are yare; yours heavy. No disgrace
line 8304-->    Shall fall you for refusing him at sea,
line 8305-->    Being prepar'd for land.
line 8306-->  ANTONY. By sea, by sea.
line 8307-->  ENOBARBUS. Most worthy sir, you therein throw away
line 8308-->    The absolute soldiership you have by land;
line 8309-->    Distract your army, which doth most consist  
line 8310-->    Of war-mark'd footmen; leave unexecuted
line 8311-->    Your own renowned knowledge; quite forgo
line 8312-->    The way which promises assurance; and
line 8313-->    Give up yourself merely to chance and hazard
line 8314-->    From firm security.
line 8315-->  ANTONY. I'll fight at sea.
line 8316-->  CLEOPATRA. I have sixty sails, Caesar none better.
line 8317-->  ANTONY. Our overplus of shipping will we burn,
line 8318-->    And, with the rest full-mann'd, from th' head of Actium
line 8319-->    Beat th' approaching Caesar. But if we fail,
line 8320-->    We then can do't at land.
line 8321-->
line 8322-->                       Enter a MESSENGER
line 8323-->
line 8324-->    Thy business?
line 8325-->  MESSENGER. The news is true, my lord: he is descried;
line 8326-->    Caesar has taken Toryne.
line 8327-->  ANTONY. Can he be there in person? 'Tis impossible-
line 8328-->    Strange that his power should be. Canidius,
line 8329-->    Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land,  
line 8330-->    And our twelve thousand horse. We'll to our ship.
line 8331-->    Away, my Thetis!
line 8332-->
line 8333-->                       Enter a SOLDIER
line 8334-->
line 8335-->    How now, worthy soldier?
line 8336-->  SOLDIER. O noble Emperor, do not fight by sea;
line 8337-->    Trust not to rotten planks. Do you misdoubt
line 8338-->    This sword and these my wounds? Let th' Egyptians
line 8339-->    And the Phoenicians go a-ducking; we
line 8340-->    Have us'd to conquer standing on the earth
line 8341-->    And fighting foot to foot.
line 8342-->  ANTONY. Well, well- away.
line 8343-->                         Exeunt ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, and ENOBARBUS
line 8344-->  SOLDIER. By Hercules, I think I am i' th' right.
line 8345-->  CANIDIUS. Soldier, thou art; but his whole action grows
line 8346-->    Not in the power on't. So our leader's led,
line 8347-->    And we are women's men.
line 8348-->  SOLDIER. You keep by land
line 8349-->    The legions and the horse whole, do you not?  
line 8350-->  CANIDIUS. Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius,
line 8351-->    Publicola, and Caelius are for sea;
line 8352-->    But we keep whole by land. This speed of Caesar's
line 8353-->    Carries beyond belief.
line 8354-->  SOLDIER. While he was yet in Rome,
line 8355-->    His power went out in such distractions as
line 8356-->    Beguil'd all spies.
line 8357-->  CANIDIUS. Who's his lieutenant, hear you?
line 8358-->  SOLDIER. They say one Taurus.
line 8359-->  CANIDIUS. Well I know the man.
line 8360-->
line 8361-->                        Enter a MESSENGER
line 8362-->
line 8363-->  MESSENGER. The Emperor calls Canidius.
line 8364-->  CANIDIUS. With news the time's with labour and throes forth
line 8365-->    Each minute some.                                     Exeunt
line 8366-->
line 8367-->ACT_3|SC_8
line 8368-->                          SCENE VIII.
line 8369-->                      A plain near Actium
line 8370-->
line 8371-->             Enter CAESAR, with his army, marching
line 8372-->
line 8373-->  CAESAR. Taurus!
line 8374-->  TAURUS. My lord?
line 8375-->  CAESAR. Strike not by land; keep whole; provoke not battle
line 8376-->    Till we have done at sea. Do not exceed
line 8377-->    The prescript of this scroll. Our fortune lies
line 8378-->    Upon this jump.                                       Exeunt
line 8379-->
line 8380-->ACT_3|SC_9
line 8381-->                           SCENE IX.
line 8382-->                  Another part of the plain
line 8383-->
line 8384-->                  Enter ANTONY and ENOBARBUS
line 8385-->
line 8386-->  ANTONY. Set we our squadrons on yon side o' th' hill,
line 8387-->    In eye of Caesar's battle; from which place
line 8388-->    We may the number of the ships behold,
line 8389-->    And so proceed accordingly.                           Exeunt
line 8390-->
line 8391-->ACT_3|SC_10
line 8392-->                           SCENE X.
line 8393-->                 Another part of the plain
line 8394-->
line 8395-->        CANIDIUS marcheth with his land army one way
line 8396-->        over the stage, and TAURUS, the Lieutenant of
line 8397-->      CAESAR, the other way. After their going in is heard
line 8398-->                   the noise of a sea-fight
line 8399-->
line 8400-->                    Alarum. Enter ENOBARBUS
line 8401-->
line 8402-->  ENOBARBUS. Naught, naught, all naught! I can behold no longer.
line 8403-->    Th' Antoniad, the Egyptian admiral,
line 8404-->    With all their sixty, fly and turn the rudder.
line 8405-->    To see't mine eyes are blasted.
line 8406-->
line 8407-->                        Enter SCARUS
line 8408-->
line 8409-->  SCARUS. Gods and goddesses,
line 8410-->    All the whole synod of them!
line 8411-->  ENOBARBUS. What's thy passion?
line 8412-->  SCARUS. The greater cantle of the world is lost
line 8413-->    With very ignorance; we have kiss'd away  
line 8414-->    Kingdoms and provinces.
line 8415-->  ENOBARBUS. How appears the fight?
line 8416-->  SCARUS. On our side like the token'd pestilence,
line 8417-->    Where death is sure. Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt-
line 8418-->    Whom leprosy o'ertake!- i' th' midst o' th' fight,
line 8419-->    When vantage like a pair of twins appear'd,
line 8420-->    Both as the same, or rather ours the elder-
line 8421-->    The breese upon her, like a cow in June-
line 8422-->    Hoists sails and flies.
line 8423-->  ENOBARBUS. That I beheld;
line 8424-->    Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not
line 8425-->    Endure a further view.
line 8426-->  SCARUS. She once being loof'd,
line 8427-->    The noble ruin of her magic, Antony,
line 8428-->    Claps on his sea-wing, and, like a doting mallard,
line 8429-->    Leaving the fight in height, flies after her.
line 8430-->    I never saw an action of such shame;
line 8431-->    Experience, manhood, honour, ne'er before
line 8432-->    Did violate so itself.
line 8433-->  ENOBARBUS. Alack, alack!  
line 8434-->
line 8435-->                       Enter CANIDIUS
line 8436-->
line 8437-->  CANIDIUS. Our fortune on the sea is out of breath,
line 8438-->    And sinks most lamentably. Had our general
line 8439-->    Been what he knew himself, it had gone well.
line 8440-->    O, he has given example for our flight
line 8441-->    Most grossly by his own!
line 8442-->  ENOBARBUS. Ay, are you thereabouts?
line 8443-->    Why then, good night indeed.
line 8444-->  CANIDIUS. Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.
line 8445-->  SCARUS. 'Tis easy to't; and there I will attend
line 8446-->    What further comes.
line 8447-->  CANIDIUS. To Caesar will I render
line 8448-->    My legions and my horse; six kings already
line 8449-->    Show me the way of yielding.
line 8450-->  ENOBARBUS. I'll yet follow
line 8451-->    The wounded chance of Antony, though my reason
line 8452-->    Sits in the wind against me.                          Exeunt
line 8453-->
line 8454-->ACT_3|SC_11
line 8455-->                         SCENE XI.
line 8456-->              Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palace
line 8457-->
line 8458-->               Enter ANTONY With attendants
line 8459-->
line 8460-->  ANTONY. Hark! the land bids me tread no more upon't;
line 8461-->    It is asham'd to bear me. Friends, come hither.
line 8462-->    I am so lated in the world that I
line 8463-->    Have lost my way for ever. I have a ship
line 8464-->    Laden with gold; take that; divide it. Fly,
line 8465-->    And make your peace with Caesar.
line 8466-->  ALL. Fly? Not we!
line 8467-->  ANTONY. I have fled myself, and have instructed cowards
line 8468-->    To run and show their shoulders. Friends, be gone;
line 8469-->    I have myself resolv'd upon a course
line 8470-->    Which has no need of you; be gone.
line 8471-->    My treasure's in the harbour, take it. O,
line 8472-->    I follow'd that I blush to look upon.
line 8473-->    My very hairs do mutiny; for the white
line 8474-->    Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them
line 8475-->    For fear and doting. Friends, be gone; you shall
line 8476-->    Have letters from me to some friends that will  
line 8477-->    Sweep your way for you. Pray you look not sad,
line 8478-->    Nor make replies of loathness; take the hint
line 8479-->    Which my despair proclaims. Let that be left
line 8480-->    Which leaves itself. To the sea-side straight way.
line 8481-->    I will possess you of that ship and treasure.
line 8482-->    Leave me, I pray, a little; pray you now;
line 8483-->    Nay, do so, for indeed I have lost command;
line 8484-->    Therefore I pray you. I'll see you by and by.    [Sits down]
line 8485-->
line 8486-->            Enter CLEOPATRA, led by CHARMIAN and IRAS,
line 8487-->                         EROS following
line 8488-->
line 8489-->  EROS. Nay, gentle madam, to him! Comfort him.
line 8490-->  IRAS. Do, most dear Queen.
line 8491-->  CHARMIAN. Do? Why, what else?
line 8492-->  CLEOPATRA. Let me sit down. O Juno!
line 8493-->  ANTONY. No, no, no, no, no.
line 8494-->  EROS. See you here, sir?
line 8495-->  ANTONY. O, fie, fie, fie!
line 8496-->  CHARMIAN. Madam!  
line 8497-->  IRAS. Madam, O good Empress!
line 8498-->  EROS. Sir, sir!
line 8499-->  ANTONY. Yes, my lord, yes. He at Philippi kept
line 8500-->    His sword e'en like a dancer, while I struck
line 8501-->    The lean and wrinkled Cassius; and 'twas I
line 8502-->    That the mad Brutus ended; he alone
line 8503-->    Dealt on lieutenantry, and no practice had
line 8504-->    In the brave squares of war. Yet now- no matter.
line 8505-->  CLEOPATRA. Ah, stand by!
line 8506-->  EROS. The Queen, my lord, the Queen!
line 8507-->  IRAS. Go to him, madam, speak to him.
line 8508-->    He is unqualitied with very shame.
line 8509-->  CLEOPATRA. Well then, sustain me. O!
line 8510--> EROS. Most noble sir, arise; the Queen approaches.
line 8511-->    Her head's declin'd, and death will seize her but
line 8512-->    Your comfort makes the rescue.
line 8513-->  ANTONY. I have offended reputation-
line 8514-->    A most unnoble swerving.
line 8515-->  EROS. Sir, the Queen.
line 8516-->  ANTONY. O, whither hast thou led me, Egypt? See
line 8517-->    How I convey my shame out of thine eyes  
line 8518-->    By looking back what I have left behind
line 8519-->    'Stroy'd in dishonour.
line 8520-->  CLEOPATRA. O my lord, my lord,
line 8521-->    Forgive my fearful sails! I little thought
line 8522-->    You would have followed.
line 8523-->  ANTONY. Egypt, thou knew'st too well
line 8524-->    My heart was to thy rudder tied by th' strings,
line 8525-->    And thou shouldst tow me after. O'er my spirit
line 8526-->    Thy full supremacy thou knew'st, and that
line 8527-->    Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods
line 8528-->    Command me.
line 8529-->  CLEOPATRA. O, my pardon!
line 8530-->  ANTONY. Now I must
line 8531-->    To the young man send humble treaties, dodge
line 8532-->    And palter in the shifts of lowness, who
line 8533-->    With half the bulk o' th' world play'd as I pleas'd,
line 8534-->    Making and marring fortunes. You did know
line 8535-->    How much you were my conqueror, and that
line 8536-->    My sword, made weak by my affection, would
line 8537-->    Obey it on all cause.  
line 8538-->  CLEOPATRA. Pardon, pardon!
line 8539-->  ANTONY. Fall not a tear, I say; one of them rates
line 8540-->    All that is won and lost. Give me a kiss;
line 8541-->    Even this repays me.
line 8542-->    We sent our schoolmaster; is 'a come back?
line 8543-->    Love, I am full of lead. Some wine,
line 8544-->    Within there, and our viands! Fortune knows
line 8545-->    We scorn her most when most she offers blows.         Exeunt
line 8546-->
line 8547-->ACT_3|SC_12
line 8548-->                         SCENE XII.
line 8549-->                   CAESAR'S camp in Egypt
line 8550-->
line 8551-->   Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, DOLABELLA, THYREUS, with others
line 8552-->
line 8553-->  CAESAR. Let him appear that's come from Antony.
line 8554-->    Know you him?
line 8555-->  DOLABELLA. Caesar, 'tis his schoolmaster:
line 8556-->    An argument that he is pluck'd, when hither
line 8557-->    He sends so poor a pinion of his wing,
line 8558-->    Which had superfluous kings for messengers
line 8559-->    Not many moons gone by.
line 8560-->
line 8561-->            Enter EUPHRONIUS, Ambassador from ANTONY
line 8562-->
line 8563-->  CAESAR. Approach, and speak.
line 8564-->  EUPHRONIUS. Such as I am, I come from Antony.
line 8565-->    I was of late as petty to his ends
line 8566-->    As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf
line 8567-->    To his grand sea.
line 8568-->  CAESAR. Be't so. Declare thine office.
line 8569-->  EUPHRONIUS. Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and  
line 8570-->    Requires to live in Egypt; which not granted,
line 8571-->    He lessens his requests and to thee sues
line 8572-->    To let him breathe between the heavens and earth,
line 8573-->    A private man in Athens. This for him.
line 8574-->    Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness,
line 8575-->    Submits her to thy might, and of thee craves
line 8576-->    The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs,
line 8577-->    Now hazarded to thy grace.
line 8578-->  CAESAR. For Antony,
line 8579-->    I have no ears to his request. The Queen
line 8580-->    Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she
line 8581-->    From Egypt drive her all-disgraced friend,
line 8582-->    Or take his life there. This if she perform,
line 8583-->    She shall not sue unheard. So to them both.
line 8584-->  EUPHRONIUS. Fortune pursue thee!
line 8585-->  CAESAR. Bring him through the bands.           Exit EUPHRONIUS
line 8586-->    [To THYREUS] To try thy eloquence, now 'tis time. Dispatch;
line 8587-->    From Antony win Cleopatra. Promise,
line 8588-->    And in our name, what she requires; add more,
line 8589-->    From thine invention, offers. Women are not  
line 8590-->    In their best fortunes strong; but want will perjure
line 8591-->    The ne'er-touch'd vestal. Try thy cunning, Thyreus;
line 8592-->    Make thine own edict for thy pains, which we
line 8593-->    Will answer as a law.
line 8594-->  THYREUS. Caesar, I go.
line 8595-->  CAESAR. Observe how Antony becomes his flaw,
line 8596-->    And what thou think'st his very action speaks
line 8597-->    In every power that moves.
line 8598-->  THYREUS. Caesar, I shall.                               Exeunt
line 8599-->
line 8600-->ACT_3|SC_13
line 8601-->                           SCENE XIII.
line 8602-->               Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palace
line 8603-->
line 8604-->        Enter CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS
line 8605-->
line 8606-->  CLEOPATRA. What shall we do, Enobarbus?
line 8607-->  ENOBARBUS. Think, and die.
line 8608-->  CLEOPATRA. Is Antony or we in fault for this?
line 8609-->  ENOBARBUS. Antony only, that would make his will
line 8610-->    Lord of his reason. What though you fled
line 8611-->    From that great face of war, whose several ranges
line 8612-->    Frighted each other? Why should he follow?
line 8613-->    The itch of his affection should not then
line 8614-->    Have nick'd his captainship, at such a point,
line 8615-->    When half to half the world oppos'd, he being
line 8616-->    The mered question. 'Twas a shame no less
line 8617-->    Than was his loss, to course your flying flags
line 8618-->    And leave his navy gazing.
line 8619-->  CLEOPATRA. Prithee, peace.
line 8620-->
line 8621-->          Enter EUPHRONIUS, the Ambassador; with ANTONY
line 8622-->  
line 8623-->  ANTONY. Is that his answer?
line 8624-->  EUPHRONIUS. Ay, my lord.
line 8625-->  ANTONY. The Queen shall then have courtesy, so she
line 8626-->    Will yield us up.
line 8627-->  EUPHRONIUS. He says so.
line 8628-->  ANTONY. Let her know't.
line 8629-->    To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head,
line 8630-->    And he will fill thy wishes to the brim
line 8631-->    With principalities.
line 8632-->  CLEOPATRA. That head, my lord?
line 8633-->  ANTONY. To him again. Tell him he wears the rose
line 8634-->    Of youth upon him; from which the world should note
line 8635-->    Something particular. His coin, ships, legions,
line 8636-->    May be a coward's whose ministers would prevail
line 8637-->    Under the service of a child as soon
line 8638-->    As i' th' command of Caesar. I dare him therefore
line 8639-->    To lay his gay comparisons apart,
line 8640-->    And answer me declin'd, sword against sword,
line 8641-->    Ourselves alone. I'll write it. Follow me.
line 8642-->                                    Exeunt ANTONY and EUPHRONIUS  
line 8643-->  EUPHRONIUS. [Aside] Yes, like enough high-battled Caesar will
line 8644-->    Unstate his happiness, and be stag'd to th' show
line 8645-->    Against a sworder! I see men's judgments are
line 8646-->    A parcel of their fortunes, and things outward
line 8647-->    Do draw the inward quality after them,
line 8648-->    To suffer all alike. That he should dream,
line 8649-->    Knowing all measures, the full Caesar will
line 8650-->    Answer his emptiness! Caesar, thou hast subdu'd
line 8651-->    His judgment too.
line 8652-->
line 8653-->                       Enter a SERVANT
line 8654-->
line 8655-->  SERVANT. A messenger from Caesar.
line 8656-->  CLEOPATRA. What, no more ceremony? See, my women!
line 8657-->    Against the blown rose may they stop their nose
line 8658-->    That kneel'd unto the buds. Admit him, sir.     Exit SERVANT
line 8659-->  ENOBARBUS. [Aside] Mine honesty and I begin to square.
line 8660-->    The loyalty well held to fools does make
line 8661-->    Our faith mere folly. Yet he that can endure
line 8662-->    To follow with allegiance a fall'n lord  
line 8663-->    Does conquer him that did his master conquer,
line 8664-->    And earns a place i' th' story.
line 8665-->
line 8666-->                       Enter THYREUS
line 8667-->
line 8668-->  CLEOPATRA. Caesar's will?
line 8669-->  THYREUS. Hear it apart.
line 8670-->  CLEOPATRA. None but friends: say boldly.
line 8671-->  THYREUS. So, haply, are they friends to Antony.
line 8672-->  ENOBARBUS. He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has,
line 8673-->    Or needs not us. If Caesar please, our master
line 8674-->    Will leap to be his friend. For us, you know
line 8675-->    Whose he is we are, and that is Caesar's.
line 8676-->  THYREUS. So.
line 8677-->    Thus then, thou most renown'd: Caesar entreats
line 8678-->    Not to consider in what case thou stand'st
line 8679-->    Further than he is Caesar.
line 8680-->  CLEOPATRA. Go on. Right royal!
line 8681-->  THYREUS. He knows that you embrace not Antony
line 8682-->    As you did love, but as you fear'd him.  
line 8683-->  CLEOPATRA. O!
line 8684-->  THYREUS. The scars upon your honour, therefore, he
line 8685-->    Does pity, as constrained blemishes,
line 8686-->    Not as deserv'd.
line 8687-->  CLEOPATRA. He is a god, and knows
line 8688-->    What is most right. Mine honour was not yielded,
line 8689-->    But conquer'd merely.
line 8690-->  ENOBARBUS. [Aside] To be sure of that,
line 8691-->    I will ask Antony. Sir, sir, thou art so leaky
line 8692-->    That we must leave thee to thy sinking, for
line 8693-->    Thy dearest quit thee.                                  Exit
line 8694-->  THYREUS. Shall I say to Caesar
line 8695-->    What you require of him? For he partly begs
line 8696-->    To be desir'd to give. It much would please him
line 8697-->    That of his fortunes you should make a staff
line 8698-->    To lean upon. But it would warm his spirits
line 8699-->    To hear from me you had left Antony,
line 8700-->    And put yourself under his shroud,
line 8701-->    The universal landlord.
line 8702-->  CLEOPATRA. What's your name?  
line 8703-->  THYREUS. My name is Thyreus.
line 8704-->  CLEOPATRA. Most kind messenger,
line 8705-->    Say to great Caesar this: in deputation
line 8706-->    I kiss his conquring hand. Tell him I am prompt
line 8707-->    To lay my crown at 's feet, and there to kneel.
line 8708-->    Tell him from his all-obeying breath I hear
line 8709-->    The doom of Egypt.
line 8710-->  THYREUS. 'Tis your noblest course.
line 8711-->    Wisdom and fortune combating together,
line 8712-->    If that the former dare but what it can,
line 8713-->    No chance may shake it. Give me grace to lay
line 8714-->    My duty on your hand.
line 8715-->  CLEOPATRA. Your Caesar's father oft,
line 8716-->    When he hath mus'd of taking kingdoms in,
line 8717-->    Bestow'd his lips on that unworthy place,
line 8718-->    As it rain'd kisses.
line 8719-->
line 8720-->                Re-enter ANTONY and ENOBARBUS
line 8721-->
line 8722-->  ANTONY. Favours, by Jove that thunders!  
line 8723-->    What art thou, fellow?
line 8724-->  THYREUS. One that but performs
line 8725-->    The bidding of the fullest man, and worthiest
line 8726-->    To have command obey'd.
line 8727-->  ENOBARBUS. [Aside] You will be whipt.
line 8728-->  ANTONY. Approach there.- Ah, you kite!- Now, gods and devils!
line 8729-->    Authority melts from me. Of late, when I cried 'Ho!'
line 8730-->    Like boys unto a muss, kings would start forth
line 8731-->    And cry 'Your will?' Have you no ears? I am
line 8732-->    Antony yet.
line 8733-->
line 8734-->                       Enter servants
line 8735-->
line 8736-->    Take hence this Jack and whip him.
line 8737-->  ENOBARBUS. 'Tis better playing with a lion's whelp
line 8738-->    Than with an old one dying.
line 8739-->  ANTONY. Moon and stars!
line 8740-->    Whip him. Were't twenty of the greatest tributaries
line 8741-->    That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them
line 8742-->    So saucy with the hand of she here- what's her name  
line 8743-->    Since she was Cleopatra? Whip him, fellows,
line 8744-->    Till like a boy you see him cringe his face,
line 8745-->    And whine aloud for mercy. Take him hence.
line 8746-->  THYMUS. Mark Antony-
line 8747-->  ANTONY. Tug him away. Being whipt,
line 8748-->    Bring him again: the Jack of Caesar's shall
line 8749-->    Bear us an errand to him.       Exeunt servants with THYREUS
line 8750-->    You were half blasted ere I knew you. Ha!
line 8751-->    Have I my pillow left unpress'd in Rome,
line 8752-->    Forborne the getting of a lawful race,
line 8753-->    And by a gem of women, to be abus'd
line 8754-->    By one that looks on feeders?
line 8755-->  CLEOPATRA. Good my lord-
line 8756-->  ANTONY. You have been a boggler ever.
line 8757-->    But when we in our viciousness grow hard-
line 8758-->    O misery on't!- the wise gods seel our eyes,
line 8759-->    In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us
line 8760-->    Adore our errors, laugh at's while we strut
line 8761-->    To our confusion.
line 8762-->  CLEOPATRA. O, is't come to this?  
line 8763-->  ANTONY. I found you as a morsel cold upon
line 8764-->    Dead Caesar's trencher. Nay, you were a fragment
line 8765-->    Of Cneius Pompey's, besides what hotter hours,
line 8766-->    Unregist'red in vulgar fame, you have
line 8767-->    Luxuriously pick'd out; for I am sure,
line 8768-->    Though you can guess what temperance should be,
line 8769-->    You know not what it is.
line 8770-->  CLEOPATRA. Wherefore is this?
line 8771-->  ANTONY. To let a fellow that will take rewards,
line 8772-->    And say 'God quit you!' be familiar with
line 8773-->    My playfellow, your hand, this kingly seal
line 8774-->    And plighter of high hearts! O that I were
line 8775-->    Upon the hill of Basan to outroar
line 8776-->    The horned herd! For I have savage cause,
line 8777-->    And to proclaim it civilly were like
line 8778-->    A halter'd neck which does the hangman thank
line 8779-->    For being yare about him.
line 8780-->
line 8781-->              Re-enter a SERVANT with THYREUS
line 8782-->  
line 8783-->    Is he whipt?
line 8784-->  SERVANT. Soundly, my lord.
line 8785-->  ANTONY. Cried he? and begg'd 'a pardon?
line 8786-->  SERVANT. He did ask favour.
line 8787-->  ANTONY. If that thy father live, let him repent
line 8788-->    Thou wast not made his daughter; and be thou sorry
line 8789-->    To follow Caesar in his triumph, since
line 8790-->    Thou hast been whipt for following him. Henceforth
line 8791-->    The white hand of a lady fever thee!
line 8792-->    Shake thou to look on't. Get thee back to Caesar;
line 8793-->    Tell him thy entertainment; look thou say
line 8794-->    He makes me angry with him; for he seems
line 8795-->    Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am,
line 8796-->    Not what he knew I was. He makes me angry;
line 8797-->    And at this time most easy 'tis to do't,
line 8798-->    When my good stars, that were my former guides,
line 8799-->    Have empty left their orbs and shot their fires
line 8800-->    Into th' abysm of hell. If he mislike
line 8801-->    My speech and what is done, tell him he has
line 8802-->    Hipparchus, my enfranched bondman, whom  
line 8803-->    He may at pleasure whip or hang or torture,
line 8804-->    As he shall like, to quit me. Urge it thou.
line 8805-->    Hence with thy stripes, be gone.                Exit THYREUS
line 8806-->  CLEOPATRA. Have you done yet?
line 8807-->  ANTONY. Alack, our terrene moon
line 8808-->    Is now eclips'd, and it portends alone
line 8809-->    The fall of Antony.
line 8810-->  CLEOPATRA. I must stay his time.
line 8811-->  ANTONY. To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes
line 8812-->    With one that ties his points?
line 8813-->  CLEOPATRA. Not know me yet?
line 8814-->  ANTONY. Cold-hearted toward me?
line 8815-->  CLEOPATRA. Ah, dear, if I be so,
line 8816-->    From my cold heart let heaven engender hail,
line 8817-->    And poison it in the source, and the first stone
line 8818-->    Drop in my neck; as it determines, so
line 8819-->    Dissolve my life! The next Caesarion smite!
line 8820-->    Till by degrees the memory of my womb,
line 8821-->    Together with my brave Egyptians all,
line 8822-->    By the discandying of this pelleted storm,  
line 8823-->    Lie graveless, till the flies and gnats of Nile
line 8824-->    Have buried them for prey.
line 8825-->  ANTONY. I am satisfied.
line 8826-->    Caesar sits down in Alexandria, where
line 8827-->    I will oppose his fate. Our force by land
line 8828-->    Hath nobly held; our sever'd navy to
line 8829-->    Have knit again, and fleet, threat'ning most sea-like.
line 8830-->    Where hast thou been, my heart? Dost thou hear, lady?
line 8831-->    If from the field I shall return once more
line 8832-->    To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood.
line 8833-->    I and my sword will earn our chronicle.
line 8834-->    There's hope in't yet.
line 8835-->  CLEOPATRA. That's my brave lord!
line 8836-->  ANTONY. I will be treble-sinew'd, hearted, breath'd,
line 8837-->    And fight maliciously. For when mine hours
line 8838-->    Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives
line 8839-->    Of me for jests; but now I'll set my teeth,
line 8840-->    And send to darkness all that stop me. Come,
line 8841-->    Let's have one other gaudy night. Call to me
line 8842-->    All my sad captains; fill our bowls once more;  
line 8843-->    Let's mock the midnight bell.
line 8844-->  CLEOPATRA. It is my birthday.
line 8845-->    I had thought t'have held it poor; but since my lord
line 8846-->    Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.
line 8847-->  ANTONY. We will yet do well.
line 8848-->  CLEOPATRA. Call all his noble captains to my lord.
line 8849-->  ANTONY. Do so, we'll speak to them; and to-night I'll force
line 8850-->    The wine peep through their scars. Come on, my queen,
line 8851-->    There's sap in't yet. The next time I do fight
line 8852-->    I'll make death love me; for I will contend
line 8853-->    Even with his pestilent scythe.     Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS
line 8854-->  ENOBARBUS. Now he'll outstare the lightning. To be furious
line 8855-->    Is to be frighted out of fear, and in that mood
line 8856-->    The dove will peck the estridge; and I see still
line 8857-->    A diminution in our captain's brain
line 8858-->    Restores his heart. When valour preys on reason,
line 8859-->    It eats the sword it fights with. I will seek
line 8860-->    Some way to leave him.                                  Exit
line 8861-->
line 8862-->ACT_4|SC_1
line 8863-->                      ACT IV. SCENE I.
line 8864-->              CAESAR'S camp before Alexandria
line 8865-->
line 8866-->      Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, and MAECENAS, with his army;
line 8867-->                 CAESAR reading a letter
line 8868-->
line 8869-->  CAESAR. He calls me boy, and chides as he had power
line 8870-->    To beat me out of Egypt. My messenger
line 8871-->    He hath whipt with rods; dares me to personal combat,
line 8872-->    Caesar to Antony. Let the old ruffian know
line 8873-->    I have many other ways to die, meantime
line 8874-->    Laugh at his challenge.
line 8875-->  MAECENAS. Caesar must think
line 8876-->    When one so great begins to rage, he's hunted
line 8877-->    Even to falling. Give him no breath, but now
line 8878-->    Make boot of his distraction. Never anger
line 8879-->    Made good guard for itself.
line 8880-->  CAESAR. Let our best heads
line 8881-->    Know that to-morrow the last of many battles
line 8882-->    We mean to fight. Within our files there are
line 8883-->    Of those that serv'd Mark Antony but late
line 8884-->    Enough to fetch him in. See it done;  
line 8885-->    And feast the army; we have store to do't,
line 8886-->    And they have earn'd the waste. Poor Antony!          Exeunt
line 8887-->
line 8888-->ACT_4|SC_2
line 8889-->                          SCENE II.
line 8890-->               Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace
line 8891-->
line 8892-->      Enter ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, IRAS,
line 8893-->                     ALEXAS, with others
line 8894-->
line 8895-->  ANTONY. He will not fight with me, Domitius?
line 8896-->  ENOBARBUS. No.
line 8897-->  ANTONY. Why should he not?
line 8898-->  ENOBARBUS. He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune,
line 8899-->    He is twenty men to one.
line 8900-->  ANTONY. To-morrow, soldier,
line 8901-->    By sea and land I'll fight. Or I will live,
line 8902-->    Or bathe my dying honour in the blood
line 8903-->    Shall make it live again. Woo't thou fight well?
line 8904-->  ENOBARBUS. I'll strike, and cry 'Take all.'
line 8905-->  ANTONY. Well said; come on.
line 8906-->    Call forth my household servants; let's to-night
line 8907-->    Be bounteous at our meal.
line 8908-->
line 8909-->                Enter three or four servitors
line 8910-->  
line 8911-->    Give me thy hand,
line 8912-->    Thou has been rightly honest. So hast thou;
line 8913-->    Thou, and thou, and thou. You have serv'd me well,
line 8914-->    And kings have been your fellows.
line 8915-->  CLEOPATRA. [Aside to ENOBARBUS] What means this?
line 8916-->  ENOBARBUS. [Aside to CLEOPATRA] 'Tis one of those odd tricks which
line 8917-->      sorrow shoots
line 8918-->    Out of the mind.
line 8919-->  ANTONY. And thou art honest too.
line 8920-->    I wish I could be made so many men,
line 8921-->    And all of you clapp'd up together in
line 8922-->    An Antony, that I might do you service
line 8923-->    So good as you have done.
line 8924-->  SERVANT. The gods forbid!
line 8925-->  ANTONY. Well, my good fellows, wait on me to-night.
line 8926-->    Scant not my cups, and make as much of me
line 8927-->    As when mine empire was your fellow too,
line 8928-->    And suffer'd my command.
line 8929-->  CLEOPATRA. [Aside to ENOBARBUS] What does he mean?
line 8930-->    ENOBARBUS. [Aside to CLEOPATRA] To make his followers weep.  
line 8931-->  ANTONY. Tend me to-night;
line 8932-->    May be it is the period of your duty.
line 8933-->    Haply you shall not see me more; or if,
line 8934-->    A mangled shadow. Perchance to-morrow
line 8935-->    You'll serve another master. I look on you
line 8936-->    As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends,
line 8937-->    I turn you not away; but, like a master
line 8938-->    Married to your good service, stay till death.
line 8939-->    Tend me to-night two hours, I ask no more,
line 8940-->    And the gods yield you for't!
line 8941-->  ENOBARBUS. What mean you, sir,
line 8942-->    To give them this discomfort? Look, they weep;
line 8943-->    And I, an ass, am onion-ey'd. For shame!
line 8944-->    Transform us not to women.
line 8945-->  ANTONY. Ho, ho, ho!
line 8946-->    Now the witch take me if I meant it thus!
line 8947-->    Grace grow where those drops fall! My hearty friends,
line 8948-->    You take me in too dolorous a sense;
line 8949-->    For I spake to you for your comfort, did desire you
line 8950-->    To burn this night with torches. Know, my hearts,  
line 8951-->    I hope well of to-morrow, and will lead you
line 8952-->    Where rather I'll expect victorious life
line 8953-->    Than death and honour. Let's to supper, come,
line 8954-->    And drown consideration.                              Exeunt
line 8955-->
line 8956-->ACT_4|SC_3
line 8957-->                          SCENE III.
line 8958-->             Alexandria. Before CLEOPATRA's palace
line 8959-->
line 8960-->                 Enter a company of soldiers
line 8961-->
line 8962-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Brother, good night. To-morrow is the day.
line 8963-->  SECOND SOLDIER. It will determine one way. Fare you well.
line 8964-->    Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?
line 8965-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Nothing. What news?
line 8966-->  SECOND SOLDIER. Belike 'tis but a rumour. Good night to you.
line 8967-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Well, sir, good night.
line 8968-->                                      [They meet other soldiers]
line 8969-->  SECOND SOLDIER. Soldiers, have careful watch.
line 8970-->  FIRST SOLDIER. And you. Good night, good night.
line 8971-->                [The two companies separate and place themselves
line 8972-->                                   in every corner of the stage]
line 8973-->  SECOND SOLDIER. Here we. And if to-morrow
line 8974-->    Our navy thrive, I have an absolute hope
line 8975-->    Our landmen will stand up.
line 8976-->  THIRD SOLDIER. 'Tis a brave army,
line 8977-->    And full of purpose.
line 8978-->                      [Music of the hautboys is under the stage]  
line 8979-->  SECOND SOLDIER. Peace, what noise?
line 8980-->  THIRD SOLDIER. List, list!
line 8981-->  SECOND SOLDIER. Hark!
line 8982-->  THIRD SOLDIER. Music i' th' air.
line 8983-->  FOURTH SOLDIER. Under the earth.
line 8984-->  THIRD SOLDIER. It signs well, does it not?
line 8985-->  FOURTH SOLDIER. No.
line 8986-->  THIRD SOLDIER. Peace, I say!
line 8987-->    What should this mean?
line 8988-->  SECOND SOLDIER. 'Tis the god Hercules, whom Antony lov'd,
line 8989-->    Now leaves him.
line 8990-->  THIRD SOLDIER. Walk; let's see if other watchmen
line 8991-->    Do hear what we do.
line 8992-->  SECOND SOLDIER. How now, masters!
line 8993-->  SOLDIERS. [Speaking together] How now!
line 8994-->    How now! Do you hear this?
line 8995-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Ay; is't not strange?
line 8996-->  THIRD SOLDIER. Do you hear, masters? Do you hear?
line 8997-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Follow the noise so far as we have quarter;
line 8998-->    Let's see how it will give off.  
line 8999-->  SOLDIERS. Content. 'Tis strange.                        Exeunt
line 9000-->
line 9001-->ACT_4|SC_4
line 9002-->                           SCENE IV.
line 9003-->               Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace
line 9004-->
line 9005-->         Enter ANTONY and CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS,
line 9006-->                          with others
line 9007-->
line 9008-->  ANTONY. Eros! mine armour, Eros!
line 9009-->  CLEOPATRA. Sleep a little.
line 9010-->  ANTONY. No, my chuck. Eros! Come, mine armour, Eros!
line 9011-->
line 9012-->                   Enter EROS with armour
line 9013-->
line 9014-->    Come, good fellow, put mine iron on.
line 9015-->    If fortune be not ours to-day, it is
line 9016-->    Because we brave her. Come.
line 9017-->  CLEOPATRA. Nay, I'll help too.
line 9018-->    What's this for?
line 9019-->  ANTONY. Ah, let be, let be! Thou art
line 9020-->    The armourer of my heart. False, false; this, this.
line 9021-->  CLEOPATRA. Sooth, la, I'll help. Thus it must be.
line 9022-->  ANTONY. Well, well;
line 9023-->    We shall thrive now. Seest thou, my good fellow?  
line 9024-->    Go put on thy defences.
line 9025-->  EROS. Briefly, sir.
line 9026-->  CLEOPATRA. Is not this buckled well?
line 9027-->  ANTONY. Rarely, rarely!
line 9028-->    He that unbuckles this, till we do please
line 9029-->    To daff't for our repose, shall hear a storm.
line 9030-->    Thou fumblest, Eros, and my queen's a squire
line 9031-->    More tight at this than thou. Dispatch. O love,
line 9032-->    That thou couldst see my wars to-day, and knew'st
line 9033-->    The royal occupation! Thou shouldst see
line 9034-->    A workman in't.
line 9035-->
line 9036-->                   Enter an armed SOLDIER
line 9037-->
line 9038-->    Good-morrow to thee. Welcome.
line 9039-->    Thou look'st like him that knows a warlike charge.
line 9040-->    To business that we love we rise betime,
line 9041-->    And go to't with delight.
line 9042-->  SOLDIER. A thousand, sir,
line 9043-->    Early though't be, have on their riveted trim,  
line 9044-->    And at the port expect you.
line 9045-->                            [Shout. Flourish of trumpets within]
line 9046-->
line 9047-->                 Enter CAPTAINS and soldiers
line 9048-->
line 9049-->  CAPTAIN. The morn is fair. Good morrow, General.
line 9050-->  ALL. Good morrow, General.
line 9051-->  ANTONY. 'Tis well blown, lads.
line 9052-->    This morning, like the spirit of a youth
line 9053-->    That means to be of note, begins betimes.
line 9054-->    So, so. Come, give me that. This way. Well said.
line 9055-->    Fare thee well, dame, whate'er becomes of me.
line 9056-->    This is a soldier's kiss. Rebukeable,
line 9057-->    And worthy shameful check it were, to stand
line 9058-->    On more mechanic compliment; I'll leave thee
line 9059-->    Now like a man of steel. You that will fight,
line 9060-->    Follow me close; I'll bring you to't. Adieu.
line 9061-->                      Exeunt ANTONY, EROS, CAPTAINS and soldiers
line 9062-->  CHARMIAN. Please you retire to your chamber?
line 9063-->  CLEOPATRA. Lead me.
line 9064-->    He goes forth gallantly. That he and Caesar might
line 9065-->    Determine this great war in single fight!
line 9066-->    Then, Antony- but now. Well, on.                      Exeunt
line 9067-->
line 9068-->ACT_4|SC_5
line 9069-->                          SCENE V.
line 9070-->                  Alexandria. ANTONY'S camp
line 9071-->
line 9072-->        Trumpets sound. Enter ANTONY and EROS, a SOLDIER
line 9073-->                       meeting them
line 9074-->
line 9075-->  SOLDIER. The gods make this a happy day to Antony!
line 9076-->  ANTONY. Would thou and those thy scars had once prevail'd
line 9077-->    To make me fight at land!
line 9078-->  SOLDIER. Hadst thou done so,
line 9079-->    The kings that have revolted, and the soldier
line 9080-->    That has this morning left thee, would have still
line 9081-->    Followed thy heels.
line 9082-->  ANTONY. Who's gone this morning?
line 9083-->  SOLDIER. Who?
line 9084-->    One ever near thee. Call for Enobarbus,
line 9085-->    He shall not hear thee; or from Caesar's camp
line 9086-->    Say 'I am none of thine.'
line 9087-->  ANTONY. What say'st thou?
line 9088-->  SOLDIER. Sir,
line 9089-->    He is with Caesar.
line 9090-->  EROS. Sir, his chests and treasure  
line 9091-->    He has not with him.
line 9092-->  ANTONY. Is he gone?
line 9093-->  SOLDIER. Most certain.
line 9094-->  ANTONY. Go, Eros, send his treasure after; do it;
line 9095-->    Detain no jot, I charge thee. Write to him-
line 9096-->    I will subscribe- gentle adieus and greetings;
line 9097-->    Say that I wish he never find more cause
line 9098-->    To change a master. O, my fortunes have
line 9099-->    Corrupted honest men! Dispatch. Enobarbus!            Exeunt
line 9100-->
line 9101-->ACT_4|SC_6
line 9102-->                         SCENE VI.
line 9103-->                 Alexandria. CAESAR'S camp
line 9104-->
line 9105-->       Flourish. Enter AGRIPPA, CAESAR, With DOLABELLA
line 9106-->                       and ENOBARBUS
line 9107-->
line 9108-->  CAESAR. Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight.
line 9109-->    Our will is Antony be took alive;
line 9110-->    Make it so known.
line 9111-->  AGRIPPA. Caesar, I shall.                                 Exit
line 9112-->  CAESAR. The time of universal peace is near.
line 9113-->    Prove this a prosp'rous day, the three-nook'd world
line 9114-->    Shall bear the olive freely.
line 9115-->
line 9116-->                     Enter A MESSENGER
line 9117-->
line 9118-->  MESSENGER. Antony
line 9119-->    Is come into the field.
line 9120-->  CAESAR. Go charge Agrippa
line 9121-->    Plant those that have revolted in the vant,
line 9122-->    That Antony may seem to spend his fury
line 9123-->    Upon himself.                       Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS  
line 9124-->  ENOBARBUS. Alexas did revolt and went to Jewry on
line 9125-->    Affairs of Antony; there did dissuade
line 9126-->    Great Herod to incline himself to Caesar
line 9127-->    And leave his master Antony. For this pains
line 9128-->    Casaer hath hang'd him. Canidius and the rest
line 9129-->    That fell away have entertainment, but
line 9130-->    No honourable trust. I have done ill,
line 9131-->    Of which I do accuse myself so sorely
line 9132-->    That I will joy no more.
line 9133-->
line 9134-->                  Enter a SOLDIER of CAESAR'S
line 9135-->
line 9136-->  SOLDIER. Enobarbus, Antony
line 9137-->    Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with
line 9138-->    His bounty overplus. The messenger
line 9139-->    Came on my guard, and at thy tent is now
line 9140-->    Unloading of his mules.
line 9141-->  ENOBARBUS. I give it you.
line 9142-->  SOLDIER. Mock not, Enobarbus.
line 9143-->    I tell you true. Best you saf'd the bringer  
line 9144-->    Out of the host. I must attend mine office,
line 9145-->    Or would have done't myself. Your emperor
line 9146-->    Continues still a Jove.                                 Exit
line 9147-->  ENOBARBUS. I am alone the villain of the earth,
line 9148-->    And feel I am so most. O Antony,
line 9149-->    Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid
line 9150-->    My better service, when my turpitude
line 9151-->    Thou dost so crown with gold! This blows my heart.
line 9152-->    If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean
line 9153-->    Shall outstrike thought; but thought will do't, I feel.
line 9154-->    I fight against thee? No! I will go seek
line 9155-->    Some ditch wherein to die; the foul'st best fits
line 9156-->    My latter part of life.                                 Exit
line 9157-->
line 9158-->ACT_4|SC_7
line 9159-->                          SCENE VII.
line 9160-->             Field of battle between the camps
line 9161-->
line 9162-->         Alarum. Drums and trumpets. Enter AGRIPPA
line 9163-->                        and others
line 9164-->
line 9165-->  AGRIPPA. Retire. We have engag'd ourselves too far.
line 9166-->    Caesar himself has work, and our oppression
line 9167-->    Exceeds what we expected.                             Exeunt
line 9168-->
line 9169-->          Alarums. Enter ANTONY, and SCARUS wounded
line 9170-->
line 9171-->  SCARUS. O my brave Emperor, this is fought indeed!
line 9172-->    Had we done so at first, we had droven them home
line 9173-->    With clouts about their heads.
line 9174-->  ANTONY. Thou bleed'st apace.
line 9175-->  SCARUS. I had a wound here that was like a T,
line 9176-->    But now 'tis made an H.
line 9177-->  ANTONY. They do retire.
line 9178-->  SCARUS. We'll beat'em into bench-holes. I have yet
line 9179-->    Room for six scotches more.
line 9180-->  
line 9181-->                        Enter EROS
line 9182-->
line 9183-->  EROS. They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves
line 9184-->    For a fair victory.
line 9185-->  SCARUS. Let us score their backs
line 9186-->    And snatch 'em up, as we take hares, behind.
line 9187-->    'Tis sport to maul a runner.
line 9188-->  ANTONY. I will reward thee
line 9189-->    Once for thy sprightly comfort, and tenfold
line 9190-->    For thy good valour. Come thee on.
line 9191-->    SCARUS. I'll halt after.                              Exeunt
line 9192-->
line 9193-->ACT_4|SC_8
line 9194-->                         SCENE VIII.
line 9195-->               Under the walls of Alexandria
line 9196-->
line 9197-->        Alarum. Enter ANTONY, again in a march; SCARUS
line 9198-->                        with others
line 9199-->
line 9200-->  ANTONY. We have beat him to his camp. Run one before
line 9201-->    And let the Queen know of our gests. To-morrow,
line 9202-->    Before the sun shall see's, we'll spill the blood
line 9203-->    That has to-day escap'd. I thank you all;
line 9204-->    For doughty-handed are you, and have fought
line 9205-->    Not as you serv'd the cause, but as't had been
line 9206-->    Each man's like mine; you have shown all Hectors.
line 9207-->    Enter the city, clip your wives, your friends,
line 9208-->    Tell them your feats; whilst they with joyful tears
line 9209-->    Wash the congealment from your wounds and kiss
line 9210-->    The honour'd gashes whole.
line 9211-->
line 9212-->                 Enter CLEOPATRA, attended
line 9213-->
line 9214-->    [To SCARUS] Give me thy hand-
line 9215-->    To this great fairy I'll commend thy acts,  
line 9216-->    Make her thanks bless thee. O thou day o' th' world,
line 9217-->    Chain mine arm'd neck. Leap thou, attire and all,
line 9218-->    Through proof of harness to my heart, and there
line 9219-->    Ride on the pants triumphing.
line 9220-->  CLEOPATRA. Lord of lords!
line 9221-->    O infinite virtue, com'st thou smiling from
line 9222-->    The world's great snare uncaught?
line 9223-->  ANTONY. Mine nightingale,
line 9224-->    We have beat them to their beds. What, girl! though grey
line 9225-->    Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha' we
line 9226-->    A brain that nourishes our nerves, and can
line 9227-->    Get goal for goal of youth. Behold this man;
line 9228-->    Commend unto his lips thy favouring hand-
line 9229-->    Kiss it, my warrior- he hath fought to-day
line 9230-->    As if a god in hate of mankind had
line 9231-->    Destroyed in such a shape.
line 9232-->  CLEOPATRA. I'll give thee, friend,
line 9233-->    An armour all of gold; it was a king's.
line 9234-->  ANTONY. He has deserv'd it, were it carbuncled
line 9235-->    Like holy Phoebus' car. Give me thy hand.  
line 9236-->    Through Alexandria make a jolly march;
line 9237-->    Bear our hack'd targets like the men that owe them.
line 9238-->    Had our great palace the capacity
line 9239-->    To camp this host, we all would sup together,
line 9240-->    And drink carouses to the next day's fate,
line 9241-->    Which promises royal peril. Trumpeters,
line 9242-->    With brazen din blast you the city's ear;
line 9243-->    Make mingle with our rattling tabourines,
line 9244-->    That heaven and earth may strike their sounds together
line 9245-->    Applauding our approach.                              Exeunt
line 9246-->
line 9247-->ACT_4|SC_9
line 9248-->                         SCENE IX.
line 9249-->                      CAESAR'S camp
line 9250-->
line 9251-->      Enter a CENTURION and his company; ENOBARBUS follows
line 9252-->
line 9253-->  CENTURION. If we be not reliev'd within this hour,
line 9254-->    We must return to th' court of guard. The night
line 9255-->    Is shiny, and they say we shall embattle
line 9256-->    By th' second hour i' th' morn.
line 9257-->  FIRST WATCH. This last day was
line 9258-->    A shrewd one to's.
line 9259-->  ENOBARBUS. O, bear me witness, night-
line 9260-->  SECOND WATCH. What man is this?
line 9261-->  FIRST WATCH. Stand close and list him.
line 9262-->  ENOBARBUS. Be witness to me, O thou blessed moon,
line 9263-->    When men revolted shall upon record
line 9264-->    Bear hateful memory, poor Enobarbus did
