line 9265-->    Before thy face repent!
line 9266-->  CENTURION. Enobarbus?
line 9267-->  SECOND WATCH. Peace!
line 9268-->    Hark further.
line 9269-->  ENOBARBUS. O sovereign mistress of true melancholy,  
line 9270-->    The poisonous damp of night disponge upon me,
line 9271-->    That life, a very rebel to my will,
line 9272-->    May hang no longer on me. Throw my heart
line 9273-->    Against the flint and hardness of my fault,
line 9274-->    Which, being dried with grief, will break to powder,
line 9275-->    And finish all foul thoughts. O Antony,
line 9276-->    Nobler than my revolt is infamous,
line 9277-->    Forgive me in thine own particular,
line 9278-->    But let the world rank me in register
line 9279-->    A master-leaver and a fugitive!
line 9280-->    O Antony! O Antony!                                   [Dies]
line 9281-->  FIRST WATCH. Let's speak to him.
line 9282-->  CENTURION. Let's hear him, for the things he speaks
line 9283-->    May concern Caesar.
line 9284-->  SECOND WATCH. Let's do so. But he sleeps.
line 9285-->  CENTURION. Swoons rather; for so bad a prayer as his
line 9286-->    Was never yet for sleep.
line 9287-->  FIRST WATCH. Go we to him.
line 9288-->  SECOND WATCH. Awake, sir, awake; speak to us.
line 9289-->  FIRST WATCH. Hear you, sir?  
line 9290-->  CENTURION. The hand of death hath raught him.
line 9291-->    [Drums afar off ] Hark! the drums
line 9292-->    Demurely wake the sleepers. Let us bear him
line 9293-->    To th' court of guard; he is of note. Our hour
line 9294-->    Is fully out.
line 9295-->  SECOND WATCH. Come on, then;
line 9296-->    He may recover yet.                     Exeunt with the body
line 9297-->
line 9298-->ACT_4|SC_10
line 9299-->                          SCENE X.
line 9300-->                    Between the two camps
line 9301-->
line 9302-->            Enter ANTONY and SCARUS, with their army
line 9303-->
line 9304-->  ANTONY. Their preparation is to-day by sea;
line 9305-->    We please them not by land.
line 9306-->  SCARUS. For both, my lord.
line 9307-->  ANTONY. I would they'd fight i' th' fire or i' th' air;
line 9308-->    We'd fight there too. But this it is, our foot
line 9309-->    Upon the hills adjoining to the city
line 9310-->    Shall stay with us- Order for sea is given;
line 9311-->    They have put forth the haven-
line 9312-->    Where their appointment we may best discover
line 9313-->    And look on their endeavour.                          Exeunt
line 9314-->
line 9315-->ACT_4|SC_11
line 9316-->                         SCENE XI.
line 9317-->                    Between the camps
line 9318-->
line 9319-->                Enter CAESAR and his army
line 9320-->
line 9321-->  CAESAR. But being charg'd, we will be still by land,
line 9322-->    Which, as I take't, we shall; for his best force
line 9323-->    Is forth to man his galleys. To the vales,
line 9324-->    And hold our best advantage.                          Exeunt
line 9325-->
line 9326-->ACT_4|SC_12
line 9327-->                         SCENE XII.
line 9328-->                  A hill near Alexandria
line 9329-->
line 9330-->                  Enter ANTONY and SCARUS
line 9331-->
line 9332-->  ANTONY. Yet they are not join'd. Where yond pine does stand
line 9333-->    I shall discover all. I'll bring thee word
line 9334-->    Straight how 'tis like to go.                           Exit
line 9335-->  SCARUS. Swallows have built
line 9336-->    In Cleopatra's sails their nests. The augurers
line 9337-->    Say they know not, they cannot tell; look grimly,
line 9338-->    And dare not speak their knowledge. Antony
line 9339-->    Is valiant and dejected; and by starts
line 9340-->    His fretted fortunes give him hope and fear
line 9341-->    Of what he has and has not.
line 9342-->                            [Alarum afar off, as at a sea-fight]
line 9343-->
line 9344-->                      Re-enter ANTONY
line 9345-->
line 9346-->  ANTONY. All is lost!
line 9347-->    This foul Egyptian hath betrayed me.
line 9348-->    My fleet hath yielded to the foe, and yonder  
line 9349-->    They cast their caps up and carouse together
line 9350-->    Like friends long lost. Triple-turn'd whore! 'tis thou
line 9351-->    Hast sold me to this novice; and my heart
line 9352-->    Makes only wars on thee. Bid them all fly;
line 9353-->    For when I am reveng'd upon my charm,
line 9354-->    I have done all. Bid them all fly; begone.       Exit SCARUS
line 9355-->    O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more!
line 9356-->    Fortune and Antony part here; even here
line 9357-->    Do we shake hands. All come to this? The hearts
line 9358-->    That spaniel'd me at heels, to whom I gave
line 9359-->    Their wishes, do discandy, melt their sweets
line 9360-->    On blossoming Caesar; and this pine is bark'd
line 9361-->    That overtopp'd them all. Betray'd I am.
line 9362-->    O this false soul of Egypt! this grave charm-
line 9363-->    Whose eye beck'd forth my wars and call'd them home,
line 9364-->    Whose bosom was my crownet, my chief end-
line 9365-->    Like a right gypsy hath at fast and loose
line 9366-->    Beguil'd me to the very heart of loss.
line 9367-->    What, Eros, Eros!
line 9368-->  
line 9369-->                      Enter CLEOPATRA
line 9370-->
line 9371-->    Ah, thou spell! Avaunt!
line 9372-->  CLEOPATRA. Why is my lord enrag'd against his love?
line 9373-->  ANTONY. Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving
line 9374-->    And blemish Caesar's triumph. Let him take thee
line 9375-->    And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians;
line 9376-->    Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot
line 9377-->    Of all thy sex; most monster-like, be shown
line 9378-->    For poor'st diminutives, for doits, and let
line 9379-->    Patient Octavia plough thy visage up
line 9380-->    With her prepared nails.                      Exit CLEOPATRA
line 9381-->    'Tis well th'art gone,
line 9382-->    If it be well to live; but better 'twere
line 9383-->    Thou fell'st into my fury, for one death
line 9384-->    Might have prevented many. Eros, ho!
line 9385-->    The shirt of Nessus is upon me; teach me,
line 9386-->    Alcides, thou mine ancestor, thy rage;
line 9387-->    Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o' th' moon,
line 9388-->    And with those hands that grasp'd the heaviest club
line 9389-->    Subdue my worthiest self. The witch shall die.
line 9390-->    To the young Roman boy she hath sold me, and I fall
line 9391-->    Under this plot. She dies for't. Eros, ho!              Exit
line 9392-->
line 9393-->ACT_4|SC_13
line 9394-->                          SCENE XIII.
line 9395-->               Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace
line 9396-->
line 9397-->      Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN
line 9398-->
line 9399-->  CLEOPATRA. Help me, my women. O, he is more mad
line 9400-->    Than Telamon for his shield; the boar of Thessaly
line 9401-->    Was never so emboss'd.
line 9402-->  CHARMIAN. To th'monument!
line 9403-->    There lock yourself, and send him word you are dead.
line 9404-->    The soul and body rive not more in parting
line 9405-->    Than greatness going off.
line 9406-->  CLEOPATRA. To th' monument!
line 9407-->    Mardian, go tell him I have slain myself;
line 9408-->    Say that the last I spoke was 'Antony'
line 9409-->    And word it, prithee, piteously. Hence, Mardian,
line 9410-->    And bring me how he takes my death. To th' monument!
line 9411-->                                                          Exeunt
line 9412-->
line 9413-->ACT_4|SC_14
line 9414-->                          SCENE XIV.
line 9415-->                     CLEOPATRA'S palace
line 9416-->
line 9417-->                   Enter ANTONY and EROS
line 9418-->
line 9419-->  ANTONY. Eros, thou yet behold'st me?
line 9420-->  EROS. Ay, noble lord.
line 9421-->  ANTONY. Sometime we see a cloud that's dragonish;
line 9422-->    A vapour sometime like a bear or lion,
line 9423-->    A tower'd citadel, a pendent rock,
line 9424-->    A forked mountain, or blue promontory
line 9425-->    With trees upon't that nod unto the world
line 9426-->    And mock our eyes with air. Thou hast seen these signs;
line 9427-->    They are black vesper's pageants.
line 9428-->  EROS. Ay, my lord.
line 9429-->  ANTONY. That which is now a horse, even with a thought
line 9430-->    The rack dislimns, and makes it indistinct,
line 9431-->    As water is in water.
line 9432-->  EROS. It does, my lord.
line 9433-->  ANTONY. My good knave Eros, now thy captain is
line 9434-->    Even such a body. Here I am Antony;
line 9435-->    Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.  
line 9436-->    I made these wars for Egypt; and the Queen-
line 9437-->    Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine,
line 9438-->    Which, whilst it was mine, had annex'd unto't
line 9439-->    A million moe, now lost- she, Eros, has
line 9440-->    Pack'd cards with Caesar, and false-play'd my glory
line 9441-->    Unto an enemy's triumph.
line 9442-->    Nay, weep not, gentle Eros; there is left us
line 9443-->    Ourselves to end ourselves.
line 9444-->
line 9445-->                         Enter MARDIAN
line 9446-->
line 9447-->    O, thy vile lady!
line 9448-->    She has robb'd me of my sword.
line 9449-->  MARDIAN. No, Antony;
line 9450-->    My mistress lov'd thee, and her fortunes mingled
line 9451-->    With thine entirely.
line 9452-->  ANTONY. Hence, saucy eunuch; peace!
line 9453-->    She hath betray'd me, and shall die the death.
line 9454-->  MARDIAN. Death of one person can be paid but once,
line 9455-->    And that she has discharg'd. What thou wouldst do  
line 9456-->    Is done unto thy hand. The last she spake
line 9457-->    Was 'Antony! most noble Antony!'
line 9458-->    Then in the midst a tearing groan did break
line 9459-->    The name of Antony; it was divided
line 9460-->    Between her heart and lips. She rend'red life,
line 9461-->    Thy name so buried in her.
line 9462-->  ANTONY. Dead then?
line 9463-->  MARDIAN. Dead.
line 9464-->  ANTONY. Unarm, Eros; the long day's task is done,
line 9465-->    And we must sleep. That thou depart'st hence safe
line 9466-->    Does pay thy labour richly. Go.                 Exit MARDIAN
line 9467-->    Off, pluck off!
line 9468-->    The sevenfold shield of Ajax cannot keep
line 9469-->    The battery from my heart. O, cleave, my sides!
line 9470-->    Heart, once be stronger than thy continent,
line 9471-->    Crack thy frail case. Apace, Eros, apace.-
line 9472-->    No more a soldier. Bruised pieces, go;
line 9473-->    You have been nobly borne.- From me awhile.        Exit EROS
line 9474-->    I will o'ertake thee, Cleopatra, and
line 9475-->    Weep for my pardon. So it must be, for now  
line 9476-->    All length is torture. Since the torch is out,
line 9477-->    Lie down, and stray no farther. Now all labour
line 9478-->    Mars what it does; yea, very force entangles
line 9479-->    Itself with strength. Seal then, and all is done.
line 9480-->    Eros!- I come, my queen.- Eros!- Stay for me;
line 9481-->    Where souls do couch on flowers, we'll hand in hand,
line 9482-->    And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze.
line 9483-->    Dido and her Aeneas shall want troops,
line 9484-->    And all the haunt be ours.- Come, Eros, Eros!
line 9485-->
line 9486-->                       Re-enter EROS
line 9487-->
line 9488-->  EROS. What would my lord?
line 9489-->  ANTONY. Since Cleopatra died,
line 9490-->    I have liv'd in such dishonour that the gods
line 9491-->    Detest my baseness. I, that with my sword
line 9492-->    Quarter'd the world, and o'er green Neptune's back
line 9493-->    With ships made cities, condemn myself to lack
line 9494-->    The courage of a woman; less noble mind
line 9495-->    Than she which by her death our Caesar tells  
line 9496-->    'I am conqueror of myself.' Thou art sworn, Eros,
line 9497-->    That, when the exigent should come- which now
line 9498-->    Is come indeed- when I should see behind me
line 9499-->    Th' inevitable prosecution of
line 9500-->    Disgrace and horror, that, on my command,
line 9501-->    Thou then wouldst kill me. Do't; the time is come.
line 9502-->    Thou strik'st not me; 'tis Caesar thou defeat'st.
line 9503-->    Put colour in thy cheek.
line 9504-->  EROS. The gods withhold me!
line 9505-->    Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts,
line 9506-->    Though enemy, lost aim and could not?
line 9507-->  ANTONY. Eros,
line 9508-->    Wouldst thou be window'd in great Rome and see
line 9509-->    Thy master thus with pleach'd arms, bending down
line 9510-->    His corrigible neck, his face subdu'd
line 9511-->    To penetrative shame, whilst the wheel'd seat
line 9512-->    Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded
line 9513-->    His baseness that ensued?
line 9514-->  EROS. I would not see't.
line 9515-->  ANTONY. Come, then; for with a wound I must be cur'd.  
line 9516-->    Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn
line 9517-->    Most useful for thy country.
line 9518-->  EROS. O, sir, pardon me!
line 9519-->  ANTONY. When I did make thee free, swor'st thou not then
line 9520-->    To do this when I bade thee? Do it at once,
line 9521-->    Or thy precedent services are all
line 9522-->    But accidents unpurpos'd. Draw, and come.
line 9523-->  EROS. Turn from me then that noble countenance,
line 9524-->    Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.
line 9525-->  ANTONY. Lo thee!                            [Turning from him]
line 9526-->  EROS. My sword is drawn.
line 9527-->  ANTONY. Then let it do at once
line 9528-->    The thing why thou hast drawn it.
line 9529-->  EROS. My dear master,
line 9530-->    My captain and my emperor, let me say,
line 9531-->    Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.
line 9532-->  ANTONY. 'Tis said, man; and farewell.
line 9533-->  EROS. Farewell, great chief. Shall I strike now?
line 9534-->  ANTONY. Now, Eros.
line 9535-->  EROS. Why, there then! Thus do I escape the sorrow  
line 9536-->    Of Antony's death.                            [Kills himself
line 9537-->  ANTONY. Thrice nobler than myself!
line 9538-->    Thou teachest me, O valiant Eros, what
line 9539-->    I should, and thou couldst not. My queen and Eros
line 9540-->    Have, by their brave instruction, got upon me
line 9541-->    A nobleness in record. But I will be
line 9542-->    A bridegroom in my death, and run into't
line 9543-->    As to a lover's bed. Come, then; and, Eros,
line 9544-->    Thy master dies thy scholar. To do thus
line 9545-->                                          [Falling on his sword]
line 9546-->    I learn'd of thee. How? not dead? not dead?-
line 9547-->    The guard, ho! O, dispatch me!
line 9548-->
line 9549-->                  Enter DERCETAS and a guard
line 9550-->
line 9551-->  FIRST GUARD. What's the noise?
line 9552-->  ANTONY. I have done my work ill, friends. O, make an end
line 9553-->    Of what I have begun.
line 9554-->  SECOND GUARD. The star is fall'n.
line 9555-->  FIRST GUARD. And time is at his period.  
line 9556-->  ALL. Alas, and woe!
line 9557-->  ANTONY. Let him that loves me, strike me dead.
line 9558-->  FIRST GUARD. Not I.
line 9559-->  SECOND GUARD. Nor I.
line 9560-->  THIRD GUARD. Nor any one.                         Exeunt guard
line 9561-->  DERCETAS. Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
line 9562-->    This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings,
line 9563-->    Shall enter me with him.
line 9564-->
line 9565-->                       Enter DIOMEDES
line 9566-->
line 9567-->  DIOMEDES. Where's Antony?
line 9568-->  DERCETAS. There, Diomed, there.
line 9569-->  DIOMEDES. Lives he?
line 9570-->    Wilt thou not answer, man?                     Exit DERCETAS
line 9571-->  ANTONY. Art thou there, Diomed? Draw thy sword and give me
line 9572-->    Sufficing strokes for death.
line 9573-->  DIOMEDES. Most absolute lord,
line 9574-->    My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.
line 9575-->  ANTONY. When did she send thee?  
line 9576-->  DIOMEDES. Now, my lord.
line 9577-->  ANTONY. Where is she?
line 9578-->  DIOMEDES. Lock'd in her monument. She had a prophesying fear
line 9579-->    Of what hath come to pass; for when she saw-
line 9580-->    Which never shall be found- you did suspect
line 9581-->    She had dispos'd with Caesar, and that your rage
line 9582-->    Would not be purg'd, she sent you word she was dead;
line 9583-->    But fearing since how it might work, hath sent
line 9584-->    Me to proclaim the truth; and I am come,
line 9585-->    I dread, too late.
line 9586-->  ANTONY. Too late, good Diomed. Call my guard, I prithee.
line 9587-->  DIOMEDES. What, ho! the Emperor's guard! The guard, what ho!
line 9588-->    Come, your lord calls!
line 9589-->
line 9590-->             Enter four or five of the guard of ANTONY
line 9591-->
line 9592-->  ANTONY. Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides;
line 9593-->    'Tis the last service that I shall command you.
line 9594-->  FIRST GUARD. Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear
line 9595-->    All your true followers out.  
line 9596-->  ALL. Most heavy day!
line 9597-->  ANTONY. Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate
line 9598-->    To grace it with your sorrows. Bid that welcome
line 9599-->    Which comes to punish us, and we punish it,
line 9600-->    Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up.
line 9601-->    I have led you oft; carry me now, good friends,
line 9602-->    And have my thanks for all.           Exeunt, hearing ANTONY
line 9603-->ACT_4|SC_15
line 9604-->                         SCENE XV.
line 9605-->                   Alexandria. A monument
line 9606-->
line 9607-->      Enter CLEOPATRA and her maids aloft, with CHARMIAN
line 9608-->                         and IRAS
line 9609-->
line 9610-->  CLEOPATRA. O Charmian, I will never go from hence!
line 9611-->  CHARMIAN. Be comforted, dear madam.
line 9612-->  CLEOPATRA. No, I will not.
line 9613-->    All strange and terrible events are welcome,
line 9614-->    But comforts we despise; our size of sorrow,
line 9615-->    Proportion'd to our cause, must be as great
line 9616-->    As that which makes it.
line 9617-->
line 9618-->                   Enter DIOMEDES, below
line 9619-->
line 9620-->    How now! Is he dead?
line 9621-->  DIOMEDES. His death's upon him, but not dead.
line 9622-->    Look out o' th' other side your monument;
line 9623-->    His guard have brought him thither.
line 9624-->
line 9625-->            Enter, below, ANTONY, borne by the guard  
line 9626-->
line 9627-->  CLEOPATRA. O sun,
line 9628-->    Burn the great sphere thou mov'st in! Darkling stand
line 9629-->    The varying shore o' th' world. O Antony,
line 9630-->    Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian; help, Iras, help;
line 9631-->    Help, friends below! Let's draw him hither.
line 9632-->  ANTONY. Peace!
line 9633-->    Not Caesar's valour hath o'erthrown Antony,
line 9634-->    But Antony's hath triumph'd on itself.
line 9635-->  CLEOPATRA. So it should be, that none but Antony
line 9636-->    Should conquer Antony; but woe 'tis so!
line 9637-->  ANTONY. I am dying, Egypt, dying; only
line 9638-->    I here importune death awhile, until
line 9639-->    Of many thousand kisses the poor last
line 9640-->    I lay upon thy lips.
line 9641-->  CLEOPATRA. I dare not, dear.
line 9642-->    Dear my lord, pardon! I dare not,
line 9643-->    Lest I be taken. Not th' imperious show
line 9644-->    Of the full-fortun'd Caesar ever shall
line 9645-->    Be brooch'd with me. If knife, drugs, serpents, have  
line 9646-->    Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe.
line 9647-->    Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes
line 9648-->    And still conclusion, shall acquire no honour
line 9649-->    Demuring upon me. But come, come, Antony-
line 9650-->    Help me, my women- we must draw thee up;
line 9651-->    Assist, good friends.
line 9652-->  ANTONY. O, quick, or I am gone.
line 9653-->  CLEOPATRA. Here's sport indeed! How heavy weighs my lord!
line 9654-->    Our strength is all gone into heaviness;
line 9655-->    That makes the weight. Had I great Juno's power,
line 9656-->    The strong-wing'd Mercury should fetch thee up,
line 9657-->    And set thee by Jove's side. Yet come a little.
line 9658-->    Wishers were ever fools. O come, come,
line 9659-->                          [They heave ANTONY aloft to CLEOPATRA]
line 9660-->    And welcome, welcome! Die where thou hast liv'd.
line 9661-->    Quicken with kissing. Had my lips that power,
line 9662-->    Thus would I wear them out.
line 9663-->  ALL. A heavy sight!
line 9664-->  ANTONY. I am dying, Egypt, dying.
line 9665-->    Give me some wine, and let me speak a little.  
line 9666-->  CLEOPATRA. No, let me speak; and let me rail so high
line 9667-->    That the false huswife Fortune break her wheel,
line 9668-->    Provok'd by my offence.
line 9669-->  ANTONY. One word, sweet queen:
line 9670-->    Of Caesar seek your honour, with your safety. O!
line 9671-->  CLEOPATRA. They do not go together.
line 9672-->  ANTONY. Gentle, hear me:
line 9673-->    None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.
line 9674-->  CLEOPATRA. My resolution and my hands I'll trust;
line 9675-->    None about Caesar
line 9676-->  ANTONY. The miserable change now at my end
line 9677-->    Lament nor sorrow at; but please your thoughts
line 9678-->    In feeding them with those my former fortunes
line 9679-->    Wherein I liv'd the greatest prince o' th' world,
line 9680-->    The noblest; and do now not basely die,
line 9681-->    Not cowardly put off my helmet to
line 9682-->    My countryman- a Roman by a Roman
line 9683-->    Valiantly vanquish'd. Now my spirit is going
line 9684-->    I can no more.
line 9685-->  CLEOPATRA. Noblest of men, woo't die?  
line 9686-->    Hast thou no care of me? Shall I abide
line 9687-->    In this dull world, which in thy absence is
line 9688-->    No better than a sty? O, see, my women,        [Antony dies]
line 9689-->    The crown o' th' earth doth melt. My lord!
line 9690-->    O, wither'd is the garland of the war,
line 9691-->    The soldier's pole is fall'n! Young boys and girls
line 9692-->    Are level now with men. The odds is gone,
line 9693-->    And there is nothing left remarkable
line 9694-->    Beneath the visiting moon.                          [Swoons]
line 9695-->  CHARMIAN. O, quietness, lady!
line 9696-->  IRAS. She's dead too, our sovereign.
line 9697-->  CHARMIAN. Lady!
line 9698-->  IRAS. Madam!
line 9699-->  CHARMIAN. O madam, madam, madam!
line 9700-->  IRAS. Royal Egypt, Empress!
line 9701-->  CHARMIAN. Peace, peace, Iras!
line 9702-->  CLEOPATRA. No more but e'en a woman, and commanded
line 9703-->    By such poor passion as the maid that milks
line 9704-->    And does the meanest chares. It were for me
line 9705-->    To throw my sceptre at the injurious gods;  
line 9706-->    To tell them that this world did equal theirs
line 9707-->    Till they had stol'n our jewel. All's but nought;
line 9708-->    Patience is sottish, and impatience does
line 9709-->    Become a dog that's mad. Then is it sin
line 9710-->    To rush into the secret house of death
line 9711-->    Ere death dare come to us? How do you, women?
line 9712-->    What, what! good cheer! Why, how now, Charmian!
line 9713-->    My noble girls! Ah, women, women, look,
line 9714-->    Our lamp is spent, it's out! Good sirs, take heart.
line 9715-->    We'll bury him; and then, what's brave, what's noble,
line 9716-->    Let's do it after the high Roman fashion,
line 9717-->    And make death proud to take us. Come, away;
line 9718-->    This case of that huge spirit now is cold.
line 9719-->    Ah, women, women! Come; we have no friend
line 9720-->    But resolution and the briefest end.
line 9721-->                   Exeunt; those above hearing off ANTONY'S body
line 9722-->
line 9723-->ACT_5|SC_1
line 9724-->                       ACT V. SCENE I.
line 9725-->                  Alexandria. CAESAR'S camp
line 9726-->
line 9727-->      Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, DOLABELLA, MAECENAS, GALLUS,
line 9728-->          PROCULEIUS, and others, his Council of War
line 9729-->
line 9730-->  CAESAR. Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield;
line 9731-->    Being so frustrate, tell him he mocks
line 9732-->    The pauses that he makes.
line 9733-->  DOLABELLA. Caesar, I shall.                               Exit
line 9734-->
line 9735-->             Enter DERCETAS With the sword of ANTONY
line 9736-->
line 9737-->  CAESAR. Wherefore is that? And what art thou that dar'st
line 9738-->    Appear thus to us?
line 9739-->  DERCETAS. I am call'd Dercetas;
line 9740-->    Mark Antony I serv'd, who best was worthy
line 9741-->    Best to be serv'd. Whilst he stood up and spoke,
line 9742-->    He was my master, and I wore my life
line 9743-->    To spend upon his haters. If thou please
line 9744-->    To take me to thee, as I was to him
line 9745-->    I'll be to Caesar; if thou pleasest not,  
line 9746-->    I yield thee up my life.
line 9747-->  CAESAR. What is't thou say'st?
line 9748-->  DERCETAS. I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.
line 9749-->  CAESAR. The breaking of so great a thing should make
line 9750-->    A greater crack. The round world
line 9751-->    Should have shook lions into civil streets,
line 9752-->    And citizens to their dens. The death of Antony
line 9753-->    Is not a single doom; in the name lay
line 9754-->    A moiety of the world.
line 9755-->  DERCETAS. He is dead, Caesar,
line 9756-->    Not by a public minister of justice,
line 9757-->    Nor by a hired knife; but that self hand
line 9758-->    Which writ his honour in the acts it did
line 9759-->    Hath, with the courage which the heart did lend it,
line 9760-->    Splitted the heart. This is his sword;
line 9761-->    I robb'd his wound of it; behold it stain'd
line 9762-->    With his most noble blood.
line 9763-->  CAESAR. Look you sad, friends?
line 9764-->    The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings
line 9765-->    To wash the eyes of kings.  
line 9766-->  AGRIPPA. And strange it is
line 9767-->    That nature must compel us to lament
line 9768-->    Our most persisted deeds.
line 9769-->  MAECENAS. His taints and honours
line 9770-->    Wag'd equal with him.
line 9771-->  AGRIPPA. A rarer spirit never
line 9772-->    Did steer humanity. But you gods will give us
line 9773-->    Some faults to make us men. Caesar is touch'd.
line 9774-->  MAECENAS. When such a spacious mirror's set before him,
line 9775-->    He needs must see himself.
line 9776-->  CAESAR. O Antony,
line 9777-->    I have follow'd thee to this! But we do lance
line 9778-->    Diseases in our bodies. I must perforce
line 9779-->    Have shown to thee such a declining day
line 9780-->    Or look on thine; we could not stall together
line 9781-->    In the whole world. But yet let me lament,
line 9782-->    With tears as sovereign as the blood of hearts,
line 9783-->    That thou, my brother, my competitor
line 9784-->    In top of all design, my mate in empire,
line 9785-->    Friend and companion in the front of war,  
line 9786-->    The arm of mine own body, and the heart
line 9787-->    Where mine his thoughts did kindle- that our stars,
line 9788-->    Unreconciliable, should divide
line 9789-->    Our equalness to this. Hear me, good friends-
line 9790-->
line 9791-->                    Enter an EGYPTIAN
line 9792-->
line 9793-->    But I will tell you at some meeter season.
line 9794-->    The business of this man looks out of him;
line 9795-->    We'll hear him what he says. Whence are you?
line 9796-->  EGYPTIAN. A poor Egyptian, yet the Queen, my mistress,
line 9797-->    Confin'd in all she has, her monument,
line 9798-->    Of thy intents desires instruction,
line 9799-->    That she preparedly may frame herself
line 9800-->    To th' way she's forc'd to.
line 9801-->  CAESAR. Bid her have good heart.
line 9802-->    She soon shall know of us, by some of ours,
line 9803-->    How honourable and how kindly we
line 9804-->    Determine for her; for Caesar cannot learn
line 9805-->    To be ungentle.  
line 9806-->  EGYPTIAN. So the gods preserve thee!                      Exit
line 9807-->  CAESAR. Come hither, Proculeius. Go and say
line 9808-->    We purpose her no shame. Give her what comforts
line 9809-->    The quality of her passion shall require,
line 9810-->    Lest, in her greatness, by some mortal stroke
line 9811-->    She do defeat us; for her life in Rome
line 9812-->    Would be eternal in our triumph. Go,
line 9813-->    And with your speediest bring us what she says,
line 9814-->    And how you find her.
line 9815-->  PROCULEIUS. Caesar, I shall.                              Exit
line 9816-->  CAESAR. Gallus, go you along.                      Exit GALLUS
line 9817-->    Where's Dolabella, to second Proculeius?
line 9818-->  ALL. Dolabella!
line 9819-->  CAESAR. Let him alone, for I remember now
line 9820-->    How he's employ'd; he shall in time be ready.
line 9821-->    Go with me to my tent, where you shall see
line 9822-->    How hardly I was drawn into this war,
line 9823-->    How calm and gentle I proceeded still
line 9824-->    In all my writings. Go with me, and see
line 9825-->    What I can show in this.                              Exeunt
line 9826-->
line 9827-->ACT_5|SC_2
line 9828-->                         SCENE II.
line 9829-->                Alexandria. The monument
line 9830-->
line 9831-->      Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN
line 9832-->
line 9833-->  CLEOPATRA. My desolation does begin to make
line 9834-->    A better life. 'Tis paltry to be Caesar:
line 9835-->    Not being Fortune, he's but Fortune's knave,
line 9836-->    A minister of her will; and it is great
line 9837-->    To do that thing that ends all other deeds,
line 9838-->    Which shackles accidents and bolts up change,
line 9839-->    Which sleeps, and never palates more the dug,
line 9840-->    The beggar's nurse and Caesar's.
line 9841-->
line 9842-->       Enter, to the gates of the monument, PROCULEIUS, GALLUS,
line 9843-->                          and soldiers
line 9844-->
line 9845-->  PROCULEIUS. Caesar sends greetings to the Queen of Egypt,
line 9846-->    And bids thee study on what fair demands
line 9847-->    Thou mean'st to have him grant thee.
line 9848-->  CLEOPATRA. What's thy name?
line 9849-->  PROCULEIUS. My name is Proculeius.  
line 9850-->  CLEOPATRA. Antony
line 9851-->    Did tell me of you, bade me trust you; but
line 9852-->    I do not greatly care to be deceiv'd,
line 9853-->    That have no use for trusting. If your master
line 9854-->    Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him
line 9855-->    That majesty, to keep decorum, must
line 9856-->    No less beg than a kingdom. If he please
line 9857-->    To give me conquer'd Egypt for my son,
line 9858-->    He gives me so much of mine own as I
line 9859-->    Will kneel to him with thanks.
line 9860-->  PROCULEIUS. Be of good cheer;
line 9861-->    Y'are fall'n into a princely hand; fear nothing.
line 9862-->    Make your full reference freely to my lord,
line 9863-->    Who is so full of grace that it flows over
line 9864-->    On all that need. Let me report to him
line 9865-->    Your sweet dependency, and you shall find
line 9866-->    A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness
line 9867-->    Where he for grace is kneel'd to.
line 9868-->  CLEOPATRA. Pray you tell him
line 9869-->    I am his fortune's vassal and I send him  
line 9870-->    The greatness he has got. I hourly learn
line 9871-->    A doctrine of obedience, and would gladly
line 9872-->    Look him i' th' face.
line 9873-->  PROCULEIUS. This I'll report, dear lady.
line 9874-->    Have comfort, for I know your plight is pitied
line 9875-->    Of him that caus'd it.
line 9876-->  GALLUS. You see how easily she may be surpris'd.
line 9877-->
line 9878-->      Here PROCULEIUS and two of the guard ascend the
line 9879-->       monument by a ladder placed against a window,
line 9880-->       and come behind CLEOPATRA. Some of the guard
line 9881-->                unbar and open the gates
line 9882-->
line 9883-->    Guard her till Caesar come.                             Exit
line 9884-->  IRAS. Royal Queen!
line 9885-->  CHARMIAN. O Cleopatra! thou art taken, Queen!
line 9886-->  CLEOPATRA. Quick, quick, good hands.        [Drawing a dagger]
line 9887-->  PROCULEIUS. Hold, worthy lady, hold,             [Disarms her]
line 9888-->    Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this
line 9889-->    Reliev'd, but not betray'd.  
line 9890-->  CLEOPATRA. What, of death too,
line 9891-->    That rids our dogs of languish?
line 9892-->  PROCULEIUS. Cleopatra,
line 9893-->    Do not abuse my master's bounty by
line 9894-->    Th' undoing of yourself. Let the world see
line 9895-->    His nobleness well acted, which your death
line 9896-->    Will never let come forth.
line 9897-->  CLEOPATRA. Where art thou, death?
line 9898-->    Come hither, come! Come, come, and take a queen
line 9899-->    Worth many babes and beggars!
line 9900-->  PROCULEIUS. O, temperance, lady!
line 9901-->  CLEOPATRA. Sir, I will eat no meat; I'll not drink, sir;
line 9902-->    If idle talk will once be necessary,
line 9903-->    I'll not sleep neither. This mortal house I'll ruin,
line 9904-->    Do Caesar what he can. Know, sir, that I
line 9905-->    Will not wait pinion'd at your master's court,
line 9906-->    Nor once be chastis'd with the sober eye
line 9907-->    Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up,
line 9908-->    And show me to the shouting varletry
line 9909-->    Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt  
line 9910-->    Be gentle grave unto me! Rather on Nilus' mud
line 9911-->    Lay me stark-nak'd, and let the water-flies
line 9912-->    Blow me into abhorring! Rather make
line 9913-->    My country's high pyramides my gibbet,
line 9914-->    And hang me up in chains!
line 9915-->  PROCULEIUS. You do extend
line 9916-->    These thoughts of horror further than you shall
line 9917-->    Find cause in Caesar.
line 9918-->
line 9919-->                      Enter DOLABELLA
line 9920-->
line 9921-->  DOLABELLA. Proculeius,
line 9922-->    What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows,
line 9923-->    And he hath sent for thee. For the Queen,
line 9924-->    I'll take her to my guard.
line 9925-->  PROCULEIUS. So, Dolabella,
line 9926-->    It shall content me best. Be gentle to her.
line 9927-->    [To CLEOPATRA] To Caesar I will speak what you shall please,
line 9928-->    If you'll employ me to him.
line 9929-->  CLEOPATRA. Say I would die.  
line 9930-->                                  Exeunt PROCULEIUS and soldiers
line 9931-->  DOLABELLA. Most noble Empress, you have heard of me?
line 9932-->  CLEOPATRA. I cannot tell.
line 9933-->  DOLABELLA. Assuredly you know me.
line 9934-->  CLEOPATRA. No matter, sir, what I have heard or known.
line 9935-->    You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams;
line 9936-->    Is't not your trick?
line 9937-->  DOLABELLA. I understand not, madam.
line 9938-->  CLEOPATRA. I dreamt there was an Emperor Antony-
line 9939-->    O, such another sleep, that I might see
line 9940-->    But such another man!
line 9941-->  DOLABELLA. If it might please ye-
line 9942-->  CLEOPATRA. His face was as the heav'ns, and therein stuck
line 9943-->    A sun and moon, which kept their course and lighted
line 9944-->    The little O, the earth.
line 9945-->  DOLABELLA. Most sovereign creature-
line 9946-->  CLEOPATRA. His legs bestrid the ocean; his rear'd arm
line 9947-->    Crested the world. His voice was propertied
line 9948-->    As all the tuned spheres, and that to friends;
line 9949-->    But when he meant to quail and shake the orb,  
line 9950-->    He was as rattling thunder. For his bounty,
line 9951-->    There was no winter in't; an autumn 'twas
line 9952-->    That grew the more by reaping. His delights
line 9953-->    Were dolphin-like: they show'd his back above
line 9954-->    The element they liv'd in. In his livery
line 9955-->    Walk'd crowns and crownets; realms and islands were
line 9956-->    As plates dropp'd from his pocket.
line 9957-->  DOLABELLA. Cleopatra-
line 9958-->  CLEOPATRA. Think you there was or might be such a man
line 9959-->    As this I dreamt of?
line 9960-->  DOLABELLA. Gentle madam, no.
line 9961-->  CLEOPATRA. You lie, up to the hearing of the gods.
line 9962-->    But if there be nor ever were one such,
line 9963-->    It's past the size of drearning. Nature wants stuff
line 9964-->    To vie strange forms with fancy; yet t' imagine
line 9965-->    An Antony were nature's piece 'gainst fancy,
line 9966-->    Condemning shadows quite.
line 9967-->  DOLABELLA. Hear me, good madam.
line 9968-->    Your loss is, as yourself, great; and you bear it
line 9969-->    As answering to the weight. Would I might never  
line 9970-->    O'ertake pursu'd success, but I do feel,
line 9971-->    By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites
line 9972-->    My very heart at root.
line 9973-->  CLEOPATRA. I thank you, sir.
line 9974-->    Know you what Caesar means to do with me?
line 9975-->  DOLABELLA. I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.
line 9976-->  CLEOPATRA. Nay, pray you, sir.
line 9977-->  DOLABELLA. Though he be honourable-
line 9978-->  CLEOPATRA. He'll lead me, then, in triumph?
line 9979-->  DOLABELLA. Madam, he will. I know't.                [Flourish]
line 9980-->                              [Within: 'Make way there-Caesar!']
line 9981-->
line 9982-->       Enter CAESAR; GALLUS, PROCULEIUS, MAECENAS, SELEUCUS,
line 9983-->                     and others of his train
line 9984-->
line 9985-->  CAESAR. Which is the Queen of Egypt?
line 9986-->  DOLABELLA. It is the Emperor, madam.        [CLEOPATPA kneels]
line 9987-->  CAESAR. Arise, you shall not kneel.
line 9988-->    I pray you, rise; rise, Egypt.
line 9989-->  CLEOPATRA. Sir, the gods  
line 9990-->    Will have it thus; my master and my lord
line 9991-->    I must obey.
line 9992-->  CAESAR. Take to you no hard thoughts.
line 9993-->    The record of what injuries you did us,
line 9994-->    Though written in our flesh, we shall remember
line 9995-->    As things but done by chance.
line 9996-->  CLEOPATRA. Sole sir o' th' world,
line 9997-->    I cannot project mine own cause so well
line 9998-->    To make it clear, but do confess I have
line 9999-->    Been laden with like frailties which before
line 10000-->    Have often sham'd our sex.
line 10001-->  CAESAR. Cleopatra, know
line 10002-->    We will extenuate rather than enforce.
line 10003-->    If you apply yourself to our intents-
line 10004-->    Which towards you are most gentle- you shall find
line 10005-->    A benefit in this change; but if you seek
line 10006-->    To lay on me a cruelty by taking
line 10007-->    Antony's course, you shall bereave yourself
line 10008-->    Of my good purposes, and put your children
line 10009-->    To that destruction which I'll guard them from,  
line 10010-->    If thereon you rely. I'll take my leave.
line 10011-->  CLEOPATRA. And may, through all the world. 'Tis yours, and we,
line 10012-->    Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shall
line 10013-->    Hang in what place you please. Here, my good lord.
line 10014-->  CAESAR. You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.
line 10015-->  CLEOPATRA. This is the brief of money, plate, and jewels,
line 10016-->    I am possess'd of. 'Tis exactly valued,
line 10017-->    Not petty things admitted. Where's Seleucus?
line 10018-->  SELEUCUS. Here, madam.
line 10019-->  CLEOPATRA. This is my treasurer; let him speak, my lord,
line 10020-->    Upon his peril, that I have reserv'd
line 10021-->    To myself nothing. Speak the truth, Seleucus.
line 10022-->  SELEUCUS. Madam,
line 10023-->    I had rather seal my lips than to my peril
line 10024-->    Speak that which is not.
line 10025-->  CLEOPATRA. What have I kept back?
line 10026-->  SELEUCUS. Enough to purchase what you have made known.
line 10027-->  CAESAR. Nay, blush not, Cleopatra; I approve
line 10028-->    Your wisdom in the deed.
line 10029-->  CLEOPATRA. See, Caesar! O, behold,  
line 10030-->    How pomp is followed! Mine will now be yours;
line 10031-->    And, should we shift estates, yours would be mine.
line 10032-->    The ingratitude of this Seleucus does
line 10033-->    Even make me wild. O slave, of no more trust
line 10034-->    Than love that's hir'd! What, goest thou back? Thou shalt
line 10035-->    Go back, I warrant thee; but I'll catch thine eyes
line 10036-->    Though they had wings. Slave, soulless villain, dog!
line 10037-->    O rarely base!
line 10038-->  CAESAR. Good Queen, let us entreat you.
line 10039-->  CLEOPATRA. O Caesar, what a wounding shame is this,
line 10040-->    That thou vouchsafing here to visit me,
line 10041-->    Doing the honour of thy lordliness
line 10042-->    To one so meek, that mine own servant should
line 10043-->    Parcel the sum of my disgraces by
line 10044-->    Addition of his envy! Say, good Caesar,
line 10045-->    That I some lady trifles have reserv'd,
line 10046-->    Immoment toys, things of such dignity
line 10047-->    As we greet modern friends withal; and say
line 10048-->    Some nobler token I have kept apart
line 10049-->    For Livia and Octavia, to induce  
line 10050-->    Their mediation- must I be unfolded
line 10051-->    With one that I have bred? The gods! It smites me
line 10052-->    Beneath the fall I have. [To SELEUCUS] Prithee go hence;
line 10053-->    Or I shall show the cinders of my spirits
line 10054-->    Through th' ashes of my chance. Wert thou a man,
line 10055-->    Thou wouldst have mercy on me.
line 10056-->  CAESAR. Forbear, Seleucus.                       Exit SELEUCUS
line 10057-->  CLEOPATRA. Be it known that we, the greatest, are misthought
line 10058-->    For things that others do; and when we fall
line 10059-->    We answer others' merits in our name,
line 10060-->    Are therefore to be pitied.
line 10061-->  CAESAR. Cleopatra,
line 10062-->    Not what you have reserv'd, nor what acknowledg'd,
line 10063-->    Put we i' th' roll of conquest. Still be't yours,
line 10064-->    Bestow it at your pleasure; and believe
line 10065-->    Caesar's no merchant, to make prize with you
line 10066-->    Of things that merchants sold. Therefore be cheer'd;
line 10067-->    Make not your thoughts your prisons. No, dear Queen;
line 10068-->    For we intend so to dispose you as
line 10069-->    Yourself shall give us counsel. Feed and sleep.  
line 10070-->    Our care and pity is so much upon you
line 10071-->    That we remain your friend; and so, adieu.
line 10072-->  CLEOPATRA. My master and my lord!
line 10073-->  CAESAR. Not so. Adieu.
line 10074-->                           Flourish. Exeunt CAESAR and his train
line 10075-->  CLEOPATRA. He words me, girls, he words me, that I should not
line 10076-->    Be noble to myself. But hark thee, Charmian!
line 10077-->                                             [Whispers CHARMIAN]
line 10078-->  IRAS. Finish, good lady; the bright day is done,
line 10079-->    And we are for the dark.
line 10080-->  CLEOPATRA. Hie thee again.
line 10081-->    I have spoke already, and it is provided;
line 10082-->    Go put it to the haste.
line 10083-->  CHARMIAN. Madam, I will.
line 10084-->
line 10085-->                      Re-enter DOLABELLA
line 10086-->
line 10087-->  DOLABELLA. Where's the Queen?
line 10088-->  CHARMIAN. Behold, sir.                                    Exit
line 10089-->  CLEOPATRA. Dolabella!  
line 10090-->  DOLABELLA. Madam, as thereto sworn by your command,
line 10091-->    Which my love makes religion to obey,
line 10092-->    I tell you this: Caesar through Syria
line 10093-->    Intends his journey, and within three days
line 10094-->    You with your children will he send before.
line 10095-->    Make your best use of this; I have perform'd
line 10096-->    Your pleasure and my promise.
line 10097-->  CLEOPATRA. Dolabella,
line 10098-->    I shall remain your debtor.
line 10099-->  DOLABELLA. I your servant.
line 10100-->    Adieu, good Queen; I must attend on Caesar.
line 10101-->  CLEOPATRA. Farewell, and thanks.                Exit DOLABELLA
line 10102-->    Now, Iras, what think'st thou?
line 10103-->    Thou an Egyptian puppet shall be shown
line 10104-->    In Rome as well as I. Mechanic slaves,
line 10105-->    With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers, shall
line 10106-->    Uplift us to the view; in their thick breaths,
line 10107-->    Rank of gross diet, shall we be enclouded,
line 10108-->    And forc'd to drink their vapour.
line 10109-->  IRAS. The gods forbid!  
line 10110-->  CLEOPATRA. Nay, 'tis most certain, Iras. Saucy lictors
line 10111-->    Will catch at us like strumpets, and scald rhymers
line 10112-->    Ballad us out o' tune; the quick comedians
line 10113-->    Extemporally will stage us, and present
line 10114-->    Our Alexandrian revels; Antony
line 10115-->    Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see
line 10116-->    Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness
line 10117-->    I' th' posture of a whore.
line 10118-->  IRAS. O the good gods!
line 10119-->  CLEOPATRA. Nay, that's certain.
line 10120-->  IRAS. I'll never see't, for I am sure mine nails
line 10121-->    Are stronger than mine eyes.
line 10122-->  CLEOPATRA. Why, that's the way
line 10123-->    To fool their preparation and to conquer
line 10124-->    Their most absurd intents.
line 10125-->
line 10126-->                      Enter CHARMIAN
line 10127-->
line 10128-->    Now, Charmian!
line 10129-->    Show me, my women, like a queen. Go fetch  
line 10130-->    My best attires. I am again for Cydnus,
line 10131-->    To meet Mark Antony. Sirrah, Iras, go.
line 10132-->    Now, noble Charmian, we'll dispatch indeed;
line 10133-->    And when thou hast done this chare, I'll give thee leave
line 10134-->    To play till doomsday. Bring our crown and all.
line 10135-->                                       Exit IRAS. A noise within
line 10136-->    Wherefore's this noise?
line 10137-->
line 10138-->                     Enter a GUARDSMAN
line 10139-->
line 10140-->  GUARDSMAN. Here is a rural fellow
line 10141-->    That will not be denied your Highness' presence.
line 10142-->    He brings you figs.
line 10143-->  CLEOPATRA. Let him come in.                     Exit GUARDSMAN
line 10144-->    What poor an instrument
line 10145-->    May do a noble deed! He brings me liberty.
line 10146-->    My resolution's plac'd, and I have nothing
line 10147-->    Of woman in me. Now from head to foot
line 10148-->    I am marble-constant; now the fleeting moon
line 10149-->    No planet is of mine.  
line 10150-->
line 10151-->          Re-enter GUARDSMAN and CLOWN, with a basket
line 10152-->
line 10153-->  GUARDSMAN. This is the man.
line 10154-->  CLEOPATRA. Avoid, and leave him.                Exit GUARDSMAN
line 10155-->    Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there
line 10156-->    That kills and pains not?
line 10157-->  CLOWN. Truly, I have him. But I would not be the party that should
line 10158-->    desire you to touch him, for his biting is immortal; those that
line 10159-->    do die of it do seldom or never recover.
line 10160-->  CLEOPATRA. Remember'st thou any that have died on't?
line 10161-->  CLOWN. Very many, men and women too. I heard of one of them no
line 10162-->    longer than yesterday: a very honest woman, but something given
line 10163-->    to lie, as a woman should not do but in the way of honesty; how
line 10164-->    she died of the biting of it, what pain she felt- truly she makes
line 10165-->    a very good report o' th' worm. But he that will believe all that
line 10166-->    they say shall never be saved by half that they do. But this is
line 10167-->    most falliable, the worm's an odd worm.
line 10168-->  CLEOPATRA. Get thee hence; farewell.
line 10169-->  CLOWN. I wish you all joy of the worm.  
line 10170-->                                          [Sets down the basket]
line 10171-->  CLEOPATRA. Farewell.
line 10172-->  CLOWN. You must think this, look you, that the worm will do his
line 10173-->    kind.
line 10174-->  CLEOPATRA. Ay, ay; farewell.
line 10175-->  CLOWN. Look you, the worm is not to be trusted but in the keeping
line 10176-->    of wise people; for indeed there is no goodness in the worm.
line 10177-->  CLEOPATRA. Take thou no care; it shall be heeded.
line 10178-->  CLOWN. Very good. Give it nothing, I pray you, for it is not worth
line 10179-->    the feeding.
line 10180-->  CLEOPATRA. Will it eat me?
line 10181-->  CLOWN. You must not think I am so simple but I know the devil
line 10182-->    himself will not eat a woman. I know that a woman is a dish for
line 10183-->    the gods, if the devil dress her not. But truly, these same
line 10184-->    whoreson devils do the gods great harm in their women, for in
line 10185-->    every ten that they make the devils mar five.
line 10186-->  CLEOPATRA. Well, get thee gone; farewell.
line 10187-->  CLOWN. Yes, forsooth. I wish you joy o' th' worm.         Exit
line 10188-->
line 10189-->             Re-enter IRAS, with a robe, crown, &c.  
line 10190-->
line 10191-->  CLEOPATRA. Give me my robe, put on my crown; I have
line 10192-->    Immortal longings in me. Now no more
line 10193-->    The juice of Egypt's grape shall moist this lip.
line 10194-->    Yare, yare, good Iras; quick. Methinks I hear
line 10195-->    Antony call. I see him rouse himself
line 10196-->    To praise my noble act. I hear him mock
line 10197-->    The luck of Caesar, which the gods give men
line 10198-->    To excuse their after wrath. Husband, I come.
line 10199-->    Now to that name my courage prove my title!
line 10200-->    I am fire and air; my other elements
line 10201-->    I give to baser life. So, have you done?
line 10202-->    Come then, and take the last warmth of my lips.
line 10203-->    Farewell, kind Charmian. Iras, long farewell.
line 10204-->                              [Kisses them. IRAS falls and dies]
line 10205-->    Have I the aspic in my lips? Dost fall?
line 10206-->    If thus thou and nature can so gently part,
line 10207-->    The stroke of death is as a lover's pinch,
line 10208-->    Which hurts and is desir'd. Dost thou lie still?
line 10209-->    If thou vanishest, thou tell'st the world  
line 10210-->    It is not worth leave-taking.
line 10211-->  CHARMIAN. Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain, that I may say
line 10212-->    The gods themselves do weep.
line 10213-->  CLEOPATRA. This proves me base.
line 10214-->    If she first meet the curled Antony,
line 10215-->    He'll make demand of her, and spend that kiss
line 10216-->    Which is my heaven to have. Come, thou mortal wretch,
line 10217-->                    [To an asp, which she applies to her breast]
line 10218-->    With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate
line 10219-->    Of life at once untie. Poor venomous fool,
line 10220-->    Be angry and dispatch. O couldst thou speak,
line 10221-->    That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass
line 10222-->    Unpolicied!
line 10223-->  CHARMIAN. O Eastern star!
line 10224-->  CLEOPATRA. Peace, peace!
line 10225-->    Dost thou not see my baby at my breast
line 10226-->    That sucks the nurse asleep?
line 10227-->  CHARMIAN. O, break! O, break!
line 10228-->  CLEOPATRA. As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle-
line 10229-->    O Antony! Nay, I will take thee too:  
line 10230-->                               [Applying another asp to her arm]
line 10231-->    What should I stay-                                   [Dies]
line 10232-->  CHARMIAN. In this vile world? So, fare thee well.
line 10233-->    Now boast thee, death, in thy possession lies
line 10234-->    A lass unparallel'd. Downy windows, close;
line 10235-->    And golden Phoebus never be beheld
line 10236-->    Of eyes again so royal! Your crown's awry;
line 10237-->    I'll mend it and then play-
line 10238-->
line 10239-->                  Enter the guard, rushing in
line 10240-->
line 10241-->  FIRST GUARD. Where's the Queen?
line 10242-->  CHARMIAN. Speak softly, wake her not.
line 10243-->  FIRST GUARD. Caesar hath sent-
line 10244-->  CHARMIAN. Too slow a messenger.               [Applies an asp]
line 10245-->    O, come apace, dispatch. I partly feel thee.
line 10246-->  FIRST GUARD. Approach, ho! All's not well: Caesar's beguil'd.
line 10247-->  SECOND GUARD. There's Dolabella sent from Caesar; call him.
line 10248-->  FIRST GUARD. What work is here! Charmian, is this well done?
line 10249-->  CHARMIAN. It is well done, and fitting for a princes  
line 10250-->    Descended of so many royal kings.
line 10251-->    Ah, soldier!                                 [CHARMIAN dies]
line 10252-->
line 10253-->                      Re-enter DOLABELLA
line 10254-->
line 10255-->  DOLABELLA. How goes it here?
line 10256-->  SECOND GUARD. All dead.
line 10257-->  DOLABELLA. Caesar, thy thoughts
line 10258-->    Touch their effects in this. Thyself art coming
line 10259-->    To see perform'd the dreaded act which thou
line 10260-->    So sought'st to hinder.
line 10261-->                      [Within: 'A way there, a way for Caesar!']
line 10262-->
line 10263-->              Re-enter CAESAR and all his train
line 10264-->
line 10265-->  DOLABELLA. O sir, you are too sure an augurer:
line 10266-->    That you did fear is done.
line 10267-->  CAESAR. Bravest at the last,
line 10268-->    She levell'd at our purposes, and being royal,
line 10269-->    Took her own way. The manner of their deaths?  
line 10270-->    I do not see them bleed.
line 10271-->  DOLABELLA. Who was last with them?
line 10272-->  FIRST GUARD. A simple countryman that brought her figs.
line 10273-->    This was his basket.
line 10274-->  CAESAR. Poison'd then.
line 10275-->  FIRST GUARD. O Caesar,
line 10276-->    This Charmian liv'd but now; she stood and spake.
line 10277-->    I found her trimming up the diadem
line 10278-->    On her dead mistress. Tremblingly she stood,
line 10279-->    And on the sudden dropp'd.
line 10280-->  CAESAR. O noble weakness!
line 10281-->    If they had swallow'd poison 'twould appear
line 10282-->    By external swelling; but she looks like sleep,
line 10283-->    As she would catch another Antony
line 10284-->    In her strong toil of grace.
line 10285-->  DOLABELLA. Here on her breast
line 10286-->    There is a vent of blood, and something blown;
line 10287-->    The like is on her arm.
line 10288-->  FIRST GUARD. This is an aspic's trail; and these fig-leaves
line 10289-->    Have slime upon them, such as th' aspic leaves  
line 10290-->    Upon the caves of Nile.
line 10291-->  CAESAR. Most probable
line 10292-->    That so she died; for her physician tells me
line 10293-->    She hath pursu'd conclusions infinite
line 10294-->    Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed,
line 10295-->    And bear her women from the monument.
line 10296-->    She shall be buried by her Antony;
line 10297-->    No grave upon the earth shall clip in it
line 10298-->    A pair so famous. High events as these
line 10299-->    Strike those that make them; and their story is
line 10300-->    No less in pity than his glory which
line 10301-->    Brought them to be lamented. Our army shall
line 10302-->    In solemn show attend this funeral,
line 10303-->    And then to Rome. Come, Dolabella, see
line 10304-->    High order in this great solemnity.                   Exeunt
line 10305-->
line 10306-->
line 10307-->THE END

line 10372-->
line 10373-->SCENE:
line 10374-->OLIVER'S house; FREDERICK'S court; and the Forest of Arden
line 10375-->
line 10376-->ACT I. SCENE I.
line 10377-->Orchard of OLIVER'S house
line 10378-->
line 10379-->Enter ORLANDO and ADAM
line 10380-->
line 10381-->  ORLANDO. As I remember, Adam, it was upon this fashion bequeathed
line 10382-->    me by will but poor a thousand crowns, and, as thou say'st,
line 10383-->    charged my brother, on his blessing, to breed me well; and there
line 10384-->    begins my sadness. My brother Jaques he keeps at school, and
line 10385-->    report speaks goldenly of his profit. For my part, he keeps me
line 10386-->    rustically at home, or, to speak more properly, stays me here at
line 10387-->    home unkept; for call you that keeping for a gentleman of my
line 10388-->    birth that differs not from the stalling of an ox? His horses are
line 10389-->    bred better; for, besides that they are fair with their feeding,
line 10390-->    they are taught their manage, and to that end riders dearly
line 10391-->    hir'd; but I, his brother, gain nothing under him but growth; for
line 10392-->    the which his animals on his dunghills are as much bound to him
line 10393-->    as I. Besides this nothing that he so plentifully gives me, the
line 10394-->    something that nature gave me his countenance seems to take from
line 10395-->    me. He lets me feed with his hinds, bars me the place of a
line 10396-->    brother, and as much as in him lies, mines my gentility with my
line 10397-->    education. This is it, Adam, that grieves me; and the spirit of  
line 10398-->    my father, which I think is within me, begins to mutiny against
line 10399-->    this servitude. I will no longer endure it, though yet I know no
line 10400-->    wise remedy how to avoid it.
line 10401-->
line 10402-->                           Enter OLIVER
line 10403-->
line 10404-->  ADAM. Yonder comes my master, your brother.
line 10405-->  ORLANDO. Go apart, Adam, and thou shalt hear how he will shake me
line 10406-->    up.                                           [ADAM retires]
line 10407-->  OLIVER. Now, sir! what make you here?
line 10408-->  ORLANDO. Nothing; I am not taught to make any thing.
line 10409-->  OLIVER. What mar you then, sir?
line 10410-->  ORLANDO. Marry, sir, I am helping you to mar that which God made, a
line 10411-->    poor unworthy brother of yours, with idleness.
line 10412-->  OLIVER. Marry, sir, be better employed, and be nought awhile.
line 10413-->  ORLANDO. Shall I keep your hogs, and eat husks with them? What
line 10414-->    prodigal portion have I spent that I should come to such penury?
line 10415-->  OLIVER. Know you where you are, sir?
line 10416-->  ORLANDO. O, sir, very well; here in your orchard.
line 10417-->  OLIVER. Know you before whom, sir?  
line 10418-->  ORLANDO. Ay, better than him I am before knows me. I know you are
line 10419-->    my eldest brother; and in the gentle condition of blood, you
line 10420-->    should so know me. The courtesy of nations allows you my better
line 10421-->    in that you are the first-born; but the same tradition takes not
line 10422-->    away my blood, were there twenty brothers betwixt us. I have as
line 10423-->    much of my father in me as you, albeit I confess your coming
line 10424-->    before me is nearer to his reverence.
line 10425-->  OLIVER. What, boy!                               [Strikes him]
line 10426-->  ORLANDO. Come, come, elder brother, you are too young in this.
line 10427-->  OLIVER. Wilt thou lay hands on me, villain?
line 10428-->  ORLANDO. I am no villain; I am the youngest son of Sir Rowland de
line 10429-->    Boys. He was my father; and he is thrice a villain that says such
line 10430-->    a father begot villains. Wert thou not my brother, I would not
line 10431-->    take this hand from thy throat till this other had pull'd out thy
line 10432-->    tongue for saying so. Thou has rail'd on thyself.
line 10433-->  ADAM. [Coming forward] Sweet masters, be patient; for your father's
line 10434-->    remembrance, be at accord.
line 10435-->  OLIVER. Let me go, I say.
line 10436-->  ORLANDO. I will not, till I please; you shall hear me. My father
line 10437-->    charg'd you in his will to give me good education: you have  
line 10438-->    train'd me like a peasant, obscuring and hiding from me all
line 10439-->    gentleman-like qualities. The spirit of my father grows strong in
line 10440-->    me, and I will no longer endure it; therefore allow me such
line 10441-->    exercises as may become a gentleman, or give me the poor
line 10442-->    allottery my father left me by testament; with that I will go buy
line 10443-->    my fortunes.
line 10444-->  OLIVER. And what wilt thou do? Beg, when that is spent? Well, sir,
line 10445-->    get you in. I will not long be troubled with you; you shall have
line 10446-->    some part of your will. I pray you leave me.
line 10447-->  ORLANDO. I no further offend you than becomes me for my good.
line 10448-->  OLIVER. Get you with him, you old dog.
line 10449-->  ADAM. Is 'old dog' my reward? Most true, I have lost my teeth in
line 10450-->    your service. God be with my old master! He would not have spoke
line 10451-->    such a word.
line 10452-->                                         Exeunt ORLANDO and ADAM
line 10453-->  OLIVER. Is it even so? Begin you to grow upon me? I will physic
line 10454-->    your rankness, and yet give no thousand crowns neither. Holla,
line 10455-->    Dennis!
line 10456-->
line 10457-->                          Enter DENNIS  
line 10458-->
line 10459-->  DENNIS. Calls your worship?
line 10460-->  OLIVER. not Charles, the Duke's wrestler, here to speak with me?
line 10461-->  DENNIS. So please you, he is here at the door and importunes access
line 10462-->    to you.
line 10463-->  OLIVER. Call him in. [Exit DENNIS] 'Twill be a good way; and
line 10464-->    to-morrow the wrestling is.
line 10465-->
line 10466-->                          Enter CHARLES
line 10467-->
line 10468-->  CHARLES. Good morrow to your worship.
line 10469-->  OLIVER. Good Monsieur Charles! What's the new news at the new
line 10470-->    court?
line 10471-->  CHARLES. There's no news at the court, sir, but the old news; that
line 10472-->    is, the old Duke is banished by his younger brother the new Duke;
line 10473-->    and three or four loving lords have put themselves into voluntary
line 10474-->    exile with him, whose lands and revenues enrich the new Duke;
line 10475-->    therefore he gives them good leave to wander.
line 10476-->  OLIVER. Can you tell if Rosalind, the Duke's daughter, be banished
line 10477-->    with her father?  
line 10478-->  CHARLES. O, no; for the Duke's daughter, her cousin, so loves her,
line 10479-->    being ever from their cradles bred together, that she would have
line 10480-->    followed her exile, or have died to stay behind her. She is at
line 10481-->    the court, and no less beloved of her uncle than his own
line 10482-->    daughter; and never two ladies loved as they do.
line 10483-->  OLIVER. Where will the old Duke live?
line 10484-->  CHARLES. They say he is already in the Forest of Arden, and a many
line 10485-->    merry men with him; and there they live like the old Robin Hood
line 10486-->    of England. They say many young gentlemen flock to him every day,
line 10487-->    and fleet the time carelessly, as they did in the golden world.
line 10488-->  OLIVER. What, you wrestle to-morrow before the new Duke?
line 10489-->  CHARLES. Marry, do I, sir; and I came to acquaint you with a
line 10490-->    matter. I am given, sir, secretly to understand that your younger
line 10491-->    brother, Orlando, hath a disposition to come in disguis'd against
line 10492-->    me to try a fall. To-morrow, sir, I wrestle for my credit; and he
line 10493-->    that escapes me without some broken limb shall acquit him well.
line 10494-->    Your brother is but young and tender; and, for your love, I would
line 10495-->    be loath to foil him, as I must, for my own honour, if he come
line 10496-->    in; therefore, out of my love to you, I came hither to acquaint
line 10497-->    you withal, that either you might stay him from his intendment,  
line 10498-->    or brook such disgrace well as he shall run into, in that it is
line 10499-->    thing of his own search and altogether against my will.
line 10500-->  OLIVER. Charles, I thank thee for thy love to me, which thou shalt
line 10501-->    find I will most kindly requite. I had myself notice of my
line 10502-->    brother's purpose herein, and have by underhand means laboured to
line 10503-->    dissuade him from it; but he is resolute. I'll tell thee,
line 10504-->    Charles, it is the stubbornest young fellow of France; full of
line 10505-->    ambition, an envious emulator of every man's good parts, a secret
line 10506-->    and villainous contriver against me his natural brother.
line 10507-->    Therefore use thy discretion: I had as lief thou didst break his
line 10508-->    neck as his finger. And thou wert best look to't; for if thou
line 10509-->    dost him any slight disgrace, or if he do not mightily grace
line 10510-->    himself on thee, he will practise against thee by poison, entrap
line 10511-->    thee by some treacherous device, and never leave thee till he
line 10512-->    hath ta'en thy life by some indirect means or other; for, I
line 10513-->    assure thee, and almost with tears I speak it, there is not one
line 10514-->    so young and so villainous this day living. I speak but brotherly
line 10515-->    of him; but should I anatomize him to thee as he is, I must blush
line 10516-->    and weep, and thou must look pale and wonder.
line 10517-->  CHARLES. I am heartily glad I came hither to you. If he come  
line 10518-->    to-morrow I'll give him his payment. If ever he go alone again,
line 10519-->    I'll never wrestle for prize more. And so, God keep your worship!
line 10520--> Exit
line 10521-->  OLIVER. Farewell, good Charles. Now will I stir this gamester. I
line 10522-->    hope I shall see an end of him; for my soul, yet I know not why,
line 10523-->    hates nothing more than he. Yet he's gentle; never school'd and
line 10524-->    yet learned; full of noble device; of all sorts enchantingly
line 10525-->    beloved; and, indeed, so much in the heart of the world, and
line 10526-->    especially of my own people, who best know him, that I am
line 10527-->    altogether misprised. But it shall not be so long; this wrestler
line 10528-->    shall clear all. Nothing remains but that I kindle the boy
line 10529-->    thither, which now I'll go about.                       Exit
line 10530-->
line 10531-->
line 10532-->
