line 10541-->
line 10542-->
line 10543-->
line 10544-->
line 10545-->SCENE II.
line 10546-->A lawn before the DUKE'S palace
line 10547-->
line 10548-->Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
line 10549-->
line 10550-->  CELIA. I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry.
line 10551-->  ROSALIND. Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistress of; and
line 10552-->    would you yet I were merrier? Unless you could teach me to forget
line 10553-->    a banished father, you must not learn me how to remember any
line 10554-->    extraordinary pleasure.
line 10555-->  CELIA. Herein I see thou lov'st me not with the full weight that I
line 10556-->    love thee. If my uncle, thy banished father, had banished thy
line 10557-->    uncle, the Duke my father, so thou hadst been still with me, I
line 10558-->    could have taught my love to take thy father for mine; so wouldst
line 10559-->    thou, if the truth of thy love to me were so righteously temper'd
line 10560-->    as mine is to thee.
line 10561-->  ROSALIND. Well, I will forget the condition of my estate, to
line 10562-->    rejoice in yours.
line 10563-->  CELIA. You know my father hath no child but I, nor none is like to
line 10564-->    have; and, truly, when he dies thou shalt be his heir; for what
line 10565-->    he hath taken away from thy father perforce, I will render thee
line 10566-->    again in affection. By mine honour, I will; and when I break that  
line 10567-->    oath, let me turn monster; therefore, my sweet Rose, my dear
line 10568-->    Rose, be merry.
line 10569-->  ROSALIND. From henceforth I will, coz, and devise sports.
line 10570-->    Let me see; what think you of falling in love?
line 10571-->  CELIA. Marry, I prithee, do, to make sport withal; but love no man
line 10572-->    in good earnest, nor no further in sport neither than with safety
line 10573-->    of a pure blush thou mayst in honour come off again.
line 10574-->  ROSALIND. What shall be our sport, then?
line 10575-->  CELIA. Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from her
line 10576-->    wheel, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equally.
line 10577-->  ROSALIND. I would we could do so; for her benefits are mightily
line 10578-->    misplaced; and the bountiful blind woman doth most mistake in her
line 10579-->    gifts to women.
line 10580-->  CELIA. 'Tis true; for those that she makes fair she scarce makes
line 10581-->    honest; and those that she makes honest she makes very
line 10582-->    ill-favouredly.
line 10583-->  ROSALIND. Nay; now thou goest from Fortune's office to Nature's:
line 10584-->    Fortune reigns in gifts of the world, not in the lineaments of
line 10585-->    Nature.
line 10586-->  
line 10587-->                         Enter TOUCHSTONE
line 10588-->
line 10589-->  CELIA. No; when Nature hath made a fair creature, may she not by
line 10590-->    Fortune fall into the fire? Though Nature hath given us wit to
line 10591-->    flout at Fortune, hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off
line 10592-->    the argument?
line 10593-->  ROSALIND. Indeed, there is Fortune too hard for Nature, when
line 10594-->    Fortune makes Nature's natural the cutter-off of Nature's wit.
line 10595-->  CELIA. Peradventure this is not Fortune's work neither, but
line 10596-->    Nature's, who perceiveth our natural wits too dull to reason of
line 10597-->    such goddesses, and hath sent this natural for our whetstone; for
line 10598-->    always the dullness of the fool is the whetstone of the wits. How
line 10599-->    now, wit! Whither wander you?
line 10600-->  TOUCHSTONE. Mistress, you must come away to your father.
line 10601-->  CELIA. Were you made the messenger?
line 10602-->  TOUCHSTONE. No, by mine honour; but I was bid to come for you.
line 10603-->  ROSALIND. Where learned you that oath, fool?
line 10604-->  TOUCHSTONE. Of a certain knight that swore by his honour they were
line 10605-->    good pancakes, and swore by his honour the mustard was naught.
line 10606-->    Now I'll stand to it, the pancakes were naught and the mustard  
line 10607-->    was good, and yet was not the knight forsworn.
line 10608-->  CELIA. How prove you that, in the great heap of your knowledge?
line 10609-->  ROSALIND. Ay, marry, now unmuzzle your wisdom.
line 10610-->  TOUCHSTONE. Stand you both forth now: stroke your chins, and swear
line 10611-->    by your beards that I am a knave.
line 10612-->  CELIA. By our beards, if we had them, thou art.
line 10613-->  TOUCHSTONE. By my knavery, if I had it, then I were. But if you
line 10614-->    swear by that that not, you are not forsworn; no more was this
line 10615-->    knight, swearing by his honour, for he never had any; or if he
line 10616-->    had, he had sworn it away before ever he saw those pancackes or
line 10617-->    that mustard.
line 10618-->  CELIA. Prithee, who is't that thou mean'st?
line 10619-->  TOUCHSTONE. One that old Frederick, your father, loves.
line 10620-->  CELIA. My father's love is enough to honour him. Enough, speak no
line 10621-->    more of him; you'll be whipt for taxation one of these days.
line 10622-->  TOUCHSTONE. The more pity that fools may not speak wisely what wise
line 10623-->    men do foolishly.
line 10624-->  CELIA. By my troth, thou sayest true; for since the little wit that
line 10625-->    fools have was silenced, the little foolery that wise men have
line 10626-->    makes a great show. Here comes Monsieur Le Beau.  
line 10627-->
line 10628-->                           Enter LE BEAU
line 10629-->
line 10630-->  ROSALIND. With his mouth full of news.
line 10631-->  CELIA. Which he will put on us as pigeons feed their young.
line 10632-->  ROSALIND. Then shall we be news-cramm'd.
line 10633-->  CELIA. All the better; we shall be the more marketable. Bon jour,
line 10634-->    Monsieur Le Beau. What's the news?
line 10635-->  LE BEAU. Fair Princess, you have lost much good sport.
line 10636-->  CELIA. Sport! of what colour?
line 10637-->  LE BEAU. What colour, madam? How shall I answer you?
line 10638-->  ROSALIND. As wit and fortune will.
line 10639-->  TOUCHSTONE. Or as the Destinies decrees.
line 10640-->  CELIA. Well said; that was laid on with a trowel.
line 10641-->  TOUCHSTONE. Nay, if I keep not my rank-
line 10642-->  ROSALIND. Thou losest thy old smell.
line 10643-->  LE BEAU. You amaze me, ladies. I would have told you of good
line 10644-->    wrestling, which you have lost the sight of.
line 10645-->  ROSALIND. Yet tell us the manner of the wrestling.
line 10646-->  LE BEAU. I will tell you the beginning, and, if it please your  
line 10647-->    ladyships, you may see the end; for the best is yet to do; and
line 10648-->    here, where you are, they are coming to perform it.
line 10649-->  CELIA. Well, the beginning, that is dead and buried.
line 10650-->  LE BEAU. There comes an old man and his three sons-
line 10651-->  CELIA. I could match this beginning with an old tale.
line 10652-->  LE BEAU. Three proper young men, of excellent growth and presence.
line 10653-->  ROSALIND. With bills on their necks: 'Be it known unto all men by
line 10654-->    these presents'-
line 10655-->  LE BEAU. The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, the Duke's
line 10656-->    wrestler; which Charles in a moment threw him, and broke three of
line 10657-->    his ribs, that there is little hope of life in him. So he serv'd
line 10658-->    the second, and so the third. Yonder they lie; the poor old man,
line 10659-->    their father, making such pitiful dole over them that all the
line 10660-->    beholders take his part with weeping.
line 10661-->  ROSALIND. Alas!
line 10662-->  TOUCHSTONE. But what is the sport, monsieur, that the ladies have
line 10663-->    lost?
line 10664-->  LE BEAU. Why, this that I speak of.
line 10665-->  TOUCHSTONE. Thus men may grow wiser every day. It is the first time
line 10666-->    that ever I heard breaking of ribs was sport for ladies.  
line 10667-->  CELIA. Or I, I promise thee.
line 10668-->  ROSALIND. But is there any else longs to see this broken music in
line 10669-->    his sides? Is there yet another dotes upon rib-breaking? Shall we
line 10670-->    see this wrestling, cousin?
line 10671-->  LE BEAU. You must, if you stay here; for here is the place
line 10672-->    appointed for the wrestling, and they are ready to perform it.
line 10673-->  CELIA. Yonder, sure, they are coming. Let us now stay and see it.
line 10674-->
line 10675-->           Flourish. Enter DUKE FREDERICK, LORDS, ORLANDO,
line 10676-->                     CHARLES, and ATTENDANTS
line 10677-->
line 10678-->  FREDERICK. Come on; since the youth will not be entreated, his own
line 10679-->    peril on his forwardness.
line 10680-->  ROSALIND. Is yonder the man?
line 10681-->  LE BEAU. Even he, madam.
line 10682-->  CELIA. Alas, he is too young; yet he looks successfully.
line 10683-->  FREDERICK. How now, daughter and cousin! Are you crept hither to
line 10684-->    see the wrestling?
line 10685-->  ROSALIND. Ay, my liege; so please you give us leave.
line 10686-->  FREDERICK. You will take little delight in it, I can tell you,  
line 10687-->    there is such odds in the man. In pity of the challenger's youth
line 10688-->    I would fain dissuade him, but he will not be entreated. Speak to
line 10689-->    him, ladies; see if you can move him.
line 10690-->  CELIA. Call him hither, good Monsieur Le Beau.
line 10691-->  FREDERICK. Do so; I'll not be by.
line 10692-->                                     [DUKE FREDERICK goes apart]
line 10693-->  LE BEAU. Monsieur the Challenger, the Princess calls for you.
line 10694-->  ORLANDO. I attend them with all respect and duty.
line 10695-->  ROSALIND. Young man, have you challeng'd Charles the wrestler?
line 10696-->  ORLANDO. No, fair Princess; he is the general challenger. I come
line 10697-->    but in, as others do, to try with him the strength of my youth.
line 10698-->  CELIA. Young gentleman, your spirits are too bold for your years.
line 10699-->    You have seen cruel proof of this man's strength; if you saw
line 10700-->    yourself with your eyes, or knew yourself with your judgment, the
line 10701-->    fear of your adventure would counsel you to a more equal
line 10702-->    enterprise. We pray you, for your own sake, to embrace your own
line 10703-->    safety and give over this attempt.
line 10704-->  ROSALIND. Do, young sir; your reputation shall not therefore be
line 10705-->    misprised: we will make it our suit to the Duke that the
line 10706-->    wrestling might not go forward.  
line 10707-->  ORLANDO. I beseech you, punish me not with your hard thoughts,
line 10708-->    wherein I confess me much guilty to deny so fair and excellent
line 10709-->    ladies any thing. But let your fair eyes and gentle wishes go
line 10710-->    with me to my trial; wherein if I be foil'd there is but one
line 10711-->    sham'd that was never gracious; if kill'd, but one dead that is
line 10712-->    willing to be so. I shall do my friends no wrong, for I have none
line 10713-->    to lament me; the world no injury, for in it I have nothing; only
line 10714-->    in the world I fill up a place, which may be better supplied when
line 10715-->    I have made it empty.
line 10716-->  ROSALIND. The little strength that I have, I would it were with
line 10717-->    you.
line 10718-->  CELIA. And mine to eke out hers.
line 10719-->  ROSALIND. Fare you well. Pray heaven I be deceiv'd in you!
line 10720-->  CELIA. Your heart's desires be with you!
line 10721-->  CHARLES. Come, where is this young gallant that is so desirous to
line 10722-->    lie with his mother earth?
line 10723-->  ORLANDO. Ready, sir; but his will hath in it a more modest working.
line 10724-->  FREDERICK. You shall try but one fall.
line 10725-->  CHARLES. No, I warrant your Grace, you shall not entreat him to a
line 10726-->    second, that have so mightily persuaded him from a first.  
line 10727-->  ORLANDO. You mean to mock me after; you should not have mock'd me
line 10728-->    before; but come your ways.
line 10729-->  ROSALIND. Now, Hercules be thy speed, young man!
line 10730-->  CELIA. I would I were invisible, to catch the strong fellow by the
line 10731-->    leg.                                          [They wrestle]
line 10732-->  ROSALIND. O excellent young man!
line 10733-->  CELIA. If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye, I can tell who should
line 10734-->    down.
line 10735-->                                      [CHARLES is thrown. Shout]
line 10736-->  FREDERICK. No more, no more.
line 10737-->  ORLANDO. Yes, I beseech your Grace; I am not yet well breath'd.
line 10738-->  FREDERICK. How dost thou, Charles?
line 10739-->  LE BEAU. He cannot speak, my lord.
line 10740-->  FREDERICK. Bear him away. What is thy name, young man?
line 10741-->  ORLANDO. Orlando, my liege; the youngest son of Sir Rowland de
line 10742-->    Boys.
line 10743-->  FREDERICK. I would thou hadst been son to some man else.
line 10744-->    The world esteem'd thy father honourable,
line 10745-->    But I did find him still mine enemy.
line 10746-->    Thou shouldst have better pleas'd me with this deed,  
line 10747-->    Hadst thou descended from another house.
line 10748-->    But fare thee well; thou art a gallant youth;
line 10749-->    I would thou hadst told me of another father.
line 10750-->                                 Exeunt DUKE, train, and LE BEAU
line 10751-->  CELIA. Were I my father, coz, would I do this?
line 10752-->  ORLANDO. I am more proud to be Sir Rowland's son,
line 10753-->    His youngest son- and would not change that calling
line 10754-->    To be adopted heir to Frederick.
line 10755-->  ROSALIND. My father lov'd Sir Rowland as his soul,
line 10756-->    And all the world was of my father's mind;
line 10757-->    Had I before known this young man his son,
line 10758-->    I should have given him tears unto entreaties
line 10759-->    Ere he should thus have ventur'd.
line 10760-->  CELIA. Gentle cousin,
line 10761-->    Let us go thank him, and encourage him;
line 10762-->    My father's rough and envious disposition
line 10763-->    Sticks me at heart. Sir, you have well deserv'd;
line 10764-->    If you do keep your promises in love
line 10765-->    But justly as you have exceeded all promise,
line 10766-->    Your mistress shall be happy.  
line 10767-->  ROSALIND. Gentleman,        [Giving him a chain from her neck]
line 10768-->    Wear this for me; one out of suits with fortune,
line 10769-->    That could give more, but that her hand lacks means.
line 10770-->    Shall we go, coz?
line 10771-->  CELIA. Ay. Fare you well, fair gentleman.
line 10772-->  ORLANDO. Can I not say 'I thank you'? My better parts
line 10773-->    Are all thrown down; and that which here stands up
line 10774-->    Is but a quintain, a mere lifeless block.
line 10775-->  ROSALIND. He calls us back. My pride fell with my fortunes;
line 10776-->    I'll ask him what he would. Did you call, sir?
line 10777-->    Sir, you have wrestled well, and overthrown
line 10778-->    More than your enemies.
line 10779-->  CELIA. Will you go, coz?
line 10780-->  ROSALIND. Have with you. Fare you well.
line 10781-->                                       Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA
line 10782-->  ORLANDO. What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue?
line 10783-->    I cannot speak to her, yet she urg'd conference.
line 10784-->    O poor Orlando, thou art overthrown!
line 10785-->    Or Charles or something weaker masters thee.
line 10786-->  
line 10787-->                      Re-enter LE BEAU
line 10788-->
line 10789-->  LE BEAU. Good sir, I do in friendship counsel you
line 10790-->    To leave this place. Albeit you have deserv'd
line 10791-->    High commendation, true applause, and love,
line 10792-->    Yet such is now the Duke's condition
line 10793-->    That he misconstrues all that you have done.
line 10794-->    The Duke is humorous; what he is, indeed,
line 10795-->    More suits you to conceive than I to speak of.
line 10796-->  ORLANDO. I thank you, sir; and pray you tell me this:
line 10797-->    Which of the two was daughter of the Duke
line 10798-->    That here was at the wrestling?
line 10799-->  LE BEAU. Neither his daughter, if we judge by manners;
line 10800-->    But yet, indeed, the smaller is his daughter;
line 10801-->    The other is daughter to the banish'd Duke,
line 10802-->    And here detain'd by her usurping uncle,
line 10803-->    To keep his daughter company; whose loves
line 10804-->    Are dearer than the natural bond of sisters.
line 10805-->    But I can tell you that of late this Duke
line 10806-->    Hath ta'en displeasure 'gainst his gentle niece,  
line 10807-->    Grounded upon no other argument
line 10808-->    But that the people praise her for her virtues
line 10809-->    And pity her for her good father's sake;
line 10810-->    And, on my life, his malice 'gainst the lady
line 10811-->    Will suddenly break forth. Sir, fare you well.
line 10812-->    Hereafter, in a better world than this,
line 10813-->    I shall desire more love and knowledge of you.
line 10814-->  ORLANDO. I rest much bounden to you; fare you well.
line 10815-->                                                    Exit LE BEAU
line 10816-->    Thus must I from the smoke into the smother;
line 10817-->    From tyrant Duke unto a tyrant brother.
line 10818-->    But heavenly Rosalind!                                  Exit
line 10819-->
line 10820-->
line 10821-->
line 10822-->
line 10823-->SCENE III.
line 10824-->The DUKE's palace
line 10825-->
line 10826-->Enter CELIA and ROSALIND
line 10827-->
line 10828-->  CELIA. Why, cousin! why, Rosalind! Cupid have mercy!
line 10829-->    Not a word?
line 10830-->  ROSALIND. Not one to throw at a dog.
line 10831-->  CELIA. No, thy words are too precious to be cast away upon curs;
line 10832-->    throw some of them at me; come, lame me with reasons.
line 10833-->  ROSALIND. Then there were two cousins laid up, when the one should
line 10834-->    be lam'd with reasons and the other mad without any.
line 10835-->  CELIA. But is all this for your father?
line 10836-->  ROSALIND. No, some of it is for my child's father. O, how full of
line 10837-->    briers is this working-day world!
line 10838-->  CELIA. They are but burs, cousin, thrown upon thee in holiday
line 10839-->    foolery; if we walk not in the trodden paths, our very petticoats
line 10840-->    will catch them.
line 10841-->  ROSALIND. I could shake them off my coat: these burs are in my
line 10842-->    heart.
line 10843-->  CELIA. Hem them away.
line 10844-->  ROSALIND. I would try, if I could cry 'hem' and have him.  
line 10845-->  CELIA. Come, come, wrestle with thy affections.
line 10846-->  ROSALIND. O, they take the part of a better wrestler than myself.
line 10847-->  CELIA. O, a good wish upon you! You will try in time, in despite of
line 10848-->    a fall. But, turning these jests out of service, let us talk in
line 10849-->    good earnest. Is it possible, on such a sudden, you should fall
line 10850-->    into so strong a liking with old Sir Rowland's youngest son?
line 10851-->  ROSALIND. The Duke my father lov'd his father dearly.
line 10852-->  CELIA. Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his son dearly?
line 10853-->    By this kind of chase I should hate him, for my father hated his
line 10854-->    father dearly; yet I hate not Orlando.
line 10855-->  ROSALIND. No, faith, hate him not, for my sake.
line 10856-->  CELIA. Why should I not? Doth he not deserve well?
line 10857-->
line 10858-->                    Enter DUKE FREDERICK, with LORDS
line 10859-->
line 10860-->  ROSALIND. Let me love him for that; and do you love him because I
line 10861-->    do. Look, here comes the Duke.
line 10862-->  CELIA. With his eyes full of anger.
line 10863-->  FREDERICK. Mistress, dispatch you with your safest haste,
line 10864-->    And get you from our court.  
line 10865-->  ROSALIND. Me, uncle?
line 10866-->  FREDERICK. You, cousin.
line 10867-->    Within these ten days if that thou beest found
line 10868-->    So near our public court as twenty miles,
line 10869-->    Thou diest for it.
line 10870-->  ROSALIND. I do beseech your Grace,
line 10871-->    Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me.
line 10872-->    If with myself I hold intelligence,
line 10873-->    Or have acquaintance with mine own desires;
line 10874-->    If that I do not dream, or be not frantic-
line 10875-->    As I do trust I am not- then, dear uncle,
line 10876-->    Never so much as in a thought unborn
line 10877-->    Did I offend your Highness.
line 10878-->  FREDERICK. Thus do all traitors;
line 10879-->    If their purgation did consist in words,
line 10880-->    They are as innocent as grace itself.
line 10881-->    Let it suffice thee that I trust thee not.
line 10882-->  ROSALIND. Yet your mistrust cannot make me a traitor.
line 10883-->    Tell me whereon the likelihood depends.
line 10884-->  FREDERICK. Thou art thy father's daughter; there's enough.  
line 10885-->  ROSALIND. SO was I when your Highness took his dukedom;
line 10886-->    So was I when your Highness banish'd him.
line 10887-->    Treason is not inherited, my lord;
line 10888-->    Or, if we did derive it from our friends,
line 10889-->    What's that to me? My father was no traitor.
line 10890-->    Then, good my liege, mistake me not so much
line 10891-->    To think my poverty is treacherous.
line 10892-->  CELIA. Dear sovereign, hear me speak.
line 10893-->  FREDERICK. Ay, Celia; we stay'd her for your sake,
line 10894-->    Else had she with her father rang'd along.
line 10895-->  CELIA. I did not then entreat to have her stay;
line 10896-->    It was your pleasure, and your own remorse;
line 10897-->    I was too young that time to value her,
line 10898-->    But now I know her. If she be a traitor,
line 10899-->    Why so am I: we still have slept together,
line 10900-->    Rose at an instant, learn'd, play'd, eat together;
line 10901-->    And wheresoe'er we went, like Juno's swans,
line 10902-->    Still we went coupled and inseparable.
line 10903-->  FREDERICK. She is too subtle for thee; and her smoothness,
line 10904-->    Her very silence and her patience,  
line 10905-->    Speak to the people, and they pity her.
line 10906-->    Thou art a fool. She robs thee of thy name;
line 10907-->    And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous
line 10908-->    When she is gone. Then open not thy lips.
line 10909-->    Firm and irrevocable is my doom
line 10910-->    Which I have pass'd upon her; she is banish'd.
line 10911-->  CELIA. Pronounce that sentence, then, on me, my liege;
line 10912-->    I cannot live out of her company.
line 10913-->  FREDERICK. You are a fool. You, niece, provide yourself.
line 10914-->    If you outstay the time, upon mine honour,
line 10915-->    And in the greatness of my word, you die.
line 10916-->                                           Exeunt DUKE and LORDS
line 10917-->  CELIA. O my poor Rosalind! Whither wilt thou go?
line 10918-->    Wilt thou change fathers? I will give thee mine.
line 10919-->    I charge thee be not thou more griev'd than I am.
line 10920-->  ROSALIND. I have more cause.
line 10921-->  CELIA. Thou hast not, cousin.
line 10922-->    Prithee be cheerful. Know'st thou not the Duke
line 10923-->    Hath banish'd me, his daughter?
line 10924-->  ROSALIND. That he hath not.  
line 10925-->  CELIA. No, hath not? Rosalind lacks, then, the love
line 10926-->    Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one.
line 10927-->    Shall we be sund'red? Shall we part, sweet girl?
line 10928-->    No; let my father seek another heir.
line 10929-->    Therefore devise with me how we may fly,
line 10930-->    Whither to go, and what to bear with us;
line 10931-->    And do not seek to take your charge upon you,
line 10932-->    To bear your griefs yourself, and leave me out;
line 10933-->    For, by this heaven, now at our sorrows pale,
line 10934-->    Say what thou canst, I'll go along with thee.
line 10935-->  ROSALIND. Why, whither shall we go?
line 10936-->  CELIA. To seek my uncle in the Forest of Arden.
line 10937-->  ROSALIND. Alas, what danger will it be to us,
line 10938-->    Maids as we are, to travel forth so far!
line 10939-->    Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.
line 10940-->  CELIA. I'll put myself in poor and mean attire,
line 10941-->    And with a kind of umber smirch my face;
line 10942-->    The like do you; so shall we pass along,
line 10943-->    And never stir assailants.
line 10944-->  ROSALIND. Were it not better,  
line 10945-->    Because that I am more than common tall,
line 10946-->    That I did suit me all points like a man?
line 10947-->    A gallant curtle-axe upon my thigh,
line 10948-->    A boar spear in my hand; and- in my heart
line 10949-->    Lie there what hidden woman's fear there will-
line 10950-->    We'll have a swashing and a martial outside,
line 10951-->    As many other mannish cowards have
line 10952-->    That do outface it with their semblances.
line 10953-->  CELIA. What shall I call thee when thou art a man?
line 10954-->  ROSALIND. I'll have no worse a name than Jove's own page,
line 10955-->    And therefore look you call me Ganymede.
line 10956-->    But what will you be call'd?
line 10957-->  CELIA. Something that hath a reference to my state:
line 10958-->    No longer Celia, but Aliena.
line 10959-->  ROSALIND. But, cousin, what if we assay'd to steal
line 10960-->    The clownish fool out of your father's court?
line 10961-->    Would he not be a comfort to our travel?
line 10962-->  CELIA. He'll go along o'er the wide world with me;
line 10963-->    Leave me alone to woo him. Let's away,
line 10964-->    And get our jewels and our wealth together;  
line 10965-->    Devise the fittest time and safest way
line 10966-->    To hide us from pursuit that will be made
line 10967-->    After my flight. Now go we in content
line 10968-->    To liberty, and not to banishment.                    Exeunt
line 10969-->
line 10970-->
line 10971-->

line 10981-->
line 10982-->
line 10983-->
line 10984-->ACT II. SCENE I.
line 10985-->The Forest of Arden
line 10986-->
line 10987-->Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and two or three LORDS, like foresters
line 10988-->
line 10989-->  DUKE SENIOR. Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile,
line 10990-->    Hath not old custom made this life more sweet
line 10991-->    Than that of painted pomp? Are not these woods
line 10992-->    More free from peril than the envious court?
line 10993-->    Here feel we not the penalty of Adam,
line 10994-->    The seasons' difference; as the icy fang
line 10995-->    And churlish chiding of the winter's wind,
line 10996-->    Which when it bites and blows upon my body,
line 10997-->    Even till I shrink with cold, I smile and say
line 10998-->    'This is no flattery; these are counsellors
line 10999-->    That feelingly persuade me what I am.'
line 11000-->    Sweet are the uses of adversity,
line 11001-->    Which, like the toad, ugly and venomous,
line 11002-->    Wears yet a precious jewel in his head;
line 11003-->    And this our life, exempt from public haunt,
line 11004-->    Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks,  
line 11005-->    Sermons in stones, and good in everything.
line 11006-->    I would not change it.
line 11007-->  AMIENS. Happy is your Grace,
line 11008-->    That can translate the stubbornness of fortune
line 11009-->    Into so quiet and so sweet a style.
line 11010-->  DUKE SENIOR. Come, shall we go and kill us venison?
line 11011-->    And yet it irks me the poor dappled fools,
line 11012-->    Being native burghers of this desert city,
line 11013-->    Should, in their own confines, with forked heads
line 11014-->    Have their round haunches gor'd.
line 11015-->  FIRST LORD. Indeed, my lord,
line 11016-->    The melancholy Jaques grieves at that;
line 11017-->    And, in that kind, swears you do more usurp
line 11018-->    Than doth your brother that hath banish'd you.
line 11019-->    To-day my Lord of Amiens and myself
line 11020-->    Did steal behind him as he lay along
line 11021-->    Under an oak whose antique root peeps out
line 11022-->    Upon the brook that brawls along this wood!
line 11023-->    To the which place a poor sequest'red stag,
line 11024-->    That from the hunter's aim had ta'en a hurt,  
line 11025-->    Did come to languish; and, indeed, my lord,
line 11026-->    The wretched animal heav'd forth such groans
line 11027-->    That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat
line 11028-->    Almost to bursting; and the big round tears
line 11029-->    Cours'd one another down his innocent nose
line 11030-->    In piteous chase; and thus the hairy fool,
line 11031-->    Much marked of the melancholy Jaques,
line 11032-->    Stood on th' extremest verge of the swift brook,
line 11033-->    Augmenting it with tears.
line 11034-->  DUKE SENIOR. But what said Jaques?
line 11035-->    Did he not moralize this spectacle?
line 11036-->  FIRST LORD. O, yes, into a thousand similes.
line 11037-->    First, for his weeping into the needless stream:
line 11038-->    'Poor deer,' quoth he 'thou mak'st a testament
line 11039-->    As worldlings do, giving thy sum of more
line 11040-->    To that which had too much.' Then, being there alone,
line 11041-->    Left and abandoned of his velvet friends:
line 11042-->    ''Tis right'; quoth he 'thus misery doth part
line 11043-->    The flux of company.' Anon, a careless herd,
line 11044-->    Full of the pasture, jumps along by him  
line 11045-->    And never stays to greet him. 'Ay,' quoth Jaques
line 11046-->    'Sweep on, you fat and greasy citizens;
line 11047-->    'Tis just the fashion. Wherefore do you look
line 11048-->    Upon that poor and broken bankrupt there?'
line 11049-->    Thus most invectively he pierceth through
line 11050-->    The body of the country, city, court,
line 11051-->    Yea, and of this our life; swearing that we
line 11052-->    Are mere usurpers, tyrants, and what's worse,
line 11053-->    To fright the animals, and to kill them up
line 11054-->    In their assign'd and native dwelling-place.
line 11055-->  DUKE SENIOR. And did you leave him in this contemplation?
line 11056-->  SECOND LORD. We did, my lord, weeping and commenting
line 11057-->    Upon the sobbing deer.
line 11058-->  DUKE SENIOR. Show me the place;
line 11059-->    I love to cope him in these sullen fits,
line 11060-->    For then he's full of matter.
line 11061-->  FIRST LORD. I'll bring you to him straight.             Exeunt
line 11062-->
line 11063-->
line 11064-->
line 11065-->
line 11066-->SCENE II.
line 11067-->The DUKE'S palace
line 11068-->
line 11069-->Enter DUKE FREDERICK, with LORDS
line 11070-->
line 11071-->  FREDERICK. Can it be possible that no man saw them?
line 11072-->    It cannot be; some villains of my court
line 11073-->    Are of consent and sufferance in this.
line 11074-->  FIRST LORD. I cannot hear of any that did see her.
line 11075-->    The ladies, her attendants of her chamber,
line 11076-->    Saw her abed, and in the morning early
line 11077-->    They found the bed untreasur'd of their mistress.
line 11078-->  SECOND LORD. My lord, the roynish clown, at whom so oft
line 11079-->    Your Grace was wont to laugh, is also missing.
line 11080-->    Hisperia, the Princess' gentlewoman,
line 11081-->    Confesses that she secretly o'erheard
line 11082-->    Your daughter and her cousin much commend
line 11083-->    The parts and graces of the wrestler
line 11084-->    That did but lately foil the sinewy Charles;
line 11085-->    And she believes, wherever they are gone,
line 11086-->    That youth is surely in their company.
line 11087-->  FREDERICK. Send to his brother; fetch that gallant hither.  
line 11088-->    If he be absent, bring his brother to me;
line 11089-->    I'll make him find him. Do this suddenly;
line 11090-->    And let not search and inquisition quail
line 11091-->    To bring again these foolish runaways.                Exeunt
line 11092-->
line 11093-->
line 11094-->
line 11095-->
line 11096-->SCENE III.
line 11097-->Before OLIVER'S house
line 11098-->
line 11099-->Enter ORLANDO and ADAM, meeting
line 11100-->
line 11101-->  ORLANDO. Who's there?
line 11102-->  ADAM. What, my young master? O my gentle master!
line 11103-->    O my sweet master! O you memory
line 11104-->    Of old Sir Rowland! Why, what make you here?
line 11105-->    Why are you virtuous? Why do people love you?
line 11106-->    And wherefore are you gentle, strong, and valiant?
line 11107-->    Why would you be so fond to overcome
line 11108-->    The bonny prizer of the humorous Duke?
line 11109-->    Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.
line 11110-->    Know you not, master, to some kind of men
line 11111-->    Their graces serve them but as enemies?
line 11112-->    No more do yours. Your virtues, gentle master,
line 11113-->    Are sanctified and holy traitors to you.
line 11114-->    O, what a world is this, when what is comely
line 11115-->    Envenoms him that bears it!
line 11116-->  ORLANDO. Why, what's the matter?
line 11117-->  ADAM. O unhappy youth!  
line 11118-->    Come not within these doors; within this roof
line 11119-->    The enemy of all your graces lives.
line 11120-->    Your brother- no, no brother; yet the son-
line 11121-->    Yet not the son; I will not call him son
line 11122-->    Of him I was about to call his father-
line 11123-->    Hath heard your praises; and this night he means
line 11124-->    To burn the lodging where you use to lie,
line 11125-->    And you within it. If he fail of that,
line 11126-->    He will have other means to cut you off;
line 11127-->    I overheard him and his practices.
line 11128-->    This is no place; this house is but a butchery;
line 11129-->    Abhor it, fear it, do not enter it.
line 11130-->  ORLANDO. Why, whither, Adam, wouldst thou have me go?
line 11131-->  ADAM. No matter whither, so you come not here.
line 11132-->  ORLANDO. What, wouldst thou have me go and beg my food,
line 11133-->    Or with a base and boist'rous sword enforce
line 11134-->    A thievish living on the common road?
line 11135-->    This I must do, or know not what to do;
line 11136-->    Yet this I will not do, do how I can.
line 11137-->    I rather will subject me to the malice  
line 11138-->    Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.
line 11139-->  ADAM. But do not so. I have five hundred crowns,
line 11140-->    The thrifty hire I sav'd under your father,
line 11141-->    Which I did store to be my foster-nurse,
line 11142-->    When service should in my old limbs lie lame,
line 11143-->    And unregarded age in corners thrown.
line 11144-->    Take that, and He that doth the ravens feed,
line 11145-->    Yea, providently caters for the sparrow,
line 11146-->    Be comfort to my age! Here is the gold;
line 11147-->    All this I give you. Let me be your servant;
line 11148-->    Though I look old, yet I am strong and lusty;
line 11149-->    For in my youth I never did apply
line 11150-->    Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood,
line 11151-->    Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo
line 11152-->    The means of weakness and debility;
line 11153-->    Therefore my age is as a lusty winter,
line 11154-->    Frosty, but kindly. Let me go with you;
line 11155-->    I'll do the service of a younger man
line 11156-->    In all your business and necessities.
line 11157-->  ORLANDO. O good old man, how well in thee appears  
line 11158-->    The constant service of the antique world,
line 11159-->    When service sweat for duty, not for meed!
line 11160-->    Thou art not for the fashion of these times,
line 11161-->    Where none will sweat but for promotion,
line 11162-->    And having that do choke their service up
line 11163-->    Even with the having; it is not so with thee.
line 11164-->    But, poor old man, thou prun'st a rotten tree
line 11165-->    That cannot so much as a blossom yield
line 11166-->    In lieu of all thy pains and husbandry.
line 11167-->    But come thy ways, we'll go along together,
line 11168-->    And ere we have thy youthful wages spent
line 11169-->    We'll light upon some settled low content.
line 11170-->  ADAM. Master, go on; and I will follow the
line 11171-->    To the last gasp, with truth and loyalty.
line 11172-->    From seventeen years till now almost four-score
line 11173-->    Here lived I, but now live here no more.
line 11174-->    At seventeen years many their fortunes seek,
line 11175-->    But at fourscore it is too late a week;
line 11176-->    Yet fortune cannot recompense me better
line 11177-->    Than to die well and not my master's debtor.          Exeunt
line 11178-->
line 11179-->
line 11180-->
line 11181-->
line 11182-->SCENE IV.
line 11183-->The Forest of Arden
line 11184-->
line 11185-->Enter ROSALIND for GANYMEDE, CELIA for ALIENA, and CLOWN alias TOUCHSTONE
line 11186-->
line 11187-->  ROSALIND. O Jupiter, how weary are my spirits!
line 11188-->  TOUCHSTONE. I Care not for my spirits, if my legs were not weary.
line 11189-->  ROSALIND. I could find in my heart to disgrace my man's apparel,
line 11190-->    and to cry like a woman; but I must comfort the weaker vessel, as
line 11191-->    doublet and hose ought to show itself courageous to petticoat;
line 11192-->    therefore, courage, good Aliena.
line 11193-->  CELIA. I pray you bear with me; I cannot go no further.
line 11194-->  TOUCHSTONE. For my part, I had rather bear with you than bear you;
line 11195-->    yet I should bear no cross if I did bear you; for I think you
line 11196-->    have no money in your purse.
line 11197-->  ROSALIND. Well,. this is the Forest of Arden.
line 11198-->  TOUCHSTONE. Ay, now am I in Arden; the more fool I; when I was at
line 11199-->    home I was in a better place; but travellers must be content.
line 11200-->
line 11201-->                        Enter CORIN and SILVIUS
line 11202-->  
line 11203-->  ROSALIND. Ay, be so, good Touchstone. Look you, who comes here, a
line 11204-->    young man and an old in solemn talk.
line 11205-->  CORIN. That is the way to make her scorn you still.
line 11206-->  SILVIUS. O Corin, that thou knew'st how I do love her!
line 11207-->  CORIN. I partly guess; for I have lov'd ere now.
line 11208-->  SILVIUS. No, Corin, being old, thou canst not guess,
line 11209-->    Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover
line 11210-->    As ever sigh'd upon a midnight pillow.
line 11211-->    But if thy love were ever like to mine,
line 11212-->    As sure I think did never man love so,
line 11213-->    How many actions most ridiculous
line 11214-->    Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?
line 11215-->  CORIN. Into a thousand that I have forgotten.
line 11216-->  SILVIUS. O, thou didst then never love so heartily!
line 11217-->    If thou rememb'rest not the slightest folly
line 11218-->    That ever love did make thee run into,
line 11219-->    Thou hast not lov'd;
line 11220-->    Or if thou hast not sat as I do now,
line 11221-->    Wearing thy hearer in thy mistress' praise,
line 11222-->    Thou hast not lov'd;  
line 11223-->    Or if thou hast not broke from company
line 11224-->    Abruptly, as my passion now makes me,
line 11225-->    Thou hast not lov'd.
line 11226-->    O Phebe, Phebe, Phebe!                          Exit Silvius
line 11227-->  ROSALIND. Alas, poor shepherd! searching of thy wound,
line 11228-->    I have by hard adventure found mine own.
line 11229-->  TOUCHSTONE. And I mine. I remember, when I was in love, I broke my
line 11230-->    sword upon a stone, and bid him take that for coming a-night to
line 11231-->    Jane Smile; and I remember the kissing of her batler, and the
line 11232-->    cow's dugs that her pretty chopt hands had milk'd; and I remember
line 11233-->    the wooing of  peascod instead of her; from whom I took two cods,
line 11234-->    and giving her them again, said with weeping tears 'Wear these
line 11235-->    for my sake.' We that are true lovers run into strange capers;
line 11236-->    but as all is mortal in nature, so is all nature in love mortal
line 11237-->    in folly.
line 11238-->  ROSALIND. Thou speak'st wiser than thou art ware of.
line 11239-->  TOUCHSTONE. Nay, I shall ne'er be ware of mine own wit till I break
line 11240-->    my shins against it.
line 11241-->  ROSALIND. Jove, Jove! this shepherd's passion
line 11242-->    Is much upon my fashion.  
line 11243-->  TOUCHSTONE. And mine; but it grows something stale with me.
line 11244-->  CELIA. I pray you, one of you question yond man
line 11245-->    If he for gold will give us any food;
line 11246-->    I faint almost to death.
line 11247-->  TOUCHSTONE. Holla, you clown!
line 11248-->  ROSALIND. Peace, fool; he's not thy Ensman.
line 11249-->  CORIN. Who calls?
line 11250-->  TOUCHSTONE. Your betters, sir.
line 11251-->  CORIN. Else are they very wretched.
line 11252-->  ROSALIND. Peace, I say. Good even to you, friend.
line 11253-->  CORIN. And to you, gentle sir, and to you all.
line 11254-->  ROSALIND. I prithee, shepherd, if that love or gold
line 11255-->    Can in this desert place buy entertainment,
line 11256-->    Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed.
line 11257-->    Here's a young maid with travel much oppress'd,
line 11258-->    And faints for succour.
line 11259-->  CORIN. Fair sir, I pity her,
line 11260-->    And wish, for her sake more than for mine own,
line 11261-->    My fortunes were more able to relieve her;
line 11262-->    But I am shepherd to another man,  
line 11263-->    And do not shear the fleeces that I graze.
line 11264-->    My master is of churlish disposition,
line 11265-->    And little recks to find the way to heaven
line 11266-->    By doing deeds of hospitality.
line 11267-->    Besides, his cote, his flocks, and bounds of feed,
line 11268-->    Are now on sale; and at our sheepcote now,
line 11269-->    By reason of his absence, there is nothing
line 11270-->    That you will feed on; but what is, come see,
line 11271-->    And in my voice most welcome shall you be.
line 11272-->  ROSALIND. What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture?
line 11273-->  CORIN. That young swain that you saw here but erewhile,
line 11274-->    That little cares for buying any thing.
line 11275-->  ROSALIND. I pray thee, if it stand with honesty,
line 11276-->    Buy thou the cottage, pasture, and the flock,
line 11277-->    And thou shalt have to pay for it of us.
line 11278-->  CELIA. And we will mend thy wages. I like this place,
line 11279-->    And willingly could waste my time in it.
line 11280-->  CORIN. Assuredly the thing is to be sold.
line 11281-->    Go with me; if you like upon report
line 11282-->    The soil, the profit, and this kind of life,  
line 11283-->    I will your very faithful feeder be,
line 11284-->    And buy it with your gold right suddenly.             Exeunt
line 11285-->
line 11286-->
line 11287-->
line 11288-->
line 11289-->SCENE V.
line 11290-->Another part of the forest
line 11291-->
line 11292-->Enter AMIENS, JAQUES, and OTHERS
line 11293-->
line 11294-->                       SONG
line 11295-->  AMIENS.    Under the greenwood tree
line 11296-->               Who loves to lie with me,
line 11297-->               And turn his merry note
line 11298-->               Unto the sweet bird's throat,
line 11299-->             Come hither, come hither, come hither.
line 11300-->               Here shall he see
line 11301-->               No enemy
line 11302-->             But winter and rough weather.
line 11303-->
line 11304-->  JAQUES. More, more, I prithee, more.
line 11305-->  AMIENS. It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.
line 11306-->  JAQUES. I thank it. More, I prithee, more. I can suck melancholy
line 11307-->    out of a song, as a weasel sucks eggs. More, I prithee, more.
line 11308-->  AMIENS. My voice is ragged; I know I cannot please you.
line 11309-->  JAQUES. I do not desire you to please me; I do desire you to sing.
line 11310-->    Come, more; another stanzo. Call you 'em stanzos?  
line 11311-->  AMIENS. What you will, Monsieur Jaques.
line 11312-->  JAQUES. Nay, I care not for their names; they owe me nothing. Will
line 11313-->    you sing?
line 11314-->  AMIENS. More at your request than to please myself.
line 11315-->  JAQUES. Well then, if ever I thank any man, I'll thank you; but
line 11316-->    that they call compliment is like th' encounter of two dog-apes;
line 11317-->    and when a man thanks me heartily, methinks have given him a
line 11318-->    penny, and he renders me the beggarly thanks. Come, sing; and you
line 11319-->    that will not, hold your tongues.
line 11320-->  AMIENS. Well, I'll end the song. Sirs, cover the while; the Duke
line 11321-->    will drink under this tree. He hath been all this day to look
line 11322-->    you.
line 11323-->  JAQUES. And I have been all this day to avoid him. He is to
line 11324-->    disputable for my company. I think of as many matters as he; but
line 11325-->    I give heaven thanks, and make no boast of them. Come, warble,
line 11326-->    come.
line 11327-->
line 11328-->                       SONG
line 11329-->              [All together here]
line 11330-->  
line 11331-->           Who doth ambition shun,
line 11332-->           And loves to live i' th' sun,
line 11333-->           Seeking the food he eats,
line 11334-->           And pleas'd with what he gets,
line 11335-->         Come hither, come hither, come hither.
line 11336-->           Here shall he see
line 11337-->           No enemy
line 11338-->           But winter and rough weather.
line 11339-->
line 11340-->  JAQUES. I'll give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in
line 11341-->    despite of my invention.
line 11342-->  AMIENS. And I'll sing it.
line 11343-->  JAQUES. Thus it goes:
line 11344-->
line 11345-->             If it do come to pass
line 11346-->             That any man turn ass,
line 11347-->             Leaving his wealth and ease
line 11348-->             A stubborn will to please,
line 11349-->           Ducdame, ducdame, ducdame;
line 11350-->             Here shall he see  
line 11351-->             Gross fools as he,
line 11352-->             An if he will come to me.
line 11353-->
line 11354-->  AMIENS. What's that 'ducdame'?
line 11355-->  JAQUES. 'Tis a Greek invocation, to call fools into a circle. I'll
line 11356-->    go sleep, if I can; if I cannot, I'll rail against all the
line 11357-->    first-born of Egypt.
line 11358-->  AMIENS. And I'll go seek the Duke; his banquet is prepar'd.
line 11359-->                                                Exeunt severally
line 11360-->
line 11361-->
line 11362-->
line 11363-->
line 11364-->SCENE VI.
line 11365-->The forest
line 11366-->
line 11367-->Enter ORLANDO and ADAM
line 11368-->
line 11369-->  ADAM. Dear master, I can go no further. O, I die for food! Here lie
line 11370-->    I down, and measure out my grave. Farewell, kind master.
line 11371-->  ORLANDO. Why, how now, Adam! No greater heart in thee? Live a
line 11372-->    little; comfort a little; cheer thyself a little. If this uncouth
line 11373-->    forest yield anything savage, I will either be food for it or
line 11374-->    bring it for food to thee. Thy conceit is nearer death than thy
line 11375-->    powers. For my sake be comfortable; hold death awhile at the
line 11376-->    arm's end. I will here be with the presently; and if I bring thee
line 11377-->    not something to eat, I will give thee leave to die; but if thou
line 11378-->    diest before I come, thou art a mocker of my labour. Well said!
line 11379-->    thou look'st cheerly; and I'll be with thee quickly. Yet thou
line 11380-->    liest in the bleak air. Come, I will bear thee to some shelter;
line 11381-->    and thou shalt not die for lack of a dinner, if there live
line 11382-->    anything in this desert. Cheerly, good Adam!          Exeunt
line 11383-->
line 11384-->
line 11385-->
line 11386-->
line 11387-->SCENE VII.
line 11388-->The forest
line 11389-->
line 11390-->A table set out. Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and LORDS, like outlaws
line 11391-->
line 11392-->  DUKE SENIOR. I think he be transform'd into a beast;
line 11393-->    For I can nowhere find him like a man.
line 11394-->  FIRST LORD. My lord, he is but even now gone hence;
line 11395-->    Here was he merry, hearing of a song.
line 11396-->  DUKE SENIOR. If he, compact of jars, grow musical,
line 11397-->    We shall have shortly discord in the spheres.
line 11398-->    Go seek him; tell him I would speak with him.
line 11399-->
line 11400-->                         Enter JAQUES
line 11401-->
line 11402-->  FIRST LORD. He saves my labour by his own approach.
line 11403-->  DUKE SENIOR. Why, how now, monsieur! what a life is this,
line 11404-->    That your poor friends must woo your company?
line 11405-->    What, you look merrily!
line 11406-->  JAQUES. A fool, a fool! I met a fool i' th' forest,
line 11407-->    A motley fool. A miserable world!  
line 11408-->    As I do live by food, I met a fool,
line 11409-->    Who laid him down and bask'd him in the sun,
line 11410-->    And rail'd on Lady Fortune in good terms,
line 11411-->    In good set terms- and yet a motley fool.
line 11412-->    'Good morrow, fool,' quoth I; 'No, sir,' quoth he,
line 11413-->    'Call me not fool till heaven hath sent me fortune.'
line 11414-->    And then he drew a dial from his poke,
line 11415-->    And, looking on it with lack-lustre eye,
line 11416-->    Says very wisely, 'It is ten o'clock;
line 11417-->    Thus we may see,' quoth he, 'how the world wags;
line 11418-->    'Tis but an hour ago since it was nine;
line 11419-->    And after one hour more 'twill be eleven;
line 11420-->    And so, from hour to hour, we ripe and ripe,
line 11421-->    And then, from hour to hour, we rot and rot;
line 11422-->    And thereby hangs a tale.' When I did hear
line 11423-->    The motley fool thus moral on the time,
line 11424-->    My lungs began to crow like chanticleer
line 11425-->    That fools should be so deep contemplative;
line 11426-->    And I did laugh sans intermission
line 11427-->    An hour by his dial. O noble fool!  
line 11428-->    A worthy fool! Motley's the only wear.
line 11429-->  DUKE SENIOR. What fool is this?
line 11430-->  JAQUES. O worthy fool! One that hath been a courtier,
line 11431-->    And says, if ladies be but young and fair,
line 11432-->    They have the gift to know it; and in his brain,
line 11433-->    Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit
line 11434-->    After a voyage, he hath strange places cramm'd
line 11435-->    With observation, the which he vents
line 11436-->    In mangled forms. O that I were a fool!
line 11437-->    I am ambitious for a motley coat.
line 11438-->  DUKE SENIOR. Thou shalt have one.
line 11439-->  JAQUES. It is my only suit,
line 11440-->    Provided that you weed your better judgments
line 11441-->    Of all opinion that grows rank in them
line 11442-->    That I am wise. I must have liberty
line 11443-->    Withal, as large a charter as the wind,
line 11444-->    To blow on whom I please, for so fools have;
line 11445-->    And they that are most galled with my folly,
line 11446-->    They most must laugh. And why, sir, must they so?
line 11447-->    The why is plain as way to parish church:  
line 11448-->    He that a fool doth very wisely hit
line 11449-->    Doth very foolishly, although he smart,
line 11450-->    Not to seem senseless of the bob; if not,
line 11451-->    The wise man's folly is anatomiz'd
line 11452-->    Even by the squand'ring glances of the fool.
line 11453-->    Invest me in my motley; give me leave
line 11454-->    To speak my mind, and I will through and through
line 11455-->    Cleanse the foul body of th' infected world,
line 11456-->    If they will patiently receive my medicine.
line 11457-->  DUKE SENIOR. Fie on thee! I can tell what thou wouldst do.
line 11458-->  JAQUES. What, for a counter, would I do but good?
line 11459-->  DUKE SENIOR. Most Mischievous foul sin, in chiding sin;
line 11460-->    For thou thyself hast been a libertine,
line 11461-->    As sensual as the brutish sting itself;
line 11462-->    And all th' embossed sores and headed evils
line 11463-->    That thou with license of free foot hast caught
line 11464-->    Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.
line 11465-->  JAQUES. Why, who cries out on pride
line 11466-->    That can therein tax any private party?
line 11467-->    Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea,  
line 11468-->    Till that the wearer's very means do ebb?
line 11469-->    What woman in the city do I name
line 11470-->    When that I say the city-woman bears
line 11471-->    The cost of princes on unworthy shoulders?
line 11472-->    Who can come in and say that I mean her,
line 11473-->    When such a one as she such is her neighbour?
line 11474-->    Or what is he of basest function
line 11475-->    That says his bravery is not on my cost,
line 11476-->    Thinking that I mean him, but therein suits
line 11477-->    His folly to the mettle of my speech?
line 11478-->    There then! how then? what then? Let me see wherein
line 11479-->    My tongue hath wrong'd him: if it do him right,
line 11480-->    Then he hath wrong'd himself; if he be free,
line 11481-->    Why then my taxing like a wild-goose flies,
line 11482-->    Unclaim'd of any man. But who comes here?
line 11483-->
line 11484-->             Enter ORLANDO with his sword drawn
line 11485-->
line 11486-->  ORLANDO. Forbear, and eat no more.
line 11487-->  JAQUES. Why, I have eat none yet.  
line 11488-->  ORLANDO. Nor shalt not, till necessity be serv'd.
line 11489-->  JAQUES. Of what kind should this cock come of?
line 11490-->  DUKE SENIOR. Art thou thus bolden'd, man, by thy distress?
line 11491-->    Or else a rude despiser of good manners,
line 11492-->    That in civility thou seem'st so empty?
line 11493-->  ORLANDO. You touch'd my vein at first: the thorny point
line 11494-->    Of bare distress hath ta'en from me the show
line 11495-->    Of smooth civility; yet arn I inland bred,
line 11496-->    And know some nurture. But forbear, I say;
line 11497-->    He dies that touches any of this fruit
line 11498-->    Till I and my affairs are answered.
line 11499-->  JAQUES. An you will not be answer'd with reason, I must die.
line 11500-->  DUKE SENIOR. What would you have? Your gentleness shall force
line 11501-->    More than your force move us to gentleness.
line 11502-->  ORLANDO. I almost die for food, and let me have it.
line 11503-->  DUKE SENIOR. Sit down and feed, and welcome to our table.
line 11504-->  ORLANDO. Speak you so gently? Pardon me, I pray you;
line 11505-->    I thought that all things had been savage here,
line 11506-->    And therefore put I on the countenance
line 11507-->    Of stern commandment. But whate'er you are  
line 11508-->    That in this desert inaccessible,
line 11509-->    Under the shade of melancholy boughs,
line 11510-->    Lose and neglect the creeping hours of time;
line 11511-->    If ever you have look'd on better days,
line 11512-->    If ever been where bells have knoll'd to church,
line 11513-->    If ever sat at any good man's feast,
line 11514-->    If ever from your eyelids wip'd a tear,
line 11515-->    And know what 'tis to pity and be pitied,
line 11516-->    Let gentleness my strong enforcement be;
line 11517-->    In the which hope I blush, and hide my sword.
line 11518-->  DUKE SENIOR. True is it that we have seen better days,
line 11519-->    And have with holy bell been knoll'd to church,
line 11520-->    And sat at good men's feasts, and wip'd our eyes
line 11521-->    Of drops that sacred pity hath engend'red;
line 11522-->    And therefore sit you down in gentleness,
line 11523-->    And take upon command what help we have
line 11524-->    That to your wanting may be minist'red.
line 11525-->  ORLANDO. Then but forbear your food a little while,
line 11526-->    Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn,
line 11527-->    And give it food. There is an old poor man  
line 11528-->    Who after me hath many a weary step
line 11529-->    Limp'd in pure love; till he be first suffic'd,
line 11530-->    Oppress'd with two weak evils, age and hunger,
line 11531-->    I will not touch a bit.
line 11532-->  DUKE SENIOR. Go find him out.
line 11533-->    And we will nothing waste till you return.
line 11534-->  ORLANDO. I thank ye; and be blest for your good comfort!
line 11535--> Exit
line 11536-->  DUKE SENIOR. Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy:
line 11537-->    This wide and universal theatre
line 11538-->    Presents more woeful pageants than the scene
line 11539-->    Wherein we play in.
line 11540-->  JAQUES. All the world's a stage,
line 11541-->    And all the men and women merely players;
line 11542-->    They have their exits and their entrances;
line 11543-->    And one man in his time plays many parts,
line 11544-->    His acts being seven ages. At first the infant,
line 11545-->    Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms;
line 11546-->    Then the whining school-boy, with his satchel
line 11547-->    And shining morning face, creeping like snail  
line 11548-->    Unwillingly to school. And then the lover,
line 11549-->    Sighing like furnace, with a woeful ballad
line 11550-->    Made to his mistress' eyebrow. Then a soldier,
line 11551-->    Full of strange oaths, and bearded like the pard,
line 11552-->    Jealous in honour, sudden and quick in quarrel,
line 11553-->    Seeking the bubble reputation
line 11554-->    Even in the cannon's mouth. And then the justice,
line 11555-->    In fair round belly with good capon lin'd,
line 11556-->    With eyes severe and beard of formal cut,
line 11557-->    Full of wise saws and modern instances;
line 11558-->    And so he plays his part. The sixth age shifts
line 11559-->    Into the lean and slipper'd pantaloon,
line 11560-->    With spectacles on nose and pouch on side,
line 11561-->    His youthful hose, well sav'd, a world too wide
line 11562-->    For his shrunk shank; and his big manly voice,
line 11563-->    Turning again toward childish treble, pipes
line 11564-->    And whistles in his sound. Last scene of all,
line 11565-->    That ends this strange eventful history,
line 11566-->    Is second childishness and mere oblivion;
line 11567-->    Sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans every thing.  
line 11568-->
line 11569-->                  Re-enter ORLANDO with ADAM
line 11570-->
line 11571-->  DUKE SENIOR. Welcome. Set down your venerable burden.
line 11572-->    And let him feed.
line 11573-->  ORLANDO. I thank you most for him.
line 11574-->  ADAM. So had you need;
line 11575-->    I scarce can speak to thank you for myself.
line 11576-->  DUKE SENIOR. Welcome; fall to. I will not trouble you
line 11577-->    As yet to question you about your fortunes.
line 11578-->    Give us some music; and, good cousin, sing.
line 11579-->
line 11580-->                         SONG
line 11581-->            Blow, blow, thou winter wind,
line 11582-->            Thou art not so unkind
line 11583-->              As man's ingratitude;
line 11584-->            Thy tooth is not so keen,
line 11585-->            Because thou art not seen,
line 11586-->              Although thy breath be rude.
line 11587-->    Heigh-ho! sing heigh-ho! unto the green holly.  
line 11588-->    Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly.
line 11589-->            Then, heigh-ho, the holly!
line 11590-->              This life is most jolly.
line 11591-->
line 11592-->            Freeze, freeze, thou bitter sky,
line 11593-->            That dost not bite so nigh
line 11594-->              As benefits forgot;
line 11595-->            Though thou the waters warp,
line 11596-->            Thy sting is not so sharp
line 11597-->              As friend rememb'red not.
line 11598-->    Heigh-ho! sing, &c.
line 11599-->
line 11600-->  DUKE SENIOR. If that you were the good Sir Rowland's son,
line 11601-->    As you have whisper'd faithfully you were,
line 11602-->    And as mine eye doth his effigies witness
line 11603-->    Most truly limn'd and living in your face,
line 11604-->    Be truly welcome hither. I am the Duke
line 11605-->    That lov'd your father. The residue of your fortune,
line 11606-->    Go to my cave and tell me. Good old man,
line 11607-->    Thou art right welcome as thy master is.  
line 11608-->    Support him by the arm. Give me your hand,
line 11609-->    And let me all your fortunes understand.              Exeunt
line 11610-->
line 11611-->
line 11612-->
line 11613-->
line 11614-->ACT III. SCENE I.
line 11615-->The palace
line 11616-->
line 11617-->Enter DUKE FREDERICK, OLIVER, and LORDS
line 11618-->
line 11619-->  FREDERICK. Not see him since! Sir, sir, that cannot be.
line 11620-->    But were I not the better part made mercy,
line 11621-->    I should not seek an absent argument
line 11622-->    Of my revenge, thou present. But look to it:
line 11623-->    Find out thy brother wheresoe'er he is;
line 11624-->    Seek him with candle; bring him dead or living
line 11625-->    Within this twelvemonth, or turn thou no more
line 11626-->    To seek a living in our territory.
line 11627-->    Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine
line 11628-->    Worth seizure do we seize into our hands,
line 11629-->    Till thou canst quit thee by thy brother's mouth
line 11630-->    Of what we think against thee.
line 11631-->  OLIVER. O that your Highness knew my heart in this!
line 11632-->    I never lov'd my brother in my life.
line 11633-->  FREDERICK. More villain thou. Well, push him out of doors;
line 11634-->    And let my officers of such a nature
line 11635-->    Make an extent upon his house and lands.  
line 11636-->    Do this expediently, and turn him going.              Exeunt
line 11637-->
line 11638-->
line 11639-->
line 11640-->
line 11641-->SCENE II.
line 11642-->The forest
line 11643-->
line 11644-->Enter ORLANDO, with a paper
line 11645-->
line 11646-->  ORLANDO. Hang there, my verse, in witness of my love;
line 11647-->    And thou, thrice-crowned Queen of Night, survey
line 11648-->    With thy chaste eye, from thy pale sphere above,
line 11649-->    Thy huntress' name that my full life doth sway.
line 11650-->    O Rosalind! these trees shall be my books,
line 11651-->    And in their barks my thoughts I'll character,
line 11652-->    That every eye which in this forest looks
line 11653-->    Shall see thy virtue witness'd every where.
line 11654-->    Run, run, Orlando; carve on every tree,
line 11655-->    The fair, the chaste, and unexpressive she.             Exit
line 11656-->
line 11657-->                     Enter CORIN and TOUCHSTONE
line 11658-->
line 11659-->  CORIN. And how like you this shepherd's life, Master Touchstone?
line 11660-->  TOUCHSTONE. Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a good
line 11661-->    life; but in respect that it is a shepherd's life, it is nought.
line 11662-->    In respect that it is solitary, I like it very well; but in  
line 11663-->    respect that it is private, it is a very vile life. Now in
line 11664-->    respect it is in the fields, it pleaseth me well; but in respect
line 11665-->    it is not in the court, it is tedious. As it is a spare life,
line 11666-->    look you, it fits my humour well; but as there is no more plenty
line 11667-->    in it, it goes much against my stomach. Hast any philosophy in
line 11668-->    thee, shepherd?
line 11669-->  CORIN. No more but that I know the more one sickens the worse at
line 11670-->    ease he is; and that he that wants money, means, and content, is
line 11671-->    without three good friends; that the property of rain is to wet,
line 11672-->    and fire to burn; that good pasture makes fat sheep; and that a
line 11673-->    great cause of the night is lack of the sun; that he that hath
line 11674-->    learned no wit by nature nor art may complain of good breeding,
line 11675-->    or comes of a very dull kindred.
line 11676-->  TOUCHSTONE. Such a one is a natural philosopher. Wast ever in
line 11677-->    court, shepherd?
line 11678-->  CORIN. No, truly.
line 11679-->  TOUCHSTONE. Then thou art damn'd.
line 11680-->  CORIN. Nay, I hope.
line 11681-->  TOUCHSTONE. Truly, thou art damn'd, like an ill-roasted egg, all on
line 11682-->    one side.  
line 11683-->  CORIN. For not being at court? Your reason.
line 11684-->  TOUCHSTONE. Why, if thou never wast at court thou never saw'st good
line 11685-->    manners; if thou never saw'st good manners, then thy manners must
line 11686-->    be wicked; and wickedness is sin, and sin is damnation. Thou art
line 11687-->    in a parlous state, shepherd.
line 11688-->  CORIN. Not a whit, Touchstone. Those that are good manners at the
line 11689-->    court are as ridiculous in the country as the behaviour of the
line 11690-->    country is most mockable at the court. You told me you salute not
line 11691-->    at the court, but you kiss your hands; that courtesy would be
line 11692-->    uncleanly if courtiers were shepherds.
line 11693-->  TOUCHSTONE. Instance, briefly; come, instance.
line 11694-->  CORIN. Why, we are still handling our ewes; and their fells, you
line 11695-->    know, are greasy.
line 11696-->  TOUCHSTONE. Why, do not your courtier's hands sweat? And is not the
line 11697-->    grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of a man? Shallow,
line 11698-->    shallow. A better instance, I say; come.
line 11699-->  CORIN. Besides, our hands are hard.
line 11700-->  TOUCHSTONE. Your lips will feel them the sooner. Shallow again. A
line 11701-->    more sounder instance; come.
line 11702-->  CORIN. And they are often tarr'd over with the surgery of our  
line 11703-->    sheep; and would you have us kiss tar? The courtier's hands are
line 11704-->    perfum'd with civet.
line 11705-->  TOUCHSTONE. Most shallow man! thou worm's meat in respect of a good
line 11706-->    piece of flesh indeed! Learn of the wise, and perpend: civet is
line 11707-->    of a baser birth than tar- the very uncleanly flux of a cat. Mend
line 11708-->    the instance, shepherd.
line 11709-->  CORIN. You have too courtly a wit for me; I'll rest.
line 11710-->  TOUCHSTONE. Wilt thou rest damn'd? God help thee, shallow man! God
line 11711-->    make incision in thee! thou art raw.
line 11712-->  CORIN. Sir, I am a true labourer: I earn that I eat, get that I
line 11713-->    wear; owe no man hate, envy no man's happiness; glad of other
line 11714-->    men's good, content with my harm; and the greatest of my pride is
line 11715-->    to see my ewes graze and my lambs suck.
line 11716-->  TOUCHSTONE. That is another simple sin in you: to bring the ewes
line 11717-->    and the rams together, and to offer to get your living by the
line 11718-->    copulation of cattle; to be bawd to a bell-wether, and to betray
line 11719-->    a she-lamb of a twelvemonth to crooked-pated, old, cuckoldly ram,
line 11720-->    out of all reasonable match. If thou beest not damn'd for this,
line 11721-->    the devil himself will have no shepherds; I cannot see else how
line 11722-->    thou shouldst scape.  
line 11723-->  CORIN. Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new mistress's brother.
line 11724-->
line 11725-->                  Enter ROSALIND, reading a paper
line 11726-->
line 11727-->  ROSALIND.   'From the east to western Inde,
line 11728-->              No jewel is like Rosalinde.
line 11729-->              Her worth, being mounted on the wind,
line 11730-->              Through all the world bears Rosalinde.
line 11731-->              All the pictures fairest lin'd
line 11732-->              Are but black to Rosalinde.
line 11733-->              Let no face be kept in mind
line 11734-->              But the fair of Rosalinde.'
line 11735-->  TOUCHSTONE. I'll rhyme you so eight years together, dinners, and
line 11736-->    suppers, and sleeping hours, excepted. It is the right
line 11737-->    butter-women's rank to market.
line 11738-->  ROSALIND. Out, fool!
line 11739-->  TOUCHSTONE.   For a taste:
line 11740-->                If a hart do lack a hind,
line 11741-->                Let him seek out Rosalinde.
line 11742-->                If the cat will after kind,  
line 11743-->                So be sure will Rosalinde.
line 11744-->                Winter garments must be lin'd,
line 11745-->                So must slender Rosalinde.
line 11746-->                They that reap must sheaf and bind,
line 11747-->                Then to cart with Rosalinde.
line 11748-->                Sweetest nut hath sourest rind,
line 11749-->                Such a nut is Rosalinde.
line 11750-->                He that sweetest rose will find
line 11751-->                Must find love's prick and Rosalinde.
line 11752-->    This is the very false gallop of verses; why do you infect
line 11753-->    yourself with them?
line 11754-->  ROSALIND. Peace, you dull fool! I found them on a tree.
line 11755-->  TOUCHSTONE. Truly, the tree yields bad fruit.
line 11756-->  ROSALIND. I'll graff it with you, and then I shall graff it with a
line 11757-->    medlar. Then it will be the earliest fruit i' th' country; for
line 11758-->    you'll be rotten ere you be half ripe, and that's the right
line 11759-->    virtue of the medlar.
line 11760-->  TOUCHSTONE. You have said; but whether wisely or no, let the forest
line 11761-->    judge.
line 11762-->  
line 11763-->                      Enter CELIA, with a writing
line 11764-->
line 11765-->  ROSALIND. Peace!
line 11766-->    Here comes my sister, reading; stand aside.
line 11767-->  CELIA.   'Why should this a desert be?
line 11768-->             For it is unpeopled? No;
line 11769-->           Tongues I'll hang on every tree
line 11770-->             That shall civil sayings show.
line 11771-->           Some, how brief the life of man
line 11772-->             Runs his erring pilgrimage,
line 11773-->           That the streching of a span
line 11774-->             Buckles in his sum of age;
line 11775-->           Some, of violated vows
line 11776-->             'Twixt the souls of friend and friend;
line 11777-->           But upon the fairest boughs,
line 11778-->             Or at every sentence end,
line 11779-->           Will I Rosalinda write,
line 11780-->             Teaching all that read to know
line 11781-->           The quintessence of every sprite
line 11782-->             Heaven would in little show.  
line 11783-->           Therefore heaven Nature charg'd
line 11784-->             That one body should be fill'd
line 11785-->           With all graces wide-enlarg'd.
line 11786-->             Nature presently distill'd
line 11787-->           Helen's cheek, but not her heart,
line 11788-->             Cleopatra's majesty,
line 11789-->           Atalanta's better part,
line 11790-->             Sad Lucretia's modesty.
line 11791-->           Thus Rosalinde of many parts
line 11792-->             By heavenly synod was devis'd,
line 11793-->           Of many faces, eyes, and hearts,
line 11794-->             To have the touches dearest priz'd.
line 11795-->           Heaven would that she these gifts should have,
line 11796-->           And I to live and die her slave.'
line 11797-->  ROSALIND. O most gentle pulpiter! What tedious homily of love have
line 11798-->    you wearied your parishioners withal, and never cried 'Have
line 11799-->    patience, good people.'
line 11800-->  CELIA. How now! Back, friends; shepherd, go off a little; go with
line 11801-->    him, sirrah.
line 11802-->  TOUCHSTONE. Come, shepherd, let us make an honourable retreat;  
line 11803-->    though not with bag and baggage, yet with scrip and scrippage.
line 11804-->                                     Exeunt CORIN and TOUCHSTONE
line 11805-->  CELIA. Didst thou hear these verses?
line 11806-->  ROSALIND. O, yes, I heard them all, and more too; for some of them
line 11807-->    had in them more feet than the verses would bear.
line 11808-->  CELIA. That's no matter; the feet might bear the verses.
line 11809-->  ROSALIND. Ay, but the feet were lame, and could not bear themselves
line 11810-->    without the verse, and therefore stood lamely in the verse.
line 11811-->  CELIA. But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name should be
line 11812-->    hang'd and carved upon these trees?
line 11813-->  ROSALIND. I was seven of the nine days out of the wonder before you
line 11814-->    came; for look here what I found on a palm-tree. I was never so
line 11815-->    berhym'd since Pythagoras' time that I was an Irish rat, which I
line 11816-->    can hardly remember.
line 11817-->  CELIA. Trow you who hath done this?
line 11818-->  ROSALIND. Is it a man?
line 11819-->  CELIA. And a chain, that you once wore, about his neck.
line 11820-->    Change you colour?
line 11821-->  ROSALIND. I prithee, who?
line 11822-->  CELIA. O Lord, Lord! it is a hard matter for friends to meet; but  
line 11823-->    mountains may be remov'd with earthquakes, and so encounter.
line 11824-->  ROSALIND. Nay, but who is it?
line 11825-->  CELIA. Is it possible?
line 11826-->  ROSALIND. Nay, I prithee now, with most petitionary vehemence, tell
line 11827-->    me who it is.
line 11828-->  CELIA. O wonderful, wonderful, most wonderful wonderful, and yet
line 11829-->    again wonderful, and after that, out of all whooping!
line 11830-->  ROSALIND. Good my complexion! dost thou think, though I am
line 11831-->    caparison'd like a man, I have a doublet and hose in my
line 11832-->    disposition? One inch of delay more is a South Sea of discovery.
line 11833-->    I prithee tell me who is it quickly, and speak apace. I would
line 11834-->    thou could'st stammer, that thou mightst pour this conceal'd man
line 11835-->    out of thy mouth, as wine comes out of narrow-mouth'd bottle-
line 11836-->    either too much at once or none at all. I prithee take the cork
line 11837-->    out of thy mouth that I may drink thy tidings.
line 11838-->  CELIA. So you may put a man in your belly.
line 11839-->  ROSALIND. Is he of God's making? What manner of man?
line 11840-->    Is his head worth a hat or his chin worth a beard?
line 11841-->  CELIA. Nay, he hath but a little beard.
line 11842-->  ROSALIND. Why, God will send more if the man will be thankful. Let  
line 11843-->    me stay the growth of his beard, if thou delay me not the
line 11844-->    knowledge of his chin.
line 11845-->  CELIA. It is young Orlando, that tripp'd up the wrestler's heels
line 11846-->    and your heart both in an instant.
line 11847-->  ROSALIND. Nay, but the devil take mocking! Speak sad brow and true
line 11848-->    maid.
line 11849-->  CELIA. I' faith, coz, 'tis he.
line 11850-->  ROSALIND. Orlando?
line 11851-->  CELIA. Orlando.
line 11852-->  ROSALIND. Alas the day! what shall I do with my doublet and hose?
line 11853-->    What did he when thou saw'st him? What said he? How look'd he?
line 11854-->    Wherein went he? What makes he here? Did he ask for me? Where
line 11855-->    remains he? How parted he with thee? And when shalt thou see him
line 11856-->    again? Answer me in one word.
line 11857-->  CELIA. You must borrow me Gargantua's mouth first; 'tis a word too
line 11858-->    great for any mouth of this age's size. To say ay and no to these
line 11859-->    particulars is more than to answer in a catechism.
line 11860-->  ROSALIND. But doth he know that I am in this forest, and in man's
line 11861-->    apparel? Looks he as freshly as he did the day he wrestled?
line 11862-->  CELIA. It is as easy to count atomies as to resolve the  
line 11863-->    propositions of a lover; but take a taste of my finding him, and
line 11864-->    relish it with good observance. I found him under a tree, like a
line 11865-->    dropp'd acorn.
line 11866-->  ROSALIND. It may well be call'd Jove's tree, when it drops forth
line 11867-->    such fruit.
line 11868-->  CELIA. Give me audience, good madam.
line 11869-->  ROSALIND. Proceed.
line 11870-->  CELIA. There lay he, stretch'd along like a wounded knight.
line 11871-->  ROSALIND. Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well becomes
line 11872-->    the ground.
line 11873-->  CELIA. Cry 'Holla' to thy tongue, I prithee; it curvets
line 11874-->    unseasonably. He was furnish'd like a hunter.
line 11875-->  ROSALIND. O, ominous! he comes to kill my heart.
line 11876-->  CELIA. I would sing my song without a burden; thou bring'st me out
line 11877-->    of tune.
line 11878-->  ROSALIND. Do you not know I am a woman? When I think, I must speak.
line 11879-->    Sweet, say on.
line 11880-->  CELIA. You bring me out. Soft! comes he not here?
line 11881-->
line 11882-->                   Enter ORLANDO and JAQUES  
line 11883-->
line 11884-->  ROSALIND. 'Tis he; slink by, and note him.
line 11885-->  JAQUES. I thank you for your company; but, good faith, I had as
line 11886-->    lief have been myself alone.
line 11887-->  ORLANDO. And so had I; but yet, for fashion sake, I thank you too
line 11888-->    for your society.
line 11889-->  JAQUES. God buy you; let's meet as little as we can.
line 11890-->  ORLANDO. I do desire we may be better strangers.
line 11891-->  JAQUES. I pray you mar no more trees with writing love songs in
line 11892-->    their barks.
line 11893-->  ORLANDO. I pray you mar no more of my verses with reading them
line 11894-->    ill-favouredly.
line 11895-->  JAQUES. Rosalind is your love's name?
line 11896-->  ORLANDO. Yes, just.
line 11897-->  JAQUES. I do not like her name.
line 11898-->  ORLANDO. There was no thought of pleasing you when she was
line 11899-->    christen'd.
line 11900-->  JAQUES. What stature is she of?
line 11901-->  ORLANDO. Just as high as my heart.
line 11902-->  JAQUES. You are full of pretty answers. Have you not been  
line 11903-->    acquainted with goldsmiths' wives, and conn'd them out of rings?
line 11904-->  ORLANDO. Not so; but I answer you right painted cloth, from whence
line 11905-->    you have studied your questions.
line 11906-->  JAQUES. You have a nimble wit; I think 'twas made of Atalanta's
line 11907-->    heels. Will you sit down with me? and we two will rail against
line 11908-->    our mistress the world, and all our misery.
line 11909-->  ORLANDO. I will chide no breather in the world but myself, against
line 11910-->    whom I know most faults.
line 11911-->  JAQUES. The worst fault you have is to be in love.
line 11912-->  ORLANDO. 'Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue. I am
line 11913-->    weary of you.
line 11914-->  JAQUES. By my troth, I was seeking for a fool when I found you.
line 11915-->  ORLANDO. He is drown'd in the brook; look but in, and you shall see
line 11916-->    him.
line 11917-->  JAQUES. There I shall see mine own figure.
line 11918-->  ORLANDO. Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.
line 11919-->  JAQUES. I'll tarry no longer with you; farewell, good Signior Love.
line 11920-->  ORLANDO. I am glad of your departure; adieu, good Monsieur
line 11921-->    Melancholy.
line 11922-->                                                     Exit JAQUES  
line 11923-->  ROSALIND. [Aside to CELIA] I will speak to him like a saucy lackey,
line 11924-->    and under that habit play the knave with him.- Do you hear,
line 11925-->    forester?
line 11926-->  ORLANDO. Very well; what would you?
line 11927-->  ROSALIND. I pray you, what is't o'clock?
line 11928-->  ORLANDO. You should ask me what time o' day; there's no clock in
line 11929-->    the forest.
