line 11930-->  ROSALIND. Then there is no true lover in the forest, else sighing
line 11931-->    every minute and groaning every hour would detect the lazy foot
line 11932-->    of Time as well as a clock.
line 11933-->  ORLANDO. And why not the swift foot of Time? Had not that been as
line 11934-->    proper?
line 11935-->  ROSALIND. By no means, sir. Time travels in divers paces with
line 11936-->    divers persons. I'll tell you who Time ambles withal, who Time
line 11937-->    trots withal, who Time gallops withal, and who he stands still
line 11938-->    withal.
line 11939-->  ORLANDO. I prithee, who doth he trot withal?
line 11940-->  ROSALIND. Marry, he trots hard with a young maid between the
line 11941-->    contract of her marriage and the day it is solemniz'd; if the
line 11942-->    interim be but a se'nnight, Time's pace is so hard that it seems  
line 11943-->    the length of seven year.
line 11944-->  ORLANDO. Who ambles Time withal?
line 11945-->  ROSALIND. With a priest that lacks Latin and a rich man that hath
line 11946-->    not the gout; for the one sleeps easily because he cannot study,
line 11947-->    and the other lives merrily because he feels no pain; the one
line 11948-->    lacking the burden of lean and wasteful learning, the other
line 11949-->    knowing no burden of heavy tedious penury. These Time ambles
line 11950-->    withal.
line 11951-->  ORLANDO. Who doth he gallop withal?
line 11952-->  ROSALIND. With a thief to the gallows; for though he go as softly
line 11953-->    as foot can fall, he thinks himself too soon there.
line 11954-->  ORLANDO. Who stays it still withal?
line 11955-->  ROSALIND. With lawyers in the vacation; for they sleep between term
line 11956-->    and term, and then they perceive not how Time moves.
line 11957-->  ORLANDO. Where dwell you, pretty youth?
line 11958-->  ROSALIND. With this shepherdess, my sister; here in the skirts of
line 11959-->    the forest, like fringe upon a petticoat.
line 11960-->  ORLANDO. Are you native of this place?
line 11961-->  ROSALIND. As the coney that you see dwell where she is kindled.
line 11962-->  ORLANDO. Your accent is something finer than you could purchase in  
line 11963-->    so removed a dwelling.
line 11964-->  ROSALIND. I have been told so of many; but indeed an old religious
line 11965-->    uncle of mine taught me to speak, who was in his youth an inland
line 11966-->    man; one that knew courtship too well, for there he fell in love.
line 11967-->    I have heard him read many lectures against it; and I thank God I
line 11968-->    am not a woman, to be touch'd with so many giddy offences as he
line 11969-->    hath generally tax'd their whole sex withal.
line 11970-->  ORLANDO. Can you remember any of the principal evils that he laid
line 11971-->    to the charge of women?
line 11972-->  ROSALIND. There were none principal; they were all like one another
line 11973-->    as halfpence are; every one fault seeming monstrous till his
line 11974-->    fellow-fault came to match it.
line 11975-->  ORLANDO. I prithee recount some of them.
line 11976-->  ROSALIND. No; I will not cast away my physic but on those that are
line 11977-->    sick. There is a man haunts the forest that abuses our young
line 11978-->    plants with carving 'Rosalind' on their barks; hangs odes upon
line 11979-->    hawthorns and elegies on brambles; all, forsooth, deifying the
line 11980-->    name of Rosalind. If I could meet that fancy-monger, I would give
line 11981-->    him some good counsel, for he seems to have the quotidian of love
line 11982-->    upon him.  
line 11983-->  ORLANDO. I am he that is so love-shak'd; I pray you tell me your
line 11984-->    remedy.
line 11985-->  ROSALIND. There is none of my uncle's marks upon you; he taught me
line 11986-->    how to know a man in love; in which cage of rushes I am sure you
line 11987-->    are not prisoner.
line 11988-->  ORLANDO. What were his marks?
line 11989-->  ROSALIND. A lean cheek, which you have not; a blue eye and sunken,
line 11990-->    which you have not; an unquestionable spirit, which you have not;
line 11991-->    a beard neglected, which you have not; but I pardon you for that,
line 11992-->    for simply your having in beard is a younger brother's revenue.
line 11993-->    Then your hose should be ungarter'd, your bonnet unbanded, your
line 11994-->    sleeve unbutton'd, your shoe untied, and every thing about you
line 11995-->    demonstrating a careless desolation. But you are no such man; you
line 11996-->    are rather point-device in your accoutrements, as loving yourself
line 11997-->    than seeming the lover of any other.
line 11998-->  ORLANDO. Fair youth, I would I could make thee believe I love.
line 11999-->  ROSALIND. Me believe it! You may as soon make her that you love
line 12000-->    believe it; which, I warrant, she is apter to do than to confess
line 12001-->    she does. That is one of the points in the which women still give
line 12002-->    the lie to their consciences. But, in good sooth, are you he that  
line 12003-->    hangs the verses on the trees wherein Rosalind is so admired?
line 12004-->  ORLANDO. I swear to thee, youth, by the white hand of Rosalind, I
line 12005-->    am that he, that unfortunate he.
line 12006-->  ROSALIND. But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak?
line 12007-->  ORLANDO. Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much.
line 12008-->  ROSALIND. Love is merely a madness; and, I tell you, deserves as
line 12009-->    well a dark house and a whip as madmen do; and the reason why
line 12010-->    they are not so punish'd and cured is that the lunacy is so
line 12011-->    ordinary that the whippers are in love too. Yet I profess curing
line 12012-->    it by counsel.
line 12013-->  ORLANDO. Did you ever cure any so?
line 12014-->  ROSALIND. Yes, one; and in this manner. He was to imagine me his
line 12015-->    love, his mistress; and I set him every day to woo me; at which
line 12016-->    time would I, being but a moonish youth, grieve, be effeminate,
line 12017-->    changeable, longing and liking, proud, fantastical, apish,
line 12018-->    shallow, inconstant, full of tears, full of smiles; for every
line 12019-->    passion something and for no passion truly anything, as boys and
line 12020-->    women are for the most part cattle of this colour; would now like
line 12021-->    him, now loathe him; then entertain him, then forswear him; now
line 12022-->    weep for him, then spit at him; that I drave my suitor from his  
line 12023-->    mad humour of love to a living humour of madness; which was, to
line 12024-->    forswear the full stream of the world and to live in a nook
line 12025-->    merely monastic. And thus I cur'd him; and this way will I take
line 12026-->    upon me to wash your liver as clean as a sound sheep's heart,
line 12027-->    that there shall not be one spot of love in 't.
line 12028-->  ORLANDO. I would not be cured, youth.
line 12029-->  ROSALIND. I would cure you, if you would but call me Rosalind, and
line 12030-->    come every day to my cote and woo me.
line 12031-->  ORLANDO. Now, by the faith of my love, I will. Tell me where it is.
line 12032-->  ROSALIND. Go with me to it, and I'll show it you; and, by the way,
line 12033-->    you shall tell me where in the forest you live. Will you go?
line 12034-->  ORLANDO. With all my heart, good youth.
line 12035-->  ROSALIND. Nay, you must call me Rosalind. Come, sister, will you
line 12036-->    go?                                                   Exeunt
line 12037-->
line 12038-->
line 12039-->
line 12040-->
line 12041-->SCENE III.
line 12042-->The forest
line 12043-->
line 12044-->Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY; JAQUES behind
line 12045-->
line 12046-->  TOUCHSTONE. Come apace, good Audrey; I will fetch up your goats,
line 12047-->    Audrey. And how, Audrey, am I the man yet? Doth my simple feature
line 12048-->    content you?
line 12049-->  AUDREY. Your features! Lord warrant us! What features?
line 12050-->  TOUCHSTONE. I am here with thee and thy goats, as the most
line 12051-->    capricious poet, honest Ovid, was among the Goths.
line 12052-->  JAQUES. [Aside] O knowledge ill-inhabited, worse than Jove in a
line 12053-->    thatch'd house!
line 12054-->  TOUCHSTONE. When a man's verses cannot be understood, nor a man's
line 12055-->    good wit seconded with the forward child understanding, it
line 12056-->    strikes a man more dead than a great reckoning in a little room.
line 12057-->    Truly, I would the gods had made thee poetical.
line 12058-->  AUDREY. I do not know what 'poetical' is. Is it honest in deed and
line 12059-->    word? Is it a true thing?
line 12060-->  TOUCHSTONE. No, truly; for the truest poetry is the most feigning,
line 12061-->    and lovers are given to poetry; and what they swear in poetry may
line 12062-->    be said as lovers they do feign.  
line 12063-->  AUDREY. Do you wish, then, that the gods had made me poetical?
line 12064-->  TOUCHSTONE. I do, truly, for thou swear'st to me thou art honest;
line 12065-->    now, if thou wert a poet, I might have some hope thou didst
line 12066-->    feign.
line 12067-->  AUDREY. Would you not have me honest?
line 12068-->  TOUCHSTONE. No, truly, unless thou wert hard-favour'd; for honesty
line 12069-->    coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar.
line 12070-->  JAQUES. [Aside] A material fool!
line 12071-->  AUDREY. Well, I am not fair; and therefore I pray the gods make me
line 12072-->    honest.
line 12073-->  TOUCHSTONE. Truly, and to cast away honesty upon a foul slut were
line 12074-->    to put good meat into an unclean dish.
line 12075-->  AUDREY. I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul.
line 12076-->  TOUCHSTONE. Well, praised be the gods for thy foulness;
line 12077-->    sluttishness may come hereafter. But be it as it may be, I will
line 12078-->    marry thee; and to that end I have been with Sir Oliver Martext,
line 12079-->    the vicar of the next village, who hath promis'd to meet me in
line 12080-->    this place of the forest, and to couple us.
line 12081-->  JAQUES. [Aside] I would fain see this meeting.
line 12082-->  AUDREY. Well, the gods give us joy!  
line 12083-->  TOUCHSTONE. Amen. A man may, if he were of a fearful heart, stagger
line 12084-->    in this attempt; for here we have no temple but the wood, no
line 12085-->    assembly but horn-beasts. But what though? Courage! As horns are
line 12086-->    odious, they are necessary. It is said: 'Many a man knows no end
line 12087-->    of his goods.' Right! Many a man has good horns and knows no end
line 12088-->    of them. Well, that is the dowry of his wife; 'tis none of his
line 12089-->    own getting. Horns? Even so. Poor men alone? No, no; the noblest
line 12090-->    deer hath them as huge as the rascal. Is the single man therefore
line 12091-->    blessed? No; as a wall'd town is more worthier than a village, so
line 12092-->    is the forehead of a married man more honourable than the bare
line 12093-->    brow of a bachelor; and by how much defence is better than no
line 12094-->    skill, by so much is horn more precious than to want. Here comes
line 12095-->    Sir Oliver.
line 12096-->
line 12097-->                       Enter SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
line 12098-->
line 12099-->    Sir Oliver Martext, you are well met. Will you dispatch us here
line 12100-->    under this tree, or shall we go with you to your chapel?
line 12101-->  MARTEXT. Is there none here to give the woman?
line 12102-->  TOUCHSTONE. I will not take her on gift of any man.  
line 12103-->  MARTEXT. Truly, she must be given, or the marriage is not lawful.
line 12104-->  JAQUES. [Discovering himself] Proceed, proceed; I'll give her.
line 12105-->  TOUCHSTONE. Good even, good Master What-ye-call't; how do you, sir?
line 12106-->    You are very well met. Goddild you for your last company. I am
line 12107-->    very glad to see you. Even a toy in hand here, sir. Nay; pray be
line 12108-->    cover'd.
line 12109-->  JAQUES. Will you be married, motley?
line 12110-->  TOUCHSTONE. As the ox hath his bow, sir, the horse his curb, and
line 12111-->    the falcon her bells, so man hath his desires; and as pigeons
line 12112-->    bill, so wedlock would be nibbling.
line 12113-->  JAQUES. And will you, being a man of your breeding, be married
line 12114-->    under a bush, like a beggar? Get you to church and have a good
line 12115-->    priest that can tell you what marriage is; this fellow will but
line 12116-->    join you together as they join wainscot; then one of you will
line 12117-->    prove a shrunk panel, and like green timber warp, warp.
line 12118-->  TOUCHSTONE. [Aside] I am not in the mind but I were better to be
line 12119-->    married of him than of another; for he is not like to marry me
line 12120-->    well; and not being well married, it will be a good excuse for me
line 12121-->    hereafter to leave my wife.
line 12122-->  JAQUES. Go thou with me, and let me counsel thee.  
line 12123-->  TOUCHSTONE. Come, sweet Audrey;
line 12124-->    We must be married or we must live in bawdry.
line 12125-->    Farewell, good Master Oliver. Not-
line 12126-->               O sweet Oliver,
line 12127-->               O brave Oliver,
line 12128-->           Leave me not behind thee.
line 12129-->    But-
line 12130-->                 Wind away,
line 12131-->               Begone, I say,
line 12132-->           I will not to wedding with thee.
line 12133-->                           Exeunt JAQUES, TOUCHSTONE, and AUDREY
line 12134-->  MARTEXT. 'Tis no matter; ne'er a fantastical knave of them all
line 12135-->    shall flout me out of my calling.                       Exit
line 12136-->
line 12137-->
line 12138-->
line 12139-->
line 12140-->SCENE IV.
line 12141-->The forest
line 12142-->
line 12143-->Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
line 12144-->
line 12145-->  ROSALIND. Never talk to me; I will weep.
line 12146-->  CELIA. Do, I prithee; but yet have the grace to consider that tears
line 12147-->    do not become a man.
line 12148-->  ROSALIND. But have I not cause to weep?
line 12149-->  CELIA. As good cause as one would desire; therefore weep.
line 12150-->  ROSALIND. His very hair is of the dissembling colour.
line 12151-->  CELIA. Something browner than Judas's.
line 12152-->    Marry, his kisses are Judas's own children.
line 12153-->  ROSALIND. I' faith, his hair is of a good colour.
line 12154-->  CELIA. An excellent colour: your chestnut was ever the only colour.
line 12155-->  ROSALIND. And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of
line 12156-->    holy bread.
line 12157-->  CELIA. He hath bought a pair of cast lips of Diana. A nun of
line 12158-->    winter's sisterhood kisses not more religiously; the very ice of
line 12159-->    chastity is in them.
line 12160-->  ROSALIND. But why did he swear he would come this morning, and
line 12161-->    comes not?
line 12162-->  CELIA. Nay, certainly, there is no truth in him.  
line 12163-->  ROSALIND. Do you think so?
line 12164-->  CELIA. Yes; I think he is not a pick-purse nor a horse-stealer; but
line 12165-->    for his verity in love, I do think him as concave as covered
line 12166-->    goblet or a worm-eaten nut.
line 12167-->  ROSALIND. Not true in love?
line 12168-->  CELIA. Yes, when he is in; but I think he is not in.
line 12169-->  ROSALIND. You have heard him swear downright he was.
line 12170-->  CELIA. 'Was' is not 'is'; besides, the oath of a lover is no
line 12171-->    stronger than the word of a tapster; they are both the confirmer
line 12172-->    of false reckonings. He attends here in the forest on the Duke,
line 12173-->    your father.
line 12174-->  ROSALIND. I met the Duke yesterday, and had much question with him.
line 12175-->    He asked me of what parentage I was; I told him, of as good as
line 12176-->    he; so he laugh'd and let me go. But what talk we of fathers when
line 12177-->    there is such a man as Orlando?
line 12178-->  CELIA. O, that's a brave man! He writes brave verses, speaks brave
line 12179-->    words, swears brave oaths, and breaks them bravely, quite
line 12180-->    traverse, athwart the heart of his lover; as a puny tilter, that
line 12181-->    spurs his horse but on one side, breaks his staff like a noble
line 12182-->    goose. But all's brave that youth mounts and folly guides. Who  
line 12183-->    comes here?
line 12184-->
line 12185-->                         Enter CORIN
line 12186-->
line 12187-->  CORIN. Mistress and master, you have oft enquired
line 12188-->    After the shepherd that complain'd of love,
line 12189-->    Who you saw sitting by me on the turf,
line 12190-->    Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess
line 12191-->    That was his mistress.
line 12192-->  CELIA. Well, and what of him?
line 12193-->  CORIN. If you will see a pageant truly play'd
line 12194-->    Between the pale complexion of true love
line 12195-->    And the red glow of scorn and proud disdain,
line 12196-->    Go hence a little, and I shall conduct you,
line 12197-->    If you will mark it.
line 12198-->  ROSALIND. O, come, let us remove!
line 12199-->    The sight of lovers feedeth those in love.
line 12200-->    Bring us to this sight, and you shall say
line 12201-->    I'll prove a busy actor in their play.                Exeunt
line 12202-->
line 12203-->
line 12204-->
line 12205-->
line 12206-->SCENE V.
line 12207-->Another part of the forest
line 12208-->
line 12209-->Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE
line 12210-->
line 12211-->  SILVIUS. Sweet Phebe, do not scorn me; do not, Phebe.
line 12212-->    Say that you love me not; but say not so
line 12213-->    In bitterness. The common executioner,
line 12214-->    Whose heart th' accustom'd sight of death makes hard,
line 12215-->    Falls not the axe upon the humbled neck
line 12216-->    But first begs pardon. Will you sterner be
line 12217-->    Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops?
line 12218-->
line 12219-->          Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN, at a distance
line 12220-->
line 12221-->  PHEBE. I would not be thy executioner;
line 12222-->    I fly thee, for I would not injure thee.
line 12223-->    Thou tell'st me there is murder in mine eye.
line 12224-->    'Tis pretty, sure, and very probable,
line 12225-->    That eyes, that are the frail'st and softest things,
line 12226-->    Who shut their coward gates on atomies,
line 12227-->    Should be call'd tyrants, butchers, murderers!  
line 12228-->    Now I do frown on thee with all my heart;
line 12229-->    And if mine eyes can wound, now let them kill thee.
line 12230-->    Now counterfeit to swoon; why, now fall down;
line 12231-->    Or, if thou canst not, O, for shame, for shame,
line 12232-->    Lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers.
line 12233-->    Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee.
line 12234-->    Scratch thee but with a pin, and there remains
line 12235-->    Some scar of it; lean upon a rush,
line 12236-->    The cicatrice and capable impressure
line 12237-->    Thy palm some moment keeps; but now mine eyes,
line 12238-->    Which I have darted at thee, hurt thee not;
line 12239-->    Nor, I am sure, there is not force in eyes
line 12240-->    That can do hurt.
line 12241-->  SILVIUS. O dear Phebe,
line 12242-->    If ever- as that ever may be near-
line 12243-->    You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy,
line 12244-->    Then shall you know the wounds invisible
line 12245-->    That love's keen arrows make.
line 12246-->  PHEBE. But till that time
line 12247-->    Come not thou near me; and when that time comes,  
line 12248-->    Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not;
line 12249-->    As till that time I shall not pity thee.
line 12250-->  ROSALIND. [Advancing] And why, I pray you? Who might be your
line 12251-->      mother,
line 12252-->    That you insult, exult, and all at once,
line 12253-->    Over the wretched? What though you have no beauty-
line 12254-->    As, by my faith, I see no more in you
line 12255-->    Than without candle may go dark to bed-
line 12256-->    Must you be therefore proud and pitiless?
line 12257-->    Why, what means this? Why do you look on me?
line 12258-->    I see no more in you than in the ordinary
line 12259-->    Of nature's sale-work. 'Od's my little life,
line 12260-->    I think she means to tangle my eyes too!
line 12261-->    No faith, proud mistress, hope not after it;
line 12262-->    'Tis not your inky brows, your black silk hair,
line 12263-->    Your bugle eyeballs, nor your cheek of cream,
line 12264-->    That can entame my spirits to your worship.
line 12265-->    You foolish shepherd, wherefore do you follow her,
line 12266-->    Like foggy south, puffing with wind and rain?
line 12267-->    You are a thousand times a properer man  
line 12268-->    Than she a woman. 'Tis such fools as you
line 12269-->    That makes the world full of ill-favour'd children.
line 12270-->    'Tis not her glass, but you, that flatters her;
line 12271-->    And out of you she sees herself more proper
line 12272-->    Than any of her lineaments can show her.
line 12273-->    But, mistress, know yourself. Down on your knees,
line 12274-->    And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man's love;
line 12275-->    For I must tell you friendly in your ear:
line 12276-->    Sell when you can; you are not for all markets.
line 12277-->    Cry the man mercy, love him, take his offer;
line 12278-->    Foul is most foul, being foul to be a scoffer.
line 12279-->    So take her to thee, shepherd. Fare you well.
line 12280-->  PHEBE. Sweet youth, I pray you chide a year together;
line 12281-->    I had rather hear you chide than this man woo.
line 12282-->  ROSALIND. He's fall'n in love with your foulness, and she'll fall
line 12283-->    in love with my anger. If it be so, as fast as she answers thee
line 12284-->    with frowning looks, I'll sauce her with bitter words. Why look
line 12285-->    you so upon me?
line 12286-->  PHEBE. For no ill will I bear you.
line 12287-->  ROSALIND. I pray you do not fall in love with me,  
line 12288-->    For I am falser than vows made in wine;
line 12289-->    Besides, I like you not. If you will know my house,
line 12290-->    'Tis at the tuft of olives here hard by.
line 12291-->    Will you go, sister? Shepherd, ply her hard.
line 12292-->    Come, sister. Shepherdess, look on him better,
line 12293-->    And be not proud; though all the world could see,
line 12294-->    None could be so abus'd in sight as he.
line 12295-->    Come, to our flock.        Exeunt ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN
line 12296-->  PHEBE. Dead shepherd, now I find thy saw of might:
line 12297-->    'Who ever lov'd that lov'd not at first sight?'
line 12298-->  SILVIUS. Sweet Phebe.
line 12299-->  PHEBE. Ha! what say'st thou, Silvius?
line 12300-->  SILVIUS. Sweet Phebe, pity me.
line 12301-->  PHEBE. Why, I arn sorry for thee, gentle Silvius.
line 12302-->  SILVIUS. Wherever sorrow is, relief would be.
line 12303-->    If you do sorrow at my grief in love,
line 12304-->    By giving love, your sorrow and my grief
line 12305-->    Were both extermin'd.
line 12306-->  PHEBE. Thou hast my love; is not that neighbourly?
line 12307-->  SILVIUS. I would have you.  
line 12308-->  PHEBE. Why, that were covetousness.
line 12309-->    Silvius, the time was that I hated thee;
line 12310-->    And yet it is not that I bear thee love;
line 12311-->    But since that thou canst talk of love so well,
line 12312-->    Thy company, which erst was irksome to me,
line 12313-->    I will endure; and I'll employ thee too.
line 12314-->    But do not look for further recompense
line 12315-->    Than thine own gladness that thou art employ'd.
line 12316-->  SILVIUS. So holy and so perfect is my love,
line 12317-->    And I in such a poverty of grace,
line 12318-->    That I shall think it a most plenteous crop
line 12319-->    To glean the broken ears after the man
line 12320-->    That the main harvest reaps; loose now and then
line 12321-->    A scatt'red smile, and that I'll live upon.
line 12322-->  PHEBE. Know'st thou the youth that spoke to me erewhile?
line 12323-->  SILVIUS. Not very well; but I have met him oft;
line 12324-->    And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds
line 12325-->    That the old carlot once was master of.
line 12326-->  PHEBE. Think not I love him, though I ask for him;
line 12327-->    'Tis but a peevish boy; yet he talks well.  
line 12328-->    But what care I for words? Yet words do well
line 12329-->    When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.
line 12330-->    It is a pretty youth- not very pretty;
line 12331-->    But, sure, he's proud; and yet his pride becomes him.
line 12332-->    He'll make a proper man. The best thing in him
line 12333-->    Is his complexion; and faster than his tongue
line 12334-->    Did make offence, his eye did heal it up.
line 12335-->    He is not very tall; yet for his years he's tall;
line 12336-->    His leg is but so-so; and yet 'tis well.
line 12337-->    There was a pretty redness in his lip,
line 12338-->    A little riper and more lusty red
line 12339-->    Than that mix'd in his cheek; 'twas just the difference
line 12340-->    Betwixt the constant red and mingled damask.
line 12341-->    There be some women, Silvius, had they mark'd him
line 12342-->    In parcels as I did, would have gone near
line 12343-->    To fall in love with him; but, for my part,
line 12344-->    I love him not, nor hate him not; and yet
line 12345-->    I have more cause to hate him than to love him;
line 12346-->    For what had he to do to chide at me?
line 12347-->    He said mine eyes were black, and my hair black,  
line 12348-->    And, now I am rememb'red, scorn'd at me.
line 12349-->    I marvel why I answer'd not again;
line 12350-->    But that's all one: omittance is no quittance.
line 12351-->    I'll write to him a very taunting letter,
line 12352-->    And thou shalt bear it; wilt thou, Silvius?
line 12353-->  SILVIUS. Phebe, with all my heart.
line 12354-->  PHEBE. I'll write it straight;
line 12355-->    The matter's in my head and in my heart;
line 12356-->    I will be bitter with him and passing short.
line 12357-->    Go with me, Silvius.                                  Exeunt
line 12358-->
line 12359-->
line 12360-->

line 12363-->SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND IS

line 12370-->
line 12371-->
line 12372-->
line 12373-->ACT IV. SCENE I.
line 12374-->The forest
line 12375-->
line 12376-->Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and JAQUES
line 12377-->
line 12378-->  JAQUES. I prithee, pretty youth, let me be better acquainted with
line 12379-->    thee.
line 12380-->  ROSALIND. They say you are a melancholy fellow.
line 12381-->  JAQUES. I am so; I do love it better than laughing.
line 12382-->  ROSALIND. Those that are in extremity of either are abominable
line 12383-->    fellows, and betray themselves to every modern censure worse than
line 12384-->    drunkards.
line 12385-->  JAQUES. Why, 'tis good to be sad and say nothing.
line 12386-->  ROSALIND. Why then, 'tis good to be a post.
line 12387-->  JAQUES. I have neither the scholar's melancholy, which is
line 12388-->    emulation; nor the musician's, which is fantastical; nor the
line 12389-->    courtier's, which is proud; nor the soldier's, which is
line 12390-->    ambitious; nor the lawyer's, which is politic; nor the lady's,
line 12391-->    which is nice; nor the lover's, which is all these; but it is a
line 12392-->    melancholy of mine own, compounded of many simples, extracted
line 12393-->    from many objects, and, indeed, the sundry contemplation of my
line 12394-->    travels; in which my often rumination wraps me in a most humorous  
line 12395-->    sadness.
line 12396-->  ROSALIND. A traveller! By my faith, you have great reason to be
line 12397-->    sad. I fear you have sold your own lands to see other men's; then
line 12398-->    to have seen much and to have nothing is to have rich eyes and
line 12399-->    poor hands.
line 12400-->  JAQUES. Yes, I have gain'd my experience.
line 12401-->
line 12402-->                        Enter ORLANDO
line 12403-->
line 12404-->  ROSALIND. And your experience makes you sad. I had rather have a
line 12405-->    fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad- and to
line 12406-->    travel for it too.
line 12407-->  ORLANDO. Good day, and happiness, dear Rosalind!
line 12408-->  JAQUES. Nay, then, God buy you, an you talk in blank verse.
line 12409-->  ROSALIND. Farewell, Monsieur Traveller; look you lisp and wear
line 12410-->    strange suits, disable all the benefits of your own country, be
line 12411-->    out of love with your nativity, and almost chide God for making
line 12412-->    you that countenance you are; or I will scarce think you have
line 12413-->    swam in a gondola. [Exit JAQUES] Why, how now, Orlando! where
line 12414-->    have you been all this while? You a lover! An you serve me such  
line 12415-->    another trick, never come in my sight more.
line 12416-->  ORLANDO. My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise.
line 12417-->  ROSALIND. Break an hour's promise in love! He that will divide a
line 12418-->    minute into a thousand parts, and break but a part of the
line 12419-->    thousand part of a minute in the affairs of love, it may be said
line 12420-->    of him that Cupid hath clapp'd him o' th' shoulder, but I'll
line 12421-->    warrant him heart-whole.
line 12422-->  ORLANDO. Pardon me, dear Rosalind.
line 12423-->  ROSALIND. Nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight. I had
line 12424-->    as lief be woo'd of a snail.
line 12425-->  ORLANDO. Of a snail!
line 12426-->  ROSALIND. Ay, of a snail; for though he comes slowly, he carries
line 12427-->    his house on his head- a better jointure, I think, than you make
line 12428-->    a woman; besides, he brings his destiny with him.
line 12429-->  ORLANDO. What's that?
line 12430-->  ROSALIND. Why, horns; which such as you are fain to be beholding to
line 12431-->    your wives for; but he comes armed in his fortune, and prevents
line 12432-->    the slander of his wife.
line 12433-->  ORLANDO. Virtue is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is virtuous.
line 12434-->  ROSALIND. And I am your Rosalind.  
line 12435-->  CELIA. It pleases him to call you so; but he hath a Rosalind of a
line 12436-->    better leer than you.
line 12437-->  ROSALIND. Come, woo me, woo me; for now I am in a holiday humour,
line 12438-->    and like enough to consent. What would you say to me now, an I
line 12439-->    were your very very Rosalind?
line 12440-->  ORLANDO. I would kiss before I spoke.
line 12441-->  ROSALIND. Nay, you were better speak first; and when you were
line 12442-->    gravell'd for lack of matter, you might take occasion to kiss.
line 12443-->    Very good orators, when they are out, they will spit; and for
line 12444-->    lovers lacking- God warn us!- matter, the cleanliest shift is to
line 12445-->    kiss.
line 12446-->  ORLANDO. How if the kiss be denied?
line 12447-->  ROSALIND. Then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins new
line 12448-->    matter.
line 12449-->  ORLANDO. Who could be out, being before his beloved mistress?
line 12450-->  ROSALIND. Marry, that should you, if I were your mistress; or I
line 12451-->    should think my honesty ranker than my wit.
line 12452-->  ORLANDO. What, of my suit?
line 12453-->  ROSALIND. Not out of your apparel, and yet out of your suit.
line 12454-->    Am not I your Rosalind?  
line 12455-->  ORLANDO. I take some joy to say you are, because I would be talking
line 12456-->    of her.
line 12457-->  ROSALIND. Well, in her person, I say I will not have you.
line 12458-->  ORLANDO. Then, in mine own person, I die.
line 12459-->  ROSALIND. No, faith, die by attorney. The poor world is almost six
line 12460-->    thousand years old, and in all this time there was not any man
line 12461-->    died in his own person, videlicet, in a love-cause. Troilus had
line 12462-->    his brains dash'd out with a Grecian club; yet he did what he
line 12463-->    could to die before, and he is one of the patterns of love.
line 12464-->    Leander, he would have liv'd many a fair year, though Hero had
line 12465-->    turn'd nun, if it had not been for a hot midsummer night; for,
line 12466-->    good youth, he went but forth to wash him in the Hellespont, and,
line 12467-->    being taken with the cramp, was drown'd; and the foolish
line 12468-->    chroniclers of that age found it was- Hero of Sestos. But these
line 12469-->    are all lies: men have died from time to time, and worms have
line 12470-->    eaten them, but not for love.
line 12471-->  ORLANDO. I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind; for, I
line 12472-->    protest, her frown might kill me.
line 12473-->  ROSALIND. By this hand, it will not kill a fly. But come, now I
line 12474-->    will be your Rosalind in a more coming-on disposition; and ask me  
line 12475-->    what you will, I will grant it.
line 12476-->  ORLANDO. Then love me, Rosalind.
line 12477-->  ROSALIND. Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays, and all.
line 12478-->  ORLANDO. And wilt thou have me?
line 12479-->  ROSALIND. Ay, and twenty such.
line 12480-->  ORLANDO. What sayest thou?
line 12481-->  ROSALIND. Are you not good?
line 12482-->  ORLANDO. I hope so.
line 12483-->  ROSALIND. Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing? Come,
line 12484-->    sister, you shall be the priest, and marry us. Give me your hand,
line 12485-->    Orlando. What do you say, sister?
line 12486-->  ORLANDO. Pray thee, marry us.
line 12487-->  CELIA. I cannot say the words.
line 12488-->  ROSALIND. You must begin 'Will you, Orlando'-
line 12489-->  CELIA. Go to. Will you, Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind?
line 12490-->  ORLANDO. I will.
line 12491-->  ROSALIND. Ay, but when?
line 12492-->  ORLANDO. Why, now; as fast as she can marry us.
line 12493-->  ROSALIND. Then you must say 'I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.'
line 12494-->  ORLANDO. I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.  
line 12495-->  ROSALIND. I might ask you for your commission; but- I do take thee,
line 12496-->    Orlando, for my husband. There's a girl goes before the priest;
line 12497-->    and, certainly, a woman's thought runs before her actions.
line 12498-->  ORLANDO. So do all thoughts; they are wing'd.
line 12499-->  ROSALIND. Now tell me how long you would have her, after you have
line 12500-->    possess'd her.
line 12501-->  ORLANDO. For ever and a day.
line 12502-->  ROSALIND. Say 'a day' without the 'ever.' No, no, Orlando; men are
line 12503-->    April when they woo, December when they wed: maids are May when
line 12504-->    they are maids, but the sky changes when they are wives. I will
line 12505-->    be more jealous of thee than a Barbary cock-pigeon over his hen,
line 12506-->    more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more new-fangled than
line 12507-->    an ape, more giddy in my desires than a monkey. I will weep for
line 12508-->    nothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I will do that when you
line 12509-->    are dispos'd to be merry; I will laugh like a hyen, and that when
line 12510-->    thou are inclin'd to sleep.
line 12511-->  ORLANDO. But will my Rosalind do so?
line 12512-->  ROSALIND. By my life, she will do as I do.
line 12513-->  ORLANDO. O, but she is wise.
line 12514-->  ROSALIND. Or else she could not have the wit to do this. The wiser,  
line 12515-->    the waywarder. Make the doors upon a woman's wit, and it will out
line 12516-->    at the casement; shut that, and 'twill out at the key-hole; stop
line 12517-->    that, 'twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney.
line 12518-->  ORLANDO. A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say 'Wit,
line 12519-->    whither wilt?' ROSALIND. Nay, you might keep that check for it, till you met your
line 12520-->    wife's wit going to your neighbour's bed.
line 12521-->  ORLANDO. And what wit could wit have to excuse that?
line 12522-->  ROSALIND. Marry, to say she came to seek you there. You shall never
line 12523-->    take her without her answer, unless you take her without her
line 12524-->    tongue. O, that woman that cannot make her fault her husband's
line 12525-->    occasion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she will
line 12526-->    breed it like a fool!
line 12527-->  ORLANDO. For these two hours, Rosalind, I will leave thee.
line 12528-->  ROSALIND. Alas, dear love, I cannot lack thee two hours!
line 12529-->  ORLANDO. I must attend the Duke at dinner; by two o'clock I will be
line 12530-->    with thee again.
line 12531-->  ROSALIND. Ay, go your ways, go your ways. I knew what you would
line 12532-->    prove; my friends told me as much, and I thought no less. That
line 12533-->    flattering tongue of yours won me. 'Tis but one cast away, and  
line 12534-->    so, come death! Two o'clock is your hour?
line 12535-->  ORLANDO. Ay, sweet Rosalind.
line 12536-->  ROSALIND. By my troth, and in good earnest, and so God mend me, and
line 12537-->    by all pretty oaths that are not dangerous, if you break one jot
line 12538-->    of your promise, or come one minute behind your hour, I will
line 12539-->    think you the most pathetical break-promise, and the most hollow
line 12540-->    lover, and the most unworthy of her you call Rosalind, that may
line 12541-->    be chosen out of the gross band of the unfaithful. Therefore
line 12542-->    beware my censure, and keep your promise.
line 12543-->  ORLANDO. With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my
line 12544-->    Rosalind; so, adieu.
line 12545-->  ROSALIND. Well, Time is the old justice that examines all such
line 12546-->    offenders, and let Time try. Adieu.             Exit ORLANDO
line 12547-->  CELIA. You have simply misus'd our sex in your love-prate. We must
line 12548-->    have your doublet and hose pluck'd over your head, and show the
line 12549-->    world what the bird hath done to her own nest.
line 12550-->  ROSALIND. O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou didst
line 12551-->    know how many fathom deep I am in love! But it cannot be sounded;
line 12552-->    my affection hath an unknown bottom, like the Bay of Portugal.
line 12553-->  CELIA. Or rather, bottomless; that as fast as you pour affection  
line 12554-->    in, it runs out.
line 12555-->  ROSALIND. No; that same wicked bastard of Venus, that was begot of
line 12556-->    thought, conceiv'd of spleen, and born of madness; that blind
line 12557-->    rascally boy, that abuses every one's eyes, because his own are
line 12558-->    out- let him be judge how deep I am in love. I'll tell thee,
line 12559-->    Aliena, I cannot be out of the sight of Orlando. I'll go find a
line 12560-->    shadow, and sigh till he come.
line 12561-->  CELIA. And I'll sleep.                                  Exeunt
line 12562-->
line 12563-->
line 12564-->
line 12565-->
line 12566-->SCENE II.
line 12567-->The forest
line 12568-->
line 12569-->        Enter JAQUES and LORDS, in the habit of foresters
line 12570-->
line 12571-->  JAQUES. Which is he that killed the deer?
line 12572-->  LORD. Sir, it was I.
line 12573-->  JAQUES. Let's present him to the Duke, like a Roman conqueror; and
line 12574-->    it would do well to set the deer's horns upon his head for a
line 12575-->    branch of victory. Have you no song, forester, for this purpose?
line 12576-->  LORD. Yes, sir.
line 12577-->  JAQUES. Sing it; 'tis no matter how it be in tune, so it make noise
line 12578-->    enough.
line 12579-->
line 12580-->                    SONG.
line 12581-->
line 12582-->      What shall he have that kill'd the deer?
line 12583-->      His leather skin and horns to wear.
line 12584-->                              [The rest shall hear this burden:]
line 12585-->           Then sing him home.
line 12586-->
line 12587-->      Take thou no scorn to wear the horn;  
line 12588-->      It was a crest ere thou wast born.
line 12589-->           Thy father's father wore it;
line 12590-->           And thy father bore it.
line 12591-->      The horn, the horn, the lusty horn,
line 12592-->      Is not a thing to laugh to scorn.                   Exeunt
line 12593-->
line 12594-->
line 12595-->
line 12596-->
line 12597-->SCENE III.
line 12598-->The forest
line 12599-->
line 12600-->Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
line 12601-->
line 12602-->  ROSALIND. How say you now? Is it not past two o'clock?
line 12603-->    And here much Orlando!
line 12604-->  CELIA. I warrant you, with pure love and troubled brain, he hath
line 12605-->    ta'en his bow and arrows, and is gone forth- to sleep. Look, who
line 12606-->    comes here.
line 12607-->
line 12608-->                      Enter SILVIUS
line 12609-->
line 12610-->  SILVIUS. My errand is to you, fair youth;
line 12611-->    My gentle Phebe did bid me give you this.
line 12612-->    I know not the contents; but, as I guess
line 12613-->    By the stern brow and waspish action
line 12614-->    Which she did use as she was writing of it,
line 12615-->    It bears an angry tenour. Pardon me,
line 12616-->    I am but as a guiltless messenger.
line 12617-->  ROSALIND. Patience herself would startle at this letter,
line 12618-->    And play the swaggerer. Bear this, bear all.
line 12619-->    She says I am not fair, that I lack manners;  
line 12620-->    She calls me proud, and that she could not love me,
line 12621-->    Were man as rare as Phoenix. 'Od's my will!
line 12622-->    Her love is not the hare that I do hunt;
line 12623-->    Why writes she so to me? Well, shepherd, well,
line 12624-->    This is a letter of your own device.
line 12625-->  SILVIUS. No, I protest, I know not the contents;
line 12626-->    Phebe did write it.
line 12627-->  ROSALIND. Come, come, you are a fool,
line 12628-->    And turn'd into the extremity of love.
line 12629-->    I saw her hand; she has a leathern hand,
line 12630-->    A freestone-colour'd hand; I verily did think
line 12631-->    That her old gloves were on, but 'twas her hands;
line 12632-->    She has a huswife's hand- but that's no matter.
line 12633-->    I say she never did invent this letter:
line 12634-->    This is a man's invention, and his hand.
line 12635-->  SILVIUS. Sure, it is hers.
line 12636-->  ROSALIND. Why, 'tis a boisterous and a cruel style;
line 12637-->    A style for challengers. Why, she defies me,
line 12638-->    Like Turk to Christian. Women's gentle brain
line 12639-->    Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention,  
line 12640-->    Such Ethiope words, blacker in their effect
line 12641-->    Than in their countenance. Will you hear the letter?
line 12642-->  SILVIUS. So please you, for I never heard it yet;
line 12643-->    Yet heard too much of Phebe's cruelty.
line 12644-->  ROSALIND. She Phebes me: mark how the tyrant writes.
line 12645-->                                                         [Reads]
line 12646-->
line 12647-->            'Art thou god to shepherd turn'd,
line 12648-->            That a maiden's heart hath burn'd?'
line 12649-->
line 12650-->    Can a woman rail thus?
line 12651-->  SILVIUS. Call you this railing?
line 12652-->  ROSALIND. 'Why, thy godhead laid apart,
line 12653-->             Warr'st thou with a woman's heart?'
line 12654-->
line 12655-->    Did you ever hear such railing?
line 12656-->
line 12657-->            'Whiles the eye of man did woo me,
line 12658-->            That could do no vengeance to me.'
line 12659-->  
line 12660-->    Meaning me a beast.
line 12661-->
line 12662-->            'If the scorn of your bright eyne
line 12663-->            Have power to raise such love in mine,
line 12664-->            Alack, in me what strange effect
line 12665-->            Would they work in mild aspect!
line 12666-->            Whiles you chid me, I did love;
line 12667-->            How then might your prayers move!
line 12668-->            He that brings this love to the
line 12669-->            Little knows this love in me;
line 12670-->            And by him seal up thy mind,
line 12671-->            Whether that thy youth and kind
line 12672-->            Will the faithful offer take
line 12673-->            Of me and all that I can make;
line 12674-->            Or else by him my love deny,
line 12675-->            And then I'll study how to die.'
line 12676-->  SILVIUS. Call you this chiding?
line 12677-->  CELIA. Alas, poor shepherd!
line 12678-->  ROSALIND. Do you pity him? No, he deserves no pity. Wilt thou love
line 12679-->    such a woman? What, to make thee an instrument, and play false  
line 12680-->    strains upon thee! Not to be endur'd! Well, go your way to her,
line 12681-->    for I see love hath made thee tame snake, and say this to her-
line 12682-->    that if she love me, I charge her to love thee; if she will not,
line 12683-->    I will never have her unless thou entreat for her. If you be a
line 12684-->    true lover, hence, and not a word; for here comes more company.
line 12685-->                                                    Exit SILVIUS
line 12686-->
line 12687-->                         Enter OLIVER
line 12688-->
line 12689-->  OLIVER. Good morrow, fair ones; pray you, if you know,
line 12690-->    Where in the purlieus of this forest stands
line 12691-->    A sheep-cote fenc'd about with olive trees?
line 12692-->  CELIA. West of this place, down in the neighbour bottom.
line 12693-->    The rank of osiers by the murmuring stream
line 12694-->    Left on your right hand brings you to the place.
line 12695-->    But at this hour the house doth keep itself;
line 12696-->    There's none within.
line 12697-->  OLIVER. If that an eye may profit by a tongue,
line 12698-->    Then should I know you by description-
line 12699-->    Such garments, and such years: 'The boy is fair,  
line 12700-->    Of female favour, and bestows himself
line 12701-->    Like a ripe sister; the woman low,
line 12702-->    And browner than her brother.' Are not you
line 12703-->    The owner of the house I did inquire for?
line 12704-->  CELIA. It is no boast, being ask'd, to say we are.
line 12705-->  OLIVER. Orlando doth commend him to you both;
line 12706-->    And to that youth he calls his Rosalind
line 12707-->    He sends this bloody napkin. Are you he?
line 12708-->  ROSALIND. I am. What must we understand by this?
line 12709-->  OLIVER. Some of my shame; if you will know of me
line 12710-->    What man I am, and how, and why, and where,
line 12711-->    This handkercher was stain'd.
line 12712-->  CELIA. I pray you, tell it.
line 12713-->  OLIVER. When last the young Orlando parted from you,
line 12714-->    He left a promise to return again
line 12715-->    Within an hour; and, pacing through the forest,
line 12716-->    Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy,
line 12717-->    Lo, what befell! He threw his eye aside,
line 12718-->    And mark what object did present itself.
line 12719-->    Under an oak, whose boughs were moss'd with age,  
line 12720-->    And high top bald with dry antiquity,
line 12721-->    A wretched ragged man, o'ergrown with hair,
line 12722-->    Lay sleeping on his back. About his neck
line 12723-->    A green and gilded snake had wreath'd itself,
line 12724-->    Who with her head nimble in threats approach'd
line 12725-->    The opening of his mouth; but suddenly,
line 12726-->    Seeing Orlando, it unlink'd itself,
line 12727-->    And with indented glides did slip away
line 12728-->    Into a bush; under which bush's shade
line 12729-->    A lioness, with udders all drawn dry,
line 12730-->    Lay couching, head on ground, with catlike watch,
line 12731-->    When that the sleeping man should stir; for 'tis
line 12732-->    The royal disposition of that beast
line 12733-->    To prey on nothing that doth seem as dead.
line 12734-->    This seen, Orlando did approach the man,
line 12735-->    And found it was his brother, his elder brother.
line 12736-->  CELIA. O, I have heard him speak of that same brother;
line 12737-->    And he did render him the most unnatural
line 12738-->    That liv'd amongst men.
line 12739-->  OLIVER. And well he might so do,  
line 12740-->    For well I know he was unnatural.
line 12741-->  ROSALIND. But, to Orlando: did he leave him there,
line 12742-->    Food to the suck'd and hungry lioness?
line 12743-->  OLIVER. Twice did he turn his back, and purpos'd so;
line 12744-->    But kindness, nobler ever than revenge,
line 12745-->    And nature, stronger than his just occasion,
line 12746-->    Made him give battle to the lioness,
line 12747-->    Who quickly fell before him; in which hurtling
line 12748-->    From miserable slumber I awak'd.
line 12749-->  CELIA. Are you his brother?
line 12750-->  ROSALIND. Was't you he rescu'd?
line 12751-->  CELIA. Was't you that did so oft contrive to kill him?
line 12752-->  OLIVER. 'Twas I; but 'tis not I. I do not shame
line 12753-->    To tell you what I was, since my conversion
line 12754-->    So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.
line 12755-->  ROSALIND. But for the bloody napkin?
line 12756-->  OLIVER. By and by.
line 12757-->    When from the first to last, betwixt us two,
line 12758-->    Tears our recountments had most kindly bath'd,
line 12759-->    As how I came into that desert place-  
line 12760-->    In brief, he led me to the gentle Duke,
line 12761-->    Who gave me fresh array and entertainment,
line 12762-->    Committing me unto my brother's love;
line 12763-->    Who led me instantly unto his cave,
line 12764-->    There stripp'd himself, and here upon his arm
line 12765-->    The lioness had torn some flesh away,
line 12766-->    Which all this while had bled; and now he fainted,
line 12767-->    And cried, in fainting, upon Rosalind.
line 12768-->    Brief, I recover'd him, bound up his wound,
line 12769-->    And, after some small space, being strong at heart,
line 12770-->    He sent me hither, stranger as I am,
line 12771-->    To tell this story, that you might excuse
line 12772-->    His broken promise, and to give this napkin,
line 12773-->    Dy'd in his blood, unto the shepherd youth
line 12774-->    That he in sport doth call his Rosalind.
line 12775-->                                               [ROSALIND swoons]
line 12776-->  CELIA. Why, how now, Ganymede! sweet Ganymede!
line 12777-->  OLIVER. Many will swoon when they do look on blood.
line 12778-->  CELIA. There is more in it. Cousin Ganymede!
line 12779-->  OLIVER. Look, he recovers.  
line 12780-->  ROSALIND. I would I were at home.
line 12781-->  CELIA. We'll lead you thither.
line 12782-->    I pray you, will you take him by the arm?
line 12783-->  OLIVER. Be of good cheer, youth. You a man!
line 12784-->    You lack a man's heart.
line 12785-->  ROSALIND. I do so, I confess it. Ah, sirrah, a body would think
line 12786-->    this was well counterfeited. I pray you tell your brother how
line 12787-->    well I counterfeited. Heigh-ho!
line 12788-->  OLIVER. This was not counterfeit; there is too great testimony in
line 12789-->    your complexion that it was a passion of earnest.
line 12790-->  ROSALIND. Counterfeit, I assure you.
line 12791-->  OLIVER. Well then, take a good heart and counterfeit to be a man.
line 12792-->  ROSALIND. So I do; but, i' faith, I should have been a woman by
line 12793-->    right.
line 12794-->  CELIA. Come, you look paler and paler; pray you draw homewards.
line 12795-->    Good sir, go with us.
line 12796-->  OLIVER. That will I, for I must bear answer back
line 12797-->    How you excuse my brother, Rosalind.
line 12798-->  ROSALIND. I shall devise something; but, I pray you, commend my
line 12799-->    counterfeiting to him. Will you go?                   Exeunt
line 12800-->
