line 12813-->
line 12814-->
line 12815-->ACT V. SCENE I.
line 12816-->The forest
line 12817-->
line 12818-->Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY
line 12819-->
line 12820-->  TOUCHSTONE. We shall find a time, Audrey; patience, gentle Audrey.
line 12821-->  AUDREY. Faith, the priest was good enough, for all the old
line 12822-->    gentleman's saying.
line 12823-->  TOUCHSTONE. A most wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a most vile Martext.
line 12824-->    But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the forest lays claim to
line 12825-->    you.
line 12826-->  AUDREY. Ay, I know who 'tis; he hath no interest in me in the
line 12827-->    world; here comes the man you mean.
line 12828-->
line 12829-->                         Enter WILLIAM
line 12830-->
line 12831-->  TOUCHSTONE. It is meat and drink to me to see a clown. By my troth,
line 12832-->    we that have good wits have much to answer for: we shall be
line 12833-->    flouting; we cannot hold.
line 12834-->  WILLIAM. Good ev'n, Audrey.
line 12835-->  AUDREY. God ye good ev'n, William.
line 12836-->  WILLIAM. And good ev'n to you, sir.  
line 12837-->  TOUCHSTONE. Good ev'n, gentle friend. Cover thy head, cover thy
line 12838-->    head; nay, prithee be cover'd. How old are you, friend?
line 12839-->  WILLIAM. Five and twenty, sir.
line 12840-->  TOUCHSTONE. A ripe age. Is thy name William?
line 12841-->  WILLIAM. William, sir.
line 12842-->  TOUCHSTONE. A fair name. Wast born i' th' forest here?
line 12843-->  WILLIAM. Ay, sir, I thank God.
line 12844-->  TOUCHSTONE. 'Thank God.' A good answer.
line 12845-->    Art rich?
line 12846-->  WILLIAM. Faith, sir, so so.
line 12847-->  TOUCHSTONE. 'So so' is good, very good, very excellent good; and
line 12848-->    yet it is not; it is but so so. Art thou wise?
line 12849-->  WILLIAM. Ay, sir, I have a pretty wit.
line 12850-->  TOUCHSTONE. Why, thou say'st well. I do now remember a saying: 'The
line 12851-->    fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be
line 12852-->    a fool.' The heathen philosopher, when he had a desire to eat a
line 12853-->    grape, would open his lips when he put it into his mouth; meaning
line 12854-->    thereby that grapes were made to eat and lips to open. You do
line 12855-->    love this maid?
line 12856-->  WILLIAM. I do, sir.  
line 12857-->  TOUCHSTONE. Give me your hand. Art thou learned?
line 12858-->  WILLIAM. No, sir.
line 12859-->  TOUCHSTONE. Then learn this of me: to have is to have; for it is a
line 12860-->    figure in rhetoric that drink, being pour'd out of cup into a
line 12861-->    glass, by filling the one doth empty the other; for all your
line 12862-->    writers do consent that ipse is he; now, you are not ipse, for I
line 12863-->    am he.
line 12864-->  WILLIAM. Which he, sir?
line 12865-->  TOUCHSTONE. He, sir, that must marry this woman. Therefore, you
line 12866-->    clown, abandon- which is in the vulgar leave- the society- which
line 12867-->    in the boorish is company- of this female- which in the common is
line 12868-->    woman- which together is: abandon the society of this female; or,
line 12869-->    clown, thou perishest; or, to thy better understanding, diest;
line 12870-->    or, to wit, I kill thee, make thee away, translate thy life into
line 12871-->    death, thy liberty into bondage. I will deal in poison with thee,
line 12872-->    or in bastinado, or in steel; I will bandy with thee in faction;
line 12873-->    will o'er-run thee with policy; I will kill thee a hundred and
line 12874-->    fifty ways; therefore tremble and depart.
line 12875-->  AUDREY. Do, good William.
line 12876-->  WILLIAM. God rest you merry, sir.                         Exit  
line 12877-->
line 12878-->                          Enter CORIN
line 12879-->
line 12880-->  CORIN. Our master and mistress seeks you; come away, away.
line 12881-->  TOUCHSTONE. Trip, Audrey, trip, Audrey. I attend, I attend.
line 12882-->                                                          Exeunt
line 12883-->
line 12884-->
line 12885-->
line 12886-->
line 12887-->SCENE II.
line 12888-->The forest
line 12889-->
line 12890-->Enter ORLANDO and OLIVER
line 12891-->
line 12892-->  ORLANDO. Is't possible that on so little acquaintance you should
line 12893-->    like her? that but seeing you should love her? and loving woo?
line 12894-->    and, wooing, she should grant? and will you persever to enjoy
line 12895-->    her?
line 12896-->  OLIVER. Neither call the giddiness of it in question, the poverty
line 12897-->    of her, the small acquaintance, my sudden wooing, nor her sudden
line 12898-->    consenting; but say with me, I love Aliena; say with her that she
line 12899-->    loves me; consent with both that we may enjoy each other. It
line 12900-->    shall be to your good; for my father's house and all the revenue
line 12901-->    that was old Sir Rowland's will I estate upon you, and here live
line 12902-->    and die a shepherd.
line 12903-->  ORLANDO. You have my consent. Let your wedding be to-morrow.
line 12904-->    Thither will I invite the Duke and all's contented followers. Go
line 12905-->    you and prepare Aliena; for, look you, here comes my Rosalind.
line 12906-->
line 12907-->                        Enter ROSALIND
line 12908-->  
line 12909-->  ROSALIND. God save you, brother.
line 12910-->  OLIVER. And you, fair sister.                             Exit
line 12911-->  ROSALIND. O, my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee wear
line 12912-->    thy heart in a scarf!
line 12913-->  ORLANDO. It is my arm.
line 12914-->  ROSALIND. I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of a
line 12915-->    lion.
line 12916-->  ORLANDO. Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a lady.
line 12917-->  ROSALIND. Did your brother tell you how I counterfeited to swoon
line 12918-->    when he show'd me your handkercher?
line 12919-->  ORLANDO. Ay, and greater wonders than that.
line 12920-->  ROSALIND. O, I know where you are. Nay, 'tis true. There was never
line 12921-->    any thing so sudden but the fight of two rams and Caesar's
line 12922-->    thrasonical brag of 'I came, saw, and overcame.' For your brother
line 12923-->    and my sister no sooner met but they look'd; no sooner look'd but
line 12924-->    they lov'd; no sooner lov'd but they sigh'd; no sooner sigh'd but
line 12925-->    they ask'd one another the reason; no sooner knew the reason but
line 12926-->    they sought the remedy- and in these degrees have they made pair
line 12927-->    of stairs to marriage, which they will climb incontinent, or else
line 12928-->    be incontinent before marriage. They are in the very wrath of  
line 12929-->    love, and they will together. Clubs cannot part them.
line 12930-->  ORLANDO. They shall be married to-morrow; and I will bid the Duke
line 12931-->    to the nuptial. But, O, how bitter a thing it is to look into
line 12932-->    happiness through another man's eyes! By so much the more shall I
line 12933-->    to-morrow be at the height of heart-heaviness, by how much I
line 12934-->    shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for.
line 12935-->  ROSALIND. Why, then, to-morrow I cannot serve your turn for
line 12936-->    Rosalind?
line 12937-->  ORLANDO. I can live no longer by thinking.
line 12938-->  ROSALIND. I will weary you, then, no longer with idle talking. Know
line 12939-->    of me then- for now I speak to some purpose- that I know you are
line 12940-->    a gentleman of good conceit. I speak not this that you should
line 12941-->    bear a good opinion of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you
line 12942-->    are; neither do I labour for a greater esteem than may in some
line 12943-->    little measure draw a belief from you, to do yourself good, and
line 12944-->    not to grace me. Believe then, if you please, that I can do
line 12945-->    strange things. I have, since I was three year old, convers'd
line 12946-->    with a magician, most profound in his art and yet not damnable.
line 12947-->    If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries
line 12948-->    it out, when your brother marries Aliena shall you marry her. I  
line 12949-->    know into what straits of fortune she is driven; and it is not
line 12950-->    impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to you, to set
line 12951-->    her before your eyes to-morrow, human as she is, and without any
line 12952-->    danger.
line 12953-->  ORLANDO. Speak'st thou in sober meanings?
line 12954-->  ROSALIND. By my life, I do; which I tender dearly, though I say I
line 12955-->    am a magician. Therefore put you in your best array, bid your
line 12956-->    friends; for if you will be married to-morrow, you shall; and to
line 12957-->    Rosalind, if you will.
line 12958-->
line 12959-->                     Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE
line 12960-->
line 12961-->    Look, here comes a lover of mine, and a lover of hers.
line 12962-->  PHEBE. Youth, you have done me much ungentleness
line 12963-->    To show the letter that I writ to you.
line 12964-->  ROSALIND. I care not if I have. It is my study
line 12965-->    To seem despiteful and ungentle to you.
line 12966-->    You are there follow'd by a faithful shepherd;
line 12967-->    Look upon him, love him; he worships you.
line 12968-->  PHEBE. Good shepherd, tell this youth what 'tis to love.  
line 12969-->  SILVIUS. It is to be all made of sighs and tears;
line 12970-->    And so am I for Phebe.
line 12971-->  PHEBE. And I for Ganymede.
line 12972-->  ORLANDO. And I for Rosalind.
line 12973-->  ROSALIND. And I for no woman.
line 12974-->  SILVIUS. It is to be all made of faith and service;
line 12975-->    And so am I for Phebe.
line 12976-->  PHEBE. And I for Ganymede.
line 12977-->  ORLANDO. And I for Rosalind.
line 12978-->  ROSALIND. And I for no woman.
line 12979-->  SILVIUS. It is to be all made of fantasy,
line 12980-->    All made of passion, and all made of wishes;
line 12981-->    All adoration, duty, and observance,
line 12982-->    All humbleness, all patience, and impatience,
line 12983-->    All purity, all trial, all obedience;
line 12984-->    And so am I for Phebe.
line 12985-->  PHEBE. And so am I for Ganymede.
line 12986-->  ORLANDO. And so am I for Rosalind.
line 12987-->  ROSALIND. And so am I for no woman.
line 12988-->  PHEBE. If this be so, why blame you me to love you?  
line 12989-->  SILVIUS. If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
line 12990-->  ORLANDO. If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
line 12991-->  ROSALIND. Why do you speak too, 'Why blame you me to love you?'
line 12992-->  ORLANDO. To her that is not here, nor doth not hear.
line 12993-->  ROSALIND. Pray you, no more of this; 'tis like the howling of Irish
line 12994-->    wolves against the moon. [To SILVIUS] I will help you if I can.
line 12995-->    [To PHEBE] I would love you if I could.- To-morrow meet me all
line 12996-->    together. [ To PHEBE ] I will marry you if ever I marry woman,
line 12997-->    and I'll be married to-morrow. [To ORLANDO] I will satisfy you if
line 12998-->    ever I satisfied man, and you shall be married to-morrow. [To
line 12999-->    Silvius] I will content you if what pleases you contents you, and
line 13000-->    you shall be married to-morrow. [To ORLANDO] As you love
line 13001-->    Rosalind, meet. [To SILVIUS] As you love Phebe, meet;- and as I
line 13002-->    love no woman, I'll meet. So, fare you well; I have left you
line 13003-->    commands.
line 13004-->  SILVIUS. I'll not fail, if I live.
line 13005-->  PHEBE. Nor I.
line 13006-->  ORLANDO. Nor I.                                         Exeunt
line 13007-->
line 13008-->
line 13009-->
line 13010-->
line 13011-->SCENE III.
line 13012-->The forest
line 13013-->
line 13014-->Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY
line 13015-->
line 13016-->  TOUCHSTONE. To-morrow is the joyful day, Audre'y; to-morrow will we
line 13017-->    be married.
line 13018-->  AUDREY. I do desire it with all my heart; and I hope it is no
line 13019-->    dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world. Here come
line 13020-->    two of the banish'd Duke's pages.
line 13021-->
line 13022-->                            Enter two PAGES
line 13023-->
line 13024-->  FIRST PAGE. Well met, honest gentleman.
line 13025-->  TOUCHSTONE. By my troth, well met. Come sit, sit, and a song.
line 13026-->  SECOND PAGE. We are for you; sit i' th' middle.
line 13027-->  FIRST PAGE. Shall we clap into't roundly, without hawking, or
line 13028-->    spitting, or saying we are hoarse, which are the only prologues
line 13029-->    to a bad voice?
line 13030-->  SECOND PAGE. I'faith, i'faith; and both in a tune, like two gipsies
line 13031-->    on a horse.
line 13032-->  
line 13033-->                      SONG.
line 13034-->        It was a lover and his lass,
line 13035-->          With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
line 13036-->        That o'er the green corn-field did pass
line 13037-->          In the spring time, the only pretty ring time,
line 13038-->        When birds do sing, hey ding a ding, ding.
line 13039-->        Sweet lovers love the spring.
line 13040-->
line 13041-->        Between the acres of the rye,
line 13042-->          With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
line 13043-->        These pretty country folks would lie,
line 13044-->          In the spring time, &c.
line 13045-->
line 13046-->        This carol they began that hour,
line 13047-->          With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
line 13048-->        How that a life was but a flower,
line 13049-->          In the spring time, &c.
line 13050-->
line 13051-->        And therefore take the present time,
line 13052-->          With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,  
line 13053-->        For love is crowned with the prime,
line 13054-->          In the spring time, &c.
line 13055-->
line 13056-->  TOUCHSTONE. Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great
line 13057-->    matter in the ditty, yet the note was very untuneable.
line 13058-->  FIRST PAGE. YOU are deceiv'd, sir; we kept time, we lost not our
line 13059-->    time.
line 13060-->  TOUCHSTONE. By my troth, yes; I count it but time lost to hear such
line 13061-->    a foolish song. God buy you; and God mend your voices. Come,
line 13062-->    Audrey.                                               Exeunt
line 13063-->
line 13064-->
line 13065-->
line 13066-->
line 13067-->SCENE IV.
line 13068-->The forest
line 13069-->
line 13070-->Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, JAQUES, ORLANDO, OLIVER, and CELIA
line 13071-->
line 13072-->  DUKE SENIOR. Dost thou believe, Orlando, that the boy
line 13073-->    Can do all this that he hath promised?
line 13074-->  ORLANDO. I sometimes do believe and sometimes do not:
line 13075-->    As those that fear they hope, and know they fear.
line 13076-->
line 13077-->               Enter ROSALIND, SILVIUS, and PHEBE
line 13078-->
line 13079-->  ROSALIND. Patience once more, whiles our compact is urg'd:
line 13080-->    You say, if I bring in your Rosalind,
line 13081-->    You will bestow her on Orlando here?
line 13082-->  DUKE SENIOR. That would I, had I kingdoms to give with her.
line 13083-->  ROSALIND. And you say you will have her when I bring her?
line 13084-->  ORLANDO. That would I, were I of all kingdoms king.
line 13085-->  ROSALIND. You say you'll marry me, if I be willing?
line 13086-->  PHEBE. That will I, should I die the hour after.
line 13087-->  ROSALIND. But if you do refuse to marry me,  
line 13088-->    You'll give yourself to this most faithful shepherd?
line 13089-->  PHEBE. So is the bargain.
line 13090-->  ROSALIND. You say that you'll have Phebe, if she will?
line 13091-->  SILVIUS. Though to have her and death were both one thing.
line 13092-->  ROSALIND. I have promis'd to make all this matter even.
line 13093-->    Keep you your word, O Duke, to give your daughter;
line 13094-->    You yours, Orlando, to receive his daughter;
line 13095-->    Keep your word, Phebe, that you'll marry me,
line 13096-->    Or else, refusing me, to wed this shepherd;
line 13097-->    Keep your word, Silvius, that you'll marry her
line 13098-->    If she refuse me; and from hence I go,
line 13099-->    To make these doubts all even.
line 13100-->                                       Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA
line 13101-->  DUKE SENIOR. I do remember in this shepherd boy
line 13102-->    Some lively touches of my daughter's favour.
line 13103-->  ORLANDO. My lord, the first time that I ever saw him
line 13104-->    Methought he was a brother to your daughter.
line 13105-->    But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born,
line 13106-->    And hath been tutor'd in the rudiments
line 13107-->    Of many desperate studies by his uncle,  
line 13108-->    Whom he reports to be a great magician,
line 13109-->    Obscured in the circle of this forest.
line 13110-->
line 13111-->                    Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY
line 13112-->
line 13113-->  JAQUES. There is, sure, another flood toward, and these couples are
line 13114-->    coming to the ark. Here comes a pair of very strange beasts which
line 13115-->    in all tongues are call'd fools.
line 13116-->  TOUCHSTONE. Salutation and greeting to you all!
line 13117-->  JAQUES. Good my lord, bid him welcome. This is the motley-minded
line 13118-->    gentleman that I have so often met in the forest. He hath been a
line 13119-->     courtier, he swears.
line 13120-->  TOUCHSTONE. If any man doubt that, let him put me to my purgation.
line 13121-->    I have trod a measure; I have flatt'red a lady; I have been
line 13122-->    politic with my friend, smooth with mine enemy; I have undone
line 13123-->    three tailors; I have had four quarrels, and like to have fought
line 13124-->    one.
line 13125-->  JAQUES. And how was that ta'en up?
line 13126-->  TOUCHSTONE. Faith, we met, and found the quarrel was upon the
line 13127-->    seventh cause.  
line 13128-->  JAQUES. How seventh cause? Good my lord, like this fellow.
line 13129-->  DUKE SENIOR. I like him very well.
line 13130-->  TOUCHSTONE. God 'ild you, sir; I desire you of the like. I press in
line 13131-->    here, sir, amongst the rest of the country copulatives, to swear
line 13132-->    and to forswear, according as marriage binds and blood breaks. A
line 13133-->    poor virgin, sir, an ill-favour'd thing, sir, but mine own; a
line 13134-->    poor humour of mine, sir, to take that that man else will. Rich
line 13135-->    honesty dwells like a miser, sir, in a poor house; as your pearl
line 13136-->    in your foul oyster.
line 13137-->  DUKE SENIOR. By my faith, he is very swift and sententious.
line 13138-->  TOUCHSTONE. According to the fool's bolt, sir, and such dulcet
line 13139-->    diseases.
line 13140-->  JAQUES. But, for the seventh cause: how did you find the quarrel on
line 13141-->    the seventh cause?
line 13142-->  TOUCHSTONE. Upon a lie seven times removed- bear your body more
line 13143-->    seeming, Audrey- as thus, sir. I did dislike the cut of a certain
line 13144-->    courtier's beard; he sent me word, if I said his beard was not
line 13145-->    cut well, he was in the mind it was. This is call'd the Retort
line 13146-->    Courteous. If I sent him word again it was not well cut, he would
line 13147-->    send me word he cut it to please himself. This is call'd the Quip  
line 13148-->    Modest. If again it was not well cut, he disabled my judgment.
line 13149-->    This is call'd the Reply Churlish. If again it was not well cut,
line 13150-->    he would answer I spake not true. This is call'd the Reproof
line 13151-->    Valiant. If again it was not well cut, he would say I lie. This
line 13152-->    is call'd the Countercheck Quarrelsome. And so to the Lie
line 13153-->    Circumstantial and the Lie Direct.
line 13154-->  JAQUES. And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut?
line 13155-->  TOUCHSTONE. I durst go no further than the Lie Circumstantial, nor
line 13156-->    he durst not give me the Lie Direct; and so we measur'd swords
line 13157-->    and parted.
line 13158-->  JAQUES. Can you nominate in order now the degrees of the lie?
line 13159-->  TOUCHSTONE. O, sir, we quarrel in print by the book, as you have
line 13160-->    books for good manners. I will name you the degrees. The first,
line 13161-->    the Retort Courteous; the second, the Quip Modest; the third, the
line 13162-->    Reply Churlish; the fourth, the Reproof Valiant; the fifth, the
line 13163-->    Countercheck Quarrelsome; the sixth, the Lie with Circumstance;
line 13164-->    the seventh, the Lie Direct. All these you may avoid but the Lie
line 13165-->    Direct; and you may avoid that too with an If. I knew when seven
line 13166-->    justices could not take up a quarrel; but when the parties were
line 13167-->    met themselves, one of them thought but of an If, as: 'If you  
line 13168-->    said so, then I said so.' And they shook hands, and swore
line 13169-->    brothers. Your If is the only peace-maker; much virtue in If.
line 13170-->  JAQUES. Is not this a rare fellow, my lord?
line 13171-->    He's as good at any thing, and yet a fool.
line 13172-->  DUKE SENIOR. He uses his folly like a stalking-horse, and under the
line 13173-->    presentation of that he shoots his wit:
line 13174-->
line 13175-->          Enter HYMEN, ROSALIND, and CELIA. Still MUSIC
line 13176-->
line 13177-->    HYMEN.    Then is there mirth in heaven,
line 13178-->              When earthly things made even
line 13179-->                Atone together.
line 13180-->              Good Duke, receive thy daughter;
line 13181-->              Hymen from heaven brought her,
line 13182-->                Yea, brought her hither,
line 13183-->              That thou mightst join her hand with his,
line 13184-->              Whose heart within his bosom is.
line 13185-->  ROSALIND. [To DUKE] To you I give myself, for I am yours.
line 13186-->    [To ORLANDO] To you I give myself, for I am yours.
line 13187-->  DUKE SENIOR. If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter.  
line 13188-->  ORLANDO. If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind.
line 13189-->  PHEBE. If sight and shape be true,
line 13190-->    Why then, my love adieu!
line 13191-->  ROSALIND. I'll have no father, if you be not he;
line 13192-->    I'll have no husband, if you be not he;
line 13193-->    Nor ne'er wed woman, if you be not she.
line 13194-->  HYMEN.    Peace, ho! I bar confusion;
line 13195-->            'Tis I must make conclusion
line 13196-->              Of these most strange events.
line 13197-->            Here's eight that must take hands
line 13198-->            To join in Hymen's bands,
line 13199-->              If truth holds true contents.
line 13200-->            You and you no cross shall part;
line 13201-->            You and you are heart in heart;
line 13202-->            You to his love must accord,
line 13203-->            Or have a woman to your lord;
line 13204-->            You and you are sure together,
line 13205-->            As the winter to foul weather.
line 13206-->            Whiles a wedlock-hymn we sing,
line 13207-->            Feed yourselves with questioning,  
line 13208-->            That reason wonder may diminish,
line 13209-->            How thus we met, and these things finish.
line 13210-->
line 13211-->                       SONG
line 13212-->            Wedding is great Juno's crown;
line 13213-->              O blessed bond of board and bed!
line 13214-->            'Tis Hymen peoples every town;
line 13215-->              High wedlock then be honoured.
line 13216-->            Honour, high honour, and renown,
line 13217-->            To Hymen, god of every town!
line 13218-->
line 13219-->  DUKE SENIOR. O my dear niece, welcome thou art to me!
line 13220-->    Even daughter, welcome in no less degree.
line 13221-->  PHEBE. I will not eat my word, now thou art mine;
line 13222-->    Thy faith my fancy to thee doth combine.
line 13223-->
line 13224-->                 Enter JAQUES de BOYS
line 13225-->
line 13226-->  JAQUES de BOYS. Let me have audience for a word or two.
line 13227-->    I am the second son of old Sir Rowland,  
line 13228-->    That bring these tidings to this fair assembly.
line 13229-->    Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day
line 13230-->    Men of great worth resorted to this forest,
line 13231-->    Address'd a mighty power; which were on foot,
line 13232-->    In his own conduct, purposely to take
line 13233-->    His brother here, and put him to the sword;
line 13234-->    And to the skirts of this wild wood he came,
line 13235-->    Where, meeting with an old religious man,
line 13236-->    After some question with him, was converted
line 13237-->    Both from his enterprise and from the world;
line 13238-->    His crown bequeathing to his banish'd brother,
line 13239-->    And all their lands restor'd to them again
line 13240-->    That were with him exil'd. This to be true
line 13241-->    I do engage my life.
line 13242-->  DUKE SENIOR. Welcome, young man.
line 13243-->    Thou offer'st fairly to thy brothers' wedding:
line 13244-->    To one, his lands withheld; and to the other,
line 13245-->    A land itself at large, a potent dukedom.
line 13246-->    First, in this forest let us do those ends
line 13247-->    That here were well begun and well begot;  
line 13248-->    And after, every of this happy number,
line 13249-->    That have endur'd shrewd days and nights with us,
line 13250-->    Shall share the good of our returned fortune,
line 13251-->    According to the measure of their states.
line 13252-->    Meantime, forget this new-fall'n dignity,
line 13253-->    And fall into our rustic revelry.
line 13254-->    Play, music; and you brides and bridegrooms all,
line 13255-->    With measure heap'd in joy, to th' measures fall.
line 13256-->  JAQUES. Sir, by your patience. If I heard you rightly,
line 13257-->    The Duke hath put on a religious life,
line 13258-->    And thrown into neglect the pompous court.
line 13259-->  JAQUES DE BOYS. He hath.
line 13260-->  JAQUES. To him will I. Out of these convertites
line 13261-->    There is much matter to be heard and learn'd.
line 13262-->    [To DUKE] You to your former honour I bequeath;
line 13263-->    Your patience and your virtue well deserves it.
line 13264-->    [To ORLANDO] You to a love that your true faith doth merit;
line 13265-->    [To OLIVER] You to your land, and love, and great allies
line 13266-->    [To SILVIUS] You to a long and well-deserved bed;
line 13267-->    [To TOUCHSTONE] And you to wrangling; for thy loving voyage  
line 13268-->    Is but for two months victuall'd.- So to your pleasures;
line 13269-->    I am for other than for dancing measures.
line 13270-->  DUKE SENIOR. Stay, Jaques, stay.
line 13271-->  JAQUES. To see no pastime I. What you would have
line 13272-->    I'll stay to know at your abandon'd cave.               Exit
line 13273-->  DUKE SENIOR. Proceed, proceed. We will begin these rites,
line 13274-->    As we do trust they'll end, in true delights.    [A dance] Exeunt
line 13275-->
line 13276-->EPILOGUE
line 13277-->                           EPILOGUE.
line 13278-->  ROSALIND. It is not the fashion to see the lady the epilogue; but
line 13279-->    it is no more unhandsome than to see the lord the prologue. If it
line 13280-->    be true that good wine needs no bush, 'tis true that a good play
line 13281-->    needs no epilogue. Yet to good wine they do use good bushes; and
line 13282-->    good plays prove the better by the help of good epilogues. What a
line 13283-->    case am I in then, that am neither a good epilogue, nor cannot
line 13284-->    insinuate with you in the behalf of a good play! I am not
line 13285-->    furnish'd like a beggar; therefore to beg will not become me. My
line 13286-->    way is to conjure you; and I'll begin with the women. I charge
line 13287-->    you, O women, for the love you bear to men, to like as much of
line 13288-->    this play as please you; and I charge you, O men, for the love
line 13289-->    you bear to women- as I perceive by your simp'ring none of you
line 13290-->    hates them- that between you and the women the play may please.
line 13291-->    If I were a woman, I would kiss as many of you as had beards that
line 13292-->    pleas'd me, complexions that lik'd me, and breaths that I defied
line 13293-->    not; and, I am sure, as many as have good beards, or good faces,
line 13294-->    or sweet breaths, will, for my kind offer, when I make curtsy,
line 13295-->    bid me farewell.
line 13296-->
line 13297-->THE END
line 13298-->
line 13299-->

line 13323-->SOLINUS, Duke of Ephesus
line 13324-->AEGEON, a merchant of Syracuse
line 13325-->
line 13326-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS twin brothers and sons to
line 13327-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Aegion and Aemelia
line 13328-->
line 13329-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS twin brothers, and attendants on
line 13330-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE the two Antipholuses
line 13331-->
line 13332-->BALTHAZAR, a merchant
line 13333-->ANGELO, a goldsmith
line 13334-->FIRST MERCHANT, friend to Antipholus of Syracuse
line 13335-->SECOND MERCHANT, to whom Angelo is a debtor
line 13336-->PINCH, a schoolmaster
line 13337-->
line 13338-->AEMILIA, wife to AEgeon; an abbess at Ephesus
line 13339-->ADRIANA, wife to Antipholus of Ephesus
line 13340-->LUCIANA, her sister
line 13341-->LUCE, servant to Adriana
line 13342-->
line 13343-->A COURTEZAN
line 13344-->
line 13345-->Gaoler, Officers, Attendants
line 13346-->
line 13347-->
line 13348-->
line 13349-->
line 13350-->
line 13351-->SCENE:
line 13352-->Ephesus
line 13353-->
line 13354-->
line 13355--><<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
line 13356-->SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND IS
line 13357-->PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
line 13358-->WITH PERMISSION.  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
line 13359-->DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
line 13360-->PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
line 13361-->COMMERCIALLY.  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
line 13362-->SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>>
line 13363-->
line 13364-->
line 13365-->
line 13366-->
line 13367-->THE COMEDY OF ERRORS
line 13368-->
line 13369-->ACT I. SCENE 1
line 13370-->
line 13371-->A hall in the DUKE'S palace
line 13372-->
line 13373-->Enter the DUKE OF EPHESUS, AEGEON, the Merchant
line 13374-->of Syracuse, GAOLER, OFFICERS, and other ATTENDANTS
line 13375-->
line 13376-->AEGEON. Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall,
line 13377-->  And by the doom of death end woes and all.
line 13378-->DUKE. Merchant of Syracuse, plead no more;
line 13379-->  I am not partial to infringe our laws.
line 13380-->  The enmity and discord which of late
line 13381-->  Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your duke
line 13382-->  To merchants, our well-dealing countrymen,
line 13383-->  Who, wanting guilders to redeem their lives,
line 13384-->  Have seal'd his rigorous statutes with their bloods,
line 13385-->  Excludes all pity from our threat'ning looks.
line 13386-->  For, since the mortal and intestine jars
line 13387-->  'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us,
line 13388-->  It hath in solemn synods been decreed,
line 13389-->  Both by the Syracusians and ourselves,
line 13390-->  To admit no traffic to our adverse towns;
line 13391-->  Nay, more: if any born at Ephesus
line 13392-->  Be seen at any Syracusian marts and fairs;
line 13393-->  Again, if any Syracusian born
line 13394-->  Come to the bay of Ephesus-he dies,
line 13395-->  His goods confiscate to the Duke's dispose,
line 13396-->  Unless a thousand marks be levied,
line 13397-->  To quit the penalty and to ransom him.
line 13398-->  Thy substance, valued at the highest rate,
line 13399-->  Cannot amount unto a hundred marks;
line 13400-->  Therefore by law thou art condemn'd to die.
line 13401-->AEGEON. Yet this my comfort: when your words are done,
line 13402-->  My woes end likewise with the evening sun.
line 13403-->DUKE. Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause
line 13404-->  Why thou departed'st from thy native home,
line 13405-->  And for what cause thou cam'st to Ephesus.
line 13406-->AEGEON. A heavier task could not have been impos'd
line 13407-->  Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable;
line 13408-->  Yet, that the world may witness that my end
line 13409-->  Was wrought by nature, not by vile offence,
line 13410-->  I'll utter what my sorrow gives me leave.
line 13411-->  In Syracuse was I born, and wed
line 13412-->  Unto a woman, happy but for me,
line 13413-->  And by me, had not our hap been bad.
line 13414-->  With her I liv'd in joy; our wealth increas'd
line 13415-->  By prosperous voyages I often made
line 13416-->  To Epidamnum; till my factor's death,
line 13417-->  And the great care of goods at random left,
line 13418-->  Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse:
line 13419-->  From whom my absence was not six months old,
line 13420-->  Before herself, almost at fainting under
line 13421-->  The pleasing punishment that women bear,
line 13422-->  Had made provision for her following me,
line 13423-->  And soon and safe arrived where I was.
line 13424-->  There had she not been long but she became
line 13425-->  A joyful mother of two goodly sons;
line 13426-->  And, which was strange, the one so like the other
line 13427-->  As could not be disdnguish'd but by names.
line 13428-->  That very hour, and in the self-same inn,
line 13429-->  A mean woman was delivered
line 13430-->  Of such a burden, male twins, both alike.
line 13431-->  Those, for their parents were exceeding poor,
line 13432-->  I bought, and brought up to attend my sons.
line 13433-->  My wife, not meanly proud of two such boys,
line 13434-->  Made daily motions for our home return;
line 13435-->  Unwilling, I agreed. Alas! too soon
line 13436-->  We came aboard.
line 13437-->  A league from Epidamnum had we sail'd
line 13438-->  Before the always-wind-obeying deep
line 13439-->  Gave any tragic instance of our harm:
line 13440-->  But longer did we not retain much hope,
line 13441-->  For what obscured light the heavens did grant
line 13442-->  Did but convey unto our fearful minds
line 13443-->  A doubtful warrant of immediate death;
line 13444-->  Which though myself would gladly have embrac'd,
line 13445-->  Yet the incessant weepings of my wife,
line 13446-->  Weeping before for what she saw must come,
line 13447-->  And piteous plainings of the pretty babes,
line 13448-->  That mourn'd for fashion, ignorant what to fear,
line 13449-->  Forc'd me to seek delays for them and me.
line 13450-->  And this it was, for other means was none:
line 13451-->  The sailors sought for safety by our boat,
line 13452-->  And left the ship, then sinking-ripe, to us;
line 13453-->  My wife, more careful for the latter-born,
line 13454-->  Had fast'ned him unto a small spare mast,
line 13455-->  Such as sea-faring men provide for storms;
line 13456-->  To him one of the other twins was bound,
line 13457-->  Whilst I had been like heedful of the other.
line 13458-->  The children thus dispos'd, my wife and I,
line 13459-->  Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fix'd,
line 13460-->  Fast'ned ourselves at either end the mast,
line 13461-->  And, floating straight, obedient to the stream,
line 13462-->  Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.
line 13463-->  At length the sun, gazing upon the earth,
line 13464-->  Dispers'd those vapours that offended us;
line 13465-->  And, by the benefit of his wished light,
line 13466-->  The seas wax'd calm, and we discovered
line 13467-->  Two ships from far making amain to us-
line 13468-->  Of Corinth that, of Epidaurus this.
line 13469-->  But ere they came-O, let me say no more!
line 13470-->  Gather the sequel by that went before.
line 13471-->DUKE. Nay, forward, old man, do not break off so;
line 13472-->  For we may pity, though not pardon thee.
line 13473-->AEGEON. O, had the gods done so, I had not now
line 13474-->  Worthily term'd them merciless to us!
line 13475-->  For, ere the ships could meet by twice five leagues,
line 13476-->  We were encount'red by a mighty rock,
line 13477-->  Which being violently borne upon,
line 13478-->  Our helpful ship was splitted in the midst;
line 13479-->  So that, in this unjust divorce of us,
line 13480-->  Fortune had left to both of us alike
line 13481-->  What to delight in, what to sorrow for.
line 13482-->  Her part, poor soul, seeming as burdened
line 13483-->  With lesser weight, but not with lesser woe,
line 13484-->  Was carried with more speed before the wind;
line 13485-->  And in our sight they three were taken up
line 13486-->  By fishermen of Corinth, as we thought.
line 13487-->  At length another ship had seiz'd on us;
line 13488-->  And, knowing whom it was their hap to save,
line 13489-->  Gave healthful welcome to their ship-wreck'd guests,
line 13490-->  And would have reft the fishers of their prey,
line 13491-->  Had not their bark been very slow of sail;
line 13492-->  And therefore homeward did they bend their course.
line 13493-->  Thus have you heard me sever'd from my bliss,
line 13494-->  That by misfortunes was my life prolong'd,
line 13495-->  To tell sad stories of my own mishaps.
line 13496-->DUKE. And, for the sake of them thou sorrowest for,
line 13497-->  Do me the favour to dilate at full
line 13498-->  What have befall'n of them and thee till now.
line 13499-->AEGEON. My youngest boy, and yet my eldest care,
line 13500-->  At eighteen years became inquisitive
line 13501-->  After his brother, and importun'd me
line 13502-->  That his attendant-so his case was like,
line 13503-->  Reft of his brother, but retain'd his name-
line 13504-->  Might bear him company in the quest of him;
line 13505-->  Whom whilst I laboured of a love to see,
line 13506-->  I hazarded the loss of whom I lov'd.
line 13507-->  Five summers have I spent in farthest Greece,
line 13508-->  Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia,
line 13509-->  And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus;
line 13510-->  Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought
line 13511-->  Or that or any place that harbours men.
line 13512-->  But here must end the story of my life;
line 13513-->  And happy were I in my timely death,
line 13514-->  Could all my travels warrant me they live.
line 13515-->DUKE. Hapless, Aegeon, whom the fates have mark'd
line 13516-->  To bear the extremity of dire mishap!
line 13517-->  Now, trust me, were it not against our laws,
line 13518-->  Against my crown, my oath, my dignity,
line 13519-->  Which princes, would they, may not disannul,
line 13520-->  My soul should sue as advocate for thee.
line 13521-->  But though thou art adjudged to the death,
line 13522-->  And passed sentence may not be recall'd
line 13523-->  But to our honour's great disparagement,
line 13524-->  Yet will I favour thee in what I can.
line 13525-->  Therefore, merchant, I'll limit thee this day
line 13526-->  To seek thy help by beneficial hap.
line 13527-->  Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus;
line 13528-->  Beg thou, or borrow, to make up the sum,
line 13529-->  And live; if no, then thou art doom'd to die.
line 13530-->  Gaoler, take him to thy custody.
line 13531-->GAOLER. I will, my lord.
line 13532-->AEGEON. Hopeless and helpless doth Aegeon wend,
line 13533-->  But to procrastinate his lifeless end.
line 13534--><Exeunt
line 13535-->
line 13536-->
line 13537-->SCENE 2
line 13538-->
line 13539-->The mart
line 13540-->
line 13541-->Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE, DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, and FIRST MERCHANT
line 13542-->
line 13543-->FIRST MERCHANT. Therefore, give out you are of Epidamnum,
line 13544-->  Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate.
line 13545-->  This very day a Syracusian merchant
line 13546-->  Is apprehended for arrival here;
line 13547-->  And, not being able to buy out his life,
line 13548-->  According to the statute of the town,
line 13549-->  Dies ere the weary sun set in the west.
line 13550-->  There is your money that I had to keep.
line 13551-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host.
line 13552-->  And stay there, Dromio, till I come to thee.
line 13553-->  Within this hour it will be dinner-time;
line 13554-->  Till that, I'll view the manners of the town,
line 13555-->  Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings,
line 13556-->  And then return and sleep within mine inn;
line 13557-->  For with long travel I am stiff and weary.
line 13558-->  Get thee away.
line 13559-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Many a man would take you at your word,
line 13560-->  And go indeed, having so good a mean.
line 13561--><Exit
line 13562-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. A trusty villain, sir, that very oft,
line 13563-->  When I am dull with care and melancholy,
line 13564-->  Lightens my humour with his merry jests.
line 13565-->  What, will you walk with me about the town,
line 13566-->  And then go to my inn and dine with me?
line 13567-->FIRST MERCHANT. I am invited, sir, to certain merchants,
line 13568-->  Of whom I hope to make much benefit;
line 13569-->  I crave your pardon. Soon at five o'clock,
line 13570-->  Please you, I'll meet with you upon the mart,
line 13571-->  And afterward consort you till bed time.
line 13572-->  My present business calls me from you now.
line 13573-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Farewell till then. I will go lose myself,
line 13574-->  And wander up and down to view the city.
line 13575-->FIRST MERCHANT. Sir, I commend you to your own content.
line 13576--><Exit FIRST MERCHANT
line 13577-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. He that commends me to mine own content
line 13578-->  Commends me to the thing I cannot get.
line 13579-->  I to the world am like a drop of water
line 13580-->  That in the ocean seeks another drop,
line 13581-->  Who, falling there to find his fellow forth,
line 13582-->  Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself.
line 13583-->  So I, to find a mother and a brother,
line 13584-->  In quest of them, unhappy, lose myself.
line 13585-->
line 13586-->Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUS
line 13587-->
line 13588-->  Here comes the almanac of my true date.
line 13589-->  What now? How chance thou art return'd so soon?
line 13590-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Return'd so soon! rather approach'd too late.
line 13591-->  The capon burns, the pig falls from the spit;
line 13592-->  The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell-
line 13593-->  My mistress made it one upon my cheek;
line 13594-->  She is so hot because the meat is cold,
line 13595-->  The meat is cold because you come not home,
line 13596-->  You come not home because you have no stomach,
line 13597-->  You have no stomach, having broke your fast;
line 13598-->  But we, that know what 'tis to fast and pray,
line 13599-->  Are penitent for your default to-day.
line 13600-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Stop in your wind, sir; tell me this, I pray:
line 13601-->  Where have you left the money that I gave you?
line 13602-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. O-Sixpence that I had a Wednesday last
line 13603-->  To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper?
line 13604-->  The saddler had it, sir; I kept it not.
line 13605-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I am not in a sportive humour now;
line 13606-->  Tell me, and dally not, where is the money?
line 13607-->  We being strangers here, how dar'st thou trust
line 13608-->  So great a charge from thine own custody?
line 13609-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I pray you jest, sir, as you sit at dinner.
line 13610-->  I from my mistress come to you in post;
line 13611-->  If I return, I shall be post indeed,
line 13612-->  For she will score your fault upon my pate.
line 13613-->  Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock,
line 13614-->  And strike you home without a messenger.
line 13615-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season;
line 13616-->  Reserve them till a merrier hour than this.
line 13617-->  Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?
line 13618-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. To me, sir? Why, you gave no gold to me.
line 13619-->  ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Come on, sir knave, have done your foolishness,
line 13620-->  And tell me how thou hast dispos'd thy charge.
line 13621-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. My charge was but to fetch you from the mart
line 13622-->  Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner.
line 13623-->  My mistress and her sister stays for you.
line 13624-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Now, as I am a Christian, answer me
line 13625-->  In what safe place you have bestow'd my money,
line 13626-->  Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours,
line 13627-->  That stands on tricks when I am undispos'd.
line 13628-->  Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?
line 13629-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I have some marks of yours upon my pate,
line 13630-->  Some of my mistress' marks upon my shoulders,
line 13631-->  But not a thousand marks between you both.
line 13632-->  If I should pay your worship those again,
line 13633-->  Perchance you will not bear them patiently.
line 13634-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thy mistress' marks! What mistress, slave, hast thou?
line 13635-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Your worship's wife, my mistress at the Phoenix;
line 13636-->  She that doth fast till you come home to dinner,
line 13637-->  And prays that you will hie you home to dinner.
line 13638-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face,
line 13639-->  Being forbid? There, take you that, sir knave.
line 13640-->[Beats him]
line 13641-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. What mean you, sir? For God's sake hold your hands!
line 13642-->  Nay, an you will not, sir, I'll take my heels.
line 13643--><Exit
line 13644-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Upon my life, by some device or other
line 13645-->  The villain is o'erraught of all my money.
line 13646-->  They say this town is full of cozenage;
line 13647-->  As, nimble jugglers that deceive the eye,
line 13648-->  Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind,
line 13649-->  Soul-killing witches that deform the body,
line 13650-->  Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks,
line 13651-->  And many such-like liberties of sin;
line 13652-->  If it prove so, I will be gone the sooner.
line 13653-->  I'll to the Centaur to go seek this slave.
line 13654-->  I greatly fear my money is not safe.
line 13655--><Exit
line 13656-->
line 13657-->

line 13659-->SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND IS

line 13666-->
line 13667-->
line 13668-->
line 13669-->
line 13670-->
line 13671-->ACT Il. SCENE 1
line 13672-->
line 13673-->The house of ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
line 13674-->
line 13675-->Enter ADRIANA, wife to ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS, with LUCIANA, her sister
line 13676-->
line 13677-->ADRIANA. Neither my husband nor the slave return'd
line 13678-->  That in such haste I sent to seek his master!
line 13679-->  Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.
line 13680-->LUCIANA. Perhaps some merchant hath invited him,
line 13681-->  And from the mart he's somewhere gone to dinner;
line 13682-->  Good sister, let us dine, and never fret.
line 13683-->  A man is master of his liberty;
line 13684-->  Time is their master, and when they see time,
line 13685-->  They'll go or come. If so, be patient, sister.
line 13686-->ADRIANA. Why should their liberty than ours be more?
line 13687-->LUCIANA. Because their business still lies out o' door.
line 13688-->ADRIANA. Look when I serve him so, he takes it ill.
line 13689-->LUCIANA. O, know he is the bridle of your will.
line 13690-->ADRIANA. There's none but asses will be bridled so.
line 13691-->LUCIANA. Why, headstrong liberty is lash'd with woe.
line 13692-->  There's nothing situate under heaven's eye
line 13693-->  But hath his bound, in earth, in sea, in sky.
line 13694-->  The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowls,
line 13695-->  Are their males' subjects, and at their controls.
line 13696-->  Man, more divine, the master of all these,
line 13697-->  Lord of the wide world and wild wat'ry seas,
line 13698-->  Indu'd with intellectual sense and souls,
line 13699-->  Of more pre-eminence than fish and fowls,
line 13700-->  Are masters to their females, and their lords;
line 13701-->  Then let your will attend on their accords.
line 13702-->ADRIANA. This servitude makes you to keep unwed.
line 13703-->LUCIANA. Not this, but troubles of the marriage-bed.
line 13704-->ADRIANA. But, were you wedded, you would bear some sway.
line 13705-->LUCIANA. Ere I learn love, I'll practise to obey.
line 13706-->ADRIANA. How if your husband start some other where?
line 13707-->LUCIANA. Till he come home again, I would forbear.
line 13708-->ADRIANA. Patience unmov'd! no marvel though she pause:
line 13709-->  They can be meek that have no other cause.
line 13710-->  A wretched soul, bruis'd with adversity,
line 13711-->  We bid be quiet when we hear it cry;
line 13712-->  But were we burd'ned with like weight of pain,
line 13713-->  As much, or more, we should ourselves complain.
line 13714-->  So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee,
line 13715-->  With urging helpless patience would relieve me;
line 13716-->  But if thou live to see like right bereft,
line 13717-->  This fool-begg'd patience in thee will be left.
line 13718-->LUCIANA. Well, I will marry one day, but to try.
line 13719-->  Here comes your man, now is your husband nigh.
line 13720-->
line 13721-->Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUS
line 13722-->
line 13723-->ADRIANA. Say, is your tardy master now at hand?
line 13724-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Nay, he's at two hands with me, and that my two
line 13725-->  ears can witness.
line 13726-->ADRIANA. Say, didst thou speak with him? Know'st thou his mind?
line 13727-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Ay, ay, he told his mind upon mine ear.
line 13728-->  Beshrew his hand, I scarce could understand it.
line 13729-->LUCIANA. Spake he so doubtfully thou could'st not feel his meaning?
line 13730-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Nay, he struck so plainly I could to
line 13731-->  well feel his blows; and withal so doubtfully that I could
line 13732-->  scarce understand them.
line 13733-->ADRIANA. But say, I prithee, is he coming home?
line 13734-->  It seems he hath great care to please his wife.
line 13735-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Why, mistress, sure my master is horn-mad.
line 13736-->ADRIANA. Horn-mad, thou villain!
line 13737-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I mean not cuckold-mad;
line 13738-->  But, sure, he is stark mad.
line 13739-->  When I desir'd him to come home to dinner,
line 13740-->  He ask'd me for a thousand marks in gold.
line 13741-->  "Tis dinner time' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he.
line 13742-->  'Your meat doth burn' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he.
line 13743-->  'Will you come home?' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he.
line 13744-->  'Where is the thousand marks I gave thee, villain?'
line 13745-->  'The pig' quoth I 'is burn'd'; 'My gold!' quoth he.
line 13746-->  'My mistress, sir,' quoth I; 'Hang up thy mistress;
line 13747-->  I know not thy mistress; out on thy mistress.'
line 13748-->LUCIANA. Quoth who?
line 13749-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Quoth my master.
line 13750-->  'I know' quoth he 'no house, no wife, no mistress.'
line 13751-->  So that my errand, due unto my tongue,
line 13752-->  I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders;
line 13753-->  For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.
line 13754-->ADRIANA. Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.
line 13755-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Go back again, and be new beaten home?
line 13756-->  For God's sake, send some other messenger.
line 13757-->ADRIANA. Back, slave, or I will break thy pate across.
line 13758-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. And he will bless that cross with other beating;
line 13759-->  Between you I shall have a holy head.
line 13760-->ADRIANA. Hence, prating peasant! Fetch thy master home.
line 13761-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Am I so round with you, as you with me,
line 13762-->  That like a football you do spurn me thus?
line 13763-->  You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither;
line 13764-->  If I last in this service, you must case me in leather.
line 13765--><Exit
line 13766-->LUCIANA. Fie, how impatience loureth in your face!
line 13767-->ADRIANA. His company must do his minions grace,
line 13768-->  Whilst I at home starve for a merry look.
line 13769-->  Hath homely age th' alluring beauty took
line 13770-->  From my poor cheek? Then he hath wasted it.
line 13771-->  Are my discourses dull? Barren my wit?
line 13772-->  If voluble and sharp discourse be marr'd,
line 13773-->  Unkindness blunts it more than marble hard.
line 13774-->  Do their gay vestments his affections bait?
line 13775-->  That's not my fault; he's master of my state.
line 13776-->  What ruins are in me that can be found
line 13777-->  By him not ruin'd? Then is he the ground
line 13778-->  Of my defeatures. My decayed fair
line 13779-->  A sunny look of his would soon repair.
line 13780-->  But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale,
line 13781-->  And feeds from home; poor I am but his stale.
line 13782-->LUCIANA. Self-harming jealousy! fie, beat it hence.
line 13783-->ADRIANA. Unfeeling fools can with such wrongs dispense.
line 13784-->  I know his eye doth homage otherwhere;
line 13785-->  Or else what lets it but he would be here?
line 13786-->  Sister, you know he promis'd me a chain;
line 13787-->  Would that alone a love he would detain,
line 13788-->  So he would keep fair quarter with his bed!
line 13789-->  I see the jewel best enamelled
line 13790-->  Will lose his beauty; yet the gold bides still
line 13791-->  That others touch and, often touching, will
line 13792-->  Where gold; and no man that hath a name
line 13793-->  By falsehood and corruption doth it shame.
line 13794-->  Since that my beauty cannot please his eye,
line 13795-->  I'll weep what's left away, and weeping die.
line 13796-->LUCIANA. How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!
line 13797--><Exeunt
line 13798-->
line 13799-->
line 13800-->SCENE 2
line 13801-->
line 13802-->The mart
line 13803-->
line 13804-->Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
line 13805-->
line 13806-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up
line 13807-->  Safe at the Centaur, and the heedful slave
line 13808-->  Is wand'red forth in care to seek me out.
line 13809-->  By computation and mine host's report
line 13810-->  I could not speak with Dromio since at first
line 13811-->  I sent him from the mart. See, here he comes.
line 13812-->
line 13813-->Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
line 13814-->
line 13815-->  How now, sir, is your merry humour alter'd?
line 13816-->  As you love strokes, so jest with me again.
line 13817-->  You know no Centaur! You receiv'd no gold!
line 13818-->  Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner!
line 13819-->  My house was at the Phoenix! Wast thou mad,
line 13820-->  That thus so madly thou didst answer me?
line 13821-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. What answer, sir? When spake I such a word?
line 13822-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Even now, even here, not half an hour since.
line 13823-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I did not see you since you sent me hence,
line 13824-->  Home to the Centaur, with the gold you gave me.
line 13825-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Villain, thou didst deny the gold's receipt,
line 13826-->  And told'st me of a mistress and a dinner;
line 13827-->  For which, I hope, thou felt'st I was displeas'd.
line 13828-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I am glad to see you in this merry vein.
line 13829-->  What means this jest? I pray you, master, tell me.
line 13830-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth?
line 13831-->  Think'st thou I jest? Hold, take thou that, and that.
line 13832-->[Beating him]
line 13833-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Hold, sir, for God's sake! Now your jest is earnest.
line 13834-->  Upon what bargain do you give it me?
line 13835-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Because that I familiarly sometimes
line 13836-->  Do use you for my fool and chat with you,
line 13837-->  Your sauciness will jest upon my love,
line 13838-->  And make a common of my serious hours.
line 13839-->  When the sun shines let foolish gnats make sport,
line 13840-->  But creep in crannies when he hides his beams.
line 13841-->  If you will jest with me, know my aspect,
line 13842-->  And fashion your demeanour to my looks,
line 13843-->  Or I will beat this method in your sconce.
line 13844-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Sconce, call you it? So you would
line 13845-->  leave battering, I had rather have it a head. An you use
line 13846-->  these blows long, I must get a sconce for my head, and
line 13847-->  insconce it too; or else I shall seek my wit in my shoulders.
line 13848-->  But I pray, sir, why am I beaten?
line 13849-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Dost thou not know?
line 13850-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Nothing, sir, but that I am beaten.
line 13851-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Shall I tell you why?
line 13852-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Ay, sir, and wherefore; for they say
line 13853-->  every why hath a wherefore.
line 13854-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, first for flouting me; and then wherefore,
line 13855-->  For urging it the second time to me.
line 13856-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season,
line 13857-->  When in the why and the wherefore is neither rhyme nor reason?
line 13858-->  Well, sir, I thank you.
line 13859-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thank me, sir! for what?
line 13860-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Marry, sir, for this something that you gave
line 13861-->  me for nothing.
line 13862-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I'll make you amends next, to
line 13863-->  give you nothing for something. But say, sir, is it dinnertime?
line 13864-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No, sir; I think the meat wants that I have.
line 13865-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. In good time, sir, what's that?
line 13866-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Basting.
line 13867-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Well, sir, then 'twill be dry.
line 13868-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. If it be, sir, I pray you eat none of it.
line 13869-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Your reason?
line 13870-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Lest it make you choleric, and purchase me
line 13871-->  another dry basting.
line 13872-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Well, sir, learn to jest in good time;
line 13873-->  there's a time for all things.
line 13874-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I durst have denied that, before you
line 13875-->  were so choleric.
line 13876-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. By what rule, sir?
line 13877-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the
line 13878-->  plain bald pate of Father Time himself.
line 13879-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Let's hear it.
line 13880-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. There's no time for a man to recover
line 13881-->  his hair that grows bald by nature.
line 13882-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. May he not do it by fine and recovery?
line 13883-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig, and
line 13884-->  recover the lost hair of another man.
line 13885-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why is Time such a niggard of
line 13886-->  hair, being, as it is, so plentiful an excrement?
line 13887-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Because it is a blessing that he bestows
line 13888-->  on beasts, and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath
line 13889-->  given them in wit.
line 13890-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, but there's many a man
line 13891-->  hath more hair than wit.
line 13892-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Not a man of those but he hath the
line 13893-->  wit to lose his hair.
line 13894-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, thou didst conclude hairy
line 13895-->  men plain dealers without wit.
line 13896-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. The plainer dealer, the sooner lost;
line 13897-->  yet he loseth it in a kind of jollity.
line 13898-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. For what reason?
line 13899-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. For two; and sound ones too.
line 13900-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Nay, not sound I pray you.
line 13901-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Sure ones, then.
line 13902-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.
line 13903-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Certain ones, then.
line 13904-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Name them.
line 13905-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. The one, to save the money that he spends in
line 13906-->  tiring; the other, that at dinner they should not drop in his
line 13907-->  porridge.
line 13908-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. You would all this time have prov'd there
line 13909-->  is no time for all things.
line 13910-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Marry, and did, sir; namely, no time to recover
line 13911-->  hair lost by nature.
line 13912-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. But your reason was not substantial, why
line 13913-->  there is no time to recover.
line 13914-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald,
line 13915-->  and therefore to the world's end will have bald followers.
line 13916-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I knew 't'would be a bald conclusion. But,
line 13917-->  soft, who wafts us yonder?
line 13918-->
line 13919-->Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA
line 13920-->
line 13921-->ADRIANA. Ay, ay, Antipholus, look strange and frown.
line 13922-->  Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects;
line 13923-->  I am not Adriana, nor thy wife.
line 13924-->  The time was once when thou unurg'd wouldst vow
line 13925-->  That never words were music to thine ear,
line 13926-->  That never object pleasing in thine eye,
line 13927-->  That never touch well welcome to thy hand,
line 13928-->  That never meat sweet-savour'd in thy taste,
line 13929-->  Unless I spake, or look'd, or touch'd, or carv'd to thee.
line 13930-->  How comes it now, my husband, O, how comes it,
line 13931-->  That thou art then estranged from thyself?
line 13932-->  Thyself I call it, being strange to me,
line 13933-->  That, undividable, incorporate,
line 13934-->  Am better than thy dear self's better part.
line 13935-->  Ah, do not tear away thyself from me;
line 13936-->  For know, my love, as easy mayst thou fall
line 13937-->  A drop of water in the breaking gulf,
line 13938-->  And take unmingled thence that drop again
line 13939-->  Without addition or diminishing,
line 13940-->  As take from me thyself, and not me too.
line 13941-->  How dearly would it touch thee to the quick,
line 13942-->  Should'st thou but hear I were licentious,
line 13943-->  And that this body, consecrate to thee,
line 13944-->  By ruffian lust should be contaminate!
line 13945-->  Wouldst thou not spit at me and spurn at me,
line 13946-->  And hurl the name of husband in my face,
line 13947-->  And tear the stain'd skin off my harlot-brow,
line 13948-->  And from my false hand cut the wedding-ring,
line 13949-->  And break it with a deep-divorcing vow?
line 13950-->  I know thou canst, and therefore see thou do it.
line 13951-->  I am possess'd with an adulterate blot;
line 13952-->  My blood is mingled with the crime of lust;
line 13953-->  For if we two be one, and thou play false,
line 13954-->  I do digest the poison of thy flesh,
line 13955-->  Being strumpeted by thy contagion.
line 13956-->  Keep then fair league and truce with thy true bed;
line 13957-->  I live dis-stain'd, thou undishonoured.
line 13958-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Plead you to me, fair dame? I know you not:
line 13959-->  In Ephesus I am but two hours old,
line 13960-->  As strange unto your town as to your talk,
line 13961-->  Who, every word by all my wit being scann'd,
line 13962-->  Wants wit in all one word to understand.
line 13963-->LUCIANA. Fie, brother, how the world is chang'd with you!
line 13964-->  When were you wont to use my sister thus?
line 13965-->  She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner.
line 13966-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. By Dromio?
line 13967-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. By me?
line 13968-->ADRIANA. By thee; and this thou didst return from him-
line 13969-->  That he did buffet thee, and in his blows
line 13970-->  Denied my house for his, me for his wife.
line 13971-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman?
line 13972-->  What is the course and drift of your compact?
line 13973-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I, Sir? I never saw her till this time.
line 13974-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Villain, thou liest; for even her very words
line 13975-->  Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.
line 13976-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I never spake with her in all my life.
line 13977-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. How can she thus, then, call us by our names,
line 13978-->  Unless it be by inspiration?
line 13979-->ADRIANA. How ill agrees it with your gravity
line 13980-->  To counterfeit thus grossly with your slave,
line 13981-->  Abetting him to thwart me in my mood!
line 13982-->  Be it my wrong you are from me exempt,
line 13983-->  But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt.
line 13984-->  Come, I will fasten on this sleeve of thine;
line 13985-->  Thou art an elm, my husband, I a vine,
line 13986-->  Whose weakness, married to thy stronger state,
line 13987-->  Makes me with thy strength to communicate.
line 13988-->  If aught possess thee from me, it is dross,
line 13989-->  Usurping ivy, brier, or idle moss;
line 13990-->  Who all, for want of pruning, with intrusion
line 13991-->  Infect thy sap, and live on thy confusion.
line 13992-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. To me she speaks; she moves me for her theme.
line 13993-->  What, was I married to her in my dream?
line 13994-->  Or sleep I now, and think I hear all this?
line 13995-->  What error drives our eyes and ears amiss?
line 13996-->  Until I know this sure uncertainty,
line 13997-->  I'll entertain the offer'd fallacy.
line 13998-->LUCIANA. Dromio, go bid the servants spread for dinner.
line 13999-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O, for my beads! I cross me for sinner.
line 14000-->  This is the fairy land. O spite of spites!
line 14001-->  We talk with goblins, owls, and sprites.
line 14002-->  If we obey them not, this will ensue:
line 14003-->  They'll suck our breath, or pinch us black and blue.
line 14004-->LUCIANA. Why prat'st thou to thyself, and answer'st not?
line 14005-->  Dromio, thou drone, thou snail, thou slug, thou sot!
line 14006-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I am transformed, master, am not I?
line 14007-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I think thou art in mind, and so am I.
line 14008-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.
line 14009-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thou hast thine own form.
line 14010-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No, I am an ape.
line 14011-->LUCIANA. If thou art chang'd to aught, 'tis to an ass.
line 14012-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 'Tis true; she rides me, and I long for grass.
line 14013-->  'Tis so, I am an ass; else it could never be
line 14014-->  But I should know her as well as she knows me.
line 14015-->ADRIANA. Come, come, no longer will I be a fool,
line 14016-->  To put the finger in the eye and weep,
line 14017-->  Whilst man and master laughs my woes to scorn.
line 14018-->  Come, sir, to dinner. Dromio, keep the gate.
line 14019-->  Husband, I'll dine above with you to-day,
line 14020-->  And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks.
line 14021-->  Sirrah, if any ask you for your master,
line 14022-->  Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter.
line 14023-->  Come, sister. Dromio, play the porter well.
line 14024-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hell?
line 14025-->  Sleeping or waking, mad or well-advis'd?
line 14026-->  Known unto these, and to myself disguis'd!
line 14027-->  I'll say as they say, and persever so,
line 14028-->  And in this mist at all adventures go.
line 14029-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, shall I be porter at the gate?
line 14030-->ADRIANA. Ay; and let none enter, lest I break your pate.
line 14031-->LUCIANA. Come, come, Antipholus, we dine too late.
line 14032--><Exeunt
line 14033-->
line 14034-->
