line 14045-->
line 14046-->
line 14047-->
line 14048-->ACT III. SCENE 1
line 14049-->
line 14050-->Before the house of ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
line 14051-->
line 14052-->Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS, DROMIO OF EPHESUS, ANGELO, and BALTHAZAR
line 14053-->
line 14054-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all;
line 14055-->  My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours.
line 14056-->  Say that I linger'd with you at your shop
line 14057-->  To see the making of her carcanet,
line 14058-->  And that to-morrow you will bring it home.
line 14059-->  But here's a villain that would face me down
line 14060-->  He met me on the mart, and that I beat him,
line 14061-->  And charg'd him with a thousand marks in gold,
line 14062-->  And that I did deny my wife and house.
line 14063-->  Thou drunkard, thou, what didst thou mean by this?
line 14064-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Say what you will, sir, but I know what I know.
line 14065-->  That you beat me at the mart I have your hand to show;
line 14066-->  If the skin were parchment, and the blows you gave were ink,
line 14067-->  Your own handwriting would tell you what I think.
line 14068-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I think thou art an ass.
line 14069-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Marry, so it doth appear
line 14070-->  By the wrongs I suffer and the blows I bear.
line 14071-->  I should kick, being kick'd; and being at that pass,
line 14072-->  You would keep from my heels, and beware of an ass.
line 14073-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Y'are sad, Signior Balthazar; pray God our cheer
line 14074-->  May answer my good will and your good welcome here.
line 14075-->BALTHAZAR. I hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your welcome dear.
line 14076-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. O, Signior Balthazar, either at flesh or fish,
line 14077-->  A table full of welcome makes scarce one dainty dish.
line 14078-->BALTHAZAR. Good meat, sir, is common; that every churl affords.
line 14079-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. And welcome more common; for that's nothing
line 14080-->  but words.
line 14081-->BALTHAZAR. Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.
line 14082-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Ay, to a niggardly host and more sparing guest.
line 14083-->  But though my cates be mean, take them in good part;
line 14084-->  Better cheer may you have, but not with better heart.
line 14085-->  But, soft, my door is lock'd; go bid them let us in.
line 14086-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Maud, Bridget, Marian, Cicely, Gillian, Ginn!
line 14087-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. [Within] Mome, malt-horse, capon, coxcomb, idiot, patch!
line 14088-->  Either get thee from the door, or sit down at the hatch.
line 14089-->  Dost thou conjure for wenches, that thou call'st for such store,
line 14090-->  When one is one too many? Go get thee from the door.
line 14091-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. What patch is made our porter?
line 14092-->  My master stays in the street.
line 14093-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.  [Within]  Let him walk from whence he came,
line 14094-->    lest he catch cold on's feet.
line 14095-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Who talks within there? Ho, open the door!
line 14096-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.  [Within]  Right, sir; I'll tell you when,
line 14097-->    an you'll tell me wherefore.
line 14098-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Wherefore? For my dinner;
line 14099-->    I have not din'd to-day.
line 14100-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.  [Within]  Nor to-day here you must not;
line 14101-->    come again when you may.
line 14102-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. What art thou that keep'st me out
line 14103-->    from the house I owe?
line 14104-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.  [Within]  The porter for this time,
line 14105-->    sir, and my name is Dromio.
line 14106-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. O Villain, thou hast stol'n both mine
line 14107-->    office and my name!
line 14108-->  The one ne'er got me credit, the other mickle blame.
line 14109-->  If thou hadst been Dromio to-day in my place,
line 14110-->  Thou wouldst have chang'd thy face for a name, or thy name for an ass.
line 14111-->
line 14112-->Enter LUCE, within
line 14113-->
line 14114-->LUCE.  [Within]  What a coil is there, Dromio? Who are those at the gate?
line 14115-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Let my master in, Luce.
line 14116-->LUCE.  [Within]  Faith, no, he comes too late;
line 14117-->  And so tell your master.
line 14118-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. O Lord, I must laugh!
line 14119-->  Have at you with a proverb: Shall I set in my staff?
line 14120-->LUCE.  [Within]  Have at you with another: that's-when? can you tell?
line 14121-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.  [Within]  If thy name be called Luce
line 14122-->    -Luce, thou hast answer'd him well.
line 14123-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Do you hear, you minion? You'll let us in, I hope?
line 14124-->LUCE.  [Within]  I thought to have ask'd you.
line 14125-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.  [Within]  And you said no.
line 14126-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. SO, Come, help: well struck! there was blow for blow.
line 14127-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Thou baggage, let me in.
line 14128-->LUCE.  [Within]  Can you tell for whose sake?
line 14129-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Master, knock the door hard.
line 14130-->LUCE.  [Within]  Let him knock till it ache.
line 14131-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. You'll cry for this, minion, if beat the door down.
line 14132-->LUCE.  [Within] What needs all that, and a pair of stocks in the town?
line 14133-->
line 14134-->Enter ADRIANA, within
line 14135-->
line 14136-->ADRIANA.  [Within]  Who is that at the door, that keeps all this noise?
line 14137-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.  [Within]  By my troth, your town is
line 14138-->    troubled with unruly boys.
line 14139-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Are you there, wife? You might
line 14140-->    have come before.
line 14141-->ADRIANA.  [Within]  Your wife, sir knave! Go get you from the door.
line 14142-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. If YOU went in pain, master, this 'knave' would go sore.
line 14143-->ANGELO. Here is neither cheer, sir, nor welcome; we would fain have either.
line 14144-->BALTHAZAR. In debating which was best, we shall part with neither.
line 14145-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. They stand at the door, master; bid them welcome hither.
line 14146-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. There is something in the wind, that we cannot get in.
line 14147-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. You would say so, master, if your garments were thin.
line 14148-->  Your cake here is warm within; you stand here in the cold;
line 14149-->  It would make a man mad as a buck to be so bought and sold.
line 14150-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Go fetch me something; I'll break ope the gate.
line 14151-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.  [Within]  Break any breaking here,
line 14152-->    and I'll break your knave's pate.
line 14153-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. A man may break a word with you,
line 14154-->    sir; and words are but wind;
line 14155-->  Ay, and break it in your face, so he break it not behind.
line 14156-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.  [Within]  It seems thou want'st breaking;
line 14157-->    out upon thee, hind!
line 14158-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Here's too much 'out upon thee!' pray thee let me in.
line 14159-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.  [Within]  Ay, when fowls have no
line 14160-->    feathers and fish have no fin.
line 14161-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Well, I'll break in; go borrow me a crow.
line 14162-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. A crow without feather? Master, mean you so?
line 14163-->  For a fish without a fin, there's a fowl without a feather;
line 14164-->  If a crow help us in, sirrah, we'll pluck a crow together.
line 14165-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Go get thee gone; fetch me an iron crow.
line 14166-->BALTHAZAR. Have patience, sir; O, let it not be so!
line 14167-->  Herein you war against your reputation,
line 14168-->  And draw within the compass of suspect
line 14169-->  Th' unviolated honour of your wife.
line 14170-->  Once this-your long experience of her wisdom,
line 14171-->  Her sober virtue, years, and modesty,
line 14172-->  Plead on her part some cause to you unknown;
line 14173-->  And doubt not, sir, but she will well excuse
line 14174-->  Why at this time the doors are made against you.
line 14175-->  Be rul'd by me: depart in patience,
line 14176-->  And let us to the Tiger all to dinner;
line 14177-->  And, about evening, come yourself alone
line 14178-->  To know the reason of this strange restraint.
line 14179-->  If by strong hand you offer to break in
line 14180-->  Now in the stirring passage of the day,
line 14181-->  A vulgar comment will be made of it,
line 14182-->  And that supposed by the common rout
line 14183-->  Against your yet ungalled estimation
line 14184-->  That may with foul intrusion enter in
line 14185-->  And dwell upon your grave when you are dead;
line 14186-->  For slander lives upon succession,
line 14187-->  For ever hous'd where it gets possession.
line 14188-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. You have prevail'd. I will depart in quiet,
line 14189-->  And in despite of mirth mean to be merry.
line 14190-->  I know a wench of excellent discourse,
line 14191-->  Pretty and witty; wild, and yet, too, gentle;
line 14192-->  There will we dine. This woman that I mean,
line 14193-->  My wife-but, I protest, without desert-
line 14194-->  Hath oftentimes upbraided me withal;
line 14195-->  To her will we to dinner.  [To ANGELO]  Get you home
line 14196-->  And fetch the chain; by this I know 'tis made.
line 14197-->  Bring it, I pray you, to the Porpentine;
line 14198-->  For there's the house. That chain will I bestow-
line 14199-->  Be it for nothing but to spite my wife-
line 14200-->  Upon mine hostess there; good sir, make haste.
line 14201-->  Since mine own doors refuse to entertain me,
line 14202-->  I'll knock elsewhere, to see if they'll disdain me.
line 14203-->ANGELO. I'll meet you at that place some hour hence.
line 14204-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Do so; this jest shall cost me some expense.
line 14205--><Exeunt
line 14206-->
line 14207-->
line 14208-->SCENE 2
line 14209-->
line 14210-->Before the house of ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
line 14211-->
line 14212-->Enter LUCIANA with ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
line 14213-->
line 14214-->LUCIANA. And may it be that you have quite forgot
line 14215-->  A husband's office? Shall, Antipholus,
line 14216-->  Even in the spring of love, thy love-springs rot?
line 14217-->  Shall love, in building, grow so ruinous?
line 14218-->  If you did wed my sister for her wealth,
line 14219-->  Then for her wealth's sake use her with more kindness;
line 14220-->  Or, if you like elsewhere, do it by stealth;
line 14221-->  Muffle your false love with some show of blindness;
line 14222-->  Let not my sister read it in your eye;
line 14223-->  Be not thy tongue thy own shame's orator;
line 14224-->  Look sweet, speak fair, become disloyalty;
line 14225-->  Apparel vice like virtue's harbinger;
line 14226-->  Bear a fair presence, though your heart be tainted;
line 14227-->  Teach sin the carriage of a holy saint;
line 14228-->  Be secret-false. What need she be acquainted?
line 14229-->  What simple thief brags of his own attaint?
line 14230-->  'Tis double wrong to truant with your bed
line 14231-->  And let her read it in thy looks at board;
line 14232-->  Shame hath a bastard fame, well managed;
line 14233-->  Ill deeds is doubled with an evil word.
line 14234-->  Alas, poor women! make us but believe,
line 14235-->  Being compact of credit, that you love us;
line 14236-->  Though others have the arm, show us the sleeve;
line 14237-->  We in your motion turn, and you may move us.
line 14238-->  Then, gentle brother, get you in again;
line 14239-->  Comfort my sister, cheer her, call her wife.
line 14240-->  'Tis holy sport to be a little vain
line 14241-->  When the sweet breath of flattery conquers strife.
line 14242-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Sweet mistress-what your name is else, I know not,
line 14243-->  Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine-
line 14244-->  Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not
line 14245-->  Than our earth's wonder-more than earth, divine.
line 14246-->  Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak;
line 14247-->  Lay open to my earthy-gross conceit,
line 14248-->  Smoth'red in errors, feeble, shallow, weak,
line 14249-->  The folded meaning of your words' deceit.
line 14250-->  Against my soul's pure truth why labour you
line 14251-->  To make it wander in an unknown field?
line 14252-->  Are you a god? Would you create me new?
line 14253-->  Transform me, then, and to your pow'r I'll yield.
line 14254-->  But if that I am I, then well I know
line 14255-->  Your weeping sister is no wife of mine,
line 14256-->  Nor to her bed no homage do I owe;
line 14257-->  Far more, far more, to you do I decline.
line 14258-->  O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note,
line 14259-->  To drown me in thy sister's flood of tears.
line 14260-->  Sing, siren, for thyself, and I will dote;
line 14261-->  Spread o'er the silver waves thy golden hairs,
line 14262-->  And as a bed I'll take them, and there he;
line 14263-->  And in that glorious supposition think
line 14264-->  He gains by death that hath such means to die.
line 14265-->  Let Love, being light, be drowned if she sink.
line 14266-->LUCIANA. What, are you mad, that you do reason so?
line 14267-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Not mad, but mated; how, I do not know.
line 14268-->LUCIANA. It is a fault that springeth from your eye.
line 14269-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.
line 14270-->LUCIANA. Gaze where you should, and that will clear your sight.
line 14271-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. As good to wink, sweet love, as look on night.
line 14272-->LUCIANA. Why call you me love? Call my sister so.
line 14273-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thy sister's sister.
line 14274-->LUCIANA. That's my sister.
line 14275-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. No;
line 14276-->  It is thyself, mine own self's better part;
line 14277-->  Mine eye's clear eye, my dear heart's dearer heart,
line 14278-->  My food, my fortune, and my sweet hope's aim,
line 14279-->  My sole earth's heaven, and my heaven's claim.
line 14280-->LUCIANA. All this my sister is, or else should be.
line 14281-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Call thyself sister, sweet, for I am thee;
line 14282-->  Thee will I love, and with thee lead my life;
line 14283-->  Thou hast no husband yet, nor I no wife.
line 14284-->  Give me thy hand.
line 14285-->LUCIANA. O, soft, sir, hold you still;
line 14286-->  I'll fetch my sister to get her good will.
line 14287--><Exit LUCIANA
line 14288-->
line 14289-->Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.
line 14290-->
line 14291-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, how now, Dromio! Where run'st thou
line 14292-->  so fast?
line 14293-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Do you know me, sir? Am I Dromio?
line 14294-->  Am I your man? Am I myself?
line 14295-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thou art Dromio, thou art my
line 14296-->  man, thou art thyself.
line 14297-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I am an ass, I am a woman's man, and besides
line 14298-->  myself.
line 14299-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What woman's man, and how besides thyself?
line 14300-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Marry, sir, besides myself, I am due
line 14301-->  to a woman-one that claims me, one that haunts me, one
line 14302-->  that will have me.
line 14303-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What claim lays she to thee?
line 14304-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Marry, sir, such claim as you would
line 14305-->  lay to your horse; and she would have me as a beast: not
line 14306-->  that, I being a beast, she would have me; but that she,
line 14307-->  being a very beastly creature, lays claim to me.
line 14308-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What is she?
line 14309-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. A very reverent body; ay, such a one
line 14310-->  as a man may not speak of without he say 'Sir-reverence.'
line 14311-->  I have but lean luck in the match, and yet is she a
line 14312-->  wondrous fat marriage.
line 14313-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. How dost thou mean a fat marriage?
line 14314-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Marry, sir, she's the kitchen-wench,
line 14315-->  and all grease; and I know not what use to put her to but
line 14316-->  to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light.
line 14317-->  I warrant, her rags and the tallow in them will burn
line 14318-->  Poland winter. If she lives till doomsday, she'll burn
line 14319-->  week longer than the whole world.
line 14320-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What complexion is she of?
line 14321-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Swart, like my shoe; but her face
line 14322-->  nothing like so clean kept; for why, she sweats, a man may
line 14323-->  go over shoes in the grime of it.
line 14324-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. That's a fault that water will mend.
line 14325-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No, sir, 'tis in grain; Noah's flood
line 14326-->  could not do it.
line 14327-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What's her name?
line 14328-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Nell, sir; but her name and three
line 14329-->  quarters, that's an ell and three quarters, will not measure
line 14330-->  her from hip to hip.
line 14331-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Then she bears some breadth?
line 14332-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No longer from head to foot than
line 14333-->  from hip to hip: she is spherical, like a globe; I could find
line 14334-->  out countries in her.
line 14335-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. In what part of her body stands Ireland?
line 14336-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Marry, sir, in her buttocks; I found it out by
line 14337-->  the bogs.
line 14338-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where Scotland?
line 14339-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I found it by the barrenness, hard in
line 14340-->  the palm of the hand.
line 14341-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where France?
line 14342-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. In her forehead, arm'd and reverted,
line 14343-->  making war against her heir.
line 14344-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where England?
line 14345-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I look'd for the chalky cliffs, but I
line 14346-->  could find no whiteness in them; but I guess it stood in her
line 14347-->  chin, by the salt rheum that ran between France and it.
line 14348-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where Spain?
line 14349-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Faith, I saw it not, but I felt it hot in
line 14350-->  her breath.
line 14351-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where America, the Indies?
line 14352-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O, sir, upon her nose, an o'er embellished with
line 14353-->  rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their rich aspect to the
line 14354-->  hot breath of Spain; who sent whole armadoes of caracks to be
line 14355-->  ballast at her nose.
line 14356-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where stood Belgia, the Netherlands?
line 14357-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O, Sir, I did not look so low. To
line 14358-->  conclude: this drudge or diviner laid claim to me; call'd me
line 14359-->  Dromio; swore I was assur'd to her; told me what privy
line 14360-->  marks I had about me, as, the mark of my shoulder, the
line 14361-->  mole in my neck, the great wart on my left arm, that I,
line 14362-->  amaz'd, ran from her as a witch.
line 14363-->  And, I think, if my breast had not been made of faith,
line 14364-->    and my heart of steel,
line 14365-->  She had transform'd me to a curtal dog, and made me turn i' th' wheel.
line 14366-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Go hie thee presently post to the road;
line 14367-->  An if the wind blow any way from shore,
line 14368-->  I will not harbour in this town to-night.
line 14369-->  If any bark put forth, come to the mart,
line 14370-->  Where I will walk till thou return to me.
line 14371-->  If every one knows us, and we know none,
line 14372-->  'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack and be gone.
line 14373-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. As from a bear a man would run for life,
line 14374-->  So fly I from her that would be my wife.
line 14375--><Exit
line 14376-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. There's none but witches do inhabit here,
line 14377-->  And therefore 'tis high time that I were hence.
line 14378-->  She that doth call me husband, even my soul
line 14379-->  Doth for a wife abhor. But her fair sister,
line 14380-->  Possess'd with such a gentle sovereign grace,
line 14381-->  Of such enchanting presence and discourse,
line 14382-->  Hath almost made me traitor to myself;
line 14383-->  But, lest myself be guilty to self-wrong,
line 14384-->  I'll stop mine ears against the mermaid's song.
line 14385-->
line 14386-->Enter ANGELO with the chain
line 14387-->
line 14388-->ANGELO. Master Antipholus!
line 14389-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Ay, that's my name.
line 14390-->ANGELO. I know it well, sir. Lo, here is the chain.
line 14391-->  I thought to have ta'en you at the Porpentine;
line 14392-->  The chain unfinish'd made me stay thus long.
line 14393-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What is your will that I shall do with this?
line 14394-->ANGELO. What please yourself, sir; I have made it for you.
line 14395-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Made it for me, sir! I bespoke it not.
line 14396-->ANGELO. Not once nor twice, but twenty times you have.
line 14397-->  Go home with it, and please your wife withal;
line 14398-->  And soon at supper-time I'll visit you,
line 14399-->  And then receive my money for the chain.
line 14400-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I pray you, sir, receive the money now,
line 14401-->  For fear you ne'er see chain nor money more.
line 14402-->ANGELO. You are a merry man, sir; fare you well.
line 14403--><Exit
line 14404-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What I should think of this cannot tell:
line 14405-->  But this I think, there's no man is so vain
line 14406-->  That would refuse so fair an offer'd chain.
line 14407-->  I see a man here needs not live by shifts,
line 14408-->  When in the streets he meets such golden gifts.
line 14409-->  I'll to the mart, and there for Dromio stay;
line 14410-->  If any ship put out, then straight away.
line 14411--><Exit
line 14412-->
line 14413-->

line 14423-->
line 14424-->
line 14425-->
line 14426-->
line 14427-->ACT IV. SCENE 1
line 14428-->
line 14429-->A public place
line 14430-->
line 14431-->Enter SECOND MERCHANT, ANGELO, and an OFFICER
line 14432-->
line 14433-->SECOND MERCHANT. You know since Pentecost the sum is due,
line 14434-->  And since I have not much importun'd you;
line 14435-->  Nor now I had not, but that I am bound
line 14436-->  To Persia, and want guilders for my voyage.
line 14437-->  Therefore make present satisfaction,
line 14438-->  Or I'll attach you by this officer.
line 14439-->ANGELO. Even just the sum that I do owe to you
line 14440-->  Is growing to me by Antipholus;
line 14441-->  And in the instant that I met with you
line 14442-->  He had of me a chain; at five o'clock
line 14443-->  I shall receive the money for the same.
line 14444-->  Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house,
line 14445-->  I will discharge my bond, and thank you too.
line 14446-->
line 14447-->Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS, and DROMIO OF EPHESUS, from the COURTEZAN'S
line 14448-->
line 14449-->OFFICER. That labour may you save; see where he comes.
line 14450-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. While I go to the goldsmith's house, go thou
line 14451-->  And buy a rope's end; that will I bestow
line 14452-->  Among my wife and her confederates,
line 14453-->  For locking me out of my doors by day.
line 14454-->  But, soft, I see the goldsmith. Get thee gone;
line 14455-->  Buy thou a rope, and bring it home to me.
line 14456-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I buy a thousand pound a year; I buy a rope.
line 14457--><Exit DROMIO
line 14458-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. A man is well holp up that trusts to you!
line 14459-->  I promised your presence and the chain;
line 14460-->  But neither chain nor goldsmith came to me.
line 14461-->  Belike you thought our love would last too long,
line 14462-->  If it were chain'd together, and therefore came not.
line 14463-->ANGELO. Saving your merry humour, here's the note
line 14464-->  How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat,
line 14465-->  The fineness of the gold, and chargeful fashion,
line 14466-->  Which doth amount to three odd ducats more
line 14467-->  Than I stand debted to this gentleman.
line 14468-->  I pray you see him presently discharg'd,
line 14469-->  For he is bound to sea, and stays but for it.
line 14470-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I am not furnish'd with the present money;
line 14471-->  Besides, I have some business in the town.
line 14472-->  Good signior, take the stranger to my house,
line 14473-->  And with you take the chain, and bid my wife
line 14474-->  Disburse the sum on the receipt thereof.
line 14475-->  Perchance I will be there as soon as you.
line 14476-->ANGELO. Then you will bring the chain to her yourself?
line 14477-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. No; bear it with you, lest I come not time enough.
line 14478-->ANGELO. Well, sir, I will. Have you the chain about you?
line 14479-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. An if I have not, sir, I hope you have;
line 14480-->  Or else you may return without your money.
line 14481-->ANGELO. Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain;
line 14482-->  Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman,
line 14483-->  And I, to blame, have held him here too long.
line 14484-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Good Lord! you use this dalliance to excuse
line 14485-->  Your breach of promise to the Porpentine;
line 14486-->  I should have chid you for not bringing it,
line 14487-->  But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl.
line 14488-->SECOND MERCHANT. The hour steals on; I pray you, sir, dispatch.
line 14489-->ANGELO. You hear how he importunes me-the chain!
line 14490-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Why, give it to my wife, and fetch your money.
line 14491-->ANGELO. Come, come, you know I gave it you even now.
line 14492-->  Either send the chain or send by me some token.
line 14493-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Fie, now you run this humour out of breath!
line 14494-->  Come, where's the chain? I pray you let me see it.
line 14495-->SECOND MERCHANT. My business cannot brook this dalliance.
line 14496-->  Good sir, say whe'r you'll answer me or no;
line 14497-->  If not, I'll leave him to the officer.
line 14498-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I answer you! What should I answer you?
line 14499-->ANGELO. The money that you owe me for the chain.
line 14500-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I owe you none till I receive the chain.
line 14501-->ANGELO. You know I gave it you half an hour since.
line 14502-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. You gave me none; you wrong me much to say so.
line 14503-->ANGELO. You wrong me more, sir, in denying it.
line 14504-->  Consider how it stands upon my credit.
line 14505-->SECOND MERCHANT. Well, officer, arrest him at my suit.
line 14506-->OFFICER. I do; and charge you in the Duke's name to obey me.
line 14507-->ANGELO. This touches me in reputation.
line 14508-->  Either consent to pay this sum for me,
line 14509-->  Or I attach you by this officer.
line 14510-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Consent to pay thee that I never had!
line 14511-->  Arrest me, foolish fellow, if thou dar'st.
line 14512-->ANGELO. Here is thy fee; arrest him, officer.
line 14513-->  I would not spare my brother in this case,
line 14514-->  If he should scorn me so apparently.
line 14515-->OFFICER. I do arrest you, sir; you hear the suit.
line 14516-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I do obey thee till I give thee bail.
line 14517-->  But, sirrah, you shall buy this sport as dear
line 14518-->  As all the metal in your shop will answer.
line 14519-->ANGELO. Sir, sir, I shall have law in Ephesus,
line 14520-->  To your notorious shame, I doubt it not.
line 14521-->
line 14522-->Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, from the bay
line 14523-->
line 14524-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, there's a bark of Epidamnum
line 14525-->  That stays but till her owner comes aboard,
line 14526-->  And then, sir, she bears away. Our fraughtage, sir,
line 14527-->  I have convey'd aboard; and I have bought
line 14528-->  The oil, the balsamum, and aqua-vitx.
line 14529-->  The ship is in her trim; the merry wind
line 14530-->  Blows fair from land; they stay for nought at an
line 14531-->  But for their owner, master, and yourself.
line 14532-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. How now! a madman? Why, thou peevish sheep,
line 14533-->  What ship of Epidamnum stays for me?
line 14534-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. A ship you sent me to, to hire waftage.
line 14535-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. THOU drunken slave! I sent the for a rope;
line 14536-->  And told thee to what purpose and what end.
line 14537-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. YOU sent me for a rope's end as soon-
line 14538-->  You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark.
line 14539-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I Will debate this matter at more leisure,
line 14540-->  And teach your ears to list me with more heed.
line 14541-->  To Adriana, villain, hie thee straight;
line 14542-->  Give her this key, and tell her in the desk
line 14543-->  That's cover'd o'er with Turkish tapestry
line 14544-->  There is a purse of ducats; let her send it.
line 14545-->  Tell her I am arrested in the street,
line 14546-->  And that shall bail me; hie thee, slave, be gone.
line 14547-->  On, officer, to prison till it come.
line 14548--><Exeunt all but DROMIO
line 14549-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. To Adriana! that is where we din'd,
line 14550-->  Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband.
line 14551-->  She is too big, I hope, for me to compass.
line 14552-->  Thither I must, although against my will,
line 14553-->  For servants must their masters' minds fulfil.
line 14554--><Exit
line 14555-->
line 14556-->
line 14557-->SCENE 2
line 14558-->
line 14559-->The house of ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
line 14560-->
line 14561-->Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA
line 14562-->
line 14563-->ADRIANA. Ah, Luciana, did he tempt thee so?
line 14564-->  Might'st thou perceive austerely in his eye
line 14565-->  That he did plead in earnest? Yea or no?
line 14566-->  Look'd he or red or pale, or sad or merrily?
line 14567-->  What observation mad'st thou in this case
line 14568-->  Of his heart's meteors tilting in his face?
line 14569-->LUCIANA. First he denied you had in him no right.
line 14570-->ADRIANA. He meant he did me none-the more my spite.
line 14571-->LUCIANA. Then swore he that he was a stranger here.
line 14572-->ADRIANA. And true he swore, though yet forsworn he were.
line 14573-->LUCIANA. Then pleaded I for you.
line 14574-->ADRIANA. And what said he?
line 14575-->LUCIANA. That love I begg'd for you he begg'd of me.
line 14576-->ADRIANA. With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?
line 14577-->LUCIANA. With words that in an honest suit might move.
line 14578-->  First he did praise my beauty, then my speech.
line 14579-->ADRIANA. Didst speak him fair?
line 14580-->LUCIANA. Have patience, I beseech.
line 14581-->ADRIANA. I cannot, nor I will not hold me still;
line 14582-->  My tongue, though not my heart, shall have his will.
line 14583-->  He is deformed, crooked, old, and sere,
line 14584-->  Ill-fac'd, worse bodied, shapeless everywhere;
line 14585-->  Vicious, ungentle, foolish, blunt, unkind;
line 14586-->  Stigmatical in making, worse in mind.
line 14587-->LUCIANA. Who would be jealous then of such a one?
line 14588-->  No evil lost is wail'd when it is gone.
line 14589-->ADRIANA. Ah, but I think him better than I say,
line 14590-->  And yet would herein others' eyes were worse.
line 14591-->  Far from her nest the lapwing cries away;
line 14592-->  My heart prays for him, though my tongue do curse.
line 14593-->
line 14594-->Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.
line 14595-->
line 14596-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Here go-the desk, the purse. Sweet
line 14597-->  now, make haste.
line 14598-->LUCIANA. How hast thou lost thy breath?
line 14599-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. By running fast.
line 14600-->ADRIANA. Where is thy master, Dromio? Is he well?
line 14601-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No, he's in Tartar limbo, worse than hell.
line 14602-->  A devil in an everlasting garment hath him;
line 14603-->  One whose hard heart is button'd up with steel;
line 14604-->  A fiend, a fairy, pitiless and rough;
line 14605-->  A wolf, nay worse, a fellow all in buff;
line 14606-->  A back-friend, a shoulder-clapper, one that countermands
line 14607-->  The passages of alleys, creeks, and narrow lands;
line 14608-->  A hound that runs counter, and yet draws dry-foot well;
line 14609-->  One that, before the Judgment, carries poor souls to hell.
line 14610-->ADRIANA. Why, man, what is the matter?
line 14611-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I do not know the matter; he is rested on the case.
line 14612-->ADRIANA. What, is he arrested? Tell me, at whose suit?
line 14613-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I know not at whose suit he is arrested well;
line 14614-->  But he's in a suit of buff which 'rested him, that can I tell.
line 14615-->  Will you send him, mistress, redemption, the money in his desk?
line 14616-->ADRIANA. Go fetch it, sister.  [Exit LUCIANA]  This I wonder at:
line 14617-->  Thus he unknown to me should be in debt.
line 14618-->  Tell me, was he arrested on a band?
line 14619-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. on a band, but on a stronger thing,
line 14620-->  A chain, a chain. Do you not hear it ring?
line 14621-->ADRIANA. What, the chain?
line 14622-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No, no, the bell; 'tis time that I were gone.
line 14623-->  It was two ere I left him, and now the clock strikes one.
line 14624-->ADRIANA. The hours come back! That did I never hear.
line 14625-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O yes. If any hour meet a sergeant,
line 14626-->    'a turns back for very fear.
line 14627-->ADRIANA. As if Time were in debt! How fondly dost thou reason!
line 14628-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Time is a very bankrupt, and owes
line 14629-->    more than he's worth to season.
line 14630-->  Nay, he's a thief too: have you not heard men say
line 14631-->  That Time comes stealing on by night and day?
line 14632-->  If 'a be in debt and theft, and a sergeant in the way,
line 14633-->  Hath he not reason to turn back an hour in a day?
line 14634-->
line 14635-->Re-enter LUCIANA with a purse
line 14636-->
line 14637-->ADRIANA. Go, Dromio, there's the money; bear it straight,
line 14638-->  And bring thy master home immediately.
line 14639-->  Come, sister; I am press'd down with conceit-
line 14640-->  Conceit, my comfort and my injury.
line 14641--><Exeunt
line 14642-->
line 14643-->
line 14644-->SCENE 3
line 14645-->
line 14646-->The mart
line 14647-->
line 14648-->Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
line 14649-->
line 14650-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. There's not a man I meet but doth salute me
line 14651-->  As if I were their well-acquainted friend;
line 14652-->  And every one doth call me by my name.
line 14653-->  Some tender money to me, some invite me,
line 14654-->  Some other give me thanks for kindnesses,
line 14655-->  Some offer me commodities to buy;
line 14656-->  Even now a tailor call'd me in his shop,
line 14657-->  And show'd me silks that he had bought for me,
line 14658-->  And therewithal took measure of my body.
line 14659-->  Sure, these are but imaginary wiles,
line 14660-->  And Lapland sorcerers inhabit here.
line 14661-->
line 14662-->Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
line 14663-->
line 14664-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, here's the gold you sent me
line 14665-->  for. What, have you got the picture of old Adam new-apparell'd?
line 14666-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What gold is this? What Adam dost thou mean?
line 14667-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Not that Adam that kept the Paradise,
line 14668-->  but that Adam that keeps the prison; he that goes in the
line 14669-->  calf's skin that was kill'd for the Prodigal; he that came behind
line 14670-->  you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid you forsake your liberty.
line 14671-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I understand thee not.
line 14672-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No? Why, 'tis a plain case: he that
line 14673-->  went, like a bass-viol, in a case of leather; the man, sir,
line 14674-->  that, when gentlemen are tired, gives them a sob, and rest
line 14675-->  them; he, sir, that takes pity on decayed men, and give
line 14676-->  them suits of durance; he that sets up his rest to do more
line 14677-->  exploits with his mace than a morris-pike.
line 14678-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What, thou mean'st an officer?
line 14679-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band;
line 14680-->  that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band; on
line 14681-->  that thinks a man always going to bed, and says 'God give
line 14682-->  you good rest!'
line 14683-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Well, sir, there rest in your foolery. Is
line 14684-->  there any ship puts forth to-night? May we be gone?
line 14685-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Why, sir, I brought you word an
line 14686-->  hour since that the bark Expedition put forth to-night; and
line 14687-->  then were you hind'red by the sergeant, to tarry for the
line 14688-->  boy Delay. Here are the angels that you sent for to deliver you.
line 14689-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. The fellow is distract, and so am I;
line 14690-->  And here we wander in illusions.
line 14691-->  Some blessed power deliver us from hence!
line 14692-->
line 14693-->Enter a COURTEZAN
line 14694-->
line 14695-->COURTEZAN. Well met, well met, Master Antipholus.
line 14696-->  I see, sir, you have found the goldsmith now.
line 14697-->  Is that the chain you promis'd me to-day?
line 14698-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Satan, avoid! I charge thee, tempt me not.
line 14699-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, is this Mistress Satan?
line 14700-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. It is the devil.
line 14701-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Nay, she is worse, she is the devil's
line 14702-->  dam, and here she comes in the habit of a light wench; and
line 14703-->  thereof comes that the wenches say 'God damn me!' That's
line 14704-->  as much to say 'God make me a light wench!' It is written
line 14705-->  they appear to men like angels of light; light is an effect
line 14706-->  of fire, and fire will burn; ergo, light wenches will burn.
line 14707-->  Come not near her.
line 14708-->COURTEZAN. Your man and you are marvellous merry, sir.
line 14709-->  Will you go with me? We'll mend our dinner here.
line 14710-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, if you do, expect spoon-meat,
line 14711-->  or bespeak a long spoon.
line 14712-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, Dromio?
line 14713-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Marry, he must have a long spoon
line 14714-->  that must eat with the devil.
line 14715-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Avoid then, fiend! What tell'st thou me of supping?
line 14716-->  Thou art, as you are all, a sorceress;
line 14717-->  I conjure thee to leave me and be gone.
line 14718-->COURTEZAN. Give me the ring of mine you had at dinner,
line 14719-->  Or, for my diamond, the chain you promis'd,
line 14720-->  And I'll be gone, sir, and not trouble you.
line 14721-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Some devils ask but the parings of one's nail,
line 14722-->  A rush, a hair, a drop of blood, a pin,
line 14723-->  A nut, a cherry-stone;
line 14724-->  But she, more covetous, would have a chain.
line 14725-->  Master, be wise; an if you give it her,
line 14726-->  The devil will shake her chain, and fright us with it.
line 14727-->COURTEZAN. I pray you, sir, my ring, or else the chain;
line 14728-->  I hope you do not mean to cheat me so.
line 14729-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Avaunt, thou witch! Come, Dromio, let us go.
line 14730-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 'Fly pride' says the peacock. Mistress, that you know.
line 14731--><Exeunt ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
line 14732-->COURTEZAN. Now, out of doubt, Antipholus is mad,
line 14733-->  Else would he never so demean himself.
line 14734-->  A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats,
line 14735-->  And for the same he promis'd me a chain;
line 14736-->  Both one and other he denies me now.
line 14737-->  The reason that I gather he is mad,
line 14738-->  Besides this present instance of his rage,
line 14739-->  Is a mad tale he told to-day at dinner
line 14740-->  Of his own doors being shut against his entrance.
line 14741-->  Belike his wife, acquainted with his fits,
line 14742-->  On purpose shut the doors against his way.
line 14743-->  My way is now to hie home to his house,
line 14744-->  And tell his wife that, being lunatic,
line 14745-->  He rush'd into my house and took perforce
line 14746-->  My ring away. This course I fittest choose,
line 14747-->  For forty ducats is too much to lose.
line 14748--><Exit
line 14749-->
line 14750-->
line 14751-->SCENE 4
line 14752-->
line 14753-->A street
line 14754-->
line 14755-->Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS with the OFFICER
line 14756-->
line 14757-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Fear me not, man; I will not break away.
line 14758-->  I'll give thee, ere I leave thee, so much money,
line 14759-->  To warrant thee, as I am 'rested for.
line 14760-->  My wife is in a wayward mood to-day,
line 14761-->  And will not lightly trust the messenger.
line 14762-->  That I should be attach'd in Ephesus,
line 14763-->  I tell you 'twill sound harshly in her cars.
line 14764-->
line 14765-->Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUS, with a rope's-end
line 14766-->
line 14767-->  Here comes my man; I think he brings the money.
line 14768-->  How now, sir! Have you that I sent you for?
line 14769-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Here's that, I warrant you, will pay them all.
line 14770-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. But where's the money?
line 14771-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.
line 14772-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Five hundred ducats, villain, for rope?
line 14773-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I'll serve you, sir, five hundred at the rate.
line 14774-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?
line 14775-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. To a rope's-end, sir; and to that end am I
line 14776-->  return'd.
line 14777-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. And to that end, sir, I will welcome you.
line 14778-->[Beating him]
line 14779-->OFFICER. Good sir, be patient.
line 14780-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Nay, 'tis for me to be patient; I am in
line 14781-->  adversity.
line 14782-->OFFICER. Good now, hold thy tongue.
line 14783-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Nay, rather persuade him to hold his hands.
line 14784-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Thou whoreson, senseless villain!
line 14785-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I would I were senseless, sir, that I
line 14786-->  might not feel your blows.
line 14787-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Thou art sensible in nothing but
line 14788-->  blows, and so is an ass.
line 14789-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I am an ass indeed; you may prove it
line 14790-->  by my long 'ears. I have served him from the hour of my
line 14791-->  nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for
line 14792-->  my service but blows. When I am cold he heats me with
line 14793-->  beating; when I am warm he cools me with beating. I am
line 14794-->  wak'd with it when I sleep; rais'd with it when I sit; driven
line 14795-->  out of doors with it when I go from home; welcom'd home
line 14796-->  with it when I return; nay, I bear it on my shoulders as
line 14797-->  beggar wont her brat; and I think, when he hath lam'd me,
line 14798-->  I shall beg with it from door to door.
line 14799-->
line 14800-->Enter ADRIANA, LUCIANA, the COURTEZAN, and a SCHOOLMASTER
line 14801-->call'd PINCH
line 14802-->
line 14803-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Come, go along; my wife is coming yonder.
line 14804-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Mistress, 'respice finem,' respect your end; or
line 14805-->  rather, to prophesy like the parrot, 'Beware the rope's-end.'
line 14806-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Wilt thou still talk?
line 14807-->[Beating him]
line 14808-->COURTEZAN. How say you now? Is not your husband mad?
line 14809-->ADRIANA. His incivility confirms no less.
line 14810-->  Good Doctor Pinch, you are a conjurer:
line 14811-->  Establish him in his true sense again,
line 14812-->  And I will please you what you will demand.
line 14813-->LUCIANA. Alas, how fiery and how sharp he looks!
line 14814-->COURTEZAN. Mark how he trembles in his ecstasy.
line 14815-->PINCH. Give me your hand, and let me feel your pulse.
line 14816-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. There is my hand, and let it feel your ear.
line 14817-->[Striking him]
line 14818-->PINCH. I charge thee, Satan, hous'd within this man,
line 14819-->  To yield possession to my holy prayers,
line 14820-->  And to thy state of darkness hie thee straight.
line 14821-->  I conjure thee by all the saints in heaven.
line 14822-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Peace, doting wizard, peace! I am not mad.
line 14823-->ADRIANA. O, that thou wert not, poor distressed soul!
line 14824-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. You minion, you, are these your customers?
line 14825-->  Did this companion with the saffron face
line 14826-->  Revel and feast it at my house to-day,
line 14827-->  Whilst upon me the guilty doors were shut,
line 14828-->  And I denied to enter in my house?
line 14829-->ADRIANA. O husband, God doth know you din'd at home,
line 14830-->  Where would you had remain'd until this time,
line 14831-->  Free from these slanders and this open shame!
line 14832-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Din'd at home! Thou villain, what sayest thou?
line 14833-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Sir, Sooth to say, you did not dine at home.
line 14834-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Were not my doors lock'd up and I shut out?
line 14835-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Perdie, your doors were lock'd and you shut out.
line 14836-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. And did not she herself revile me there?
line 14837-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Sans fable, she herself revil'd you there.
line 14838-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Did not her kitchen-maid rail, taunt, and scorn me?
line 14839-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Certes, she did; the kitchen-vestal scorn'd you.
line 14840-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. And did not I in rage depart from thence?
line 14841-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. In verity, you did. My bones bear witness,
line 14842-->  That since have felt the vigour of his rage.
line 14843-->ADRIANA. Is't good to soothe him in these contraries?
line 14844-->PINCH. It is no shame; the fellow finds his vein,
line 14845-->  And, yielding to him, humours well his frenzy.
line 14846-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Thou hast suborn'd the goldsmith to arrest me.
line 14847-->ADRIANA. Alas, I sent you money to redeem you,
line 14848-->  By Dromio here, who came in haste for it.
line 14849-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Money by me! Heart and goodwill you might,
line 14850-->  But surely, master, not a rag of money.
line 14851-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Went'st not thou to her for purse of ducats?
line 14852-->ADRIANA. He came to me, and I deliver'd it.
line 14853-->LUCIANA. And I am witness with her that she did.
line 14854-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. God and the rope-maker bear me witness
line 14855-->  That I was sent for nothing but a rope!
line 14856-->PINCH. Mistress, both man and master is possess'd;
line 14857-->  I know it by their pale and deadly looks.
line 14858-->  They must be bound, and laid in some dark room.
line 14859-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Say, wherefore didst thou lock me forth to-day?
line 14860-->  And why dost thou deny the bag of gold?
line 14861-->ADRIANA. I did not, gentle husband, lock thee forth.
line 14862-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. And, gentle master, I receiv'd no gold;
line 14863-->  But I confess, sir, that we were lock'd out.
line 14864-->ADRIANA. Dissembling villain, thou speak'st false in both.
line 14865-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Dissembling harlot, thou art false in all,
line 14866-->  And art confederate with a damned pack
line 14867-->  To make a loathsome abject scorn of me;
line 14868-->  But with these nails I'll pluck out these false eyes
line 14869-->  That would behold in me this shameful sport.
line 14870-->ADRIANA. O, bind him, bind him; let him not come near me.
line 14871-->PINCH. More company! The fiend is strong within him.
line 14872-->
line 14873-->Enter three or four, and offer to bind him. He strives
line 14874-->
line 14875-->LUCIANA. Ay me, poor man, how pale and wan he looks!
line 14876-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. What, will you murder me? Thou gaoler, thou,
line 14877-->  I am thy prisoner. Wilt thou suffer them
line 14878-->  To make a rescue?
line 14879-->OFFICER. Masters, let him go;
line 14880-->  He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him.
line 14881-->PINCH. Go bind this man, for he is frantic too.
line 14882-->[They bind DROMIO]
line 14883-->ADRIANA. What wilt thou do, thou peevish officer?
line 14884-->  Hast thou delight to see a wretched man
line 14885-->  Do outrage and displeasure to himself?
line 14886-->OFFICER. He is my prisoner; if I let him go,
line 14887-->  The debt he owes will be requir'd of me.
line 14888-->ADRIANA. I will discharge thee ere I go from thee;
line 14889-->  Bear me forthwith unto his creditor,
line 14890-->  And, knowing how the debt grows, I will pay it.
line 14891-->  Good Master Doctor, see him safe convey'd
line 14892-->  Home to my house. O most unhappy day!
line 14893-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. O most unhappy strumpet!
line 14894-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Master, I am here ent'red in bond for you.
line 14895-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Out on thee, villian! Wherefore
line 14896-->  dost thou mad me?
line 14897-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Will you be bound for nothing?
line 14898-->  Be mad, good master; cry 'The devil!'
line 14899-->LUCIANA. God help, poor souls, how idly do they talk!
line 14900-->ADRIANA. Go bear him hence. Sister, go you with me.
line 14901--><Exeunt all but ADRIANA, LUCIANA, OFFICERS, and COURTEZAN
line 14902-->  Say now, whose suit is he arrested at?
line 14903-->OFFICER. One Angelo, a goldsmith; do you know him?
line 14904-->ADRIANA. I know the man. What is the sum he owes?
line 14905-->OFFICER. Two hundred ducats.
line 14906-->ADRIANA. Say, how grows it due?
line 14907-->OFFICER. Due for a chain your husband had of him.
line 14908-->ADRIANA. He did bespeak a chain for me, but had it not.
line 14909-->COURTEZAN. When as your husband, all in rage, to-day
line 14910-->  Came to my house, and took away my ring-
line 14911-->  The ring I saw upon his finger now-
line 14912-->  Straight after did I meet him with a chain.
line 14913-->ADRIANA. It may be so, but I did never see it.
line 14914-->  Come, gaoler, bring me where the goldsmith is;
line 14915-->  I long to know the truth hereof at large.
line 14916-->
line 14917-->Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE, with his rapier drawn, and
line 14918-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.
line 14919-->
line 14920-->LUCIANA. God, for thy mercy! they are loose again.
line 14921-->ADRIANA. And come with naked swords.
line 14922-->  Let's call more help to have them bound again.
line 14923-->OFFICER. Away, they'll kill us!
line 14924--><Exeunt all but ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and
line 14925-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE as fast as may be, frighted
line 14926-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I see these witches are afraid of swords.
line 14927-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. She that would be your wife now ran from you.
line 14928-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Come to the Centaur; fetch our stuff from thence.
line 14929-->  I long that we were safe and sound aboard.
line 14930-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Faith, stay here this night; they will
line 14931-->  surely do us no harm; you saw they speak us fair, give us
line 14932-->  gold; methinks they are such a gentle nation that, but for
line 14933-->  the mountain of mad flesh that claims marriage of me,
line 14934-->  could find in my heart to stay here still and turn witch.
line 14935-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I will not stay to-night for all the town;
line 14936-->  Therefore away, to get our stuff aboard.
line 14937--><Exeunt
line 14938-->
line 14939-->

line 14950-->
line 14951-->
line 14952-->
line 14953-->ACT V. SCENE 1
line 14954-->
line 14955-->A street before a priory
line 14956-->
line 14957-->Enter SECOND MERCHANT and ANGELO
line 14958-->
line 14959-->ANGELO. I am sorry, sir, that I have hind'red you;
line 14960-->  But I protest he had the chain of me,
line 14961-->  Though most dishonestly he doth deny it.
line 14962-->SECOND MERCHANT. How is the man esteem'd here in the city?
line 14963-->ANGELO. Of very reverend reputation, sir,
line 14964-->  Of credit infinite, highly belov'd,
line 14965-->  Second to none that lives here in the city;
line 14966-->  His word might bear my wealth at any time.
line 14967-->SECOND MERCHANT. Speak softly; yonder, as I think, he walks.
line 14968-->
line 14969-->Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
line 14970-->
line 14971-->ANGELO. 'Tis so; and that self chain about his neck
line 14972-->  Which he forswore most monstrously to have.
line 14973-->  Good sir, draw near to me, I'll speak to him.
line 14974-->  Signior Andpholus, I wonder much
line 14975-->  That you would put me to this shame and trouble;
line 14976-->  And, not without some scandal to yourself,
line 14977-->  With circumstance and oaths so to deny
line 14978-->  This chain, which now you wear so openly.
line 14979-->  Beside the charge, the shame, imprisonment,
line 14980-->  You have done wrong to this my honest friend;
line 14981-->  Who, but for staying on our controversy,
line 14982-->  Had hoisted sail and put to sea to-day.
line 14983-->  This chain you had of me; can you deny it?
line 14984-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I think I had; I never did deny it.
line 14985-->SECOND MERCHANT. Yes, that you did, sir, and forswore it too.
line 14986-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Who heard me to deny it or forswear it?
line 14987-->SECOND MERCHANT. These ears of mine, thou know'st, did hear thee.
line 14988-->  Fie on thee, wretch! 'tis pity that thou liv'st
line 14989-->  To walk where any honest men resort.
line 14990-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thou art a villain to impeach me thus;
line 14991-->  I'll prove mine honour and mine honesty
line 14992-->  Against thee presently, if thou dar'st stand.
line 14993-->SECOND MERCHANT. I dare, and do defy thee for a villain.
line 14994-->[They draw]
line 14995-->
line 14996-->Enter ADRIANA, LUCIANA, the COURTEZAN, and OTHERS
line 14997-->
line 14998-->ADRIANA. Hold, hurt him not, for God's sake! He is mad.
line 14999-->  Some get within him, take his sword away;
line 15000-->  Bind Dromio too, and bear them to my house.
line 15001-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Run, master, run; for God's sake take a house.
line 15002-->  This is some priory. In, or we are spoil'd.
line 15003--><Exeunt ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and DROMIO OF SYRACUSE to the priory
line 15004-->
line 15005-->Enter the LADY ABBESS
line 15006-->
line 15007-->ABBESS. Be quiet, people. Wherefore throng you hither?
line 15008-->ADRIANA. To fetch my poor distracted husband hence.
line 15009-->  Let us come in, that we may bind him fast,
line 15010-->  And bear him home for his recovery.
line 15011-->ANGELO. I knew he was not in his perfect wits.
line 15012-->SECOND MERCHANT. I am sorry now that I did draw on him.
line 15013-->ABBESS. How long hath this possession held the man?
line 15014-->ADRIANA. This week he hath been heavy, sour, sad,
line 15015-->  And much different from the man he was;
line 15016-->  But till this afternoon his passion
line 15017-->  Ne'er brake into extremity of rage.
line 15018-->ABBESS. Hath he not lost much wealth by wreck of sea?
line 15019-->  Buried some dear friend? Hath not else his eye
line 15020-->  Stray'd his affection in unlawful love?
line 15021-->  A sin prevailing much in youthful men
line 15022-->  Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing.
line 15023-->  Which of these sorrows is he subject to?
line 15024-->ADRIANA. To none of these, except it be the last;
line 15025-->  Namely, some love that drew him oft from home.
line 15026-->ABBESS. You should for that have reprehended him.
line 15027-->ADRIANA. Why, so I did.
line 15028-->ABBESS. Ay, but not rough enough.
line 15029-->ADRIANA. As roughly as my modesty would let me.
line 15030-->ABBESS. Haply in private.
line 15031-->ADRIANA. And in assemblies too.
line 15032-->ABBESS. Ay, but not enough.
line 15033-->ADRIANA. It was the copy of our conference.
line 15034-->  In bed, he slept not for my urging it;
line 15035-->  At board, he fed not for my urging it;
line 15036-->  Alone, it was the subject of my theme;
line 15037-->  In company, I often glanced it;
line 15038-->  Still did I tell him it was vile and bad.
line 15039-->ABBESS. And thereof came it that the man was mad.
line 15040-->  The venom clamours of a jealous woman
line 15041-->  Poisons more deadly than a mad dog's tooth.
line 15042-->  It seems his sleeps were hind'red by thy railing,
line 15043-->  And thereof comes it that his head is light.
line 15044-->  Thou say'st his meat was sauc'd with thy upbraidings:
line 15045-->  Unquiet meals make ill digestions;
line 15046-->  Thereof the raging fire of fever bred;
line 15047-->  And what's a fever but a fit of madness?
line 15048-->  Thou say'st his sports were hind'red by thy brawls.
line 15049-->  Sweet recreation barr'd, what doth ensue
line 15050-->  But moody and dull melancholy,
line 15051-->  Kinsman to grim and comfortless despair,
line 15052-->  And at her heels a huge infectious troop
line 15053-->  Of pale distemperatures and foes to life?
line 15054-->  In food, in sport, and life-preserving rest,
line 15055-->  To be disturb'd would mad or man or beast.
line 15056-->  The consequence is, then, thy jealous fits
line 15057-->  Hath scar'd thy husband from the use of wits.
line 15058-->LUCIANA. She never reprehended him but mildly,
line 15059-->  When he demean'd himself rough, rude, and wildly.
line 15060-->  Why bear you these rebukes, and answer not?
line 15061-->ADRIANA. She did betray me to my own reproof.
line 15062-->  Good people, enter, and lay hold on him.
line 15063-->ABBESS. No, not a creature enters in my house.
line 15064-->ADRIANA. Then let your servants bring my husband forth.
line 15065-->ABBESS. Neither; he took this place for sanctuary,
line 15066-->  And it shall privilege him from your hands
line 15067-->  Till I have brought him to his wits again,
line 15068-->  Or lose my labour in assaying it.
line 15069-->ADRIANA. I will attend my husband, be his nurse,
line 15070-->  Diet his sickness, for it is my office,
line 15071-->  And will have no attorney but myself;
line 15072-->  And therefore let me have him home with me.
line 15073-->ABBESS. Be patient; for I will not let him stir
line 15074-->  Till I have us'd the approved means I have,
line 15075-->  With wholesome syrups, drugs, and holy prayers,
line 15076-->  To make of him a formal man again.
line 15077-->  It is a branch and parcel of mine oath,
line 15078-->  A charitable duty of my order;
line 15079-->  Therefore depart, and leave him here with me.
line 15080-->ADRIANA. I will not hence and leave my husband here;
line 15081-->  And ill it doth beseem your holiness
line 15082-->  To separate the husband and the wife.
line 15083-->ABBESS. Be quiet, and depart; thou shalt not have him.
line 15084--><Exit
line 15085-->LUCIANA. Complain unto the Duke of this indignity.
line 15086-->ADRIANA. Come, go; I will fall prostrate at his feet,
line 15087-->  And never rise until my tears and prayers
line 15088-->  Have won his Grace to come in person hither
line 15089-->  And take perforce my husband from the Abbess.
line 15090-->SECOND MERCHANT. By this, I think, the dial points at five;
line 15091-->  Anon, I'm sure, the Duke himself in person
line 15092-->  Comes this way to the melancholy vale,
line 15093-->  The place of death and sorry execution,
line 15094-->  Behind the ditches of the abbey here.
line 15095-->ANGELO. Upon what cause?
line 15096-->SECOND MERCHANT. To see a reverend Syracusian merchant,
line 15097-->  Who put unluckily into this bay
line 15098-->  Against the laws and statutes of this town,
line 15099-->  Beheaded publicly for his offence.
line 15100-->ANGELO. See where they come; we will behold his death.
line 15101-->LUCIANA. Kneel to the Duke before he pass the abbey.
line 15102-->
line 15103-->Enter the DUKE, attended; AEGEON, bareheaded;
line 15104-->with the HEADSMAN and other OFFICERS
line 15105-->
line 15106-->DUKE. Yet once again proclaim it publicly,
line 15107-->  If any friend will pay the sum for him,
line 15108-->  He shall not die; so much we tender him.
line 15109-->ADRIANA. Justice, most sacred Duke, against the Abbess!
line 15110-->DUKE. She is a virtuous and a reverend lady;
line 15111-->  It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.
line 15112-->ADRIANA. May it please your Grace, Antipholus, my husband,
line 15113-->  Who I made lord of me and all I had
line 15114-->  At your important letters-this ill day
line 15115-->  A most outrageous fit of madness took him,
line 15116-->  That desp'rately he hurried through the street,
line 15117-->  With him his bondman all as mad as he,
line 15118-->  Doing displeasure to the citizens
line 15119-->  By rushing in their houses, bearing thence
line 15120-->  Rings, jewels, anything his rage did like.
line 15121-->  Once did I get him bound and sent him home,
line 15122-->  Whilst to take order for the wrongs I went,
line 15123-->  That here and there his fury had committed.
line 15124-->  Anon, I wot not by what strong escape,
line 15125-->  He broke from those that had the guard of him,
line 15126-->  And with his mad attendant and himself,
line 15127-->  Each one with ireful passion, with drawn swords,
line 15128-->  Met us again and, madly bent on us,
line 15129-->  Chas'd us away; till, raising of more aid,
line 15130-->  We came again to bind them. Then they fled
line 15131-->  Into this abbey, whither we pursu'd them;
line 15132-->  And here the Abbess shuts the gates on us,
line 15133-->  And will not suffer us to fetch him out,
line 15134-->  Nor send him forth that we may bear him hence.
line 15135-->  Therefore, most gracious Duke, with thy command
line 15136-->  Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help.
line 15137-->DUKE. Long since thy husband serv'd me in my wars,
line 15138-->  And I to thee engag'd a prince's word,
line 15139-->  When thou didst make him master of thy bed,
line 15140-->  To do him all the grace and good I could.
line 15141-->  Go, some of you, knock at the abbey gate,
line 15142-->  And bid the Lady Abbess come to me,
line 15143-->  I will determine this before I stir.
line 15144-->
line 15145-->Enter a MESSENGER
line 15146-->
line 15147-->MESSENGER. O mistress, mistress, shift and save yourself!
line 15148-->  My master and his man are both broke loose,
line 15149-->  Beaten the maids a-row and bound the doctor,
line 15150-->  Whose beard they have sing'd off with brands of fire;
line 15151-->  And ever, as it blaz'd, they threw on him
line 15152-->  Great pails of puddled mire to quench the hair.
line 15153-->  My master preaches patience to him, and the while
line 15154-->  His man with scissors nicks him like a fool;
line 15155-->  And sure, unless you send some present help,
line 15156-->  Between them they will kill the conjurer.
line 15157-->ADRIANA. Peace, fool! thy master and his man are here,
line 15158-->  And that is false thou dost report to us.
line 15159-->MESSENGER. Mistress, upon my life, I tell you true;
line 15160-->  I have not breath'd almost since I did see it.
line 15161-->  He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you,
line 15162-->  To scorch your face, and to disfigure you.
line 15163-->[Cry within]
line 15164-->  Hark, hark, I hear him, mistress; fly, be gone!
line 15165-->DUKE. Come, stand by me; fear nothing. Guard with halberds.
line 15166-->ADRIANA. Ay me, it is my husband! Witness you
line 15167-->  That he is borne about invisible.
line 15168-->  Even now we hous'd him in the abbey here,
line 15169-->  And now he's there, past thought of human reason.
line 15170-->
line 15171-->Enter ANTIPHOLUS OFEPHESUS and DROMIO OFEPHESUS
line 15172-->
line 15173-->ANTIPHOLUS OFEPHESUS. Justice, most gracious Duke; O, grant me justice!
line 15174-->  Even for the service that long since I did thee,
line 15175-->  When I bestrid thee in the wars, and took
line 15176-->  Deep scars to save thy life; even for the blood
line 15177-->  That then I lost for thee, now grant me justice.
line 15178-->AEGEON. Unless the fear of death doth make me dote,
line 15179-->  I see my son Antipholus, and Dromio.
line 15180-->ANTIPHOLUS OFEPHESUS. Justice, sweet Prince, against that woman there!
line 15181-->  She whom thou gav'st to me to be my wife,
line 15182-->  That hath abused and dishonoured me
line 15183-->  Even in the strength and height of injury.
line 15184-->  Beyond imagination is the wrong
line 15185-->  That she this day hath shameless thrown on me.
line 15186-->DUKE. Discover how, and thou shalt find me just.
line 15187-->ANTIPHOLUS OFEPHESUS. This day, great Duke, she shut the doors upon me,
line 15188-->  While she with harlots feasted in my house.
line 15189-->DUKE. A grievous fault. Say, woman, didst thou so?
line 15190-->ADRIANA. No, my good lord. Myself, he, and my sister,
line 15191-->  To-day did dine together. So befall my soul
line 15192-->  As this is false he burdens me withal!
line 15193-->LUCIANA. Ne'er may I look on day nor sleep on night
line 15194-->  But she tells to your Highness simple truth!
line 15195-->ANGELO. O peflur'd woman! They are both forsworn.
line 15196-->  In this the madman justly chargeth them.
line 15197-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. My liege, I am advised what I say;
line 15198-->  Neither disturbed with the effect of wine,
line 15199-->  Nor heady-rash, provok'd with raging ire,
line 15200-->  Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad.
line 15201-->  This woman lock'd me out this day from dinner;
line 15202-->  That goldsmith there, were he not pack'd with her,
line 15203-->  Could witness it, for he was with me then;
line 15204-->  Who parted with me to go fetch a chain,
line 15205-->  Promising to bring it to the Porpentine,
line 15206-->  Where Balthazar and I did dine together.
line 15207-->  Our dinner done, and he not coming thither,
line 15208-->  I went to seek him. In the street I met him,
line 15209-->  And in his company that gentleman.
line 15210-->  There did this perjur'd goldsmith swear me down
line 15211-->  That I this day of him receiv'd the chain,
line 15212-->  Which, God he knows, I saw not; for the which
line 15213-->  He did arrest me with an officer.
line 15214-->  I did obey, and sent my peasant home
line 15215-->  For certain ducats; he with none return'd.
line 15216-->  Then fairly I bespoke the officer
line 15217-->  To go in person with me to my house.
line 15218-->  By th' way we met my wife, her sister, and a rabble more
line 15219-->  Of vile confederates. Along with them
line 15220-->  They brought one Pinch, a hungry lean-fac'd villain,
line 15221-->  A mere anatomy, a mountebank,
line 15222-->  A threadbare juggler, and a fortune-teller,
line 15223-->  A needy, hollow-ey'd, sharp-looking wretch,
line 15224-->  A living dead man. This pernicious slave,
line 15225-->  Forsooth, took on him as a conjurer,
line 15226-->  And gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse,
line 15227-->  And with no face, as 'twere, outfacing me,
line 15228-->  Cries out I was possess'd. Then all together
line 15229-->  They fell upon me, bound me, bore me thence,
line 15230-->  And in a dark and dankish vault at home
line 15231-->  There left me and my man, both bound together;
line 15232-->  Till, gnawing with my teeth my bonds in sunder,
line 15233-->  I gain'd my freedom, and immediately
line 15234-->  Ran hither to your Grace; whom I beseech
line 15235-->  To give me ample satisfaction
line 15236-->  For these deep shames and great indignities.
line 15237-->ANGELO. My lord, in truth, thus far I witness with him,
line 15238-->  That he din'd not at home, but was lock'd out.
line 15239-->DUKE. But had he such a chain of thee, or no?
line 15240-->ANGELO. He had, my lord, and when he ran in here,
line 15241-->  These people saw the chain about his neck.
line 15242-->SECOND MERCHANT. Besides, I will be sworn these ears of mine
line 15243-->  Heard you confess you had the chain of him,
line 15244-->  After you first forswore it on the mart;
line 15245-->  And thereupon I drew my sword on you,
line 15246-->  And then you fled into this abbey here,
line 15247-->  From whence, I think, you are come by miracle.
line 15248-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I never came within these abbey walls,
line 15249-->  Nor ever didst thou draw thy sword on me;
line 15250-->  I never saw the chain, so help me Heaven!
line 15251-->  And this is false you burden me withal.
line 15252-->DUKE. Why, what an intricate impeach is this!
line 15253-->  I think you all have drunk of Circe's cup.
line 15254-->  If here you hous'd him, here he would have been;
line 15255-->  If he were mad, he would not plead so coldly.
line 15256-->  You say he din'd at home: the goldsmith here
line 15257-->  Denies that saying. Sirrah, what say you?
line 15258-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Sir, he din'd with her there, at the Porpentine.
line 15259-->COURTEZAN. He did; and from my finger snatch'd that ring.
line 15260-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. 'Tis true, my liege; this ring I had of her.
line 15261-->DUKE. Saw'st thou him enter at the abbey here?
line 15262-->COURTEZAN. As sure, my liege, as I do see your Grace.
line 15263-->DUKE. Why, this is strange. Go call the Abbess hither.
line 15264-->  I think you are all mated or stark mad.
line 15265--><Exit one to the ABBESS
line 15266-->AEGEON. Most mighty Duke, vouchsafe me speak a word:
line 15267-->  Haply I see a friend will save my life
line 15268-->  And pay the sum that may deliver me.
line 15269-->DUKE. Speak freely, Syracusian, what thou wilt.
line 15270-->AEGEON. Is not your name, sir, call'd Antipholus?
line 15271-->  And is not that your bondman Dromio?
line 15272-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Within this hour I was his bondman, sir,
line 15273-->  But he, I thank him, gnaw'd in two my cords
line 15274-->  Now am I Dromio and his man unbound.
line 15275-->AEGEON. I am sure you both of you remember me.
line 15276-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Ourselves we do remember, sir, by you;
line 15277-->  For lately we were bound as you are now.
line 15278-->  You are not Pinch's patient, are you, sir?
line 15279-->AEGEON. Why look you strange on me? You know me well.
line 15280-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I never saw you in my life till now.
line 15281-->AEGEON. O! grief hath chang'd me since you saw me last;
line 15282-->  And careful hours with time's deformed hand
line 15283-->  Have written strange defeatures in my face.
line 15284-->  But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?
line 15285-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Neither.
line 15286-->AEGEON. Dromio, nor thou?
line 15287-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. No, trust me, sir, nor I.
line 15288-->AEGEON. I am sure thou dost.
line 15289-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Ay, sir, but I am sure I do not; and
line 15290-->  whatsoever a man denies, you are now bound to believe him.
line 15291-->AEGEON. Not know my voice! O time's extremity,
line 15292-->  Hast thou so crack'd and splitted my poor tongue
line 15293-->  In seven short years that here my only son
line 15294-->  Knows not my feeble key of untun'd cares?
line 15295-->  Though now this grained face of mine be hid
line 15296-->  In sap-consuming winter's drizzled snow,
line 15297-->  And all the conduits of my blood froze up,
line 15298-->  Yet hath my night of life some memory,
line 15299-->  My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left,
line 15300-->  My dull deaf ears a little use to hear;
line 15301-->  All these old witnesses-I cannot err-
line 15302-->  Tell me thou art my son Antipholus.
line 15303-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I never saw my father in my life.
line 15304-->AEGEON. But seven years since, in Syracuse, boy,
line 15305-->  Thou know'st we parted; but perhaps, my son,
line 15306-->  Thou sham'st to acknowledge me in misery.
line 15307-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. The Duke and all that know me in
line 15308-->  the city Can witness with me that it is not so:
line 15309-->  I ne'er saw Syracuse in my life.
line 15310-->DUKE. I tell thee, Syracusian, twenty years
line 15311-->  Have I been patron to Antipholus,
line 15312-->  During which time he ne'er saw Syracuse.
line 15313-->  I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.
line 15314-->
line 15315-->Re-enter the ABBESS, with ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
line 15316-->
line 15317-->ABBESS. Most mighty Duke, behold a man much wrong'd.
line 15318-->[All gather to see them]
line 15319-->ADRIANA. I see two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me.
line 15320-->DUKE. One of these men is genius to the other;
line 15321-->  And so of these. Which is the natural man,
line 15322-->  And which the spirit? Who deciphers them?
line 15323-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I, sir, am Dromio; command him away.
line 15324-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I, Sir, am Dromio; pray let me stay.
line 15325-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Aegeon, art thou not? or else his
line 15326-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O, my old master! who hath bound
line 15327-->ABBESS. Whoever bound him, I will loose his bonds,
line 15328-->  And gain a husband by his liberty.
line 15329-->  Speak, old Aegeon, if thou be'st the man
line 15330-->  That hadst a wife once call'd Aemilia,
line 15331-->  That bore thee at a burden two fair sons.
line 15332-->  O, if thou be'st the same Aegeon, speak,
line 15333-->  And speak unto the same Aemilia!
line 15334-->AEGEON. If I dream not, thou art Aemilia.
line 15335-->  If thou art she, tell me where is that son
line 15336-->  That floated with thee on the fatal raft?
line 15337-->ABBESS. By men of Epidamnum he and I
line 15338-->  And the twin Dromio, all were taken up;
line 15339-->  But by and by rude fishermen of Corinth
line 15340-->  By force took Dromio and my son from them,
line 15341-->  And me they left with those of Epidamnum.
line 15342-->  What then became of them I cannot tell;
line 15343-->  I to this fortune that you see me in.
line 15344-->DUKE. Why, here begins his morning story right.
line 15345-->  These two Antipholus', these two so like,
line 15346-->  And these two Dromios, one in semblance-
line 15347-->  Besides her urging of her wreck at sea-
line 15348-->  These are the parents to these children,
line 15349-->  Which accidentally are met together.
line 15350-->  Antipholus, thou cam'st from Corinth first?
line 15351-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. No, sir, not I; I came from Syracuse.
line 15352-->DUKE. Stay, stand apart; I know not which is which.
line 15353-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord.
line 15354-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. And I with him.
line 15355-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Brought to this town by that most famous warrior,
line 15356-->  Duke Menaphon, your most renowned uncle.
line 15357-->ADRIANA. Which of you two did dine with me to-day?
line 15358-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I, gentle mistress.
line 15359-->ADRIANA. And are not you my husband?
line 15360-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. No; I say nay to that.
line 15361-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. And so do I, yet did she call me so;
line 15362-->  And this fair gentlewoman, her sister here,
line 15363-->  Did call me brother.  [To LUCIANA]  What I told you then,
line 15364-->  I hope I shall have leisure to make good;
line 15365-->  If this be not a dream I see and hear.
line 15366-->ANGELO. That is the chain, sir, which you had of me.
line 15367-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I think it be, sir; I deny it not.
line 15368-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. And you, sir, for this chain arrested me.
line 15369-->ANGELO. I think I did, sir; I deny it not.
line 15370-->ADRIANA. I sent you money, sir, to be your bail,
line 15371-->  By Dromio; but I think he brought it not.
line 15372-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. No, none by me.
line 15373-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. This purse of ducats I receiv'd from you,
line 15374-->  And Dromio my man did bring them me.
line 15375-->  I see we still did meet each other's man,
line 15376-->  And I was ta'en for him, and he for me,
line 15377-->  And thereupon these ERRORS are arose.
line 15378-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. These ducats pawn I for my father here.
line 15379-->DUKE. It shall not need; thy father hath his life.
line 15380-->COURTEZAN. Sir, I must have that diamond from you.
line 15381-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. There, take it; and much thanks for my
line 15382-->  good cheer.
line 15383-->ABBESS. Renowned Duke, vouchsafe to take the pains
line 15384-->  To go with us into the abbey here,
line 15385-->  And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes;
line 15386-->  And all that are assembled in this place
line 15387-->  That by this sympathized one day's error
line 15388-->  Have suffer'd wrong, go keep us company,
line 15389-->  And we shall make full satisfaction.
line 15390-->  Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail
line 15391-->  Of you, my sons; and till this present hour
line 15392-->  My heavy burden ne'er delivered.
line 15393-->  The Duke, my husband, and my children both,
line 15394-->  And you the calendars of their nativity,
line 15395-->  Go to a gossips' feast, and go with me;
line 15396-->  After so long grief, such nativity!
line 15397-->DUKE. With all my heart, I'll gossip at this feast.
line 15398--><Exeunt all but ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE, ANTIPHOLUS OF
line 15399-->EPHESUS, DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, and DROMIO OF EPHESUS
line 15400-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, shall I fetch your stuff from shipboard?
line 15401-->ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Dromio, what stuff of mine hast thou embark'd?
line 15402-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Your goods that lay at host, sir, in the Centaur.
line 15403-->ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. He speaks to me. I am your master, Dromio.
line 15404-->  Come, go with us; we'll look to that anon.
line 15405-->  Embrace thy brother there; rejoice with him.
line 15406--><Exeunt ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
line 15407-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. There is a fat friend at your master's house,
line 15408-->  That kitchen'd me for you to-day at dinner;
line 15409-->  She now shall be my sister, not my wife.
line 15410-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother;
line 15411-->  I see by you I am a sweet-fac'd youth.
line 15412-->  Will you walk in to see their gossiping?
line 15413-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Not I, sir; you are my elder.
line 15414-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. That's a question; how shall we try it?
line 15415-->DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. We'll draw cuts for the senior; till then,
line 15416-->    lead thou first.
line 15417-->DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Nay, then, thus:
line 15418-->  We came into the world like brother and brother,
line 15419-->  And now let's go hand in hand, not one before another.
line 15420--><Exeunt
line 15421-->
line 15422-->
line 15423-->THE END
