line 15493-->
line 15494-->SCENE:
line 15495-->Rome and the neighbourhood; Corioli and the neighbourhood; Antium
line 15496-->
line 15497-->
line 15498-->
line 15499-->ACT I. SCENE I.
line 15500-->Rome. A street
line 15501-->
line 15502-->Enter a company of mutinous citizens, with staves, clubs, and other weapons
line 15503-->
line 15504-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.
line 15505-->  ALL. Speak, speak.
line 15506-->  FIRST CITIZEN. YOU are all resolv'd rather to die than to famish?
line 15507-->  ALL. Resolv'd, resolv'd.
line 15508-->  FIRST CITIZEN. First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the
line 15509-->    people.
line 15510-->  ALL. We know't, we know't.
line 15511-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own
line 15512-->    price. Is't a verdict?
line 15513-->  ALL. No more talking on't; let it be done. Away, away!
line 15514-->  SECOND CITIZEN. One word, good citizens.
line 15515-->  FIRST CITIZEN. We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good.
line 15516-->    What authority surfeits on would relieve us; if they would yield
line 15517-->    us but the superfluity while it were wholesome, we might guess
line 15518-->    they relieved us humanely; but they think we are too dear. The
line 15519-->    leanness that afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an  
line 15520-->    inventory to particularize their abundance; our sufferance is a
line 15521-->    gain to them. Let us revenge this with our pikes ere we become
line 15522-->    rakes; for the gods know I speak this in hunger for bread, not in
line 15523-->    thirst for revenge.
line 15524-->  SECOND CITIZEN. Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius?
line 15525-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Against him first; he's a very dog to the
line 15526-->    commonalty.
line 15527-->  SECOND CITIZEN. Consider you what services he has done for his
line 15528-->    country?
line 15529-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Very well, and could be content to give him good
line 15530-->    report for't but that he pays himself with being proud.
line 15531-->  SECOND CITIZEN. Nay, but speak not maliciously.
line 15532-->  FIRST CITIZEN. I say unto you, what he hath done famously he did it
line 15533-->    to that end; though soft-conscienc'd men can be content to say it
line 15534-->    was for his country, he did it to please his mother and to be
line 15535-->    partly proud, which he is, even to the altitude of his virtue.
line 15536-->  SECOND CITIZEN. What he cannot help in his nature you account a
line 15537-->    vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.
line 15538-->  FIRST CITIZEN. If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations;
line 15539-->    he hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition.  [Shouts  
line 15540-->    within]  What shouts are these? The other side o' th' city is
line 15541-->    risen. Why stay we prating here? To th' Capitol!
line 15542-->  ALL. Come, come.
line 15543-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Soft! who comes here?
line 15544-->
line 15545-->                       Enter MENENIUS AGRIPPA
line 15546-->
line 15547-->  SECOND CITIZEN. Worthy Menenius Agrippa; one that hath always lov'd
line 15548-->    the people.
line 15549-->  FIRST CITIZEN. He's one honest enough; would all the rest were so!
line 15550-->  MENENIUS. What work's, my countrymen, in hand? Where go you
line 15551-->    With bats and clubs? The matter? Speak, I pray you.
line 15552-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Our business is not unknown to th' Senate; they have
line 15553-->    had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do, which now we'll
line 15554-->    show 'em in deeds. They say poor suitors have strong breaths;
line 15555-->    they shall know we have strong arms too.
line 15556-->  MENENIUS. Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours,
line 15557-->    Will you undo yourselves?
line 15558-->  FIRST CITIZEN. We cannot, sir; we are undone already.
line 15559-->  MENENIUS. I tell you, friends, most charitable care  
line 15560-->    Have the patricians of you. For your wants,
line 15561-->    Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well
line 15562-->    Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them
line 15563-->    Against the Roman state; whose course will on
line 15564-->    The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs
line 15565-->    Of more strong link asunder than can ever
line 15566-->    Appear in your impediment. For the dearth,
line 15567-->    The gods, not the patricians, make it, and
line 15568-->    Your knees to them, not arms, must help. Alack,
line 15569-->    You are transported by calamity
line 15570-->    Thither where more attends you; and you slander
line 15571-->    The helms o' th' state, who care for you like fathers,
line 15572-->    When you curse them as enemies.
line 15573-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Care for us! True, indeed! They ne'er car'd for us
line 15574-->    yet. Suffer us to famish, and their storehouses cramm'd with
line 15575-->    grain; make edicts for usury, to support usurers; repeal daily
line 15576-->    any wholesome act established against the rich, and provide more
line 15577-->    piercing statutes daily to chain up and restrain the poor. If the
line 15578-->    wars eat us not up, they will; and there's all the love they bear
line 15579-->    us.  
line 15580-->  MENENIUS. Either you must
line 15581-->    Confess yourselves wondrous malicious,
line 15582-->    Or be accus'd of folly. I shall tell you
line 15583-->    A pretty tale. It may be you have heard it;
line 15584-->    But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture
line 15585-->    To stale't a little more.
line 15586-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Well, I'll hear it, sir; yet you must not think to
line 15587-->    fob off our disgrace with a tale. But, an't please you, deliver.
line 15588-->  MENENIUS. There was a time when all the body's members
line 15589-->    Rebell'd against the belly; thus accus'd it:
line 15590-->    That only like a gulf it did remain
line 15591-->    I' th' midst o' th' body, idle and unactive,
line 15592-->    Still cupboarding the viand, never bearing
line 15593-->    Like labour with the rest; where th' other instruments
line 15594-->    Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel,
line 15595-->    And, mutually participate, did minister
line 15596-->    Unto the appetite and affection common
line 15597-->    Of the whole body. The belly answer'd-
line 15598-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Well, sir, what answer made the belly?
line 15599-->  MENENIUS. Sir, I shall tell you. With a kind of smile,  
line 15600-->    Which ne'er came from the lungs, but even thus-
line 15601-->    For look you, I may make the belly smile
line 15602-->    As well as speak- it tauntingly replied
line 15603-->    To th' discontented members, the mutinous parts
line 15604-->    That envied his receipt; even so most fitly
line 15605-->    As you malign our senators for that
line 15606-->    They are not such as you.
line 15607-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Your belly's answer- What?
line 15608-->    The kingly crowned head, the vigilant eye,
line 15609-->    The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier,
line 15610-->    Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter,
line 15611-->    With other muniments and petty helps
line 15612-->    Is this our fabric, if that they-
line 15613-->  MENENIUS. What then?
line 15614-->    Fore me, this fellow speaks! What then? What then?
line 15615-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Should by the cormorant belly be restrain'd,
line 15616-->    Who is the sink o' th' body-
line 15617-->  MENENIUS. Well, what then?
line 15618-->  FIRST CITIZEN. The former agents, if they did complain,
line 15619-->    What could the belly answer?  
line 15620-->  MENENIUS. I will tell you;
line 15621-->    If you'll bestow a small- of what you have little-
line 15622-->    Patience awhile, you'st hear the belly's answer.
line 15623-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Y'are long about it.
line 15624-->  MENENIUS. Note me this, good friend:
line 15625-->    Your most grave belly was deliberate,
line 15626-->    Not rash like his accusers, and thus answered.
line 15627-->    'True is it, my incorporate friends,' quoth he
line 15628-->    'That I receive the general food at first
line 15629-->    Which you do live upon; and fit it is,
line 15630-->    Because I am the storehouse and the shop
line 15631-->    Of the whole body. But, if you do remember,
line 15632-->    I send it through the rivers of your blood,
line 15633-->    Even to the court, the heart, to th' seat o' th' brain;
line 15634-->    And, through the cranks and offices of man,
line 15635-->    The strongest nerves and small inferior veins
line 15636-->    From me receive that natural competency
line 15637-->    Whereby they live. And though that all at once
line 15638-->    You, my good friends'- this says the belly; mark me.
line 15639-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Ay, sir; well, well.  
line 15640-->  MENENIUS. 'Though all at once cannot
line 15641-->    See what I do deliver out to each,
line 15642-->    Yet I can make my audit up, that all
line 15643-->    From me do back receive the flour of all,
line 15644-->    And leave me but the bran.' What say you to' t?
line 15645-->  FIRST CITIZEN. It was an answer. How apply you this?
line 15646-->  MENENIUS. The senators of Rome are this good belly,
line 15647-->    And you the mutinous members; for, examine
line 15648-->    Their counsels and their cares, digest things rightly
line 15649-->    Touching the weal o' th' common, you shall find
line 15650-->    No public benefit which you receive
line 15651-->    But it proceeds or comes from them to you,
line 15652-->    And no way from yourselves. What do you think,
line 15653-->    You, the great toe of this assembly?
line 15654-->  FIRST CITIZEN. I the great toe? Why the great toe?
line 15655-->  MENENIUS. For that, being one o' th' lowest, basest, poorest,
line 15656-->    Of this most wise rebellion, thou goest foremost.
line 15657-->    Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run,
line 15658-->    Lead'st first to win some vantage.
line 15659-->    But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs.  
line 15660-->    Rome and her rats are at the point of battle;
line 15661-->    The one side must have bale.
line 15662-->
line 15663-->                      Enter CAIUS MARCIUS
line 15664-->
line 15665-->    Hail, noble Marcius!
line 15666-->  MARCIUS. Thanks. What's the matter, you dissentious rogues
line 15667-->    That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion,
line 15668-->    Make yourselves scabs?
line 15669-->  FIRST CITIZEN. We have ever your good word.
line 15670-->  MARCIUS. He that will give good words to thee will flatter
line 15671-->    Beneath abhorring. What would you have, you curs,
line 15672-->    That like nor peace nor war? The one affrights you,
line 15673-->    The other makes you proud. He that trusts to you,
line 15674-->    Where he should find you lions, finds you hares;
line 15675-->    Where foxes, geese; you are no surer, no,
line 15676-->    Than is the coal of fire upon the ice
line 15677-->    Or hailstone in the sun. Your virtue is
line 15678-->    To make him worthy whose offence subdues him,
line 15679-->    And curse that justice did it. Who deserves greatness  
line 15680-->    Deserves your hate; and your affections are
line 15681-->    A sick man's appetite, who desires most that
line 15682-->    Which would increase his evil. He that depends
line 15683-->    Upon your favours swims with fins of lead,
line 15684-->    And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye! Trust ye?
line 15685-->    With every minute you do change a mind
line 15686-->    And call him noble that was now your hate,
line 15687-->    Him vile that was your garland. What's the matter
line 15688-->    That in these several places of the city
line 15689-->    You cry against the noble Senate, who,
line 15690-->    Under the gods, keep you in awe, which else
line 15691-->    Would feed on one another? What's their seeking?
line 15692-->  MENENIUS. For corn at their own rates, whereof they say
line 15693-->    The city is well stor'd.
line 15694-->  MARCIUS. Hang 'em! They say!
line 15695-->    They'll sit by th' fire and presume to know
line 15696-->    What's done i' th' Capitol, who's like to rise,
line 15697-->    Who thrives and who declines; side factions, and give out
line 15698-->    Conjectural marriages, making parties strong,
line 15699-->    And feebling such as stand not in their liking  
line 15700-->    Below their cobbled shoes. They say there's grain enough!
line 15701-->    Would the nobility lay aside their ruth
line 15702-->    And let me use my sword, I'd make a quarry
line 15703-->    With thousands of these quarter'd slaves, as high
line 15704-->    As I could pick my lance.
line 15705-->  MENENIUS. Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded;
line 15706-->    For though abundantly they lack discretion,
line 15707-->    Yet are they passing cowardly. But, I beseech you,
line 15708-->    What says the other troop?
line 15709-->  MARCIUS. They are dissolv'd. Hang 'em!
line 15710-->    They said they were an-hungry; sigh'd forth proverbs-
line 15711-->    That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat,
line 15712-->    That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent not
line 15713-->    Corn for the rich men only. With these shreds
line 15714-->    They vented their complainings; which being answer'd,
line 15715-->    And a petition granted them- a strange one,
line 15716-->    To break the heart of generosity
line 15717-->    And make bold power look pale- they threw their caps
line 15718-->    As they would hang them on the horns o' th' moon,
line 15719-->    Shouting their emulation.  
line 15720-->  MENENIUS. What is granted them?
line 15721-->  MARCIUS. Five tribunes, to defend their vulgar wisdoms,
line 15722-->    Of their own choice. One's Junius Brutus-
line 15723-->    Sicinius Velutus, and I know not. 'Sdeath!
line 15724-->    The rabble should have first unroof'd the city
line 15725-->    Ere so prevail'd with me; it will in time
line 15726-->    Win upon power and throw forth greater themes
line 15727-->    For insurrection's arguing.
line 15728-->  MENENIUS. This is strange.
line 15729-->  MARCIUS. Go get you home, you fragments.
line 15730-->
line 15731-->                     Enter a MESSENGER, hastily
line 15732-->
line 15733-->  MESSENGER. Where's Caius Marcius?
line 15734-->  MARCIUS. Here. What's the matter?
line 15735-->  MESSENGER. The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms.
line 15736-->  MARCIUS. I am glad on't; then we shall ha' means to vent
line 15737-->    Our musty superfluity. See, our best elders.
line 15738-->
line 15739-->         Enter COMINIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, with other SENATORS;  
line 15740-->                  JUNIUS BRUTUS and SICINIUS VELUTUS
line 15741-->
line 15742-->  FIRST SENATOR. Marcius, 'tis true that you have lately told us:
line 15743-->    The Volsces are in arms.
line 15744-->  MARCIUS. They have a leader,
line 15745-->    Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to't.
line 15746-->    I sin in envying his nobility;
line 15747-->    And were I anything but what I am,
line 15748-->    I would wish me only he.
line 15749-->  COMINIUS. You have fought together?
line 15750-->  MARCIUS. Were half to half the world by th' ears, and he
line 15751-->    Upon my party, I'd revolt, to make
line 15752-->    Only my wars with him. He is a lion
line 15753-->    That I am proud to hunt.
line 15754-->  FIRST SENATOR. Then, worthy Marcius,
line 15755-->    Attend upon Cominius to these wars.
line 15756-->  COMINIUS. It is your former promise.
line 15757-->  MARCIUS. Sir, it is;
line 15758-->    And I am constant. Titus Lartius, thou
line 15759-->    Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus' face.  
line 15760-->    What, art thou stiff? Stand'st out?
line 15761-->  LARTIUS. No, Caius Marcius;
line 15762-->    I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with t'other
line 15763-->    Ere stay behind this business.
line 15764-->  MENENIUS. O, true bred!
line 15765-->  FIRST SENATOR. Your company to th' Capitol; where, I know,
line 15766-->    Our greatest friends attend us.
line 15767-->  LARTIUS.  [To COMINIUS]  Lead you on.
line 15768-->    [To MARCIUS]  Follow Cominius; we must follow you;
line 15769-->    Right worthy you priority.
line 15770-->  COMINIUS. Noble Marcius!
line 15771-->  FIRST SENATOR.  [To the Citizens]  Hence to your homes; be gone.
line 15772-->  MARCIUS. Nay, let them follow.
line 15773-->    The Volsces have much corn: take these rats thither
line 15774-->    To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutineers,
line 15775-->    Your valour puts well forth; pray follow.
line 15776-->         Ciitzens steal away. Exeunt all but SICINIUS and BRUTUS
line 15777-->  SICINIUS. Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius?
line 15778-->  BRUTUS. He has no equal.
line 15779-->  SICINIUS. When we were chosen tribunes for the people-  
line 15780-->  BRUTUS. Mark'd you his lip and eyes?
line 15781-->  SICINIUS. Nay, but his taunts!
line 15782-->  BRUTUS. Being mov'd, he will not spare to gird the gods.
line 15783-->  SICINIUS. Bemock the modest moon.
line 15784-->  BRUTUS. The present wars devour him! He is grown
line 15785-->    Too proud to be so valiant.
line 15786-->  SICINIUS. Such a nature,
line 15787-->    Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow
line 15788-->    Which he treads on at noon. But I do wonder
line 15789-->    His insolence can brook to be commanded
line 15790-->    Under Cominius.
line 15791-->  BRUTUS. Fame, at the which he aims-
line 15792-->    In whom already he is well grac'd- cannot
line 15793-->    Better be held nor more attain'd than by
line 15794-->    A place below the first; for what miscarries
line 15795-->    Shall be the general's fault, though he perform
line 15796-->    To th' utmost of a man, and giddy censure
line 15797-->    Will then cry out of Marcius 'O, if he
line 15798-->    Had borne the business!'
line 15799-->  SICINIUS. Besides, if things go well,  
line 15800-->    Opinion, that so sticks on Marcius, shall
line 15801-->    Of his demerits rob Cominius.
line 15802-->  BRUTUS. Come.
line 15803-->    Half all Cominius' honours are to Marcius,
line 15804-->    Though Marcius earn'd them not; and all his faults
line 15805-->    To Marcius shall be honours, though indeed
line 15806-->    In aught he merit not.
line 15807-->  SICINIUS. Let's hence and hear
line 15808-->    How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion,
line 15809-->    More than his singularity, he goes
line 15810-->    Upon this present action.
line 15811-->  BRUTUS. Let's along.                                    Exeunt
line 15812-->
line 15813-->
line 15814-->
line 15815-->
line 15816-->SCENE II.
line 15817-->Corioli. The Senate House.
line 15818-->
line 15819-->Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS with SENATORS of Corioli
line 15820-->
line 15821-->  FIRST SENATOR. So, your opinion is, Aufidius,
line 15822-->    That they of Rome are ent'red in our counsels
line 15823-->    And know how we proceed.
line 15824-->  AUFIDIUS. Is it not yours?
line 15825-->    What ever have been thought on in this state
line 15826-->    That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome
line 15827-->    Had circumvention? 'Tis not four days gone
line 15828-->    Since I heard thence; these are the words- I think
line 15829-->    I have the letter here;.yes, here it is:
line 15830-->    [Reads]  'They have press'd a power, but it is not known
line 15831-->    Whether for east or west. The dearth is great;
line 15832-->    The people mutinous; and it is rumour'd,
line 15833-->    Cominius, Marcius your old enemy,
line 15834-->    Who is of Rome worse hated than of you,
line 15835-->    And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman,
line 15836-->    These three lead on this preparation
line 15837-->    Whither 'tis bent. Most likely 'tis for you;  
line 15838-->    Consider of it.'
line 15839-->  FIRST SENATOR. Our army's in the field;
line 15840-->    We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready
line 15841-->    To answer us.
line 15842-->  AUFIDIUS. Nor did you think it folly
line 15843-->    To keep your great pretences veil'd till when
line 15844-->    They needs must show themselves; which in the hatching,
line 15845-->    It seem'd, appear'd to Rome. By the discovery
line 15846-->    We shall be short'ned in our aim, which was
line 15847-->    To take in many towns ere almost Rome
line 15848-->    Should know we were afoot.
line 15849-->  SECOND SENATOR. Noble Aufidius,
line 15850-->    Take your commission; hie you to your bands;
line 15851-->    Let us alone to guard Corioli.
line 15852-->    If they set down before's, for the remove
line 15853-->    Bring up your army; but I think you'll find
line 15854-->    Th' have not prepar'd for us.
line 15855-->  AUFIDIUS. O, doubt not that!
line 15856-->    I speak from certainties. Nay more,
line 15857-->    Some parcels of their power are forth already,  
line 15858-->    And only hitherward. I leave your honours.
line 15859-->    If we and Caius Marcius chance to meet,
line 15860-->    'Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike
line 15861-->    Till one can do no more.
line 15862-->  ALL. The gods assist you!
line 15863-->  AUFIDIUS. And keep your honours safe!
line 15864-->  FIRST SENATOR. Farewell.
line 15865-->  SECOND SENATOR. Farewell.
line 15866-->  ALL. Farewell.                                           Exeunt
line 15867-->
line 15868-->
line 15869-->
line 15870-->
line 15871-->SCENE III.
line 15872-->Rome. MARCIUS' house
line 15873-->
line 15874-->Enter VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA, mother and wife to MARCIUS;
line 15875-->they set them down on two low stools and sew
line 15876-->
line 15877-->  VOLUMNIA. I pray you, daughter, sing, or express yourself in a more
line 15878-->    comfortable sort. If my son were my husband, I should freelier
line 15879-->    rejoice in that absence wherein he won honour than in the
line 15880-->    embracements of his bed where he would show most love. When yet
line 15881-->    he was but tender-bodied, and the only son of my womb; when youth
line 15882-->    with comeliness pluck'd all gaze his way; when, for a day of
line 15883-->    kings' entreaties, a mother should not sell him an hour from her
line 15884-->    beholding; I, considering how honour would become such a person-
line 15885-->    that it was no better than picture-like to hang by th' wall, if
line 15886-->    renown made it not stir- was pleas'd to let him seek danger where
line 15887-->    he was to find fame. To a cruel war I sent him, from whence he
line 15888-->    return'd his brows bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I
line 15889-->    sprang not more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child than
line 15890-->    now in first seeing he had proved himself a man.
line 15891-->  VIRGILIA. But had he died in the business, madam, how then?
line 15892-->  VOLUMNIA. Then his good report should have been my son; I therein  
line 15893-->    would have found issue. Hear me profess sincerely: had I a dozen
line 15894-->    sons, each in my love alike, and none less dear than thine and my
line 15895-->    good Marcius, I had rather had eleven die nobly for their country
line 15896-->    than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.
line 15897-->
line 15898-->                        Enter a GENTLEWOMAN
line 15899-->
line 15900-->  GENTLEWOMAN. Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to visit you.
line 15901-->  VIRGILIA. Beseech you give me leave to retire myself.
line 15902-->  VOLUMNIA. Indeed you shall not.
line 15903-->    Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum;
line 15904-->    See him pluck Aufidius down by th' hair;
line 15905-->    As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him.
line 15906-->    Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call thus:
line 15907-->    'Come on, you cowards! You were got in fear,
line 15908-->    Though you were born in Rome.' His bloody brow
line 15909-->    With his mail'd hand then wiping, forth he goes,
line 15910-->    Like to a harvest-man that's task'd to mow
line 15911-->    Or all or lose his hire.
line 15912-->  VIRGILIA. His bloody brow? O Jupiter, no blood!  
line 15913-->  VOLUMNIA. Away, you fool! It more becomes a man
line 15914-->    Than gilt his trophy. The breasts of Hecuba,
line 15915-->    When she did suckle Hector, look'd not lovelier
line 15916-->    Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blood
line 15917-->    At Grecian sword, contemning. Tell Valeria
line 15918-->    We are fit to bid her welcome.              Exit GENTLEWOMAN
line 15919-->  VIRGILIA. Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!
line 15920-->  VOLUMNIA. He'll beat Aufidius' head below his knee
line 15921-->    And tread upon his neck.
line 15922-->
line 15923-->         Re-enter GENTLEWOMAN, With VALERIA and an usher
line 15924-->
line 15925-->  VALERIA. My ladies both, good day to you.
line 15926-->  VOLUMNIA. Sweet madam!
line 15927-->  VIRGILIA. I am glad to see your ladyship.
line 15928-->  VALERIA. How do you both? You are manifest housekeepers. What are
line 15929-->    you sewing here? A fine spot, in good faith. How does your little
line 15930-->    son?
line 15931-->  VIRGILIA. I thank your ladyship; well, good madam.
line 15932-->  VOLUMNIA. He had rather see the swords and hear a drum than look  
line 15933-->    upon his schoolmaster.
line 15934-->  VALERIA. O' my word, the father's son! I'll swear 'tis a very
line 15935-->    pretty boy. O' my troth, I look'd upon him a Wednesday half an
line 15936-->    hour together; has such a confirm'd countenance! I saw him run
line 15937-->    after a gilded butterfly; and when he caught it he let it go
line 15938-->    again, and after it again, and over and over he comes, and up
line 15939-->    again, catch'd it again; or whether his fall enrag'd him, or how
line 15940-->    'twas, he did so set his teeth and tear it. O, I warrant, how he
line 15941-->    mammock'd it!
line 15942-->  VOLUMNIA. One on's father's moods.
line 15943-->  VALERIA. Indeed, la, 'tis a noble child.
line 15944-->  VIRGILIA. A crack, madam.
line 15945-->  VALERIA. Come, lay aside your stitchery; I must have you play the
line 15946-->    idle huswife with me this afternoon.
line 15947-->  VIRGILIA. No, good madam; I will not out of doors.
line 15948-->  VALERIA. Not out of doors!
line 15949-->  VOLUMNIA. She shall, she shall.
line 15950-->  VIRGILIA. Indeed, no, by your patience; I'll not over the threshold
line 15951-->    till my lord return from the wars.
line 15952-->  VALERIA. Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably; come, you  
line 15953-->    must go visit the good lady that lies in.
line 15954-->  VIRGILIA. I will wish her speedy strength, and visit her with my
line 15955-->    prayers; but I cannot go thither.
line 15956-->  VOLUMNIA. Why, I pray you?
line 15957-->  VIRGILIA. 'Tis not to save labour, nor that I want love.
line 15958-->  VALERIA. You would be another Penelope; yet they say all the yarn
line 15959-->    she spun in Ulysses' absence did but fill Ithaca full of moths.
line 15960-->    Come, I would your cambric were sensible as your finger, that you
line 15961-->    might leave pricking it for pity. Come, you shall go with us.
line 15962-->  VIRGILIA. No, good madam, pardon me; indeed I will not forth.
line 15963-->  VALERIA. In truth, la, go with me; and I'll tell you excellent news
line 15964-->    of your husband.
line 15965-->  VIRGILIA. O, good madam, there can be none yet.
line 15966-->  VALERIA. Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from him
line 15967-->    last night.
line 15968-->  VIRGILIA. Indeed, madam?
line 15969-->  VALERIA. In earnest, it's true; I heard a senator speak it. Thus it
line 15970-->    is: the Volsces have an army forth; against whom Cominius the
line 15971-->    general is gone, with one part of our Roman power. Your lord and
line 15972-->    Titus Lartius are set down before their city Corioli; they  
line 15973-->    nothing doubt prevailing and to make it brief wars. This is true,
line 15974-->    on mine honour; and so, I pray, go with us.
line 15975-->  VIRGILIA. Give me excuse, good madam; I will obey you in everything
line 15976-->    hereafter.
line 15977-->  VOLUMNIA. Let her alone, lady; as she is now, she will but disease
line 15978-->    our better mirth.
line 15979-->  VALERIA. In troth, I think she would. Fare you well, then. Come,
line 15980-->    good sweet lady. Prithee, Virgilia, turn thy solemness out o'
line 15981-->    door and go along with us.
line 15982-->  VIRGILIA. No, at a word, madam; indeed I must not. I wish you much
line 15983-->    mirth.
line 15984-->  VALERIA. Well then, farewell.                           Exeunt
line 15985-->
line 15986-->
line 15987-->
line 15988-->
line 15989-->SCENE IV.
line 15990-->Before Corioli
line 15991-->
line 15992-->Enter MARCIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, with drum and colours,
line 15993-->with CAPTAINS and soldiers. To them a MESSENGER
line 15994-->
line 15995-->  MARCIUS. Yonder comes news; a wager- they have met.
line 15996-->  LARTIUS. My horse to yours- no.
line 15997-->  MARCIUS. 'Tis done.
line 15998-->  LARTIUS. Agreed.
line 15999-->  MARCIUS. Say, has our general met the enemy?
line 16000-->  MESSENGER. They lie in view, but have not spoke as yet.
line 16001-->  LARTIUS. So, the good horse is mine.
line 16002-->  MARCIUS. I'll buy him of you.
line 16003-->  LARTIUS. No, I'll nor sell nor give him; lend you him I will
line 16004-->    For half a hundred years. Summon the town.
line 16005-->  MARCIUS. How far off lie these armies?
line 16006-->  MESSENGER. Within this mile and half.
line 16007-->  MARCIUS. Then shall we hear their 'larum, and they ours.
line 16008-->    Now, Mars, I prithee, make us quick in work,
line 16009-->    That we with smoking swords may march from hence
line 16010-->    To help our fielded friends! Come, blow thy blast.  
line 16011-->
line 16012-->          They sound a parley. Enter two SENATORS with others,
line 16013-->                      on the walls of Corioli
line 16014-->
line 16015-->    Tullus Aufidius, is he within your walls?
line 16016-->  FIRST SENATOR. No, nor a man that fears you less than he:
line 16017-->    That's lesser than a little.  [Drum afar off]  Hark, our drums
line 16018-->    Are bringing forth our youth. We'll break our walls
line 16019-->    Rather than they shall pound us up; our gates,
line 16020-->    Which yet seem shut, we have but pinn'd with rushes;
line 16021-->    They'll open of themselves.  [Alarum far off]  Hark you far off!
line 16022-->    There is Aufidius. List what work he makes
line 16023-->    Amongst your cloven army.
line 16024-->  MARCIUS. O, they are at it!
line 16025-->  LARTIUS. Their noise be our instruction. Ladders, ho!
line 16026-->
line 16027-->                   Enter the army of the Volsces
line 16028-->
line 16029-->  MARCIUS. They fear us not, but issue forth their city.
line 16030-->    Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight  
line 16031-->    With hearts more proof than shields. Advance, brave Titus.
line 16032-->    They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts,
line 16033-->    Which makes me sweat with wrath. Come on, my fellows.
line 16034-->    He that retires, I'll take him for a Volsce,
line 16035-->    And he shall feel mine edge.
line 16036-->
line 16037-->          Alarum. The Romans are beat back to their trenches.
line 16038-->                      Re-enter MARCIUS, cursing
line 16039-->
line 16040-->  MARCIUS. All the contagion of the south light on you,
line 16041-->    You shames of Rome! you herd of- Boils and plagues
line 16042-->    Plaster you o'er, that you may be abhorr'd
line 16043-->    Farther than seen, and one infect another
line 16044-->    Against the wind a mile! You souls of geese
line 16045-->    That bear the shapes of men, how have you run
line 16046-->    From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell!
line 16047-->    All hurt behind! Backs red, and faces pale
line 16048-->    With flight and agued fear! Mend and charge home,
line 16049-->    Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave the foe
line 16050-->    And make my wars on you. Look to't. Come on;  
line 16051-->    If you'll stand fast we'll beat them to their wives,
line 16052-->    As they us to our trenches. Follow me.
line 16053-->
line 16054-->         Another alarum. The Volsces fly, and MARCIUS follows
line 16055-->                          them to the gates
line 16056-->
line 16057-->    So, now the gates are ope; now prove good seconds;
line 16058-->    'Tis for the followers fortune widens them,
line 16059-->    Not for the fliers. Mark me, and do the like.
line 16060-->
line 16061-->                    [MARCIUS enters the gates]
line 16062-->
line 16063-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Fool-hardiness; not I.
line 16064-->  SECOND SOLDIER. Not I.                    [MARCIUS is shut in]
line 16065-->  FIRST SOLDIER. See, they have shut him in.
line 16066-->  ALL. To th' pot, I warrant him.             [Alarum continues]
line 16067-->
line 16068-->                      Re-enter TITUS LARTIUS
line 16069-->
line 16070-->  LARTIUS. What is become of Marcius?  
line 16071-->  ALL. Slain, sir, doubtless.
line 16072-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Following the fliers at the very heels,
line 16073-->    With them he enters; who, upon the sudden,
line 16074-->    Clapp'd to their gates. He is himself alone,
line 16075-->    To answer all the city.
line 16076-->  LARTIUS. O noble fellow!
line 16077-->    Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword,
line 16078-->    And when it bows stand'st up. Thou art left, Marcius;
line 16079-->    A carbuncle entire, as big as thou art,
line 16080-->    Were not so rich a jewel. Thou wast a soldier
line 16081-->    Even to Cato's wish, not fierce and terrible
line 16082-->    Only in strokes; but with thy grim looks and
line 16083-->    The thunder-like percussion of thy sounds
line 16084-->    Thou mad'st thine enemies shake, as if the world
line 16085-->    Were feverous and did tremble.
line 16086-->
line 16087-->          Re-enter MARCIUS, bleeding, assaulted by the enemy
line 16088-->
line 16089-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Look, sir.
line 16090-->  LARTIUS. O, 'tis Marcius!  
line 16091-->    Let's fetch him off, or make remain alike.
line 16092-->                            [They fight, and all enter the city]
line 16093-->
line 16094-->
line 16095-->
line 16096-->
line 16097-->SCENE V.
line 16098-->Within Corioli. A street
line 16099-->
line 16100-->Enter certain Romans, with spoils
line 16101-->
line 16102-->  FIRST ROMAN. This will I carry to Rome.
line 16103-->  SECOND ROMAN. And I this.
line 16104-->  THIRD ROMAN. A murrain on 't! I took this for silver.
line 16105-->                               [Alarum continues still afar off]
line 16106-->
line 16107-->          Enter MARCIUS and TITUS LARTIUS With a trumpeter
line 16108-->
line 16109-->  MARCIUS. See here these movers that do prize their hours
line 16110-->    At a crack'd drachma! Cushions, leaden spoons,
line 16111-->    Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would
line 16112-->    Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves,
line 16113-->    Ere yet the fight be done, pack up. Down with them!
line 16114-->                                                Exeunt pillagers
line 16115-->    And hark, what noise the general makes! To him!
line 16116-->    There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius,
line 16117-->    Piercing our Romans; then, valiant Titus, take
line 16118-->    Convenient numbers to make good the city;  
line 16119-->    Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste
line 16120-->    To help Cominius.
line 16121-->  LARTIUS. Worthy sir, thou bleed'st;
line 16122-->    Thy exercise hath been too violent
line 16123-->    For a second course of fight.
line 16124-->  MARCIUS. Sir, praise me not;
line 16125-->    My work hath yet not warm'd me. Fare you well;
line 16126-->    The blood I drop is rather physical
line 16127-->    Than dangerous to me. To Aufidius thus
line 16128-->    I will appear, and fight.
line 16129-->  LARTIUS. Now the fair goddess, Fortune,
line 16130-->    Fall deep in love with thee, and her great charms
line 16131-->    Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman,
line 16132-->    Prosperity be thy page!
line 16133-->  MARCIUS. Thy friend no less
line 16134-->    Than those she placeth highest! So farewell.
line 16135-->  LARTIUS. Thou worthiest Marcius!                  Exit MARCIUS
line 16136-->    Go sound thy trumpet in the market-place;
line 16137-->    Call thither all the officers o' th' town,
line 16138-->    Where they shall know our mind. Away!                 Exeunt
line 16139-->
line 16140-->
line 16141-->
line 16142-->
line 16143-->SCENE VI.
line 16144-->Near the camp of COMINIUS
line 16145-->
line 16146-->Enter COMINIUS, as it were in retire, with soldiers
line 16147-->
line 16148-->  COMINIUS. Breathe you, my friends. Well fought; we are come off
line 16149-->    Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands
line 16150-->    Nor cowardly in retire. Believe me, sirs,
line 16151-->    We shall be charg'd again. Whiles we have struck,
line 16152-->    By interims and conveying gusts we have heard
line 16153-->    The charges of our friends. The Roman gods,
line 16154-->    Lead their successes as we wish our own,
line 16155-->    That both our powers, with smiling fronts encount'ring,
line 16156-->    May give you thankful sacrifice!
line 16157-->
line 16158-->                         Enter A MESSENGER
line 16159-->
line 16160-->    Thy news?
line 16161-->  MESSENGER. The citizens of Corioli have issued
line 16162-->    And given to Lartius and to Marcius battle;
line 16163-->    I saw our party to their trenches driven,
line 16164-->    And then I came away.  
line 16165-->  COMINIUS. Though thou speak'st truth,
line 16166-->    Methinks thou speak'st not well. How long is't since?
line 16167-->  MESSENGER. Above an hour, my lord.
line 16168-->  COMINIUS. 'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums.
line 16169-->    How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour,
line 16170-->    And bring thy news so late?
line 16171-->  MESSENGER. Spies of the Volsces
line 16172-->    Held me in chase, that I was forc'd to wheel
line 16173-->    Three or four miles about; else had I, sir,
line 16174-->    Half an hour since brought my report.
line 16175-->
line 16176-->                           Enter MARCIUS
line 16177-->
line 16178-->  COMINIUS. Who's yonder
line 16179-->    That does appear as he were flay'd? O gods!
line 16180-->    He has the stamp of Marcius, and I have
line 16181-->    Before-time seen him thus.
line 16182-->  MARCIUS. Come I too late?
line 16183-->  COMINIUS. The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabor
line 16184-->    More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue  
line 16185-->    From every meaner man.
line 16186-->  MARCIUS. Come I too late?
line 16187-->  COMINIUS. Ay, if you come not in the blood of others,
line 16188-->    But mantled in your own.
line 16189-->  MARCIUS. O! let me clip ye
line 16190-->    In arms as sound as when I woo'd, in heart
line 16191-->    As merry as when our nuptial day was done,
line 16192-->    And tapers burn'd to bedward.
line 16193-->  COMINIUS. Flower of warriors,
line 16194-->    How is't with Titus Lartius?
line 16195-->  MARCIUS. As with a man busied about decrees:
line 16196-->    Condemning some to death and some to exile;
line 16197-->    Ransoming him or pitying, threat'ning th' other;
line 16198-->    Holding Corioli in the name of Rome
line 16199-->    Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash,
line 16200-->    To let him slip at will.
line 16201-->  COMINIUS. Where is that slave
line 16202-->    Which told me they had beat you to your trenches?
line 16203-->    Where is he? Call him hither.
line 16204-->  MARCIUS. Let him alone;  
line 16205-->    He did inform the truth. But for our gentlemen,
line 16206-->    The common file- a plague! tribunes for them!
line 16207-->    The mouse ne'er shunn'd the cat as they did budge
line 16208-->    From rascals worse than they.
line 16209-->  COMINIUS. But how prevail'd you?
line 16210-->  MARCIUS. Will the time serve to tell? I do not think.
line 16211-->    Where is the enemy? Are you lords o' th' field?
line 16212-->    If not, why cease you till you are so?
line 16213-->  COMINIUS. Marcius,
line 16214-->    We have at disadvantage fought, and did
line 16215-->    Retire to win our purpose.
line 16216-->  MARCIUS. How lies their battle? Know you on which side
line 16217-->    They have plac'd their men of trust?
line 16218-->  COMINIUS. As I guess, Marcius,
line 16219-->    Their bands i' th' vaward are the Antiates,
line 16220-->    Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius,
line 16221-->    Their very heart of hope.
line 16222-->  MARCIUS. I do beseech you,
line 16223-->    By all the battles wherein we have fought,
line 16224-->    By th' blood we have shed together, by th' vows  
line 16225-->    We have made to endure friends, that you directly
line 16226-->    Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates;
line 16227-->    And that you not delay the present, but,
line 16228-->    Filling the air with swords advanc'd and darts,
line 16229-->    We prove this very hour.
line 16230-->  COMINIUS. Though I could wish
line 16231-->    You were conducted to a gentle bath
line 16232-->    And balms applied to you, yet dare I never
line 16233-->    Deny your asking: take your choice of those
line 16234-->    That best can aid your action.
line 16235-->  MARCIUS. Those are they
line 16236-->    That most are willing. If any such be here-
line 16237-->    As it were sin to doubt- that love this painting
line 16238-->    Wherein you see me smear'd; if any fear
line 16239-->    Lesser his person than an ill report;
line 16240-->    If any think brave death outweighs bad life
line 16241-->    And that his country's dearer than himself;
line 16242-->    Let him alone, or so many so minded,
line 16243-->    Wave thus to express his disposition,
line 16244-->    And follow Marcius.           [They all shout and wave their  
line 16245-->       swords, take him up in their arms and cast up their caps]
line 16246-->    O, me alone! Make you a sword of me?
line 16247-->    If these shows be not outward, which of you
line 16248-->    But is four Volsces? None of you but is
line 16249-->    Able to bear against the great Aufidius
line 16250-->    A shield as hard as his. A certain number,
line 16251-->    Though thanks to all, must I select from all; the rest
line 16252-->    Shall bear the business in some other fight,
line 16253-->    As cause will be obey'd. Please you to march;
line 16254-->    And four shall quickly draw out my command,
line 16255-->    Which men are best inclin'd.
line 16256-->  COMINIUS. March on, my fellows;
line 16257-->    Make good this ostentation, and you shall
line 16258-->    Divide in all with us.                                Exeunt
line 16259-->
line 16260-->
line 16261-->
line 16262-->
line 16263-->SCENE VII.
line 16264-->The gates of Corioli
line 16265-->
line 16266-->TITUS LARTIUS, having set a guard upon Corioli, going with drum and trumpet
line 16267-->toward COMINIUS and CAIUS MARCIUS, enters with a LIEUTENANT, other soldiers,
line 16268-->and a scout
line 16269-->
line 16270-->  LARTIUS. So, let the ports be guarded; keep your duties
line 16271-->    As I have set them down. If I do send, dispatch
line 16272-->    Those centuries to our aid; the rest will serve
line 16273-->    For a short holding. If we lose the field
line 16274-->    We cannot keep the town.
line 16275-->  LIEUTENANT. Fear not our care, sir.
line 16276-->  LARTIUS. Hence, and shut your gates upon's.
line 16277-->    Our guider, come; to th' Roman camp conduct us.       Exeunt
line 16278-->
line 16279-->
line 16280-->
line 16281-->
line 16282-->SCENE VIII.
line 16283-->A field of battle between the Roman and the Volscian camps
line 16284-->
line 16285-->Alarum, as in battle. Enter MARCIUS and AUFIDIUS at several doors
line 16286-->
line 16287-->  MARCIUS. I'll fight with none but thee, for I do hate thee
line 16288-->    Worse than a promise-breaker.
line 16289-->  AUFIDIUS. We hate alike:
line 16290-->    Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor
line 16291-->    More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.
line 16292-->  MARCIUS. Let the first budger die the other's slave,
line 16293-->    And the gods doom him after!
line 16294-->  AUFIDIUS. If I fly, Marcius,
line 16295-->    Halloa me like a hare.
line 16296-->  MARCIUS. Within these three hours, Tullus,
line 16297-->    Alone I fought in your Corioli walls,
line 16298-->    And made what work I pleas'd. 'Tis not my blood
line 16299-->    Wherein thou seest me mask'd. For thy revenge
line 16300-->    Wrench up thy power to th' highest.
line 16301-->  AUFIDIUS. Wert thou the Hector
line 16302-->    That was the whip of your bragg'd progeny,  
line 16303-->    Thou shouldst not scape me here.
line 16304-->
line 16305-->       Here they fight, and certain Volsces come in the aid
line 16306-->        of AUFIDIUS. MARCIUS fights till they be driven in
line 16307-->                             breathless
line 16308-->
line 16309-->    Officious, and not valiant, you have sham'd me
line 16310-->    In your condemned seconds.                            Exeunt
line 16311-->
line 16312-->
line 16313-->
line 16314-->
line 16315-->SCENE IX.
line 16316-->The Roman camp
line 16317-->
line 16318-->Flourish. Alarum. A retreat is sounded. Enter, at one door,
line 16319-->COMINIUS with the Romans; at another door, MARCIUS, with his arm in a scarf
line 16320-->
line 16321-->  COMINIUS. If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's work,
line 16322-->    Thou't not believe thy deeds; but I'll report it
line 16323-->    Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles;
line 16324-->    Where great patricians shall attend, and shrug,
line 16325-->    I' th' end admire; where ladies shall be frighted
line 16326-->    And, gladly quak'd, hear more; where the dull tribunes,
line 16327-->    That with the fusty plebeians hate thine honours,
line 16328-->    Shall say against their hearts 'We thank the gods
line 16329-->    Our Rome hath such a soldier.'
line 16330-->    Yet cam'st thou to a morsel of this feast,
line 16331-->    Having fully din'd before.
line 16332-->
line 16333-->         Enter TITUS LARTIUS, with his power, from the pursuit
line 16334-->
line 16335-->  LARTIUS. O General,  
line 16336-->    Here is the steed, we the caparison.
line 16337-->    Hadst thou beheld-
line 16338-->  MARCIUS. Pray now, no more; my mother,
line 16339-->    Who has a charter to extol her blood,
line 16340-->    When she does praise me grieves me. I have done
line 16341-->    As you have done- that's what I can; induc'd
line 16342-->    As you have been- that's for my country.
line 16343-->    He that has but effected his good will
line 16344-->    Hath overta'en mine act.
line 16345-->  COMINIUS. You shall not be
line 16346-->    The grave of your deserving; Rome must know
line 16347-->    The value of her own. 'Twere a concealment
line 16348-->    Worse than a theft, no less than a traducement,
line 16349-->    To hide your doings and to silence that
line 16350-->    Which, to the spire and top of praises vouch'd,
line 16351-->    Would seem but modest. Therefore, I beseech you,
line 16352-->    In sign of what you are, not to reward
line 16353-->    What you have done, before our army hear me.
line 16354-->  MARCIUS. I have some wounds upon me, and they smart
line 16355-->    To hear themselves rememb'red.  
line 16356-->  COMINIUS. Should they not,
line 16357-->    Well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude
line 16358-->    And tent themselves with death. Of all the horses-
line 16359-->    Whereof we have ta'en good, and good store- of all
line 16360-->    The treasure in this field achiev'd and city,
line 16361-->    We render you the tenth; to be ta'en forth
line 16362-->    Before the common distribution at
line 16363-->    Your only choice.
line 16364-->  MARCIUS. I thank you, General,
line 16365-->    But cannot make my heart consent to take
line 16366-->    A bribe to pay my sword. I do refuse it,
line 16367-->    And stand upon my common part with those
line 16368-->    That have beheld the doing.
line 16369-->
line 16370-->           A long flourish. They all cry 'Marcius, Marcius!'
line 16371-->   cast up their caps and lances. COMINIUS and LARTIUS stand bare
line 16372-->
line 16373-->    May these same instruments which you profane
line 16374-->    Never sound more! When drums and trumpets shall
line 16375-->    I' th' field prove flatterers, let courts and cities be  
line 16376-->    Made all of false-fac'd soothing. When steel grows
line 16377-->    Soft as the parasite's silk, let him be made
line 16378-->    An overture for th' wars. No more, I say.
line 16379-->    For that I have not wash'd my nose that bled,
line 16380-->    Or foil'd some debile wretch, which without note
line 16381-->    Here's many else have done, you shout me forth
line 16382-->    In acclamations hyperbolical,
line 16383-->    As if I lov'd my little should be dieted
line 16384-->    In praises sauc'd with lies.
line 16385-->  COMINIUS. Too modest are you;
line 16386-->    More cruel to your good report than grateful
line 16387-->    To us that give you truly. By your patience,
line 16388-->    If 'gainst yourself you be incens'd, we'll put you-
line 16389-->    Like one that means his proper harm- in manacles,
line 16390-->    Then reason safely with you. Therefore be it known,
line 16391-->    As to us, to all the world, that Caius Marcius
line 16392-->    Wears this war's garland; in token of the which,
line 16393-->    My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him,
line 16394-->    With all his trim belonging; and from this time,
line 16395-->    For what he did before Corioli, can him  
line 16396-->    With all th' applause-and clamour of the host,
line 16397-->    Caius Marcius Coriolanus.
line 16398-->    Bear th' addition nobly ever!
line 16399-->                           [Flourish. Trumpets sound, and drums]
line 16400-->  ALL. Caius Marcius Coriolanus!
line 16401-->  CORIOLANUS. I will go wash;
line 16402-->    And when my face is fair you shall perceive
line 16403-->    Whether I blush or no. Howbeit, I thank you;
line 16404-->    I mean to stride your steed, and at all times
line 16405-->    To undercrest your good addition
line 16406-->    To th' fairness of my power.
line 16407-->  COMINIUS. So, to our tent;
line 16408-->    Where, ere we do repose us, we will write
line 16409-->    To Rome of our success. You, Titus Lartius,
line 16410-->    Must to Corioli back. Send us to Rome
line 16411-->    The best, with whom we may articulate
line 16412-->    For their own good and ours.
line 16413-->  LARTIUS. I shall, my lord.
line 16414-->  CORIOLANUS. The gods begin to mock me. I, that now
line 16415-->    Refus'd most princely gifts, am bound to beg  
line 16416-->    Of my Lord General.
line 16417-->  COMINIUS. Take't- 'tis yours; what is't?
line 16418-->  CORIOLANUS. I sometime lay here in Corioli
line 16419-->    At a poor man's house; he us'd me kindly.
line 16420-->    He cried to me; I saw him prisoner;
line 16421-->    But then Aufidius was within my view,
line 16422-->    And wrath o'erwhelm'd my pity. I request you
line 16423-->    To give my poor host freedom.
line 16424-->  COMINIUS. O, well begg'd!
line 16425-->    Were he the butcher of my son, he should
line 16426-->    Be free as is the wind. Deliver him, Titus.
line 16427-->  LARTIUS. Marcius, his name?
line 16428-->  CORIOLANUS. By Jupiter, forgot!
line 16429-->    I am weary; yea, my memory is tir'd.
line 16430-->    Have we no wine here?
line 16431-->  COMINIUS. Go we to our tent.
line 16432-->    The blood upon your visage dries; 'tis time
line 16433-->    It should be look'd to. Come.                         Exeunt
line 16434-->
line 16435-->
line 16436-->
line 16437-->
line 16438-->SCENE X.
line 16439-->The camp of the Volsces
line 16440-->
line 16441-->A flourish. Cornets. Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS bloody, with two or three soldiers
line 16442-->
line 16443-->  AUFIDIUS. The town is ta'en.
line 16444-->  FIRST SOLDIER. 'Twill be deliver'd back on good condition.
line 16445-->  AUFIDIUS. Condition!
line 16446-->    I would I were a Roman; for I cannot,
line 16447-->    Being a Volsce, be that I am. Condition?
line 16448-->    What good condition can a treaty find
line 16449-->    I' th' part that is at mercy? Five times, Marcius,
line 16450-->    I have fought with thee; so often hast thou beat me;
line 16451-->    And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounter
line 16452-->    As often as we eat. By th' elements,
line 16453-->    If e'er again I meet him beard to beard,
line 16454-->    He's mine or I am his. Mine emulation
line 16455-->    Hath not that honour in't it had; for where
line 16456-->    I thought to crush him in an equal force,
line 16457-->    True sword to sword, I'll potch at him some way,
line 16458-->    Or wrath or craft may get him.  
line 16459-->  FIRST SOLDIER. He's the devil.
line 16460-->  AUFIDIUS. Bolder, though not so subtle. My valour's poison'd
line 16461-->    With only suff'ring stain by him; for him
line 16462-->    Shall fly out of itself. Nor sleep nor sanctuary,
line 16463-->    Being naked, sick, nor fane nor Capitol,
line 16464-->    The prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice,
line 16465-->    Embarquements all of fury, shall lift up
line 16466-->    Their rotten privilege and custom 'gainst
line 16467-->    My hate to Marcius. Where I find him, were it
line 16468-->    At home, upon my brother's guard, even there,
line 16469-->    Against the hospitable canon, would I
line 16470-->    Wash my fierce hand in's heart. Go you to th' city;
line 16471-->    Learn how 'tis held, and what they are that must
line 16472-->    Be hostages for Rome.
line 16473-->  FIRST SOLDIER. Will not you go?
line 16474-->  AUFIDIUS. I am attended at the cypress grove; I pray you-
line 16475-->    'Tis south the city mills- bring me word thither
line 16476-->    How the world goes, that to the pace of it
line 16477-->    I may spur on my journey.
line 16478-->  FIRST SOLDIER. I shall, sir.                            Exeunt
line 16479-->
line 16480-->

line 16491-->
line 16492-->
line 16493-->
line 16494-->ACT II. SCENE I.
line 16495-->Rome. A public place
line 16496-->
line 16497-->Enter MENENIUS, with the two Tribunes of the people, SICINIUS and BRUTUS
line 16498-->
line 16499-->  MENENIUS. The augurer tells me we shall have news tonight.
line 16500-->  BRUTUS. Good or bad?
line 16501-->  MENENIUS. Not according to the prayer of the people, for they love
line 16502-->    not Marcius.
line 16503-->  SICINIUS. Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.
line 16504-->  MENENIUS. Pray you, who does the wolf love?
line 16505-->  SICINIUS. The lamb.
line 16506-->  MENENIUS. Ay, to devour him, as the hungry plebeians would the
line 16507-->    noble Marcius.
line 16508-->  BRUTUS. He's a lamb indeed, that baes like a bear.
line 16509-->  MENENIUS. He's a bear indeed, that lives fike a lamb. You two are
line 16510-->    old men; tell me one thing that I shall ask you.
line 16511-->  BOTH TRIBUNES. Well, sir.
line 16512-->  MENENIUS. In what enormity is Marcius poor in that you two have not
line 16513-->    in abundance?
line 16514-->  BRUTUS. He's poor in no one fault, but stor'd with all.  
line 16515-->  SICINIUS. Especially in pride.
line 16516-->  BRUTUS. And topping all others in boasting.
line 16517-->  MENENIUS. This is strange now. Do you two know how you are censured
line 16518-->    here in the city- I mean of us o' th' right-hand file? Do you?
line 16519-->  BOTH TRIBUNES. Why, how are we censur'd?
line 16520-->  MENENIUS. Because you talk of pride now- will you not be angry?
line 16521-->  BOTH TRIBUNES. Well, well, sir, well.
line 16522-->  MENENIUS. Why, 'tis no great matter; for a very little thief of
line 16523-->    occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience. Give your
line 16524-->    dispositions the reins, and be angry at your pleasures- at the
line 16525-->    least, if you take it as a pleasure to you in being so. You blame
line 16526-->    Marcius for being proud?
line 16527-->  BRUTUS. We do it not alone, sir.
line 16528-->  MENENIUS. I know you can do very little alone; for your helps are
line 16529-->    many, or else your actions would grow wondrous single: your
line 16530-->    abilities are too infant-like for doing much alone. You talk of
line 16531-->    pride. O that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your
line 16532-->    necks, and make but an interior survey of your good selves! O
line 16533-->    that you could!
line 16534-->  BOTH TRIBUNES. What then, sir?  
line 16535-->  MENENIUS. Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting,
line 16536-->    proud, violent, testy magistrates-alias fools- as any in Rome.
line 16537-->  SICINIUS. Menenius, you are known well enough too.
line 16538-->  MENENIUS. I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that loves
line 16539-->    a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying Tiber in't; said to
line 16540-->    be something imperfect in favouring the first complaint, hasty
line 16541-->    and tinder-like upon too trivial motion; one that converses more
line 16542-->    with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the
line 16543-->    morning. What I think I utter, and spend my malice in my breath.
line 16544-->    Meeting two such wealsmen as you are- I cannot call you
line 16545-->    Lycurguses- if the drink you give me touch my palate adversely, I
line 16546-->    make a crooked face at it. I cannot say your worships have
line 16547-->    deliver'd the matter well, when I find the ass in compound with
line 16548-->    the major part of your syllables; and though I must be content to
line 16549-->    bear with those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they lie
line 16550-->    deadly that tell you you have good faces. If you see this in the
line 16551-->    map of my microcosm, follows it that I am known well enough too?
line 16552-->    What harm can your bisson conspectuities glean out of this
line 16553-->    character, if I be known well enough too?
line 16554-->  BRUTUS. Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.  
line 16555-->  MENENIUS. You know neither me, yourselves, nor any thing. You are
line 16556-->    ambitious for poor knaves' caps and legs; you wear out a good
line 16557-->    wholesome forenoon in hearing a cause between an orange-wife and
line 16558-->    a fosset-seller, and then rejourn the controversy of threepence
line 16559-->    to a second day of audience. When you are hearing a matter
line 16560-->    between party and party, if you chance to be pinch'd with the
line 16561-->    colic, you make faces like mummers, set up the bloody flag
line 16562-->    against all patience, and, in roaring for a chamber-pot, dismiss
line 16563-->    the controversy bleeding, the more entangled by your hearing. All
line 16564-->    the peace you make in their cause is calling both the parties
line 16565-->    knaves. You are a pair of strange ones.
line 16566-->  BRUTUS. Come, come, you are well understood to be a perfecter giber
line 16567-->    for the table than a necessary bencher in the Capitol.
line 16568-->  MENENIUS. Our very priests must become mockers, if they shall
line 16569-->    encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are. When you speak
line 16570-->    best unto the purpose, it is not worth the wagging of your
line 16571-->    beards; and your beards deserve not so honourable a grave as to
line 16572-->    stuff a botcher's cushion or to be entomb'd in an ass's
line 16573-->    pack-saddle. Yet you must be saying Marcius is proud; who, in a
line 16574-->    cheap estimation, is worth all your predecessors since Deucalion;  
line 16575-->    though peradventure some of the best of 'em were hereditary
line 16576-->    hangmen. God-den to your worships. More of your conversation
line 16577-->    would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly
line 16578-->    plebeians. I will be bold to take my leave of you.
line 16579-->                                  [BRUTUS and SICINIUS go aside]
line 16580-->
line 16581-->               Enter VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA, and VALERIA
line 16582-->
line 16583-->    How now, my as fair as noble ladies- and the moon, were she
line 16584-->    earthly, no nobler- whither do you follow your eyes so fast?
line 16585-->  VOLUMNIA. Honourable Menenius, my boy Marcius approaches; for the
line 16586-->    love of Juno, let's go.
line 16587-->  MENENIUS. Ha! Marcius coming home?
line 16588-->  VOLUMNIA. Ay, worthy Menenius, and with most prosperous
line 16589-->    approbation.
line 16590-->  MENENIUS. Take my cap, Jupiter, and I thank thee. Hoo!
line 16591-->    Marcius coming home!
line 16592-->  VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA. Nay, 'tis true.
line 16593-->  VOLUMNIA. Look, here's a letter from him; the state hath another,
line 16594-->    his wife another; and I think there's one at home for you.  
line 16595-->  MENENIUS. I will make my very house reel to-night. A letter for me?
line 16596-->  VIRGILIA. Yes, certain, there's a letter for you; I saw't.
line 16597-->  MENENIUS. A letter for me! It gives me an estate of seven years'
line 16598-->    health; in which time I will make a lip at the physician. The
line 16599-->    most sovereign prescription in Galen is but empiricutic and, to
line 16600-->    this preservative, of no better report than a horse-drench. Is he
line 16601-->    not wounded? He was wont to come home wounded.
line 16602-->  VIRGILIA. O, no, no, no.
line 16603-->  VOLUMNIA. O, he is wounded, I thank the gods for't.
line 16604-->  MENENIUS. So do I too, if it be not too much. Brings a victory in
line 16605-->    his pocket? The wounds become him.
line 16606-->  VOLUMNIA. On's brows, Menenius, he comes the third time home with
line 16607-->    the oaken garland.
line 16608-->  MENENIUS. Has he disciplin'd Aufidius soundly?
line 16609-->  VOLUMNIA. Titus Lartius writes they fought together, but Aufidius
line 16610-->    got off.
line 16611-->  MENENIUS. And 'twas time for him too, I'll warrant him that; an he
line 16612-->    had stay'd by him, I would not have been so fidius'd for all the
line 16613-->    chests in Corioli and the gold that's in them. Is the Senate
line 16614-->    possess'd of this?  
line 16615-->  VOLUMNIA. Good ladies, let's go. Yes, yes, yes: the Senate has
line 16616-->    letters from the general, wherein he gives my son the whole name
line 16617-->    of the war; he hath in this action outdone his former deeds
line 16618-->    doubly.
line 16619-->  VALERIA. In troth, there's wondrous things spoke of him.
line 16620-->  MENENIUS. Wondrous! Ay, I warrant you, and not without his true
line 16621-->    purchasing.
line 16622-->  VIRGILIA. The gods grant them true!
line 16623-->  VOLUMNIA. True! pow, waw.
line 16624-->  MENENIUS. True! I'll be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded?
line 16625-->    [To the TRIBUNES]  God save your good worships! Marcius is coming
line 16626-->    home; he has more cause to be proud. Where is he wounded?
line 16627-->  VOLUMNIA. I' th' shoulder and i' th' left arm; there will be large
line 16628-->    cicatrices to show the people when he shall stand for his place.
line 16629-->    He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts i' th' body.
line 16630-->  MENENIUS. One i' th' neck and two i' th' thigh- there's nine that I
line 16631-->    know.
line 16632-->  VOLUMNIA. He had before this last expedition twenty-five wounds
line 16633-->    upon him.
line 16634-->  MENENIUS. Now it's twenty-seven; every gash was an enemy's grave.  
line 16635-->    [A shout and flourish]  Hark! the trumpets.
line 16636-->  VOLUMNIA. These are the ushers of Marcius. Before him he carries
line 16637-->      noise, and behind him he leaves tears;
line 16638-->    Death, that dark spirit, in's nervy arm doth lie,
line 16639-->    Which, being advanc'd, declines, and then men die.
line 16640-->
line 16641-->            A sennet. Trumpets sound. Enter COMINIUS the
line 16642-->              GENERAL, and TITUS LARTIUS; between them,
line 16643-->           CORIOLANUS, crown'd with an oaken garland; with
line 16644-->                   CAPTAINS and soldiers and a HERALD
line 16645-->
line 16646-->  HERALD. Know, Rome, that all alone Marcius did fight
line 16647-->    Within Corioli gates, where he hath won,
line 16648-->    With fame, a name to Caius Marcius; these
line 16649-->    In honour follows Coriolanus.
line 16650-->    Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!             [Flourish]
line 16651-->  ALL. Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!
line 16652-->  CORIOLANUS. No more of this, it does offend my heart.
line 16653-->    Pray now, no more.
line 16654-->  COMINIUS. Look, sir, your mother!  
line 16655-->  CORIOLANUS. O,
line 16656-->    You have, I know, petition'd all the gods
line 16657-->    For my prosperity!                                  [Kneels]
line 16658-->  VOLUMNIA. Nay, my good soldier, up;
line 16659-->    My gentle Marcius, worthy Caius, and
line 16660-->    By deed-achieving honour newly nam'd-
line 16661-->    What is it? Coriolanus must I can thee?
line 16662-->    But, O, thy wife!
line 16663-->  CORIOLANUS. My gracious silence, hail!
line 16664-->    Wouldst thou have laugh'd had I come coffin'd home,
line 16665-->    That weep'st to see me triumph? Ah, my dear,
line 16666-->    Such eyes the widows in Corioli wear,
line 16667-->    And mothers that lack sons.
line 16668-->  MENENIUS. Now the gods crown thee!
line 16669-->  CORIOLANUS. And live you yet?  [To VALERIA]  O my sweet lady,
line 16670-->    pardon.
line 16671-->  VOLUMNIA. I know not where to turn.
line 16672-->    O, welcome home! And welcome, General.
line 16673-->    And y'are welcome all.
line 16674-->  MENENIUS. A hundred thousand welcomes. I could weep  
line 16675-->    And I could laugh; I am light and heavy. Welcome!
line 16676-->    A curse begin at very root on's heart
line 16677-->    That is not glad to see thee! You are three
line 16678-->    That Rome should dote on; yet, by the faith of men,
line 16679-->    We have some old crab trees here at home that will not
line 16680-->    Be grafted to your relish. Yet welcome, warriors.
line 16681-->    We call a nettle but a nettle, and
line 16682-->    The faults of fools but folly.
line 16683-->  COMINIUS. Ever right.
line 16684-->  CORIOLANUS. Menenius ever, ever.
line 16685-->  HERALD. Give way there, and go on.
line 16686-->  CORIOLANUS.  [To his wife and mother]  Your hand, and yours.
line 16687-->    Ere in our own house I do shade my head,
line 16688-->    The good patricians must be visited;
line 16689-->    From whom I have receiv'd not only greetings,
line 16690-->    But with them change of honours.
line 16691-->  VOLUMNIA. I have lived
line 16692-->    To see inherited my very wishes,
line 16693-->    And the buildings of my fancy; only
line 16694-->    There's one thing wanting, which I doubt not but  
line 16695-->    Our Rome will cast upon thee.
line 16696-->  CORIOLANUS. Know, good mother,
line 16697-->    I had rather be their servant in my way
line 16698-->    Than sway with them in theirs.
line 16699-->  COMINIUS. On, to the Capitol.
line 16700-->                 [Flourish. Cornets. Exeunt in state, as before]
line 16701-->
line 16702-->                BRUTUS and SICINIUS come forward
line 16703-->
line 16704-->  BRUTUS. All tongues speak of him and the bleared sights
line 16705-->    Are spectacled to see him. Your prattling nurse
line 16706-->    Into a rapture lets her baby cry
line 16707-->    While she chats him; the kitchen malkin pins
line 16708-->    Her richest lockram 'bout her reechy neck,
line 16709-->    Clamb'ring the walls to eye him; stalls, bulks, windows,
line 16710-->    Are smother'd up, leads fill'd and ridges hors'd
line 16711-->    With variable complexions, all agreeing
line 16712-->    In earnestness to see him. Seld-shown flamens
line 16713-->    Do press among the popular throngs and puff
line 16714-->    To win a vulgar station; our veil'd dames  
line 16715-->    Commit the war of white and damask in
line 16716-->    Their nicely gawded cheeks to th' wanton spoil
line 16717-->    Of Phoebus' burning kisses. Such a pother,
line 16718-->    As if that whatsoever god who leads him
line 16719-->    Were slily crept into his human powers,
line 16720-->    And gave him graceful posture.
line 16721-->  SICINIUS. On the sudden
line 16722-->    I warrant him consul.
line 16723-->  BRUTUS. Then our office may
line 16724-->    During his power go sleep.
line 16725-->  SICINIUS. He cannot temp'rately transport his honours
line 16726-->    From where he should begin and end, but will
line 16727-->    Lose those he hath won.
line 16728-->  BRUTUS. In that there's comfort.
line 16729-->  SICINIUS. Doubt not
line 16730-->    The commoners, for whom we stand, but they
line 16731-->    Upon their ancient malice will forget
line 16732-->    With the least cause these his new honours; which
line 16733-->    That he will give them make I as little question
line 16734-->    As he is proud to do't.  
line 16735-->  BRUTUS. I heard him swear,
line 16736-->    Were he to stand for consul, never would he
line 16737-->    Appear i' th' market-place, nor on him put
line 16738-->    The napless vesture of humility;
line 16739-->    Nor, showing, as the manner is, his wounds
line 16740-->    To th' people, beg their stinking breaths.
line 16741-->  SICINIUS. 'Tis right.
line 16742-->  BRUTUS. It was his word. O, he would miss it rather
line 16743-->    Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him
line 16744-->    And the desire of the nobles.
line 16745-->  SICINIUS. I wish no better
line 16746-->    Than have him hold that purpose, and to put it
line 16747-->    In execution.
line 16748-->  BRUTUS. 'Tis most like he will.
line 16749-->  SICINIUS. It shall be to him then as our good wills:
line 16750-->    A sure destruction.
line 16751-->  BRUTUS. So it must fall out
line 16752-->    To him or our authorities. For an end,
line 16753-->    We must suggest the people in what hatred
line 16754-->    He still hath held them; that to's power he would  
line 16755-->    Have made them mules, silenc'd their pleaders, and
line 16756-->    Dispropertied their freedoms; holding them
line 16757-->    In human action and capacity
line 16758-->    Of no more soul nor fitness for the world
line 16759-->    Than camels in their war, who have their provand
line 16760-->    Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows
line 16761-->    For sinking under them.
line 16762-->  SICINIUS. This, as you say, suggested
line 16763-->    At some time when his soaring insolence
line 16764-->    Shall touch the people- which time shall not want,
line 16765-->    If he be put upon't, and that's as easy
line 16766-->    As to set dogs on sheep- will be his fire
line 16767-->    To kindle their dry stubble; and their blaze
line 16768-->    Shall darken him for ever.
line 16769-->
line 16770-->                           Enter A MESSENGER
line 16771-->
line 16772-->  BRUTUS. What's the matter?
line 16773-->  MESSENGER. You are sent for to the Capitol. 'Tis thought
line 16774-->    That Marcius shall be consul.  
line 16775-->    I have seen the dumb men throng to see him and
line 16776-->    The blind to hear him speak; matrons flung gloves,
line 16777-->    Ladies and maids their scarfs and handkerchers,
line 16778-->    Upon him as he pass'd; the nobles bended
line 16779-->    As to Jove's statue, and the commons made
line 16780-->    A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts.
line 16781-->    I never saw the like.
line 16782-->  BRUTUS. Let's to the Capitol,
line 16783-->    And carry with us ears and eyes for th' time,
line 16784-->    But hearts for the event.
line 16785-->  SICINIUS. Have with you.                                Exeunt
line 16786-->
line 16787-->
line 16788-->
line 16789-->
line 16790-->SCENE II.
line 16791-->Rome. The Capitol
line 16792-->
line 16793-->Enter two OFFICERS, to lay cushions, as it were in the Capitol
line 16794-->
line 16795-->  FIRST OFFICER. Come, come, they are almost here. How many stand for
line 16796-->    consulships?
line 16797-->  SECOND OFFICER. Three, they say; but 'tis thought of every one
line 16798-->    Coriolanus will carry it.
line 16799-->  FIRST OFFICER. That's a brave fellow; but he's vengeance proud and
line 16800-->    loves not the common people.
line 16801-->  SECOND OFFICER. Faith, there have been many great men that have
line 16802-->    flatter'd the people, who ne'er loved them; and there be many
line 16803-->    that they have loved, they know not wherefore; so that, if they
line 16804-->    love they know not why, they hate upon no better a ground.
line 16805-->    Therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or
line 16806-->    hate him manifests the true knowledge he has in their
line 16807-->    disposition, and out of his noble carelessness lets them plainly
line 16808-->    see't.
line 16809-->  FIRST OFFICER. If he did not care whether he had their love or no,
line 16810-->    he waved indifferently 'twixt doing them neither good nor harm;  
line 16811-->    but he seeks their hate with greater devotion than they can
line 16812-->    render it him, and leaves nothing undone that may fully discover
line 16813-->    him their opposite. Now to seem to affect the malice and
line 16814-->    displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he dislikes- to
line 16815-->    flatter them for their love.
line 16816-->  SECOND OFFICER. He hath deserved worthily of his country; and his
line 16817-->    ascent is not by such easy degrees as those who, having been
line 16818-->    supple and courteous to the people, bonneted, without any further
line 16819-->    deed to have them at all, into their estimation and report; but
line 16820-->    he hath so planted his honours in their eyes and his actions in
line 16821-->    their hearts that for their tongues to be silent and not confess
line 16822-->    so much were a kind of ingrateful injury; to report otherwise
line 16823-->    were a malice that, giving itself the lie, would pluck reproof
line 16824-->    and rebuke from every car that heard it.
line 16825-->  FIRST OFFICER. No more of him; he's a worthy man. Make way, they
line 16826-->    are coming.
line 16827-->
line 16828-->         A sennet. Enter the PATRICIANS and the TRIBUNES
line 16829-->         OF THE PEOPLE, LICTORS before them; CORIOLANUS,
line 16830-->            MENENIUS, COMINIUS the Consul. SICINIUS and  
line 16831-->               BRUTUS take their places by themselves.
line 16832-->                         CORIOLANUS stands
line 16833-->
line 16834-->  MENENIUS. Having determin'd of the Volsces, and
line 16835-->    To send for Titus Lartius, it remains,
line 16836-->    As the main point of this our after-meeting,
line 16837-->    To gratify his noble service that
line 16838-->    Hath thus stood for his country. Therefore please you,
line 16839-->    Most reverend and grave elders, to desire
line 16840-->    The present consul and last general
line 16841-->    In our well-found successes to report
line 16842-->    A little of that worthy work perform'd
line 16843-->    By Caius Marcius Coriolanus; whom
line 16844-->    We met here both to thank and to remember
line 16845-->    With honours like himself.                 [CORIOLANUS sits]
line 16846-->  FIRST SENATOR. Speak, good Cominius.
line 16847-->    Leave nothing out for length, and make us think
line 16848-->    Rather our state's defective for requital
line 16849-->    Than we to stretch it out. Masters o' th' people,
line 16850-->    We do request your kindest ears; and, after,  
line 16851-->    Your loving motion toward the common body,
line 16852-->    To yield what passes here.
line 16853-->  SICINIUS. We are convented
line 16854-->    Upon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts
line 16855-->    Inclinable to honour and advance
line 16856-->    The theme of our assembly.
line 16857-->  BRUTUS. Which the rather
line 16858-->    We shall be bless'd to do, if he remember
line 16859-->    A kinder value of the people than
line 16860-->    He hath hereto priz'd them at.
line 16861-->  MENENIUS. That's off, that's off;
line 16862-->    I would you rather had been silent. Please you
line 16863-->    To hear Cominius speak?
line 16864-->  BRUTUS. Most willingly.
line 16865-->    But yet my caution was more pertinent
line 16866-->    Than the rebuke you give it.
line 16867-->  MENENIUS. He loves your people;
line 16868-->    But tie him not to be their bedfellow.
line 16869-->    Worthy Cominius, speak.
line 16870-->                       [CORIOLANUS rises, and offers to go away]  
line 16871-->    Nay, keep your place.
line 16872-->  FIRST SENATOR. Sit, Coriolanus, never shame to hear
line 16873-->    What you have nobly done.
line 16874-->  CORIOLANUS. Your Honours' pardon.
line 16875-->    I had rather have my wounds to heal again
line 16876-->    Than hear say how I got them.
line 16877-->  BRUTUS. Sir, I hope
line 16878-->    My words disbench'd you not.
line 16879-->  CORIOLANUS. No, sir; yet oft,
line 16880-->    When blows have made me stay, I fled from words.
line 16881-->    You sooth'd not, therefore hurt not. But your people,
line 16882-->    I love them as they weigh-
line 16883-->  MENENIUS. Pray now, sit down.
line 16884-->  CORIOLANUS. I had rather have one scratch my head i' th' sun
line 16885-->    When the alarum were struck than idly sit
line 16886-->    To hear my nothings monster'd.                          Exit
line 16887-->  MENENIUS. Masters of the people,
line 16888-->    Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter-
line 16889-->    That's thousand to one good one- when you now see
line 16890-->    He had rather venture all his limbs for honour  
line 16891-->    Than one on's ears to hear it? Proceed, Cominius.
line 16892-->  COMINIUS. I shall lack voice; the deeds of Coriolanus
line 16893-->    Should not be utter'd feebly. It is held
line 16894-->    That valour is the chiefest virtue and
line 16895-->    Most dignifies the haver. If it be,
line 16896-->    The man I speak of cannot in the world
line 16897-->    Be singly counterpois'd. At sixteen years,
line 16898-->    When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought
line 16899-->    Beyond the mark of others; our then Dictator,
line 16900-->    Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight
line 16901-->    When with his Amazonian chin he drove
line 16902-->    The bristled lips before him; he bestrid
line 16903-->    An o'erpress'd Roman and i' th' consul's view
line 16904-->    Slew three opposers; Tarquin's self he met,
line 16905-->    And struck him on his knee. In that day's feats,
line 16906-->    When he might act the woman in the scene,
line 16907-->    He prov'd best man i' th' field, and for his meed
line 16908-->    Was brow-bound with the oak. His pupil age
line 16909-->    Man-ent'red thus, he waxed like a sea,
line 16910-->    And in the brunt of seventeen battles since  
line 16911-->    He lurch'd all swords of the garland. For this last,
line 16912-->    Before and in Corioli, let me say
line 16913-->    I cannot speak him home. He stopp'd the fliers,
line 16914-->    And by his rare example made the coward
line 16915-->    Turn terror into sport; as weeds before
line 16916-->    A vessel under sail, so men obey'd
line 16917-->    And fell below his stem. His sword, death's stamp,
line 16918-->    Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot
line 16919-->    He was a thing of blood, whose every motion
line 16920-->    Was tim'd with dying cries. Alone he ent'red
