line 16921-->    The mortal gate of th' city, which he painted
line 16922-->    With shunless destiny; aidless came off,
line 16923-->    And with a sudden re-enforcement struck
line 16924-->    Corioli like a planet. Now all's his.
line 16925-->    When by and by the din of war 'gan pierce
line 16926-->    His ready sense, then straight his doubled spirit
line 16927-->    Re-quick'ned what in flesh was fatigate,
line 16928-->    And to the battle came he; where he did
line 16929-->    Run reeking o'er the lives of men, as if
line 16930-->    'Twere a perpetual spoil; and till we call'd  
line 16931-->    Both field and city ours he never stood
line 16932-->    To ease his breast with panting.
line 16933-->  MENENIUS. Worthy man!
line 16934-->  FIRST SENATOR. He cannot but with measure fit the honours
line 16935-->    Which we devise him.
line 16936-->  COMINIUS. Our spoils he kick'd at,
line 16937-->    And look'd upon things precious as they were
line 16938-->    The common muck of the world. He covets less
line 16939-->    Than misery itself would give, rewards
line 16940-->    His deeds with doing them, and is content
line 16941-->    To spend the time to end it.
line 16942-->  MENENIUS. He's right noble;
line 16943-->    Let him be call'd for.
line 16944-->  FIRST SENATOR. Call Coriolanus.
line 16945-->    OFFICER. He doth appear.
line 16946-->
line 16947-->                            Re-enter CORIOLANUS
line 16948-->
line 16949-->  MENENIUS. The Senate, Coriolanus, are well pleas'd
line 16950-->    To make thee consul.  
line 16951-->  CORIOLANUS. I do owe them still
line 16952-->    My life and services.
line 16953-->  MENENIUS. It then remains
line 16954-->    That you do speak to the people.
line 16955-->  CORIOLANUS. I do beseech you
line 16956-->    Let me o'erleap that custom; for I cannot
line 16957-->    Put on the gown, stand naked, and entreat them
line 16958-->    For my wounds' sake to give their suffrage. Please you
line 16959-->    That I may pass this doing.
line 16960-->  SICINIUS. Sir, the people
line 16961-->    Must have their voices; neither will they bate
line 16962-->    One jot of ceremony.
line 16963-->  MENENIUS. Put them not to't.
line 16964-->    Pray you go fit you to the custom, and
line 16965-->    Take to you, as your predecessors have,
line 16966-->    Your honour with your form.
line 16967-->  CORIOLANUS. It is a part
line 16968-->    That I shall blush in acting, and might well
line 16969-->    Be taken from the people.
line 16970-->  BRUTUS. Mark you that?  
line 16971-->  CORIOLANUS. To brag unto them 'Thus I did, and thus!'
line 16972-->    Show them th' unaching scars which I should hide,
line 16973-->    As if I had receiv'd them for the hire
line 16974-->    Of their breath only!
line 16975-->  MENENIUS. Do not stand upon't.
line 16976-->    We recommend to you, Tribunes of the People,
line 16977-->    Our purpose to them; and to our noble consul
line 16978-->    Wish we all joy and honour.
line 16979-->  SENATORS. To Coriolanus come all joy and honour!
line 16980-->                             [Flourish. Cornets. Then exeunt all
line 16981-->                                        but SICINIUS and BRUTUS]
line 16982-->  BRUTUS. You see how he intends to use the people.
line 16983-->  SICINIUS. May they perceive's intent! He will require them
line 16984-->    As if he did contemn what he requested
line 16985-->    Should be in them to give.
line 16986-->  BRUTUS. Come, we'll inform them
line 16987-->    Of our proceedings here. On th' market-place
line 16988-->    I know they do attend us.                             Exeunt
line 16989-->
line 16990-->
line 16991-->
line 16992-->
line 16993-->SCENE III.
line 16994-->Rome. The Forum
line 16995-->
line 16996-->Enter seven or eight citizens
line 16997-->
line 16998-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to
line 16999-->    deny him.
line 17000-->  SECOND CITIZEN. We may, sir, if we will.
line 17001-->  THIRD CITIZEN. We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a
line 17002-->    power that we have no power to do; for if he show us his wounds
line 17003-->    and tell us his deeds, we are to put our tongues into those
line 17004-->    wounds and speak for them; so, if he tell us his noble deeds, we
line 17005-->    must also tell him our noble acceptance of them. Ingratitude is
line 17006-->    monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful were to make a
line 17007-->    monster of the multitude; of the which we being members should
line 17008-->    bring ourselves to be monstrous members.
line 17009-->  FIRST CITIZEN. And to make us no better thought of, a little help
line 17010-->    will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he himself stuck
line 17011-->    not to call us the many-headed multitude.
line 17012-->  THIRD CITIZEN. We have been call'd so of many; not that our heads
line 17013-->    are some brown, some black, some abram, some bald, but that our
line 17014-->    wits are so diversely colour'd; and truly I think if all our wits  
line 17015-->    were to issue out of one skull, they would fly east, west, north,
line 17016-->    south, and their consent of one direct way should be at once to
line 17017-->    all the points o' th' compass.
line 17018-->  SECOND CITIZEN. Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would
line 17019-->    fly?
line 17020-->  THIRD CITIZEN. Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another man's
line 17021-->    will- 'tis strongly wedg'd up in a block-head; but if it were at
line 17022-->    liberty 'twould sure southward.
line 17023-->  SECOND CITIZEN. Why that way?
line 17024-->  THIRD CITIZEN. To lose itself in a fog; where being three parts
line 17025-->   melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return for
line 17026-->    conscience' sake, to help to get thee a wife.
line 17027-->  SECOND CITIZEN. YOU are never without your tricks; you may, you
line 17028-->    may.
line 17029-->  THIRD CITIZEN. Are you all resolv'd to give your voices? But that's
line 17030-->    no matter, the greater part carries it. I say, if he would
line 17031-->    incline to the people, there was never a worthier man.
line 17032-->
line 17033-->                Enter CORIOLANUS, in a gown of humility,
line 17034-->                               with MENENIUS  
line 17035-->
line 17036-->    Here he comes, and in the gown of humility. Mark his behaviour.
line 17037-->    We are not to stay all together, but to come by him where he
line 17038-->    stands, by ones, by twos, and by threes. He's to make his
line 17039-->    requests by particulars, wherein every one of us has a single
line 17040-->    honour, in giving him our own voices with our own tongues;
line 17041-->    therefore follow me, and I'll direct you how you shall go by him.
line 17042-->  ALL. Content, content.                         Exeunt citizens
line 17043-->  MENENIUS. O sir, you are not right; have you not known
line 17044-->    The worthiest men have done't?
line 17045-->  CORIOLANUS. What must I say?
line 17046-->    'I pray, sir'- Plague upon't! I cannot bring
line 17047-->    My tongue to such a pace. 'Look, sir, my wounds
line 17048-->    I got them in my country's service, when
line 17049-->    Some certain of your brethren roar'd and ran
line 17050-->    From th' noise of our own drums.'
line 17051-->  MENENIUS. O me, the gods!
line 17052-->    You must not speak of that. You must desire them
line 17053-->    To think upon you.
line 17054-->  CORIOLANUS. Think upon me? Hang 'em!  
line 17055-->    I would they would forget me, like the virtues
line 17056-->    Which our divines lose by 'em.
line 17057-->  MENENIUS. You'll mar all.
line 17058-->    I'll leave you. Pray you speak to 'em, I pray you,
line 17059-->    In wholesome manner.                                    Exit
line 17060-->
line 17061-->                       Re-enter three of the citizens
line 17062-->
line 17063-->  CORIOLANUS. Bid them wash their faces
line 17064-->    And keep their teeth clean. So, here comes a brace.
line 17065-->    You know the cause, sir, of my standing here.
line 17066-->  THIRD CITIZEN. We do, sir; tell us what hath brought you to't.
line 17067-->  CORIOLANUS. Mine own desert.
line 17068-->  SECOND CITIZEN. Your own desert?
line 17069-->  CORIOLANUS. Ay, not mine own desire.
line 17070-->  THIRD CITIZEN. How, not your own desire?
line 17071-->  CORIOLANUS. No, sir, 'twas never my desire yet to trouble the poor
line 17072-->    with begging.
line 17073-->  THIRD CITIZEN. YOU MUST think, if we give you anything, we hope to
line 17074-->    gain by you.  
line 17075-->  CORIOLANUS. Well then, I pray, your price o' th' consulship?
line 17076-->  FIRST CITIZEN. The price is to ask it kindly.
line 17077-->  CORIOLANUS. Kindly, sir, I pray let me ha't. I have wounds to show
line 17078-->    you, which shall be yours in private. Your good voice, sir; what
line 17079-->    say you?
line 17080-->  SECOND CITIZEN. You shall ha' it, worthy sir.
line 17081-->  CORIOLANUS. A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices begg'd.
line 17082-->    I have your alms. Adieu.
line 17083-->  THIRD CITIZEN. But this is something odd.
line 17084-->  SECOND CITIZEN. An 'twere to give again- but 'tis no matter.
line 17085-->                                       Exeunt the three citizens
line 17086-->
line 17087-->                      Re-enter two other citizens
line 17088-->
line 17089-->  CORIOLANUS. Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your
line 17090-->    voices that I may be consul, I have here the customary gown.
line 17091-->  FOURTH CITIZEN. You have deserved nobly of your country, and you
line 17092-->    have not deserved nobly.
line 17093-->  CORIOLANUS. Your enigma?
line 17094-->  FOURTH CITIZEN. You have been a scourge to her enemies; you have  
line 17095-->    been a rod to her friends. You have not indeed loved the common
line 17096-->    people.
line 17097-->  CORIOLANUS. You should account me the more virtuous, that I have
line 17098-->    not been common in my love. I will, sir, flatter my sworn
line 17099-->    brother, the people, to earn a dearer estimation of them; 'tis a
line 17100-->    condition they account gentle; and since the wisdom of their
line 17101-->    choice is rather to have my hat than my heart, I will practise
line 17102-->    the insinuating nod and be off to them most counterfeitly. That
line 17103-->    is, sir, I will counterfeit the bewitchment of some popular man
line 17104-->    and give it bountiful to the desirers. Therefore, beseech you I
line 17105-->    may be consul.
line 17106-->  FIFTH CITIZEN. We hope to find you our friend; and therefore give
line 17107-->    you our voices heartily.
line 17108-->  FOURTH CITIZEN. You have received many wounds for your country.
line 17109-->  CORIOLANUS. I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I
line 17110-->    will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no farther.
line 17111-->  BOTH CITIZENS. The gods give you joy, sir, heartily!
line 17112-->                                                 Exeunt citizens
line 17113-->  CORIOLANUS. Most sweet voices!
line 17114-->    Better it is to die, better to starve,  
line 17115-->    Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.
line 17116-->    Why in this wolvish toge should I stand here
line 17117-->    To beg of Hob and Dick that do appear
line 17118-->    Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to't.
line 17119-->    What custom wills, in all things should we do't,
line 17120-->    The dust on antique time would lie unswept,
line 17121-->    And mountainous error be too highly heap'd
line 17122-->    For truth to o'erpeer. Rather than fool it so,
line 17123-->    Let the high office and the honour go
line 17124-->    To one that would do thus. I am half through:
line 17125-->    The one part suffered, the other will I do.
line 17126-->
line 17127-->                      Re-enter three citizens more
line 17128-->
line 17129-->    Here come moe voices.
line 17130-->    Your voices. For your voices I have fought;
line 17131-->    Watch'd for your voices; for your voices bear
line 17132-->    Of wounds two dozen odd; battles thrice six
line 17133-->    I have seen and heard of; for your voices have
line 17134-->    Done many things, some less, some more. Your voices?  
line 17135-->    Indeed, I would be consul.
line 17136-->  SIXTH CITIZEN. He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest
line 17137-->    man's voice.
line 17138-->  SEVENTH CITIZEN. Therefore let him be consul. The gods give him
line 17139-->    joy, and make him good friend to the people!
line 17140-->  ALL. Amen, amen. God save thee, noble consul!
line 17141-->                                                 Exeunt citizens
line 17142-->  CORIOLANUS. Worthy voices!
line 17143-->
line 17144-->             Re-enter MENENIUS with BRUTUS and SICINIUS
line 17145-->
line 17146-->  MENENIUS. You have stood your limitation, and the tribunes
line 17147-->    Endue you with the people's voice. Remains
line 17148-->    That, in th' official marks invested, you
line 17149-->    Anon do meet the Senate.
line 17150-->  CORIOLANUS. Is this done?
line 17151-->  SICINIUS. The custom of request you have discharg'd.
line 17152-->    The people do admit you, and are summon'd
line 17153-->    To meet anon, upon your approbation.
line 17154-->  CORIOLANUS. Where? At the Senate House?  
line 17155-->  SICINIUS. There, Coriolanus.
line 17156-->  CORIOLANUS. May I change these garments?
line 17157-->  SICINIUS. You may, sir.
line 17158-->  CORIOLANUS. That I'll straight do, and, knowing myself again,
line 17159-->    Repair to th' Senate House.
line 17160-->  MENENIUS. I'll keep you company. Will you along?
line 17161-->  BRUTUS. We stay here for the people.
line 17162-->  SICINIUS. Fare you well.
line 17163-->                                  Exeunt CORIOLANUS and MENENIUS
line 17164-->    He has it now; and by his looks methinks
line 17165-->    'Tis warm at's heart.
line 17166-->  BRUTUS. With a proud heart he wore
line 17167-->    His humble weeds. Will you dismiss the people?
line 17168-->
line 17169-->                            Re-enter citizens
line 17170-->
line 17171-->  SICINIUS. How now, my masters! Have you chose this man?
line 17172-->  FIRST CITIZEN. He has our voices, sir.
line 17173-->  BRUTUS. We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.
line 17174-->  SECOND CITIZEN. Amen, sir. To my poor unworthy notice,  
line 17175-->    He mock'd us when he begg'd our voices.
line 17176-->  THIRD CITIZEN. Certainly;
line 17177-->    He flouted us downright.
line 17178-->  FIRST CITIZEN. No, 'tis his kind of speech- he did not mock us.
line 17179-->  SECOND CITIZEN. Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says
line 17180-->    He us'd us scornfully. He should have show'd us
line 17181-->    His marks of merit, wounds receiv'd for's country.
line 17182-->  SICINIUS. Why, so he did, I am sure.
line 17183-->  ALL. No, no; no man saw 'em.
line 17184-->  THIRD CITIZEN. He said he had wounds which he could show in
line 17185-->      private,
line 17186-->    And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn,
line 17187-->    'I would be consul,' says he; 'aged custom
line 17188-->    But by your voices will not so permit me;
line 17189-->    Your voices therefore.' When we granted that,
line 17190-->    Here was 'I thank you for your voices. Thank you,
line 17191-->    Your most sweet voices. Now you have left your voices,
line 17192-->    I have no further with you.' Was not this mockery?
line 17193-->  SICINIUS. Why either were you ignorant to see't,
line 17194-->    Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness  
line 17195-->    To yield your voices?
line 17196-->  BRUTUS. Could you not have told him-
line 17197-->    As you were lesson'd- when he had no power
line 17198-->    But was a petty servant to the state,
line 17199-->    He was your enemy; ever spake against
line 17200-->    Your liberties and the charters that you bear
line 17201-->    I' th' body of the weal; and now, arriving
line 17202-->    A place of potency and sway o' th' state,
line 17203-->    If he should still malignantly remain
line 17204-->    Fast foe to th' plebeii, your voices might
line 17205-->    Be curses to yourselves? You should have said
line 17206-->    That as his worthy deeds did claim no less
line 17207-->    Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature
line 17208-->    Would think upon you for your voices, and
line 17209-->    Translate his malice towards you into love,
line 17210-->    Standing your friendly lord.
line 17211-->  SICINIUS. Thus to have said,
line 17212-->    As you were fore-advis'd, had touch'd his spirit
line 17213-->    And tried his inclination; from him pluck'd
line 17214-->    Either his gracious promise, which you might,  
line 17215-->    As cause had call'd you up, have held him to;
line 17216-->    Or else it would have gall'd his surly nature,
line 17217-->    Which easily endures not article
line 17218-->    Tying him to aught. So, putting him to rage,
line 17219-->    You should have ta'en th' advantage of his choler
line 17220-->    And pass'd him unelected.
line 17221-->  BRUTUS. Did you perceive
line 17222-->    He did solicit you in free contempt
line 17223-->    When he did need your loves; and do you think
line 17224-->    That his contempt shall not be bruising to you
line 17225-->    When he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodies
line 17226-->    No heart among you? Or had you tongues to cry
line 17227-->    Against the rectorship of judgment?
line 17228-->  SICINIUS. Have you
line 17229-->    Ere now denied the asker, and now again,
line 17230-->    Of him that did not ask but mock, bestow
line 17231-->    Your su'd-for tongues?
line 17232-->  THIRD CITIZEN. He's not confirm'd: we may deny him yet.
line 17233-->  SECOND CITIZENS. And will deny him;
line 17234-->    I'll have five hundred voices of that sound.  
line 17235-->  FIRST CITIZEN. I twice five hundred, and their friends to piece
line 17236-->    'em.
line 17237-->  BRUTUS. Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends
line 17238-->    They have chose a consul that will from them take
line 17239-->    Their liberties, make them of no more voice
line 17240-->    Than dogs, that are as often beat for barking
line 17241-->    As therefore kept to do so.
line 17242-->  SICINIUS. Let them assemble;
line 17243-->    And, on a safer judgment, all revoke
line 17244-->    Your ignorant election. Enforce his pride
line 17245-->    And his old hate unto you; besides, forget not
line 17246-->    With what contempt he wore the humble weed;
line 17247-->    How in his suit he scorn'd you; but your loves,
line 17248-->    Thinking upon his services, took from you
line 17249-->    Th' apprehension of his present portance,
line 17250-->    Which, most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion
line 17251-->    After the inveterate hate he bears you.
line 17252-->  BRUTUS. Lay
line 17253-->    A fault on us, your tribunes, that we labour'd,
line 17254-->    No impediment between, but that you must  
line 17255-->    Cast your election on him.
line 17256-->  SICINIUS. Say you chose him
line 17257-->    More after our commandment than as guided
line 17258-->    By your own true affections; and that your minds,
line 17259-->    Pre-occupied with what you rather must do
line 17260-->    Than what you should, made you against the grain
line 17261-->    To voice him consul. Lay the fault on us.
line 17262-->  BRUTUS. Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you,
line 17263-->    How youngly he began to serve his country,
line 17264-->    How long continued; and what stock he springs of-
line 17265-->    The noble house o' th' Marcians; from whence came
line 17266-->    That Ancus Marcius, Numa's daughter's son,
line 17267-->    Who, after great Hostilius, here was king;
line 17268-->    Of the same house Publius and Quintus were,
line 17269-->    That our best water brought by conduits hither;
line 17270-->    And Censorinus, nobly named so,
line 17271-->    Twice being by the people chosen censor,
line 17272-->    Was his great ancestor.
line 17273-->  SICINIUS. One thus descended,
line 17274-->    That hath beside well in his person wrought  
line 17275-->    To be set high in place, we did commend
line 17276-->    To your remembrances; but you have found,
line 17277-->    Scaling his present bearing with his past,
line 17278-->    That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke
line 17279-->    Your sudden approbation.
line 17280-->  BRUTUS. Say you ne'er had done't-
line 17281-->    Harp on that still- but by our putting on;
line 17282-->    And presently, when you have drawn your number,
line 17283-->    Repair to th' Capitol.
line 17284-->  CITIZENS. will will so; almost all
line 17285-->    Repent in their election.                   Exeunt plebeians
line 17286-->  BRUTUS. Let them go on;
line 17287-->    This mutiny were better put in hazard
line 17288-->    Than stay, past doubt, for greater.
line 17289-->    If, as his nature is, he fall in rage
line 17290-->    With their refusal, both observe and answer
line 17291-->    The vantage of his anger.
line 17292-->  SICINIUS. To th' Capitol, come.
line 17293-->    We will be there before the stream o' th' people;
line 17294-->    And this shall seem, as partly 'tis, their own,  
line 17295-->    Which we have goaded onward.                          Exeunt
line 17296-->
line 17297-->
line 17298-->
line 17299-->
line 17300-->ACT III. SCENE I.
line 17301-->Rome. A street
line 17302-->
line 17303-->Cornets. Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS, all the GENTRY, COMINIUS,
line 17304-->TITUS LARTIUS, and other SENATORS
line 17305-->
line 17306-->  CORIOLANUS. Tullus Aufidius, then, had made new head?
line 17307-->  LARTIUS. He had, my lord; and that it was which caus'd
line 17308-->    Our swifter composition.
line 17309-->  CORIOLANUS. So then the Volsces stand but as at first,
line 17310-->    Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road
line 17311-->    Upon's again.
line 17312-->  COMINIUS. They are worn, Lord Consul, so
line 17313-->    That we shall hardly in our ages see
line 17314-->    Their banners wave again.
line 17315-->  CORIOLANUS. Saw you Aufidius?
line 17316-->  LARTIUS. On safeguard he came to me, and did curse
line 17317-->    Against the Volsces, for they had so vilely
line 17318-->    Yielded the town. He is retir'd to Antium.
line 17319-->  CORIOLANUS. Spoke he of me?
line 17320-->  LARTIUS. He did, my lord.
line 17321-->  CORIOLANUS. How? What?  
line 17322-->  LARTIUS. How often he had met you, sword to sword;
line 17323-->    That of all things upon the earth he hated
line 17324-->    Your person most; that he would pawn his fortunes
line 17325-->    To hopeless restitution, so he might
line 17326-->    Be call'd your vanquisher.
line 17327-->  CORIOLANUS. At Antium lives he?
line 17328-->  LARTIUS. At Antium.
line 17329-->  CORIOLANUS. I wish I had a cause to seek him there,
line 17330-->    To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home.
line 17331-->
line 17332-->                       Enter SICINIUS and BRUTUS
line 17333-->
line 17334-->    Behold, these are the tribunes of the people,
line 17335-->    The tongues o' th' common mouth. I do despise them,
line 17336-->    For they do prank them in authority,
line 17337-->    Against all noble sufferance.
line 17338-->  SICINIUS. Pass no further.
line 17339-->  CORIOLANUS. Ha! What is that?
line 17340-->  BRUTUS. It will be dangerous to go on- no further.
line 17341-->  CORIOLANUS. What makes this change?  
line 17342-->  MENENIUS. The matter?
line 17343-->  COMINIUS. Hath he not pass'd the noble and the common?
line 17344-->  BRUTUS. Cominius, no.
line 17345-->  CORIOLANUS. Have I had children's voices?
line 17346-->  FIRST SENATOR. Tribunes, give way: he shall to th' market-place.
line 17347-->  BRUTUS. The people are incens'd against him.
line 17348-->  SICINIUS. Stop,
line 17349-->    Or all will fall in broil.
line 17350-->  CORIOLANUS. Are these your herd?
line 17351-->    Must these have voices, that can yield them now
line 17352-->    And straight disclaim their tongues? What are your offices?
line 17353-->    You being their mouths, why rule you not their teeth?
line 17354-->    Have you not set them on?
line 17355-->  MENENIUS. Be calm, be calm.
line 17356-->  CORIOLANUS. It is a purpos'd thing, and grows by plot,
line 17357-->    To curb the will of the nobility;
line 17358-->    Suffer't, and live with such as cannot rule
line 17359-->    Nor ever will be rul'd.
line 17360-->  BRUTUS. Call't not a plot.
line 17361-->    The people cry you mock'd them; and of late,  
line 17362-->    When corn was given them gratis, you repin'd;
line 17363-->    Scandal'd the suppliants for the people, call'd them
line 17364-->    Time-pleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.
line 17365-->  CORIOLANUS. Why, this was known before.
line 17366-->  BRUTUS. Not to them all.
line 17367-->  CORIOLANUS. Have you inform'd them sithence?
line 17368-->  BRUTUS. How? I inform them!
line 17369-->  COMINIUS. You are like to do such business.
line 17370-->  BRUTUS. Not unlike
line 17371-->    Each way to better yours.
line 17372-->  CORIOLANUS. Why then should I be consul? By yond clouds,
line 17373-->    Let me deserve so ill as you, and make me
line 17374-->    Your fellow tribune.
line 17375-->  SICINIUS. You show too much of that
line 17376-->    For which the people stir; if you will pass
line 17377-->    To where you are bound, you must enquire your way,
line 17378-->    Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit,
line 17379-->    Or never be so noble as a consul,
line 17380-->    Nor yoke with him for tribune.
line 17381-->  MENENIUS. Let's be calm.  
line 17382-->  COMINIUS. The people are abus'd; set on. This palt'ring
line 17383-->    Becomes not Rome; nor has Coriolanus
line 17384-->    Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely
line 17385-->    I' th' plain way of his merit.
line 17386-->  CORIOLANUS. Tell me of corn!
line 17387-->    This was my speech, and I will speak't again-
line 17388-->  MENENIUS. Not now, not now.
line 17389-->  FIRST SENATOR. Not in this heat, sir, now.
line 17390-->  CORIOLANUS. Now, as I live, I will.
line 17391-->    My nobler friends, I crave their pardons.
line 17392-->    For the mutable, rank-scented meiny, let them
line 17393-->    Regard me as I do not flatter, and
line 17394-->    Therein behold themselves. I say again,
line 17395-->    In soothing them we nourish 'gainst our Senate
line 17396-->    The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition,
line 17397-->    Which we ourselves have plough'd for, sow'd, and scatter'd,
line 17398-->    By mingling them with us, the honour'd number,
line 17399-->    Who lack not virtue, no, nor power, but that
line 17400-->    Which they have given to beggars.
line 17401-->  MENENIUS. Well, no more.  
line 17402-->  FIRST SENATOR. No more words, we beseech you.
line 17403-->  CORIOLANUS. How? no more!
line 17404-->    As for my country I have shed my blood,
line 17405-->    Not fearing outward force, so shall my lungs
line 17406-->    Coin words till their decay against those measles
line 17407-->    Which we disdain should tetter us, yet sought
line 17408-->    The very way to catch them.
line 17409-->  BRUTUS. You speak o' th' people
line 17410-->    As if you were a god, to punish; not
line 17411-->    A man of their infirmity.
line 17412-->  SICINIUS. 'Twere well
line 17413-->    We let the people know't.
line 17414-->  MENENIUS. What, what? his choler?
line 17415-->  CORIOLANUS. Choler!
line 17416-->    Were I as patient as the midnight sleep,
line 17417-->    By Jove, 'twould be my mind!
line 17418-->  SICINIUS. It is a mind
line 17419-->    That shall remain a poison where it is,
line 17420-->    Not poison any further.
line 17421-->  CORIOLANUS. Shall remain!  
line 17422-->    Hear you this Triton of the minnows? Mark you
line 17423-->    His absolute 'shall'?
line 17424-->  COMINIUS. 'Twas from the canon.
line 17425-->  CORIOLANUS. 'Shall'!
line 17426-->    O good but most unwise patricians! Why,
line 17427-->    You grave but reckless senators, have you thus
line 17428-->    Given Hydra here to choose an officer
line 17429-->    That with his peremptory 'shall,' being but
line 17430-->    The horn and noise o' th' monster's, wants not spirit
line 17431-->    To say he'll turn your current in a ditch,
line 17432-->    And make your channel his? If he have power,
line 17433-->    Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake
line 17434-->    Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd,
line 17435-->    Be not as common fools; if you are not,
line 17436-->    Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians,
line 17437-->    If they be senators; and they are no less,
line 17438-->    When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste
line 17439-->    Most palates theirs. They choose their magistrate;
line 17440-->    And such a one as he, who puts his 'shall,'
line 17441-->    His popular 'shall,' against a graver bench  
line 17442-->    Than ever frown'd in Greece. By Jove himself,
line 17443-->    It makes the consuls base; and my soul aches
line 17444-->    To know, when two authorities are up,
line 17445-->    Neither supreme, how soon confusion
line 17446-->    May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take
line 17447-->    The one by th' other.
line 17448-->  COMINIUS. Well, on to th' market-place.
line 17449-->  CORIOLANUS. Whoever gave that counsel to give forth
line 17450-->    The corn o' th' storehouse gratis, as 'twas us'd
line 17451-->    Sometime in Greece-
line 17452-->  MENENIUS. Well, well, no more of that.
line 17453-->  CORIOLANUS. Though there the people had more absolute pow'r-
line 17454-->    I say they nourish'd disobedience, fed
line 17455-->    The ruin of the state.
line 17456-->  BRUTUS. Why shall the people give
line 17457-->    One that speaks thus their voice?
line 17458-->  CORIOLANUS. I'll give my reasons,
line 17459-->    More worthier than their voices. They know the corn
line 17460-->    Was not our recompense, resting well assur'd
line 17461-->    They ne'er did service for't; being press'd to th' war  
line 17462-->    Even when the navel of the state was touch'd,
line 17463-->    They would not thread the gates. This kind of service
line 17464-->    Did not deserve corn gratis. Being i' th' war,
line 17465-->    Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they show'd
line 17466-->    Most valour, spoke not for them. Th' accusation
line 17467-->    Which they have often made against the Senate,
line 17468-->    All cause unborn, could never be the native
line 17469-->    Of our so frank donation. Well, what then?
line 17470-->    How shall this bosom multiplied digest
line 17471-->    The Senate's courtesy? Let deeds express
line 17472-->    What's like to be their words: 'We did request it;
line 17473-->    We are the greater poll, and in true fear
line 17474-->    They gave us our demands.' Thus we debase
line 17475-->    The nature of our seats, and make the rabble
line 17476-->    Call our cares fears; which will in time
line 17477-->    Break ope the locks o' th' Senate and bring in
line 17478-->    The crows to peck the eagles.
line 17479-->  MENENIUS. Come, enough.
line 17480-->  BRUTUS. Enough, with over measure.
line 17481-->  CORIOLANUS. No, take more.  
line 17482-->    What may be sworn by, both divine and human,
line 17483-->    Seal what I end withal! This double worship,
line 17484-->    Where one part does disdain with cause, the other
line 17485-->    Insult without all reason; where gentry, title, wisdom,
line 17486-->    Cannot conclude but by the yea and no
line 17487-->    Of general ignorance- it must omit
line 17488-->    Real necessities, and give way the while
line 17489-->    To unstable slightness. Purpose so barr'd, it follows
line 17490-->    Nothing is done to purpose. Therefore, beseech you-
line 17491-->    You that will be less fearful than discreet;
line 17492-->    That love the fundamental part of state
line 17493-->    More than you doubt the change on't; that prefer
line 17494-->    A noble life before a long, and wish
line 17495-->    To jump a body with a dangerous physic
line 17496-->    That's sure of death without it- at once pluck out
line 17497-->    The multitudinous tongue; let them not lick
line 17498-->    The sweet which is their poison. Your dishonour
line 17499-->    Mangles true judgment, and bereaves the state
line 17500-->    Of that integrity which should become't,
line 17501-->    Not having the power to do the good it would,  
line 17502-->    For th' ill which doth control't.
line 17503-->  BRUTUS. Has said enough.
line 17504-->  SICINIUS. Has spoken like a traitor and shall answer
line 17505-->    As traitors do.
line 17506-->  CORIOLANUS. Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee!
line 17507-->    What should the people do with these bald tribunes,
line 17508-->    On whom depending, their obedience fails
line 17509-->    To the greater bench? In a rebellion,
line 17510-->    When what's not meet, but what must be, was law,
line 17511-->    Then were they chosen; in a better hour
line 17512-->    Let what is meet be said it must be meet,
line 17513-->    And throw their power i' th' dust.
line 17514-->  BRUTUS. Manifest treason!
line 17515-->  SICINIUS. This a consul? No.
line 17516-->  BRUTUS. The aediles, ho!
line 17517-->
line 17518-->                           Enter an AEDILE
line 17519-->
line 17520-->    Let him be apprehended.
line 17521-->  SICINIUS. Go call the people,  [Exit AEDILE]  in whose name myself  
line 17522-->    Attach thee as a traitorous innovator,
line 17523-->    A foe to th' public weal. Obey, I charge thee,
line 17524-->    And follow to thine answer.
line 17525-->  CORIOLANUS. Hence, old goat!
line 17526-->  PATRICIANS. We'll surety him.
line 17527-->  COMINIUS. Ag'd sir, hands off.
line 17528-->  CORIOLANUS. Hence, rotten thing! or I shall shake thy bones
line 17529-->    Out of thy garments.
line 17530-->  SICINIUS. Help, ye citizens!
line 17531-->
line 17532-->              Enter a rabble of plebeians, with the AEDILES
line 17533-->
line 17534-->  MENENIUS. On both sides more respect.
line 17535-->  SICINIUS. Here's he that would take from you all your power.
line 17536-->  BRUTUS. Seize him, aediles.
line 17537-->    PLEBEIANS. Down with him! down with him!
line 17538-->  SECOND SENATOR. Weapons, weapons, weapons!
line 17539-->                              [They all bustle about CORIOLANUS]
line 17540-->  ALL. Tribunes! patricians! citizens! What, ho! Sicinius!
line 17541-->    Brutus! Coriolanus! Citizens!  
line 17542-->  PATRICIANS. Peace, peace, peace; stay, hold, peace!
line 17543-->  MENENIUS. What is about to be? I am out of breath;
line 17544-->    Confusion's near; I cannot speak. You tribunes
line 17545-->    To th' people- Coriolanus, patience!
line 17546-->    Speak, good Sicinius.
line 17547-->  SICINIUS. Hear me, people; peace!
line 17548-->  PLEBEIANS. Let's hear our tribune. Peace! Speak, speak, speak.
line 17549-->  SICINIUS. You are at point to lose your liberties.
line 17550-->    Marcius would have all from you; Marcius,
line 17551-->    Whom late you have nam'd for consul.
line 17552-->  MENENIUS. Fie, fie, fie!
line 17553-->    This is the way to kindle, not to quench.
line 17554-->  FIRST SENATOR. To unbuild the city, and to lay all flat.
line 17555-->  SICINIUS. What is the city but the people?
line 17556-->  PLEBEIANS. True,
line 17557-->    The people are the city.
line 17558-->  BRUTUS. By the consent of all we were establish'd
line 17559-->    The people's magistrates.
line 17560-->  PLEBEIANS. You so remain.
line 17561-->  MENENIUS. And so are like to do.  
line 17562-->  COMINIUS. That is the way to lay the city flat,
line 17563-->    To bring the roof to the foundation,
line 17564-->    And bury all which yet distinctly ranges
line 17565-->    In heaps and piles of ruin.
line 17566-->  SICINIUS. This deserves death.
line 17567-->  BRUTUS. Or let us stand to our authority
line 17568-->    Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce,
line 17569-->    Upon the part o' th' people, in whose power
line 17570-->    We were elected theirs: Marcius is worthy
line 17571-->    Of present death.
line 17572-->  SICINIUS. Therefore lay hold of him;
line 17573-->    Bear him to th' rock Tarpeian, and from thence
line 17574-->    Into destruction cast him.
line 17575-->  BRUTUS. AEdiles, seize him.
line 17576-->  PLEBEIANS. Yield, Marcius, yield.
line 17577-->  MENENIUS. Hear me one word; beseech you, Tribunes,
line 17578-->    Hear me but a word.
line 17579-->  AEDILES. Peace, peace!
line 17580-->  MENENIUS. Be that you seem, truly your country's friend,
line 17581-->    And temp'rately proceed to what you would  
line 17582-->    Thus violently redress.
line 17583-->  BRUTUS. Sir, those cold ways,
line 17584-->    That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous
line 17585-->    Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him
line 17586-->    And bear him to the rock.
line 17587-->                                    [CORIOLANUS draws his sword]
line 17588-->  CORIOLANUS. No: I'll die here.
line 17589-->    There's some among you have beheld me fighting;
line 17590-->    Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me.
line 17591-->  MENENIUS. Down with that sword! Tribunes, withdraw awhile.
line 17592-->  BRUTUS. Lay hands upon him.
line 17593-->  MENENIUS. Help Marcius, help,
line 17594-->    You that be noble; help him, young and old.
line 17595-->  PLEBEIANS. Down with him, down with him!
line 17596-->                      [In this mutiny the TRIBUNES, the AEDILES,
line 17597-->                                     and the people are beat in]
line 17598-->  MENENIUS. Go, get you to your house; be gone, away.
line 17599-->    All will be nought else.
line 17600-->  SECOND SENATOR. Get you gone.
line 17601-->  CORIOLANUS. Stand fast;  
line 17602-->    We have as many friends as enemies.
line 17603-->  MENENIUS. Shall it be put to that?
line 17604-->  FIRST SENATOR. The gods forbid!
line 17605-->    I prithee, noble friend, home to thy house;
line 17606-->    Leave us to cure this cause.
line 17607-->  MENENIUS. For 'tis a sore upon us
line 17608-->    You cannot tent yourself; be gone, beseech you.
line 17609-->  COMINIUS. Come, sir, along with us.
line 17610-->  CORIOLANUS. I would they were barbarians, as they are,
line 17611-->    Though in Rome litter'd; not Romans, as they are not,
line 17612-->    Though calved i' th' porch o' th' Capitol.
line 17613-->  MENENIUS. Be gone.
line 17614-->    Put not your worthy rage into your tongue;
line 17615-->    One time will owe another.
line 17616-->  CORIOLANUS. On fair ground
line 17617-->    I could beat forty of them.
line 17618-->  MENENIUS. I could myself
line 17619-->    Take up a brace o' th' best of them; yea, the two tribunes.
line 17620-->  COMINIUS. But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic,
line 17621-->    And manhood is call'd foolery when it stands  
line 17622-->    Against a falling fabric. Will you hence,
line 17623-->    Before the tag return? whose rage doth rend
line 17624-->    Like interrupted waters, and o'erbear
line 17625-->    What they are us'd to bear.
line 17626-->  MENENIUS. Pray you be gone.
line 17627-->    I'll try whether my old wit be in request
line 17628-->    With those that have but little; this must be patch'd
line 17629-->    With cloth of any colour.
line 17630-->  COMINIUS. Nay, come away.
line 17631-->                     Exeunt CORIOLANUS and COMINIUS, with others
line 17632-->  PATRICIANS. This man has marr'd his fortune.
line 17633-->  MENENIUS. His nature is too noble for the world:
line 17634-->    He would not flatter Neptune for his trident,
line 17635-->    Or Jove for's power to thunder. His heart's his mouth;
line 17636-->    What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent;
line 17637-->    And, being angry, does forget that ever
line 17638-->    He heard the name of death.                 [A noise within]
line 17639-->    Here's goodly work!
line 17640-->  PATRICIANS. I would they were a-bed.
line 17641-->  MENENIUS. I would they were in Tiber.  
line 17642-->    What the vengeance, could he not speak 'em fair?
line 17643-->
line 17644-->            Re-enter BRUTUS and SICINIUS, the rabble again
line 17645-->
line 17646-->  SICINIUS. Where is this viper
line 17647-->    That would depopulate the city and
line 17648-->    Be every man himself?
line 17649-->  MENENIUS. You worthy Tribunes-
line 17650-->  SICINIUS. He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock
line 17651-->    With rigorous hands; he hath resisted law,
line 17652-->    And therefore law shall scorn him further trial
line 17653-->    Than the severity of the public power,
line 17654-->    Which he so sets at nought.
line 17655-->  FIRST CITIZEN. He shall well know
line 17656-->    The noble tribunes are the people's mouths,
line 17657-->    And we their hands.
line 17658-->  PLEBEIANS. He shall, sure on't.
line 17659-->  MENENIUS. Sir, sir-
line 17660-->  SICINIUS. Peace!
line 17661-->  MENENIUS. Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt  
line 17662-->    With modest warrant.
line 17663-->  SICINIUS. Sir, how comes't that you
line 17664-->    Have holp to make this rescue?
line 17665-->  MENENIUS. Hear me speak.
line 17666-->    As I do know the consul's worthiness,
line 17667-->    So can I name his faults.
line 17668-->  SICINIUS. Consul! What consul?
line 17669-->  MENENIUS. The consul Coriolanus.
line 17670-->  BRUTUS. He consul!
line 17671-->  PLEBEIANS. No, no, no, no, no.
line 17672-->  MENENIUS. If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people,
line 17673-->    I may be heard, I would crave a word or two;
line 17674-->    The which shall turn you to no further harm
line 17675-->    Than so much loss of time.
line 17676-->  SICINIUS. Speak briefly, then,
line 17677-->    For we are peremptory to dispatch
line 17678-->    This viperous traitor; to eject him hence
line 17679-->    Were but one danger, and to keep him here
line 17680-->    Our certain death; therefore it is decreed
line 17681-->    He dies to-night.  
line 17682-->  MENENIUS. Now the good gods forbid
line 17683-->    That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude
line 17684-->    Towards her deserved children is enroll'd
line 17685-->    In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam
line 17686-->    Should now eat up her own!
line 17687-->  SICINIUS. He's a disease that must be cut away.
line 17688-->  MENENIUS. O, he's a limb that has but a disease-
line 17689-->    Mortal, to cut it off: to cure it, easy.
line 17690-->    What has he done to Rome that's worthy death?
line 17691-->    Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost-
line 17692-->    Which I dare vouch is more than that he hath
line 17693-->    By many an ounce- he dropt it for his country;
line 17694-->    And what is left, to lose it by his country
line 17695-->    Were to us all that do't and suffer it
line 17696-->    A brand to th' end o' th' world.
line 17697-->  SICINIUS. This is clean kam.
line 17698-->  BRUTUS. Merely awry. When he did love his country,
line 17699-->    It honour'd him.
line 17700-->  SICINIUS. The service of the foot,
line 17701-->    Being once gangren'd, is not then respected  
line 17702-->    For what before it was.
line 17703-->  BRUTUS. We'll hear no more.
line 17704-->    Pursue him to his house and pluck him thence,
line 17705-->    Lest his infection, being of catching nature,
line 17706-->    Spread further.
line 17707-->  MENENIUS. One word more, one word
line 17708-->    This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find
line 17709-->    The harm of unscann'd swiftness, will, too late,
line 17710-->    Tie leaden pounds to's heels. Proceed by process,
line 17711-->    Lest parties- as he is belov'd- break out,
line 17712-->    And sack great Rome with Romans.
line 17713-->  BRUTUS. If it were so-
line 17714-->  SICINIUS. What do ye talk?
line 17715-->    Have we not had a taste of his obedience-
line 17716-->    Our aediles smote, ourselves resisted? Come!
line 17717-->  MENENIUS. Consider this: he has been bred i' th' wars
line 17718-->    Since 'a could draw a sword, and is ill school'd
line 17719-->    In bolted language; meal and bran together
line 17720-->    He throws without distinction. Give me leave,
line 17721-->    I'll go to him and undertake to bring him  
line 17722-->    Where he shall answer by a lawful form,
line 17723-->    In peace, to his utmost peril.
line 17724-->  FIRST SENATOR. Noble Tribunes,
line 17725-->    It is the humane way; the other course
line 17726-->    Will prove too bloody, and the end of it
line 17727-->    Unknown to the beginning.
line 17728-->  SICINIUS. Noble Menenius,
line 17729-->    Be you then as the people's officer.
line 17730-->    Masters, lay down your weapons.
line 17731-->  BRUTUS. Go not home.
line 17732-->  SICINIUS. Meet on the market-place. We'll attend you there;
line 17733-->    Where, if you bring not Marcius, we'll proceed
line 17734-->    In our first way.
line 17735-->  MENENIUS. I'll bring him to you.
line 17736-->    [To the SENATORS]  Let me desire your company; he must come,
line 17737-->    Or what is worst will follow.
line 17738-->  FIRST SENATOR. Pray you let's to him.                   Exeunt
line 17739-->
line 17740-->
line 17741-->
line 17742-->
line 17743-->SCENE II.
line 17744-->Rome. The house of CORIOLANUS
line 17745-->
line 17746-->Enter CORIOLANUS with NOBLES
line 17747-->
line 17748-->  CORIOLANUS. Let them pull all about mine ears, present me
line 17749-->    Death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels;
line 17750-->    Or pile ten hills on the Tarpeian rock,
line 17751-->    That the precipitation might down stretch
line 17752-->    Below the beam of sight; yet will I still
line 17753-->    Be thus to them.
line 17754-->  FIRST PATRICIAN. You do the nobler.
line 17755-->  CORIOLANUS. I muse my mother
line 17756-->    Does not approve me further, who was wont
line 17757-->    To call them woollen vassals, things created
line 17758-->    To buy and sell with groats; to show bare heads
line 17759-->    In congregations, to yawn, be still, and wonder,
line 17760-->    When one but of my ordinance stood up
line 17761-->    To speak of peace or war.
line 17762-->
line 17763-->                          Enter VOLUMNIA
line 17764-->  
line 17765-->    I talk of you:
line 17766-->    Why did you wish me milder? Would you have me
line 17767-->    False to my nature? Rather say I play
line 17768-->    The man I am.
line 17769-->  VOLUMNIA. O, sir, sir, sir,
line 17770-->    I would have had you put your power well on
line 17771-->    Before you had worn it out.
line 17772-->  CORIOLANUS. Let go.
line 17773-->  VOLUMNIA. You might have been enough the man you are
line 17774-->    With striving less to be so; lesser had been
line 17775-->    The thwartings of your dispositions, if
line 17776-->    You had not show'd them how ye were dispos'd,
line 17777-->    Ere they lack'd power to cross you.
line 17778-->  CORIOLANUS. Let them hang.
line 17779-->  VOLUMNIA. Ay, and burn too.
line 17780-->
line 17781-->                    Enter MENENIUS with the SENATORS
line 17782-->
line 17783-->  MENENIUS. Come, come, you have been too rough, something too rough;
line 17784-->    You must return and mend it.  
line 17785-->  FIRST SENATOR. There's no remedy,
line 17786-->    Unless, by not so doing, our good city
line 17787-->    Cleave in the midst and perish.
line 17788-->  VOLUMNIA. Pray be counsell'd;
line 17789-->    I have a heart as little apt as yours,
line 17790-->    But yet a brain that leads my use of anger
line 17791-->    To better vantage.
line 17792-->  MENENIUS. Well said, noble woman!
line 17793-->    Before he should thus stoop to th' herd, but that
line 17794-->    The violent fit o' th' time craves it as physic
line 17795-->    For the whole state, I would put mine armour on,
line 17796-->    Which I can scarcely bear.
line 17797-->  CORIOLANUS. What must I do?
line 17798-->  MENENIUS. Return to th' tribunes.
line 17799-->  CORIOLANUS. Well, what then, what then?
line 17800-->  MENENIUS. Repent what you have spoke.
line 17801-->  CORIOLANUS. For them! I cannot do it to the gods;
line 17802-->    Must I then do't to them?
line 17803-->  VOLUMNIA. You are too absolute;
line 17804-->    Though therein you can never be too noble  
line 17805-->    But when extremities speak. I have heard you say
line 17806-->    Honour and policy, like unsever'd friends,
line 17807-->    I' th' war do grow together; grant that, and tell me
line 17808-->    In peace what each of them by th' other lose
line 17809-->    That they combine not there.
line 17810-->  CORIOLANUS. Tush, tush!
line 17811-->  MENENIUS. A good demand.
line 17812-->  VOLUMNIA. If it be honour in your wars to seem
line 17813-->    The same you are not, which for your best ends
line 17814-->    You adopt your policy, how is it less or worse
line 17815-->    That it shall hold companionship in peace
line 17816-->    With honour as in war; since that to both
line 17817-->    It stands in like request?
line 17818-->  CORIOLANUS. Why force you this?
line 17819-->  VOLUMNIA. Because that now it lies you on to speak
line 17820-->    To th' people, not by your own instruction,
line 17821-->    Nor by th' matter which your heart prompts you,
line 17822-->    But with such words that are but roted in
line 17823-->    Your tongue, though but bastards and syllables
line 17824-->    Of no allowance to your bosom's truth.  
line 17825-->    Now, this no more dishonours you at all
line 17826-->    Than to take in a town with gentle words,
line 17827-->    Which else would put you to your fortune and
line 17828-->    The hazard of much blood.
line 17829-->    I would dissemble with my nature where
line 17830-->    My fortunes and my friends at stake requir'd
line 17831-->    I should do so in honour. I am in this
line 17832-->    Your wife, your son, these senators, the nobles;
line 17833-->    And you will rather show our general louts
line 17834-->    How you can frown, than spend a fawn upon 'em
line 17835-->    For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard
line 17836-->    Of what that want might ruin.
line 17837-->  MENENIUS. Noble lady!
line 17838-->    Come, go with us, speak fair; you may salve so,
line 17839-->    Not what is dangerous present, but the los
line 17840-->    Of what is past.
line 17841-->  VOLUMNIA. I prithee now, My son,
line 17842-->    Go to them with this bonnet in thy hand;
line 17843-->    And thus far having stretch'd it- here be with them-
line 17844-->    Thy knee bussing the stones- for in such busines  
line 17845-->    Action is eloquence, and the eyes of th' ignorant
line 17846-->    More learned than the ears- waving thy head,
line 17847-->    Which often thus correcting thy-stout heart,
line 17848-->    Now humble as the ripest mulberry
line 17849-->    That will not hold the handling. Or say to them
line 17850-->    Thou art their soldier and, being bred in broils,
line 17851-->    Hast not the soft way which, thou dost confess,
line 17852-->    Were fit for thee to use, as they to claim,
line 17853-->    In asking their good loves; but thou wilt frame
line 17854-->    Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs, so far
line 17855-->    As thou hast power and person.
line 17856-->  MENENIUS. This but done
line 17857-->    Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours;
line 17858-->    For they have pardons, being ask'd, as free
line 17859-->    As words to little purpose.
line 17860-->  VOLUMNIA. Prithee now,
line 17861-->    Go, and be rul'd; although I know thou hadst rather
line 17862-->    Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf
line 17863-->    Than flatter him in a bower.
line 17864-->  
line 17865-->                           Enter COMINIUS
line 17866-->
line 17867-->    Here is Cominius.
line 17868-->  COMINIUS. I have been i' th' market-place; and, sir, 'tis fit
line 17869-->    You make strong party, or defend yourself
line 17870-->    By calmness or by absence; all's in anger.
line 17871-->  MENENIUS. Only fair speech.
line 17872-->  COMINIUS. I think 'twill serve, if he
line 17873-->    Can thereto frame his spirit.
line 17874-->  VOLUMNIA. He must and will.
line 17875-->    Prithee now, say you will, and go about it.
line 17876-->  CORIOLANUS. Must I go show them my unbarb'd sconce? Must I
line 17877-->    With my base tongue give to my noble heart
line 17878-->    A lie that it must bear? Well, I will do't;
line 17879-->    Yet, were there but this single plot to lose,
line 17880-->    This mould of Marcius, they to dust should grind it,
line 17881-->    And throw't against the wind. To th' market-place!
line 17882-->    You have put me now to such a part which never
line 17883-->    I shall discharge to th' life.
line 17884-->  COMINIUS. Come, come, we'll prompt you.  
line 17885-->  VOLUMNIA. I prithee now, sweet son, as thou hast said
line 17886-->    My praises made thee first a soldier, so,
line 17887-->    To have my praise for this, perform a part
line 17888-->    Thou hast not done before.
line 17889-->  CORIOLANUS. Well, I must do't.
line 17890-->    Away, my disposition, and possess me
line 17891-->    Some harlot's spirit! My throat of war be turn'd,
line 17892-->    Which quier'd with my drum, into a pipe
line 17893-->    Small as an eunuch or the virgin voice
line 17894-->    That babies lulls asleep! The smiles of knaves
line 17895-->    Tent in my cheeks, and schoolboys' tears take up
line 17896-->    The glasses of my sight! A beggar's tongue
line 17897-->    Make motion through my lips, and my arm'd knees,
line 17898-->    Who bow'd but in my stirrup, bend like his
line 17899-->    That hath receiv'd an alms! I will not do't,
line 17900-->    Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth,
line 17901-->    And by my body's action teach my mind
line 17902-->    A most inherent baseness.
line 17903-->  VOLUMNIA. At thy choice, then.
line 17904-->    To beg of thee, it is my more dishonour  
line 17905-->    Than thou of them. Come all to ruin. Let
line 17906-->    Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear
line 17907-->    Thy dangerous stoutness; for I mock at death
line 17908-->    With as big heart as thou. Do as thou list.
line 17909-->    Thy valiantness was mine, thou suck'dst it from me;
line 17910-->    But owe thy pride thyself.
line 17911-->  CORIOLANUS. Pray be content.
line 17912-->    Mother, I am going to the market-place;
line 17913-->    Chide me no more. I'll mountebank their loves,
line 17914-->    Cog their hearts from them, and come home belov'd
line 17915-->    Of all the trades in Rome. Look, I am going.
line 17916-->    Commend me to my wife. I'll return consul,
line 17917-->    Or never trust to what my tongue can do
line 17918-->    I' th' way of flattery further.
line 17919-->  VOLUMNIA. Do your will.                                   Exit
line 17920-->  COMINIUS. Away! The tribunes do attend you. Arm yourself
line 17921-->    To answer mildly; for they are prepar'd
line 17922-->    With accusations, as I hear, more strong
line 17923-->    Than are upon you yet.
line 17924-->  CORIOLANUS. The word is 'mildly.' Pray you let us go.  
line 17925-->    Let them accuse me by invention; I
line 17926-->    Will answer in mine honour.
line 17927-->  MENENIUS. Ay, but mildly.
line 17928-->  CORIOLANUS. Well, mildly be it then- mildly.            Exeunt
line 17929-->
line 17930-->
line 17931-->
line 17932-->
line 17933-->SCENE III.
line 17934-->Rome. The Forum
line 17935-->
line 17936-->Enter SICINIUS and BRUTUS
line 17937-->
line 17938-->  BRUTUS. In this point charge him home, that he affects
line 17939-->    Tyrannical power. If he evade us there,
line 17940-->    Enforce him with his envy to the people,
line 17941-->    And that the spoil got on the Antiates
line 17942-->    Was ne'er distributed.
line 17943-->
line 17944-->                           Enter an AEDILE
line 17945-->
line 17946-->    What, will he come?
line 17947-->  AEDILE. He's coming.
line 17948-->  BRUTUS. How accompanied?
line 17949-->  AEDILE. With old Menenius, and those senators
line 17950-->    That always favour'd him.
line 17951-->  SICINIUS. Have you a catalogue
line 17952-->    Of all the voices that we have procur'd,
line 17953-->    Set down by th' poll?
line 17954-->  AEDILE. I have; 'tis ready.  
line 17955-->  SICINIUS. Have you corrected them by tribes?
line 17956-->  AEDILE. I have.
line 17957-->  SICINIUS. Assemble presently the people hither;
line 17958-->    And when they hear me say 'It shall be so
line 17959-->    I' th' right and strength o' th' commons' be it either
line 17960-->    For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them,
line 17961-->    If I say fine, cry 'Fine!'- if death, cry 'Death!'
line 17962-->    Insisting on the old prerogative
line 17963-->    And power i' th' truth o' th' cause.
line 17964-->  AEDILE. I shall inform them.
line 17965-->  BRUTUS. And when such time they have begun to cry,
line 17966-->    Let them not cease, but with a din confus'd
line 17967-->    Enforce the present execution
line 17968-->    Of what we chance to sentence.
line 17969-->  AEDILE. Very well.
line 17970-->  SICINIUS. Make them be strong, and ready for this hint,
line 17971-->    When we shall hap to give't them.
line 17972-->  BRUTUS. Go about it.                               Exit AEDILE
line 17973-->    Put him to choler straight. He hath been us'd
line 17974-->    Ever to conquer, and to have his worth  
line 17975-->    Of contradiction; being once chaf'd, he cannot
line 17976-->    Be rein'd again to temperance; then he speaks
line 17977-->    What's in his heart, and that is there which looks
line 17978-->    With us to break his neck.
line 17979-->
line 17980-->          Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS and COMINIUS, with others
line 17981-->
line 17982-->  SICINIUS. Well, here he comes.
line 17983-->  MENENIUS. Calmly, I do beseech you.
line 17984-->  CORIOLANUS. Ay, as an ostler, that for th' poorest piece
line 17985-->    Will bear the knave by th' volume. Th' honour'd gods
line 17986-->    Keep Rome in safety, and the chairs of justice
line 17987-->    Supplied with worthy men! plant love among's!
line 17988-->    Throng our large temples with the shows of peace,
line 17989-->    And not our streets with war!
line 17990-->  FIRST SENATOR. Amen, amen!
line 17991-->  MENENIUS. A noble wish.
line 17992-->
line 17993-->                  Re-enter the.AEDILE,with the plebeians
line 17994-->  
line 17995-->  SICINIUS. Draw near, ye people.
line 17996-->  AEDILE. List to your tribunes. Audience! peace, I say!
line 17997-->  CORIOLANUS. First, hear me speak.
line 17998-->  BOTH TRIBUNES. Well, say. Peace, ho!
line 17999-->  CORIOLANUS. Shall I be charg'd no further than this present?
line 18000-->    Must all determine here?
line 18001-->  SICINIUS. I do demand,
line 18002-->    If you submit you to the people's voices,
line 18003-->    Allow their officers, and are content
line 18004-->    To suffer lawful censure for such faults
line 18005-->    As shall be prov'd upon you.
line 18006-->  CORIOLANUS. I am content.
line 18007-->  MENENIUS. Lo, citizens, he says he is content.
line 18008-->    The warlike service he has done, consider; think
line 18009-->    Upon the wounds his body bears, which show
line 18010-->    Like graves i' th' holy churchyard.
line 18011-->  CORIOLANUS. Scratches with briers,
line 18012-->    Scars to move laughter only.
line 18013-->  MENENIUS. Consider further,
line 18014-->    That when he speaks not like a citizen,  
line 18015-->    You find him like a soldier; do not take
line 18016-->    His rougher accents for malicious sounds,
line 18017-->    But, as I say, such as become a soldier
line 18018-->    Rather than envy you.
line 18019-->  COMINIUS. Well, well! No more.
line 18020-->  CORIOLANUS. What is the matter,
line 18021-->    That being pass'd for consul with full voice,
line 18022-->    I am so dishonour'd that the very hour
line 18023-->    You take it off again?
line 18024-->  SICINIUS. Answer to us.
line 18025-->  CORIOLANUS. Say then; 'tis true, I ought so.
line 18026-->  SICINIUS. We charge you that you have contriv'd to take
line 18027-->    From Rome all season'd office, and to wind
line 18028-->    Yourself into a power tyrannical;
line 18029-->    For which you are a traitor to the people.
line 18030-->  CORIOLANUS. How- traitor?
line 18031-->  MENENIUS. Nay, temperately! Your promise.
line 18032-->  CORIOLANUS. The fires i' th' lowest hell fold in the people!
line 18033-->    Call me their traitor! Thou injurious tribune!
line 18034-->    Within thine eyes sat twenty thousand deaths,  
line 18035-->    In thy hands clutch'd as many millions, in
line 18036-->    Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say
line 18037-->    'Thou liest' unto thee with a voice as free
line 18038-->    As I do pray the gods.
line 18039-->  SICINIUS. Mark you this, people?
line 18040-->  PLEBEIANS. To th' rock, to th' rock, with him!
line 18041-->  SICINIUS. Peace!
line 18042-->    We need not put new matter to his charge.
line 18043-->    What you have seen him do and heard him speak,
line 18044-->    Beating your officers, cursing yourselves,
line 18045-->    Opposing laws with strokes, and here defying
line 18046-->    Those whose great power must try him- even this,
line 18047-->    So criminal and in such capital kind,
line 18048-->    Deserves th' extremest death.
line 18049-->  BRUTUS. But since he hath
line 18050-->    Serv'd well for Rome-
line 18051-->  CORIOLANUS. What do you prate of service?
line 18052-->  BRUTUS. I talk of that that know it.
line 18053-->  CORIOLANUS. You!
line 18054-->  MENENIUS. Is this the promise that you made your mother?  
line 18055-->  COMINIUS. Know, I pray you-
line 18056-->  CORIOLANUS. I'll know no further.
line 18057-->    Let them pronounce the steep Tarpeian death,
line 18058-->    Vagabond exile, flaying, pent to linger
line 18059-->    But with a grain a day, I would not buy
line 18060-->    Their mercy at the price of one fair word,
line 18061-->    Nor check my courage for what they can give,
line 18062-->    To have't with saying 'Good morrow.'
line 18063-->  SICINIUS. For that he has-
line 18064-->    As much as in him lies- from time to time
line 18065-->    Envied against the people, seeking means
line 18066-->    To pluck away their power; as now at last
line 18067-->    Given hostile strokes, and that not in the presence
line 18068-->    Of dreaded justice, but on the ministers
line 18069-->    That do distribute it- in the name o' th' people,
line 18070-->    And in the power of us the tribunes, we,
line 18071-->    Ev'n from this instant, banish him our city,
line 18072-->    In peril of precipitation
line 18073-->    From off the rock Tarpeian, never more
line 18074-->    To enter our Rome gates. I' th' people's name,  
line 18075-->    I say it shall be so.
line 18076-->  PLEBEIANS. It shall be so, it shall be so! Let him away!
line 18077-->    He's banish'd, and it shall be so.
line 18078-->  COMINIUS. Hear me, my masters and my common friends-
line 18079-->  SICINIUS. He's sentenc'd; no more hearing.
line 18080-->  COMINIUS. Let me speak.
line 18081-->    I have been consul, and can show for Rome
line 18082-->    Her enemies' marks upon me. I do love
line 18083-->    My country's good with a respect more tender,
line 18084-->    More holy and profound, than mine own life,
line 18085-->    My dear wife's estimate, her womb's increase
line 18086-->    And treasure of my loins. Then if I would
line 18087-->    Speak that-
line 18088-->  SICINIUS. We know your drift. Speak what?
line 18089-->  BRUTUS. There's no more to be said, but he is banish'd,
line 18090-->    As enemy to the people and his country.
line 18091-->    It shall be so.
line 18092-->  PLEBEIANS. It shall be so, it shall be so.
line 18093-->  CORIOLANUS. YOU common cry of curs, whose breath I hate
line 18094-->    As reek o' th' rotten fens, whose loves I prize  
line 18095-->    As the dead carcasses of unburied men
line 18096-->    That do corrupt my air- I banish you.
line 18097-->    And here remain with your uncertainty!
line 18098-->    Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts;
line 18099-->    Your enemies, with nodding of their plumes,
line 18100-->    Fan you into despair! Have the power still
line 18101-->    To banish your defenders, till at length
line 18102-->    Your ignorance- which finds not till it feels,
line 18103-->    Making but reservation of yourselves
line 18104-->    Still your own foes- deliver you
line 18105-->    As most abated captives to some nation
line 18106-->    That won you without blows! Despising
line 18107-->    For you the city, thus I turn my back;
line 18108-->    There is a world elsewhere.
line 18109-->                                              Exeunt CORIOLANUS,
line 18110-->                   COMINIUS, MENENIUS, with the other PATRICIANS
line 18111-->  AEDILE. The people's enemy is gone, is gone!
line 18112-->                        [They all shout and throw up their caps]
line 18113-->  PLEBEIANS. Our enemy is banish'd, he is gone! Hoo-oo!
line 18114-->  SICINIUS. Go see him out at gates, and follow him,  
line 18115-->    As he hath follow'd you, with all despite;
line 18116-->    Give him deserv'd vexation. Let a guard
line 18117-->    Attend us through the city.
line 18118-->  PLEBEIANS. Come, come, let's see him out at gates; come!
line 18119-->    The gods preserve our noble tribunes! Come.           Exeunt
line 18120-->
line 18121-->
