line 18134-->
line 18135-->ACT IV. SCENE I.
line 18136-->Rome. Before a gate of the city
line 18137-->
line 18138-->Enter CORIOLANUS, VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA, MENENIUS, COMINIUS,
line 18139-->with the young NOBILITY of Rome
line 18140-->
line 18141-->  CORIOLANUS. Come, leave your tears; a brief farewell. The beast
line 18142-->    With many heads butts me away. Nay, mother,
line 18143-->    Where is your ancient courage? You were us'd
line 18144-->    To say extremities was the trier of spirits;
line 18145-->    That common chances common men could bear;
line 18146-->    That when the sea was calm all boats alike
line 18147-->    Show'd mastership in floating; fortune's blows,
line 18148-->    When most struck home, being gentle wounded craves
line 18149-->    A noble cunning. You were us'd to load me
line 18150-->    With precepts that would make invincible
line 18151-->    The heart that conn'd them.
line 18152-->  VIRGILIA. O heavens! O heavens!
line 18153-->  CORIOLANUS. Nay, I prithee, woman-
line 18154-->  VOLUMNIA. Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome,
line 18155-->    And occupations perish!
line 18156-->  CORIOLANUS. What, what, what!  
line 18157-->    I shall be lov'd when I am lack'd. Nay, mother,
line 18158-->    Resume that spirit when you were wont to say,
line 18159-->    If you had been the wife of Hercules,
line 18160-->    Six of his labours you'd have done, and sav'd
line 18161-->    Your husband so much sweat. Cominius,
line 18162-->    Droop not; adieu. Farewell, my wife, my mother.
line 18163-->    I'll do well yet. Thou old and true Menenius,
line 18164-->    Thy tears are salter than a younger man's
line 18165-->    And venomous to thine eyes. My sometime General,
line 18166-->    I have seen thee stern, and thou hast oft beheld
line 18167-->    Heart-hard'ning spectacles; tell these sad women
line 18168-->    'Tis fond to wail inevitable strokes,
line 18169-->    As 'tis to laugh at 'em. My mother, you wot well
line 18170-->    My hazards still have been your solace; and
line 18171-->    Believe't not lightly- though I go alone,
line 18172-->    Like to a lonely dragon, that his fen
line 18173-->    Makes fear'd and talk'd of more than seen- your son
line 18174-->    Will or exceed the common or be caught
line 18175-->    With cautelous baits and practice.
line 18176-->  VOLUMNIA. My first son,  
line 18177-->    Whither wilt thou go? Take good Cominius
line 18178-->    With thee awhile; determine on some course
line 18179-->    More than a wild exposture to each chance
line 18180-->    That starts i' th' way before thee.
line 18181-->  VIRGILIA. O the gods!
line 18182-->  COMINIUS. I'll follow thee a month, devise with the
line 18183-->    Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us,
line 18184-->    And we of thee; so, if the time thrust forth
line 18185-->    A cause for thy repeal, we shall not send
line 18186-->    O'er the vast world to seek a single man,
line 18187-->    And lose advantage, which doth ever cool
line 18188-->    I' th' absence of the needer.
line 18189-->  CORIOLANUS. Fare ye well;
line 18190-->    Thou hast years upon thee, and thou art too full
line 18191-->    Of the wars' surfeits to go rove with one
line 18192-->    That's yet unbruis'd; bring me but out at gate.
line 18193-->    Come, my sweet wife, my dearest mother, and
line 18194-->    My friends of noble touch; when I am forth,
line 18195-->    Bid me farewell, and smile. I pray you come.
line 18196-->    While I remain above the ground you shall  
line 18197-->    Hear from me still, and never of me aught
line 18198-->    But what is like me formerly.
line 18199-->  MENENIUS. That's worthily
line 18200-->    As any ear can hear. Come, let's not weep.
line 18201-->    If I could shake off but one seven years
line 18202-->    From these old arms and legs, by the good gods,
line 18203-->    I'd with thee every foot.
line 18204-->  CORIOLANUS. Give me thy hand.
line 18205-->    Come.                                                 Exeunt
line 18206-->
line 18207-->
line 18208-->
line 18209-->
line 18210-->SCENE II.
line 18211-->Rome. A street near the gate
line 18212-->
line 18213-->Enter the two Tribunes, SICINIUS and BRUTUS with the AEDILE
line 18214-->
line 18215-->  SICINIUS. Bid them all home; he's gone, and we'll no further.
line 18216-->    The nobility are vex'd, whom we see have sided
line 18217-->    In his behalf.
line 18218-->  BRUTUS. Now we have shown our power,
line 18219-->    Let us seem humbler after it is done
line 18220-->    Than when it was a-doing.
line 18221-->  SICINIUS. Bid them home.
line 18222-->    Say their great enemy is gone, and they
line 18223-->    Stand in their ancient strength.
line 18224-->  BRUTUS. Dismiss them home.                         Exit AEDILE
line 18225-->    Here comes his mother.
line 18226-->
line 18227-->                   Enter VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA, and MENENIUS
line 18228-->
line 18229-->  SICINIUS. Let's not meet her.
line 18230-->  BRUTUS. Why?  
line 18231-->  SICINIUS. They say she's mad.
line 18232-->  BRUTUS. They have ta'en note of us; keep on your way.
line 18233-->  VOLUMNIA. O, Y'are well met; th' hoarded plague o' th' gods
line 18234-->    Requite your love!
line 18235-->  MENENIUS. Peace, peace, be not so loud.
line 18236-->  VOLUMNIA. If that I could for weeping, you should hear-
line 18237-->    Nay, and you shall hear some.  [To BRUTUS] Will you be gone?
line 18238-->  VIRGILIA.  [To SICINIUS]  You shall stay too. I would I had the
line 18239-->      power
line 18240-->    To say so to my husband.
line 18241-->  SICINIUS. Are you mankind?
line 18242-->  VOLUMNIA. Ay, fool; is that a shame? Note but this, fool:
line 18243-->    Was not a man my father? Hadst thou foxship
line 18244-->    To banish him that struck more blows for Rome
line 18245-->    Than thou hast spoken words?
line 18246-->  SICINIUS. O blessed heavens!
line 18247-->  VOLUMNIA. Moe noble blows than ever thou wise words;
line 18248-->    And for Rome's good. I'll tell thee what- yet go!
line 18249-->    Nay, but thou shalt stay too. I would my son
line 18250-->    Were in Arabia, and thy tribe before him,  
line 18251-->    His good sword in his hand.
line 18252-->  SICINIUS. What then?
line 18253-->  VIRGILIA. What then!
line 18254-->    He'd make an end of thy posterity.
line 18255-->  VOLUMNIA. Bastards and all.
line 18256-->    Good man, the wounds that he does bear for Rome!
line 18257-->  MENENIUS. Come, come, peace.
line 18258-->  SICINIUS. I would he had continued to his country
line 18259-->    As he began, and not unknit himself
line 18260-->    The noble knot he made.
line 18261-->  BRUTUS. I would he had.
line 18262-->  VOLUMNIA. 'I would he had!' 'Twas you incens'd the rabble-
line 18263-->    Cats that can judge as fitly of his worth
line 18264-->    As I can of those mysteries which heaven
line 18265-->    Will not have earth to know.
line 18266-->  BRUTUS. Pray, let's go.
line 18267-->  VOLUMNIA. Now, pray, sir, get you gone;
line 18268-->    You have done a brave deed. Ere you go, hear this:
line 18269-->    As far as doth the Capitol exceed
line 18270-->    The meanest house in Rome, so far my son-  
line 18271-->    This lady's husband here, this, do you see?-
line 18272-->    Whom you have banish'd does exceed you an.
line 18273-->  BRUTUS. Well, well, we'll leave you.
line 18274-->  SICINIUS. Why stay we to be baited
line 18275-->    With one that wants her wits?                Exeunt TRIBUNES
line 18276-->  VOLUMNIA. Take my prayers with you.
line 18277-->    I would the gods had nothing else to do
line 18278-->    But to confirm my curses. Could I meet 'em
line 18279-->    But once a day, it would unclog my heart
line 18280-->    Of what lies heavy to't.
line 18281-->  MENENIUS. You have told them home,
line 18282-->    And, by my troth, you have cause. You'll sup with me?
line 18283-->  VOLUMNIA. Anger's my meat; I sup upon myself,
line 18284-->    And so shall starve with feeding. Come, let's go.
line 18285-->    Leave this faint puling and lament as I do,
line 18286-->    In anger, Juno-like. Come, come, come.
line 18287-->                                    Exeunt VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA
line 18288-->  MENENIUS. Fie, fie, fie!                                  Exit
line 18289-->
line 18290-->
line 18291-->
line 18292-->
line 18293-->SCENE III.
line 18294-->A highway between Rome and Antium
line 18295-->
line 18296-->Enter a ROMAN and a VOLSCE, meeting
line 18297-->
line 18298-->  ROMAN. I know you well, sir, and you know me; your name, I think,
line 18299-->    is Adrian.
line 18300-->  VOLSCE. It is so, sir. Truly, I have forgot you.
line 18301-->  ROMAN. I am a Roman; and my services are, as you are, against 'em.
line 18302-->    Know you me yet?
line 18303-->  VOLSCE. Nicanor? No!
line 18304-->  ROMAN. The same, sir.
line 18305-->  VOLSCE. YOU had more beard when I last saw you, but your favour is
line 18306-->    well appear'd by your tongue. What's the news in Rome? I have a
line 18307-->    note from the Volscian state, to find you out there. You have
line 18308-->    well saved me a day's journey.
line 18309-->  ROMAN. There hath been in Rome strange insurrections: the people
line 18310-->    against the senators, patricians, and nobles.
line 18311-->  VOLSCE. Hath been! Is it ended, then? Our state thinks not so; they
line 18312-->    are in a most warlike preparation, and hope to come upon them in
line 18313-->    the heat of their division.
line 18314-->  ROMAN. The main blaze of it is past, but a small thing would make  
line 18315-->    it flame again; for the nobles receive so to heart the banishment
line 18316-->    of that worthy Coriolanus that they are in a ripe aptness to take
line 18317-->    all power from the people, and to pluck from them their tribunes
line 18318-->    for ever. This lies glowing, I can tell you, and is almost mature
line 18319-->    for the violent breaking out.
line 18320-->  VOLSCE. Coriolanus banish'd!
line 18321-->  ROMAN. Banish'd, sir.
line 18322-->  VOLSCE. You will be welcome with this intelligence, Nicanor.
line 18323-->  ROMAN. The day serves well for them now. I have heard it said the
line 18324-->    fittest time to corrupt a man's wife is when she's fall'n out
line 18325-->    with her husband. Your noble Tullus Aufidius will appear well in
line 18326-->    these wars, his great opposer, Coriolanus, being now in no
line 18327-->    request of his country.
line 18328-->  VOLSCE. He cannot choose. I am most fortunate thus accidentally to
line 18329-->    encounter you; you have ended my business, and I will merrily
line 18330-->    accompany you home.
line 18331-->  ROMAN. I shall between this and supper tell you most strange things
line 18332-->    from Rome, all tending to the good of their adversaries. Have you
line 18333-->    an army ready, say you?
line 18334-->  VOLSCE. A most royal one: the centurions and their charges,  
line 18335-->    distinctly billeted, already in th' entertainment, and to be on
line 18336-->    foot at an hour's warning.
line 18337-->  ROMAN. I am joyful to hear of their readiness, and am the man, I
line 18338-->    think, that shall set them in present action. So, sir, heartily
line 18339-->    well met, and most glad of your company.
line 18340-->  VOLSCE. You take my part from me, sir. I have the most cause to be
line 18341-->    glad of yours.
line 18342-->  ROMAN. Well, let us go together.
line 18343-->
line 18344-->
line 18345-->
line 18346-->
line 18347-->SCENE IV.
line 18348-->Antium. Before AUFIDIUS' house
line 18349-->
line 18350-->Enter CORIOLANUS, in mean apparel, disguis'd and muffled
line 18351-->
line 18352-->  CORIOLANUS. A goodly city is this Antium. City,
line 18353-->    'Tis I that made thy widows: many an heir
line 18354-->    Of these fair edifices fore my wars
line 18355-->    Have I heard groan and drop. Then know me not.
line 18356-->    Lest that thy wives with spits and boys with stones,
line 18357-->    In puny battle slay me.
line 18358-->
line 18359-->                           Enter A CITIZEN
line 18360-->
line 18361-->    Save you, sir.
line 18362-->  CITIZEN. And you.
line 18363-->  CORIOLANUS. Direct me, if it be your will,
line 18364-->    Where great Aufidius lies. Is he in Antium?
line 18365-->  CITIZEN. He is, and feasts the nobles of the state
line 18366-->    At his house this night.
line 18367-->  CORIOLANUS. Which is his house, beseech you?
line 18368-->  CITIZEN. This here before you.  
line 18369-->  CORIOLANUS. Thank you, sir; farewell.             Exit CITIZEN
line 18370-->    O world, thy slippery turns! Friends now fast sworn,
line 18371-->    Whose double bosoms seems to wear one heart,
line 18372-->    Whose hours, whose bed, whose meal and exercise
line 18373-->    Are still together, who twin, as 'twere, in love,
line 18374-->    Unseparable, shall within this hour,
line 18375-->    On a dissension of a doit, break out
line 18376-->    To bitterest enmity; so fellest foes,
line 18377-->    Whose passions and whose plots have broke their sleep
line 18378-->    To take the one the other, by some chance,
line 18379-->    Some trick not worth an egg, shall grow dear friends
line 18380-->    And interjoin their issues. So with me:
line 18381-->    My birthplace hate I, and my love's upon
line 18382-->    This enemy town. I'll enter. If he slay me,
line 18383-->    He does fair justice: if he give me way,
line 18384-->    I'll do his country service.
line 18385-->
line 18386-->
line 18387-->
line 18388-->
line 18389-->SCENE V.
line 18390-->Antium. AUFIDIUS' house
line 18391-->
line 18392-->Music plays. Enter A SERVINGMAN
line 18393-->
line 18394-->  FIRST SERVANT. Wine, wine, wine! What service is here! I think our
line 18395-->    fellows are asleep.                                     Exit
line 18396-->
line 18397-->                     Enter another SERVINGMAN
line 18398-->
line 18399-->  SECOND SERVANT.Where's Cotus? My master calls for him.
line 18400-->    Cotus!                                                  Exit
line 18401-->
line 18402-->                       Enter CORIOLANUS
line 18403-->
line 18404-->  CORIOLANUS. A goodly house. The feast smells well, but I
line 18405-->    Appear not like a guest.
line 18406-->
line 18407-->                 Re-enter the first SERVINGMAN
line 18408-->
line 18409-->  FIRST SERVANT. What would you have, friend?
line 18410-->    Whence are you? Here's no place for you: pray go to the door.  
line 18411--> Exit
line 18412-->  CORIOLANUS. I have deserv'd no better entertainment
line 18413-->    In being Coriolanus.
line 18414-->
line 18415-->                   Re-enter second SERVINGMAN
line 18416-->
line 18417-->  SECOND SERVANT. Whence are you, sir? Has the porter his eyes in his
line 18418-->    head that he gives entrance to such companions? Pray get you out.
line 18419-->  CORIOLANUS. Away!
line 18420-->  SECOND SERVANT. Away? Get you away.
line 18421-->  CORIOLANUS. Now th' art troublesome.
line 18422-->  SECOND SERVANT. Are you so brave? I'll have you talk'd with anon.
line 18423-->
line 18424-->          Enter a third SERVINGMAN. The first meets him
line 18425-->
line 18426-->  THIRD SERVANT. What fellow's this?
line 18427-->  FIRST SERVANT. A strange one as ever I look'd on. I cannot get him
line 18428-->    out o' th' house. Prithee call my master to him.
line 18429-->  THIRD SERVANT. What have you to do here, fellow? Pray you avoid the
line 18430-->    house.  
line 18431-->  CORIOLANUS. Let me but stand- I will not hurt your hearth.
line 18432-->  THIRD SERVANT. What are you?
line 18433-->  CORIOLANUS. A gentleman.
line 18434-->  THIRD SERVANT. A marv'llous poor one.
line 18435-->  CORIOLANUS. True, so I am.
line 18436-->  THIRD SERVANT. Pray you, poor gentleman, take up some other
line 18437-->    station; here's no place for you. Pray you avoid. Come.
line 18438-->  CORIOLANUS. Follow your function, go and batten on cold bits.
line 18439-->                                      [Pushes him away from him]
line 18440-->  THIRD SERVANT. What, you will not? Prithee tell my master what a
line 18441-->    strange guest he has here.
line 18442-->  SECOND SERVANT. And I shall.                              Exit
line 18443-->  THIRD SERVANT. Where dwell'st thou?
line 18444-->  CORIOLANUS. Under the canopy.
line 18445-->  THIRD SERVANT. Under the canopy?
line 18446-->  CORIOLANUS. Ay.
line 18447-->  THIRD SERVANT. Where's that?
line 18448-->  CORIOLANUS. I' th' city of kites and crows.
line 18449-->  THIRD SERVANT. I' th' city of kites and crows!
line 18450-->    What an ass it is! Then thou dwell'st with daws too?  
line 18451-->  CORIOLANUS. No, I serve not thy master.
line 18452-->  THIRD SERVANT. How, sir! Do you meddle with my master?
line 18453-->  CORIOLANUS. Ay; 'tis an honester service than to meddle with thy
line 18454-->    mistress. Thou prat'st and prat'st; serve with thy trencher;
line 18455-->    hence!                                      [Beats him away]
line 18456-->
line 18457-->             Enter AUFIDIUS with the second SERVINGMAN
line 18458-->
line 18459-->  AUFIDIUS. Where is this fellow?
line 18460-->  SECOND SERVANT. Here, sir; I'd have beaten him like a dog, but for
line 18461-->    disturbing the lords within.
line 18462-->  AUFIDIUS. Whence com'st thou? What wouldst thou? Thy name?
line 18463-->    Why speak'st not? Speak, man. What's thy name?
line 18464-->  CORIOLANUS.  [Unmuffling]  If, Tullus,
line 18465-->    Not yet thou know'st me, and, seeing me, dost not
line 18466-->    Think me for the man I am, necessity
line 18467-->    Commands me name myself.
line 18468-->  AUFIDIUS. What is thy name?
line 18469-->  CORIOLANUS. A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears,
line 18470-->    And harsh in sound to thine.  
line 18471-->  AUFIDIUS. Say, what's thy name?
line 18472-->    Thou has a grim appearance, and thy face
line 18473-->    Bears a command in't; though thy tackle's torn,
line 18474-->    Thou show'st a noble vessel. What's thy name?
line 18475-->  CORIOLANUS. Prepare thy brow to frown- know'st thou me yet?
line 18476-->  AUFIDIUS. I know thee not. Thy name?
line 18477-->  CORIOLANUS. My name is Caius Marcius, who hath done
line 18478-->    To thee particularly, and to all the Volsces,
line 18479-->    Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness may
line 18480-->    My surname, Coriolanus. The painful service,
line 18481-->    The extreme dangers, and the drops of blood
line 18482-->    Shed for my thankless country, are requited
line 18483-->    But with that surname- a good memory
line 18484-->    And witness of the malice and displeasure
line 18485-->    Which thou shouldst bear me. Only that name remains;
line 18486-->    The cruelty and envy of the people,
line 18487-->    Permitted by our dastard nobles, who
line 18488-->    Have all forsook me, hath devour'd the rest,
line 18489-->    An suffer'd me by th' voice of slaves to be
line 18490-->    Whoop'd out of Rome. Now this extremity  
line 18491-->    Hath brought me to thy hearth; not out of hope,
line 18492-->    Mistake me not, to save my life; for if
line 18493-->    I had fear'd death, of all the men i' th' world
line 18494-->    I would have 'voided thee; but in mere spite,
line 18495-->    To be full quit of those my banishers,
line 18496-->    Stand I before thee here. Then if thou hast
line 18497-->    A heart of wreak in thee, that wilt revenge
line 18498-->    Thine own particular wrongs and stop those maims
line 18499-->    Of shame seen through thy country, speed thee straight
line 18500-->    And make my misery serve thy turn. So use it
line 18501-->    That my revengeful services may prove
line 18502-->    As benefits to thee; for I will fight
line 18503-->    Against my cank'red country with the spleen
line 18504-->    Of all the under fiends. But if so be
line 18505-->    Thou dar'st not this, and that to prove more fortunes
line 18506-->    Th'art tir'd, then, in a word, I also am
line 18507-->    Longer to live most weary, and present
line 18508-->    My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice;
line 18509-->    Which not to cut would show thee but a fool,
line 18510-->    Since I have ever followed thee with hate,  
line 18511-->    Drawn tuns of blood out of thy country's breast,
line 18512-->    And cannot live but to thy shame, unless
line 18513-->    It be to do thee service.
line 18514-->  AUFIDIUS. O Marcius, Marcius!
line 18515-->    Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart
line 18516-->    A root of ancient envy. If Jupiter
line 18517-->    Should from yond cloud speak divine things,
line 18518-->    And say ''Tis true,' I'd not believe them more
line 18519-->    Than thee, all noble Marcius. Let me twine
line 18520-->    Mine arms about that body, where against
line 18521-->    My grained ash an hundred times hath broke
line 18522-->    And scarr'd the moon with splinters; here I clip
line 18523-->    The anvil of my sword, and do contest
line 18524-->    As hotly and as nobly with thy love
line 18525-->    As ever in ambitious strength I did
line 18526-->    Contend against thy valour. Know thou first,
line 18527-->    I lov'd the maid I married; never man
line 18528-->    Sigh'd truer breath; but that I see thee here,
line 18529-->    Thou noble thing, more dances my rapt heart
line 18530-->    Than when I first my wedded mistress saw  
line 18531-->    Bestride my threshold. Why, thou Mars, I tell the
line 18532-->    We have a power on foot, and I had purpose
line 18533-->    Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn,
line 18534-->    Or lose mine arm for't. Thou hast beat me out
line 18535-->    Twelve several times, and I have nightly since
line 18536-->    Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me-
line 18537-->    We have been down together in my sleep,
line 18538-->    Unbuckling helms, fisting each other's throat-
line 18539-->    And wak'd half dead with nothing. Worthy Marcius,
line 18540-->    Had we no other quarrel else to Rome but that
line 18541-->    Thou art thence banish'd, we would muster all
line 18542-->    From twelve to seventy, and, pouring war
line 18543-->    Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome,
line 18544-->    Like a bold flood o'erbeat. O, come, go in,
line 18545-->    And take our friendly senators by th' hands,
line 18546-->    Who now are here, taking their leaves of me
line 18547-->    Who am prepar'd against your territories,
line 18548-->    Though not for Rome itself.
line 18549-->  CORIOLANUS. You bless me, gods!
line 18550-->  AUFIDIUS. Therefore, most. absolute sir, if thou wilt have  
line 18551-->    The leading of thine own revenges, take
line 18552-->    Th' one half of my commission, and set down-
line 18553-->    As best thou art experienc'd, since thou know'st
line 18554-->    Thy country's strength and weakness- thine own ways,
line 18555-->    Whether to knock against the gates of Rome,
line 18556-->    Or rudely visit them in parts remote
line 18557-->    To fright them ere destroy. But come in;
line 18558-->    Let me commend thee first to those that shall
line 18559-->    Say yea to thy desires. A thousand welcomes!
line 18560-->    And more a friend than e'er an enemy;
line 18561-->    Yet, Marcius, that was much. Your hand; most welcome!
line 18562-->                                  Exeunt CORIOLANUS and AUFIDIUS
line 18563-->
line 18564-->                    The two SERVINGMEN come forward
line 18565-->
line 18566-->  FIRST SERVANT. Here's a strange alteration!
line 18567-->  SECOND SERVANT. By my hand, I had thought to have strucken him with
line 18568-->    a cudgel; and yet my mind gave me his clothes made a false report
line 18569-->    of him.
line 18570-->  FIRST SERVANT. What an arm he has! He turn'd me about with his  
line 18571-->    finger and his thumb, as one would set up a top.
line 18572-->  SECOND SERVANT. Nay, I knew by his face that there was something in
line 18573-->    him; he had, sir, a kind of face, methought- I cannot tell how to
line 18574-->    term it.
line 18575-->  FIRST SERVANT. He had so, looking as it were- Would I were hang'd,
line 18576-->    but I thought there was more in him than I could think.
line 18577-->  SECOND SERVANT. So did I, I'll be sworn. He is simply the rarest
line 18578-->    man i' th' world.
line 18579-->  FIRST SERVANT. I think he is; but a greater soldier than he you wot
line 18580-->    on.
line 18581-->  SECOND SERVANT. Who, my master?
line 18582-->  FIRST SERVANT. Nay, it's no matter for that.
line 18583-->  SECOND SERVANT. Worth six on him.
line 18584-->  FIRST SERVANT. Nay, not so neither; but I take him to be the
line 18585-->    greater soldier.
line 18586-->  SECOND SERVANT. Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that;
line 18587-->    for the defence of a town our general is excellent.
line 18588-->  FIRST SERVANT. Ay, and for an assault too.
line 18589-->
line 18590-->                       Re-enter the third SERVINGMAN  
line 18591-->
line 18592-->  THIRD SERVANT. O slaves, I can tell you news- news, you rascals!
line 18593-->  BOTH. What, what, what? Let's partake.
line 18594-->  THIRD SERVANT. I would not be a Roman, of all nations;
line 18595-->    I had as lief be a condemn'd man.
line 18596-->  BOTH. Wherefore? wherefore?
line 18597-->  THIRD SERVANT. Why, here's he that was wont to thwack our general-
line 18598-->    Caius Marcius.
line 18599-->  FIRST SERVANT. Why do you say 'thwack our general'?
line 18600-->  THIRD SERVANT. I do not say 'thwack our general,' but he was always
line 18601-->    good enough for him.
line 18602-->  SECOND SERVANT. Come, we are fellows and friends. He was ever too
line 18603-->    hard for him, I have heard him say so himself.
line 18604-->  FIRST SERVANT. He was too hard for him directly, to say the troth
line 18605-->    on't; before Corioli he scotch'd him and notch'd him like a
line 18606-->    carbonado.
line 18607-->  SECOND SERVANT. An he had been cannibally given, he might have
line 18608-->    broil'd and eaten him too.
line 18609-->  FIRST SERVANT. But more of thy news!
line 18610-->  THIRD SERVANT. Why, he is so made on here within as if he were son  
line 18611-->    and heir to Mars; set at upper end o' th' table; no question
line 18612-->    asked him by any of the senators but they stand bald before him.
line 18613-->    Our general himself makes a mistress of him, sanctifies himself
line 18614-->    with's hand, and turns up the white o' th' eye to his discourse.
line 18615-->    But the bottom of the news is, our general is cut i' th' middle
line 18616-->    and but one half of what he was yesterday, for the other has half
line 18617-->    by the entreaty and grant of the whole table. He'll go, he says,
line 18618-->    and sowl the porter of Rome gates by th' ears; he will mow all
line 18619-->    down before him, and leave his passage poll'd.
line 18620-->  SECOND SERVANT. And he's as like to do't as any man I can imagine.
line 18621-->  THIRD SERVANT. Do't! He will do't; for look you, sir, he has as
line 18622-->    many friends as enemies; which friends, sir, as it were, durst
line 18623-->    not- look you, sir- show themselves, as we term it, his friends,
line 18624-->    whilst he's in directitude.
line 18625-->  FIRST SERVANT. Directitude? What's that?
line 18626-->  THIRD SERVANT. But when they shall see, sir, his crest up again and
line 18627-->    the man in blood, they will out of their burrows, like conies
line 18628-->    after rain, and revel an with him.
line 18629-->  FIRST SERVANT. But when goes this forward?
line 18630-->  THIRD SERVANT. To-morrow, to-day, presently. You shall have the  
line 18631-->    drum struck up this afternoon; 'tis as it were parcel of their
line 18632-->    feast, and to be executed ere they wipe their lips.
line 18633-->  SECOND SERVANT. Why, then we shall have a stirring world again.
line 18634-->    This peace is nothing but to rust iron, increase tailors, and
line 18635-->    breed ballad-makers.
line 18636-->  FIRST SERVANT. Let me have war, say I; it exceeds peace as far as
line 18637-->    day does night; it's spritely, waking, audible, and full of vent.
line 18638-->    Peace is a very apoplexy, lethargy; mull'd, deaf, sleepy,
line 18639-->    insensible; a getter of more bastard children than war's a
line 18640-->    destroyer of men.
line 18641-->  SECOND SERVANT. 'Tis so; and as war in some sort may be said to be
line 18642-->    a ravisher, so it cannot be denied but peace is a great maker of
line 18643-->    cuckolds.
line 18644-->  FIRST SERVANT. Ay, and it makes men hate one another.
line 18645-->  THIRD SERVANT. Reason: because they then less need one another. The
line 18646-->    wars for my money. I hope to see Romans as cheap as Volscians.
line 18647-->    They are rising, they are rising.
line 18648-->  BOTH. In, in, in, in!                                   Exeunt
line 18649-->
line 18650-->
line 18651-->
line 18652-->
line 18653-->SCENE VI.
line 18654-->Rome. A public place
line 18655-->
line 18656-->Enter the two Tribunes, SICINIUS and BRUTUS
line 18657-->
line 18658-->  SICINIUS. We hear not of him, neither need we fear him.
line 18659-->    His remedies are tame. The present peace
line 18660-->    And quietness of the people, which before
line 18661-->    Were in wild hurry, here do make his friends
line 18662-->    Blush that the world goes well; who rather had,
line 18663-->    Though they themselves did suffer by't, behold
line 18664-->    Dissentious numbers pest'ring streets than see
line 18665-->    Our tradesmen singing in their shops, and going
line 18666-->    About their functions friendly.
line 18667-->
line 18668-->                          Enter MENENIUS
line 18669-->
line 18670-->  BRUTUS. We stood to't in good time. Is this Menenius?
line 18671-->  SICINIUS. 'Tis he, 'tis he. O, he is grown most kind
line 18672-->    Of late. Hail, sir!
line 18673-->  MENENIUS. Hail to you both!
line 18674-->  SICINIUS. Your Coriolanus is not much miss'd  
line 18675-->    But with his friends. The commonwealth doth stand,
line 18676-->    And so would do, were he more angry at it.
line 18677-->  MENENIUS. All's well, and might have been much better
line 18678-->    He could have temporiz'd.
line 18679-->  SICINIUS. Where is he, hear you?
line 18680-->  MENENIUS. Nay, I hear nothing; his mother and his wife
line 18681-->    Hear nothing from him.
line 18682-->
line 18683-->                     Enter three or four citizens
line 18684-->
line 18685-->  CITIZENS. The gods preserve you both!
line 18686-->  SICINIUS. God-den, our neighbours.
line 18687-->  BRUTUS. God-den to you all, god-den to you an.
line 18688-->  FIRST CITIZEN. Ourselves, our wives, and children, on our knees
line 18689-->    Are bound to pray for you both.
line 18690-->  SICINIUS. Live and thrive!
line 18691-->  BRUTUS. Farewell, kind neighbours; we wish'd Coriolanus
line 18692-->    Had lov'd you as we did.
line 18693-->  CITIZENS. Now the gods keep you!
line 18694-->  BOTH TRIBUNES. Farewell, farewell.             Exeunt citizens  
line 18695-->  SICINIUS. This is a happier and more comely time
line 18696-->    Than when these fellows ran about the streets
line 18697-->    Crying confusion.
line 18698-->  BRUTUS. Caius Marcius was
line 18699-->    A worthy officer i' the war, but insolent,
line 18700-->    O'ercome with pride, ambitious past all thinking,
line 18701-->    Self-loving-
line 18702-->  SICINIUS. And affecting one sole throne,
line 18703-->    Without assistance.
line 18704-->  MENENIUS. I think not so.
line 18705-->  SICINIUS. We should by this, to all our lamentation,
line 18706-->    If he had gone forth consul, found it so.
line 18707-->  BRUTUS. The gods have well prevented it, and Rome
line 18708-->    Sits safe and still without him.
line 18709-->
line 18710-->                             Enter an AEDILE
line 18711-->
line 18712-->  AEDILE. Worthy tribunes,
line 18713-->    There is a slave, whom we have put in prison,
line 18714-->    Reports the Volsces with several powers  
line 18715-->    Are ent'red in the Roman territories,
line 18716-->    And with the deepest malice of the war
line 18717-->    Destroy what lies before 'em.
line 18718-->  MENENIUS. 'Tis Aufidius,
line 18719-->    Who, hearing of our Marcius' banishment,
line 18720-->    Thrusts forth his horns again into the world,
line 18721-->    Which were inshell'd when Marcius stood for Rome,
line 18722-->    And durst not once peep out.
line 18723-->  SICINIUS. Come, what talk you of Marcius?
line 18724-->  BRUTUS. Go see this rumourer whipp'd. It cannot be
line 18725-->    The Volsces dare break with us.
line 18726-->  MENENIUS. Cannot be!
line 18727-->    We have record that very well it can;
line 18728-->    And three examples of the like hath been
line 18729-->    Within my age. But reason with the fellow
line 18730-->    Before you punish him, where he heard this,
line 18731-->    Lest you shall chance to whip your information
line 18732-->    And beat the messenger who bids beware
line 18733-->    Of what is to be dreaded.
line 18734-->  SICINIUS. Tell not me.  
line 18735-->    I know this cannot be.
line 18736-->  BRUTUS. Not Possible.
line 18737-->
line 18738-->                           Enter A MESSENGER
line 18739-->
line 18740-->  MESSENGER. The nobles in great earnestness are going
line 18741-->    All to the Senate House; some news is come
line 18742-->    That turns their countenances.
line 18743-->  SICINIUS. 'Tis this slave-
line 18744-->    Go whip him fore the people's eyes- his raising,
line 18745-->    Nothing but his report.
line 18746-->  MESSENGER. Yes, worthy sir,
line 18747-->    The slave's report is seconded, and more,
line 18748-->    More fearful, is deliver'd.
line 18749-->  SICINIUS. What more fearful?
line 18750-->  MESSENGER. It is spoke freely out of many mouths-
line 18751-->    How probable I do not know- that Marcius,
line 18752-->    Join'd with Aufidius, leads a power 'gainst Rome,
line 18753-->    And vows revenge as spacious as between
line 18754-->    The young'st and oldest thing.  
line 18755-->  SICINIUS. This is most likely!
line 18756-->  BRUTUS. Rais'd only that the weaker sort may wish
line 18757-->    Good Marcius home again.
line 18758-->  SICINIUS. The very trick on 't.
line 18759-->  MENENIUS. This is unlikely.
line 18760-->    He and Aufidius can no more atone
line 18761-->    Than violent'st contrariety.
line 18762-->
line 18763-->                      Enter a second MESSENGER
line 18764-->
line 18765-->  SECOND MESSENGER. You are sent for to the Senate.
line 18766-->    A fearful army, led by Caius Marcius
line 18767-->    Associated with Aufidius, rages
line 18768-->    Upon our territories, and have already
line 18769-->    O'erborne their way, consum'd with fire and took
line 18770-->    What lay before them.
line 18771-->
line 18772-->                            Enter COMINIUS
line 18773-->
line 18774-->  COMINIUS. O, you have made good work!  
line 18775-->  MENENIUS. What news? what news?
line 18776-->  COMINIUS. You have holp to ravish your own daughters and
line 18777-->    To melt the city leads upon your pates,
line 18778-->    To see your wives dishonour'd to your noses-
line 18779-->  MENENIUS. What's the news? What's the news?
line 18780-->  COMINIUS. Your temples burned in their cement, and
line 18781-->    Your franchises, whereon you stood, confin'd
line 18782-->    Into an auger's bore.
line 18783-->  MENENIUS. Pray now, your news?
line 18784-->    You have made fair work, I fear me. Pray, your news.
line 18785-->    If Marcius should be join'd wi' th' Volscians-
line 18786-->  COMINIUS. If!
line 18787-->    He is their god; he leads them like a thing
line 18788-->    Made by some other deity than Nature,
line 18789-->    That shapes man better; and they follow him
line 18790-->    Against us brats with no less confidence
line 18791-->    Than boys pursuing summer butterflies,
line 18792-->    Or butchers killing flies.
line 18793-->  MENENIUS. You have made good work,
line 18794-->    You and your apron men; you that stood so much  
line 18795-->    Upon the voice of occupation and
line 18796-->    The breath of garlic-eaters!
line 18797-->  COMINIUS. He'll shake
line 18798-->    Your Rome about your ears.
line 18799-->  MENENIUS. As Hercules
line 18800-->    Did shake down mellow fruit. You have made fair work!
line 18801-->  BRUTUS. But is this true, sir?
line 18802-->  COMINIUS. Ay; and you'll look pale
line 18803-->    Before you find it other. All the regions
line 18804-->    Do smilingly revolt, and who resists
line 18805-->    Are mock'd for valiant ignorance,
line 18806-->    And perish constant fools. Who is't can blame him?
line 18807-->    Your enemies and his find something in him.
line 18808-->  MENENIUS. We are all undone unless
line 18809-->    The noble man have mercy.
line 18810-->  COMINIUS. Who shall ask it?
line 18811-->    The tribunes cannot do't for shame; the people
line 18812-->    Deserve such pity of him as the wolf
line 18813-->    Does of the shepherds; for his best friends, if they
line 18814-->    Should say 'Be good to Rome'- they charg'd him even  
line 18815-->    As those should do that had deserv'd his hate,
line 18816-->    And therein show'd fike enemies.
line 18817-->  MENENIUS. 'Tis true;
line 18818-->    If he were putting to my house the brand
line 18819-->    That should consume it, I have not the face
line 18820-->    To say 'Beseech you, cease.' You have made fair hands,
line 18821-->    You and your crafts! You have crafted fair!
line 18822-->  COMINIUS. You have brought
line 18823-->    A trembling upon Rome, such as was never
line 18824-->    S' incapable of help.
line 18825-->  BOTH TRIBUNES. Say not we brought it.
line 18826-->  MENENIUS. How! Was't we? We lov'd him, but, like beasts
line 18827-->    And cowardly nobles, gave way unto your clusters,
line 18828-->    Who did hoot him out o' th' city.
line 18829-->  COMINIUS. But I fear
line 18830-->    They'll roar him in again. Tullus Aufidius,
line 18831-->    The second name of men, obeys his points
line 18832-->    As if he were his officer. Desperation
line 18833-->    Is all the policy, strength, and defence,
line 18834-->    That Rome can make against them.  
line 18835-->
line 18836-->                       Enter a troop of citizens
line 18837-->
line 18838-->  MENENIUS. Here comes the clusters.
line 18839-->    And is Aufidius with him? You are they
line 18840-->    That made the air unwholesome when you cast
line 18841-->    Your stinking greasy caps in hooting at
line 18842-->    Coriolanus' exile. Now he's coming,
line 18843-->    And not a hair upon a soldier's head
line 18844-->    Which will not prove a whip; as many coxcombs
line 18845-->    As you threw caps up will he tumble down,
line 18846-->    And pay you for your voices. 'Tis no matter;
line 18847-->    If he could burn us all into one coal
line 18848-->    We have deserv'd it.
line 18849-->  PLEBEIANS. Faith, we hear fearful news.
line 18850-->  FIRST CITIZEN. For mine own part,
line 18851-->    When I said banish him, I said 'twas pity.
line 18852-->  SECOND CITIZEN. And so did I.
line 18853-->  THIRD CITIZEN. And so did I; and, to say the truth, so did very
line 18854-->    many of us. That we did, we did for the best; and though we  
line 18855-->    willingly consented to his banishment, yet it was against our
line 18856-->    will.
line 18857-->  COMINIUS. Y'are goodly things, you voices!
line 18858-->  MENENIUS. You have made
line 18859-->    Good work, you and your cry! Shall's to the Capitol?
line 18860-->  COMINIUS. O, ay, what else?
line 18861-->                                    Exeunt COMINIUS and MENENIUS
line 18862-->  SICINIUS. Go, masters, get you be not dismay'd;
line 18863-->    These are a side that would be glad to have
line 18864-->    This true which they so seem to fear. Go home,
line 18865-->    And show no sign of fear.
line 18866-->  FIRST CITIZEN. The gods be good to us! Come, masters, let's home. I
line 18867-->    ever said we were i' th' wrong when we banish'd him.
line 18868-->  SECOND CITIZEN. So did we all. But come, let's home.
line 18869-->                                                 Exeunt citizens
line 18870-->  BRUTUS. I do not like this news.
line 18871-->  SICINIUS. Nor I.
line 18872-->  BRUTUS. Let's to the Capitol. Would half my wealth
line 18873-->    Would buy this for a lie!
line 18874-->  SICINIUS. Pray let's go.                                Exeunt
line 18875-->
line 18876-->
line 18877-->
line 18878-->
line 18879-->SCENE VII.
line 18880-->A camp at a short distance from Rome
line 18881-->
line 18882-->Enter AUFIDIUS with his LIEUTENANT
line 18883-->
line 18884-->  AUFIDIUS. Do they still fly to th' Roman?
line 18885-->  LIEUTENANT. I do not know what witchcraft's in him, but
line 18886-->    Your soldiers use him as the grace fore meat,
line 18887-->    Their talk at table, and their thanks at end;
line 18888-->    And you are dark'ned in this action, sir,
line 18889-->    Even by your own.
line 18890-->  AUFIDIUS. I cannot help it now,
line 18891-->    Unless by using means I lame the foot
line 18892-->    Of our design. He bears himself more proudlier,
line 18893-->    Even to my person, than I thought he would
line 18894-->    When first I did embrace him; yet his nature
line 18895-->    In that's no changeling, and I must excuse
line 18896-->    What cannot be amended.
line 18897-->  LIEUTENANT. Yet I wish, sir-
line 18898-->    I mean, for your particular- you had not
line 18899-->    Join'd in commission with him, but either
line 18900-->    Had borne the action of yourself, or else  
line 18901-->    To him had left it solely.
line 18902-->  AUFIDIUS. I understand thee well; and be thou sure,
line 18903-->    When he shall come to his account, he knows not
line 18904-->    What I can urge against him. Although it seems,
line 18905-->    And so he thinks, and is no less apparent
line 18906-->    To th' vulgar eye, that he bears all things fairly
line 18907-->    And shows good husbandry for the Volscian state,
line 18908-->    Fights dragon-like, and does achieve as soon
line 18909-->    As draw his sword; yet he hath left undone
line 18910-->    That which shall break his neck or hazard mine
line 18911-->    Whene'er we come to our account.
line 18912-->  LIEUTENANT. Sir, I beseech you, think you he'll carry Rome?
line 18913-->  AUFIDIUS. All places yield to him ere he sits down,
line 18914-->    And the nobility of Rome are his;
line 18915-->    The senators and patricians love him too.
line 18916-->    The tribunes are no soldiers, and their people
line 18917-->    Will be as rash in the repeal as hasty
line 18918-->    To expel him thence. I think he'll be to Rome
line 18919-->    As is the osprey to the fish, who takes it
line 18920-->    By sovereignty of nature. First he was  
line 18921-->    A noble servant to them, but he could not
line 18922-->    Carry his honours even. Whether 'twas pride,
line 18923-->    Which out of daily fortune ever taints
line 18924-->    The happy man; whether defect of judgment,
line 18925-->    To fail in the disposing of those chances
line 18926-->    Which he was lord of; or whether nature,
line 18927-->    Not to be other than one thing, not moving
line 18928-->    From th' casque to th' cushion, but commanding peace
line 18929-->    Even with the same austerity and garb
line 18930-->    As he controll'd the war; but one of these-
line 18931-->    As he hath spices of them all- not all,
line 18932-->    For I dare so far free him- made him fear'd,
line 18933-->    So hated, and so banish'd. But he has a merit
line 18934-->    To choke it in the utt'rance. So our virtues
line 18935-->    Lie in th' interpretation of the time;
line 18936-->    And power, unto itself most commendable,
line 18937-->    Hath not a tomb so evident as a chair
line 18938-->    T' extol what it hath done.
line 18939-->    One fire drives out one fire; one nail, one nail;
line 18940-->    Rights by rights falter, strengths by strengths do fail.  
line 18941-->    Come, let's away. When, Caius, Rome is thine,
line 18942-->    Thou art poor'st of all; then shortly art thou mine.
line 18943-->                                                          Exeunt
line 18944-->
line 18945-->
line 18946-->
