line 18958-->
line 18959-->ACT V. SCENE I.
line 18960-->Rome. A public place
line 18961-->
line 18962-->Enter MENENIUS, COMINIUS, SICINIUS and BRUTUS, the two Tribunes, with others
line 18963-->
line 18964-->  MENENIUS. No, I'll not go. You hear what he hath said
line 18965-->    Which was sometime his general, who lov'd him
line 18966-->    In a most dear particular. He call'd me father;
line 18967-->    But what o' that? Go, you that banish'd him:
line 18968-->    A mile before his tent fall down, and knee
line 18969-->    The way into his mercy. Nay, if he coy'd
line 18970-->    To hear Cominius speak, I'll keep at home.
line 18971-->  COMINIUS. He would not seem to know me.
line 18972-->  MENENIUS. Do you hear?
line 18973-->  COMINIUS. Yet one time he did call me by my name.
line 18974-->    I urg'd our old acquaintance, and the drops
line 18975-->    That we have bled together. 'Coriolanus'
line 18976-->    He would not answer to; forbid all names;
line 18977-->    He was a kind of nothing, titleless,
line 18978-->    Till he had forg'd himself a name i' th' fire
line 18979-->    Of burning Rome.  
line 18980-->  MENENIUS. Why, so! You have made good work.
line 18981-->    A pair of tribunes that have wrack'd for Rome
line 18982-->    To make coals cheap- a noble memory!
line 18983-->  COMINIUS. I minded him how royal 'twas to pardon
line 18984-->    When it was less expected; he replied,
line 18985-->    It was a bare petition of a state
line 18986-->    To one whom they had punish'd.
line 18987-->  MENENIUS. Very well.
line 18988-->    Could he say less?
line 18989-->  COMINIUS. I offer'd to awaken his regard
line 18990-->    For's private friends; his answer to me was,
line 18991-->    He could not stay to pick them in a pile
line 18992-->    Of noisome musty chaff. He said 'twas folly,
line 18993-->    For one poor grain or two, to leave unburnt
line 18994-->    And still to nose th' offence.
line 18995-->  MENENIUS. For one poor grain or two!
line 18996-->    I am one of those. His mother, wife, his child,
line 18997-->    And this brave fellow too- we are the grains:
line 18998-->    You are the musty chaff, and you are smelt
line 18999-->    Above the moon. We must be burnt for you.  
line 19000-->  SICINIUS. Nay, pray be patient; if you refuse your aid
line 19001-->    In this so never-needed help, yet do not
line 19002-->    Upbraid's with our distress. But sure, if you
line 19003-->    Would be your country's pleader, your good tongue,
line 19004-->    More than the instant army we can make,
line 19005-->    Might stop our countryman.
line 19006-->  MENENIUS. No; I'll not meddle.
line 19007-->  SICINIUS. Pray you go to him.
line 19008-->  MENENIUS. What should I do?
line 19009-->  BRUTUS. Only make trial what your love can do
line 19010-->    For Rome, towards Marcius.
line 19011-->  MENENIUS. Well, and say that Marcius
line 19012-->    Return me, as Cominius is return'd,
line 19013-->    Unheard- what then?
line 19014-->    But as a discontented friend, grief-shot
line 19015-->    With his unkindness? Say't be so?
line 19016-->  SICINIUS. Yet your good will
line 19017-->    Must have that thanks from Rome after the measure
line 19018-->    As you intended well.
line 19019-->  MENENIUS. I'll undertake't;  
line 19020-->    I think he'll hear me. Yet to bite his lip
line 19021-->    And hum at good Cominius much unhearts me.
line 19022-->    He was not taken well: he had not din'd;
line 19023-->    The veins unfill'd, our blood is cold, and then
line 19024-->    We pout upon the morning, are unapt
line 19025-->    To give or to forgive; but when we have stuff'd
line 19026-->    These pipes and these conveyances of our blood
line 19027-->    With wine and feeding, we have suppler souls
line 19028-->    Than in our priest-like fasts. Therefore I'll watch him
line 19029-->    Till he be dieted to my request,
line 19030-->    And then I'll set upon him.
line 19031-->  BRUTUS. You know the very road into his kindness
line 19032-->    And cannot lose your way.
line 19033-->  MENENIUS. Good faith, I'll prove him,
line 19034-->    Speed how it will. I shall ere long have knowledge
line 19035-->    Of my success.                                          Exit
line 19036-->  COMINIUS. He'll never hear him.
line 19037-->  SICINIUS. Not?
line 19038-->  COMINIUS. I tell you he does sit in gold, his eye
line 19039-->    Red as 'twould burn Rome, and his injury  
line 19040-->    The gaoler to his pity. I kneel'd before him;
line 19041-->    'Twas very faintly he said 'Rise'; dismiss'd me
line 19042-->    Thus with his speechless hand. What he would do,
line 19043-->    He sent in writing after me; what he would not,
line 19044-->    Bound with an oath to yield to his conditions;
line 19045-->    So that all hope is vain,
line 19046-->    Unless his noble mother and his wife,
line 19047-->    Who, as I hear, mean to solicit him
line 19048-->    For mercy to his country. Therefore let's hence,
line 19049-->    And with our fair entreaties haste them on.           Exeunt
line 19050-->
line 19051-->
line 19052-->
line 19053-->
line 19054-->SCENE II.
line 19055-->The Volscian camp before Rome
line 19056-->
line 19057-->Enter MENENIUS to the WATCH on guard
line 19058-->
line 19059-->  FIRST WATCH. Stay. Whence are you?
line 19060-->  SECOND WATCH. Stand, and go back.
line 19061-->  MENENIUS. You guard like men, 'tis well; but, by your leave,
line 19062-->    I am an officer of state and come
line 19063-->    To speak with Coriolanus.
line 19064-->  FIRST WATCH. From whence?
line 19065-->  MENENIUS. From Rome.
line 19066-->  FIRST WATCH. YOU may not pass; you must return. Our general
line 19067-->    Will no more hear from thence.
line 19068-->  SECOND WATCH. You'll see your Rome embrac'd with fire before
line 19069-->    You'll speak with Coriolanus.
line 19070-->  MENENIUS. Good my friends,
line 19071-->    If you have heard your general talk of Rome
line 19072-->    And of his friends there, it is lots to blanks
line 19073-->    My name hath touch'd your ears: it is Menenius.
line 19074-->  FIRST WATCH. Be it so; go back. The virtue of your name
line 19075-->    Is not here passable.  
line 19076-->  MENENIUS. I tell thee, fellow,
line 19077-->    Thy general is my lover. I have been
line 19078-->    The book of his good acts whence men have read
line 19079-->    His fame unparallel'd haply amplified;
line 19080-->    For I have ever verified my friends-
line 19081-->    Of whom he's chief- with all the size that verity
line 19082-->    Would without lapsing suffer. Nay, sometimes,
line 19083-->    Like to a bowl upon a subtle ground,
line 19084-->    I have tumbled past the throw, and in his praise
line 19085-->    Have almost stamp'd the leasing; therefore, fellow,
line 19086-->    I must have leave to pass.
line 19087-->  FIRST WATCH. Faith, sir, if you had told as many lies in his behalf
line 19088-->    as you have uttered words in your own, you should not pass here;
line 19089-->    no, though it were as virtuous to lie as to live chastely.
line 19090-->    Therefore go back.
line 19091-->  MENENIUS. Prithee, fellow, remember my name is Menenius, always
line 19092-->    factionary on the party of your general.
line 19093-->  SECOND WATCH. Howsoever you have been his liar, as you say you
line 19094-->    have, I am one that, telling true under him, must say you cannot
line 19095-->    pass. Therefore go back.  
line 19096-->  MENENIUS. Has he din'd, canst thou tell? For I would not speak with
line 19097-->    him till after dinner.
line 19098-->  FIRST WATCH. You are a Roman, are you?
line 19099-->  MENENIUS. I am as thy general is.
line 19100-->  FIRST WATCH. Then you should hate Rome, as he does. Can you, when
line 19101-->    you have push'd out your gates the very defender of them, and in
line 19102-->    a violent popular ignorance given your enemy your shield, think
line 19103-->    to front his revenges with the easy groans of old women, the
line 19104-->    virginal palms of your daughters, or with the palsied
line 19105-->    intercession of such a decay'd dotant as you seem to be? Can you
line 19106-->    think to blow out the intended fire your city is ready to flame
line 19107-->    in with such weak breath as this? No, you are deceiv'd; therefore
line 19108-->    back to Rome and prepare for your execution. You are condemn'd;
line 19109-->    our general has sworn you out of reprieve and pardon.
line 19110-->  MENENIUS. Sirrah, if thy captain knew I were here, he would use me
line 19111-->    with estimation.
line 19112-->  FIRST WATCH. Come, my captain knows you not.
line 19113-->  MENENIUS. I mean thy general.
line 19114-->  FIRST WATCH. My general cares not for you. Back, I say; go, lest I
line 19115-->    let forth your half pint of blood. Back- that's the utmost of  
line 19116-->    your having. Back.
line 19117-->  MENENIUS. Nay, but fellow, fellow-
line 19118-->
line 19119-->                      Enter CORIOLANUS with AUFIDIUS
line 19120-->
line 19121-->  CORIOLANUS. What's the matter?
line 19122-->  MENENIUS. Now, you companion, I'll say an errand for you; you shall
line 19123-->    know now that I am in estimation; you shall perceive that a Jack
line 19124-->    guardant cannot office me from my son Coriolanus. Guess but by my
line 19125-->    entertainment with him if thou stand'st not i' th' state of
line 19126-->    hanging, or of some death more long in spectatorship and crueller
line 19127-->    in suffering; behold now presently, and swoon for what's to come
line 19128-->    upon thee. The glorious gods sit in hourly synod about thy
line 19129-->    particular prosperity, and love thee no worse than thy old father
line 19130-->    Menenius does! O my son! my son! thou art preparing fire for us;
line 19131-->    look thee, here's water to quench it. I was hardly moved to come
line 19132-->    to thee; but being assured none but myself could move thee, I
line 19133-->    have been blown out of your gates with sighs, and conjure thee to
line 19134-->    pardon Rome and thy petitionary countrymen. The good gods assuage
line 19135-->    thy wrath, and turn the dregs of it upon this varlet here; this,  
line 19136-->    who, like a block, hath denied my access to thee.
line 19137-->  CORIOLANUS. Away!
line 19138-->  MENENIUS. How! away!
line 19139-->  CORIOLANUS. Wife, mother, child, I know not. My affairs
line 19140-->    Are servanted to others. Though I owe
line 19141-->    My revenge properly, my remission lies
line 19142-->    In Volscian breasts. That we have been familiar,
line 19143-->    Ingrate forgetfulness shall poison rather
line 19144-->    Than pity note how much. Therefore be gone.
line 19145-->    Mine ears against your suits are stronger than
line 19146-->    Your gates against my force. Yet, for I lov'd thee,
line 19147-->    Take this along; I writ it for thy sake     [Gives a letter]
line 19148-->    And would have sent it. Another word, Menenius,
line 19149-->    I will not hear thee speak. This man, Aufidius,
line 19150-->    Was my belov'd in Rome; yet thou behold'st.
line 19151-->  AUFIDIUS. You keep a constant temper.
line 19152-->                                  Exeunt CORIOLANUS and Aufidius
line 19153-->  FIRST WATCH. Now, sir, is your name Menenius?
line 19154-->  SECOND WATCH. 'Tis a spell, you see, of much power! You know the
line 19155-->    way home again.  
line 19156-->  FIRST WATCH. Do you hear how we are shent for keeping your
line 19157-->    greatness back?
line 19158-->  SECOND WATCH. What cause, do you think, I have to swoon?
line 19159-->  MENENIUS. I neither care for th' world nor your general; for such
line 19160-->    things as you, I can scarce think there's any, y'are so slight.
line 19161-->    He that hath a will to die by himself fears it not from another.
line 19162-->    Let your general do his worst. For you, be that you are, long;
line 19163-->    and your misery increase with your age! I say to you, as I was
line 19164-->    said to: Away!                                          Exit
line 19165-->  FIRST WATCH. A noble fellow, I warrant him.
line 19166-->  SECOND WATCH. The worthy fellow is our general; he's the rock, the
line 19167-->    oak not to be wind-shaken.                            Exeunt
line 19168-->
line 19169-->
line 19170-->
line 19171-->
line 19172-->SCENE III.
line 19173-->The tent of CORIOLANUS
line 19174-->
line 19175-->Enter CORIOLANUS, AUFIDIUS, and others
line 19176-->
line 19177-->  CORIOLANUS. We will before the walls of Rome to-morrow
line 19178-->    Set down our host. My partner in this action,
line 19179-->    You must report to th' Volscian lords how plainly
line 19180-->    I have borne this business.
line 19181-->  AUFIDIUS. Only their ends
line 19182-->    You have respected; stopp'd your ears against
line 19183-->    The general suit of Rome; never admitted
line 19184-->    A private whisper- no, not with such friends
line 19185-->    That thought them sure of you.
line 19186-->  CORIOLANUS. This last old man,
line 19187-->    Whom with crack'd heart I have sent to Rome,
line 19188-->    Lov'd me above the measure of a father;
line 19189-->    Nay, godded me indeed. Their latest refuge
line 19190-->    Was to send him; for whose old love I have-
line 19191-->    Though I show'd sourly to him- once more offer'd
line 19192-->    The first conditions, which they did refuse
line 19193-->    And cannot now accept. To grace him only,  
line 19194-->    That thought he could do more, a very little
line 19195-->    I have yielded to; fresh embassies and suits,
line 19196-->    Nor from the state nor private friends, hereafter
line 19197-->    Will I lend ear to.  [Shout within]  Ha! what shout is this?
line 19198-->    Shall I be tempted to infringe my vow
line 19199-->    In the same time 'tis made? I will not.
line 19200-->
line 19201-->       Enter, in mourning habits, VIRGILIA, VOLUMNIA, VALERIA,
line 19202-->                   YOUNG MARCIUS, with attendants
line 19203-->
line 19204-->    My wife comes foremost, then the honour'd mould
line 19205-->    Wherein this trunk was fram'd, and in her hand
line 19206-->    The grandchild to her blood. But out, affection!
line 19207-->    All bond and privilege of nature, break!
line 19208-->    Let it be virtuous to be obstinate.
line 19209-->    What is that curtsy worth? or those doves' eyes,
line 19210-->    Which can make gods forsworn? I melt, and am not
line 19211-->    Of stronger earth than others. My mother bows,
line 19212-->    As if Olympus to a molehill should
line 19213-->    In supplication nod; and my young boy  
line 19214-->    Hath an aspect of intercession which
line 19215-->    Great nature cries 'Deny not.' Let the Volsces
line 19216-->    Plough Rome and harrow Italy; I'll never
line 19217-->    Be such a gosling to obey instinct, but stand
line 19218-->    As if a man were author of himself
line 19219-->    And knew no other kin.
line 19220-->  VIRGILIA. My lord and husband!
line 19221-->  CORIOLANUS. These eyes are not the same I wore in Rome.
line 19222-->  VIRGILIA. The sorrow that delivers us thus chang'd
line 19223-->    Makes you think so.
line 19224-->  CORIOLANUS. Like a dull actor now
line 19225-->    I have forgot my part and I am out,
line 19226-->    Even to a full disgrace. Best of my flesh,
line 19227-->    Forgive my tyranny; but do not say,
line 19228-->    For that, 'Forgive our Romans.' O, a kiss
line 19229-->    Long as my exile, sweet as my revenge!
line 19230-->    Now, by the jealous queen of heaven, that kiss
line 19231-->    I carried from thee, dear, and my true lip
line 19232-->    Hath virgin'd it e'er since. You gods! I prate,
line 19233-->    And the most noble mother of the world  
line 19234-->    Leave unsaluted. Sink, my knee, i' th' earth;       [Kneels]
line 19235-->    Of thy deep duty more impression show
line 19236-->    Than that of common sons.
line 19237-->  VOLUMNIA. O, stand up blest!
line 19238-->    Whilst with no softer cushion than the flint
line 19239-->    I kneel before thee, and unproperly
line 19240-->    Show duty, as mistaken all this while
line 19241-->    Between the child and parent.                       [Kneels]
line 19242-->  CORIOLANUS. What's this?
line 19243-->    Your knees to me, to your corrected son?
line 19244-->    Then let the pebbles on the hungry beach
line 19245-->    Fillip the stars; then let the mutinous winds
line 19246-->    Strike the proud cedars 'gainst the fiery sun,
line 19247-->    Murd'ring impossibility, to make
line 19248-->    What cannot be slight work.
line 19249-->  VOLUMNIA. Thou art my warrior;
line 19250-->    I holp to frame thee. Do you know this lady?
line 19251-->  CORIOLANUS. The noble sister of Publicola,
line 19252-->    The moon of Rome, chaste as the icicle
line 19253-->    That's curdied by the frost from purest snow,  
line 19254-->    And hangs on Dian's temple- dear Valeria!
line 19255-->  VOLUMNIA. This is a poor epitome of yours,
line 19256-->    Which by th' interpretation of full time
line 19257-->    May show like all yourself.
line 19258-->  CORIOLANUS. The god of soldiers,
line 19259-->    With the consent of supreme Jove, inform
line 19260-->    Thy thoughts with nobleness, that thou mayst prove
line 19261-->    To shame unvulnerable, and stick i' th' wars
line 19262-->    Like a great sea-mark, standing every flaw,
line 19263-->    And saving those that eye thee!
line 19264-->  VOLUMNIA. Your knee, sirrah.
line 19265-->  CORIOLANUS. That's my brave boy.
line 19266-->  VOLUMNIA. Even he, your wife, this lady, and myself,
line 19267-->    Are suitors to you.
line 19268-->  CORIOLANUS. I beseech you, peace!
line 19269-->    Or, if you'd ask, remember this before:
line 19270-->    The thing I have forsworn to grant may never
line 19271-->    Be held by you denials. Do not bid me
line 19272-->    Dismiss my soldiers, or capitulate
line 19273-->    Again with Rome's mechanics. Tell me not  
line 19274-->    Wherein I seem unnatural; desire not
line 19275-->    T'allay my rages and revenges with
line 19276-->    Your colder reasons.
line 19277-->  VOLUMNIA. O, no more, no more!
line 19278-->    You have said you will not grant us any thing-
line 19279-->    For we have nothing else to ask but that
line 19280-->    Which you deny already; yet we will ask,
line 19281-->    That, if you fail in our request, the blame
line 19282-->    May hang upon your hardness; therefore hear us.
line 19283-->  CORIOLANUS. Aufidius, and you Volsces, mark; for we'll
line 19284-->    Hear nought from Rome in private. Your request?
line 19285-->  VOLUMNIA. Should we be silent and not speak, our raiment
line 19286-->    And state of bodies would bewray what life
line 19287-->    We have led since thy exile. Think with thyself
line 19288-->    How more unfortunate than all living women
line 19289-->    Are we come hither; since that thy sight, which should
line 19290-->    Make our eyes flow with joy, hearts dance with comforts,
line 19291-->    Constrains them weep and shake with fear and sorrow,
line 19292-->    Making the mother, wife, and child, to see
line 19293-->    The son, the husband, and the father, tearing  
line 19294-->    His country's bowels out. And to poor we
line 19295-->    Thine enmity's most capital: thou bar'st us
line 19296-->    Our prayers to the gods, which is a comfort
line 19297-->    That all but we enjoy. For how can we,
line 19298-->    Alas, how can we for our country pray,
line 19299-->    Whereto we are bound, together with thy victory,
line 19300-->    Whereto we are bound? Alack, or we must lose
line 19301-->    The country, our dear nurse, or else thy person,
line 19302-->    Our comfort in the country. We must find
line 19303-->    An evident calamity, though we had
line 19304-->    Our wish, which side should win; for either thou
line 19305-->    Must as a foreign recreant be led
line 19306-->    With manacles through our streets, or else
line 19307-->    Triumphantly tread on thy country's ruin,
line 19308-->    And bear the palm for having bravely shed
line 19309-->    Thy wife and children's blood. For myself, son,
line 19310-->    I purpose not to wait on fortune till
line 19311-->    These wars determine; if I can not persuade thee
line 19312-->    Rather to show a noble grace to both parts
line 19313-->    Than seek the end of one, thou shalt no sooner  
line 19314-->    March to assault thy country than to tread-
line 19315-->    Trust to't, thou shalt not- on thy mother's womb
line 19316-->    That brought thee to this world.
line 19317-->  VIRGILIA. Ay, and mine,
line 19318-->    That brought you forth this boy to keep your name
line 19319-->    Living to time.
line 19320-->  BOY. 'A shall not tread on me!
line 19321-->    I'll run away till I am bigger, but then I'll fight.
line 19322-->  CORIOLANUS. Not of a woman's tenderness to be
line 19323-->    Requires nor child nor woman's face to see.
line 19324-->    I have sat too long.                                [Rising]
line 19325-->  VOLUMNIA. Nay, go not from us thus.
line 19326-->    If it were so that our request did tend
line 19327-->    To save the Romans, thereby to destroy
line 19328-->    The Volsces whom you serve, you might condemn us
line 19329-->    As poisonous of your honour. No, our suit
line 19330-->    Is that you reconcile them: while the Volsces
line 19331-->    May say 'This mercy we have show'd,' the Romans
line 19332-->    'This we receiv'd,' and each in either side
line 19333-->    Give the all-hail to thee, and cry 'Be blest  
line 19334-->    For making up this peace!' Thou know'st, great son,
line 19335-->    The end of war's uncertain; but this certain,
line 19336-->    That, if thou conquer Rome, the benefit
line 19337-->    Which thou shalt thereby reap is such a name
line 19338-->    Whose repetition will be dogg'd with curses;
line 19339-->    Whose chronicle thus writ: 'The man was noble,
line 19340-->    But with his last attempt he wip'd it out,
line 19341-->    Destroy'd his country, and his name remains
line 19342-->    To th' ensuing age abhorr'd.' Speak to me, son.
line 19343-->    Thou hast affected the fine strains of honour,
line 19344-->    To imitate the graces of the gods,
line 19345-->    To tear with thunder the wide cheeks o' th' air,
line 19346-->    And yet to charge thy sulphur with a bolt
line 19347-->    That should but rive an oak. Why dost not speak?
line 19348-->    Think'st thou it honourable for a noble man
line 19349-->    Still to remember wrongs? Daughter, speak you:
line 19350-->    He cares not for your weeping. Speak thou, boy;
line 19351-->    Perhaps thy childishness will move him more
line 19352-->    Than can our reasons. There's no man in the world
line 19353-->    More bound to's mother, yet here he lets me prate  
line 19354-->    Like one i' th' stocks. Thou hast never in thy life
line 19355-->    Show'd thy dear mother any courtesy,
line 19356-->    When she, poor hen, fond of no second brood,
line 19357-->    Has cluck'd thee to the wars, and safely home
line 19358-->    Loaden with honour. Say my request's unjust,
line 19359-->    And spurn me back; but if it he not so,
line 19360-->    Thou art not honest, and the gods will plague thee,
line 19361-->    That thou restrain'st from me the duty which
line 19362-->    To a mother's part belongs. He turns away.
line 19363-->    Down, ladies; let us shame him with our knees.
line 19364-->    To his surname Coriolanus 'longs more pride
line 19365-->    Than pity to our prayers. Down. An end;
line 19366-->    This is the last. So we will home to Rome,
line 19367-->    And die among our neighbours. Nay, behold's!
line 19368-->    This boy, that cannot tell what he would have
line 19369-->    But kneels and holds up hands for fellowship,
line 19370-->    Does reason our petition with more strength
line 19371-->    Than thou hast to deny't. Come, let us go.
line 19372-->    This fellow had a Volscian to his mother;
line 19373-->    His wife is in Corioli, and his child  
line 19374-->    Like him by chance. Yet give us our dispatch.
line 19375-->    I am hush'd until our city be afire,
line 19376-->    And then I'll speak a little.
line 19377-->                              [He holds her by the hand, silent]
line 19378-->  CORIOLANUS. O mother, mother!
line 19379-->    What have you done? Behold, the heavens do ope,
line 19380-->    The gods look down, and this unnatural scene
line 19381-->    They laugh at. O my mother, mother! O!
line 19382-->    You have won a happy victory to Rome;
line 19383-->    But for your son- believe it, O, believe it!-
line 19384-->    Most dangerously you have with him prevail'd,
line 19385-->    If not most mortal to him. But let it come.
line 19386-->    Aufidius, though I cannot make true wars,
line 19387-->    I'll frame convenient peace. Now, good Aufidius,
line 19388-->    Were you in my stead, would you have heard
line 19389-->    A mother less, or granted less, Aufidius?
line 19390-->  AUFIDIUS. I was mov'd withal.
line 19391-->  CORIOLANUS. I dare be sworn you were!
line 19392-->    And, sir, it is no little thing to make
line 19393-->    Mine eyes to sweat compassion. But, good sir,  
line 19394-->    What peace you'fl make, advise me. For my part,
line 19395-->    I'll not to Rome, I'll back with you; and pray you
line 19396-->    Stand to me in this cause. O mother! wife!
line 19397-->  AUFIDIUS.  [Aside]  I am glad thou hast set thy mercy and thy
line 19398-->      honour
line 19399-->    At difference in thee. Out of that I'll work
line 19400-->    Myself a former fortune.
line 19401-->  CORIOLANUS.  [To the ladies]  Ay, by and by;
line 19402-->    But we will drink together; and you shall bear
line 19403-->    A better witness back than words, which we,
line 19404-->    On like conditions, will have counter-seal'd.
line 19405-->    Come, enter with us. Ladies, you deserve
line 19406-->    To have a temple built you. All the swords
line 19407-->    In Italy, and her confederate arms,
line 19408-->    Could not have made this peace.                       Exeunt
line 19409-->
line 19410-->
line 19411-->
line 19412-->
line 19413-->SCENE IV.
line 19414-->Rome. A public place
line 19415-->
line 19416-->Enter MENENIUS and SICINIUS
line 19417-->
line 19418-->  MENENIUS. See you yond coign o' th' Capitol, yond cornerstone?
line 19419-->  SICINIUS. Why, what of that?
line 19420-->  MENENIUS. If it be possible for you to displace it with your little
line 19421-->    finger, there is some hope the ladies of Rome, especially his
line 19422-->    mother, may prevail with him. But I say there is no hope in't;
line 19423-->    our throats are sentenc'd, and stay upon execution.
line 19424-->  SICINIUS. Is't possible that so short a time can alter the
line 19425-->    condition of a man?
line 19426-->  MENENIUS. There is differency between a grub and a butterfly; yet
line 19427-->    your butterfly was a grub. This Marcius is grown from man to
line 19428-->    dragon; he has wings, he's more than a creeping thing.
line 19429-->  SICINIUS. He lov'd his mother dearly.
line 19430-->  MENENIUS. So did he me; and he no more remembers his mother now
line 19431-->    than an eight-year-old horse. The tartness of his face sours ripe
line 19432-->    grapes; when he walks, he moves like an engine and the ground
line 19433-->    shrinks before his treading. He is able to pierce a corslet with
line 19434-->    his eye, talks like a knell, and his hum is a battery. He sits in  
line 19435-->    his state as a thing made for Alexander. What he bids be done is
line 19436-->    finish'd with his bidding. He wants nothing of a god but
line 19437-->    eternity, and a heaven to throne in.
line 19438-->  SICINIUS. Yes- mercy, if you report him truly.
line 19439-->  MENENIUS. I paint him in the character. Mark what mercy his mother
line 19440-->    shall bring from him. There is no more mercy in him than there is
line 19441-->    milk in a male tiger; that shall our poor city find. And all this
line 19442-->    is 'long of you.
line 19443-->  SICINIUS. The gods be good unto us!
line 19444-->  MENENIUS. No, in such a case the gods will not be good unto us.
line 19445-->    When we banish'd him we respected not them; and, he returning to
line 19446-->    break our necks, they respect not us.
line 19447-->
line 19448-->                           Enter a MESSENGER
line 19449-->
line 19450-->  MESSENGER. Sir, if you'd save your life, fly to your house.
line 19451-->    The plebeians have got your fellow tribune
line 19452-->    And hale him up and down; all swearing if
line 19453-->    The Roman ladies bring not comfort home
line 19454-->    They'll give him death by inches.  
line 19455-->
line 19456-->                         Enter another MESSENGER
line 19457-->
line 19458-->  SICINIUS. What's the news?
line 19459-->  SECOND MESSENGER. Good news, good news! The ladies have prevail'd,
line 19460-->    The Volscians are dislodg'd, and Marcius gone.
line 19461-->    A merrier day did never yet greet Rome,
line 19462-->    No, not th' expulsion of the Tarquins.
line 19463-->  SICINIUS. Friend,
line 19464-->    Art thou certain this is true? Is't most certain?
line 19465-->  SECOND MESSENGER. As certain as I know the sun is fire.
line 19466-->    Where have you lurk'd, that you make doubt of it?
line 19467-->    Ne'er through an arch so hurried the blown tide
line 19468-->    As the recomforted through th' gates. Why, hark you!
line 19469-->                  [Trumpets, hautboys, drums beat, all together]
line 19470-->    The trumpets, sackbuts, psalteries, and fifes,
line 19471-->    Tabors and cymbals, and the shouting Romans,
line 19472-->    Make the sun dance. Hark you!               [A shout within]
line 19473-->  MENENIUS. This is good news.
line 19474-->    I will go meet the ladies. This Volumnia  
line 19475-->    Is worth of consuls, senators, patricians,
line 19476-->    A city full; of tribunes such as you,
line 19477-->    A sea and land full. You have pray'd well to-day:
line 19478-->    This morning for ten thousand of your throats
line 19479-->    I'd not have given a doit. Hark, how they joy!
line 19480-->                                   [Sound still with the shouts]
line 19481-->  SICINIUS. First, the gods bless you for your tidings; next,
line 19482-->    Accept my thankfulness.
line 19483-->  SECOND MESSENGER. Sir, we have all
line 19484-->    Great cause to give great thanks.
line 19485-->  SICINIUS. They are near the city?
line 19486-->  MESSENGER. Almost at point to enter.
line 19487-->  SICINIUS. We'll meet them,
line 19488-->    And help the joy.                                     Exeunt
line 19489-->
line 19490-->
line 19491-->
line 19492-->
line 19493-->SCENE V.
line 19494-->Rome. A street near the gate
line 19495-->
line 19496-->Enter two SENATORS With VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA, VALERIA, passing over the stage,
line 19497-->'With other LORDS
line 19498-->
line 19499-->  FIRST SENATOR. Behold our patroness, the life of Rome!
line 19500-->    Call all your tribes together, praise the gods,
line 19501-->    And make triumphant fires; strew flowers before them.
line 19502-->    Unshout the noise that banish'd Marcius,
line 19503-->    Repeal him with the welcome of his mother;
line 19504-->  ALL. Welcome, ladies, welcome!
line 19505-->                    [A flourish with drums and trumpets. Exeunt]
line 19506-->
line 19507-->
line 19508-->
line 19509-->
line 19510-->SCENE VI.
line 19511-->Corioli. A public place
line 19512-->
line 19513-->Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS with attendents
line 19514-->
line 19515-->  AUFIDIUS. Go tell the lords o' th' city I am here;
line 19516-->    Deliver them this paper' having read it,
line 19517-->    Bid them repair to th' market-place, where I,
line 19518-->    Even in theirs and in the commons' ears,
line 19519-->    Will vouch the truth of it. Him I accuse
line 19520-->    The city ports by this hath enter'd and
line 19521-->    Intends t' appear before the people, hoping
line 19522-->    To purge himself with words. Dispatch.
line 19523-->                                               Exeunt attendants
line 19524-->
line 19525-->           Enter three or four CONSPIRATORS of AUFIDIUS' faction
line 19526-->
line 19527-->    Most welcome!
line 19528-->  FIRST CONSPIRATOR. How is it with our general?
line 19529-->  AUFIDIUS. Even so
line 19530-->    As with a man by his own alms empoison'd,
line 19531-->    And with his charity slain.  
line 19532-->  SECOND CONSPIRATOR. Most noble sir,
line 19533-->    If you do hold the same intent wherein
line 19534-->    You wish'd us parties, we'll deliver you
line 19535-->    Of your great danger.
line 19536-->  AUFIDIUS. Sir, I cannot tell;
line 19537-->    We must proceed as we do find the people.
line 19538-->  THIRD CONSPIRATOR. The people will remain uncertain whilst
line 19539-->    'Twixt you there's difference; but the fall of either
line 19540-->    Makes the survivor heir of all.
line 19541-->  AUFIDIUS. I know it;
line 19542-->    And my pretext to strike at him admits
line 19543-->    A good construction. I rais'd him, and I pawn'd
line 19544-->    Mine honour for his truth; who being so heighten'd,
line 19545-->    He watered his new plants with dews of flattery,
line 19546-->    Seducing so my friends; and to this end
line 19547-->    He bow'd his nature, never known before
line 19548-->    But to be rough, unswayable, and free.
line 19549-->  THIRD CONSPIRATOR. Sir, his stoutness
line 19550-->    When he did stand for consul, which he lost
line 19551-->    By lack of stooping-  
line 19552-->  AUFIDIUS. That I would have spoken of.
line 19553-->    Being banish'd for't, he came unto my hearth,
line 19554-->    Presented to my knife his throat. I took him;
line 19555-->    Made him joint-servant with me; gave him way
line 19556-->    In all his own desires; nay, let him choose
line 19557-->    Out of my files, his projects to accomplish,
line 19558-->    My best and freshest men; serv'd his designments
line 19559-->    In mine own person; holp to reap the fame
line 19560-->    Which he did end all his, and took some pride
line 19561-->    To do myself this wrong. Till, at the last,
line 19562-->    I seem'd his follower, not partner; and
line 19563-->    He wag'd me with his countenance as if
line 19564-->    I had been mercenary.
line 19565-->  FIRST CONSPIRATOR. So he did, my lord.
line 19566-->    The army marvell'd at it; and, in the last,
line 19567-->    When he had carried Rome and that we look'd
line 19568-->    For no less spoil than glory-
line 19569-->  AUFIDIUS. There was it;
line 19570-->    For which my sinews shall be stretch'd upon him.
line 19571-->    At a few drops of women's rheum, which are  
line 19572-->    As cheap as lies, he sold the blood and labour
line 19573-->    Of our great action; therefore shall he die,
line 19574-->    And I'll renew me in his fall. But, hark!
line 19575-->                                                      [Drums and
line 19576-->                trumpets sound, with great shouts of the people]
line 19577-->  FIRST CONSPIRATOR. Your native town you enter'd like a post,
line 19578-->    And had no welcomes home; but he returns
line 19579-->    Splitting the air with noise.
line 19580-->  SECOND CONSPIRATOR. And patient fools,
line 19581-->    Whose children he hath slain, their base throats tear
line 19582-->    With giving him glory.
line 19583-->  THIRD CONSPIRATOR. Therefore, at your vantage,
line 19584-->    Ere he express himself or move the people
line 19585-->    With what he would say, let him feel your sword,
line 19586-->    Which we will second. When he lies along,
line 19587-->    After your way his tale pronounc'd shall bury
line 19588-->    His reasons with his body.
line 19589-->  AUFIDIUS. Say no more:
line 19590-->    Here come the lords.
line 19591-->  
line 19592-->                     Enter the LORDS of the city
line 19593-->
line 19594-->  LORDS. You are most welcome home.
line 19595-->  AUFIDIUS. I have not deserv'd it.
line 19596-->    But, worthy lords, have you with heed perused
line 19597-->    What I have written to you?
line 19598-->  LORDS. We have.
line 19599-->  FIRST LORD. And grieve to hear't.
line 19600-->    What faults he made before the last, I think
line 19601-->    Might have found easy fines; but there to end
line 19602-->    Where he was to begin, and give away
line 19603-->    The benefit of our levies, answering us
line 19604-->    With our own charge, making a treaty where
line 19605-->    There was a yielding- this admits no excuse.
line 19606-->  AUFIDIUS. He approaches; you shall hear him.
line 19607-->
line 19608-->            Enter CORIOLANUS, marching with drum and colours;
line 19609-->                      the commoners being with him
line 19610-->
line 19611-->  CORIOLANUS. Hail, lords! I am return'd your soldier;  
line 19612-->    No more infected with my country's love
line 19613-->    Than when I parted hence, but still subsisting
line 19614-->    Under your great command. You are to know
line 19615-->    That prosperously I have attempted, and
line 19616-->    With bloody passage led your wars even to
line 19617-->    The gates of Rome. Our spoils we have brought home
line 19618-->    Doth more than counterpoise a full third part
line 19619-->    The charges of the action. We have made peace
line 19620-->    With no less honour to the Antiates
line 19621-->    Than shame to th' Romans; and we here deliver,
line 19622-->    Subscrib'd by th' consuls and patricians,
line 19623-->    Together with the seal o' th' Senate, what
line 19624-->    We have compounded on.
line 19625-->  AUFIDIUS. Read it not, noble lords;
line 19626-->    But tell the traitor in the highest degree
line 19627-->    He hath abus'd your powers.
line 19628-->  CORIOLANUS. Traitor! How now?
line 19629-->  AUFIDIUS. Ay, traitor, Marcius.
line 19630-->  CORIOLANUS. Marcius!
line 19631-->  AUFIDIUS. Ay, Marcius, Caius Marcius! Dost thou think  
line 19632-->    I'll grace thee with that robbery, thy stol'n name
line 19633-->    Coriolanus, in Corioli?
line 19634-->    You lords and heads o' th' state, perfidiously
line 19635-->    He has betray'd your business and given up,
line 19636-->    For certain drops of salt, your city Rome-
line 19637-->    I say your city- to his wife and mother;
line 19638-->    Breaking his oath and resolution like
line 19639-->    A twist of rotten silk; never admitting
line 19640-->    Counsel o' th' war; but at his nurse's tears
line 19641-->    He whin'd and roar'd away your victory,
line 19642-->    That pages blush'd at him, and men of heart
line 19643-->    Look'd wond'ring each at others.
line 19644-->  CORIOLANUS. Hear'st thou, Mars?
line 19645-->  AUFIDIUS. Name not the god, thou boy of tears-
line 19646-->  CORIOLANUS. Ha!
line 19647-->  AUFIDIUS. -no more.
line 19648-->  CORIOLANUS. Measureless liar, thou hast made my heart
line 19649-->    Too great for what contains it. 'Boy'! O slave!
line 19650-->    Pardon me, lords, 'tis the first time that ever
line 19651-->    I was forc'd to scold. Your judgments, my grave lords,  
line 19652-->    Must give this cur the lie; and his own notion-
line 19653-->    Who wears my stripes impress'd upon him, that
line 19654-->    Must bear my beating to his grave- shall join
line 19655-->    To thrust the lie unto him.
line 19656-->  FIRST LORD. Peace, both, and hear me speak.
line 19657-->  CORIOLANUS. Cut me to pieces, Volsces; men and lads,
line 19658-->    Stain all your edges on me. 'Boy'! False hound!
line 19659-->    If you have writ your annals true, 'tis there
line 19660-->    That, like an eagle in a dove-cote, I
line 19661-->    Flutter'd your Volscians in Corioli.
line 19662-->    Alone I did it. 'Boy'!
line 19663-->  AUFIDIUS. Why, noble lords,
line 19664-->    Will you be put in mind of his blind fortune,
line 19665-->    Which was your shame, by this unholy braggart,
line 19666-->    Fore your own eyes and ears?
line 19667-->  CONSPIRATORS. Let him die for't.
line 19668-->  ALL THE PEOPLE. Tear him to pieces. Do it presently. He kill'd my
line 19669-->    son. My daughter. He kill'd my cousin Marcus. He kill'd my
line 19670-->    father.
line 19671-->  SECOND LORD. Peace, ho! No outrage- peace!  
line 19672-->    The man is noble, and his fame folds in
line 19673-->    This orb o' th' earth. His last offences to us
line 19674-->    Shall have judicious hearing. Stand, Aufidius,
line 19675-->    And trouble not the peace.
line 19676-->  CORIOLANUS. O that I had him,
line 19677-->    With six Aufidiuses, or more- his tribe,
line 19678-->    To use my lawful sword!
line 19679-->  AUFIDIUS. Insolent villain!
line 19680-->  CONSPIRATORS. Kill, kill, kill, kill, kill him!
line 19681-->           [The CONSPIRATORS draw and kill CORIOLANUS,who falls.
line 19682-->                                         AUFIDIUS stands on him]
line 19683-->  LORDS. Hold, hold, hold, hold!
line 19684-->  AUFIDIUS. My noble masters, hear me speak.
line 19685-->  FIRST LORD. O Tullus!
line 19686-->  SECOND LORD. Thou hast done a deed whereat valour will weep.
line 19687-->  THIRD LORD. Tread not upon him. Masters all, be quiet;
line 19688-->    Put up your swords.
line 19689-->  AUFIDIUS. My lords, when you shall know- as in this rage,
line 19690-->    Provok'd by him, you cannot- the great danger
line 19691-->    Which this man's life did owe you, you'll rejoice  
line 19692-->    That he is thus cut off. Please it your honours
line 19693-->    To call me to your Senate, I'll deliver
line 19694-->    Myself your loyal servant, or endure
line 19695-->    Your heaviest censure.
line 19696-->  FIRST LORD. Bear from hence his body,
line 19697-->    And mourn you for him. Let him be regarded
line 19698-->    As the most noble corse that ever herald
line 19699-->    Did follow to his um.
line 19700-->  SECOND LORD. His own impatience
line 19701-->    Takes from Aufidius a great part of blame.
line 19702-->    Let's make the best of it.
line 19703-->  AUFIDIUS. My rage is gone,
line 19704-->    And I am struck with sorrow. Take him up.
line 19705-->    Help, three o' th' chiefest soldiers; I'll be one.
line 19706-->    Beat thou the drum, that it speak mournfully;
line 19707-->    Trail your steel pikes. Though in this city he
line 19708-->    Hath widowed and unchilded many a one,
line 19709-->    Which to this hour bewail the injury,
line 19710-->    Yet he shall have a noble memory.
line 19711-->    Assist.               Exeunt, bearing the body of CORIOLANUS  
line 19712-->                                          [A dead march sounded]
line 19713-->
line 19714-->
line 19715-->THE END
