line 19784-->
line 19785-->SCENE:
line 19786-->Britain; Italy
line 19787-->
line 19788-->
line 19789-->
line 19790-->ACT I. SCENE I.
line 19791-->Britain. The garden of CYMBELINE'S palace
line 19792-->
line 19793-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. You do not meet a man but frowns; our bloods
line 19794-->    No more obey the heavens than our courtiers
line 19795-->    Still seem as does the King's.
line 19796-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. But what's the matter?
line 19797-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. His daughter, and the heir of's kingdom, whom
line 19798-->    He purpos'd to his wife's sole son- a widow
line 19799-->    That late he married- hath referr'd herself
line 19800-->    Unto a poor but worthy gentleman. She's wedded;
line 19801-->    Her husband banish'd; she imprison'd. All
line 19802-->    Is outward sorrow, though I think the King
line 19803-->    Be touch'd at very heart.
line 19804-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. None but the King?
line 19805-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. He that hath lost her too. So is the Queen,
line 19806-->    That most desir'd the match. But not a courtier,
line 19807-->    Although they wear their faces to the bent
line 19808-->    Of the King's looks, hath a heart that is not
line 19809-->    Glad at the thing they scowl at.
line 19810-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. And why so?
line 19811-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. He that hath miss'd the Princess is a thing  
line 19812-->    Too bad for bad report; and he that hath her-
line 19813-->    I mean that married her, alack, good man!
line 19814-->    And therefore banish'd- is a creature such
line 19815-->    As, to seek through the regions of the earth
line 19816-->    For one his like, there would be something failing
line 19817-->    In him that should compare. I do not think
line 19818-->    So fair an outward and such stuff within
line 19819-->    Endows a man but he.
line 19820-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. You speak him far.
line 19821-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. I do extend him, sir, within himself;
line 19822-->    Crush him together rather than unfold
line 19823-->    His measure duly.
line 19824-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. What's his name and birth?
line 19825-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. I cannot delve him to the root; his father
line 19826-->    Was call'd Sicilius, who did join his honour
line 19827-->    Against the Romans with Cassibelan,
line 19828-->    But had his titles by Tenantius, whom
line 19829-->    He serv'd with glory and admir'd success,
line 19830-->    So gain'd the sur-addition Leonatus;
line 19831-->    And had, besides this gentleman in question,  
line 19832-->    Two other sons, who, in the wars o' th' time,
line 19833-->    Died with their swords in hand; for which their father,
line 19834-->    Then old and fond of issue, took such sorrow
line 19835-->    That he quit being; and his gentle lady,
line 19836-->    Big of this gentleman, our theme, deceas'd
line 19837-->    As he was born. The King he takes the babe
line 19838-->    To his protection, calls him Posthumus Leonatus,
line 19839-->    Breeds him and makes him of his bed-chamber,
line 19840-->    Puts to him all the learnings that his time
line 19841-->    Could make him the receiver of; which he took,
line 19842-->    As we do air, fast as 'twas minist'red,
line 19843-->    And in's spring became a harvest, liv'd in court-
line 19844-->    Which rare it is to do- most prais'd, most lov'd,
line 19845-->    A sample to the youngest; to th' more mature
line 19846-->    A glass that feated them; and to the graver
line 19847-->    A child that guided dotards. To his mistress,
line 19848-->    For whom he now is banish'd- her own price
line 19849-->    Proclaims how she esteem'd him and his virtue;
line 19850-->    By her election may be truly read
line 19851-->    What kind of man he is.  
line 19852-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. I honour him
line 19853-->    Even out of your report. But pray you tell me,
line 19854-->    Is she sole child to th' King?
line 19855-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. His only child.
line 19856-->    He had two sons- if this be worth your hearing,
line 19857-->    Mark it- the eldest of them at three years old,
line 19858-->    I' th' swathing clothes the other, from their nursery
line 19859-->    Were stol'n; and to this hour no guess in knowledge
line 19860-->    Which way they went.
line 19861-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. How long is this ago?
line 19862-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. Some twenty years.
line 19863-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. That a king's children should be so convey'd,
line 19864-->    So slackly guarded, and the search so slow
line 19865-->    That could not trace them!
line 19866-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. Howsoe'er 'tis strange,
line 19867-->    Or that the negligence may well be laugh'd at,
line 19868-->    Yet is it true, sir.
line 19869-->  SECOND GENTLEMAN. I do well believe you.
line 19870-->  FIRST GENTLEMAN. We must forbear; here comes the gentleman,
line 19871-->    The Queen, and Princess.                              Exeunt  
line 19872-->
line 19873-->              Enter the QUEEN, POSTHUMUS, and IMOGEN
line 19874-->
line 19875-->  QUEEN. No, be assur'd you shall not find me, daughter,
line 19876-->    After the slander of most stepmothers,
line 19877-->    Evil-ey'd unto you. You're my prisoner, but
line 19878-->    Your gaoler shall deliver you the keys
line 19879-->    That lock up your restraint. For you, Posthumus,
line 19880-->    So soon as I can win th' offended King,
line 19881-->    I will be known your advocate. Marry, yet
line 19882-->    The fire of rage is in him, and 'twere good
line 19883-->    You lean'd unto his sentence with what patience
line 19884-->    Your wisdom may inform you.
line 19885-->  POSTHUMUS. Please your Highness,
line 19886-->    I will from hence to-day.
line 19887-->  QUEEN. You know the peril.
line 19888-->    I'll fetch a turn about the garden, pitying
line 19889-->    The pangs of barr'd affections, though the King
line 19890-->    Hath charg'd you should not speak together.             Exit
line 19891-->  IMOGEN. O dissembling courtesy! How fine this tyrant  
line 19892-->    Can tickle where she wounds! My dearest husband,
line 19893-->    I something fear my father's wrath, but nothing-
line 19894-->    Always reserv'd my holy duty- what
line 19895-->    His rage can do on me. You must be gone;
line 19896-->    And I shall here abide the hourly shot
line 19897-->    Of angry eyes, not comforted to live
line 19898-->    But that there is this jewel in the world
line 19899-->    That I may see again.
line 19900-->  POSTHUMUS. My queen! my mistress!
line 19901-->    O lady, weep no more, lest I give cause
line 19902-->    To be suspected of more tenderness
line 19903-->    Than doth become a man. I will remain
line 19904-->    The loyal'st husband that did e'er plight troth;
line 19905-->    My residence in Rome at one Philario's,
line 19906-->    Who to my father was a friend, to me
line 19907-->    Known but by letter; thither write, my queen,
line 19908-->    And with mine eyes I'll drink the words you send,
line 19909-->    Though ink be made of gall.
line 19910-->
line 19911-->                     Re-enter QUEEN  
line 19912-->
line 19913-->  QUEEN. Be brief, I pray you.
line 19914-->    If the King come, I shall incur I know not
line 19915-->    How much of his displeasure. [Aside] Yet I'll move him
line 19916-->    To walk this way. I never do him wrong
line 19917-->    But he does buy my injuries, to be friends;
line 19918-->    Pays dear for my offences.                              Exit
line 19919-->  POSTHUMUS. Should we be taking leave
line 19920-->    As long a term as yet we have to live,
line 19921-->    The loathness to depart would grow. Adieu!
line 19922-->  IMOGEN. Nay, stay a little.
line 19923-->    Were you but riding forth to air yourself,
line 19924-->    Such parting were too petty. Look here, love:
line 19925-->    This diamond was my mother's; take it, heart;
line 19926-->    But keep it till you woo another wife,
line 19927-->    When Imogen is dead.
line 19928-->  POSTHUMUS. How, how? Another?
line 19929-->    You gentle gods, give me but this I have,
line 19930-->    And sear up my embracements from a next
line 19931-->    With bonds of death! Remain, remain thou here  
line 19932-->                                              [Puts on the ring]
line 19933-->    While sense can keep it on. And, sweetest, fairest,
line 19934-->    As I my poor self did exchange for you,
line 19935-->    To your so infinite loss, so in our trifles
line 19936-->    I still win of you. For my sake wear this;
line 19937-->    It is a manacle of love; I'll place it
line 19938-->    Upon this fairest prisoner.     [Puts a bracelet on her arm]
line 19939-->  IMOGEN. O the gods!
line 19940-->    When shall we see again?
line 19941-->
line 19942-->                  Enter CYMBELINE and LORDS
line 19943-->
line 19944-->  POSTHUMUS. Alack, the King!
line 19945-->  CYMBELINE. Thou basest thing, avoid; hence from my sight
line 19946-->    If after this command thou fraught the court
line 19947-->    With thy unworthiness, thou diest. Away!
line 19948-->    Thou'rt poison to my blood.
line 19949-->  POSTHUMUS. The gods protect you,
line 19950-->    And bless the good remainders of the court!
line 19951-->    I am gone.                                              Exit  
line 19952-->  IMOGEN. There cannot be a pinch in death
line 19953-->    More sharp than this is.
line 19954-->  CYMBELINE. O disloyal thing,
line 19955-->    That shouldst repair my youth, thou heap'st
line 19956-->    A year's age on me!
line 19957-->  IMOGEN. I beseech you, sir,
line 19958-->    Harm not yourself with your vexation.
line 19959-->    I am senseless of your wrath; a touch more rare
line 19960-->    Subdues all pangs, all fears.
line 19961-->  CYMBELINE. Past grace? obedience?
line 19962-->  IMOGEN. Past hope, and in despair; that way past grace.
line 19963-->  CYMBELINE. That mightst have had the sole son of my queen!
line 19964-->  IMOGEN. O blessed that I might not! I chose an eagle,
line 19965-->    And did avoid a puttock.
line 19966-->  CYMBELINE. Thou took'st a beggar, wouldst have made my throne
line 19967-->    A seat for baseness.
line 19968-->  IMOGEN. No; I rather added
line 19969-->    A lustre to it.
line 19970-->  CYMBELINE. O thou vile one!
line 19971-->  IMOGEN. Sir,  
line 19972-->    It is your fault that I have lov'd Posthumus.
line 19973-->    You bred him as my playfellow, and he is
line 19974-->    A man worth any woman; overbuys me
line 19975-->    Almost the sum he pays.
line 19976-->  CYMBELINE. What, art thou mad?
line 19977-->  IMOGEN. Almost, sir. Heaven restore me! Would I were
line 19978-->    A neat-herd's daughter, and my Leonatus
line 19979-->    Our neighbour shepherd's son!
line 19980-->
line 19981-->                          Re-enter QUEEN
line 19982-->
line 19983-->  CYMBELINE. Thou foolish thing!
line 19984-->    [To the QUEEN] They were again together. You have done
line 19985-->    Not after our command. Away with her,
line 19986-->    And pen her up.
line 19987-->  QUEEN. Beseech your patience.- Peace,
line 19988-->    Dear lady daughter, peace!- Sweet sovereign,
line 19989-->    Leave us to ourselves, and make yourself some comfort
line 19990-->    Out of your best advice.
line 19991-->  CYMBELINE. Nay, let her languish  
line 19992-->    A drop of blood a day and, being aged,
line 19993-->    Die of this folly.                          Exit, with LORDS
line 19994-->
line 19995-->                          Enter PISANIO
line 19996-->
line 19997-->  QUEEN. Fie! you must give way.
line 19998-->    Here is your servant. How now, sir! What news?
line 19999-->  PISANIO. My lord your son drew on my master.
line 20000-->  QUEEN. Ha!
line 20001-->    No harm, I trust, is done?
line 20002-->  PISANIO. There might have been,
line 20003-->    But that my master rather play'd than fought,
line 20004-->    And had no help of anger; they were parted
line 20005-->    By gentlemen at hand.
line 20006-->  QUEEN. I am very glad on't.
line 20007-->  IMOGEN. Your son's my father's friend; he takes his part
line 20008-->    To draw upon an exile! O brave sir!
line 20009-->    I would they were in Afric both together;
line 20010-->    Myself by with a needle, that I might prick
line 20011-->    The goer-back. Why came you from your master?  
line 20012-->  PISANIO. On his command. He would not suffer me
line 20013-->    To bring him to the haven; left these notes
line 20014-->    Of what commands I should be subject to,
line 20015-->    When't pleas'd you to employ me.
line 20016-->  QUEEN. This hath been
line 20017-->    Your faithful servant. I dare lay mine honour
line 20018-->    He will remain so.
line 20019-->  PISANIO. I humbly thank your Highness.
line 20020-->  QUEEN. Pray walk awhile.
line 20021-->  IMOGEN. About some half-hour hence,
line 20022-->    Pray you speak with me. You shall at least
line 20023-->    Go see my lord aboard. For this time leave me.        Exeunt
line 20024-->
line 20025-->
line 20026-->
line 20027-->
line 20028-->SCENE II.
line 20029-->Britain. A public place
line 20030-->
line 20031-->Enter CLOTEN and two LORDS
line 20032-->
line 20033-->  FIRST LORD. Sir, I would advise you to shift a shirt; the violence
line 20034-->    of action hath made you reek as a sacrifice. Where air comes out,
line 20035-->    air comes in; there's none abroad so wholesome as that you vent.
line 20036-->  CLOTEN. If my shirt were bloody, then to shift it. Have I hurt him?
line 20037-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] No, faith; not so much as his patience.
line 20038-->  FIRST LORD. Hurt him! His body's a passable carcass if he be not
line 20039-->    hurt. It is a throughfare for steel if it be not hurt.
line 20040-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] His steel was in debt; it went o' th' back
line 20041-->    side the town.
line 20042-->  CLOTEN. The villain would not stand me.
line 20043-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] No; but he fled forward still, toward your
line 20044-->    face.
line 20045-->  FIRST LORD. Stand you? You have land enough of your own; but he
line 20046-->    added to your having, gave you some ground.
line 20047-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] As many inches as you have oceans.
line 20048-->    Puppies!
line 20049-->  CLOTEN. I would they had not come between us.  
line 20050-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] So would I, till you had measur'd how long a
line 20051-->    fool you were upon the ground.
line 20052-->  CLOTEN. And that she should love this fellow, and refuse me!
line 20053-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] If it be a sin to make a true election, she is
line 20054-->    damn'd.
line 20055-->  FIRST LORD. Sir, as I told you always, her beauty and her brain go
line 20056-->    not together; she's a good sign, but I have seen small reflection
line 20057-->    of her wit.
line 20058-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] She shines not upon fools, lest the reflection
line 20059-->    should hurt her.
line 20060-->  CLOTEN. Come, I'll to my chamber. Would there had been some hurt
line 20061-->    done!
line 20062-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] I wish not so; unless it had been the fall of
line 20063-->    an ass, which is no great hurt.
line 20064-->  CLOTEN. You'll go with us?
line 20065-->  FIRST LORD. I'll attend your lordship.
line 20066-->  CLOTEN. Nay, come, let's go together.
line 20067-->  SECOND LORD. Well, my lord.                             Exeunt
line 20068-->
line 20069-->
line 20070-->
line 20071-->
line 20072-->SCENE III.
line 20073-->Britain. CYMBELINE'S palace
line 20074-->
line 20075-->Enter IMOGEN and PISANIO
line 20076-->
line 20077-->  IMOGEN. I would thou grew'st unto the shores o' th' haven,
line 20078-->    And questioned'st every sail; if he should write,
line 20079-->    And I not have it, 'twere a paper lost,
line 20080-->    As offer'd mercy is. What was the last
line 20081-->    That he spake to thee?
line 20082-->  PISANIO. It was: his queen, his queen!
line 20083-->  IMOGEN. Then wav'd his handkerchief?
line 20084-->  PISANIO. And kiss'd it, madam.
line 20085-->  IMOGEN. Senseless linen, happier therein than I!
line 20086-->    And that was all?
line 20087-->  PISANIO. No, madam; for so long
line 20088-->    As he could make me with his eye, or care
line 20089-->    Distinguish him from others, he did keep
line 20090-->    The deck, with glove, or hat, or handkerchief,
line 20091-->    Still waving, as the fits and stirs of's mind
line 20092-->    Could best express how slow his soul sail'd on,
line 20093-->    How swift his ship.  
line 20094-->  IMOGEN. Thou shouldst have made him
line 20095-->    As little as a crow, or less, ere left
line 20096-->    To after-eye him.
line 20097-->  PISANIO. Madam, so I did.
line 20098-->  IMOGEN. I would have broke mine eyestrings, crack'd them but
line 20099-->    To look upon him, till the diminution
line 20100-->    Of space had pointed him sharp as my needle;
line 20101-->    Nay, followed him till he had melted from
line 20102-->    The smallness of a gnat to air, and then
line 20103-->    Have turn'd mine eye and wept. But, good Pisanio,
line 20104-->    When shall we hear from him?
line 20105-->  PISANIO. Be assur'd, madam,
line 20106-->    With his next vantage.
line 20107-->  IMOGEN. I did not take my leave of him, but had
line 20108-->    Most pretty things to say. Ere I could tell him
line 20109-->    How I would think on him at certain hours
line 20110-->    Such thoughts and such; or I could make him swear
line 20111-->    The shes of Italy should not betray
line 20112-->    Mine interest and his honour; or have charg'd him,
line 20113-->    At the sixth hour of morn, at noon, at midnight,  
line 20114-->    T' encounter me with orisons, for then
line 20115-->    I am in heaven for him; or ere I could
line 20116-->    Give him that parting kiss which I had set
line 20117-->    Betwixt two charming words, comes in my father,
line 20118-->    And like the tyrannous breathing of the north
line 20119-->    Shakes all our buds from growing.
line 20120-->
line 20121-->                        Enter a LADY
line 20122-->
line 20123-->  LADY. The Queen, madam,
line 20124-->    Desires your Highness' company.
line 20125-->  IMOGEN. Those things I bid you do, get them dispatch'd.
line 20126-->    I will attend the Queen.
line 20127-->  PISANIO. Madam, I shall.                                Exeunt
line 20128-->
line 20129-->
line 20130-->
line 20131-->
line 20132-->SCENE IV.
line 20133-->Rome. PHILARIO'S house
line 20134-->
line 20135-->Enter PHILARIO, IACHIMO, a FRENCHMAN, a DUTCHMAN, and a SPANIARD
line 20136-->
line 20137-->  IACHIMO. Believe it, sir, I have seen him in Britain. He was then
line 20138-->    of a crescent note, expected to prove so worthy as since he hath
line 20139-->    been allowed the name of. But I could then have look'd on him
line 20140-->    without the help of admiration, though the catalogue of his
line 20141-->    endowments had been tabled by his side, and I to peruse him by
line 20142-->    items.
line 20143-->  PHILARIO. You speak of him when he was less furnish'd than now he
line 20144-->    is with that which makes him both without and within.
line 20145-->  FRENCHMAN. I have seen him in France; we had very many there could
line 20146-->    behold the sun with as firm eyes as he.
line 20147-->  IACHIMO. This matter of marrying his king's daughter, wherein he
line 20148-->    must be weighed rather by her value than his own, words him, I
line 20149-->    doubt not, a great deal from the matter.
line 20150-->  FRENCHMAN. And then his banishment.
line 20151-->  IACHIMO. Ay, and the approbation of those that weep this lamentable
line 20152-->    divorce under her colours are wonderfully to extend him, be it
line 20153-->    but to fortify her judgment, which else an easy battery might lay  
line 20154-->    flat, for taking a beggar, without less quality. But how comes it
line 20155-->    he is to sojourn with you? How creeps acquaintance?
line 20156-->  PHILARIO. His father and I were soldiers together, to whom I have
line 20157-->    been often bound for no less than my life.
line 20158-->
line 20159-->                       Enter POSTHUMUS
line 20160-->
line 20161-->    Here comes the Briton. Let him be so entertained amongst you as
line 20162-->    suits with gentlemen of your knowing to a stranger of his
line 20163-->    quality. I beseech you all be better known to this gentleman,
line 20164-->    whom I commend to you as a noble friend of mine. How worthy he is
line 20165-->    I will leave to appear hereafter, rather than story him in his
line 20166-->    own hearing.
line 20167-->  FRENCHMAN. Sir, we have known together in Orleans.
line 20168-->  POSTHUMUS. Since when I have been debtor to you for courtesies,
line 20169-->    which I will be ever to pay and yet pay still.
line 20170-->  FRENCHMAN. Sir, you o'errate my poor kindness. I was glad I did
line 20171-->    atone my countryman and you; it had been pity you should have
line 20172-->    been put together with so mortal a purpose as then each bore,
line 20173-->    upon importance of so slight and trivial a nature.  
line 20174-->  POSTHUMUS. By your pardon, sir. I was then a young traveller;
line 20175-->    rather shunn'd to go even with what I heard than in my every
line 20176-->    action to be guided by others' experiences; but upon my mended
line 20177-->    judgment- if I offend not to say it is mended- my quarrel was not
line 20178-->    altogether slight.
line 20179-->  FRENCHMAN. Faith, yes, to be put to the arbitrement of swords, and
line 20180-->    by such two that would by all likelihood have confounded one the
line 20181-->    other or have fall'n both.
line 20182-->  IACHIMO. Can we, with manners, ask what was the difference?
line 20183-->  FRENCHMAN. Safely, I think. 'Twas a contention in public, which
line 20184-->    may, without contradiction, suffer the report. It was much like
line 20185-->    an argument that fell out last night, where each of us fell in
line 20186-->    praise of our country mistresses; this gentleman at that time
line 20187-->    vouching- and upon warrant of bloody affirmation- his to be more
line 20188-->    fair, virtuous, wise, chaste, constant, qualified, and less
line 20189-->    attemptable, than any the rarest of our ladies in France.
line 20190-->  IACHIMO. That lady is not now living, or this gentleman's opinion,
line 20191-->    by this, worn out.
line 20192-->  POSTHUMUS. She holds her virtue still, and I my mind.
line 20193-->  IACHIMO. You must not so far prefer her fore ours of Italy.  
line 20194-->  POSTHUMUS. Being so far provok'd as I was in France, I would abate
line 20195-->    her nothing, though I profess myself her adorer, not her friend.
line 20196-->  IACHIMO. As fair and as good- a kind of hand-in-hand comparison-
line 20197-->    had been something too fair and too good for any lady in Britain.
line 20198-->    If she went before others I have seen as that diamond of yours
line 20199-->    outlustres many I have beheld, I could not but believe she
line 20200-->    excelled many; but I have not seen the most precious diamond that
line 20201-->    is, nor you the lady.
line 20202-->  POSTHUMUS. I prais'd her as I rated her. So do I my stone.
line 20203-->  IACHIMO. What do you esteem it at?
line 20204-->  POSTHUMUS. More than the world enjoys.
line 20205-->  IACHIMO. Either your unparagon'd mistress is dead, or she's
line 20206-->    outpriz'd by a trifle.
line 20207-->  POSTHUMUS. You are mistaken: the one may be sold or given, if there
line 20208-->    were wealth enough for the purchase or merit for the gift; the
line 20209-->    other is not a thing for sale, and only the gift of the gods.
line 20210-->  IACHIMO. Which the gods have given you?
line 20211-->  POSTHUMUS. Which by their graces I will keep.
line 20212-->  IACHIMO. You may wear her in title yours; but you know strange fowl
line 20213-->    light upon neighbouring ponds. Your ring may be stol'n too. So  
line 20214-->    your brace of unprizable estimations, the one is but frail and
line 20215-->    the other casual; a cunning thief, or a that-way-accomplish'd
line 20216-->    courtier, would hazard the winning both of first and last.
line 20217-->  POSTHUMUS. Your Italy contains none so accomplish'd a courtier to
line 20218-->    convince the honour of my mistress, if in the holding or loss of
line 20219-->    that you term her frail. I do nothing doubt you have store of
line 20220-->    thieves; notwithstanding, I fear not my ring.
line 20221-->  PHILARIO. Let us leave here, gentlemen.
line 20222-->  POSTHUMUS. Sir, with all my heart. This worthy signior, I thank
line 20223-->    him, makes no stranger of me; we are familiar at first.
line 20224-->  IACHIMO. With five times so much conversation I should get ground
line 20225-->    of your fair mistress; make her go back even to the yielding, had
line 20226-->    I admittance and opportunity to friend.
line 20227-->  POSTHUMUS. No, no.
line 20228-->  IACHIMO. I dare thereupon pawn the moiety of my estate to your
line 20229-->    ring, which, in my opinion, o'ervalues it something. But I make
line 20230-->    my wager rather against your confidence than her reputation; and,
line 20231-->    to bar your offence herein too, I durst attempt it against any
line 20232-->    lady in the world.
line 20233-->  POSTHUMUS. You are a great deal abus'd in too bold a persuasion,  
line 20234-->    and I doubt not you sustain what y'are worthy of by your attempt.
line 20235-->  IACHIMO. What's that?
line 20236-->  POSTHUMUS. A repulse; though your attempt, as you call it, deserve
line 20237-->    more- a punishment too.
line 20238-->  PHILARIO. Gentlemen, enough of this. It came in too suddenly; let
line 20239-->    it die as it was born, and I pray you be better acquainted.
line 20240-->  IACHIMO. Would I had put my estate and my neighbour's on th'
line 20241-->    approbation of what I have spoke!
line 20242-->  POSTHUMUS. What lady would you choose to assail?
line 20243-->  IACHIMO. Yours, whom in constancy you think stands so safe. I will
line 20244-->    lay you ten thousand ducats to your ring that, commend me to the
line 20245-->    court where your lady is, with no more advantage than the
line 20246-->    opportunity of a second conference, and I will bring from thence
line 20247-->    that honour of hers which you imagine so reserv'd.
line 20248-->  POSTHUMUS. I will wage against your gold, gold to it. My ring I
line 20249-->    hold dear as my finger; 'tis part of it.
line 20250-->  IACHIMO. You are a friend, and therein the wiser. If you buy
line 20251-->    ladies' flesh at a million a dram, you cannot preserve it from
line 20252-->    tainting. But I see you have some religion in you, that you fear.
line 20253-->  POSTHUMUS. This is but a custom in your tongue; you bear a graver  
line 20254-->    purpose, I hope.
line 20255-->  IACHIMO. I am the master of my speeches, and would undergo what's
line 20256-->    spoken, I swear.
line 20257-->  POSTHUMUS. Will you? I Shall but lend my diamond till your return.
line 20258-->    Let there be covenants drawn between's. My mistress exceeds in
line 20259-->    goodness the hugeness of your unworthy thinking. I dare you to
line 20260-->    this match: here's my ring.
line 20261-->  PHILARIO. I will have it no lay.
line 20262-->  IACHIMO. By the gods, it is one. If I bring you no sufficient
line 20263-->    testimony that I have enjoy'd the dearest bodily part of your
line 20264-->    mistress, my ten thousand ducats are yours; so is your diamond
line 20265-->    too. If I come off, and leave her in such honour as you have
line 20266-->    trust in, she your jewel, this your jewel, and my gold are yours-
line 20267-->    provided I have your commendation for my more free entertainment.
line 20268-->  POSTHUMUS. I embrace these conditions; let us have articles betwixt
line 20269-->    us. Only, thus far you shall answer: if you make your voyage upon
line 20270-->    her, and give me directly to understand you have prevail'd, I am
line 20271-->    no further your enemy- she is not worth our debate; if she remain
line 20272-->    unseduc'd, you not making it appear otherwise, for your ill
line 20273-->    opinion and th' assault you have made to her chastity you shall  
line 20274-->    answer me with your sword.
line 20275-->  IACHIMO. Your hand- a covenant! We will have these things set down
line 20276-->    by lawful counsel, and straight away for Britain, lest the
line 20277-->    bargain should catch cold and starve. I will fetch my gold and
line 20278-->    have our two wagers recorded.
line 20279-->  POSTHUMUS. Agreed.                Exeunt POSTHUMUS and IACHIMO
line 20280-->  FRENCHMAN. Will this hold, think you?
line 20281-->  PHILARIO. Signior Iachimo will not from it. Pray let us follow 'em.
line 20282-->                                                          Exeunt
line 20283-->
line 20284-->
line 20285-->
line 20286-->
line 20287-->SCENE V.
line 20288-->Britain. CYMBELINE'S palace
line 20289-->
line 20290-->Enter QUEEN, LADIES, and CORNELIUS
line 20291-->
line 20292-->  QUEEN. Whiles yet the dew's on ground, gather those flowers;
line 20293-->    Make haste; who has the note of them?
line 20294-->  LADY. I, madam.
line 20295-->  QUEEN. Dispatch.                                 Exeunt LADIES
line 20296-->    Now, Master Doctor, have you brought those drugs?
line 20297-->  CORNELIUS. Pleaseth your Highness, ay. Here they are, madam.
line 20298-->                                              [Presenting a box]
line 20299-->    But I beseech your Grace, without offence-
line 20300-->    My conscience bids me ask- wherefore you have
line 20301-->    Commanded of me these most poisonous compounds
line 20302-->    Which are the movers of a languishing death,
line 20303-->    But, though slow, deadly?
line 20304-->  QUEEN. I wonder, Doctor,
line 20305-->    Thou ask'st me such a question. Have I not been
line 20306-->    Thy pupil long? Hast thou not learn'd me how
line 20307-->    To make perfumes? distil? preserve? yea, so
line 20308-->    That our great king himself doth woo me oft  
line 20309-->    For my confections? Having thus far proceeded-
line 20310-->    Unless thou think'st me devilish- is't not meet
line 20311-->    That I did amplify my judgment in
line 20312-->    Other conclusions? I will try the forces
line 20313-->    Of these thy compounds on such creatures as
line 20314-->    We count not worth the hanging- but none human-
line 20315-->    To try the vigour of them, and apply
line 20316-->    Allayments to their act, and by them gather
line 20317-->    Their several virtues and effects.
line 20318-->  CORNELIUS. Your Highness
line 20319-->    Shall from this practice but make hard your heart;
line 20320-->    Besides, the seeing these effects will be
line 20321-->    Both noisome and infectious.
line 20322-->  QUEEN. O, content thee.
line 20323-->
line 20324-->                        Enter PISANIO
line 20325-->
line 20326-->    [Aside] Here comes a flattering rascal; upon him
line 20327-->    Will I first work. He's for his master,
line 20328-->    An enemy to my son.- How now, Pisanio!  
line 20329-->    Doctor, your service for this time is ended;
line 20330-->    Take your own way.
line 20331-->  CORNELIUS. [Aside] I do suspect you, madam;
line 20332-->    But you shall do no harm.
line 20333-->  QUEEN. [To PISANIO] Hark thee, a word.
line 20334-->  CORNELIUS. [Aside] I do not like her. She doth think she has
line 20335-->    Strange ling'ring poisons. I do know her spirit,
line 20336-->    And will not trust one of her malice with
line 20337-->    A drug of such damn'd nature. Those she has
line 20338-->    Will stupefy and dull the sense awhile,
line 20339-->    Which first perchance she'll prove on cats and dogs,
line 20340-->    Then afterward up higher; but there is
line 20341-->    No danger in what show of death it makes,
line 20342-->    More than the locking up the spirits a time,
line 20343-->    To be more fresh, reviving. She is fool'd
line 20344-->    With a most false effect; and I the truer
line 20345-->    So to be false with her.
line 20346-->  QUEEN. No further service, Doctor,
line 20347-->    Until I send for thee.
line 20348-->  CORNELIUS. I humbly take my leave.                        Exit  
line 20349-->  QUEEN. Weeps she still, say'st thou? Dost thou think in time
line 20350-->    She will not quench, and let instructions enter
line 20351-->    Where folly now possesses? Do thou work.
line 20352-->    When thou shalt bring me word she loves my son,
line 20353-->    I'll tell thee on the instant thou art then
line 20354-->    As great as is thy master; greater, for
line 20355-->    His fortunes all lie speechless, and his name
line 20356-->    Is at last gasp. Return he cannot, nor
line 20357-->    Continue where he is. To shift his being
line 20358-->    Is to exchange one misery with another,
line 20359-->    And every day that comes comes comes to
line 20360-->    A day's work in him. What shalt thou expect
line 20361-->    To be depender on a thing that leans,
line 20362-->    Who cannot be new built, nor has no friends
line 20363-->    So much as but to prop him?
line 20364-->                  [The QUEEN drops the box. PISANIO takes it up]
line 20365-->    Thou tak'st up
line 20366-->    Thou know'st not what; but take it for thy labour.
line 20367-->    It is a thing I made, which hath the King
line 20368-->    Five times redeem'd from death. I do not know  
line 20369-->    What is more cordial. Nay, I prithee take it;
line 20370-->    It is an earnest of a further good
line 20371-->    That I mean to thee. Tell thy mistress how
line 20372-->    The case stands with her; do't as from thyself.
line 20373-->    Think what a chance thou changest on; but think
line 20374-->    Thou hast thy mistress still; to boot, my son,
line 20375-->    Who shall take notice of thee. I'll move the King
line 20376-->    To any shape of thy preferment, such
line 20377-->    As thou'lt desire; and then myself, I chiefly,
line 20378-->    That set thee on to this desert, am bound
line 20379-->    To load thy merit richly. Call my women.
line 20380-->    Think on my words.                              Exit PISANIO
line 20381-->    A sly and constant knave,
line 20382-->    Not to be shak'd; the agent for his master,
line 20383-->    And the remembrancer of her to hold
line 20384-->    The hand-fast to her lord. I have given him that
line 20385-->    Which, if he take, shall quite unpeople her
line 20386-->    Of leigers for her sweet; and which she after,
line 20387-->    Except she bend her humour, shall be assur'd
line 20388-->    To taste of too.  
line 20389-->
line 20390-->                   Re-enter PISANIO and LADIES
line 20391-->
line 20392-->    So, so. Well done, well done.
line 20393-->    The violets, cowslips, and the primroses,
line 20394-->    Bear to my closet. Fare thee well, Pisanio;
line 20395-->    Think on my words.                   Exeunt QUEEN and LADIES
line 20396-->  PISANIO. And shall do.
line 20397-->    But when to my good lord I prove untrue
line 20398-->    I'll choke myself- there's all I'll do for you.         Exit
line 20399-->
line 20400-->
line 20401-->
line 20402-->
line 20403-->SCENE VI.
line 20404-->Britain. The palace
line 20405-->
line 20406-->Enter IMOGEN alone
line 20407-->
line 20408-->  IMOGEN. A father cruel and a step-dame false;
line 20409-->    A foolish suitor to a wedded lady
line 20410-->    That hath her husband banish'd. O, that husband!
line 20411-->    My supreme crown of grief! and those repeated
line 20412-->    Vexations of it! Had I been thief-stol'n,
line 20413-->    As my two brothers, happy! but most miserable
line 20414-->    Is the desire that's glorious. Blessed be those,
line 20415-->    How mean soe'er, that have their honest wills,
line 20416-->    Which seasons comfort. Who may this be? Fie!
line 20417-->
line 20418-->                    Enter PISANIO and IACHIMO
line 20419-->
line 20420-->  PISANIO. Madam, a noble gentleman of Rome
line 20421-->    Comes from my lord with letters.
line 20422-->  IACHIMO. Change you, madam?
line 20423-->    The worthy Leonatus is in safety,
line 20424-->    And greets your Highness dearly.         [Presents a letter]  
line 20425-->  IMOGEN. Thanks, good sir.
line 20426-->    You're kindly welcome.
line 20427-->  IACHIMO. [Aside] All of her that is out of door most rich!
line 20428-->    If she be furnish'd with a mind so rare,
line 20429-->    She is alone th' Arabian bird, and I
line 20430-->    Have lost the wager. Boldness be my friend!
line 20431-->    Arm me, audacity, from head to foot!
line 20432-->    Or, like the Parthian, I shall flying fight;
line 20433-->    Rather, directly fly.
line 20434-->  IMOGEN. [Reads] 'He is one of the noblest note, to whose
line 20435-->    kindnesses I am most infinitely tied. Reflect upon him
line 20436-->    accordingly, as you value your trust.       LEONATUS.'
line 20437-->
line 20438-->    So far I read aloud;
line 20439-->    But even the very middle of my heart
line 20440-->    Is warm'd by th' rest and takes it thankfully.
line 20441-->    You are as welcome, worthy sir, as I
line 20442-->    Have words to bid you; and shall find it so
line 20443-->    In all that I can do.
line 20444-->  IACHIMO. Thanks, fairest lady.  
line 20445-->    What, are men mad? Hath nature given them eyes
line 20446-->    To see this vaulted arch and the rich crop
line 20447-->    Of sea and land, which can distinguish 'twixt
line 20448-->    The fiery orbs above and the twinn'd stones
line 20449-->    Upon the number'd beach, and can we not
line 20450-->    Partition make with spectacles so precious
line 20451-->    'Twixt fair and foul?
line 20452-->  IMOGEN. What makes your admiration?
line 20453-->  IACHIMO. It cannot be i' th' eye, for apes and monkeys,
line 20454-->    'Twixt two such shes, would chatter this way and
line 20455-->    Contemn with mows the other; nor i' th' judgment,
line 20456-->    For idiots in this case of favour would
line 20457-->    Be wisely definite; nor i' th' appetite;
line 20458-->    Sluttery, to such neat excellence oppos'd,
line 20459-->    Should make desire vomit emptiness,
line 20460-->    Not so allur'd to feed.
line 20461-->  IMOGEN. What is the matter, trow?
line 20462-->  IACHIMO. The cloyed will-
line 20463-->    That satiate yet unsatisfied desire, that tub
line 20464-->    Both fill'd and running- ravening first the lamb,  
line 20465-->    Longs after for the garbage.
line 20466-->  IMOGEN. What, dear sir,
line 20467-->    Thus raps you? Are you well?
line 20468-->  IACHIMO. Thanks, madam; well.- Beseech you, sir,
line 20469-->    Desire my man's abode where I did leave him.
line 20470-->    He's strange and peevish.
line 20471-->  PISANIO. I was going, sir,
line 20472-->    To give him welcome.                                    Exit
line 20473-->  IMOGEN. Continues well my lord? His health beseech you?
line 20474-->  IACHIMO. Well, madam.
line 20475-->  IMOGEN. Is he dispos'd to mirth? I hope he is.
line 20476-->  IACHIMO. Exceeding pleasant; none a stranger there
line 20477-->    So merry and so gamesome. He is call'd
line 20478-->    The Britain reveller.
line 20479-->  IMOGEN. When he was here
line 20480-->    He did incline to sadness, and oft-times
line 20481-->    Not knowing why.
line 20482-->  IACHIMO. I never saw him sad.
line 20483-->    There is a Frenchman his companion, one
line 20484-->    An eminent monsieur that, it seems, much loves  
line 20485-->    A Gallian girl at home. He furnaces
line 20486-->    The thick sighs from him; whiles the jolly Briton-
line 20487-->    Your lord, I mean- laughs from's free lungs, cries 'O,
line 20488-->    Can my sides hold, to think that man- who knows
line 20489-->    By history, report, or his own proof,
line 20490-->    What woman is, yea, what she cannot choose
line 20491-->    But must be- will's free hours languish for
line 20492-->    Assured bondage?'
line 20493-->  IMOGEN. Will my lord say so?
line 20494-->  IACHIMO. Ay, madam, with his eyes in flood with laughter.
line 20495-->    It is a recreation to be by
line 20496-->    And hear him mock the Frenchman. But heavens know
line 20497-->    Some men are much to blame.
line 20498-->  IMOGEN. Not he, I hope.
line 20499-->  IACHIMO. Not he; but yet heaven's bounty towards him might
line 20500-->    Be us'd more thankfully. In himself, 'tis much;
line 20501-->    In you, which I account his, beyond all talents.
line 20502-->    Whilst I am bound to wonder, I am bound
line 20503-->    To pity too.
line 20504-->  IMOGEN. What do you pity, sir?  
line 20505-->  IACHIMO. Two creatures heartily.
line 20506-->  IMOGEN. Am I one, sir?
line 20507-->    You look on me: what wreck discern you in me
line 20508-->    Deserves your pity?
line 20509-->  IACHIMO. Lamentable! What,
line 20510-->    To hide me from the radiant sun and solace
line 20511-->    I' th' dungeon by a snuff?
line 20512-->  IMOGEN. I pray you, sir,
line 20513-->    Deliver with more openness your answers
line 20514-->    To my demands. Why do you pity me?
line 20515-->  IACHIMO. That others do,
line 20516-->    I was about to say, enjoy your- But
line 20517-->    It is an office of the gods to venge it,
line 20518-->    Not mine to speak on't.
line 20519-->  IMOGEN. You do seem to know
line 20520-->    Something of me, or what concerns me; pray you-
line 20521-->    Since doubting things go ill often hurts more
line 20522-->    Than to be sure they do; for certainties
line 20523-->    Either are past remedies, or, timely knowing,
line 20524-->    The remedy then born- discover to me  
line 20525-->    What both you spur and stop.
line 20526-->  IACHIMO. Had I this cheek
line 20527-->    To bathe my lips upon; this hand, whose touch,
line 20528-->    Whose every touch, would force the feeler's soul
line 20529-->    To th' oath of loyalty; this object, which
line 20530-->    Takes prisoner the wild motion of mine eye,
line 20531-->    Fixing it only here; should I, damn'd then,
line 20532-->    Slaver with lips as common as the stairs
line 20533-->    That mount the Capitol; join gripes with hands
line 20534-->    Made hard with hourly falsehood- falsehood as
line 20535-->    With labour; then by-peeping in an eye
line 20536-->    Base and illustrious as the smoky light
line 20537-->    That's fed with stinking tallow- it were fit
line 20538-->    That all the plagues of hell should at one time
line 20539-->    Encounter such revolt.
line 20540-->  IMOGEN. My lord, I fear,
line 20541-->    Has forgot Britain.
line 20542-->  IACHIMO. And himself. Not I
line 20543-->    Inclin'd to this intelligence pronounce
line 20544-->    The beggary of his change; but 'tis your graces  
line 20545-->    That from my mutest conscience to my tongue
line 20546-->    Charms this report out.
line 20547-->  IMOGEN. Let me hear no more.
line 20548-->  IACHIMO. O dearest soul, your cause doth strike my heart
line 20549-->    With pity that doth make me sick! A lady
line 20550-->    So fair, and fasten'd to an empery,
line 20551-->    Would make the great'st king double, to be partner'd
line 20552-->    With tomboys hir'd with that self exhibition
line 20553-->    Which your own coffers yield! with diseas'd ventures
line 20554-->    That play with all infirmities for gold
line 20555-->    Which rottenness can lend nature! such boil'd stuff
line 20556-->    As well might poison poison! Be reveng'd;
line 20557-->    Or she that bore you was no queen, and you
line 20558-->    Recoil from your great stock.
line 20559-->  IMOGEN. Reveng'd?
line 20560-->    How should I be reveng'd? If this be true-
line 20561-->    As I have such a heart that both mine ears
line 20562-->    Must not in haste abuse- if it be true,
line 20563-->    How should I be reveng'd?
line 20564-->  IACHIMO. Should he make me  
line 20565-->    Live like Diana's priest betwixt cold sheets,
line 20566-->    Whiles he is vaulting variable ramps,
line 20567-->    In your despite, upon your purse? Revenge it.
line 20568-->    I dedicate myself to your sweet pleasure,
line 20569-->    More noble than that runagate to your bed,
line 20570-->    And will continue fast to your affection,
line 20571-->    Still close as sure.
line 20572-->  IMOGEN. What ho, Pisanio!
line 20573-->  IACHIMO. Let me my service tender on your lips.
line 20574-->  IMOGEN. Away! I do condemn mine ears that have
line 20575-->    So long attended thee. If thou wert honourable,
line 20576-->    Thou wouldst have told this tale for virtue, not
line 20577-->    For such an end thou seek'st, as base as strange.
line 20578-->    Thou wrong'st a gentleman who is as far
line 20579-->    From thy report as thou from honour; and
line 20580-->    Solicits here a lady that disdains
line 20581-->    Thee and the devil alike.- What ho, Pisanio!-
line 20582-->    The King my father shall be made acquainted
line 20583-->    Of thy assault. If he shall think it fit
line 20584-->    A saucy stranger in his court to mart  
line 20585-->    As in a Romish stew, and to expound
line 20586-->    His beastly mind to us, he hath a court
line 20587-->    He little cares for, and a daughter who
line 20588-->    He not respects at all.- What ho, Pisanio!
line 20589-->  IACHIMO. O happy Leonatus! I may say
line 20590-->    The credit that thy lady hath of thee
line 20591-->    Deserves thy trust, and thy most perfect goodness
line 20592-->    Her assur'd credit. Blessed live you long,
line 20593-->    A lady to the worthiest sir that ever
line 20594-->    Country call'd his! and you his mistress, only
line 20595-->    For the most worthiest fit! Give me your pardon.
line 20596-->    I have spoke this to know if your affiance
line 20597-->    Were deeply rooted, and shall make your lord
line 20598-->    That which he is new o'er; and he is one
line 20599-->    The truest manner'd, such a holy witch
line 20600-->    That he enchants societies into him,
line 20601-->    Half all men's hearts are his.
line 20602-->  IMOGEN. You make amends.
line 20603-->  IACHIMO. He sits 'mongst men like a descended god:
line 20604-->    He hath a kind of honour sets him of  
line 20605-->    More than a mortal seeming. Be not angry,
line 20606-->    Most mighty Princess, that I have adventur'd
line 20607-->    To try your taking of a false report, which hath
line 20608-->    Honour'd with confirmation your great judgment
line 20609-->    In the election of a sir so rare,
line 20610-->    Which you know cannot err. The love I bear him
line 20611-->    Made me to fan you thus; but the gods made you,
line 20612-->    Unlike all others, chaffless. Pray your pardon.
line 20613-->  IMOGEN. All's well, sir; take my pow'r i' th' court for yours.
line 20614-->  IACHIMO. My humble thanks. I had almost forgot
line 20615-->    T' entreat your Grace but in a small request,
line 20616-->    And yet of moment too, for it concerns
line 20617-->    Your lord; myself and other noble friends
line 20618-->    Are partners in the business.
line 20619-->  IMOGEN. Pray what is't?
line 20620-->  IACHIMO. Some dozen Romans of us, and your lord-
line 20621-->    The best feather of our wing- have mingled sums
line 20622-->    To buy a present for the Emperor;
line 20623-->    Which I, the factor for the rest, have done
line 20624-->    In France. 'Tis plate of rare device, and jewels  
line 20625-->    Of rich and exquisite form, their values great;
line 20626-->    And I am something curious, being strange,
line 20627-->    To have them in safe stowage. May it please you
line 20628-->    To take them in protection?
line 20629-->  IMOGEN. Willingly;
line 20630-->    And pawn mine honour for their safety. Since
line 20631-->    My lord hath interest in them, I will keep them
line 20632-->    In my bedchamber.
line 20633-->  IACHIMO. They are in a trunk,
line 20634-->    Attended by my men. I will make bold
line 20635-->    To send them to you only for this night;
line 20636-->    I must aboard to-morrow.
line 20637-->  IMOGEN. O, no, no.
line 20638-->  IACHIMO. Yes, I beseech; or I shall short my word
line 20639-->    By length'ning my return. From Gallia
line 20640-->    I cross'd the seas on purpose and on promise
line 20641-->    To see your Grace.
line 20642-->  IMOGEN. I thank you for your pains.
line 20643-->    But not away to-morrow!
line 20644-->  IACHIMO. O, I must, madam.  
line 20645-->    Therefore I shall beseech you, if you please
line 20646-->    To greet your lord with writing, do't to-night.
line 20647-->    I have outstood my time, which is material
line 20648-->    'To th' tender of our present.
line 20649-->  IMOGEN. I will write.
line 20650-->    Send your trunk to me; it shall safe be kept
line 20651-->    And truly yielded you. You're very welcome.           Exeunt
line 20652-->
