line 20665-->
line 20666-->
line 20667-->ACT II. SCENE I.
line 20668-->Britain. Before CYMBELINE'S palace
line 20669-->
line 20670-->Enter CLOTEN and the two LORDS
line 20671-->
line 20672-->  CLOTEN. Was there ever man had such luck! When I kiss'd the jack,
line 20673-->    upon an up-cast to be hit away! I had a hundred pound on't; and
line 20674-->    then a whoreson jackanapes must take me up for swearing, as if I
line 20675-->    borrowed mine oaths of him, and might not spend them at my
line 20676-->    pleasure.
line 20677-->  FIRST LORD. What got he by that? You have broke his pate with your
line 20678-->    bowl.
line 20679-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] If his wit had been like him that broke it, it
line 20680-->    would have run all out.
line 20681-->  CLOTEN. When a gentleman is dispos'd to swear, it is not for any
line 20682-->    standers-by to curtail his oaths. Ha?
line 20683-->  SECOND LORD. No, my lord; [Aside] nor crop the ears of them.
line 20684-->  CLOTEN. Whoreson dog! I give him satisfaction? Would he had been
line 20685-->    one of my rank!
line 20686-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] To have smell'd like a fool.
line 20687-->  CLOTEN. I am not vex'd more at anything in th' earth. A pox on't! I
line 20688-->    had rather not be so noble as I am; they dare not fight with me,  
line 20689-->    because of the Queen my mother. Every jackslave hath his bellyful
line 20690-->    of fighting, and I must go up and down like a cock that nobody
line 20691-->    can match.
line 20692-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] You are cock and capon too; and you crow,
line 20693-->    cock, with your comb on.
line 20694-->  CLOTEN. Sayest thou?
line 20695-->  SECOND LORD. It is not fit your lordship should undertake every
line 20696-->    companion that you give offence to.
line 20697-->  CLOTEN. No, I know that; but it is fit I should commit offence to
line 20698-->    my inferiors.
line 20699-->  SECOND LORD. Ay, it is fit for your lordship only.
line 20700-->  CLOTEN. Why, so I say.
line 20701-->  FIRST LORD. Did you hear of a stranger that's come to court
line 20702-->    to-night?
line 20703-->  CLOTEN. A stranger, and I not known on't?
line 20704-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] He's a strange fellow himself, and knows it
line 20705-->    not.
line 20706-->  FIRST LORD. There's an Italian come, and, 'tis thought, one of
line 20707-->    Leonatus' friends.
line 20708-->  CLOTEN. Leonatus? A banish'd rascal; and he's another, whatsoever  
line 20709-->    he be. Who told you of this stranger?
line 20710-->  FIRST LORD. One of your lordship's pages.
line 20711-->  CLOTEN. Is it fit I went to look upon him? Is there no derogation
line 20712-->    in't?
line 20713-->  SECOND LORD. You cannot derogate, my lord.
line 20714-->  CLOTEN. Not easily, I think.
line 20715-->  SECOND LORD. [Aside] You are a fool granted; therefore your issues,
line 20716-->    being foolish, do not derogate.
line 20717-->  CLOTEN. Come, I'll go see this Italian. What I have lost to-day at
line 20718-->    bowls I'll win to-night of him. Come, go.
line 20719-->  SECOND LORD. I'll attend your lordship.
line 20720-->                                    Exeunt CLOTEN and FIRST LORD
line 20721-->    That such a crafty devil as is his mother
line 20722-->    Should yield the world this ass! A woman that
line 20723-->    Bears all down with her brain; and this her son
line 20724-->    Cannot take two from twenty, for his heart,
line 20725-->    And leave eighteen. Alas, poor princess,
line 20726-->    Thou divine Imogen, what thou endur'st,
line 20727-->    Betwixt a father by thy step-dame govern'd,
line 20728-->    A mother hourly coining plots, a wooer  
line 20729-->    More hateful than the foul expulsion is
line 20730-->    Of thy dear husband, than that horrid act
line 20731-->    Of the divorce he'd make! The heavens hold firm
line 20732-->    The walls of thy dear honour, keep unshak'd
line 20733-->    That temple, thy fair mind, that thou mayst stand
line 20734-->    T' enjoy thy banish'd lord and this great land!         Exit
line 20735-->
line 20736-->
line 20737-->
line 20738-->
line 20739-->SCENE II.
line 20740-->Britain. IMOGEN'S bedchamber in CYMBELINE'S palace; a trunk in one corner
line 20741-->
line 20742-->Enter IMOGEN in her bed, and a LADY attending
line 20743-->
line 20744-->  IMOGEN. Who's there? My woman? Helen?
line 20745-->  LADY. Please you, madam.
line 20746-->  IMOGEN. What hour is it?
line 20747-->  LADY. Almost midnight, madam.
line 20748-->  IMOGEN. I have read three hours then. Mine eyes are weak;
line 20749-->    Fold down the leaf where I have left. To bed.
line 20750-->    Take not away the taper, leave it burning;
line 20751-->    And if thou canst awake by four o' th' clock,
line 20752-->    I prithee call me. Sleep hath seiz'd me wholly.    Exit LADY
line 20753-->    To your protection I commend me, gods.
line 20754-->    From fairies and the tempters of the night
line 20755-->    Guard me, beseech ye!
line 20756-->                          [Sleeps. IACHIMO comes from the trunk]
line 20757-->  IACHIMO. The crickets sing, and man's o'er-labour'd sense
line 20758-->    Repairs itself by rest. Our Tarquin thus
line 20759-->    Did softly press the rushes ere he waken'd  
line 20760-->    The chastity he wounded. Cytherea,
line 20761-->    How bravely thou becom'st thy bed! fresh lily,
line 20762-->    And whiter than the sheets! That I might touch!
line 20763-->    But kiss; one kiss! Rubies unparagon'd,
line 20764-->    How dearly they do't! 'Tis her breathing that
line 20765-->    Perfumes the chamber thus. The flame o' th' taper
line 20766-->    Bows toward her and would under-peep her lids
line 20767-->    To see th' enclosed lights, now canopied
line 20768-->    Under these windows white and azure, lac'd
line 20769-->    With blue of heaven's own tinct. But my design
line 20770-->    To note the chamber. I will write all down:
line 20771-->    Such and such pictures; there the window; such
line 20772-->    Th' adornment of her bed; the arras, figures-
line 20773-->    Why, such and such; and the contents o' th' story.
line 20774-->    Ah, but some natural notes about her body
line 20775-->    Above ten thousand meaner movables
line 20776-->    Would testify, t' enrich mine inventory.
line 20777-->    O sleep, thou ape of death, lie dull upon her!
line 20778-->    And be her sense but as a monument,
line 20779-->    Thus in a chapel lying! Come off, come off;  
line 20780-->                                       [Taking off her bracelet]
line 20781-->    As slippery as the Gordian knot was hard!
line 20782-->    'Tis mine; and this will witness outwardly,
line 20783-->    As strongly as the conscience does within,
line 20784-->    To th' madding of her lord. On her left breast
line 20785-->    A mole cinque-spotted, like the crimson drops
line 20786-->    I' th' bottom of a cowslip. Here's a voucher
line 20787-->    Stronger than ever law could make; this secret
line 20788-->    Will force him think I have pick'd the lock and ta'en
line 20789-->    The treasure of her honour. No more. To what end?
line 20790-->    Why should I write this down that's riveted,
line 20791-->    Screw'd to my memory? She hath been reading late
line 20792-->    The tale of Tereus; here the leaf's turn'd down
line 20793-->    Where Philomel gave up. I have enough.
line 20794-->    To th' trunk again, and shut the spring of it.
line 20795-->    Swift, swift, you dragons of the night, that dawning
line 20796-->    May bare the raven's eye! I lodge in fear;
line 20797-->    Though this a heavenly angel, hell is here.  [Clock strikes]
line 20798-->    One, two, three. Time, time!             Exit into the trunk
line 20799-->
line 20800-->
line 20801-->
line 20802-->
line 20803-->SCENE III.
line 20804-->CYMBELINE'S palace. An ante-chamber adjoining IMOGEN'S apartments
line 20805-->
line 20806-->Enter CLOTEN and LORDS
line 20807-->
line 20808-->  FIRST LORD. Your lordship is the most patient man in loss, the most
line 20809-->    coldest that ever turn'd up ace.
line 20810-->  CLOTEN. It would make any man cold to lose.
line 20811-->  FIRST LORD. But not every man patient after the noble temper of
line 20812-->    your lordship. You are most hot and furious when you win.
line 20813-->  CLOTEN. Winning will put any man into courage. If I could get this
line 20814-->    foolish Imogen, I should have gold enough. It's almost morning,
line 20815-->    is't not?
line 20816-->  FIRST LORD. Day, my lord.
line 20817-->  CLOTEN. I would this music would come. I am advised to give her
line 20818-->    music a mornings; they say it will penetrate.
line 20819-->
line 20820-->                       Enter musicians
line 20821-->
line 20822-->    Come on, tune. If you can penetrate her with your fingering, so.
line 20823-->    We'll try with tongue too. If none will do, let her remain; but  
line 20824-->    I'll never give o'er. First, a very excellent good-conceited
line 20825-->    thing; after, a wonderful sweet air, with admirable rich words to
line 20826-->    it- and then let her consider.
line 20827-->
line 20828-->                 SONG
line 20829-->
line 20830-->      Hark, hark! the lark at heaven's gate sings,
line 20831-->        And Phoebus 'gins arise,
line 20832-->      His steeds to water at those springs
line 20833-->        On chalic'd flow'rs that lies;
line 20834-->      And winking Mary-buds begin
line 20835-->        To ope their golden eyes.
line 20836-->      With everything that pretty bin,
line 20837-->        My lady sweet, arise;
line 20838-->          Arise, arise!
line 20839-->
line 20840-->    So, get you gone. If this penetrate, I will consider your music
line 20841-->    the better; if it do not, it is a vice in her ears which
line 20842-->    horsehairs and calves' guts, nor the voice of unpaved eunuch to
line 20843-->    boot, can never amend.                      Exeunt musicians  
line 20844-->
line 20845-->                    Enter CYMBELINE and QUEEN
line 20846-->
line 20847-->  SECOND LORD. Here comes the King.
line 20848-->  CLOTEN. I am glad I was up so late, for that's the reason I was up
line 20849-->    so early. He cannot choose but take this service I have done
line 20850-->    fatherly.- Good morrow to your Majesty and to my gracious mother.
line 20851-->  CYMBELINE. Attend you here the door of our stern daughter?
line 20852-->    Will she not forth?
line 20853-->  CLOTEN. I have assail'd her with musics, but she vouchsafes no
line 20854-->    notice.
line 20855-->  CYMBELINE. The exile of her minion is too new;
line 20856-->    She hath not yet forgot him; some more time
line 20857-->    Must wear the print of his remembrance out,
line 20858-->    And then she's yours.
line 20859-->  QUEEN. You are most bound to th' King,
line 20860-->    Who lets go by no vantages that may
line 20861-->    Prefer you to his daughter. Frame yourself
line 20862-->    To orderly soliciting, and be friended
line 20863-->    With aptness of the season; make denials  
line 20864-->    Increase your services; so seem as if
line 20865-->    You were inspir'd to do those duties which
line 20866-->    You tender to her; that you in all obey her,
line 20867-->    Save when command to your dismission tends,
line 20868-->    And therein you are senseless.
line 20869-->  CLOTEN. Senseless? Not so.
line 20870-->
line 20871-->                    Enter a MESSENGER
line 20872-->
line 20873-->  MESSENGER. So like you, sir, ambassadors from Rome;
line 20874-->    The one is Caius Lucius.
line 20875-->  CYMBELINE. A worthy fellow,
line 20876-->    Albeit he comes on angry purpose now;
line 20877-->    But that's no fault of his. We must receive him
line 20878-->    According to the honour of his sender;
line 20879-->    And towards himself, his goodness forespent on us,
line 20880-->    We must extend our notice. Our dear son,
line 20881-->    When you have given good morning to your mistress,
line 20882-->    Attend the Queen and us; we shall have need
line 20883-->    T' employ you towards this Roman. Come, our queen.  
line 20884-->                                           Exeunt all but CLOTEN
line 20885-->  CLOTEN. If she be up, I'll speak with her; if not,
line 20886-->    Let her lie still and dream. By your leave, ho!     [Knocks]
line 20887-->    I know her women are about her; what
line 20888-->    If I do line one of their hands? 'Tis gold
line 20889-->    Which buys admittance; oft it doth-yea, and makes
line 20890-->    Diana's rangers false themselves, yield up
line 20891-->    Their deer to th' stand o' th' stealer; and 'tis gold
line 20892-->    Which makes the true man kill'd and saves the thief;
line 20893-->    Nay, sometime hangs both thief and true man. What
line 20894-->    Can it not do and undo? I will make
line 20895-->    One of her women lawyer to me, for
line 20896-->    I yet not understand the case myself.
line 20897-->    By your leave.                                      [Knocks]
line 20898-->
line 20899-->                            Enter a LADY
line 20900-->
line 20901-->  LADY. Who's there that knocks?
line 20902-->  CLOTEN. A gentleman.
line 20903-->  LADY. No more?  
line 20904-->  CLOTEN. Yes, and a gentlewoman's son.
line 20905-->  LADY. That's more
line 20906-->    Than some whose tailors are as dear as yours
line 20907-->    Can justly boast of. What's your lordship's pleasure?
line 20908-->  CLOTEN. Your lady's person; is she ready?
line 20909-->  LADY. Ay,
line 20910-->    To keep her chamber.
line 20911-->  CLOTEN. There is gold for you; sell me your good report.
line 20912-->  LADY. How? My good name? or to report of you
line 20913-->    What I shall think is good? The Princess!
line 20914-->
line 20915-->                        Enter IMOGEN
line 20916-->
line 20917-->  CLOTEN. Good morrow, fairest sister. Your sweet hand.
line 20918-->                                                       Exit LADY
line 20919-->  IMOGEN. Good morrow, sir. You lay out too much pains
line 20920-->    For purchasing but trouble. The thanks I give
line 20921-->    Is telling you that I am poor of thanks,
line 20922-->    And scarce can spare them.
line 20923-->  CLOTEN. Still I swear I love you.  
line 20924-->  IMOGEN. If you but said so, 'twere as deep with me.
line 20925-->    If you swear still, your recompense is still
line 20926-->    That I regard it not.
line 20927-->  CLOTEN. This is no answer.
line 20928-->  IMOGEN. But that you shall not say I yield, being silent,
line 20929-->    I would not speak. I pray you spare me. Faith,
line 20930-->    I shall unfold equal discourtesy
line 20931-->    To your best kindness; one of your great knowing
line 20932-->    Should learn, being taught, forbearance.
line 20933-->  CLOTEN. To leave you in your madness 'twere my sin;
line 20934-->    I will not.
line 20935-->  IMOGEN. Fools are not mad folks.
line 20936-->  CLOTEN. Do you call me fool?
line 20937-->  IMOGEN. As I am mad, I do;
line 20938-->    If you'll be patient, I'll no more be mad;
line 20939-->    That cures us both. I am much sorry, sir,
line 20940-->    You put me to forget a lady's manners
line 20941-->    By being so verbal; and learn now, for all,
line 20942-->    That I, which know my heart, do here pronounce,
line 20943-->    By th' very truth of it, I care not for you,  
line 20944-->    And am so near the lack of charity
line 20945-->    To accuse myself I hate you; which I had rather
line 20946-->    You felt than make't my boast.
line 20947-->  CLOTEN. You sin against
line 20948-->    Obedience, which you owe your father. For
line 20949-->    The contract you pretend with that base wretch,
line 20950-->    One bred of alms and foster'd with cold dishes,
line 20951-->    With scraps o' th' court- it is no contract, none.
line 20952-->    And though it be allowed in meaner parties-
line 20953-->    Yet who than he more mean?- to knit their souls-
line 20954-->    On whom there is no more dependency
line 20955-->    But brats and beggary- in self-figur'd knot,
line 20956-->    Yet you are curb'd from that enlargement by
line 20957-->    The consequence o' th' crown, and must not foil
line 20958-->    The precious note of it with a base slave,
line 20959-->    A hilding for a livery, a squire's cloth,
line 20960-->    A pantler- not so eminent!
line 20961-->  IMOGEN. Profane fellow!
line 20962-->    Wert thou the son of Jupiter, and no more
line 20963-->    But what thou art besides, thou wert too base  
line 20964-->    To be his groom. Thou wert dignified enough,
line 20965-->    Even to the point of envy, if 'twere made
line 20966-->    Comparative for your virtues to be styl'd
line 20967-->    The under-hangman of his kingdom, and hated
line 20968-->    For being preferr'd so well.
line 20969-->  CLOTEN. The south fog rot him!
line 20970-->  IMOGEN. He never can meet more mischance than come
line 20971-->    To be but nam'd of thee. His mean'st garment
line 20972-->    That ever hath but clipp'd his body is dearer
line 20973-->    In my respect than all the hairs above thee,
line 20974-->    Were they all made such men. How now, Pisanio!
line 20975-->
line 20976-->                    Enter PISANIO
line 20977-->
line 20978-->  CLOTEN. 'His garments'! Now the devil-
line 20979-->  IMOGEN. To Dorothy my woman hie thee presently.
line 20980-->  CLOTEN. 'His garment'!
line 20981-->  IMOGEN. I am sprited with a fool;
line 20982-->    Frighted, and ang'red worse. Go bid my woman
line 20983-->    Search for a jewel that too casually  
line 20984-->    Hath left mine arm. It was thy master's; shrew me,
line 20985-->    If I would lose it for a revenue
line 20986-->    Of any king's in Europe! I do think
line 20987-->    I saw't this morning; confident I am
line 20988-->    Last night 'twas on mine arm; I kiss'd it.
line 20989-->    I hope it be not gone to tell my lord
line 20990-->    That I kiss aught but he.
line 20991-->  PISANIO. 'Twill not be lost.
line 20992-->  IMOGEN. I hope so. Go and search.                 Exit PISANIO
line 20993-->  CLOTEN. You have abus'd me.
line 20994-->    'His meanest garment'!
line 20995-->  IMOGEN. Ay, I said so, sir.
line 20996-->    If you will make 't an action, call witness to 't.
line 20997-->  CLOTEN. I will inform your father.
line 20998-->  IMOGEN. Your mother too.
line 20999-->    She's my good lady and will conceive, I hope,
line 21000-->    But the worst of me. So I leave you, sir,
line 21001-->    To th' worst of discontent.                             Exit
line 21002-->  CLOTEN. I'll be reveng'd.
line 21003-->    'His mean'st garment'! Well.                            Exit
line 21004-->
line 21005-->
line 21006-->
line 21007-->
line 21008-->SCENE IV.
line 21009-->Rome. PHILARIO'S house
line 21010-->
line 21011-->Enter POSTHUMUS and PHILARIO
line 21012-->
line 21013-->  POSTHUMUS. Fear it not, sir; I would I were so sure
line 21014-->    To win the King as I am bold her honour
line 21015-->    Will remain hers.
line 21016-->  PHILARIO. What means do you make to him?
line 21017-->  POSTHUMUS. Not any; but abide the change of time,
line 21018-->    Quake in the present winter's state, and wish
line 21019-->    That warmer days would come. In these fear'd hopes
line 21020-->    I barely gratify your love; they failing,
line 21021-->    I must die much your debtor.
line 21022-->  PHILARIO. Your very goodness and your company
line 21023-->    O'erpays all I can do. By this your king
line 21024-->    Hath heard of great Augustus. Caius Lucius
line 21025-->    Will do's commission throughly; and I think
line 21026-->    He'll grant the tribute, send th' arrearages,
line 21027-->    Or look upon our Romans, whose remembrance
line 21028-->    Is yet fresh in their grief.
line 21029-->  POSTHUMUS. I do believe  
line 21030-->    Statist though I am none, nor like to be,
line 21031-->    That this will prove a war; and you shall hear
line 21032-->    The legions now in Gallia sooner landed
line 21033-->    In our not-fearing Britain than have tidings
line 21034-->    Of any penny tribute paid. Our countrymen
line 21035-->    Are men more order'd than when Julius Caesar
line 21036-->    Smil'd at their lack of skill, but found their courage
line 21037-->    Worthy his frowning at. Their discipline,
line 21038-->    Now mingled with their courages, will make known
line 21039-->    To their approvers they are people such
line 21040-->    That mend upon the world.
line 21041-->
line 21042-->                      Enter IACHIMO
line 21043-->
line 21044-->  PHILARIO. See! Iachimo!
line 21045-->  POSTHUMUS. The swiftest harts have posted you by land,
line 21046-->    And winds of all the comers kiss'd your sails,
line 21047-->    To make your vessel nimble.
line 21048-->  PHILARIO. Welcome, sir.
line 21049-->  POSTHUMUS. I hope the briefness of your answer made  
line 21050-->    The speediness of your return.
line 21051-->  IACHIMO. Your lady
line 21052-->    Is one of the fairest that I have look'd upon.
line 21053-->  POSTHUMUS. And therewithal the best; or let her beauty
line 21054-->    Look through a casement to allure false hearts,
line 21055-->    And be false with them.
line 21056-->  IACHIMO. Here are letters for you.
line 21057-->  POSTHUMUS. Their tenour good, I trust.
line 21058-->  IACHIMO. 'Tis very like.
line 21059-->  PHILARIO. Was Caius Lucius in the Britain court
line 21060-->    When you were there?
line 21061-->  IACHIMO. He was expected then,
line 21062-->    But not approach'd.
line 21063-->  POSTHUMUS. All is well yet.
line 21064-->    Sparkles this stone as it was wont, or is't not
line 21065-->    Too dull for your good wearing?
line 21066-->  IACHIMO. If I have lost it,
line 21067-->    I should have lost the worth of it in gold.
line 21068-->    I'll make a journey twice as far t' enjoy
line 21069-->    A second night of such sweet shortness which  
line 21070-->    Was mine in Britain; for the ring is won.
line 21071-->  POSTHUMUS. The stone's too hard to come by.
line 21072-->  IACHIMO. Not a whit,
line 21073-->    Your lady being so easy.
line 21074-->  POSTHUMUS. Make not, sir,
line 21075-->    Your loss your sport. I hope you know that we
line 21076-->    Must not continue friends.
line 21077-->  IACHIMO. Good sir, we must,
line 21078-->    If you keep covenant. Had I not brought
line 21079-->    The knowledge of your mistress home, I grant
line 21080-->    We were to question farther; but I now
line 21081-->    Profess myself the winner of her honour,
line 21082-->    Together with your ring; and not the wronger
line 21083-->    Of her or you, having proceeded but
line 21084-->    By both your wills.
line 21085-->  POSTHUMUS. If you can make't apparent
line 21086-->    That you have tasted her in bed, my hand
line 21087-->    And ring is yours. If not, the foul opinion
line 21088-->    You had of her pure honour gains or loses
line 21089-->    Your sword or mine, or masterless leaves both  
line 21090-->    To who shall find them.
line 21091-->  IACHIMO. Sir, my circumstances,
line 21092-->    Being so near the truth as I will make them,
line 21093-->    Must first induce you to believe- whose strength
line 21094-->    I will confirm with oath; which I doubt not
line 21095-->    You'll give me leave to spare when you shall find
line 21096-->    You need it not.
line 21097-->  POSTHUMUS. Proceed.
line 21098-->  IACHIMO. First, her bedchamber,
line 21099-->    Where I confess I slept not, but profess
line 21100-->    Had that was well worth watching-it was hang'd
line 21101-->    With tapestry of silk and silver; the story,
line 21102-->    Proud Cleopatra when she met her Roman
line 21103-->    And Cydnus swell'd above the banks, or for
line 21104-->    The press of boats or pride. A piece of work
line 21105-->    So bravely done, so rich, that it did strive
line 21106-->    In workmanship and value; which I wonder'd
line 21107-->    Could be so rarely and exactly wrought,
line 21108-->    Since the true life on't was-
line 21109-->  POSTHUMUS. This is true;  
line 21110-->    And this you might have heard of here, by me
line 21111-->    Or by some other.
line 21112-->  IACHIMO. More particulars
line 21113-->    Must justify my knowledge.
line 21114-->  POSTHUMUS. So they must,
line 21115-->    Or do your honour injury.
line 21116-->  IACHIMO. The chimney
line 21117-->    Is south the chamber, and the chimneypiece
line 21118-->    Chaste Dian bathing. Never saw I figures
line 21119-->    So likely to report themselves. The cutter
line 21120-->    Was as another nature, dumb; outwent her,
line 21121-->    Motion and breath left out.
line 21122-->  POSTHUMUS. This is a thing
line 21123-->    Which you might from relation likewise reap,
line 21124-->    Being, as it is, much spoke of.
line 21125-->  IACHIMO. The roof o' th' chamber
line 21126-->    With golden cherubins is fretted; her andirons-
line 21127-->    I had forgot them- were two winking Cupids
line 21128-->    Of silver, each on one foot standing, nicely
line 21129-->    Depending on their brands.  
line 21130-->  POSTHUMUS. This is her honour!
line 21131-->    Let it be granted you have seen all this, and praise
line 21132-->    Be given to your remembrance; the description
line 21133-->    Of what is in her chamber nothing saves
line 21134-->    The wager you have laid.
line 21135-->  IACHIMO. Then, if you can,                [Shows the bracelet]
line 21136-->    Be pale. I beg but leave to air this jewel. See!
line 21137-->    And now 'tis up again. It must be married
line 21138-->    To that your diamond; I'll keep them.
line 21139-->  POSTHUMUS. Jove!
line 21140-->    Once more let me behold it. Is it that
line 21141-->    Which I left with her?
line 21142-->  IACHIMO. Sir- I thank her- that.
line 21143-->    She stripp'd it from her arm; I see her yet;
line 21144-->    Her pretty action did outsell her gift,
line 21145-->    And yet enrich'd it too. She gave it me, and said
line 21146-->    She priz'd it once.
line 21147-->  POSTHUMUS. May be she pluck'd it of
line 21148-->    To send it me.
line 21149-->  IACHIMO. She writes so to you, doth she?  
line 21150-->  POSTHUMUS. O, no, no, no! 'tis true. Here, take this too;
line 21151-->                                                [Gives the ring]
line 21152-->    It is a basilisk unto mine eye,
line 21153-->    Kills me to look on't. Let there be no honour
line 21154-->    Where there is beauty; truth where semblance; love
line 21155-->    Where there's another man. The vows of women
line 21156-->    Of no more bondage be to where they are made
line 21157-->    Than they are to their virtues, which is nothing.
line 21158-->    O, above measure false!
line 21159-->  PHILARIO. Have patience, sir,
line 21160-->    And take your ring again; 'tis not yet won.
line 21161-->    It may be probable she lost it, or
line 21162-->    Who knows if one her women, being corrupted
line 21163-->    Hath stol'n it from her?
line 21164-->  POSTHUMUS. Very true;
line 21165-->    And so I hope he came by't. Back my ring.
line 21166-->    Render to me some corporal sign about her,
line 21167-->    More evident than this; for this was stol'n.
line 21168-->  IACHIMO. By Jupiter, I had it from her arm!
line 21169-->  POSTHUMUS. Hark you, he swears; by Jupiter he swears.  
line 21170-->    'Tis true- nay, keep the ring, 'tis true. I am sure
line 21171-->    She would not lose it. Her attendants are
line 21172-->    All sworn and honourable- they induc'd to steal it!
line 21173-->    And by a stranger! No, he hath enjoy'd her.
line 21174-->    The cognizance of her incontinency
line 21175-->    Is this: she hath bought the name of whore thus dearly.
line 21176-->    There, take thy hire; and all the fiends of hell
line 21177-->    Divide themselves between you!
line 21178-->  PHILARIO. Sir, be patient;
line 21179-->    This is not strong enough to be believ'd
line 21180-->    Of one persuaded well of.
line 21181-->  POSTHUMUS. Never talk on't;
line 21182-->    She hath been colted by him.
line 21183-->  IACHIMO. If you seek
line 21184-->    For further satisfying, under her breast-
line 21185-->    Worthy the pressing- lies a mole, right proud
line 21186-->    Of that most delicate lodging. By my life,
line 21187-->    I kiss'd it; and it gave me present hunger
line 21188-->    To feed again, though full. You do remember
line 21189-->    This stain upon her?  
line 21190-->  POSTHUMUS. Ay, and it doth confirm
line 21191-->    Another stain, as big as hell can hold,
line 21192-->    Were there no more but it.
line 21193-->  IACHIMO. Will you hear more?
line 21194-->  POSTHUMUS. Spare your arithmetic; never count the turns.
line 21195-->    Once, and a million!
line 21196-->  IACHIMO. I'll be sworn-
line 21197-->  POSTHUMUS. No swearing.
line 21198-->    If you will swear you have not done't, you lie;
line 21199-->    And I will kill thee if thou dost deny
line 21200-->    Thou'st made me cuckold.
line 21201-->  IACHIMO. I'll deny nothing.
line 21202-->  POSTHUMUS. O that I had her here to tear her limb-meal!
line 21203-->    I will go there and do't, i' th' court, before
line 21204-->    Her father. I'll do something-                          Exit
line 21205-->  PHILARIO. Quite besides
line 21206-->    The government of patience! You have won.
line 21207-->    Let's follow him and pervert the present wrath
line 21208-->    He hath against himself.
line 21209-->  IACHIMO. With all my heart.                             Exeunt
line 21210-->
line 21211-->
line 21212-->
line 21213-->
line 21214-->SCENE V.
line 21215-->Rome. Another room in PHILARIO'S house
line 21216-->
line 21217-->Enter POSTHUMUS
line 21218-->
line 21219-->  POSTHUMUS. Is there no way for men to be, but women
line 21220-->    Must be half-workers? We are all bastards,
line 21221-->    And that most venerable man which I
line 21222-->    Did call my father was I know not where
line 21223-->    When I was stamp'd. Some coiner with his tools
line 21224-->    Made me a counterfeit; yet my mother seem'd
line 21225-->    The Dian of that time. So doth my wife
line 21226-->    The nonpareil of this. O, vengeance, vengeance!
line 21227-->    Me of my lawful pleasure she restrain'd,
line 21228-->    And pray'd me oft forbearance; did it with
line 21229-->    A pudency so rosy, the sweet view on't
line 21230-->    Might well have warm'd old Saturn; that I thought her
line 21231-->    As chaste as unsunn'd snow. O, all the devils!
line 21232-->    This yellow Iachimo in an hour- was't not?
line 21233-->    Or less!- at first? Perchance he spoke not, but,
line 21234-->    Like a full-acorn'd boar, a German one,
line 21235-->    Cried 'O!' and mounted; found no opposition  
line 21236-->    But what he look'd for should oppose and she
line 21237-->    Should from encounter guard. Could I find out
line 21238-->    The woman's part in me! For there's no motion
line 21239-->    That tends to vice in man but I affirm
line 21240-->    It is the woman's part. Be it lying, note it,
line 21241-->    The woman's; flattering, hers; deceiving, hers;
line 21242-->    Lust and rank thoughts, hers, hers; revenges, hers;
line 21243-->    Ambitions, covetings, change of prides, disdain,
line 21244-->    Nice longing, slanders, mutability,
line 21245-->    All faults that man may name, nay, that hell knows,
line 21246-->    Why, hers, in part or all; but rather all;
line 21247-->    For even to vice
line 21248-->    They are not constant, but are changing still
line 21249-->    One vice but of a minute old for one
line 21250-->    Not half so old as that. I'll write against them,
line 21251-->    Detest them, curse them. Yet 'tis greater skill
line 21252-->    In a true hate to pray they have their will:
line 21253-->    The very devils cannot plague them better.              Exit
line 21254-->
line 21255-->
line 21256-->
line 21257-->

line 21259-->SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND IS

line 21261-->WITH PERMISSION.  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
line 21262-->DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS

line 21267-->
line 21268-->
line 21269-->ACT III. SCENE I.
line 21270-->Britain. A hall in CYMBELINE'S palace
line 21271-->
line 21272-->Enter in state, CYMBELINE, QUEEN, CLOTEN, and LORDS at one door,
line 21273-->and at another CAIUS LUCIUS and attendants
line 21274-->
line 21275-->  CYMBELINE. Now say, what would Augustus Caesar with us?
line 21276-->  LUCIUS. When Julius Caesar- whose remembrance yet
line 21277-->    Lives in men's eyes, and will to ears and tongues
line 21278-->    Be theme and hearing ever- was in this Britain,
line 21279-->    And conquer'd it, Cassibelan, thine uncle,
line 21280-->    Famous in Caesar's praises no whit less
line 21281-->    Than in his feats deserving it, for him
line 21282-->    And his succession granted Rome a tribute,
line 21283-->    Yearly three thousand pounds, which by thee lately
line 21284-->    Is left untender'd.
line 21285-->  QUEEN. And, to kill the marvel,
line 21286-->    Shall be so ever.
line 21287-->  CLOTEN. There be many Caesars
line 21288-->    Ere such another Julius. Britain is
line 21289-->    A world by itself, and we will nothing pay
line 21290-->    For wearing our own noses.  
line 21291-->  QUEEN. That opportunity,
line 21292-->    Which then they had to take from 's, to resume
line 21293-->    We have again. Remember, sir, my liege,
line 21294-->    The kings your ancestors, together with
line 21295-->    The natural bravery of your isle, which stands
line 21296-->    As Neptune's park, ribb'd and pal'd in
line 21297-->    With rocks unscalable and roaring waters,
line 21298-->    With sands that will not bear your enemies' boats
line 21299-->    But suck them up to th' top-mast. A kind of conquest
line 21300-->    Caesar made here; but made not here his brag
line 21301-->    Of 'came, and saw, and overcame.' With shame-
line 21302-->    The first that ever touch'd him- he was carried
line 21303-->    From off our coast, twice beaten; and his shipping-
line 21304-->    Poor ignorant baubles!- on our terrible seas,
line 21305-->    Like egg-shells mov'd upon their surges, crack'd
line 21306-->    As easily 'gainst our rocks; for joy whereof
line 21307-->    The fam'd Cassibelan, who was once at point-
line 21308-->    O, giglot fortune!- to master Caesar's sword,
line 21309-->    Made Lud's Town with rejoicing fires bright
line 21310-->    And Britons strut with courage.  
line 21311-->  CLOTEN. Come, there's no more tribute to be paid. Our kingdom is
line 21312-->    stronger than it was at that time; and, as I said, there is no
line 21313-->    moe such Caesars. Other of them may have crook'd noses; but to
line 21314-->    owe such straight arms, none.
line 21315-->  CYMBELINE. Son, let your mother end.
line 21316-->  CLOTEN. We have yet many among us can gripe as hard as Cassibelan.
line 21317-->    I do not say I am one; but I have a hand. Why tribute? Why should
line 21318-->    we pay tribute? If Caesar can hide the sun from us with a blanket,
line 21319-->    or put the moon in his pocket, we will pay him tribute for light;
line 21320-->    else, sir, no more tribute, pray you now.
line 21321-->  CYMBELINE. You must know,
line 21322-->    Till the injurious Romans did extort
line 21323-->    This tribute from us, we were free. Caesar's ambition-
line 21324-->    Which swell'd so much that it did almost stretch
line 21325-->    The sides o' th' world- against all colour here
line 21326-->    Did put the yoke upon's; which to shake of
line 21327-->    Becomes a warlike people, whom we reckon
line 21328-->    Ourselves to be.
line 21329-->  CLOTEN. We do.
line 21330-->  CYMBELINE. Say then to Caesar,  
line 21331-->    Our ancestor was that Mulmutius which
line 21332-->    Ordain'd our laws- whose use the sword of Caesar
line 21333-->    Hath too much mangled; whose repair and franchise
line 21334-->    Shall, by the power we hold, be our good deed,
line 21335-->    Though Rome be therefore angry. Mulmutius made our laws,
line 21336-->    Who was the first of Britain which did put
line 21337-->    His brows within a golden crown, and call'd
line 21338-->    Himself a king.
line 21339-->  LUCIUS. I am sorry, Cymbeline,
line 21340-->    That I am to pronounce Augustus Caesar-
line 21341-->    Caesar, that hath moe kings his servants than
line 21342-->    Thyself domestic officers- thine enemy.
line 21343-->    Receive it from me, then: war and confusion
line 21344-->    In Caesar's name pronounce I 'gainst thee; look
line 21345-->    For fury not to be resisted. Thus defied,
line 21346-->    I thank thee for myself.
line 21347-->  CYMBELINE. Thou art welcome, Caius.
line 21348-->    Thy Caesar knighted me; my youth I spent
line 21349-->    Much under him; of him I gather'd honour,
line 21350-->    Which he to seek of me again, perforce,  
line 21351-->    Behoves me keep at utterance. I am perfect
line 21352-->    That the Pannonians and Dalmatians for
line 21353-->    Their liberties are now in arms, a precedent
line 21354-->    Which not to read would show the Britons cold;
line 21355-->    So Caesar shall not find them.
line 21356-->  LUCIUS. Let proof speak.
line 21357-->  CLOTEN. His majesty bids you welcome. Make pastime with us a day or
line 21358-->    two, or longer. If you seek us afterwards in other terms, you
line 21359-->    shall find us in our salt-water girdle. If you beat us out of it,
line 21360-->    it is yours; if you fall in the adventure, our crows shall fare
line 21361-->    the better for you; and there's an end.
line 21362-->  LUCIUS. So, sir.
line 21363-->  CYMBELINE. I know your master's pleasure, and he mine;
line 21364-->    All the remain is, welcome.                           Exeunt
line 21365-->
line 21366-->
line 21367-->
line 21368-->
line 21369-->SCENE II.
line 21370-->Britain. Another room in CYMBELINE'S palace
line 21371-->
line 21372-->Enter PISANIO reading of a letter
line 21373-->
line 21374-->  PISANIO. How? of adultery? Wherefore write you not
line 21375-->    What monsters her accuse? Leonatus!
line 21376-->    O master, what a strange infection
line 21377-->    Is fall'n into thy ear! What false Italian-
line 21378-->    As poisonous-tongu'd as handed- hath prevail'd
line 21379-->    On thy too ready hearing? Disloyal? No.
line 21380-->    She's punish'd for her truth, and undergoes,
line 21381-->    More goddess-like than wife-like, such assaults
line 21382-->    As would take in some virtue. O my master!
line 21383-->    Thy mind to her is now as low as were
line 21384-->    Thy fortunes. How? that I should murder her?
line 21385-->    Upon the love, and truth, and vows, which I
line 21386-->    Have made to thy command? I, her? Her blood?
line 21387-->    If it be so to do good service, never
line 21388-->    Let me be counted serviceable. How look I
line 21389-->    That I should seem to lack humanity
line 21390-->    So much as this fact comes to? [Reads] 'Do't. The letter  
line 21391-->    That I have sent her, by her own command
line 21392-->    Shall give thee opportunity.' O damn'd paper,
line 21393-->    Black as the ink that's on thee! Senseless bauble,
line 21394-->    Art thou a fedary for this act, and look'st
line 21395-->    So virgin-like without? Lo, here she comes.
line 21396-->
line 21397-->                      Enter IMOGEN
line 21398-->
line 21399-->    I am ignorant in what I am commanded.
line 21400-->  IMOGEN. How now, Pisanio!
line 21401-->  PISANIO. Madam, here is a letter from my lord.
line 21402-->  IMOGEN. Who? thy lord? That is my lord- Leonatus?
line 21403-->    O, learn'd indeed were that astronomer
line 21404-->    That knew the stars as I his characters-
line 21405-->    He'd lay the future open. You good gods,
line 21406-->    Let what is here contain'd relish of love,
line 21407-->    Of my lord's health, of his content; yet not
line 21408-->    That we two are asunder- let that grieve him!
line 21409-->    Some griefs are med'cinable; that is one of them,
line 21410-->    For it doth physic love- of his content,  
line 21411-->    All but in that. Good wax, thy leave. Blest be
line 21412-->    You bees that make these locks of counsel! Lovers
line 21413-->    And men in dangerous bonds pray not alike;
line 21414-->    Though forfeiters you cast in prison, yet
line 21415-->    You clasp young Cupid's tables. Good news, gods!
line 21416-->                                                         [Reads]
line 21417-->    'Justice and your father's wrath, should he take me in his
line 21418-->    dominion, could not be so cruel to me as you, O the dearest of
line 21419-->    creatures, would even renew me with your eyes. Take notice that I
line 21420-->    am in Cambria, at Milford Haven. What your own love will out of
line 21421-->    this advise you, follow. So he wishes you all happiness that
line 21422-->    remains loyal to his vow, and your increasing in love
line 21423-->                                            LEONATUS POSTHUMUS.'
line 21424-->
line 21425-->    O for a horse with wings! Hear'st thou, Pisanio?
line 21426-->    He is at Milford Haven. Read, and tell me
line 21427-->    How far 'tis thither. If one of mean affairs
line 21428-->    May plod it in a week, why may not I
line 21429-->    Glide thither in a day? Then, true Pisanio-
line 21430-->    Who long'st like me to see thy lord, who long'st-  
line 21431-->    O, let me 'bate!- but not like me, yet long'st,
line 21432-->    But in a fainter kind- O, not like me,
line 21433-->    For mine's beyond beyond!-say, and speak thick-
line 21434-->    Love's counsellor should fill the bores of hearing
line 21435-->    To th' smothering of the sense- how far it is
line 21436-->    To this same blessed Milford. And by th' way
line 21437-->    Tell me how Wales was made so happy as
line 21438-->    T' inherit such a haven. But first of all,
line 21439-->    How we may steal from hence; and for the gap
line 21440-->    That we shall make in time from our hence-going
line 21441-->    And our return, to excuse. But first, how get hence.
line 21442-->    Why should excuse be born or ere begot?
line 21443-->    We'll talk of that hereafter. Prithee speak,
line 21444-->    How many score of miles may we well ride
line 21445-->    'Twixt hour and hour?
line 21446-->  PISANIO. One score 'twixt sun and sun,
line 21447-->    Madam, 's enough for you, and too much too.
line 21448-->  IMOGEN. Why, one that rode to's execution, man,
line 21449-->    Could never go so slow. I have heard of riding wagers
line 21450-->    Where horses have been nimbler than the sands  
line 21451-->    That run i' th' clock's behalf. But this is fool'ry.
line 21452-->    Go bid my woman feign a sickness; say
line 21453-->    She'll home to her father; and provide me presently
line 21454-->    A riding suit, no costlier than would fit
line 21455-->    A franklin's huswife.
line 21456-->  PISANIO. Madam, you're best consider.
line 21457-->  IMOGEN. I see before me, man. Nor here, nor here,
line 21458-->    Nor what ensues, but have a fog in them
line 21459-->    That I cannot look through. Away, I prithee;
line 21460-->    Do as I bid thee. There's no more to say;
line 21461-->    Accessible is none but Milford way.                   Exeunt
line 21462-->
line 21463-->
line 21464-->
line 21465-->
line 21466-->SCENE III.
line 21467-->Wales. A mountainous country with a cave
line 21468-->
line 21469-->Enter from the cave BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS
line 21470-->
line 21471-->  BELARIUS. A goodly day not to keep house with such
line 21472-->    Whose roof's as low as ours! Stoop, boys; this gate
line 21473-->    Instructs you how t' adore the heavens, and bows you
line 21474-->    To a morning's holy office. The gates of monarchs
line 21475-->    Are arch'd so high that giants may jet through
line 21476-->    And keep their impious turbans on without
line 21477-->    Good morrow to the sun. Hail, thou fair heaven!
line 21478-->    We house i' th' rock, yet use thee not so hardly
line 21479-->    As prouder livers do.
line 21480-->  GUIDERIUS. Hail, heaven!
line 21481-->  ARVIRAGUS. Hail, heaven!
line 21482-->  BELARIUS. Now for our mountain sport. Up to yond hill,
line 21483-->    Your legs are young; I'll tread these flats. Consider,
line 21484-->    When you above perceive me like a crow,
line 21485-->    That it is place which lessens and sets off;
line 21486-->    And you may then revolve what tales I have told you
line 21487-->    Of courts, of princes, of the tricks in war.  
line 21488-->    This service is not service so being done,
line 21489-->    But being so allow'd. To apprehend thus
line 21490-->    Draws us a profit from all things we see,
line 21491-->    And often to our comfort shall we find
line 21492-->    The sharded beetle in a safer hold
line 21493-->    Than is the full-wing'd eagle. O, this life
line 21494-->    Is nobler than attending for a check,
line 21495-->    Richer than doing nothing for a bribe,
line 21496-->    Prouder than rustling in unpaid-for silk:
line 21497-->    Such gain the cap of him that makes him fine,
line 21498-->    Yet keeps his book uncross'd. No life to ours!
line 21499-->  GUIDERIUS. Out of your proof you speak. We, poor unfledg'd,
line 21500-->    Have never wing'd from view o' th' nest, nor know not
line 21501-->    What air's from home. Haply this life is best,
line 21502-->    If quiet life be best; sweeter to you
line 21503-->    That have a sharper known; well corresponding
line 21504-->    With your stiff age. But unto us it is
line 21505-->    A cell of ignorance, travelling abed,
line 21506-->    A prison for a debtor that not dares
line 21507-->    To stride a limit.  
line 21508-->  ARVIRAGUS. What should we speak of
line 21509-->    When we are old as you? When we shall hear
line 21510-->    The rain and wind beat dark December, how,
line 21511-->    In this our pinching cave, shall we discourse.
line 21512-->    The freezing hours away? We have seen nothing;
line 21513-->    We are beastly: subtle as the fox for prey,
line 21514-->    Like warlike as the wolf for what we eat.
line 21515-->    Our valour is to chase what flies; our cage
line 21516-->    We make a choir, as doth the prison'd bird,
line 21517-->    And sing our bondage freely.
line 21518-->  BELARIUS. How you speak!
line 21519-->    Did you but know the city's usuries,
line 21520-->    And felt them knowingly- the art o' th' court,
line 21521-->    As hard to leave as keep, whose top to climb
line 21522-->    Is certain falling, or so slipp'ry that
line 21523-->    The fear's as bad as falling; the toil o' th' war,
line 21524-->    A pain that only seems to seek out danger
line 21525-->    I' th'name of fame and honour, which dies i' th'search,
line 21526-->    And hath as oft a sland'rous epitaph
line 21527-->    As record of fair act; nay, many times,  
line 21528-->    Doth ill deserve by doing well; what's worse-
line 21529-->    Must curtsy at the censure. O, boys, this story
line 21530-->    The world may read in me; my body's mark'd
line 21531-->    With Roman swords, and my report was once
line 21532-->    first with the best of note. Cymbeline lov'd me;
line 21533-->    And when a soldier was the theme, my name
line 21534-->    Was not far off. Then was I as a tree
line 21535-->    Whose boughs did bend with fruit; but in one night
line 21536-->    A storm, or robbery, call it what you will,
line 21537-->    Shook down my mellow hangings, nay, my leaves,
line 21538-->    And left me bare to weather.
line 21539-->  GUIDERIUS. Uncertain favour!
line 21540-->  BELARIUS. My fault being nothing- as I have told you oft-
line 21541-->    But that two villains, whose false oaths prevail'd
line 21542-->    Before my perfect honour, swore to Cymbeline
line 21543-->    I was confederate with the Romans. So
line 21544-->    Follow'd my banishment, and this twenty years
line 21545-->    This rock and these demesnes have been my world,
line 21546-->    Where I have liv'd at honest freedom, paid
line 21547-->    More pious debts to heaven than in all  
line 21548-->    The fore-end of my time. But up to th' mountains!
line 21549-->    This is not hunters' language. He that strikes
line 21550-->    The venison first shall be the lord o' th' feast;
line 21551-->    To him the other two shall minister;
line 21552-->    And we will fear no poison, which attends
line 21553-->    In place of greater state. I'll meet you in the valleys.
line 21554-->                                  Exeunt GUIDERIUS and ARVIRAGUS
line 21555-->    How hard it is to hide the sparks of nature!
line 21556-->    These boys know little they are sons to th' King,
line 21557-->    Nor Cymbeline dreams that they are alive.
line 21558-->    They think they are mine; and though train'd up thus meanly
line 21559-->    I' th' cave wherein they bow, their thoughts do hit
line 21560-->    The roofs of palaces, and nature prompts them
line 21561-->    In simple and low things to prince it much
line 21562-->    Beyond the trick of others. This Polydore,
line 21563-->    The heir of Cymbeline and Britain, who
line 21564-->    The King his father call'd Guiderius- Jove!
line 21565-->    When on my three-foot stool I sit and tell
line 21566-->    The warlike feats I have done, his spirits fly out
line 21567-->    Into my story; say 'Thus mine enemy fell,  
line 21568-->    And thus I set my foot on's neck'; even then
line 21569-->    The princely blood flows in his cheek, he sweats,
line 21570-->    Strains his young nerves, and puts himself in posture
line 21571-->    That acts my words. The younger brother, Cadwal,
line 21572-->    Once Arviragus, in as like a figure
line 21573-->    Strikes life into my speech, and shows much more
line 21574-->    His own conceiving. Hark, the game is rous'd!
line 21575-->    O Cymbeline, heaven and my conscience knows
line 21576-->    Thou didst unjustly banish me! Whereon,
line 21577-->    At three and two years old, I stole these babes,
line 21578-->    Thinking to bar thee of succession as
line 21579-->    Thou refts me of my lands. Euriphile,
line 21580-->    Thou wast their nurse; they took thee for their mother,
line 21581-->    And every day do honour to her grave.
line 21582-->    Myself, Belarius, that am Morgan call'd,
line 21583-->    They take for natural father. The game is up.           Exit
line 21584-->
line 21585-->
line 21586-->
line 21587-->
line 21588-->SCENE IV.
line 21589-->Wales, near Milford Haven
line 21590-->
line 21591-->Enter PISANIO and IMOGEN
line 21592-->
line 21593-->  IMOGEN. Thou told'st me, when we came from horse, the place
line 21594-->    Was near at hand. Ne'er long'd my mother so
line 21595-->    To see me first as I have now. Pisanio! Man!
line 21596-->    Where is Posthumus? What is in thy mind
line 21597-->    That makes thee stare thus? Wherefore breaks that sigh
line 21598-->    From th' inward of thee? One but painted thus
line 21599-->    Would be interpreted a thing perplex'd
line 21600-->    Beyond self-explication. Put thyself
line 21601-->    Into a haviour of less fear, ere wildness
line 21602-->    Vanquish my staider senses. What's the matter?
line 21603-->    Why tender'st thou that paper to me with
line 21604-->    A look untender! If't be summer news,
line 21605-->    Smile to't before; if winterly, thou need'st
line 21606-->    But keep that count'nance still. My husband's hand?
line 21607-->    That drug-damn'd Italy hath out-craftied him,
line 21608-->    And he's at some hard point. Speak, man; thy tongue
line 21609-->    May take off some extremity, which to read  
line 21610-->    Would be even mortal to me.
line 21611-->  PISANIO. Please you read,
line 21612-->    And you shall find me, wretched man, a thing
line 21613-->    The most disdain'd of fortune.
line 21614-->  IMOGEN. [Reads] 'Thy mistress, Pisanio, hath play'd the strumpet in
line 21615-->    my bed, the testimonies whereof lie bleeding in me. I speak not
line 21616-->    out of weak surmises, but from proof as strong as my grief and as
line 21617-->    certain as I expect my revenge. That part thou, Pisanio, must act
line 21618-->    for me, if thy faith be not tainted with the breach of hers. Let
line 21619-->    thine own hands take away her life; I shall give thee opportunity
line 21620-->    at Milford Haven; she hath my letter for the purpose; where, if
line 21621-->    thou fear to strike, and to make me certain it is done, thou art
line 21622-->    the pander to her dishonour, and equally to me disloyal.'
line 21623-->  PISANIO. What shall I need to draw my sword? The paper
line 21624-->    Hath cut her throat already. No, 'tis slander,
line 21625-->    Whose edge is sharper than the sword, whose tongue
line 21626-->    Outvenoms all the worms of Nile, whose breath
line 21627-->    Rides on the posting winds and doth belie
line 21628-->    All corners of the world. Kings, queens, and states,
line 21629-->    Maids, matrons, nay, the secrets of the grave,  
line 21630-->    This viperous slander enters. What cheer, madam?
line 21631-->  IMOGEN. False to his bed? What is it to be false?
line 21632-->    To lie in watch there, and to think on him?
line 21633-->    To weep twixt clock and clock? If sleep charge nature,
line 21634-->    To break it with a fearful dream of him,
line 21635-->    And cry myself awake? That's false to's bed,
line 21636-->    Is it?
line 21637-->  PISANIO. Alas, good lady!
line 21638-->  IMOGEN. I false! Thy conscience witness! Iachimo,
line 21639-->    Thou didst accuse him of incontinency;
line 21640-->    Thou then look'dst like a villain; now, methinks,
line 21641-->    Thy favour's good enough. Some jay of Italy,
line 21642-->    Whose mother was her painting, hath betray'd him.
line 21643-->    Poor I am stale, a garment out of fashion,
line 21644-->    And for I am richer than to hang by th' walls
line 21645-->    I must be ripp'd. To pieces with me! O,
line 21646-->    Men's vows are women's traitors! All good seeming,
line 21647-->    By thy revolt, O husband, shall be thought
line 21648-->    Put on for villainy; not born where't grows,
line 21649-->    But worn a bait for ladies.  
line 21650-->  PISANIO. Good madam, hear me.
line 21651-->  IMOGEN. True honest men being heard, like false Aeneas,
line 21652-->    Were, in his time, thought false; and Sinon's weeping
line 21653-->    Did scandal many a holy tear, took pity
line 21654-->    From most true wretchedness. So thou, Posthumus,
line 21655-->    Wilt lay the leaven on all proper men:
line 21656-->    Goodly and gallant shall be false and perjur'd
line 21657-->    From thy great fail. Come, fellow, be thou honest;
line 21658-->    Do thou thy master's bidding; when thou seest him,
line 21659-->    A little witness my obedience. Look!
line 21660-->    I draw the sword myself; take it, and hit
line 21661-->    The innocent mansion of my love, my heart.
line 21662-->    Fear not; 'tis empty of all things but grief;
line 21663-->    Thy master is not there, who was indeed
line 21664-->    The riches of it. Do his bidding; strike.
line 21665-->    Thou mayst be valiant in a better cause,
line 21666-->    But now thou seem'st a coward.
line 21667-->  PISANIO. Hence, vile instrument!
line 21668-->    Thou shalt not damn my hand.
line 21669-->  IMOGEN. Why, I must die;  
line 21670-->    And if I do not by thy hand, thou art
line 21671-->    No servant of thy master's. Against self-slaughter
line 21672-->    There is a prohibition so divine
line 21673-->    That cravens my weak hand. Come, here's my heart-
line 21674-->    Something's afore't. Soft, soft! we'll no defence!-
line 21675-->    Obedient as the scabbard. What is here?
line 21676-->    The scriptures of the loyal Leonatus
line 21677-->    All turn'd to heresy? Away, away,
line 21678-->    Corrupters of my faith! you shall no more
line 21679-->    Be stomachers to my heart. Thus may poor fools
line 21680-->    Believe false teachers; though those that are betray'd
line 21681-->    Do feel the treason sharply, yet the traitor
line 21682-->    Stands in worse case of woe. And thou, Posthumus,
line 21683-->    That didst set up my disobedience 'gainst the King
line 21684-->    My father, and make me put into contempt the suits
line 21685-->    Of princely fellows, shalt hereafter find
line 21686-->    It is no act of common passage but
line 21687-->    A strain of rareness; and I grieve myself
line 21688-->    To think, when thou shalt be disedg'd by her
line 21689-->    That now thou tirest on, how thy memory  
line 21690-->    Will then be pang'd by me. Prithee dispatch.
line 21691-->    The lamp entreats the butcher. Where's thy knife?
line 21692-->    Thou art too slow to do thy master's bidding,
line 21693-->    When I desire it too.
line 21694-->  PISANIO. O gracious lady,
line 21695-->    Since I receiv'd command to do this busines
line 21696-->    I have not slept one wink.
line 21697-->  IMOGEN. Do't, and to bed then.
line 21698-->  PISANIO. I'll wake mine eyeballs first.
line 21699-->  IMOGEN. Wherefore then
line 21700-->    Didst undertake it? Why hast thou abus'd
line 21701-->    So many miles with a pretence? This place?
line 21702-->    Mine action and thine own? our horses' labour?
line 21703-->    The time inviting thee? the perturb'd court,
line 21704-->    For my being absent?- whereunto I never
line 21705-->    Purpose return. Why hast thou gone so far
line 21706-->    To be unbent when thou hast ta'en thy stand,
line 21707-->    Th' elected deer before thee?
line 21708-->  PISANIO. But to win time
line 21709-->    To lose so bad employment, in the which  
line 21710-->    I have consider'd of a course. Good lady,
line 21711-->    Hear me with patience.
line 21712-->  IMOGEN. Talk thy tongue weary- speak.
line 21713-->    I have heard I am a strumpet, and mine ear,
line 21714-->    Therein false struck, can take no greater wound,
line 21715-->    Nor tent to bottom that. But speak.
line 21716-->  PISANIO. Then, madam,
line 21717-->    I thought you would not back again.
line 21718-->  IMOGEN. Most like-
line 21719-->    Bringing me here to kill me.
line 21720-->  PISANIO. Not so, neither;
line 21721-->    But if I were as wise as honest, then
line 21722-->    My purpose would prove well. It cannot be
line 21723-->    But that my master is abus'd. Some villain,
line 21724-->    Ay, and singular in his art, hath done you both
line 21725-->    This cursed injury.
line 21726-->  IMOGEN. Some Roman courtezan!
line 21727-->  PISANIO. No, on my life!
line 21728-->    I'll give but notice you are dead, and send him
line 21729-->    Some bloody sign of it, for 'tis commanded  
line 21730-->    I should do so. You shall be miss'd at court,
line 21731-->    And that will well confirm it.
line 21732-->  IMOGEN. Why, good fellow,
line 21733-->    What shall I do the while? where bide? how live?
line 21734-->    Or in my life what comfort, when I am
line 21735-->    Dead to my husband?
line 21736-->  PISANIO. If you'll back to th' court-
line 21737-->  IMOGEN. No court, no father, nor no more ado
line 21738-->    With that harsh, noble, simple nothing-
line 21739-->    That Cloten, whose love-suit hath been to me
line 21740-->    As fearful as a siege.
line 21741-->  PISANIO. If not at court,
line 21742-->    Then not in Britain must you bide.
line 21743-->  IMOGEN. Where then?
line 21744-->    Hath Britain all the sun that shines? Day, night,
line 21745-->    Are they not but in Britain? I' th' world's volume
line 21746-->    Our Britain seems as of it, but not in't;
line 21747-->    In a great pool a swan's nest. Prithee think
line 21748-->    There's livers out of Britain.
line 21749-->  PISANIO. I am most glad  
line 21750-->    You think of other place. Th' ambassador,
line 21751-->  LUCIUS the Roman, comes to Milford Haven
line 21752-->    To-morrow. Now, if you could wear a mind
line 21753-->    Dark as your fortune is, and but disguise
line 21754-->    That which t' appear itself must not yet be
line 21755-->    But by self-danger, you should tread a course
line 21756-->    Pretty and full of view; yea, happily, near
line 21757-->    The residence of Posthumus; so nigh, at least,
line 21758-->    That though his actions were not visible, yet
line 21759-->    Report should render him hourly to your ear
line 21760-->    As truly as he moves.
line 21761-->  IMOGEN. O! for such means,
line 21762-->    Though peril to my modesty, not death on't,
line 21763-->    I would adventure.
line 21764-->  PISANIO. Well then, here's the point:
line 21765-->    You must forget to be a woman; change
line 21766-->    Command into obedience; fear and niceness-
line 21767-->    The handmaids of all women, or, more truly,
line 21768-->    Woman it pretty self- into a waggish courage;
line 21769-->    Ready in gibes, quick-answer'd, saucy, and  
line 21770-->    As quarrelous as the weasel. Nay, you must
line 21771-->    Forget that rarest treasure of your cheek,
line 21772-->    Exposing it- but, O, the harder heart!
line 21773-->    Alack, no remedy!- to the greedy touch
line 21774-->    Of common-kissing Titan, and forget
line 21775-->    Your laboursome and dainty trims wherein
line 21776-->    You made great Juno angry.
line 21777-->  IMOGEN. Nay, be brief;
line 21778-->    I see into thy end, and am almost
line 21779-->    A man already.
line 21780-->  PISANIO. First, make yourself but like one.
line 21781-->    Fore-thinking this, I have already fit-
line 21782-->    'Tis in my cloak-bag- doublet, hat, hose, all
line 21783-->    That answer to them. Would you, in their serving,
line 21784-->    And with what imitation you can borrow
line 21785-->    From youth of such a season, fore noble Lucius
line 21786-->    Present yourself, desire his service, tell him
line 21787-->    Wherein you're happy- which will make him know
line 21788-->    If that his head have ear in music; doubtless
line 21789-->    With joy he will embrace you; for he's honourable,  
line 21790-->    And, doubling that, most holy. Your means abroad-
line 21791-->    You have me, rich; and I will never fail
line 21792-->    Beginning nor supplyment.
line 21793-->  IMOGEN. Thou art all the comfort
line 21794-->    The gods will diet me with. Prithee away!
line 21795-->    There's more to be consider'd; but we'll even
line 21796-->    All that good time will give us. This attempt
line 21797-->    I am soldier to, and will abide it with
line 21798-->    A prince's courage. Away, I prithee.
line 21799-->  PISANIO. Well, madam, we must take a short farewell,
line 21800-->    Lest, being miss'd, I be suspected of
line 21801-->    Your carriage from the court. My noble mistress,
line 21802-->    Here is a box; I had it from the Queen.
line 21803-->    What's in't is precious. If you are sick at sea
line 21804-->    Or stomach-qualm'd at land, a dram of this
line 21805-->    Will drive away distemper. To some shade,
line 21806-->    And fit you to your manhood. May the gods
line 21807-->    Direct you to the best!
line 21808-->  IMOGEN. Amen. I thank thee.                   Exeunt severally
line 21809-->
line 21810-->
line 21811-->
line 21812-->
line 21813-->SCENE V.
line 21814-->Britain. CYMBELINE'S palace
line 21815-->
line 21816-->Enter CYMBELINE, QUEEN, CLOTEN, LUCIUS, and LORDS
line 21817-->
line 21818-->  CYMBELINE. Thus far; and so farewell.
line 21819-->  LUCIUS. Thanks, royal sir.
line 21820-->    My emperor hath wrote; I must from hence,
line 21821-->    And am right sorry that I must report ye
line 21822-->    My master's enemy.
line 21823-->  CYMBELINE. Our subjects, sir,
line 21824-->    Will not endure his yoke; and for ourself
line 21825-->    To show less sovereignty than they, must needs
line 21826-->    Appear unkinglike.
line 21827-->  LUCIUS. So, sir. I desire of you
line 21828-->    A conduct overland to Milford Haven.
line 21829-->    Madam, all joy befall your Grace, and you!
line 21830-->  CYMBELINE. My lords, you are appointed for that office;
line 21831-->    The due of honour in no point omit.
line 21832-->    So farewell, noble Lucius.
line 21833-->  LUCIUS. Your hand, my lord.
line 21834-->  CLOTEN. Receive it friendly; but from this time forth  
line 21835-->    I wear it as your enemy.
line 21836-->  LUCIUS. Sir, the event
line 21837-->    Is yet to name the winner. Fare you well.
line 21838-->  CYMBELINE. Leave not the worthy Lucius, good my lords,
line 21839-->    Till he have cross'd the Severn. Happiness!
line 21840-->                                         Exeunt LUCIUS and LORDS
line 21841-->  QUEEN. He goes hence frowning; but it honours us
line 21842-->    That we have given him cause.
line 21843-->  CLOTEN. 'Tis all the better;
line 21844-->    Your valiant Britons have their wishes in it.
line 21845-->  CYMBELINE. Lucius hath wrote already to the Emperor
line 21846-->    How it goes here. It fits us therefore ripely
line 21847-->    Our chariots and our horsemen be in readiness.
line 21848-->    The pow'rs that he already hath in Gallia
line 21849-->    Will soon be drawn to head, from whence he moves
line 21850-->    His war for Britain.
line 21851-->  QUEEN. 'Tis not sleepy business,
line 21852-->    But must be look'd to speedily and strongly.
line 21853-->  CYMBELINE. Our expectation that it would be thus
line 21854-->    Hath made us forward. But, my gentle queen,  
line 21855-->    Where is our daughter? She hath not appear'd
line 21856-->    Before the Roman, nor to us hath tender'd
line 21857-->    The duty of the day. She looks us like
line 21858-->    A thing more made of malice than of duty;
line 21859-->    We have noted it. Call her before us, for
line 21860-->    We have been too slight in sufferance.      Exit a MESSENGER
line 21861-->  QUEEN. Royal sir,
line 21862-->    Since the exile of Posthumus, most retir'd
line 21863-->    Hath her life been; the cure whereof, my lord,
line 21864-->    'Tis time must do. Beseech your Majesty,
line 21865-->    Forbear sharp speeches to her; she's a lady
line 21866-->    So tender of rebukes that words are strokes,
line 21867-->    And strokes death to her.
line 21868-->
line 21869-->                 Re-enter MESSENGER
line 21870-->
line 21871-->  CYMBELINE. Where is she, sir? How
line 21872-->    Can her contempt be answer'd?
line 21873-->  MESSENGER. Please you, sir,
line 21874-->    Her chambers are all lock'd, and there's no answer  
line 21875-->    That will be given to th' loud of noise we make.
line 21876-->  QUEEN. My lord, when last I went to visit her,
line 21877-->    She pray'd me to excuse her keeping close;
line 21878-->    Whereto constrain'd by her infirmity
line 21879-->    She should that duty leave unpaid to you
line 21880-->    Which daily she was bound to proffer. This
line 21881-->    She wish'd me to make known; but our great court
line 21882-->    Made me to blame in memory.
line 21883-->  CYMBELINE. Her doors lock'd?
line 21884-->    Not seen of late? Grant, heavens, that which I fear
line 21885-->    Prove false!                                            Exit
line 21886-->  QUEEN. Son, I say, follow the King.
line 21887-->  CLOTEN. That man of hers, Pisanio, her old servant,
line 21888-->    I have not seen these two days.
line 21889-->  QUEEN. Go, look after.                             Exit CLOTEN
line 21890-->    Pisanio, thou that stand'st so for Posthumus!
line 21891-->    He hath a drug of mine. I pray his absence
line 21892-->    Proceed by swallowing that; for he believes
line 21893-->    It is a thing most precious. But for her,
line 21894-->    Where is she gone? Haply despair hath seiz'd her;  
line 21895-->    Or, wing'd with fervour of her love, she's flown
line 21896-->    To her desir'd Posthumus. Gone she is
line 21897-->    To death or to dishonour, and my end
line 21898-->    Can make good use of either. She being down,
line 21899-->    I have the placing of the British crown.
line 21900-->
line 21901-->                   Re-enter CLOTEN
line 21902-->
line 21903-->    How now, my son?
line 21904-->  CLOTEN. 'Tis certain she is fled.
line 21905-->    Go in and cheer the King. He rages; none
line 21906-->    Dare come about him.
line 21907-->  QUEEN. All the better. May
line 21908-->    This night forestall him of the coming day!             Exit
line 21909-->  CLOTEN. I love and hate her; for she's fair and royal,
line 21910-->    And that she hath all courtly parts more exquisite
line 21911-->    Than lady, ladies, woman. From every one
line 21912-->    The best she hath, and she, of all compounded,
line 21913-->    Outsells them all. I love her therefore; but
line 21914-->    Disdaining me and throwing favours on  
line 21915-->    The low Posthumus slanders so her judgment
line 21916-->    That what's else rare is chok'd; and in that point
line 21917-->    I will conclude to hate her, nay, indeed,
line 21918-->    To be reveng'd upon her. For when fools
line 21919-->    Shall-
line 21920-->
line 21921-->                    Enter PISANIO
line 21922-->
line 21923-->    Who is here? What, are you packing, sirrah?
line 21924-->    Come hither. Ah, you precious pander! Villain,
line 21925-->    Where is thy lady? In a word, or else
line 21926-->    Thou art straightway with the fiends.
line 21927-->  PISANIO. O good my lord!
line 21928-->  CLOTEN. Where is thy lady? or, by Jupiter-
line 21929-->    I will not ask again. Close villain,
line 21930-->    I'll have this secret from thy heart, or rip
line 21931-->    Thy heart to find it. Is she with Posthumus?
line 21932-->    From whose so many weights of baseness cannot
line 21933-->    A dram of worth be drawn.
line 21934-->  PISANIO. Alas, my lord,  
line 21935-->    How can she be with him? When was she miss'd?
line 21936-->    He is in Rome.
line 21937-->  CLOTEN. Where is she, sir? Come nearer.
line 21938-->    No farther halting! Satisfy me home
line 21939-->    What is become of her.
line 21940-->  PISANIO. O my all-worthy lord!
line 21941-->  CLOTEN. All-worthy villain!
line 21942-->    Discover where thy mistress is at once,
line 21943-->    At the next word. No more of 'worthy lord'!
line 21944-->    Speak, or thy silence on the instant is
line 21945-->    Thy condemnation and thy death.
line 21946-->  PISANIO. Then, sir,
line 21947-->    This paper is the history of my knowledge
line 21948-->    Touching her flight.                   [Presenting a letter]
line 21949-->  CLOTEN. Let's see't. I will pursue her
line 21950-->    Even to Augustus' throne.
line 21951-->  PISANIO. [Aside] Or this or perish.
line 21952-->    She's far enough; and what he learns by this
line 21953-->    May prove his travel, not her danger.
line 21954-->  CLOTEN. Humh!  
line 21955-->  PISANIO. [Aside] I'll write to my lord she's dead. O Imogen,
line 21956-->    Safe mayst thou wander, safe return again!
line 21957-->  CLOTEN. Sirrah, is this letter true?
line 21958-->  PISANIO. Sir, as I think.
line 21959-->  CLOTEN. It is Posthumus' hand; I know't. Sirrah, if thou wouldst
line 21960-->    not be a villain, but do me true service, undergo those
line 21961-->    employments wherein I should have cause to use thee with a
line 21962-->    serious industry- that is, what villainy soe'er I bid thee do, to
line 21963-->    perform it directly and truly- I would think thee an honest man;
line 21964-->    thou shouldst neither want my means for thy relief nor my voice
line 21965-->    for thy preferment.
line 21966-->  PISANIO. Well, my good lord.
line 21967-->  CLOTEN. Wilt thou serve me? For since patiently and constantly thou
line 21968-->    hast stuck to the bare fortune of that beggar Posthumus, thou
line 21969-->    canst not, in the course of gratitude, but be a diligent follower
line 21970-->    of mine. Wilt thou serve me?
line 21971-->  PISANIO. Sir, I will.
line 21972-->  CLOTEN. Give me thy hand; here's my purse. Hast any of thy late
line 21973-->    master's garments in thy possession?
line 21974-->  PISANIO. I have, my lord, at my lodging, the same suit he wore when  
line 21975-->    he took leave of my lady and mistress.
line 21976-->  CLOTEN. The first service thou dost me, fetch that suit hither. Let
line 21977-->    it be thy first service; go.
line 21978-->  PISANIO. I shall, my lord.                                Exit
line 21979-->  CLOTEN. Meet thee at Milford Haven! I forgot to ask him one thing;
line 21980-->    I'll remember't anon. Even there, thou villain Posthumus, will I
line 21981-->    kill thee. I would these garments were come. She said upon a
line 21982-->    time- the bitterness of it I now belch from my heart- that she
line 21983-->    held the very garment of Posthumus in more respect than my noble
line 21984-->    and natural person, together with the adornment of my qualities.
line 21985-->    With that suit upon my back will I ravish her; first kill him,
line 21986-->    and in her eyes. There shall she see my valour, which will then
line 21987-->    be a torment to her contempt. He on the ground, my speech of
line 21988-->    insultment ended on his dead body, and when my lust hath dined-
line 21989-->    which, as I say, to vex her I will execute in the clothes that
line 21990-->    she so prais'd- to the court I'll knock her back, foot her home
line 21991-->    again. She hath despis'd me rejoicingly, and I'll be merry in my
line 21992-->    revenge.
line 21993-->
line 21994-->                Re-enter PISANIO, with the clothes  
line 21995-->
line 21996-->    Be those the garments?
line 21997-->  PISANIO. Ay, my noble lord.
line 21998-->  CLOTEN. How long is't since she went to Milford Haven?
line 21999-->  PISANIO. She can scarce be there yet.
line 22000-->  CLOTEN. Bring this apparel to my chamber; that is the second thing
line 22001-->    that I have commanded thee. The third is that thou wilt be a
line 22002-->    voluntary mute to my design. Be but duteous and true, preferment
line 22003-->    shall tender itself to thee. My revenge is now at Milford, would
line 22004-->    I had wings to follow it! Come, and be true.            Exit
line 22005-->  PISANIO. Thou bid'st me to my loss; for true to thee
line 22006-->    Were to prove false, which I will never be,
line 22007-->    To him that is most true. To Milford go,
line 22008-->    And find not her whom thou pursuest. Flow, flow,
line 22009-->    You heavenly blessings, on her! This fool's speed
line 22010-->    Be cross'd with slowness! Labour be his meed!           Exit
line 22011-->
line 22012-->
line 22013-->
line 22014-->
line 22015-->SCENE VI.
line 22016-->Wales. Before the cave of BELARIUS
line 22017-->
line 22018-->Enter IMOGEN alone, in boy's clothes
line 22019-->
line 22020-->  IMOGEN. I see a man's life is a tedious one.
line 22021-->    I have tir'd myself, and for two nights together
line 22022-->    Have made the ground my bed. I should be sick
line 22023-->    But that my resolution helps me. Milford,
line 22024-->    When from the mountain-top Pisanio show'd thee,
line 22025-->    Thou wast within a ken. O Jove! I think
line 22026-->    Foundations fly the wretched; such, I mean,
line 22027-->    Where they should be reliev'd. Two beggars told me
line 22028-->    I could not miss my way. Will poor folks lie,
line 22029-->    That have afflictions on them, knowing 'tis
line 22030-->    A punishment or trial? Yes; no wonder,
line 22031-->    When rich ones scarce tell true. To lapse in fulness
line 22032-->    Is sorer than to lie for need; and falsehood
line 22033-->    Is worse in kings than beggars. My dear lord!
line 22034-->    Thou art one o' th' false ones. Now I think on thee
line 22035-->    My hunger's gone; but even before, I was
line 22036-->    At point to sink for food. But what is this?  
line 22037-->    Here is a path to't; 'tis some savage hold.
line 22038-->    I were best not call; I dare not call. Yet famine,
line 22039-->    Ere clean it o'erthrow nature, makes it valiant.
line 22040-->    Plenty and peace breeds cowards; hardness ever
line 22041-->    Of hardiness is mother. Ho! who's here?
line 22042-->    If anything that's civil, speak; if savage,
line 22043-->    Take or lend. Ho! No answer? Then I'll enter.
line 22044-->    Best draw my sword; and if mine enemy
line 22045-->    But fear the sword, like me, he'll scarcely look on't.
line 22046-->    Such a foe, good heavens!                 Exit into the cave
line 22047-->
line 22048-->            Enter BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS
line 22049-->
line 22050-->  BELARIUS. You, Polydore, have prov'd best woodman and
line 22051-->    Are master of the feast. Cadwal and I
line 22052-->    Will play the cook and servant; 'tis our match.
line 22053-->    The sweat of industry would dry and die
line 22054-->    But for the end it works to. Come, our stomachs
line 22055-->    Will make what's homely savoury; weariness
line 22056-->    Can snore upon the flint, when resty sloth  
line 22057-->    Finds the down pillow hard. Now, peace be here,
line 22058-->    Poor house, that keep'st thyself!
line 22059-->  GUIDERIUS. I am thoroughly weary.
line 22060-->  ARVIRAGUS. I am weak with toil, yet strong in appetite.
line 22061-->  GUIDERIUS. There is cold meat i' th' cave; we'll browse on that
line 22062-->    Whilst what we have kill'd be cook'd.
line 22063-->  BELARIUS. [Looking into the cave] Stay, come not in.
line 22064-->    But that it eats our victuals, I should think
line 22065-->    Here were a fairy.
line 22066-->  GUIDERIUS. What's the matter, sir?
line 22067-->  BELARIUS.. By Jupiter, an angel! or, if not,
line 22068-->    An earthly paragon! Behold divineness
line 22069-->    No elder than a boy!
line 22070-->
line 22071-->                       Re-enter IMOGEN
line 22072-->
line 22073-->  IMOGEN. Good masters, harm me not.
line 22074-->    Before I enter'd here I call'd, and thought
line 22075-->    To have begg'd or bought what I have took. Good troth,
line 22076-->    I have stol'n nought; nor would not though I had found  
line 22077-->    Gold strew'd i' th' floor. Here's money for my meat.
line 22078-->    I would have left it on the board, so soon
line 22079-->    As I had made my meal, and parted
line 22080-->    With pray'rs for the provider.
line 22081-->  GUIDERIUS. Money, youth?
line 22082-->  ARVIRAGUS. All gold and silver rather turn to dirt,
line 22083-->    As 'tis no better reckon'd but of those
line 22084-->    Who worship dirty gods.
line 22085-->  IMOGEN. I see you're angry.
line 22086-->    Know, if you kill me for my fault, I should
line 22087-->    Have died had I not made it.
line 22088-->  BELARIUS. Whither bound?
line 22089-->  IMOGEN. To Milford Haven.
line 22090-->  BELARIUS. What's your name?
line 22091-->  IMOGEN. Fidele, sir. I have a kinsman who
line 22092-->    Is bound for Italy; he embark'd at Milford;
line 22093-->    To whom being going, almost spent with hunger,
line 22094-->    I am fall'n in this offence.
line 22095-->  BELARIUS. Prithee, fair youth,
line 22096-->    Think us no churls, nor measure our good minds  
line 22097-->    By this rude place we live in. Well encounter'd!
line 22098-->    'Tis almost night; you shall have better cheer
line 22099-->    Ere you depart, and thanks to stay and eat it.
line 22100-->    Boys, bid him welcome.
line 22101-->  GUIDERIUS. Were you a woman, youth,
line 22102-->    I should woo hard but be your groom. In honesty
line 22103-->    I bid for you as I'd buy.
line 22104-->  ARVIRAGUS. I'll make't my comfort
line 22105-->    He is a man. I'll love him as my brother;
line 22106-->    And such a welcome as I'd give to him
line 22107-->    After long absence, such is yours. Most welcome!
line 22108-->    Be sprightly, for you fall 'mongst friends.
line 22109-->  IMOGEN. 'Mongst friends,
