line 22110-->    If brothers. [Aside] Would it had been so that they
line 22111-->    Had been my father's sons! Then had my prize
line 22112-->    Been less, and so more equal ballasting
line 22113-->    To thee, Posthumus.
line 22114-->  BELARIUS. He wrings at some distress.
line 22115-->  GUIDERIUS. Would I could free't!
line 22116-->  ARVIRAGUS. Or I, whate'er it be,  
line 22117-->    What pain it cost, what danger! Gods!
line 22118-->  BELARIUS. [Whispering] Hark, boys.
line 22119-->  IMOGEN. [Aside] Great men,
line 22120-->    That had a court no bigger than this cave,
line 22121-->    That did attend themselves, and had the virtue
line 22122-->    Which their own conscience seal'd them, laying by
line 22123-->    That nothing-gift of differing multitudes,
line 22124-->    Could not out-peer these twain. Pardon me, gods!
line 22125-->    I'd change my sex to be companion with them,
line 22126-->    Since Leonatus' false.
line 22127-->  BELARIUS. It shall be so.
line 22128-->    Boys, we'll go dress our hunt. Fair youth, come in.
line 22129-->    Discourse is heavy, fasting; when we have supp'd,
line 22130-->    We'll mannerly demand thee of thy story,
line 22131-->    So far as thou wilt speak it.
line 22132-->  GUIDERIUS. Pray draw near.
line 22133-->  ARVIRAGUS. The night to th' owl and morn to th' lark less welcome.
line 22134-->  IMOGEN. Thanks, sir.
line 22135-->  ARVIRAGUS. I pray draw near.                            Exeunt
line 22136-->
line 22137-->
line 22138-->
line 22139-->
line 22140-->SCENE VII.
line 22141-->Rome. A public place
line 22142-->
line 22143-->Enter two ROMAN SENATORS and TRIBUNES
line 22144-->
line 22145-->  FIRST SENATOR. This is the tenour of the Emperor's writ:
line 22146-->    That since the common men are now in action
line 22147-->    'Gainst the Pannonians and Dalmatians,
line 22148-->    And that the legions now in Gallia are
line 22149-->    Full weak to undertake our wars against
line 22150-->    The fall'n-off Britons, that we do incite
line 22151-->    The gentry to this business. He creates
line 22152-->    Lucius proconsul; and to you, the tribunes,
line 22153-->    For this immediate levy, he commands
line 22154-->    His absolute commission. Long live Caesar!
line 22155-->  TRIBUNE. Is Lucius general of the forces?
line 22156-->  SECOND SENATOR. Ay.
line 22157-->  TRIBUNE. Remaining now in Gallia?
line 22158-->  FIRST SENATOR. With those legions
line 22159-->    Which I have spoke of, whereunto your levy
line 22160-->    Must be supplyant. The words of your commission
line 22161-->    Will tie you to the numbers and the time  
line 22162-->    Of their dispatch.
line 22163-->  TRIBUNE. We will discharge our duty.                    Exeunt
line 22164-->
line 22165-->
line 22166-->
line 22167-->
line 22168-->ACT IV. SCENE I.
line 22169-->Wales. Near the cave of BELARIUS
line 22170-->
line 22171-->Enter CLOTEN alone
line 22172-->
line 22173-->  CLOTEN. I am near to th' place where they should meet, if Pisanio
line 22174-->    have mapp'd it truly. How fit his garments serve me! Why should
line 22175-->    his mistress, who was made by him that made the tailor, not be
line 22176-->    fit too? The rather- saving reverence of the word- for 'tis said
line 22177-->    a woman's fitness comes by fits. Therein I must play the workman.
line 22178-->    I dare speak it to myself, for it is not vain-glory for a man and
line 22179-->    his glass to confer in his own chamber- I mean, the lines of my
line 22180-->    body are as well drawn as his; no less young, more strong, not
line 22181-->    beneath him in fortunes, beyond him in the advantage of the time,
line 22182-->    above him in birth, alike conversant in general services, and
line 22183-->    more remarkable in single oppositions. Yet this imperceiverant
line 22184-->    thing loves him in my despite. What mortality is! Posthumus, thy
line 22185-->    head, which now is growing upon thy shoulders, shall within this
line 22186-->    hour be off; thy mistress enforced; thy garments cut to pieces
line 22187-->    before her face; and all this done, spurn her home to her father,
line 22188-->    who may, haply, be a little angry for my so rough usage; but my
line 22189-->    mother, having power of his testiness, shall turn all into my  
line 22190-->    commendations. My horse is tied up safe. Out, sword, and to a
line 22191-->    sore purpose! Fortune, put them into my hand. This is the very
line 22192-->    description of their meeting-place; and the fellow dares not
line 22193-->    deceive me.                                             Exit
line 22194-->
line 22195-->
line 22196-->
line 22197-->
line 22198-->SCENE II.
line 22199-->Wales. Before the cave of BELARIUS
line 22200-->
line 22201-->Enter, from the cave, BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, ARVIRAGUS, and IMOGEN
line 22202-->
line 22203-->  BELARIUS. [To IMOGEN] You are not well. Remain here in the cave;
line 22204-->    We'll come to you after hunting.
line 22205-->  ARVIRAGUS. [To IMOGEN] Brother, stay here.
line 22206-->    Are we not brothers?
line 22207-->  IMOGEN. So man and man should be;
line 22208-->    But clay and clay differs in dignity,
line 22209-->    Whose dust is both alike. I am very sick.
line 22210-->  GUIDERIUS. Go you to hunting; I'll abide with him.
line 22211-->  IMOGEN. So sick I am not, yet I am not well;
line 22212-->    But not so citizen a wanton as
line 22213-->    To seem to die ere sick. So please you, leave me;
line 22214-->    Stick to your journal course. The breach of custom
line 22215-->    Is breach of all. I am ill, but your being by me
line 22216-->    Cannot amend me; society is no comfort
line 22217-->    To one not sociable. I am not very sick,
line 22218-->    Since I can reason of it. Pray you trust me here.  
line 22219-->    I'll rob none but myself; and let me die,
line 22220-->    Stealing so poorly.
line 22221-->  GUIDERIUS. I love thee; I have spoke it.
line 22222-->    How much the quantity, the weight as much
line 22223-->    As I do love my father.
line 22224-->  BELARIUS. What? how? how?
line 22225-->  ARVIRAGUS. If it be sin to say so, sir, I yoke me
line 22226-->    In my good brother's fault. I know not why
line 22227-->    I love this youth, and I have heard you say
line 22228-->    Love's reason's without reason. The bier at door,
line 22229-->    And a demand who is't shall die, I'd say
line 22230-->    'My father, not this youth.'
line 22231-->  BELARIUS. [Aside] O noble strain!
line 22232-->    O worthiness of nature! breed of greatness!
line 22233-->    Cowards father cowards and base things sire base.
line 22234-->    Nature hath meal and bran, contempt and grace.
line 22235-->    I'm not their father; yet who this should be
line 22236-->    Doth miracle itself, lov'd before me.-
line 22237-->    'Tis the ninth hour o' th' morn.
line 22238-->  ARVIRAGUS. Brother, farewell.  
line 22239-->  IMOGEN. I wish ye sport.
line 22240-->  ARVIRAGUS. Your health. [To BELARIUS] So please you, sir.
line 22241-->  IMOGEN. [Aside] These are kind creatures. Gods, what lies I have
line 22242-->      heard!
line 22243-->    Our courtiers say all's savage but at court.
line 22244-->    Experience, O, thou disprov'st report!
line 22245-->    Th' imperious seas breed monsters; for the dish,
line 22246-->    Poor tributary rivers as sweet fish.
line 22247-->    I am sick still; heart-sick. Pisanio,
line 22248-->    I'll now taste of thy drug.                  [Swallows some]
line 22249-->  GUIDERIUS. I could not stir him.
line 22250-->    He said he was gentle, but unfortunate;
line 22251-->    Dishonestly afflicted, but yet honest.
line 22252-->  ARVIRAGUS. Thus did he answer me; yet said hereafter
line 22253-->    I might know more.
line 22254-->  BELARIUS. To th' field, to th' field!
line 22255-->    We'll leave you for this time. Go in and rest.
line 22256-->  ARVIRAGUS. We'll not be long away.
line 22257-->  BELARIUS. Pray be not sick,
line 22258-->    For you must be our huswife.  
line 22259-->  IMOGEN. Well, or ill,
line 22260-->    I am bound to you.
line 22261-->  BELARIUS. And shalt be ever.         Exit IMOGEN into the cave
line 22262-->    This youth, howe'er distress'd, appears he hath had
line 22263-->    Good ancestors.
line 22264-->  ARVIRAGUS. How angel-like he sings!
line 22265-->  GUIDERIUS. But his neat cookery! He cut our roots in characters,
line 22266-->    And sauc'd our broths as Juno had been sick,
line 22267-->    And he her dieter.
line 22268-->  ARVIRAGUS. Nobly he yokes
line 22269-->    A smiling with a sigh, as if the sigh
line 22270-->    Was that it was for not being such a smile;
line 22271-->    The smile mocking the sigh that it would fly
line 22272-->    From so divine a temple to commix
line 22273-->    With winds that sailors rail at.
line 22274-->  GUIDERIUS. I do note
line 22275-->    That grief and patience, rooted in him both,
line 22276-->    Mingle their spurs together.
line 22277-->  ARVIRAGUS. Grow patience!
line 22278-->    And let the stinking elder, grief, untwine  
line 22279-->    His perishing root with the increasing vine!
line 22280-->  BELARIUS. It is great morning. Come, away! Who's there?
line 22281-->
line 22282-->                      Enter CLOTEN
line 22283-->
line 22284-->  CLOTEN. I cannot find those runagates; that villain
line 22285-->    Hath mock'd me. I am faint.
line 22286-->  BELARIUS. Those runagates?
line 22287-->    Means he not us? I partly know him; 'tis
line 22288-->    Cloten, the son o' th' Queen. I fear some ambush.
line 22289-->    I saw him not these many years, and yet
line 22290-->    I know 'tis he. We are held as outlaws. Hence!
line 22291-->  GUIDERIUS. He is but one; you and my brother search
line 22292-->    What companies are near. Pray you away;
line 22293-->    Let me alone with him.         Exeunt BELARIUS and ARVIRAGUS
line 22294-->  CLOTEN. Soft! What are you
line 22295-->    That fly me thus? Some villain mountaineers?
line 22296-->    I have heard of such. What slave art thou?
line 22297-->  GUIDERIUS. A thing
line 22298-->    More slavish did I ne'er than answering  
line 22299-->    'A slave' without a knock.
line 22300-->  CLOTEN. Thou art a robber,
line 22301-->    A law-breaker, a villain. Yield thee, thief.
line 22302-->  GUIDERIUS. To who? To thee? What art thou? Have not I
line 22303-->    An arm as big as thine, a heart as big?
line 22304-->    Thy words, I grant, are bigger, for I wear not
line 22305-->    My dagger in my mouth. Say what thou art;
line 22306-->    Why I should yield to thee.
line 22307-->  CLOTEN. Thou villain base,
line 22308-->    Know'st me not by my clothes?
line 22309-->  GUIDERIUS. No, nor thy tailor, rascal,
line 22310-->    Who is thy grandfather; he made those clothes,
line 22311-->    Which, as it seems, make thee.
line 22312-->  CLOTEN. Thou precious varlet,
line 22313-->    My tailor made them not.
line 22314-->  GUIDERIUS. Hence, then, and thank
line 22315-->    The man that gave them thee. Thou art some fool;
line 22316-->    I am loath to beat thee.
line 22317-->  CLOTEN. Thou injurious thief,
line 22318-->    Hear but my name, and tremble.  
line 22319-->  GUIDERIUS. What's thy name?
line 22320-->  CLOTEN. Cloten, thou villain.
line 22321-->  GUIDERIUS. Cloten, thou double villain, be thy name,
line 22322-->    I cannot tremble at it. Were it toad, or adder, spider,
line 22323-->    'Twould move me sooner.
line 22324-->  CLOTEN. To thy further fear,
line 22325-->    Nay, to thy mere confusion, thou shalt know
line 22326-->    I am son to th' Queen.
line 22327-->  GUIDERIUS. I'm sorry for't; not seeming
line 22328-->    So worthy as thy birth.
line 22329-->  CLOTEN. Art not afeard?
line 22330-->  GUIDERIUS. Those that I reverence, those I fear- the wise:
line 22331-->    At fools I laugh, not fear them.
line 22332-->  CLOTEN. Die the death.
line 22333-->    When I have slain thee with my proper hand,
line 22334-->    I'll follow those that even now fled hence,
line 22335-->    And on the gates of Lud's Town set your heads.
line 22336-->    Yield, rustic mountaineer.                  Exeunt, fighting
line 22337-->
line 22338-->                Re-enter BELARIUS and ARVIRAGUS  
line 22339-->
line 22340-->  BELARIUS. No company's abroad.
line 22341-->  ARVIRAGUS. None in the world; you did mistake him, sure.
line 22342-->  BELARIUS. I cannot tell; long is it since I saw him,
line 22343-->    But time hath nothing blurr'd those lines of favour
line 22344-->    Which then he wore; the snatches in his voice,
line 22345-->    And burst of speaking, were as his. I am absolute
line 22346-->    'Twas very Cloten.
line 22347-->  ARVIRAGUS. In this place we left them.
line 22348-->    I wish my brother make good time with him,
line 22349-->    You say he is so fell.
line 22350-->  BELARIUS. Being scarce made up,
line 22351-->    I mean to man, he had not apprehension
line 22352-->    Or roaring terrors; for defect of judgment
line 22353-->    Is oft the cease of fear.
line 22354-->
line 22355-->              Re-enter GUIDERIUS with CLOTEN'S head
line 22356-->
line 22357-->    But, see, thy brother.
line 22358-->  GUIDERIUS. This Cloten was a fool, an empty purse;  
line 22359-->    There was no money in't. Not Hercules
line 22360-->    Could have knock'd out his brains, for he had none;
line 22361-->    Yet I not doing this, the fool had borne
line 22362-->    My head as I do his.
line 22363-->  BELARIUS. What hast thou done?
line 22364-->  GUIDERIUS. I am perfect what: cut off one Cloten's head,
line 22365-->    Son to the Queen, after his own report;
line 22366-->    Who call'd me traitor, mountaineer, and swore
line 22367-->    With his own single hand he'd take us in,
line 22368-->    Displace our heads where- thank the gods!- they grow,
line 22369-->    And set them on Lud's Town.
line 22370-->  BELARIUS. We are all undone.
line 22371-->  GUIDERIUS. Why, worthy father, what have we to lose
line 22372-->    But that he swore to take, our lives? The law
line 22373-->    Protects not us; then why should we be tender
line 22374-->    To let an arrogant piece of flesh threat us,
line 22375-->    Play judge and executioner all himself,
line 22376-->    For we do fear the law? What company
line 22377-->    Discover you abroad?
line 22378-->  BELARIUS. No single soul  
line 22379-->    Can we set eye on, but in an safe reason
line 22380-->    He must have some attendants. Though his humour
line 22381-->    Was nothing but mutation- ay, and that
line 22382-->    From one bad thing to worse- not frenzy, not
line 22383-->    Absolute madness could so far have rav'd,
line 22384-->    To bring him here alone. Although perhaps
line 22385-->    It may be heard at court that such as we
line 22386-->    Cave here, hunt here, are outlaws, and in time
line 22387-->    May make some stronger head- the which he hearing,
line 22388-->    As it is like him, might break out and swear
line 22389-->    He'd fetch us in; yet is't not probable
line 22390-->    To come alone, either he so undertaking
line 22391-->    Or they so suffering. Then on good ground we fear,
line 22392-->    If we do fear this body hath a tail
line 22393-->    More perilous than the head.
line 22394-->  ARVIRAGUS. Let ordinance
line 22395-->    Come as the gods foresay it. Howsoe'er,
line 22396-->    My brother hath done well.
line 22397-->  BELARIUS. I had no mind
line 22398-->    To hunt this day; the boy Fidele's sickness  
line 22399-->    Did make my way long forth.
line 22400-->  GUIDERIUS. With his own sword,
line 22401-->    Which he did wave against my throat, I have ta'en
line 22402-->    His head from him. I'll throw't into the creek
line 22403-->    Behind our rock, and let it to the sea
line 22404-->    And tell the fishes he's the Queen's son, Cloten.
line 22405-->    That's all I reck.                                      Exit
line 22406-->  BELARIUS. I fear'twill be reveng'd.
line 22407-->    Would, Polydore, thou hadst not done't! though valour
line 22408-->    Becomes thee well enough.
line 22409-->  ARVIRAGUS. Would I had done't,
line 22410-->    So the revenge alone pursu'd me! Polydore,
line 22411-->    I love thee brotherly, but envy much
line 22412-->    Thou hast robb'd me of this deed. I would revenges,
line 22413-->    That possible strength might meet, would seek us through,
line 22414-->    And put us to our answer.
line 22415-->  BELARIUS. Well, 'tis done.
line 22416-->    We'll hunt no more to-day, nor seek for danger
line 22417-->    Where there's no profit. I prithee to our rock.
line 22418-->    You and Fidele play the cooks; I'll stay  
line 22419-->    Till hasty Polydore return, and bring him
line 22420-->    To dinner presently.
line 22421-->  ARVIRAGUS. Poor sick Fidele!
line 22422-->    I'll willingly to him; to gain his colour
line 22423-->    I'd let a parish of such Cloten's blood,
line 22424-->    And praise myself for charity.                          Exit
line 22425-->  BELARIUS. O thou goddess,
line 22426-->    Thou divine Nature, thou thyself thou blazon'st
line 22427-->    In these two princely boys! They are as gentle
line 22428-->    As zephyrs blowing below the violet,
line 22429-->    Not wagging his sweet head; and yet as rough,
line 22430-->    Their royal blood enchaf'd, as the rud'st wind
line 22431-->    That by the top doth take the mountain pine
line 22432-->    And make him stoop to th' vale. 'Tis wonder
line 22433-->    That an invisible instinct should frame them
line 22434-->    To royalty unlearn'd, honour untaught,
line 22435-->    Civility not seen from other, valour
line 22436-->    That wildly grows in them, but yields a crop
line 22437-->    As if it had been sow'd. Yet still it's strange
line 22438-->    What Cloten's being here to us portends,  
line 22439-->    Or what his death will bring us.
line 22440-->
line 22441-->                    Re-enter GUIDERIUS
line 22442-->
line 22443-->  GUIDERIUS. Where's my brother?
line 22444-->    I have sent Cloten's clotpoll down the stream,
line 22445-->    In embassy to his mother; his body's hostage
line 22446-->    For his return.                               [Solemn music]
line 22447-->  BELARIUS. My ingenious instrument!
line 22448-->    Hark, Polydore, it sounds. But what occasion
line 22449-->    Hath Cadwal now to give it motion? Hark!
line 22450-->  GUIDERIUS. Is he at home?
line 22451-->  BELARIUS. He went hence even now.
line 22452-->  GUIDERIUS. What does he mean? Since death of my dear'st mother
line 22453-->    It did not speak before. All solemn things
line 22454-->    Should answer solemn accidents. The matter?
line 22455-->    Triumphs for nothing and lamenting toys
line 22456-->    Is jollity for apes and grief for boys.
line 22457-->    Is Cadwal mad?
line 22458-->  
line 22459-->       Re-enter ARVIRAGUS, with IMOGEN as dead, bearing
line 22460-->                         her in his arms
line 22461-->
line 22462-->  BELARIUS. Look, here he comes,
line 22463-->    And brings the dire occasion in his arms
line 22464-->    Of what we blame him for!
line 22465-->  ARVIRAGUS. The bird is dead
line 22466-->    That we have made so much on. I had rather
line 22467-->    Have skipp'd from sixteen years of age to sixty,
line 22468-->    To have turn'd my leaping time into a crutch,
line 22469-->    Than have seen this.
line 22470-->  GUIDERIUS. O sweetest, fairest lily!
line 22471-->    My brother wears thee not the one half so well
line 22472-->    As when thou grew'st thyself.
line 22473-->  BELARIUS. O melancholy!
line 22474-->    Who ever yet could sound thy bottom? find
line 22475-->    The ooze to show what coast thy sluggish crare
line 22476-->    Might'st easiliest harbour in? Thou blessed thing!
line 22477-->    Jove knows what man thou mightst have made; but I,
line 22478-->    Thou diedst, a most rare boy, of melancholy.  
line 22479-->    How found you him?
line 22480-->  ARVIRAGUS. Stark, as you see;
line 22481-->    Thus smiling, as some fly had tickled slumber,
line 22482-->    Not as death's dart, being laugh'd at; his right cheek
line 22483-->    Reposing on a cushion.
line 22484-->  GUIDERIUS. Where?
line 22485-->  ARVIRAGUS. O' th' floor;
line 22486-->    His arms thus leagu'd. I thought he slept, and put
line 22487-->    My clouted brogues from off my feet, whose rudeness
line 22488-->    Answer'd my steps too loud.
line 22489-->  GUIDERIUS. Why, he but sleeps.
line 22490-->    If he be gone he'll make his grave a bed;
line 22491-->    With female fairies will his tomb be haunted,
line 22492-->    And worms will not come to thee.
line 22493-->  ARVIRAGUS. With fairest flowers,
line 22494-->    Whilst summer lasts and I live here, Fidele,
line 22495-->    I'll sweeten thy sad grave. Thou shalt not lack
line 22496-->    The flower that's like thy face, pale primrose; nor
line 22497-->    The azur'd hare-bell, like thy veins; no, nor
line 22498-->    The leaf of eglantine, whom not to slander,  
line 22499-->    Out-sweet'ned not thy breath. The ruddock would,
line 22500-->    With charitable bill- O bill, sore shaming
line 22501-->    Those rich-left heirs that let their fathers lie
line 22502-->    Without a monument!- bring thee all this;
line 22503-->    Yea, and furr'd moss besides, when flow'rs are none,
line 22504-->    To winter-ground thy corse-
line 22505-->  GUIDERIUS. Prithee have done,
line 22506-->    And do not play in wench-like words with that
line 22507-->    Which is so serious. Let us bury him,
line 22508-->    And not protract with admiration what
line 22509-->    Is now due debt. To th' grave.
line 22510-->  ARVIRAGUS. Say, where shall's lay him?
line 22511-->  GUIDERIUS. By good Euriphile, our mother.
line 22512-->  ARVIRAGUS. Be't so;
line 22513-->    And let us, Polydore, though now our voices
line 22514-->    Have got the mannish crack, sing him to th' ground,
line 22515-->    As once to our mother; use like note and words,
line 22516-->    Save that Euriphile must be Fidele.
line 22517-->  GUIDERIUS. Cadwal,
line 22518-->    I cannot sing. I'll weep, and word it with thee;  
line 22519-->    For notes of sorrow out of tune are worse
line 22520-->    Than priests and fanes that lie.
line 22521-->  ARVIRAGUS. We'll speak it, then.
line 22522-->  BELARIUS. Great griefs, I see, med'cine the less, for Cloten
line 22523-->    Is quite forgot. He was a queen's son, boys;
line 22524-->    And though he came our enemy, remember
line 22525-->    He was paid for that. Though mean and mighty rotting
line 22526-->    Together have one dust, yet reverence-
line 22527-->    That angel of the world- doth make distinction
line 22528-->    Of place 'tween high and low. Our foe was princely;
line 22529-->    And though you took his life, as being our foe,
line 22530-->    Yet bury him as a prince.
line 22531-->  GUIDERIUS. Pray you fetch him hither.
line 22532-->    Thersites' body is as good as Ajax',
line 22533-->    When neither are alive.
line 22534-->  ARVIRAGUS. If you'll go fetch him,
line 22535-->    We'll say our song the whilst. Brother, begin.
line 22536-->                                                   Exit BELARIUS
line 22537-->  GUIDERIUS. Nay, Cadwal, we must lay his head to th' East;
line 22538-->    My father hath a reason for't.  
line 22539-->  ARVIRAGUS. 'Tis true.
line 22540-->  GUIDERIUS. Come on, then, and remove him.
line 22541-->  ARVIRAGUS. So. Begin.
line 22542-->
line 22543-->                      SONG
line 22544-->
line 22545-->  GUIDERIUS. Fear no more the heat o' th' sun
line 22546-->               Nor the furious winter's rages;
line 22547-->             Thou thy worldly task hast done,
line 22548-->               Home art gone, and ta'en thy wages.
line 22549-->             Golden lads and girls all must,
line 22550-->             As chimney-sweepers, come to dust.
line 22551-->
line 22552-->  ARVIRAGUS. Fear no more the frown o' th' great;
line 22553-->               Thou art past the tyrant's stroke.
line 22554-->             Care no more to clothe and eat;
line 22555-->               To thee the reed is as the oak.
line 22556-->             The sceptre, learning, physic, must
line 22557-->             All follow this and come to dust.
line 22558-->  
line 22559-->  GUIDERIUS. Fear no more the lightning flash,
line 22560-->  ARVIRAGUS.   Nor th' all-dreaded thunder-stone;
line 22561-->  GUIDERIUS. Fear not slander, censure rash;
line 22562-->  ARVIRAGUS.   Thou hast finish'd joy and moan.
line 22563-->  BOTH.      All lovers young, all lovers must
line 22564-->             Consign to thee and come to dust.
line 22565-->
line 22566-->  GUIDERIUS. No exorciser harm thee!
line 22567-->  ARVIRAGUS. Nor no witchcraft charm thee!
line 22568-->  GUIDERIUS. Ghost unlaid forbear thee!
line 22569-->  ARVIRAGUS. Nothing ill come near thee!
line 22570-->  BOTH.      Quiet consummation have,
line 22571-->             And renowned be thy grave!
line 22572-->
line 22573-->         Re-enter BELARIUS with the body of CLOTEN
line 22574-->
line 22575-->  GUIDERIUS. We have done our obsequies. Come, lay him down.
line 22576-->  BELARIUS. Here's a few flowers; but 'bout midnight, more.
line 22577-->    The herbs that have on them cold dew o' th' night
line 22578-->    Are strewings fit'st for graves. Upon their faces.  
line 22579-->    You were as flow'rs, now wither'd. Even so
line 22580-->    These herblets shall which we upon you strew.
line 22581-->    Come on, away. Apart upon our knees.
line 22582-->    The ground that gave them first has them again.
line 22583-->    Their pleasures here are past, so is their pain.
line 22584-->                                           Exeunt all but IMOGEN
line 22585-->  IMOGEN. [Awaking] Yes, sir, to Milford Haven. Which is the way?
line 22586-->    I thank you. By yond bush? Pray, how far thither?
line 22587-->    'Ods pittikins! can it be six mile yet?
line 22588-->    I have gone all night. Faith, I'll lie down and sleep.
line 22589-->    But, soft! no bedfellow. O gods and goddesses!
line 22590-->                                               [Seeing the body]
line 22591-->    These flow'rs are like the pleasures of the world;
line 22592-->    This bloody man, the care on't. I hope I dream;
line 22593-->    For so I thought I was a cave-keeper,
line 22594-->    And cook to honest creatures. But 'tis not so;
line 22595-->    'Twas but a bolt of nothing, shot at nothing,
line 22596-->    Which the brain makes of fumes. Our very eyes
line 22597-->    Are sometimes, like our judgments, blind. Good faith,
line 22598-->    I tremble still with fear; but if there be  
line 22599-->    Yet left in heaven as small a drop of pity
line 22600-->    As a wren's eye, fear'd gods, a part of it!
line 22601-->    The dream's here still. Even when I wake it is
line 22602-->    Without me, as within me; not imagin'd, felt.
line 22603-->    A headless man? The garments of Posthumus?
line 22604-->    I know the shape of's leg; this is his hand,
line 22605-->    His foot Mercurial, his Martial thigh,
line 22606-->    The brawns of Hercules; but his Jovial face-
line 22607-->    Murder in heaven! How! 'Tis gone. Pisanio,
line 22608-->    All curses madded Hecuba gave the Greeks,
line 22609-->    And mine to boot, be darted on thee! Thou,
line 22610-->    Conspir'd with that irregulous devil, Cloten,
line 22611-->    Hath here cut off my lord. To write and read
line 22612-->    Be henceforth treacherous! Damn'd Pisanio
line 22613-->    Hath with his forged letters- damn'd Pisanio-
line 22614-->    From this most bravest vessel of the world
line 22615-->    Struck the main-top. O Posthumus! alas,
line 22616-->    Where is thy head? Where's that? Ay me! where's that?
line 22617-->    Pisanio might have kill'd thee at the heart,
line 22618-->    And left this head on. How should this be? Pisanio?  
line 22619-->    'Tis he and Cloten; malice and lucre in them
line 22620-->    Have laid this woe here. O, 'tis pregnant, pregnant!
line 22621-->    The drug he gave me, which he said was precious
line 22622-->    And cordial to me, have I not found it
line 22623-->    Murd'rous to th' senses? That confirms it home.
line 22624-->    This is Pisanio's deed, and Cloten. O!
line 22625-->    Give colour to my pale cheek with thy blood,
line 22626-->    That we the horrider may seem to those
line 22627-->    Which chance to find us. O, my lord, my lord!
line 22628-->                                    [Falls fainting on the body]
line 22629-->
line 22630-->           Enter LUCIUS, CAPTAINS, and a SOOTHSAYER
line 22631-->
line 22632-->  CAPTAIN. To them the legions garrison'd in Gallia,
line 22633-->    After your will, have cross'd the sea, attending
line 22634-->    You here at Milford Haven; with your ships,
line 22635-->    They are in readiness.
line 22636-->  LUCIUS. But what from Rome?
line 22637-->  CAPTAIN. The Senate hath stirr'd up the confiners
line 22638-->    And gentlemen of Italy, most willing spirits,  
line 22639-->    That promise noble service; and they come
line 22640-->    Under the conduct of bold Iachimo,
line 22641-->    Sienna's brother.
line 22642-->  LUCIUS. When expect you them?
line 22643-->  CAPTAIN. With the next benefit o' th' wind.
line 22644-->  LUCIUS. This forwardness
line 22645-->    Makes our hopes fair. Command our present numbers
line 22646-->    Be muster'd; bid the captains look to't. Now, sir,
line 22647-->    What have you dream'd of late of this war's purpose?
line 22648-->  SOOTHSAYER. Last night the very gods show'd me a vision-
line 22649-->    I fast and pray'd for their intelligence- thus:
line 22650-->    I saw Jove's bird, the Roman eagle, wing'd
line 22651-->    From the spongy south to this part of the west,
line 22652-->    There vanish'd in the sunbeams; which portends,
line 22653-->    Unless my sins abuse my divination,
line 22654-->    Success to th' Roman host.
line 22655-->  LUCIUS. Dream often so,
line 22656-->    And never false. Soft, ho! what trunk is here
line 22657-->    Without his top? The ruin speaks that sometime
line 22658-->    It was a worthy building. How? a page?  
line 22659-->    Or dead or sleeping on him? But dead, rather;
line 22660-->    For nature doth abhor to make his bed
line 22661-->    With the defunct, or sleep upon the dead.
line 22662-->    Let's see the boy's face.
line 22663-->  CAPTAIN. He's alive, my lord.
line 22664-->  LUCIUS. He'll then instruct us of this body. Young one,
line 22665-->    Inform us of thy fortunes; for it seems
line 22666-->    They crave to be demanded. Who is this
line 22667-->    Thou mak'st thy bloody pillow? Or who was he
line 22668-->    That, otherwise than noble nature did,
line 22669-->    Hath alter'd that good picture? What's thy interest
line 22670-->    In this sad wreck? How came't? Who is't? What art thou?
line 22671-->  IMOGEN. I am nothing; or if not,
line 22672-->    Nothing to be were better. This was my master,
line 22673-->    A very valiant Briton and a good,
line 22674-->    That here by mountaineers lies slain. Alas!
line 22675-->    There is no more such masters. I may wander
line 22676-->    From east to occident; cry out for service;
line 22677-->    Try many, all good; serve truly; never
line 22678-->    Find such another master.  
line 22679-->  LUCIUS. 'Lack, good youth!
line 22680-->    Thou mov'st no less with thy complaining than
line 22681-->    Thy master in bleeding. Say his name, good friend.
line 22682-->  IMOGEN. Richard du Champ. [Aside] If I do lie, and do
line 22683-->    No harm by it, though the gods hear, I hope
line 22684-->    They'll pardon it.- Say you, sir?
line 22685-->  LUCIUS. Thy name?
line 22686-->  IMOGEN. Fidele, sir.
line 22687-->  LUCIUS. Thou dost approve thyself the very same;
line 22688-->    Thy name well fits thy faith, thy faith thy name.
line 22689-->    Wilt take thy chance with me? I will not say
line 22690-->    Thou shalt be so well master'd; but, be sure,
line 22691-->    No less belov'd. The Roman Emperor's letters,
line 22692-->    Sent by a consul to me, should not sooner
line 22693-->    Than thine own worth prefer thee. Go with me.
line 22694-->  IMOGEN. I'll follow, sir. But first, an't please the gods,
line 22695-->    I'll hide my master from the flies, as deep
line 22696-->    As these poor pickaxes can dig; and when
line 22697-->    With wild wood-leaves and weeds I ha' strew'd his grave,
line 22698-->    And on it said a century of prayers,  
line 22699-->    Such as I can, twice o'er, I'll weep and sigh;
line 22700-->    And leaving so his service, follow you,
line 22701-->    So please you entertain me.
line 22702-->  LUCIUS. Ay, good youth;
line 22703-->    And rather father thee than master thee.
line 22704-->    My friends,
line 22705-->    The boy hath taught us manly duties; let us
line 22706-->    Find out the prettiest daisied plot we can,
line 22707-->    And make him with our pikes and partisans
line 22708-->    A grave. Come, arm him. Boy, he is preferr'd
line 22709-->    By thee to us; and he shall be interr'd
line 22710-->    As soldiers can. Be cheerful; wipe thine eyes.
line 22711-->    Some falls are means the happier to arise.            Exeunt
line 22712-->
line 22713-->
line 22714-->
line 22715-->
line 22716-->SCENE III.
line 22717-->Britain. CYMBELINE'S palace
line 22718-->
line 22719-->Enter CYMBELINE, LORDS, PISANIO, and attendants
line 22720-->
line 22721-->  CYMBELINE. Again! and bring me word how 'tis with her.
line 22722-->                                               Exit an attendant
line 22723-->    A fever with the absence of her son;
line 22724-->    A madness, of which her life's in danger. Heavens,
line 22725-->    How deeply you at once do touch me! Imogen,
line 22726-->    The great part of my comfort, gone; my queen
line 22727-->    Upon a desperate bed, and in a time
line 22728-->    When fearful wars point at me; her son gone,
line 22729-->    So needful for this present. It strikes me past
line 22730-->    The hope of comfort. But for thee, fellow,
line 22731-->    Who needs must know of her departure and
line 22732-->    Dost seem so ignorant, we'll enforce it from thee
line 22733-->    By a sharp torture.
line 22734-->  PISANIO. Sir, my life is yours;
line 22735-->    I humbly set it at your will; but for my mistress,
line 22736-->    I nothing know where she remains, why gone,
line 22737-->    Nor when she purposes return. Beseech your Highness,  
line 22738-->    Hold me your loyal servant.
line 22739-->  LORD. Good my liege,
line 22740-->    The day that she was missing he was here.
line 22741-->    I dare be bound he's true and shall perform
line 22742-->    All parts of his subjection loyally. For Cloten,
line 22743-->    There wants no diligence in seeking him,
line 22744-->    And will no doubt be found.
line 22745-->  CYMBELINE. The time is troublesome.
line 22746-->    [To PISANIO] We'll slip you for a season; but our jealousy
line 22747-->    Does yet depend.
line 22748-->  LORD. So please your Majesty,
line 22749-->    The Roman legions, all from Gallia drawn,
line 22750-->    Are landed on your coast, with a supply
line 22751-->    Of Roman gentlemen by the Senate sent.
line 22752-->  CYMBELINE. Now for the counsel of my son and queen!
line 22753-->    I am amaz'd with matter.
line 22754-->  LORD. Good my liege,
line 22755-->    Your preparation can affront no less
line 22756-->    Than what you hear of. Come more, for more you're ready.
line 22757-->    The want is but to put those pow'rs in motion  
line 22758-->    That long to move.
line 22759-->  CYMBELINE. I thank you. Let's withdraw,
line 22760-->    And meet the time as it seeks us. We fear not
line 22761-->    What can from Italy annoy us; but
line 22762-->    We grieve at chances here. Away!      Exeunt all but PISANIO
line 22763-->  PISANIO. I heard no letter from my master since
line 22764-->    I wrote him Imogen was slain. 'Tis strange.
line 22765-->    Nor hear I from my mistress, who did promise
line 22766-->    To yield me often tidings. Neither know
line 22767-->    What is betid to Cloten, but remain
line 22768-->    Perplex'd in all. The heavens still must work.
line 22769-->    Wherein I am false I am honest; not true, to be true.
line 22770-->    These present wars shall find I love my country,
line 22771-->    Even to the note o' th' King, or I'll fall in them.
line 22772-->    All other doubts, by time let them be clear'd:
line 22773-->    Fortune brings in some boats that are not steer'd.      Exit
line 22774-->
line 22775-->
line 22776-->
line 22777-->
line 22778-->SCENE IV.
line 22779-->Wales. Before the cave of BELARIUS
line 22780-->
line 22781-->Enter BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS
line 22782-->
line 22783-->  GUIDERIUS. The noise is round about us.
line 22784-->  BELARIUS. Let us from it.
line 22785-->  ARVIRAGUS. What pleasure, sir, find we in life, to lock it
line 22786-->    From action and adventure?
line 22787-->  GUIDERIUS. Nay, what hope
line 22788-->    Have we in hiding us? This way the Romans
line 22789-->    Must or for Britons slay us, or receive us
line 22790-->    For barbarous and unnatural revolts
line 22791-->    During their use, and slay us after.
line 22792-->  BELARIUS. Sons,
line 22793-->    We'll higher to the mountains; there secure us.
line 22794-->    To the King's party there's no going. Newness
line 22795-->    Of Cloten's death- we being not known, not muster'd
line 22796-->    Among the bands-may drive us to a render
line 22797-->    Where we have liv'd, and so extort from's that
line 22798-->    Which we have done, whose answer would be death,
line 22799-->    Drawn on with torture.  
line 22800-->  GUIDERIUS. This is, sir, a doubt
line 22801-->    In such a time nothing becoming you
line 22802-->    Nor satisfying us.
line 22803-->  ARVIRAGUS. It is not likely
line 22804-->    That when they hear the Roman horses neigh,
line 22805-->    Behold their quarter'd fires, have both their eyes
line 22806-->    And ears so cloy'd importantly as now,
line 22807-->    That they will waste their time upon our note,
line 22808-->    To know from whence we are.
line 22809-->  BELARIUS. O, I am known
line 22810-->    Of many in the army. Many years,
line 22811-->    Though Cloten then but young, you see, not wore him
line 22812-->    From my remembrance. And, besides, the King
line 22813-->    Hath not deserv'd my service nor your loves,
line 22814-->    Who find in my exile the want of breeding,
line 22815-->    The certainty of this hard life; aye hopeless
line 22816-->    To have the courtesy your cradle promis'd,
line 22817-->    But to be still hot summer's tanlings and
line 22818-->    The shrinking slaves of winter.
line 22819-->  GUIDERIUS. Than be so,  
line 22820-->    Better to cease to be. Pray, sir, to th' army.
line 22821-->    I and my brother are not known; yourself
line 22822-->    So out of thought, and thereto so o'ergrown,
line 22823-->    Cannot be questioned.
line 22824-->  ARVIRAGUS. By this sun that shines,
line 22825-->    I'll thither. What thing is't that I never
line 22826-->    Did see man die! scarce ever look'd on blood
line 22827-->    But that of coward hares, hot goats, and venison!
line 22828-->    Never bestrid a horse, save one that had
line 22829-->    A rider like myself, who ne'er wore rowel
line 22830-->    Nor iron on his heel! I am asham'd
line 22831-->    To look upon the holy sun, to have
line 22832-->    The benefit of his blest beams, remaining
line 22833-->    So long a poor unknown.
line 22834-->  GUIDERIUS. By heavens, I'll go!
line 22835-->    If you will bless me, sir, and give me leave,
line 22836-->    I'll take the better care; but if you will not,
line 22837-->    The hazard therefore due fall on me by
line 22838-->    The hands of Romans!
line 22839-->  ARVIRAGUS. So say I. Amen.  
line 22840-->  BELARIUS. No reason I, since of your lives you set
line 22841-->    So slight a valuation, should reserve
line 22842-->    My crack'd one to more care. Have with you, boys!
line 22843-->    If in your country wars you chance to die,
line 22844-->    That is my bed too, lads, and there I'll lie.
line 22845-->    Lead, lead. [Aside] The time seems long; their blood thinks scorn
line 22846-->    Till it fly out and show them princes born.           Exeunt
line 22847-->
line 22848-->
line 22849-->
