line 22859-->
line 22860-->
line 22861-->
line 22862-->ACT V. SCENE I.
line 22863-->Britain. The Roman camp
line 22864-->
line 22865-->Enter POSTHUMUS alone, with a bloody handkerchief
line 22866-->
line 22867-->  POSTHUMUS. Yea, bloody cloth, I'll keep thee; for I wish'd
line 22868-->    Thou shouldst be colour'd thus. You married ones,
line 22869-->    If each of you should take this course, how many
line 22870-->    Must murder wives much better than themselves
line 22871-->    For wrying but a little! O Pisanio!
line 22872-->    Every good servant does not all commands;
line 22873-->    No bond but to do just ones. Gods! if you
line 22874-->    Should have ta'en vengeance on my faults, I never
line 22875-->    Had liv'd to put on this; so had you saved
line 22876-->    The noble Imogen to repent, and struck
line 22877-->    Me, wretch more worth your vengeance. But alack,
line 22878-->    You snatch some hence for little faults; that's love,
line 22879-->    To have them fall no more. You some permit
line 22880-->    To second ills with ills, each elder worse,
line 22881-->    And make them dread it, to the doer's thrift.
line 22882-->    But Imogen is your own. Do your best wills,
line 22883-->    And make me blest to obey. I am brought hither  
line 22884-->    Among th' Italian gentry, and to fight
line 22885-->    Against my lady's kingdom. 'Tis enough
line 22886-->    That, Britain, I have kill'd thy mistress; peace!
line 22887-->    I'll give no wound to thee. Therefore, good heavens,
line 22888-->    Hear patiently my purpose. I'll disrobe me
line 22889-->    Of these Italian weeds, and suit myself
line 22890-->    As does a Britain peasant. So I'll fight
line 22891-->    Against the part I come with; so I'll die
line 22892-->    For thee, O Imogen, even for whom my life
line 22893-->    Is every breath a death. And thus unknown,
line 22894-->    Pitied nor hated, to the face of peril
line 22895-->    Myself I'll dedicate. Let me make men know
line 22896-->    More valour in me than my habits show.
line 22897-->    Gods, put the strength o' th' Leonati in me!
line 22898-->    To shame the guise o' th' world, I will begin
line 22899-->    The fashion- less without and more within.              Exit
line 22900-->
line 22901-->
line 22902-->
line 22903-->
line 22904-->SCENE II.
line 22905-->Britain. A field of battle between the British and Roman camps
line 22906-->
line 22907-->Enter LUCIUS, IACHIMO, and the Roman army at one door, and the British army
line 22908-->at another, LEONATUS POSTHUMUS following like a poor soldier.
line 22909-->They march over and go out.  Alarums.  Then enter again, in skirmish,
line 22910-->IACHIMO and POSTHUMUS.  He vanquisheth and disarmeth IACHIMO,
line 22911-->and then leaves him
line 22912-->
line 22913-->  IACHIMO. The heaviness and guilt within my bosom
line 22914-->    Takes off my manhood. I have belied a lady,
line 22915-->    The Princess of this country, and the air on't
line 22916-->    Revengingly enfeebles me; or could this carl,
line 22917-->    A very drudge of nature's, have subdu'd me
line 22918-->    In my profession? Knighthoods and honours borne
line 22919-->    As I wear mine are titles but of scorn.
line 22920-->    If that thy gentry, Britain, go before
line 22921-->    This lout as he exceeds our lords, the odds
line 22922-->    Is that we scarce are men, and you are gods.            Exit
line 22923-->
line 22924-->    The battle continues; the BRITONS fly; CYMBELINE is taken.
line 22925-->    Then enter to his rescue BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS  
line 22926-->
line 22927-->  BELARIUS. Stand, stand! We have th' advantage of the ground;
line 22928-->    The lane is guarded; nothing routs us but
line 22929-->    The villainy of our fears.
line 22930-->  GUIDERIUS and ARVIRAGUS. Stand, stand, and fight!
line 22931-->
line 22932-->    Re-enter POSTHUMUS, and seconds the Britons; they rescue
line 22933-->    CYMBELINE, and exeunt. Then re-enter LUCIUS and IACHIMO,
line 22934-->                         with IMOGEN
line 22935-->
line 22936-->  LUCIUS. Away, boy, from the troops, and save thyself;
line 22937-->    For friends kill friends, and the disorder's such
line 22938-->    As war were hoodwink'd.
line 22939-->  IACHIMO. 'Tis their fresh supplies.
line 22940-->  LUCIUS. It is a day turn'd strangely. Or betimes
line 22941-->    Let's reinforce or fly.                               Exeunt
line 22942-->
line 22943-->
line 22944-->
line 22945-->
line 22946-->SCENE III.
line 22947-->Another part of the field
line 22948-->
line 22949-->Enter POSTHUMUS and a Britain LORD
line 22950-->
line 22951-->  LORD. Cam'st thou from where they made the stand?
line 22952-->  POSTHUMUS. I did:
line 22953-->    Though you, it seems, come from the fliers.
line 22954-->  LORD. I did.
line 22955-->  POSTHUMUS. No blame be to you, sir, for all was lost,
line 22956-->    But that the heavens fought. The King himself
line 22957-->    Of his wings destitute, the army broken,
line 22958-->    And but the backs of Britons seen, an flying,
line 22959-->    Through a strait lane- the enemy, full-hearted,
line 22960-->    Lolling the tongue with slaught'ring, having work
line 22961-->    More plentiful than tools to do't, struck down
line 22962-->    Some mortally, some slightly touch'd, some falling
line 22963-->    Merely through fear, that the strait pass was damm'd
line 22964-->    With dead men hurt behind, and cowards living
line 22965-->    To die with length'ned shame.
line 22966-->  LORD. Where was this lane?
line 22967-->  POSTHUMUS. Close by the battle, ditch'd, and wall'd with turf,  
line 22968-->    Which gave advantage to an ancient soldier-
line 22969-->    An honest one, I warrant, who deserv'd
line 22970-->    So long a breeding as his white beard came to,
line 22971-->    In doing this for's country. Athwart the lane
line 22972-->    He, with two striplings- lads more like to run
line 22973-->    The country base than to commit such slaughter;
line 22974-->    With faces fit for masks, or rather fairer
line 22975-->    Than those for preservation cas'd or shame-
line 22976-->    Made good the passage, cried to those that fled
line 22977-->    'Our Britain's harts die flying, not our men.
line 22978-->    To darkness fleet souls that fly backwards! Stand;
line 22979-->    Or we are Romans and will give you that,
line 22980-->    Like beasts, which you shun beastly, and may save
line 22981-->    But to look back in frown. Stand, stand!' These three,
line 22982-->    Three thousand confident, in act as many-
line 22983-->    For three performers are the file when all
line 22984-->    The rest do nothing- with this word 'Stand, stand!'
line 22985-->    Accommodated by the place, more charming
line 22986-->    With their own nobleness, which could have turn'd
line 22987-->    A distaff to a lance, gilded pale looks,  
line 22988-->    Part shame, part spirit renew'd; that some turn'd coward
line 22989-->    But by example- O, a sin in war
line 22990-->    Damn'd in the first beginners!- gan to look
line 22991-->    The way that they did and to grin like lions
line 22992-->    Upon the pikes o' th' hunters. Then began
line 22993-->    A stop i' th' chaser, a retire; anon
line 22994-->    A rout, confusion thick. Forthwith they fly,
line 22995-->    Chickens, the way which they stoop'd eagles; slaves,
line 22996-->    The strides they victors made; and now our cowards,
line 22997-->    Like fragments in hard voyages, became
line 22998-->    The life o' th' need. Having found the back-door open
line 22999-->    Of the unguarded hearts, heavens, how they wound!
line 23000-->    Some slain before, some dying, some their friends
line 23001-->    O'erborne i' th' former wave. Ten chas'd by one
line 23002-->    Are now each one the slaughterman of twenty.
line 23003-->    Those that would die or ere resist are grown
line 23004-->    The mortal bugs o' th' field.
line 23005-->  LORD. This was strange chance:
line 23006-->    A narrow lane, an old man, and two boys.
line 23007-->  POSTHUMUS. Nay, do not wonder at it; you are made  
line 23008-->    Rather to wonder at the things you hear
line 23009-->    Than to work any. Will you rhyme upon't,
line 23010-->    And vent it for a mock'ry? Here is one:
line 23011-->    'Two boys, an old man (twice a boy), a lane,
line 23012-->    Preserv'd the Britons, was the Romans' bane.'
line 23013-->  LORD. Nay, be not angry, sir.
line 23014-->  POSTHUMUS. 'Lack, to what end?
line 23015-->    Who dares not stand his foe I'll be his friend;
line 23016-->    For if he'll do as he is made to do,
line 23017-->    I know he'll quickly fly my friendship too.
line 23018-->    You have put me into rhyme.
line 23019-->  LORD. Farewell; you're angry.                             Exit
line 23020-->  POSTHUMUS. Still going? This is a lord! O noble misery,
line 23021-->    To be i' th' field and ask 'What news?' of me!
line 23022-->    To-day how many would have given their honours
line 23023-->    To have sav'd their carcasses! took heel to do't,
line 23024-->    And yet died too! I, in mine own woe charm'd,
line 23025-->    Could not find death where I did hear him groan,
line 23026-->    Nor feel him where he struck. Being an ugly monster,
line 23027-->    'Tis strange he hides him in fresh cups, soft beds,  
line 23028-->    Sweet words; or hath moe ministers than we
line 23029-->    That draw his knives i' th' war. Well, I will find him;
line 23030-->    For being now a favourer to the Briton,
line 23031-->    No more a Briton, I have resum'd again
line 23032-->    The part I came in. Fight I will no more,
line 23033-->    But yield me to the veriest hind that shall
line 23034-->    Once touch my shoulder. Great the slaughter is
line 23035-->    Here made by th' Roman; great the answer be
line 23036-->    Britons must take. For me, my ransom's death;
line 23037-->    On either side I come to spend my breath,
line 23038-->    Which neither here I'll keep nor bear again,
line 23039-->    But end it by some means for Imogen.
line 23040-->
line 23041-->            Enter two BRITISH CAPTAINS and soldiers
line 23042-->
line 23043-->  FIRST CAPTAIN. Great Jupiter be prais'd! Lucius is taken.
line 23044-->    'Tis thought the old man and his sons were angels.
line 23045-->  SECOND CAPTAIN. There was a fourth man, in a silly habit,
line 23046-->    That gave th' affront with them.
line 23047-->  FIRST CAPTAIN. So 'tis reported;  
line 23048-->    But none of 'em can be found. Stand! who's there?
line 23049-->  POSTHUMUS. A Roman,
line 23050-->    Who had not now been drooping here if seconds
line 23051-->    Had answer'd him.
line 23052-->  SECOND CAPTAIN. Lay hands on him; a dog!
line 23053-->    A leg of Rome shall not return to tell
line 23054-->    What crows have peck'd them here. He brags his service,
line 23055-->    As if he were of note. Bring him to th' King.
line 23056-->
line 23057-->   Enter CYMBELINE, BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, ARVIRAGUS, PISANIO, and Roman
line 23058-->   captives. The CAPTAINS present POSTHUMUS to CYMBELINE, who delivers
line 23059-->            him over to a gaoler. Exeunt omnes
line 23060-->
line 23061-->
line 23062-->
line 23063-->
line 23064-->SCENE IV.
line 23065-->Britain. A prison
line 23066-->
line 23067-->Enter POSTHUMUS and two GAOLERS
line 23068-->
line 23069-->  FIRST GAOLER. You shall not now be stol'n, you have locks upon you;
line 23070-->    So graze as you find pasture.
line 23071-->  SECOND GAOLER. Ay, or a stomach.                Exeunt GAOLERS
line 23072-->  POSTHUMUS. Most welcome, bondage! for thou art a way,
line 23073-->    I think, to liberty. Yet am I better
line 23074-->    Than one that's sick o' th' gout, since he had rather
line 23075-->    Groan so in perpetuity than be cur'd
line 23076-->    By th' sure physician death, who is the key
line 23077-->    T' unbar these locks. My conscience, thou art fetter'd
line 23078-->    More than my shanks and wrists; you good gods, give me
line 23079-->    The penitent instrument to pick that bolt,
line 23080-->    Then, free for ever! Is't enough I am sorry?
line 23081-->    So children temporal fathers do appease;
line 23082-->    Gods are more full of mercy. Must I repent,
line 23083-->    I cannot do it better than in gyves,
line 23084-->    Desir'd more than constrain'd. To satisfy,
line 23085-->    If of my freedom 'tis the main part, take  
line 23086-->    No stricter render of me than my all.
line 23087-->    I know you are more clement than vile men,
line 23088-->    Who of their broken debtors take a third,
line 23089-->    A sixth, a tenth, letting them thrive again
line 23090-->    On their abatement; that's not my desire.
line 23091-->    For Imogen's dear life take mine; and though
line 23092-->    'Tis not so dear, yet 'tis a life; you coin'd it.
line 23093-->    'Tween man and man they weigh not every stamp;
line 23094-->    Though light, take pieces for the figure's sake;
line 23095-->    You rather mine, being yours. And so, great pow'rs,
line 23096-->    If you will take this audit, take this life,
line 23097-->    And cancel these cold bonds. O Imogen!
line 23098-->    I'll speak to thee in silence.                      [Sleeps]
line 23099-->
line 23100-->        Solemn music. Enter, as in an apparition, SICILIUS
line 23101-->        LEONATUS, father to POSTHUMUS, an old man attired
line 23102-->         like a warrior; leading in his hand an ancient
line 23103-->          matron, his WIFE, and mother to POSTHUMUS, with
line 23104-->        music before them. Then, after other music, follows
line 23105-->           the two young LEONATI, brothers to POSTHUMUS,  
line 23106-->              with wounds, as they died in the wars.
line 23107-->          They circle POSTHUMUS round as he lies sleeping
line 23108-->
line 23109-->  SICILIUS. No more, thou thunder-master, show
line 23110-->              Thy spite on mortal flies.
line 23111-->            With Mars fall out, with Juno chide,
line 23112-->              That thy adulteries
line 23113-->                Rates and revenges.
line 23114-->            Hath my poor boy done aught but well,
line 23115-->              Whose face I never saw?
line 23116-->            I died whilst in the womb he stay'd
line 23117-->              Attending nature's law;
line 23118-->            Whose father then, as men report
line 23119-->              Thou orphans' father art,
line 23120-->            Thou shouldst have been, and shielded him
line 23121-->              From this earth-vexing smart.
line 23122-->
line 23123-->  MOTHER.   Lucina lent not me her aid,
line 23124-->              But took me in my throes,
line 23125-->            That from me was Posthumus ripp'd,  
line 23126-->              Came crying 'mongst his foes,
line 23127-->                A thing of pity.
line 23128-->
line 23129-->  SICILIUS. Great Nature like his ancestry
line 23130-->              Moulded the stuff so fair
line 23131-->            That he deserv'd the praise o' th' world
line 23132-->              As great Sicilius' heir.
line 23133-->
line 23134-->  FIRST BROTHER. When once he was mature for man,
line 23135-->              In Britain where was he
line 23136-->            That could stand up his parallel,
line 23137-->              Or fruitful object be
line 23138-->            In eye of Imogen, that best
line 23139-->              Could deem his dignity?
line 23140-->
line 23141-->  MOTHER.   With marriage wherefore was he mock'd,
line 23142-->              To be exil'd and thrown
line 23143-->            From Leonati seat and cast
line 23144-->            From her his dearest one,
line 23145-->              Sweet Imogen?  
line 23146-->
line 23147-->  SICILIUS. Why did you suffer Iachimo,
line 23148-->              Slight thing of Italy,
line 23149-->            To taint his nobler heart and brain
line 23150-->              With needless jealousy,
line 23151-->            And to become the geck and scorn
line 23152-->              O' th' other's villainy?
line 23153-->
line 23154-->  SECOND BROTHER. For this from stiller seats we came,
line 23155-->              Our parents and us twain,
line 23156-->            That, striking in our country's cause,
line 23157-->              Fell bravely and were slain,
line 23158-->            Our fealty and Tenantius' right
line 23159-->              With honour to maintain.
line 23160-->
line 23161-->  FIRST BROTHER. Like hardiment Posthumus hath
line 23162-->              To Cymbeline perform'd.
line 23163-->            Then, Jupiter, thou king of gods,
line 23164-->              Why hast thou thus adjourn'd
line 23165-->            The graces for his merits due,  
line 23166-->              Being all to dolours turn'd?
line 23167-->
line 23168-->  SICILIUS. Thy crystal window ope; look out;
line 23169-->              No longer exercise
line 23170-->            Upon a valiant race thy harsh
line 23171-->              And potent injuries.
line 23172-->
line 23173-->  MOTHER.   Since, Jupiter, our son is good,
line 23174-->              Take off his miseries.
line 23175-->
line 23176-->  SICILIUS. Peep through thy marble mansion. Help!
line 23177-->              Or we poor ghosts will cry
line 23178-->            To th' shining synod of the rest
line 23179-->              Against thy deity.
line 23180-->
line 23181-->  BROTHERS. Help, Jupiter! or we appeal,
line 23182-->              And from thy justice fly.
line 23183-->
line 23184-->       JUPITER descends-in thunder and lightning, sitting
line 23185-->       upon an eagle. He throws a thunderbolt. The GHOSTS  
line 23186-->                     fall on their knees
line 23187-->
line 23188-->  JUPITER. No more, you petty spirits of region low,
line 23189-->    Offend our hearing; hush! How dare you ghosts
line 23190-->    Accuse the Thunderer whose bolt, you know,
line 23191-->    Sky-planted, batters all rebelling coasts?
line 23192-->    Poor shadows of Elysium, hence and rest
line 23193-->    Upon your never-withering banks of flow'rs.
line 23194-->    Be not with mortal accidents opprest:
line 23195-->    No care of yours it is; you know 'tis ours.
line 23196-->    Whom best I love I cross; to make my gift,
line 23197-->    The more delay'd, delighted. Be content;
line 23198-->    Your low-laid son our godhead will uplift;
line 23199-->    His comforts thrive, his trials well are spent.
line 23200-->    Our Jovial star reign'd at his birth, and in
line 23201-->    Our temple was he married. Rise and fade!
line 23202-->    He shall be lord of Lady Imogen,
line 23203-->    And happier much by his affliction made.
line 23204-->    This tablet lay upon his breast, wherein
line 23205-->    Our pleasure his full fortune doth confine;  
line 23206-->    And so, away; no farther with your din
line 23207-->    Express impatience, lest you stir up mine.
line 23208-->    Mount, eagle, to my palace crystalline.            [Ascends]
line 23209-->  SICILIUS. He came in thunder; his celestial breath
line 23210-->    Was sulpherous to smell; the holy eagle
line 23211-->    Stoop'd as to foot us. His ascension is
line 23212-->    More sweet than our blest fields. His royal bird
line 23213-->    Prunes the immortal wing, and cloys his beak,
line 23214-->    As when his god is pleas'd.
line 23215-->  ALL. Thanks, Jupiter!
line 23216-->  SICILIUS. The marble pavement closes, he is enter'd
line 23217-->    His radiant roof. Away! and, to be blest,
line 23218-->    Let us with care perform his great behest.   [GHOSTS vanish]
line 23219-->
line 23220-->  POSTHUMUS. [Waking] Sleep, thou has been a grandsire and begot
line 23221-->    A father to me; and thou hast created
line 23222-->    A mother and two brothers. But, O scorn,
line 23223-->    Gone! They went hence so soon as they were born.
line 23224-->    And so I am awake. Poor wretches, that depend
line 23225-->    On greatness' favour, dream as I have done;  
line 23226-->    Wake and find nothing. But, alas, I swerve;
line 23227-->    Many dream not to find, neither deserve,
line 23228-->    And yet are steep'd in favours; so am I,
line 23229-->    That have this golden chance, and know not why.
line 23230-->    What fairies haunt this ground? A book? O rare one!
line 23231-->    Be not, as is our fangled world, a garment
line 23232-->    Nobler than that it covers. Let thy effects
line 23233-->    So follow to be most unlike our courtiers,
line 23234-->    As good as promise.
line 23235-->
line 23236-->    [Reads] 'When as a lion's whelp shall, to himself unknown,
line 23237-->    without seeking find, and be embrac'd by a piece of tender air;
line 23238-->    and when from a stately cedar shall be lopp'd branches which,
line 23239-->    being dead many years, shall after revive, be jointed to the old
line 23240-->    stock, and freshly grow; then shall Posthumus end his miseries,
line 23241-->    Britain be fortunate and flourish in peace and plenty.'
line 23242-->
line 23243-->    'Tis still a dream, or else such stuff as madmen
line 23244-->    Tongue, and brain not; either both or nothing,
line 23245-->    Or senseless speaking, or a speaking such  
line 23246-->    As sense cannot untie. Be what it is,
line 23247-->    The action of my life is like it, which
line 23248-->    I'll keep, if but for sympathy.
line 23249-->
line 23250-->                  Re-enter GAOLER
line 23251-->
line 23252-->  GAOLER. Come, sir, are you ready for death?
line 23253-->  POSTHUMUS. Over-roasted rather; ready long ago.
line 23254-->  GAOLER. Hanging is the word, sir; if you be ready for that, you are
line 23255-->    well cook'd.
line 23256-->  POSTHUMUS. So, if I prove a good repast to the spectators, the dish
line 23257-->    pays the shot.
line 23258-->  GAOLER. A heavy reckoning for you, sir. But the comfort is, you
line 23259-->    shall be called to no more payments, fear no more tavern bills,
line 23260-->    which are often the sadness of parting, as the procuring of mirth.
line 23261-->    You come in faint for want of meat, depart reeling with too much
line 23262-->    drink; sorry that you have paid too much, and sorry that you are
line 23263-->    paid too much; purse and brain both empty; the brain the heavier
line 23264-->    for being too light, the purse too light, being drawn of
line 23265-->    heaviness. O, of this contradiction you shall now be quit. O, the  
line 23266-->    charity of a penny cord! It sums up thousands in a trice. You
line 23267-->    have no true debitor and creditor but it; of what's past, is, and
line 23268-->    to come, the discharge. Your neck, sir, is pen, book, and
line 23269-->    counters; so the acquittance follows.
line 23270-->  POSTHUMUS. I am merrier to die than thou art to live.
line 23271-->  GAOLER. Indeed, sir, he that sleeps feels not the toothache. But a
line 23272-->    man that were to sleep your sleep, and a hangman to help him to
line 23273-->    bed, I think he would change places with his officer; for look
line 23274-->    you, sir, you know not which way you shall go.
line 23275-->  POSTHUMUS. Yes indeed do I, fellow.
line 23276-->  GAOLER. Your death has eyes in's head, then; I have not seen him so
line 23277-->    pictur'd. You must either be directed by some that take upon them
line 23278-->    to know, or to take upon yourself that which I am sure you do not
line 23279-->    know, or jump the after-inquiry on your own peril. And how you
line 23280-->    shall speed in your journey's end, I think you'll never return to
line 23281-->    tell one.
line 23282-->  POSTHUMUS. I tell thee, fellow, there are none want eyes to direct
line 23283-->    them the way I am going, but such as wink and will not use them.
line 23284-->  GAOLER. What an infinite mock is this, that a man should have the
line 23285-->    best use of eyes to see the way of blindness! I am sure hanging's  
line 23286-->    the way of winking.
line 23287-->
line 23288-->                        Enter a MESSENGER
line 23289-->
line 23290-->  MESSENGER. Knock off his manacles; bring your prisoner to the King.
line 23291-->  POSTHUMUS. Thou bring'st good news: I am call'd to be made free.
line 23292-->  GAOLER. I'll be hang'd then.
line 23293-->  POSTHUMUS. Thou shalt be then freer than a gaoler; no bolts for the
line 23294-->    dead.                         Exeunt POSTHUMUS and MESSENGER
line 23295-->  GAOLER. Unless a man would marry a gallows and beget young gibbets,
line 23296-->    I never saw one so prone. Yet, on my conscience, there are verier
line 23297-->    knaves desire to live, for all he be a Roman; and there be some
line 23298-->    of them too that die against their wills; so should I, if I were
line 23299-->    one. I would we were all of one mind, and one mind good. O, there
line 23300-->    were desolation of gaolers and gallowses! I speak against my
line 23301-->    present profit, but my wish hath a preferment in't.     Exit
line 23302-->
line 23303-->
line 23304-->
line 23305-->
line 23306-->SCENE V.
line 23307-->Britain. CYMBELINE'S tent
line 23308-->
line 23309-->Enter CYMBELINE, BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, ARVIRAGUS, PISANIO, LORDS,
line 23310-->OFFICERS, and attendants
line 23311-->
line 23312-->  CYMBELINE. Stand by my side, you whom the gods have made
line 23313-->    Preservers of my throne. Woe is my heart
line 23314-->    That the poor soldier that so richly fought,
line 23315-->    Whose rags sham'd gilded arms, whose naked breast
line 23316-->    Stepp'd before targes of proof, cannot be found.
line 23317-->    He shall be happy that can find him, if
line 23318-->    Our grace can make him so.
line 23319-->  BELARIUS. I never saw
line 23320-->    Such noble fury in so poor a thing;
line 23321-->    Such precious deeds in one that promis'd nought
line 23322-->    But beggary and poor looks.
line 23323-->  CYMBELINE. No tidings of him?
line 23324-->  PISANIO. He hath been search'd among the dead and living,
line 23325-->    But no trace of him.
line 23326-->  CYMBELINE. To my grief, I am
line 23327-->    The heir of his reward; [To BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS]  
line 23328-->      which I will add
line 23329-->    To you, the liver, heart, and brain, of Britain,
line 23330-->    By whom I grant she lives. 'Tis now the time
line 23331-->    To ask of whence you are. Report it.
line 23332-->  BELARIUS. Sir,
line 23333-->    In Cambria are we born, and gentlemen;
line 23334-->    Further to boast were neither true nor modest,
line 23335-->    Unless I add we are honest.
line 23336-->  CYMBELINE. Bow your knees.
line 23337-->    Arise my knights o' th' battle; I create you
line 23338-->    Companions to our person, and will fit you
line 23339-->    With dignities becoming your estates.
line 23340-->
line 23341-->             Enter CORNELIUS and LADIES
line 23342-->
line 23343-->    There's business in these faces. Why so sadly
line 23344-->    Greet you our victory? You look like Romans,
line 23345-->    And not o' th' court of Britain.
line 23346-->  CORNELIUS. Hail, great King!
line 23347-->    To sour your happiness I must report  
line 23348-->    The Queen is dead.
line 23349-->  CYMBELINE. Who worse than a physician
line 23350-->    Would this report become? But I consider
line 23351-->    By med'cine'life may be prolong'd, yet death
line 23352-->    Will seize the doctor too. How ended she?
line 23353-->  CORNELIUS. With horror, madly dying, like her life;
line 23354-->    Which, being cruel to the world, concluded
line 23355-->    Most cruel to herself. What she confess'd
line 23356-->    I will report, so please you; these her women
line 23357-->    Can trip me if I err, who with wet cheeks
line 23358-->    Were present when she finish'd.
line 23359-->  CYMBELINE. Prithee say.
line 23360-->  CORNELIUS. First, she confess'd she never lov'd you; only
line 23361-->    Affected greatness got by you, not you;
line 23362-->    Married your royalty, was wife to your place;
line 23363-->    Abhorr'd your person.
line 23364-->  CYMBELINE. She alone knew this;
line 23365-->    And but she spoke it dying, I would not
line 23366-->    Believe her lips in opening it. Proceed.
line 23367-->  CORNELIUS. Your daughter, whom she bore in hand to love  
line 23368-->    With such integrity, she did confess
line 23369-->    Was as a scorpion to her sight; whose life,
line 23370-->    But that her flight prevented it, she had
line 23371-->    Ta'en off by poison.
line 23372-->  CYMBELINE. O most delicate fiend!
line 23373-->    Who is't can read a woman? Is there more?
line 23374-->  CORNELIUS. More, sir, and worse. She did confess she had
line 23375-->    For you a mortal mineral, which, being took,
line 23376-->    Should by the minute feed on life, and ling'ring,
line 23377-->    By inches waste you. In which time she purpos'd,
line 23378-->    By watching, weeping, tendance, kissing, to
line 23379-->    O'ercome you with her show; and in time,
line 23380-->    When she had fitted you with her craft, to work
line 23381-->    Her son into th' adoption of the crown;
line 23382-->    But failing of her end by his strange absence,
line 23383-->    Grew shameless-desperate, open'd, in despite
line 23384-->    Of heaven and men, her purposes, repented
line 23385-->    The evils she hatch'd were not effected; so,
line 23386-->    Despairing, died.
line 23387-->  CYMBELINE. Heard you all this, her women?  
line 23388-->  LADY. We did, so please your Highness.
line 23389-->  CYMBELINE. Mine eyes
line 23390-->    Were not in fault, for she was beautiful;
line 23391-->    Mine ears, that heard her flattery; nor my heart
line 23392-->    That thought her like her seeming. It had been vicious
line 23393-->    To have mistrusted her; yet, O my daughter!
line 23394-->    That it was folly in me thou mayst say,
line 23395-->    And prove it in thy feeling. Heaven mend all!
line 23396-->
line 23397-->         Enter LUCIUS, IACHIMO, the SOOTHSAYER, and other
line 23398-->      Roman prisoners, guarded; POSTHUMUS behind, and IMOGEN
line 23399-->
line 23400-->    Thou com'st not, Caius, now for tribute; that
line 23401-->    The Britons have raz'd out, though with the loss
line 23402-->    Of many a bold one, whose kinsmen have made suit
line 23403-->    That their good souls may be appeas'd with slaughter
line 23404-->    Of you their captives, which ourself have granted;
line 23405-->    So think of your estate.
line 23406-->  LUCIUS. Consider, sir, the chance of war. The day
line 23407-->    Was yours by accident; had it gone with us,  
line 23408-->    We should not, when the blood was cool, have threaten'd
line 23409-->    Our prisoners with the sword. But since the gods
line 23410-->    Will have it thus, that nothing but our lives
line 23411-->    May be call'd ransom, let it come. Sufficeth
line 23412-->    A Roman with a Roman's heart can suffer.
line 23413-->    Augustus lives to think on't; and so much
line 23414-->    For my peculiar care. This one thing only
line 23415-->    I will entreat: my boy, a Briton born,
line 23416-->    Let him be ransom'd. Never master had
line 23417-->    A page so kind, so duteous, diligent,
line 23418-->    So tender over his occasions, true,
line 23419-->    So feat, so nurse-like; let his virtue join
line 23420-->    With my request, which I'll make bold your Highness
line 23421-->    Cannot deny; he hath done no Briton harm
line 23422-->    Though he have serv'd a Roman. Save him, sir,
line 23423-->    And spare no blood beside.
line 23424-->  CYMBELINE. I have surely seen him;
line 23425-->    His favour is familiar to me. Boy,
line 23426-->    Thou hast look'd thyself into my grace,
line 23427-->    And art mine own. I know not why, wherefore  
line 23428-->    To say 'Live, boy.' Ne'er thank thy master. Live;
line 23429-->    And ask of Cymbeline what boon thou wilt,
line 23430-->    Fitting my bounty and thy state, I'll give it;
line 23431-->    Yea, though thou do demand a prisoner,
line 23432-->    The noblest ta'en.
line 23433-->  IMOGEN. I humbly thank your Highness.
line 23434-->  LUCIUS. I do not bid thee beg my life, good lad,
line 23435-->    And yet I know thou wilt.
line 23436-->  IMOGEN. No, no! Alack,
line 23437-->    There's other work in hand. I see a thing
line 23438-->    Bitter to me as death; your life, good master,
line 23439-->    Must shuffle for itself.
line 23440-->  LUCIUS. The boy disdains me,
line 23441-->    He leaves me, scorns me. Briefly die their joys
line 23442-->    That place them on the truth of girls and boys.
line 23443-->    Why stands he so perplex'd?
line 23444-->  CYMBELINE. What wouldst thou, boy?
line 23445-->    I love thee more and more; think more and more
line 23446-->    What's best to ask. Know'st him thou look'st on? Speak,
line 23447-->    Wilt have him live? Is he thy kin? thy friend?  
line 23448-->  IMOGEN. He is a Roman, no more kin to me
line 23449-->    Than I to your Highness; who, being born your vassal,
line 23450-->    Am something nearer.
line 23451-->  CYMBELINE. Wherefore ey'st him so?
line 23452-->  IMOGEN. I'll tell you, sir, in private, if you please
line 23453-->    To give me hearing.
line 23454-->  CYMBELINE. Ay, with all my heart,
line 23455-->    And lend my best attention. What's thy name?
line 23456-->  IMOGEN. Fidele, sir.
line 23457-->  CYMBELINE. Thou'rt my good youth, my page;
line 23458-->    I'll be thy master. Walk with me; speak freely.
line 23459-->                           [CYMBELINE and IMOGEN converse apart]
line 23460-->  BELARIUS. Is not this boy reviv'd from death?
line 23461-->  ARVIRAGUS. One sand another
line 23462-->    Not more resembles- that sweet rosy lad
line 23463-->    Who died and was Fidele. What think you?
line 23464-->  GUIDERIUS. The same dead thing alive.
line 23465-->  BELARIUS. Peace, peace! see further. He eyes us not; forbear.
line 23466-->    Creatures may be alike; were't he, I am sure
line 23467-->    He would have spoke to us.  
line 23468-->  GUIDERIUS. But we saw him dead.
line 23469-->  BELARIUS. Be silent; let's see further.
line 23470-->  PISANIO. [Aside] It is my mistress.
line 23471-->    Since she is living, let the time run on
line 23472-->    To good or bad.               [CYMBELINE and IMOGEN advance]
line 23473-->  CYMBELINE. Come, stand thou by our side;
line 23474-->    Make thy demand aloud. [To IACHIMO] Sir, step you forth;
line 23475-->    Give answer to this boy, and do it freely,
line 23476-->    Or, by our greatness and the grace of it,
line 23477-->    Which is our honour, bitter torture shall
line 23478-->    Winnow the truth from falsehood. On, speak to him.
line 23479-->  IMOGEN. My boon is that this gentleman may render
line 23480-->    Of whom he had this ring.
line 23481-->  POSTHUMUS. [Aside] What's that to him?
line 23482-->  CYMBELINE. That diamond upon your finger, say
line 23483-->    How came it yours?
line 23484-->  IACHIMO. Thou'lt torture me to leave unspoken that
line 23485-->    Which to be spoke would torture thee.
line 23486-->  CYMBELINE. How? me?
line 23487-->  IACHIMO. I am glad to be constrain'd to utter that  
line 23488-->    Which torments me to conceal. By villainy
line 23489-->    I got this ring; 'twas Leonatus' jewel,
line 23490-->    Whom thou didst banish; and- which more may grieve thee,
line 23491-->    As it doth me- a nobler sir ne'er liv'd
line 23492-->    'Twixt sky and ground. Wilt thou hear more, my lord?
line 23493-->  CYMBELINE. All that belongs to this.
line 23494-->  IACHIMO. That paragon, thy daughter,
line 23495-->    For whom my heart drops blood and my false spirits
line 23496-->    Quail to remember- Give me leave, I faint.
line 23497-->  CYMBELINE. My daughter? What of her? Renew thy strength;
line 23498-->    I had rather thou shouldst live while nature will
line 23499-->    Than die ere I hear more. Strive, man, and speak.
line 23500-->  IACHIMO. Upon a time- unhappy was the clock
line 23501-->    That struck the hour!- was in Rome- accurs'd
line 23502-->    The mansion where!- 'twas at a feast- O, would
line 23503-->    Our viands had been poison'd, or at least
line 23504-->    Those which I heav'd to head!- the good Posthumus-
line 23505-->    What should I say? he was too good to be
line 23506-->    Where ill men were, and was the best of all
line 23507-->    Amongst the rar'st of good ones- sitting sadly  
line 23508-->    Hearing us praise our loves of Italy
line 23509-->    For beauty that made barren the swell'd boast
line 23510-->    Of him that best could speak; for feature, laming
line 23511-->    The shrine of Venus or straight-pight Minerva,
line 23512-->    Postures beyond brief nature; for condition,
line 23513-->    A shop of all the qualities that man
line 23514-->    Loves woman for; besides that hook of wiving,
line 23515-->    Fairness which strikes the eye-
line 23516-->  CYMBELINE. I stand on fire.
line 23517-->    Come to the matter.
line 23518-->  IACHIMO. All too soon I shall,
line 23519-->    Unless thou wouldst grieve quickly. This Posthumus,
line 23520-->    Most like a noble lord in love and one
line 23521-->    That had a royal lover, took his hint;
line 23522-->    And not dispraising whom we prais'd- therein
line 23523-->    He was as calm as virtue- he began
line 23524-->    His mistress' picture; which by his tongue being made,
line 23525-->    And then a mind put in't, either our brags
line 23526-->    Were crack'd of kitchen trulls, or his description
line 23527-->    Prov'd us unspeaking sots.  
line 23528-->  CYMBELINE. Nay, nay, to th' purpose.
line 23529-->  IACHIMO. Your daughter's chastity- there it begins.
line 23530-->    He spake of her as Dian had hot dreams
line 23531-->    And she alone were cold; whereat I, wretch,
line 23532-->    Made scruple of his praise, and wager'd with him
line 23533-->    Pieces of gold 'gainst this which then he wore
line 23534-->    Upon his honour'd finger, to attain
line 23535-->    In suit the place of's bed, and win this ring
line 23536-->    By hers and mine adultery. He, true knight,
line 23537-->    No lesser of her honour confident
line 23538-->    Than I did truly find her, stakes this ring;
line 23539-->    And would so, had it been a carbuncle
line 23540-->    Of Phoebus' wheel; and might so safely, had it
line 23541-->    Been all the worth of's car. Away to Britain
line 23542-->    Post I in this design. Well may you, sir,
line 23543-->    Remember me at court, where I was taught
line 23544-->    Of your chaste daughter the wide difference
line 23545-->    'Twixt amorous and villainous. Being thus quench'd
line 23546-->    Of hope, not longing, mine Italian brain
line 23547-->    Gan in your duller Britain operate  
line 23548-->    Most vilely; for my vantage, excellent;
line 23549-->    And, to be brief, my practice so prevail'd
line 23550-->    That I return'd with simular proof enough
line 23551-->    To make the noble Leonatus mad,
line 23552-->    By wounding his belief in her renown
line 23553-->    With tokens thus and thus; averring notes
line 23554-->    Of chamber-hanging, pictures, this her bracelet-
line 23555-->    O cunning, how I got it!- nay, some marks
line 23556-->    Of secret on her person, that he could not
line 23557-->    But think her bond of chastity quite crack'd,
line 23558-->    I having ta'en the forfeit. Whereupon-
line 23559-->    Methinks I see him now-
line 23560-->  POSTHUMUS. [Coming forward] Ay, so thou dost,
line 23561-->    Italian fiend! Ay me, most credulous fool,
line 23562-->    Egregious murderer, thief, anything
line 23563-->    That's due to all the villains past, in being,
line 23564-->    To come! O, give me cord, or knife, or poison,
line 23565-->    Some upright justicer! Thou, King, send out
line 23566-->    For torturers ingenious. It is I
line 23567-->    That all th' abhorred things o' th' earth amend  
line 23568-->    By being worse than they. I am Posthumus,
line 23569-->    That kill'd thy daughter; villain-like, I lie-
line 23570-->    That caus'd a lesser villain than myself,
line 23571-->    A sacrilegious thief, to do't. The temple
line 23572-->    Of virtue was she; yea, and she herself.
line 23573-->    Spit, and throw stones, cast mire upon me, set
line 23574-->    The dogs o' th' street to bay me. Every villain
line 23575-->    Be call'd Posthumus Leonatus, and
line 23576-->    Be villainy less than 'twas! O Imogen!
line 23577-->    My queen, my life, my wife! O Imogen,
line 23578-->    Imogen, Imogen!
line 23579-->  IMOGEN. Peace, my lord. Hear, hear!
line 23580-->  POSTHUMUS. Shall's have a play of this? Thou scornful page,
line 23581-->    There lies thy part.                [Strikes her. She falls]
line 23582-->  PISANIO. O gentlemen, help!
line 23583-->    Mine and your mistress! O, my lord Posthumus!
line 23584-->    You ne'er kill'd Imogen till now. Help, help!
line 23585-->    Mine honour'd lady!
line 23586-->  CYMBELINE. Does the world go round?
line 23587-->  POSTHUMUS. How comes these staggers on me?  
line 23588-->  PISANIO. Wake, my mistress!
line 23589-->  CYMBELINE. If this be so, the gods do mean to strike me
line 23590-->    To death with mortal joy.
line 23591-->  PISANIO. How fares my mistress?
line 23592-->  IMOGEN. O, get thee from my sight;
line 23593-->    Thou gav'st me poison. Dangerous fellow, hence!
line 23594-->    Breathe not where princes are.
line 23595-->  CYMBELINE. The tune of Imogen!
line 23596-->  PISANIO. Lady,
line 23597-->    The gods throw stones of sulphur on me, if
line 23598-->    That box I gave you was not thought by me
line 23599-->    A precious thing! I had it from the Queen.
line 23600-->  CYMBELINE. New matter still?
line 23601-->  IMOGEN. It poison'd me.
line 23602-->  CORNELIUS. O gods!
line 23603-->    I left out one thing which the Queen confess'd,
line 23604-->    Which must approve thee honest. 'If Pisanio
line 23605-->    Have' said she 'given his mistress that confection
line 23606-->    Which I gave him for cordial, she is serv'd
line 23607-->    As I would serve a rat.'  
line 23608-->  CYMBELINE. What's this, Cornelius?
line 23609-->  CORNELIUS. The Queen, sir, very oft importun'd me
line 23610-->    To temper poisons for her; still pretending
line 23611-->    The satisfaction of her knowledge only
line 23612-->    In killing creatures vile, as cats and dogs,
line 23613-->    Of no esteem. I, dreading that her purpose
line 23614-->    Was of more danger, did compound for her
line 23615-->    A certain stuff, which, being ta'en would cease
line 23616-->    The present pow'r of life, but in short time
line 23617-->    All offices of nature should again
line 23618-->    Do their due functions. Have you ta'en of it?
line 23619-->  IMOGEN. Most like I did, for I was dead.
line 23620-->  BELARIUS. My boys,
line 23621-->    There was our error.
line 23622-->  GUIDERIUS. This is sure Fidele.
line 23623-->  IMOGEN. Why did you throw your wedded lady from you?
line 23624-->    Think that you are upon a rock, and now
line 23625-->    Throw me again.                              [Embracing him]
line 23626-->  POSTHUMUS. Hang there like fruit, my soul,
line 23627-->    Till the tree die!  
line 23628-->  CYMBELINE. How now, my flesh? my child?
line 23629-->    What, mak'st thou me a dullard in this act?
line 23630-->    Wilt thou not speak to me?
line 23631-->  IMOGEN. [Kneeling] Your blessing, sir.
line 23632-->  BELARIUS. [To GUIDERIUS and ARVIRAGUS] Though you did love this
line 23633-->      youth, I blame ye not;
line 23634-->    You had a motive for't.
line 23635-->  CYMBELINE. My tears that fall
line 23636-->    Prove holy water on thee! Imogen,
line 23637-->    Thy mother's dead.
line 23638-->  IMOGEN. I am sorry for't, my lord.
line 23639-->  CYMBELINE. O, she was naught, and long of her it was
line 23640-->    That we meet here so strangely; but her son
line 23641-->    Is gone, we know not how nor where.
line 23642-->  PISANIO. My lord,
line 23643-->    Now fear is from me, I'll speak troth. Lord Cloten,
line 23644-->    Upon my lady's missing, came to me
line 23645-->    With his sword drawn, foam'd at the mouth, and swore,
line 23646-->    If I discover'd not which way she was gone,
line 23647-->    It was my instant death. By accident  
line 23648-->    I had a feigned letter of my master's
line 23649-->    Then in my pocket, which directed him
line 23650-->    To seek her on the mountains near to Milford;
line 23651-->    Where, in a frenzy, in my master's garments,
line 23652-->    Which he enforc'd from me, away he posts
line 23653-->    With unchaste purpose, and with oath to violate
line 23654-->    My lady's honour. What became of him
line 23655-->    I further know not.
line 23656-->  GUIDERIUS. Let me end the story:
line 23657-->    I slew him there.
line 23658-->  CYMBELINE. Marry, the gods forfend!
line 23659-->    I would not thy good deeds should from my lips
line 23660-->    Pluck a hard sentence. Prithee, valiant youth,
line 23661-->    Deny't again.
line 23662-->  GUIDERIUS. I have spoke it, and I did it.
line 23663-->  CYMBELINE. He was a prince.
line 23664-->  GUIDERIUS. A most incivil one. The wrongs he did me
line 23665-->    Were nothing prince-like; for he did provoke me
line 23666-->    With language that would make me spurn the sea,
line 23667-->    If it could so roar to me. I cut off's head,  
line 23668-->    And am right glad he is not standing here
line 23669-->    To tell this tale of mine.
line 23670-->  CYMBELINE. I am sorry for thee.
line 23671-->    By thine own tongue thou art condemn'd, and must
line 23672-->    Endure our law. Thou'rt dead.
line 23673-->  IMOGEN. That headless man
line 23674-->    I thought had been my lord.
line 23675-->  CYMBELINE. Bind the offender,
line 23676-->    And take him from our presence.
line 23677-->  BELARIUS. Stay, sir King.
line 23678-->    This man is better than the man he slew,
line 23679-->    As well descended as thyself, and hath
line 23680-->    More of thee merited than a band of Clotens
line 23681-->    Had ever scar for. [To the guard] Let his arms alone;
line 23682-->    They were not born for bondage.
line 23683-->  CYMBELINE. Why, old soldier,
line 23684-->    Wilt thou undo the worth thou art unpaid for
line 23685-->    By tasting of our wrath? How of descent
line 23686-->    As good as we?
line 23687-->  ARVIRAGUS. In that he spake too far.  
line 23688-->  CYMBELINE. And thou shalt die for't.
line 23689-->  BELARIUS. We will die all three;
line 23690-->    But I will prove that two on's are as good
line 23691-->    As I have given out him. My sons, I must
line 23692-->    For mine own part unfold a dangerous speech,
line 23693-->    Though haply well for you.
line 23694-->  ARVIRAGUS. Your danger's ours.
line 23695-->  GUIDERIUS. And our good his.
line 23696-->  BELARIUS. Have at it then by leave!
line 23697-->    Thou hadst, great King, a subject who
line 23698-->    Was call'd Belarius.
line 23699-->  CYMBELINE. What of him? He is
line 23700-->    A banish'd traitor.
line 23701-->  BELARIUS. He it is that hath
line 23702-->    Assum'd this age; indeed a banish'd man;
line 23703-->    I know not how a traitor.
line 23704-->  CYMBELINE. Take him hence,
line 23705-->    The whole world shall not save him.
line 23706-->  BELARIUS. Not too hot.
line 23707-->    First pay me for the nursing of thy sons,  
line 23708-->    And let it be confiscate all, so soon
line 23709-->    As I have receiv'd it.
line 23710-->  CYMBELINE. Nursing of my sons?
line 23711-->  BELARIUS. I am too blunt and saucy: here's my knee.
line 23712-->    Ere I arise I will prefer my sons;
line 23713-->    Then spare not the old father. Mighty sir,
line 23714-->    These two young gentlemen that call me father,
line 23715-->    And think they are my sons, are none of mine;
line 23716-->    They are the issue of your loins, my liege,
line 23717-->    And blood of your begetting.
line 23718-->  CYMBELINE. How? my issue?
line 23719-->  BELARIUS. So sure as you your father's. I, old Morgan,
line 23720-->    Am that Belarius whom you sometime banish'd.
line 23721-->    Your pleasure was my mere offence, my punishment
line 23722-->    Itself, and all my treason; that I suffer'd
line 23723-->    Was all the harm I did. These gentle princes-
line 23724-->    For such and so they are- these twenty years
line 23725-->    Have I train'd up; those arts they have as
line 23726-->    Could put into them. My breeding was, sir, as
line 23727-->    Your Highness knows. Their nurse, Euriphile,  
line 23728-->    Whom for the theft I wedded, stole these children
line 23729-->    Upon my banishment; I mov'd her to't,
line 23730-->    Having receiv'd the punishment before
line 23731-->    For that which I did then. Beaten for loyalty
line 23732-->    Excited me to treason. Their dear loss,
line 23733-->    The more of you 'twas felt, the more it shap'd
line 23734-->    Unto my end of stealing them. But, gracious sir,
line 23735-->    Here are your sons again, and I must lose
line 23736-->    Two of the sweet'st companions in the world.
line 23737-->    The benediction of these covering heavens
line 23738-->    Fall on their heads like dew! for they are worthy
line 23739-->    To inlay heaven with stars.
line 23740-->  CYMBELINE. Thou weep'st and speak'st.
line 23741-->    The service that you three have done is more
line 23742-->    Unlike than this thou tell'st. I lost my children.
line 23743-->    If these be they, I know not how to wish
line 23744-->    A pair of worthier sons.
line 23745-->  BELARIUS. Be pleas'd awhile.
line 23746-->    This gentleman, whom I call Polydore,
line 23747-->    Most worthy prince, as yours, is true Guiderius;  
line 23748-->    This gentleman, my Cadwal, Arviragus,
line 23749-->    Your younger princely son; he, sir, was lapp'd
line 23750-->    In a most curious mantle, wrought by th' hand
line 23751-->    Of his queen mother, which for more probation
line 23752-->    I can with ease produce.
line 23753-->  CYMBELINE. Guiderius had
line 23754-->    Upon his neck a mole, a sanguine star;
line 23755-->    It was a mark of wonder.
line 23756-->  BELARIUS. This is he,
line 23757-->    Who hath upon him still that natural stamp.
line 23758-->    It was wise nature's end in the donation,
line 23759-->    To be his evidence now.
line 23760-->  CYMBELINE. O, what am I?
line 23761-->    A mother to the birth of three? Ne'er mother
line 23762-->    Rejoic'd deliverance more. Blest pray you be,
line 23763-->    That, after this strange starting from your orbs,
line 23764-->    You may reign in them now! O Imogen,
line 23765-->    Thou hast lost by this a kingdom.
line 23766-->  IMOGEN. No, my lord;
line 23767-->    I have got two worlds by't. O my gentle brothers,  
line 23768-->    Have we thus met? O, never say hereafter
line 23769-->    But I am truest speaker! You call'd me brother,
line 23770-->    When I was but your sister: I you brothers,
line 23771-->    When we were so indeed.
line 23772-->  CYMBELINE. Did you e'er meet?
line 23773-->  ARVIRAGUS. Ay, my good lord.
line 23774-->  GUIDERIUS. And at first meeting lov'd,
line 23775-->    Continu'd so until we thought he died.
line 23776-->  CORNELIUS. By the Queen's dram she swallow'd.
line 23777-->  CYMBELINE. O rare instinct!
line 23778-->    When shall I hear all through? This fierce abridgment
line 23779-->    Hath to it circumstantial branches, which
line 23780-->    Distinction should be rich in. Where? how liv'd you?
line 23781-->    And when came you to serve our Roman captive?
line 23782-->    How parted with your brothers? how first met them?
line 23783-->    Why fled you from the court? and whither? These,
line 23784-->    And your three motives to the battle, with
line 23785-->    I know not how much more, should be demanded,
line 23786-->    And all the other by-dependences,
line 23787-->    From chance to chance; but nor the time nor place  
line 23788-->    Will serve our long interrogatories. See,
line 23789-->    Posthumus anchors upon Imogen;
line 23790-->    And she, like harmless lightning, throws her eye
line 23791-->    On him, her brothers, me, her master, hitting
line 23792-->    Each object with a joy; the counterchange
line 23793-->    Is severally in all. Let's quit this ground,
line 23794-->    And smoke the temple with our sacrifices.
line 23795-->    [To BELARIUS] Thou art my brother; so we'll hold thee ever.
line 23796-->  IMOGEN. You are my father too, and did relieve me
line 23797-->    To see this gracious season.
line 23798-->  CYMBELINE. All o'erjoy'd
line 23799-->    Save these in bonds. Let them be joyful too,
line 23800-->    For they shall taste our comfort.
line 23801-->  IMOGEN. My good master,
line 23802-->    I will yet do you service.
line 23803-->  LUCIUS. Happy be you!
line 23804-->  CYMBELINE. The forlorn soldier, that so nobly fought,
line 23805-->    He would have well becom'd this place and grac'd
line 23806-->    The thankings of a king.
line 23807-->  POSTHUMUS. I am, sir,  
line 23808-->    The soldier that did company these three
line 23809-->    In poor beseeming; 'twas a fitment for
line 23810-->    The purpose I then follow'd. That I was he,
line 23811-->    Speak, Iachimo. I had you down, and might
line 23812-->    Have made you finish.
line 23813-->  IACHIMO. [Kneeling] I am down again;
line 23814-->    But now my heavy conscience sinks my knee,
line 23815-->    As then your force did. Take that life, beseech you,
line 23816-->    Which I so often owe; but your ring first,
line 23817-->    And here the bracelet of the truest princess
line 23818-->    That ever swore her faith.
line 23819-->  POSTHUMUS. Kneel not to me.
line 23820-->    The pow'r that I have on you is to spare you;
line 23821-->    The malice towards you to forgive you. Live,
line 23822-->    And deal with others better.
line 23823-->  CYMBELINE. Nobly doom'd!
line 23824-->    We'll learn our freeness of a son-in-law;
line 23825-->    Pardon's the word to all.
line 23826-->  ARVIRAGUS. You holp us, sir,
line 23827-->    As you did mean indeed to be our brother;  
line 23828-->    Joy'd are we that you are.
line 23829-->  POSTHUMUS. Your servant, Princes. Good my lord of Rome,
line 23830-->    Call forth your soothsayer. As I slept, methought
line 23831-->    Great Jupiter, upon his eagle back'd,
line 23832-->    Appear'd to me, with other spritely shows
line 23833-->    Of mine own kindred. When I wak'd, I found
line 23834-->    This label on my bosom; whose containing
line 23835-->    Is so from sense in hardness that I can
line 23836-->    Make no collection of it. Let him show
line 23837-->    His skill in the construction.
line 23838-->  LUCIUS. Philarmonus!
line 23839-->  SOOTHSAYER. Here, my good lord.
line 23840-->  LUCIUS. Read, and declare the meaning.
line 23841-->  SOOTHSAYER. [Reads] 'When as a lion's whelp shall, to himself
line 23842-->    unknown, without seeking find, and be embrac'd by
line 23843-->    a piece of tender air; and when from a stately cedar shall
line 23844-->    be lopp'd branches which, being dead many years, shall
line 23845-->    after revive, be jointed to the old stock, and freshly grow;
line 23846-->    then shall Posthumus end his miseries, Britain be fortunate
line 23847-->    and flourish in peace and plenty.'  
line 23848-->    Thou, Leonatus, art the lion's whelp;
line 23849-->    The fit and apt construction of thy name,
line 23850-->    Being Leo-natus, doth import so much.
line 23851-->    [To CYMBELINE] The piece of tender air, thy virtuous daughter,
line 23852-->    Which we call 'mollis aer,' and 'mollis aer'
line 23853-->    We term it 'mulier'; which 'mulier' I divine
line 23854-->    Is this most constant wife, who even now
line 23855-->    Answering the letter of the oracle,
line 23856-->    Unknown to you, unsought, were clipp'd about
line 23857-->    With this most tender air.
line 23858-->  CYMBELINE. This hath some seeming.
line 23859-->  SOOTHSAYER. The lofty cedar, royal Cymbeline,
line 23860-->    Personates thee; and thy lopp'd branches point
line 23861-->    Thy two sons forth, who, by Belarius stol'n,
line 23862-->    For many years thought dead, are now reviv'd,
line 23863-->    To the majestic cedar join'd, whose issue
line 23864-->    Promises Britain peace and plenty.
line 23865-->  CYMBELINE. Well,
line 23866-->    My peace we will begin. And, Caius Lucius,
line 23867-->    Although the victor, we submit to Caesar  
line 23868-->    And to the Roman empire, promising
line 23869-->    To pay our wonted tribute, from the which
line 23870-->    We were dissuaded by our wicked queen,
line 23871-->    Whom heavens in justice, both on her and hers,
line 23872-->    Have laid most heavy hand.
line 23873-->  SOOTHSAYER. The fingers of the pow'rs above do tune
line 23874-->    The harmony of this peace. The vision
line 23875-->    Which I made known to Lucius ere the stroke
line 23876-->    Of yet this scarce-cold battle, at this instant
line 23877-->    Is full accomplish'd; for the Roman eagle,
line 23878-->    From south to west on wing soaring aloft,
line 23879-->    Lessen'd herself and in the beams o' th' sun
line 23880-->    So vanish'd; which foreshow'd our princely eagle,
line 23881-->    Th'imperial Caesar, Caesar, should again unite
line 23882-->    His favour with the radiant Cymbeline,
line 23883-->    Which shines here in the west.
line 23884-->  CYMBELINE. Laud we the gods;
line 23885-->    And let our crooked smokes climb to their nostrils
line 23886-->    From our bless'd altars. Publish we this peace
line 23887-->    To all our subjects. Set we forward; let  
line 23888-->    A Roman and a British ensign wave
line 23889-->    Friendly together. So through Lud's Town march;
line 23890-->    And in the temple of great Jupiter
line 23891-->    Our peace we'll ratify; seal it with feasts.
line 23892-->    Set on there! Never was a war did cease,
line 23893-->    Ere bloody hands were wash'd, with such a peace.      Exeunt
line 23894-->
line 23895-->THE END
line 23896-->
