line 23971-->ACT I. Scene I.
line 23972-->Elsinore. A platform before the Castle.
line 23973-->
line 23974-->Enter two Sentinels-[first,] Francisco, [who paces up and down
line 23975-->at his post; then] Bernardo, [who approaches him].
line 23976-->
line 23977-->  Ber. Who's there.?
line 23978-->  Fran. Nay, answer me. Stand and unfold yourself.
line 23979-->  Ber. Long live the King!
line 23980-->  Fran. Bernardo?
line 23981-->  Ber. He.
line 23982-->  Fran. You come most carefully upon your hour.
line 23983-->  Ber. 'Tis now struck twelve. Get thee to bed, Francisco.
line 23984-->  Fran. For this relief much thanks. 'Tis bitter cold,
line 23985-->    And I am sick at heart.
line 23986-->  Ber. Have you had quiet guard?
line 23987-->  Fran. Not a mouse stirring.
line 23988-->  Ber. Well, good night.
line 23989-->    If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus,
line 23990-->    The rivals of my watch, bid them make haste.
line 23991-->
line 23992-->                    Enter Horatio and Marcellus.  
line 23993-->
line 23994-->  Fran. I think I hear them. Stand, ho! Who is there?
line 23995-->  Hor. Friends to this ground.
line 23996-->  Mar. And liegemen to the Dane.
line 23997-->  Fran. Give you good night.
line 23998-->  Mar. O, farewell, honest soldier.
line 23999-->    Who hath reliev'd you?
line 24000-->  Fran. Bernardo hath my place.
line 24001-->    Give you good night.                                   Exit.
line 24002-->  Mar. Holla, Bernardo!
line 24003-->  Ber. Say-
line 24004-->    What, is Horatio there ?
line 24005-->  Hor. A piece of him.
line 24006-->  Ber. Welcome, Horatio. Welcome, good Marcellus.
line 24007-->  Mar. What, has this thing appear'd again to-night?
line 24008-->  Ber. I have seen nothing.
line 24009-->  Mar. Horatio says 'tis but our fantasy,
line 24010-->    And will not let belief take hold of him
line 24011-->    Touching this dreaded sight, twice seen of us.
line 24012-->    Therefore I have entreated him along,  
line 24013-->    With us to watch the minutes of this night,
line 24014-->    That, if again this apparition come,
line 24015-->    He may approve our eyes and speak to it.
line 24016-->  Hor. Tush, tush, 'twill not appear.
line 24017-->  Ber. Sit down awhile,
line 24018-->    And let us once again assail your ears,
line 24019-->    That are so fortified against our story,
line 24020-->    What we two nights have seen.
line 24021-->  Hor. Well, sit we down,
line 24022-->    And let us hear Bernardo speak of this.
line 24023-->  Ber. Last night of all,
line 24024-->    When yond same star that's westward from the pole
line 24025-->    Had made his course t' illume that part of heaven
line 24026-->    Where now it burns, Marcellus and myself,
line 24027-->    The bell then beating one-
line 24028-->
line 24029-->                        Enter Ghost.
line 24030-->
line 24031-->  Mar. Peace! break thee off! Look where it comes again!
line 24032-->  Ber. In the same figure, like the King that's dead.  
line 24033-->  Mar. Thou art a scholar; speak to it, Horatio.
line 24034-->  Ber. Looks it not like the King? Mark it, Horatio.
line 24035-->  Hor. Most like. It harrows me with fear and wonder.
line 24036-->  Ber. It would be spoke to.
line 24037-->  Mar. Question it, Horatio.
line 24038-->  Hor. What art thou that usurp'st this time of night
line 24039-->    Together with that fair and warlike form
line 24040-->    In which the majesty of buried Denmark
line 24041-->    Did sometimes march? By heaven I charge thee speak!
line 24042-->  Mar. It is offended.
line 24043-->  Ber. See, it stalks away!
line 24044-->  Hor. Stay! Speak, speak! I charge thee speak!
line 24045-->                                                     Exit Ghost.
line 24046-->  Mar. 'Tis gone and will not answer.
line 24047-->  Ber. How now, Horatio? You tremble and look pale.
line 24048-->    Is not this something more than fantasy?
line 24049-->    What think you on't?
line 24050-->  Hor. Before my God, I might not this believe
line 24051-->    Without the sensible and true avouch
line 24052-->    Of mine own eyes.  
line 24053-->  Mar. Is it not like the King?
line 24054-->  Hor. As thou art to thyself.
line 24055-->    Such was the very armour he had on
line 24056-->    When he th' ambitious Norway combated.
line 24057-->    So frown'd he once when, in an angry parle,
line 24058-->    He smote the sledded Polacks on the ice.
line 24059-->    'Tis strange.
line 24060-->  Mar. Thus twice before, and jump at this dead hour,
line 24061-->    With martial stalk hath he gone by our watch.
line 24062-->  Hor. In what particular thought to work I know not;
line 24063-->    But, in the gross and scope of my opinion,
line 24064-->    This bodes some strange eruption to our state.
line 24065-->  Mar. Good now, sit down, and tell me he that knows,
line 24066-->    Why this same strict and most observant watch
line 24067-->    So nightly toils the subject of the land,
line 24068-->    And why such daily cast of brazen cannon
line 24069-->    And foreign mart for implements of war;
line 24070-->    Why such impress of shipwrights, whose sore task
line 24071-->    Does not divide the Sunday from the week.
line 24072-->    What might be toward, that this sweaty haste  
line 24073-->    Doth make the night joint-labourer with the day?
line 24074-->    Who is't that can inform me?
line 24075-->  Hor. That can I.
line 24076-->    At least, the whisper goes so. Our last king,
line 24077-->    Whose image even but now appear'd to us,
line 24078-->    Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,
line 24079-->    Thereto prick'd on by a most emulate pride,
line 24080-->    Dar'd to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet
line 24081-->    (For so this side of our known world esteem'd him)
line 24082-->    Did slay this Fortinbras; who, by a seal'd compact,
line 24083-->    Well ratified by law and heraldry,
line 24084-->    Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands
line 24085-->    Which he stood seiz'd of, to the conqueror;
line 24086-->    Against the which a moiety competent
line 24087-->    Was gaged by our king; which had return'd
line 24088-->    To the inheritance of Fortinbras,
line 24089-->    Had he been vanquisher, as, by the same comart
line 24090-->    And carriage of the article design'd,
line 24091-->    His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras,
line 24092-->    Of unimproved mettle hot and full,  
line 24093-->    Hath in the skirts of Norway, here and there,
line 24094-->    Shark'd up a list of lawless resolutes,
line 24095-->    For food and diet, to some enterprise
line 24096-->    That hath a stomach in't; which is no other,
line 24097-->    As it doth well appear unto our state,
line 24098-->    But to recover of us, by strong hand
line 24099-->    And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands
line 24100-->    So by his father lost; and this, I take it,
line 24101-->    Is the main motive of our preparations,
line 24102-->    The source of this our watch, and the chief head
line 24103-->    Of this post-haste and romage in the land.
line 24104-->  Ber. I think it be no other but e'en so.
line 24105-->    Well may it sort that this portentous figure
line 24106-->    Comes armed through our watch, so like the King
line 24107-->    That was and is the question of these wars.
line 24108-->  Hor. A mote it is to trouble the mind's eye.
line 24109-->    In the most high and palmy state of Rome,
line 24110-->    A little ere the mightiest Julius fell,
line 24111-->    The graves stood tenantless, and the sheeted dead
line 24112-->    Did squeak and gibber in the Roman streets;  
line 24113-->    As stars with trains of fire, and dews of blood,
line 24114-->    Disasters in the sun; and the moist star
line 24115-->    Upon whose influence Neptune's empire stands
line 24116-->    Was sick almost to doomsday with eclipse.
line 24117-->    And even the like precurse of fierce events,
line 24118-->    As harbingers preceding still the fates
line 24119-->    And prologue to the omen coming on,
line 24120-->    Have heaven and earth together demonstrated
line 24121-->    Unto our climature and countrymen.
line 24122-->
line 24123-->                      Enter Ghost again.
line 24124-->
line 24125-->    But soft! behold! Lo, where it comes again!
line 24126-->    I'll cross it, though it blast me.- Stay illusion!
line 24127-->                                               Spreads his arms.
line 24128-->    If thou hast any sound, or use of voice,
line 24129-->    Speak to me.
line 24130-->    If there be any good thing to be done,
line 24131-->    That may to thee do ease, and, race to me,
line 24132-->    Speak to me.  
line 24133-->    If thou art privy to thy country's fate,
line 24134-->    Which happily foreknowing may avoid,
line 24135-->    O, speak!
line 24136-->    Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life
line 24137-->    Extorted treasure in the womb of earth
line 24138-->    (For which, they say, you spirits oft walk in death),
line 24139-->                                                 The cock crows.
line 24140-->    Speak of it! Stay, and speak!- Stop it, Marcellus!
line 24141-->  Mar. Shall I strike at it with my partisan?
line 24142-->  Hor. Do, if it will not stand.
line 24143-->  Ber. 'Tis here!
line 24144-->  Hor. 'Tis here!
line 24145-->  Mar. 'Tis gone!
line 24146-->                                                     Exit Ghost.
line 24147-->    We do it wrong, being so majestical,
line 24148-->    To offer it the show of violence;
line 24149-->    For it is as the air, invulnerable,
line 24150-->    And our vain blows malicious mockery.
line 24151-->  Ber. It was about to speak, when the cock crew.
line 24152-->  Hor. And then it started, like a guilty thing  
line 24153-->    Upon a fearful summons. I have heard
line 24154-->    The cock, that is the trumpet to the morn,
line 24155-->    Doth with his lofty and shrill-sounding throat
line 24156-->    Awake the god of day; and at his warning,
line 24157-->    Whether in sea or fire, in earth or air,
line 24158-->    Th' extravagant and erring spirit hies
line 24159-->    To his confine; and of the truth herein
line 24160-->    This present object made probation.
line 24161-->  Mar. It faded on the crowing of the cock.
line 24162-->    Some say that ever, 'gainst that season comes
line 24163-->    Wherein our Saviour's birth is celebrated,
line 24164-->    The bird of dawning singeth all night long;
line 24165-->    And then, they say, no spirit dare stir abroad,
line 24166-->    The nights are wholesome, then no planets strike,
line 24167-->    No fairy takes, nor witch hath power to charm,
line 24168-->    So hallow'd and so gracious is the time.
line 24169-->  Hor. So have I heard and do in part believe it.
line 24170-->    But look, the morn, in russet mantle clad,
line 24171-->    Walks o'er the dew of yon high eastward hill.
line 24172-->    Break we our watch up; and by my advice  
line 24173-->    Let us impart what we have seen to-night
line 24174-->    Unto young Hamlet; for, upon my life,
line 24175-->    This spirit, dumb to us, will speak to him.
line 24176-->    Do you consent we shall acquaint him with it,
line 24177-->    As needful in our loves, fitting our duty?
line 24178-->    Let's do't, I pray; and I this morning know
line 24179-->    Where we shall find him most conveniently.           Exeunt.
line 24180-->
line 24181-->
line 24182-->
line 24183-->
line 24184-->Scene II.
line 24185-->Elsinore. A room of state in the Castle.
line 24186-->
line 24187-->Flourish. [Enter Claudius, King of Denmark, Gertrude the Queen, Hamlet,
line 24188-->Polonius, Laertes and his sister Ophelia, [Voltemand, Cornelius,]
line 24189-->Lords Attendant.
line 24190-->
line 24191-->  King. Though yet of Hamlet our dear brother's death
line 24192-->    The memory be green, and that it us befitted
line 24193-->    To bear our hearts in grief, and our whole kingdom
line 24194-->    To be contracted in one brow of woe,
line 24195-->    Yet so far hath discretion fought with nature
line 24196-->    That we with wisest sorrow think on him
line 24197-->    Together with remembrance of ourselves.
line 24198-->    Therefore our sometime sister, now our queen,
line 24199-->    Th' imperial jointress to this warlike state,
line 24200-->    Have we, as 'twere with a defeated joy,
line 24201-->    With an auspicious, and a dropping eye,
line 24202-->    With mirth in funeral, and with dirge in marriage,
line 24203-->    In equal scale weighing delight and dole,
line 24204-->    Taken to wife; nor have we herein barr'd
line 24205-->    Your better wisdoms, which have freely gone  
line 24206-->    With this affair along. For all, our thanks.
line 24207-->    Now follows, that you know, young Fortinbras,
line 24208-->    Holding a weak supposal of our worth,
line 24209-->    Or thinking by our late dear brother's death
line 24210-->    Our state to be disjoint and out of frame,
line 24211-->    Colleagued with this dream of his advantage,
line 24212-->    He hath not fail'd to pester us with message
line 24213-->    Importing the surrender of those lands
line 24214-->    Lost by his father, with all bands of law,
line 24215-->    To our most valiant brother. So much for him.
line 24216-->    Now for ourself and for this time of meeting.
line 24217-->    Thus much the business is: we have here writ
line 24218-->    To Norway, uncle of young Fortinbras,
line 24219-->    Who, impotent and bedrid, scarcely hears
line 24220-->    Of this his nephew's purpose, to suppress
line 24221-->    His further gait herein, in that the levies,
line 24222-->    The lists, and full proportions are all made
line 24223-->    Out of his subject; and we here dispatch
line 24224-->    You, good Cornelius, and you, Voltemand,
line 24225-->    For bearers of this greeting to old Norway,  
line 24226-->    Giving to you no further personal power
line 24227-->    To business with the King, more than the scope
line 24228-->    Of these dilated articles allow.            [Gives a paper.]
line 24229-->    Farewell, and let your haste commend your duty.
line 24230-->  Cor., Volt. In that, and all things, will we show our duty.
line 24231-->  King. We doubt it nothing. Heartily farewell.
line 24232-->                                 Exeunt Voltemand and Cornelius.
line 24233-->    And now, Laertes, what's the news with you?
line 24234-->    You told us of some suit. What is't, Laertes?
line 24235-->    You cannot speak of reason to the Dane
line 24236-->    And lose your voice. What wouldst thou beg, Laertes,
line 24237-->    That shall not be my offer, not thy asking?
line 24238-->    The head is not more native to the heart,
line 24239-->    The hand more instrumental to the mouth,
line 24240-->    Than is the throne of Denmark to thy father.
line 24241-->    What wouldst thou have, Laertes?
line 24242-->  Laer. My dread lord,
line 24243-->    Your leave and favour to return to France;
line 24244-->    From whence though willingly I came to Denmark
line 24245-->    To show my duty in your coronation,  
line 24246-->    Yet now I must confess, that duty done,
line 24247-->    My thoughts and wishes bend again toward France
line 24248-->    And bow them to your gracious leave and pardon.
line 24249-->  King. Have you your father's leave? What says Polonius?
line 24250-->  Pol. He hath, my lord, wrung from me my slow leave
line 24251-->    By laboursome petition, and at last
line 24252-->    Upon his will I seal'd my hard consent.
line 24253-->    I do beseech you give him leave to go.
line 24254-->  King. Take thy fair hour, Laertes. Time be thine,
line 24255-->    And thy best graces spend it at thy will!
line 24256-->    But now, my cousin Hamlet, and my son-
line 24257-->  Ham. [aside] A little more than kin, and less than kind!
line 24258-->  King. How is it that the clouds still hang on you?
line 24259-->  Ham. Not so, my lord. I am too much i' th' sun.
line 24260-->  Queen. Good Hamlet, cast thy nighted colour off,
line 24261-->    And let thine eye look like a friend on Denmark.
line 24262-->    Do not for ever with thy vailed lids
line 24263-->    Seek for thy noble father in the dust.
line 24264-->    Thou know'st 'tis common. All that lives must die,
line 24265-->    Passing through nature to eternity.  
line 24266-->  Ham. Ay, madam, it is common.
line 24267-->  Queen. If it be,
line 24268-->    Why seems it so particular with thee?
line 24269-->  Ham. Seems, madam, Nay, it is. I know not 'seems.'
line 24270-->    'Tis not alone my inky cloak, good mother,
line 24271-->    Nor customary suits of solemn black,
line 24272-->    Nor windy suspiration of forc'd breath,
line 24273-->    No, nor the fruitful river in the eye,
line 24274-->    Nor the dejected havior of the visage,
line 24275-->    Together with all forms, moods, shapes of grief,
line 24276-->    'That can denote me truly. These indeed seem,
line 24277-->    For they are actions that a man might play;
line 24278-->    But I have that within which passeth show-
line 24279-->    These but the trappings and the suits of woe.
line 24280-->  King. 'Tis sweet and commendable in your nature, Hamlet,
line 24281-->    To give these mourning duties to your father;
line 24282-->    But you must know, your father lost a father;
line 24283-->    That father lost, lost his, and the survivor bound
line 24284-->    In filial obligation for some term
line 24285-->    To do obsequious sorrow. But to persever  
line 24286-->    In obstinate condolement is a course
line 24287-->    Of impious stubbornness. 'Tis unmanly grief;
line 24288-->    It shows a will most incorrect to heaven,
line 24289-->    A heart unfortified, a mind impatient,
line 24290-->    An understanding simple and unschool'd;
line 24291-->    For what we know must be, and is as common
line 24292-->    As any the most vulgar thing to sense,
line 24293-->    Why should we in our peevish opposition
line 24294-->    Take it to heart? Fie! 'tis a fault to heaven,
line 24295-->    A fault against the dead, a fault to nature,
line 24296-->    To reason most absurd, whose common theme
line 24297-->    Is death of fathers, and who still hath cried,
line 24298-->    From the first corse till he that died to-day,
line 24299-->    'This must be so.' We pray you throw to earth
line 24300-->    This unprevailing woe, and think of us
line 24301-->    As of a father; for let the world take note
line 24302-->    You are the most immediate to our throne,
line 24303-->    And with no less nobility of love
line 24304-->    Than that which dearest father bears his son
line 24305-->    Do I impart toward you. For your intent  
line 24306-->    In going back to school in Wittenberg,
line 24307-->    It is most retrograde to our desire;
line 24308-->    And we beseech you, bend you to remain
line 24309-->    Here in the cheer and comfort of our eye,
line 24310-->    Our chiefest courtier, cousin, and our son.
line 24311-->  Queen. Let not thy mother lose her prayers, Hamlet.
line 24312-->    I pray thee stay with us, go not to Wittenberg.
line 24313-->  Ham. I shall in all my best obey you, madam.
line 24314-->  King. Why, 'tis a loving and a fair reply.
line 24315-->    Be as ourself in Denmark. Madam, come.
line 24316-->    This gentle and unforc'd accord of Hamlet
line 24317-->    Sits smiling to my heart; in grace whereof,
line 24318-->    No jocund health that Denmark drinks to-day
line 24319-->    But the great cannon to the clouds shall tell,
line 24320-->    And the King's rouse the heaven shall bruit again,
line 24321-->    Respeaking earthly thunder. Come away.
line 24322-->                                Flourish. Exeunt all but Hamlet.
line 24323-->  Ham. O that this too too solid flesh would melt,
line 24324-->    Thaw, and resolve itself into a dew!
line 24325-->    Or that the Everlasting had not fix'd  
line 24326-->    His canon 'gainst self-slaughter! O God! God!
line 24327-->    How weary, stale, flat, and unprofitable
line 24328-->    Seem to me all the uses of this world!
line 24329-->    Fie on't! ah, fie! 'Tis an unweeded garden
line 24330-->    That grows to seed; things rank and gross in nature
line 24331-->    Possess it merely. That it should come to this!
line 24332-->    But two months dead! Nay, not so much, not two.
line 24333-->    So excellent a king, that was to this
line 24334-->    Hyperion to a satyr; so loving to my mother
line 24335-->    That he might not beteem the winds of heaven
line 24336-->    Visit her face too roughly. Heaven and earth!
line 24337-->    Must I remember? Why, she would hang on him
line 24338-->    As if increase of appetite had grown
line 24339-->    By what it fed on; and yet, within a month-
line 24340-->    Let me not think on't! Frailty, thy name is woman!-
line 24341-->    A little month, or ere those shoes were old
line 24342-->    With which she followed my poor father's body
line 24343-->    Like Niobe, all tears- why she, even she
line 24344-->    (O God! a beast that wants discourse of reason
line 24345-->    Would have mourn'd longer) married with my uncle;  
line 24346-->    My father's brother, but no more like my father
line 24347-->    Than I to Hercules. Within a month,
line 24348-->    Ere yet the salt of most unrighteous tears
line 24349-->    Had left the flushing in her galled eyes,
line 24350-->    She married. O, most wicked speed, to post
line 24351-->    With such dexterity to incestuous sheets!
line 24352-->    It is not, nor it cannot come to good.
line 24353-->    But break my heart, for I must hold my tongue!
line 24354-->
line 24355-->          Enter Horatio, Marcellus, and Bernardo.
line 24356-->
line 24357-->  Hor. Hail to your lordship!
line 24358-->  Ham. I am glad to see you well.
line 24359-->    Horatio!- or I do forget myself.
line 24360-->  Hor. The same, my lord, and your poor servant ever.
line 24361-->  Ham. Sir, my good friend- I'll change that name with you.
line 24362-->    And what make you from Wittenberg, Horatio?
line 24363-->    Marcellus?
line 24364-->  Mar. My good lord!
line 24365-->  Ham. I am very glad to see you.- [To Bernardo] Good even, sir.-  
line 24366-->    But what, in faith, make you from Wittenberg?
line 24367-->  Hor. A truant disposition, good my lord.
line 24368-->  Ham. I would not hear your enemy say so,
line 24369-->    Nor shall you do my ear that violence
line 24370-->    To make it truster of your own report
line 24371-->    Against yourself. I know you are no truant.
line 24372-->    But what is your affair in Elsinore?
line 24373-->    We'll teach you to drink deep ere you depart.
line 24374-->  Hor. My lord, I came to see your father's funeral.
line 24375-->  Ham. I prithee do not mock me, fellow student.
line 24376-->    I think it was to see my mother's wedding.
line 24377-->  Hor. Indeed, my lord, it followed hard upon.
line 24378-->  Ham. Thrift, thrift, Horatio! The funeral bak'd meats
line 24379-->    Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables.
line 24380-->    Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven
line 24381-->    Or ever I had seen that day, Horatio!
line 24382-->    My father- methinks I see my father.
line 24383-->  Hor. O, where, my lord?
line 24384-->  Ham. In my mind's eye, Horatio.
line 24385-->  Hor. I saw him once. He was a goodly king.  
line 24386-->  Ham. He was a man, take him for all in all.
line 24387-->    I shall not look upon his like again.
line 24388-->  Hor. My lord, I think I saw him yesternight.
line 24389-->  Ham. Saw? who?
line 24390-->  Hor. My lord, the King your father.
line 24391-->  Ham. The King my father?
line 24392-->  Hor. Season your admiration for a while
line 24393-->    With an attent ear, till I may deliver
line 24394-->    Upon the witness of these gentlemen,
line 24395-->    This marvel to you.
line 24396-->  Ham. For God's love let me hear!
line 24397-->  Hor. Two nights together had these gentlemen
line 24398-->    (Marcellus and Bernardo) on their watch
line 24399-->    In the dead vast and middle of the night
line 24400-->    Been thus encount'red. A figure like your father,
line 24401-->    Armed at point exactly, cap-a-pe,
line 24402-->    Appears before them and with solemn march
line 24403-->    Goes slow and stately by them. Thrice he walk'd
line 24404-->    By their oppress'd and fear-surprised eyes,
line 24405-->    Within his truncheon's length; whilst they distill'd  
line 24406-->    Almost to jelly with the act of fear,
line 24407-->    Stand dumb and speak not to him. This to me
line 24408-->    In dreadful secrecy impart they did,
line 24409-->    And I with them the third night kept the watch;
line 24410-->    Where, as they had deliver'd, both in time,
line 24411-->    Form of the thing, each word made true and good,
line 24412-->    The apparition comes. I knew your father.
line 24413-->    These hands are not more like.
line 24414-->  Ham. But where was this?
line 24415-->  Mar. My lord, upon the platform where we watch'd.
line 24416-->  Ham. Did you not speak to it?
line 24417-->  Hor. My lord, I did;
line 24418-->    But answer made it none. Yet once methought
line 24419-->    It lifted up it head and did address
line 24420-->    Itself to motion, like as it would speak;
line 24421-->    But even then the morning cock crew loud,
line 24422-->    And at the sound it shrunk in haste away
line 24423-->    And vanish'd from our sight.
line 24424-->  Ham. 'Tis very strange.
line 24425-->  Hor. As I do live, my honour'd lord, 'tis true;  
line 24426-->    And we did think it writ down in our duty
line 24427-->    To let you know of it.
line 24428-->  Ham. Indeed, indeed, sirs. But this troubles me.
line 24429-->    Hold you the watch to-night?
line 24430-->  Both [Mar. and Ber.] We do, my lord.
line 24431-->  Ham. Arm'd, say you?
line 24432-->  Both. Arm'd, my lord.
line 24433-->  Ham. From top to toe?
line 24434-->  Both. My lord, from head to foot.
line 24435-->  Ham. Then saw you not his face?
line 24436-->  Hor. O, yes, my lord! He wore his beaver up.
line 24437-->  Ham. What, look'd he frowningly.
line 24438-->  Hor. A countenance more in sorrow than in anger.
line 24439-->  Ham. Pale or red?
line 24440-->  Hor. Nay, very pale.
line 24441-->  Ham. And fix'd his eyes upon you?
line 24442-->  Hor. Most constantly.
line 24443-->  Ham. I would I had been there.
line 24444-->  Hor. It would have much amaz'd you.
line 24445-->  Ham. Very like, very like. Stay'd it long?  
line 24446-->  Hor. While one with moderate haste might tell a hundred.
line 24447-->  Both. Longer, longer.
line 24448-->  Hor. Not when I saw't.
line 24449-->  Ham. His beard was grizzled- no?
line 24450-->  Hor. It was, as I have seen it in his life,
line 24451-->    A sable silver'd.
line 24452-->  Ham. I will watch to-night.
line 24453-->    Perchance 'twill walk again.
line 24454-->  Hor. I warr'nt it will.
line 24455-->  Ham. If it assume my noble father's person,
line 24456-->    I'll speak to it, though hell itself should gape
line 24457-->    And bid me hold my peace. I pray you all,
line 24458-->    If you have hitherto conceal'd this sight,
line 24459-->    Let it be tenable in your silence still;
line 24460-->    And whatsoever else shall hap to-night,
line 24461-->    Give it an understanding but no tongue.
line 24462-->    I will requite your loves. So, fare you well.
line 24463-->    Upon the platform, 'twixt eleven and twelve,
line 24464-->    I'll visit you.
line 24465-->  All. Our duty to your honour.  
line 24466-->  Ham. Your loves, as mine to you. Farewell.
line 24467-->                                        Exeunt [all but Hamlet].
line 24468-->    My father's spirit- in arms? All is not well.
line 24469-->    I doubt some foul play. Would the night were come!
line 24470-->    Till then sit still, my soul. Foul deeds will rise,
line 24471-->    Though all the earth o'erwhelm them, to men's eyes.
line 24472-->Exit.
line 24473-->
line 24474-->
line 24475-->
line 24476-->
line 24477-->Scene III.
line 24478-->Elsinore. A room in the house of Polonius.
line 24479-->
line 24480-->Enter Laertes and Ophelia.
line 24481-->
line 24482-->  Laer. My necessaries are embark'd. Farewell.
line 24483-->    And, sister, as the winds give benefit
line 24484-->    And convoy is assistant, do not sleep,
line 24485-->    But let me hear from you.
line 24486-->  Oph. Do you doubt that?
line 24487-->  Laer. For Hamlet, and the trifling of his favour,
line 24488-->    Hold it a fashion, and a toy in blood;
line 24489-->    A violet in the youth of primy nature,
line 24490-->    Forward, not permanent- sweet, not lasting;
line 24491-->    The perfume and suppliance of a minute;
line 24492-->    No more.
line 24493-->  Oph. No more but so?
line 24494-->  Laer. Think it no more.
line 24495-->    For nature crescent does not grow alone
line 24496-->    In thews and bulk; but as this temple waxes,
line 24497-->    The inward service of the mind and soul
line 24498-->    Grows wide withal. Perhaps he loves you now,  
line 24499-->    And now no soil nor cautel doth besmirch
line 24500-->    The virtue of his will; but you must fear,
line 24501-->    His greatness weigh'd, his will is not his own;
line 24502-->    For he himself is subject to his birth.
line 24503-->    He may not, as unvalued persons do,
line 24504-->    Carve for himself, for on his choice depends
line 24505-->    The safety and health of this whole state,
line 24506-->    And therefore must his choice be circumscrib'd
line 24507-->    Unto the voice and yielding of that body
line 24508-->    Whereof he is the head. Then if he says he loves you,
line 24509-->    It fits your wisdom so far to believe it
line 24510-->    As he in his particular act and place
line 24511-->    May give his saying deed; which is no further
line 24512-->    Than the main voice of Denmark goes withal.
line 24513-->    Then weigh what loss your honour may sustain
line 24514-->    If with too credent ear you list his songs,
line 24515-->    Or lose your heart, or your chaste treasure open
line 24516-->    To his unmast'red importunity.
line 24517-->    Fear it, Ophelia, fear it, my dear sister,
line 24518-->    And keep you in the rear of your affection,  
line 24519-->    Out of the shot and danger of desire.
line 24520-->    The chariest maid is prodigal enough
line 24521-->    If she unmask her beauty to the moon.
line 24522-->    Virtue itself scopes not calumnious strokes.
line 24523-->    The canker galls the infants of the spring
line 24524-->    Too oft before their buttons be disclos'd,
line 24525-->    And in the morn and liquid dew of youth
line 24526-->    Contagious blastments are most imminent.
line 24527-->    Be wary then; best safety lies in fear.
line 24528-->    Youth to itself rebels, though none else near.
line 24529-->  Oph. I shall th' effect of this good lesson keep
line 24530-->    As watchman to my heart. But, good my brother,
line 24531-->    Do not as some ungracious pastors do,
line 24532-->    Show me the steep and thorny way to heaven,
line 24533-->    Whiles, like a puff'd and reckless libertine,
line 24534-->    Himself the primrose path of dalliance treads
line 24535-->    And recks not his own rede.
line 24536-->  Laer. O, fear me not!
line 24537-->
line 24538-->                       Enter Polonius.  
line 24539-->
line 24540-->    I stay too long. But here my father comes.
line 24541-->    A double blessing is a double grace;
line 24542-->    Occasion smiles upon a second leave.
line 24543-->  Pol. Yet here, Laertes? Aboard, aboard, for shame!
line 24544-->    The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail,
line 24545-->    And you are stay'd for. There- my blessing with thee!
line 24546-->    And these few precepts in thy memory
line 24547-->    Look thou character. Give thy thoughts no tongue,
line 24548-->    Nor any unproportion'd thought his act.
line 24549-->    Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar:
line 24550-->    Those friends thou hast, and their adoption tried,
line 24551-->    Grapple them unto thy soul with hoops of steel;
line 24552-->    But do not dull thy palm with entertainment
line 24553-->    Of each new-hatch'd, unfledg'd comrade. Beware
line 24554-->    Of entrance to a quarrel; but being in,
line 24555-->    Bear't that th' opposed may beware of thee.
line 24556-->    Give every man thine ear, but few thy voice;
line 24557-->    Take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment.
line 24558-->    Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy,  
line 24559-->    But not express'd in fancy; rich, not gaudy;
line 24560-->    For the apparel oft proclaims the man,
line 24561-->    And they in France of the best rank and station
line 24562-->    Are most select and generous, chief in that.
line 24563-->    Neither a borrower nor a lender be;
line 24564-->    For loan oft loses both itself and friend,
line 24565-->    And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.
line 24566-->    This above all- to thine own self be true,
line 24567-->    And it must follow, as the night the day,
line 24568-->    Thou canst not then be false to any man.
line 24569-->    Farewell. My blessing season this in thee!
line 24570-->  Laer. Most humbly do I take my leave, my lord.
line 24571-->  Pol. The time invites you. Go, your servants tend.
line 24572-->  Laer. Farewell, Ophelia, and remember well
line 24573-->    What I have said to you.
line 24574-->  Oph. 'Tis in my memory lock'd,
line 24575-->    And you yourself shall keep the key of it.
line 24576-->  Laer. Farewell.                                          Exit.
line 24577-->  Pol. What is't, Ophelia, he hath said to you?
line 24578-->  Oph. So please you, something touching the Lord Hamlet.  
line 24579-->  Pol. Marry, well bethought!
line 24580-->    'Tis told me he hath very oft of late
line 24581-->    Given private time to you, and you yourself
line 24582-->    Have of your audience been most free and bounteous.
line 24583-->    If it be so- as so 'tis put on me,
line 24584-->    And that in way of caution- I must tell you
line 24585-->    You do not understand yourself so clearly
line 24586-->    As it behooves my daughter and your honour.
line 24587-->    What is between you? Give me up the truth.
line 24588-->  Oph. He hath, my lord, of late made many tenders
line 24589-->    Of his affection to me.
line 24590-->  Pol. Affection? Pooh! You speak like a green girl,
line 24591-->    Unsifted in such perilous circumstance.
line 24592-->    Do you believe his tenders, as you call them?
line 24593-->  Oph. I do not know, my lord, what I should think,
line 24594-->  Pol. Marry, I will teach you! Think yourself a baby
line 24595-->    That you have ta'en these tenders for true pay,
line 24596-->    Which are not sterling. Tender yourself more dearly,
line 24597-->    Or (not to crack the wind of the poor phrase,
line 24598-->    Running it thus) you'll tender me a fool.  
line 24599-->  Oph. My lord, he hath importun'd me with love
line 24600-->    In honourable fashion.
line 24601-->  Pol. Ay, fashion you may call it. Go to, go to!
line 24602-->  Oph. And hath given countenance to his speech, my lord,
line 24603-->    With almost all the holy vows of heaven.
line 24604-->  Pol. Ay, springes to catch woodcocks! I do know,
line 24605-->    When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul
line 24606-->    Lends the tongue vows. These blazes, daughter,
line 24607-->    Giving more light than heat, extinct in both
line 24608-->    Even in their promise, as it is a-making,
line 24609-->    You must not take for fire. From this time
line 24610-->    Be something scanter of your maiden presence.
line 24611-->    Set your entreatments at a higher rate
line 24612-->    Than a command to parley. For Lord Hamlet,
line 24613-->    Believe so much in him, that he is young,
line 24614-->    And with a larger tether may he walk
line 24615-->    Than may be given you. In few, Ophelia,
line 24616-->    Do not believe his vows; for they are brokers,
line 24617-->    Not of that dye which their investments show,
line 24618-->    But mere implorators of unholy suits,  
line 24619-->    Breathing like sanctified and pious bawds,
line 24620-->    The better to beguile. This is for all:
line 24621-->    I would not, in plain terms, from this time forth
line 24622-->    Have you so slander any moment leisure
line 24623-->    As to give words or talk with the Lord Hamlet.
line 24624-->    Look to't, I charge you. Come your ways.
line 24625-->  Oph. I shall obey, my lord.
line 24626-->                                                         Exeunt.
line 24627-->
line 24628-->
line 24629-->
line 24630-->
line 24631-->Scene IV.
line 24632-->Elsinore. The platform before the Castle.
line 24633-->
line 24634-->Enter Hamlet, Horatio, and Marcellus.
line 24635-->
line 24636-->  Ham. The air bites shrewdly; it is very cold.
line 24637-->  Hor. It is a nipping and an eager air.
line 24638-->  Ham. What hour now?
line 24639-->  Hor. I think it lacks of twelve.
line 24640-->  Mar. No, it is struck.
line 24641-->  Hor. Indeed? I heard it not. It then draws near the season
line 24642-->    Wherein the spirit held his wont to walk.
line 24643-->                   A flourish of trumpets, and two pieces go off.
line 24644-->    What does this mean, my lord?
line 24645-->  Ham. The King doth wake to-night and takes his rouse,
line 24646-->    Keeps wassail, and the swagg'ring upspring reels,
line 24647-->    And, as he drains his draughts of Rhenish down,
line 24648-->    The kettledrum and trumpet thus bray out
line 24649-->    The triumph of his pledge.
line 24650-->  Hor. Is it a custom?
line 24651-->  Ham. Ay, marry, is't;
line 24652-->    But to my mind, though I am native here  
line 24653-->    And to the manner born, it is a custom
line 24654-->    More honour'd in the breach than the observance.
line 24655-->    This heavy-headed revel east and west
line 24656-->    Makes us traduc'd and tax'd of other nations;
line 24657-->    They clip us drunkards and with swinish phrase
line 24658-->    Soil our addition; and indeed it takes
line 24659-->    From our achievements, though perform'd at height,
line 24660-->    The pith and marrow of our attribute.
line 24661-->    So oft it chances in particular men
line 24662-->    That, for some vicious mole of nature in them,
line 24663-->    As in their birth,- wherein they are not guilty,
line 24664-->    Since nature cannot choose his origin,-
line 24665-->    By the o'ergrowth of some complexion,
line 24666-->    Oft breaking down the pales and forts of reason,
line 24667-->    Or by some habit that too much o'erleavens
line 24668-->    The form of plausive manners, that these men
line 24669-->    Carrying, I say, the stamp of one defect,
line 24670-->    Being nature's livery, or fortune's star,
line 24671-->    Their virtues else- be they as pure as grace,
line 24672-->    As infinite as man may undergo-  
line 24673-->    Shall in the general censure take corruption
line 24674-->    From that particular fault. The dram of e'il
line 24675-->    Doth all the noble substance often dout To his own scandal.
line 24676-->
line 24677-->                         Enter Ghost.
line 24678-->
line 24679-->  Hor. Look, my lord, it comes!
line 24680-->  Ham. Angels and ministers of grace defend us!
line 24681-->    Be thou a spirit of health or goblin damn'd,
line 24682-->    Bring with thee airs from heaven or blasts from hell,
line 24683-->    Be thy intents wicked or charitable,
line 24684-->    Thou com'st in such a questionable shape
line 24685-->    That I will speak to thee. I'll call thee Hamlet,
line 24686-->    King, father, royal Dane. O, answer me?
line 24687-->    Let me not burst in ignorance, but tell
line 24688-->    Why thy canoniz'd bones, hearsed in death,
line 24689-->    Have burst their cerements; why the sepulchre
line 24690-->    Wherein we saw thee quietly inurn'd,
line 24691-->    Hath op'd his ponderous and marble jaws
line 24692-->    To cast thee up again. What may this mean  
line 24693-->    That thou, dead corse, again in complete steel,
line 24694-->    Revisits thus the glimpses of the moon,
line 24695-->    Making night hideous, and we fools of nature
line 24696-->    So horridly to shake our disposition
line 24697-->    With thoughts beyond the reaches of our souls?
line 24698-->    Say, why is this? wherefore? What should we do?
line 24699-->                                           Ghost beckons Hamlet.
line 24700-->  Hor. It beckons you to go away with it,
line 24701-->    As if it some impartment did desire
line 24702-->    To you alone.
line 24703-->  Mar. Look with what courteous action
line 24704-->    It waves you to a more removed ground.
line 24705-->    But do not go with it!
line 24706-->  Hor. No, by no means!
line 24707-->  Ham. It will not speak. Then will I follow it.
line 24708-->  Hor. Do not, my lord!
line 24709-->  Ham. Why, what should be the fear?
line 24710-->    I do not set my life at a pin's fee;
line 24711-->    And for my soul, what can it do to that,
line 24712-->    Being a thing immortal as itself?  
line 24713-->    It waves me forth again. I'll follow it.
line 24714-->  Hor. What if it tempt you toward the flood, my lord,
line 24715-->    Or to the dreadful summit of the cliff
line 24716-->    That beetles o'er his base into the sea,
line 24717-->    And there assume some other, horrible form
line 24718-->    Which might deprive your sovereignty of reason
line 24719-->    And draw you into madness? Think of it.
line 24720-->    The very place puts toys of desperation,
line 24721-->    Without more motive, into every brain
line 24722-->    That looks so many fadoms to the sea
line 24723-->    And hears it roar beneath.
line 24724-->  Ham. It waves me still.
line 24725-->    Go on. I'll follow thee.
line 24726-->  Mar. You shall not go, my lord.
line 24727-->  Ham. Hold off your hands!
line 24728-->  Hor. Be rul'd. You shall not go.
line 24729-->  Ham. My fate cries out
line 24730-->    And makes each petty artire in this body
line 24731-->    As hardy as the Nemean lion's nerve.
line 24732-->                                                [Ghost beckons.]  
line 24733-->    Still am I call'd. Unhand me, gentlemen.
line 24734-->    By heaven, I'll make a ghost of him that lets me!-
line 24735-->    I say, away!- Go on. I'll follow thee.
line 24736-->                                        Exeunt Ghost and Hamlet.
line 24737-->  Hor. He waxes desperate with imagination.
line 24738-->  Mar. Let's follow. 'Tis not fit thus to obey him.
line 24739-->  Hor. Have after. To what issue wail this come?
line 24740-->  Mar. Something is rotten in the state of Denmark.
line 24741-->  Hor. Heaven will direct it.
line 24742-->  Mar. Nay, let's follow him.
line 24743-->                                                         Exeunt.
line 24744-->
line 24745-->
line 24746-->
line 24747-->
line 24748-->Scene V.
line 24749-->Elsinore. The Castle. Another part of the fortifications.
line 24750-->
line 24751-->Enter Ghost and Hamlet.
line 24752-->
line 24753-->  Ham. Whither wilt thou lead me? Speak! I'll go no further.
line 24754-->  Ghost. Mark me.
line 24755-->  Ham. I will.
line 24756-->  Ghost. My hour is almost come,
line 24757-->    When I to sulph'rous and tormenting flames
line 24758-->    Must render up myself.
line 24759-->  Ham. Alas, poor ghost!
line 24760-->  Ghost. Pity me not, but lend thy serious hearing
line 24761-->    To what I shall unfold.
line 24762-->  Ham. Speak. I am bound to hear.
line 24763-->  Ghost. So art thou to revenge, when thou shalt hear.
line 24764-->  Ham. What?
line 24765-->  Ghost. I am thy father's spirit,
line 24766-->    Doom'd for a certain term to walk the night,
line 24767-->    And for the day confin'd to fast in fires,
line 24768-->    Till the foul crimes done in my days of nature
line 24769-->    Are burnt and purg'd away. But that I am forbid  
line 24770-->    To tell the secrets of my prison house,
line 24771-->    I could a tale unfold whose lightest word
line 24772-->    Would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy young blood,
line 24773-->    Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres,
line 24774-->    Thy knotted and combined locks to part,
line 24775-->    And each particular hair to stand an end
line 24776-->    Like quills upon the fretful porpentine.
line 24777-->    But this eternal blazon must not be
line 24778-->    To ears of flesh and blood. List, list, O, list!
line 24779-->    If thou didst ever thy dear father love-
line 24780-->  Ham. O God!
line 24781-->  Ghost. Revenge his foul and most unnatural murther.
line 24782-->  Ham. Murther?
line 24783-->  Ghost. Murther most foul, as in the best it is;
line 24784-->    But this most foul, strange, and unnatural.
line 24785-->  Ham. Haste me to know't, that I, with wings as swift
line 24786-->    As meditation or the thoughts of love,
line 24787-->    May sweep to my revenge.
line 24788-->  Ghost. I find thee apt;
line 24789-->    And duller shouldst thou be than the fat weed  
line 24790-->    That rots itself in ease on Lethe wharf,
line 24791-->    Wouldst thou not stir in this. Now, Hamlet, hear.
line 24792-->    'Tis given out that, sleeping in my orchard,
line 24793-->    A serpent stung me. So the whole ear of Denmark
line 24794-->    Is by a forged process of my death
line 24795-->    Rankly abus'd. But know, thou noble youth,
line 24796-->    The serpent that did sting thy father's life
line 24797-->    Now wears his crown.
line 24798-->  Ham. O my prophetic soul!
line 24799-->    My uncle?
line 24800-->  Ghost. Ay, that incestuous, that adulterate beast,
line 24801-->    With witchcraft of his wit, with traitorous gifts-
line 24802-->    O wicked wit and gifts, that have the power
line 24803-->    So to seduce!- won to his shameful lust
line 24804-->    The will of my most seeming-virtuous queen.
line 24805-->    O Hamlet, what a falling-off was there,
line 24806-->    From me, whose love was of that dignity
line 24807-->    That it went hand in hand even with the vow
line 24808-->    I made to her in marriage, and to decline
line 24809-->    Upon a wretch whose natural gifts were poor  
line 24810-->    To those of mine!
line 24811-->    But virtue, as it never will be mov'd,
line 24812-->    Though lewdness court it in a shape of heaven,
line 24813-->    So lust, though to a radiant angel link'd,
line 24814-->    Will sate itself in a celestial bed
line 24815-->    And prey on garbage.
line 24816-->    But soft! methinks I scent the morning air.
line 24817-->    Brief let me be. Sleeping within my orchard,
line 24818-->    My custom always of the afternoon,
line 24819-->    Upon my secure hour thy uncle stole,
line 24820-->    With juice of cursed hebona in a vial,
line 24821-->    And in the porches of my ears did pour
line 24822-->    The leperous distilment; whose effect
line 24823-->    Holds such an enmity with blood of man
line 24824-->    That swift as quicksilverr it courses through
line 24825-->    The natural gates and alleys of the body,
line 24826-->    And with a sudden vigour it doth posset
line 24827-->    And curd, like eager droppings into milk,
line 24828-->    The thin and wholesome blood. So did it mine;
line 24829-->    And a most instant tetter bark'd about,  
line 24830-->    Most lazar-like, with vile and loathsome crust
line 24831-->    All my smooth body.
line 24832-->    Thus was I, sleeping, by a brother's hand
line 24833-->    Of life, of crown, of queen, at once dispatch'd;
line 24834-->    Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin,
line 24835-->    Unhous'led, disappointed, unanel'd,
line 24836-->    No reckoning made, but sent to my account
line 24837-->    With all my imperfections on my head.
line 24838-->  Ham. O, horrible! O, horrible! most horrible!
line 24839-->  Ghost. If thou hast nature in thee, bear it not.
line 24840-->    Let not the royal bed of Denmark be
line 24841-->    A couch for luxury and damned incest.
line 24842-->    But, howsoever thou pursuest this act,
line 24843-->    Taint not thy mind, nor let thy soul contrive
line 24844-->    Against thy mother aught. Leave her to heaven,
line 24845-->    And to those thorns that in her bosom lodge
line 24846-->    To prick and sting her. Fare thee well at once.
line 24847-->    The glowworm shows the matin to be near
line 24848-->    And gins to pale his uneffectual fire.
line 24849-->    Adieu, adieu, adieu! Remember me.                      Exit.  
line 24850-->  Ham. O all you host of heaven! O earth! What else?
line 24851-->    And shall I couple hell? Hold, hold, my heart!
line 24852-->    And you, my sinews, grow not instant old,
line 24853-->    But bear me stiffly up. Remember thee?
line 24854-->    Ay, thou poor ghost, while memory holds a seat
line 24855-->    In this distracted globe. Remember thee?
line 24856-->    Yea, from the table of my memory
line 24857-->    I'll wipe away all trivial fond records,
line 24858-->    All saws of books, all forms, all pressures past
line 24859-->    That youth and observation copied there,
line 24860-->    And thy commandment all alone shall live
line 24861-->    Within the book and volume of my brain,
line 24862-->    Unmix'd with baser matter. Yes, by heaven!
line 24863-->    O most pernicious woman!
line 24864-->    O villain, villain, smiling, damned villain!
line 24865-->    My tables! Meet it is I set it down
line 24866-->    That one may smile, and smile, and be a villain;
line 24867-->    At least I am sure it may be so in Denmark.        [Writes.]
line 24868-->    So, uncle, there you are. Now to my word:
line 24869-->    It is 'Adieu, adieu! Remember me.'  
line 24870-->    I have sworn't.
line 24871-->  Hor. (within) My lord, my lord!
line 24872-->
line 24873-->                   Enter Horatio and Marcellus.
line 24874-->
line 24875-->  Mar. Lord Hamlet!
line 24876-->  Hor. Heaven secure him!
line 24877-->  Ham. So be it!
line 24878-->  Mar. Illo, ho, ho, my lord!
line 24879-->  Ham. Hillo, ho, ho, boy! Come, bird, come.
line 24880-->  Mar. How is't, my noble lord?
line 24881-->  Hor. What news, my lord?
line 24882-->  Mar. O, wonderful!
line 24883-->  Hor. Good my lord, tell it.
line 24884-->  Ham. No, you will reveal it.
line 24885-->  Hor. Not I, my lord, by heaven!
line 24886-->  Mar. Nor I, my lord.
line 24887-->  Ham. How say you then? Would heart of man once think it?
line 24888-->    But you'll be secret?
line 24889-->  Both. Ay, by heaven, my lord.  
line 24890-->  Ham. There's neer a villain dwelling in all Denmark
line 24891-->    But he's an arrant knave.
line 24892-->  Hor. There needs no ghost, my lord, come from the grave
line 24893-->    To tell us this.
line 24894-->  Ham. Why, right! You are in the right!
line 24895-->    And so, without more circumstance at all,
line 24896-->    I hold it fit that we shake hands and part;
line 24897-->    You, as your business and desires shall point you,
line 24898-->    For every man hath business and desire,
line 24899-->    Such as it is; and for my own poor part,
line 24900-->    Look you, I'll go pray.
line 24901-->  Hor. These are but wild and whirling words, my lord.
line 24902-->  Ham. I am sorry they offend you, heartily;
line 24903-->    Yes, faith, heartily.
line 24904-->  Hor. There's no offence, my lord.
line 24905-->  Ham. Yes, by Saint Patrick, but there is, Horatio,
line 24906-->    And much offence too. Touching this vision here,
line 24907-->    It is an honest ghost, that let me tell you.
line 24908-->    For your desire to know what is between us,
line 24909-->    O'ermaster't as you may. And now, good friends,  
line 24910-->    As you are friends, scholars, and soldiers,
line 24911-->    Give me one poor request.
line 24912-->  Hor. What is't, my lord? We will.
line 24913-->  Ham. Never make known what you have seen to-night.
line 24914-->  Both. My lord, we will not.
line 24915-->  Ham. Nay, but swear't.
line 24916-->  Hor. In faith,
line 24917-->    My lord, not I.
line 24918-->  Mar. Nor I, my lord- in faith.
line 24919-->  Ham. Upon my sword.
line 24920-->  Mar. We have sworn, my lord, already.
line 24921-->  Ham. Indeed, upon my sword, indeed.
line 24922-->
line 24923-->                 Ghost cries under the stage.
line 24924-->
line 24925-->  Ghost. Swear.
line 24926-->  Ham. Aha boy, say'st thou so? Art thou there, truepenny?
line 24927-->    Come on! You hear this fellow in the cellarage.
line 24928-->    Consent to swear.
line 24929-->  Hor. Propose the oath, my lord.  
line 24930-->  Ham. Never to speak of this that you have seen.
line 24931-->    Swear by my sword.
line 24932-->  Ghost. [beneath] Swear.
line 24933-->  Ham. Hic et ubique? Then we'll shift our ground.
line 24934-->    Come hither, gentlemen,
line 24935-->    And lay your hands again upon my sword.
line 24936-->    Never to speak of this that you have heard:
line 24937-->    Swear by my sword.
line 24938-->  Ghost. [beneath] Swear by his sword.
line 24939-->  Ham. Well said, old mole! Canst work i' th' earth so fast?
line 24940-->    A worthy pioner! Once more remove, good friends."
line 24941-->  Hor. O day and night, but this is wondrous strange!
line 24942-->  Ham. And therefore as a stranger give it welcome.
line 24943-->    There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio,
line 24944-->    Than are dreamt of in your philosophy.
line 24945-->    But come!
line 24946-->    Here, as before, never, so help you mercy,
line 24947-->    How strange or odd soe'er I bear myself
line 24948-->    (As I perchance hereafter shall think meet
line 24949-->    To put an antic disposition on),  
line 24950-->    That you, at such times seeing me, never shall,
line 24951-->    With arms encumb'red thus, or this head-shake,
line 24952-->    Or by pronouncing of some doubtful phrase,
line 24953-->    As 'Well, well, we know,' or 'We could, an if we would,'
line 24954-->    Or 'If we list to speak,' or 'There be, an if they might,'
line 24955-->    Or such ambiguous giving out, to note
line 24956-->    That you know aught of me- this is not to do,
line 24957-->    So grace and mercy at your most need help you,
line 24958-->    Swear.
line 24959-->  Ghost. [beneath] Swear.
line 24960-->                                                   [They swear.]
line 24961-->  Ham. Rest, rest, perturbed spirit! So, gentlemen,
line 24962-->    With all my love I do commend me to you;
line 24963-->    And what so poor a man as Hamlet is
line 24964-->    May do t' express his love and friending to you,
line 24965-->    God willing, shall not lack. Let us go in together;
line 24966-->    And still your fingers on your lips, I pray.
line 24967-->    The time is out of joint. O cursed spite
line 24968-->    That ever I was born to set it right!
line 24969-->    Nay, come, let's go together.  
line 24970-->                                                         Exeunt.
line 24971-->
