line 24985-->
line 24986-->Act II. Scene I.
line 24987-->Elsinore. A room in the house of Polonius.
line 24988-->
line 24989-->Enter Polonius and Reynaldo.
line 24990-->
line 24991-->  Pol. Give him this money and these notes, Reynaldo.
line 24992-->  Rey. I will, my lord.
line 24993-->  Pol. You shall do marvell's wisely, good Reynaldo,
line 24994-->    Before You visit him, to make inquire
line 24995-->    Of his behaviour.
line 24996-->  Rey. My lord, I did intend it.
line 24997-->  Pol. Marry, well said, very well said. Look you, sir,
line 24998-->    Enquire me first what Danskers are in Paris;
line 24999-->    And how, and who, what means, and where they keep,
line 25000-->    What company, at what expense; and finding
line 25001-->    By this encompassment and drift of question
line 25002-->    That they do know my son, come you more nearer
line 25003-->    Than your particular demands will touch it.
line 25004-->    Take you, as 'twere, some distant knowledge of him;
line 25005-->    As thus, 'I know his father and his friends,
line 25006-->    And in part him.' Do you mark this, Reynaldo?
line 25007-->  Rey. Ay, very well, my lord.  
line 25008-->  Pol. 'And in part him, but,' you may say, 'not well.
line 25009-->    But if't be he I mean, he's very wild
line 25010-->    Addicted so and so'; and there put on him
line 25011-->    What forgeries you please; marry, none so rank
line 25012-->    As may dishonour him- take heed of that;
line 25013-->    But, sir, such wanton, wild, and usual slips
line 25014-->    As are companions noted and most known
line 25015-->    To youth and liberty.
line 25016-->  Rey. As gaming, my lord.
line 25017-->  Pol. Ay, or drinking, fencing, swearing, quarrelling,
line 25018-->    Drabbing. You may go so far.
line 25019-->  Rey. My lord, that would dishonour him.
line 25020-->  Pol. Faith, no, as you may season it in the charge.
line 25021-->    You must not put another scandal on him,
line 25022-->    That he is open to incontinency.
line 25023-->    That's not my meaning. But breathe his faults so quaintly
line 25024-->    That they may seem the taints of liberty,
line 25025-->    The flash and outbreak of a fiery mind,
line 25026-->    A savageness in unreclaimed blood,
line 25027-->    Of general assault.  
line 25028-->  Rey. But, my good lord-
line 25029-->  Pol. Wherefore should you do this?
line 25030-->  Rey. Ay, my lord,
line 25031-->    I would know that.
line 25032-->  Pol. Marry, sir, here's my drift,
line 25033-->    And I believe it is a fetch of warrant.
line 25034-->    You laying these slight sullies on my son
line 25035-->    As 'twere a thing a little soil'd i' th' working,
line 25036-->    Mark you,
line 25037-->    Your party in converse, him you would sound,
line 25038-->    Having ever seen in the prenominate crimes
line 25039-->    The youth you breathe of guilty, be assur'd
line 25040-->    He closes with you in this consequence:
line 25041-->    'Good sir,' or so, or 'friend,' or 'gentleman'-
line 25042-->    According to the phrase or the addition
line 25043-->    Of man and country-
line 25044-->  Rey. Very good, my lord.
line 25045-->  Pol. And then, sir, does 'a this- 'a does- What was I about to say?
line 25046-->    By the mass, I was about to say something! Where did I leave?
line 25047-->  Rey. At 'closes in the consequence,' at 'friend or so,' and  
line 25048-->    gentleman.'
line 25049-->  Pol. At 'closes in the consequence'- Ay, marry!
line 25050-->    He closes thus: 'I know the gentleman.
line 25051-->    I saw him yesterday, or t'other day,
line 25052-->    Or then, or then, with such or such; and, as you say,
line 25053-->    There was 'a gaming; there o'ertook in's rouse;
line 25054-->    There falling out at tennis'; or perchance,
line 25055-->    'I saw him enter such a house of sale,'
line 25056-->    Videlicet, a brothel, or so forth.
line 25057-->    See you now-
line 25058-->    Your bait of falsehood takes this carp of truth;
line 25059-->    And thus do we of wisdom and of reach,
line 25060-->    With windlasses and with assays of bias,
line 25061-->    By indirections find directions out.
line 25062-->    So, by my former lecture and advice,
line 25063-->    Shall you my son. You have me, have you not
line 25064-->  Rey. My lord, I have.
line 25065-->  Pol. God b' wi' ye, fare ye well!
line 25066-->  Rey. Good my lord!                                    [Going.]
line 25067-->  Pol. Observe his inclination in yourself.  
line 25068-->  Rey. I shall, my lord.
line 25069-->  Pol. And let him ply his music.
line 25070-->  Rey. Well, my lord.
line 25071-->  Pol. Farewell!
line 25072-->                                                  Exit Reynaldo.
line 25073-->
line 25074-->                       Enter Ophelia.
line 25075-->
line 25076-->    How now, Ophelia? What's the matter?
line 25077-->  Oph. O my lord, my lord, I have been so affrighted!
line 25078-->  Pol. With what, i' th' name of God I
line 25079-->  Oph. My lord, as I was sewing in my closet,
line 25080-->    Lord Hamlet, with his doublet all unbrac'd,
line 25081-->    No hat upon his head, his stockings foul'd,
line 25082-->    Ungart'red, and down-gyved to his ankle;
line 25083-->    Pale as his shirt, his knees knocking each other,
line 25084-->    And with a look so piteous in purport
line 25085-->    As if he had been loosed out of hell
line 25086-->    To speak of horrors- he comes before me.
line 25087-->  Pol. Mad for thy love?  
line 25088-->  Oph. My lord, I do not know,
line 25089-->    But truly I do fear it.
line 25090-->  Pol. What said he?
line 25091-->  Oph. He took me by the wrist and held me hard;
line 25092-->    Then goes he to the length of all his arm,
line 25093-->    And, with his other hand thus o'er his brow,
line 25094-->    He falls to such perusal of my face
line 25095-->    As he would draw it. Long stay'd he so.
line 25096-->    At last, a little shaking of mine arm,
line 25097-->    And thrice his head thus waving up and down,
line 25098-->    He rais'd a sigh so piteous and profound
line 25099-->    As it did seem to shatter all his bulk
line 25100-->    And end his being. That done, he lets me go,
line 25101-->    And with his head over his shoulder turn'd
line 25102-->    He seem'd to find his way without his eyes,
line 25103-->    For out o' doors he went without their help
line 25104-->    And to the last bended their light on me.
line 25105-->  Pol. Come, go with me. I will go seek the King.
line 25106-->    This is the very ecstasy of love,
line 25107-->    Whose violent property fordoes itself  
line 25108-->    And leads the will to desperate undertakings
line 25109-->    As oft as any passion under heaven
line 25110-->    That does afflict our natures. I am sorry.
line 25111-->    What, have you given him any hard words of late?
line 25112-->  Oph. No, my good lord; but, as you did command,
line 25113-->    I did repel his letters and denied
line 25114-->    His access to me.
line 25115-->  Pol. That hath made him mad.
line 25116-->    I am sorry that with better heed and judgment
line 25117-->    I had not quoted him. I fear'd he did but trifle
line 25118-->    And meant to wrack thee; but beshrew my jealousy!
line 25119-->    By heaven, it is as proper to our age
line 25120-->    To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions
line 25121-->    As it is common for the younger sort
line 25122-->    To lack discretion. Come, go we to the King.
line 25123-->    This must be known; which, being kept close, might move
line 25124-->    More grief to hide than hate to utter love.
line 25125-->    Come.
line 25126-->                                                         Exeunt.
line 25127-->
line 25128-->Scene II.
line 25129-->Elsinore. A room in the Castle.
line 25130-->
line 25131-->Flourish. [Enter King and Queen, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, cum aliis.
line 25132-->
line 25133-->  King. Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.
line 25134-->    Moreover that we much did long to see you,
line 25135-->    The need we have to use you did provoke
line 25136-->    Our hasty sending. Something have you heard
line 25137-->    Of Hamlet's transformation. So I call it,
line 25138-->    Sith nor th' exterior nor the inward man
line 25139-->    Resembles that it was. What it should be,
line 25140-->    More than his father's death, that thus hath put him
line 25141-->    So much from th' understanding of himself,
line 25142-->    I cannot dream of. I entreat you both
line 25143-->    That, being of so young clays brought up with him,
line 25144-->    And since so neighbour'd to his youth and haviour,
line 25145-->    That you vouchsafe your rest here in our court
line 25146-->    Some little time; so by your companies
line 25147-->    To draw him on to pleasures, and to gather
line 25148-->    So much as from occasion you may glean,  
line 25149-->    Whether aught to us unknown afflicts him thus
line 25150-->    That, open'd, lies within our remedy.
line 25151-->  Queen. Good gentlemen, he hath much talk'd of you,
line 25152-->    And sure I am two men there are not living
line 25153-->    To whom he more adheres. If it will please you
line 25154-->    To show us so much gentry and good will
line 25155-->    As to expend your time with us awhile
line 25156-->    For the supply and profit of our hope,
line 25157-->    Your visitation shall receive such thanks
line 25158-->    As fits a king's remembrance.
line 25159-->  Ros. Both your Majesties
line 25160-->    Might, by the sovereign power you have of us,
line 25161-->    Put your dread pleasures more into command
line 25162-->    Than to entreaty.
line 25163-->  Guil. But we both obey,
line 25164-->    And here give up ourselves, in the full bent,
line 25165-->    To lay our service freely at your feet,
line 25166-->    To be commanded.
line 25167-->  King. Thanks, Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern.
line 25168-->  Queen. Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz.  
line 25169-->    And I beseech you instantly to visit
line 25170-->    My too much changed son.- Go, some of you,
line 25171-->    And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is.
line 25172-->  Guil. Heavens make our presence and our practices
line 25173-->    Pleasant and helpful to him!
line 25174-->  Queen. Ay, amen!
line 25175-->                 Exeunt Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, [with some
line 25176-->                                                    Attendants].
line 25177-->
line 25178-->                         Enter Polonius.
line 25179-->
line 25180-->  Pol. Th' ambassadors from Norway, my good lord,
line 25181-->    Are joyfully return'd.
line 25182-->  King. Thou still hast been the father of good news.
line 25183-->  Pol. Have I, my lord? Assure you, my good liege,
line 25184-->    I hold my duty as I hold my soul,
line 25185-->    Both to my God and to my gracious king;
line 25186-->    And I do think- or else this brain of mine
line 25187-->    Hunts not the trail of policy so sure
line 25188-->    As it hath us'd to do- that I have found  
line 25189-->    The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy.
line 25190-->  King. O, speak of that! That do I long to hear.
line 25191-->  Pol. Give first admittance to th' ambassadors.
line 25192-->    My news shall be the fruit to that great feast.
line 25193-->  King. Thyself do grace to them, and bring them in.
line 25194-->                                                [Exit Polonius.]
line 25195-->    He tells me, my dear Gertrude, he hath found
line 25196-->    The head and source of all your son's distemper.
line 25197-->  Queen. I doubt it is no other but the main,
line 25198-->    His father's death and our o'erhasty marriage.
line 25199-->  King. Well, we shall sift him.
line 25200-->
line 25201-->              Enter Polonius, Voltemand, and Cornelius.
line 25202-->
line 25203-->    Welcome, my good friends.
line 25204-->    Say, Voltemand, what from our brother Norway?
line 25205-->  Volt. Most fair return of greetings and desires.
line 25206-->    Upon our first, he sent out to suppress
line 25207-->    His nephew's levies; which to him appear'd
line 25208-->    To be a preparation 'gainst the Polack,  
line 25209-->    But better look'd into, he truly found
line 25210-->    It was against your Highness; whereat griev'd,
line 25211-->    That so his sickness, age, and impotence
line 25212-->    Was falsely borne in hand, sends out arrests
line 25213-->    On Fortinbras; which he, in brief, obeys,
line 25214-->    Receives rebuke from Norway, and, in fine,
line 25215-->    Makes vow before his uncle never more
line 25216-->    To give th' assay of arms against your Majesty.
line 25217-->    Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy,
line 25218-->    Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee
line 25219-->    And his commission to employ those soldiers,
line 25220-->    So levied as before, against the Polack;
line 25221-->    With an entreaty, herein further shown,
line 25222-->                                                [Gives a paper.]
line 25223-->    That it might please you to give quiet pass
line 25224-->    Through your dominions for this enterprise,
line 25225-->    On such regards of safety and allowance
line 25226-->    As therein are set down.
line 25227-->  King. It likes us well;
line 25228-->    And at our more consider'd time we'll read,  
line 25229-->    Answer, and think upon this business.
line 25230-->    Meantime we thank you for your well-took labour.
line 25231-->    Go to your rest; at night we'll feast together.
line 25232-->    Most welcome home!                       Exeunt Ambassadors.
line 25233-->  Pol. This business is well ended.
line 25234-->    My liege, and madam, to expostulate
line 25235-->    What majesty should be, what duty is,
line 25236-->    Why day is day, night is night, and time is time.
line 25237-->    Were nothing but to waste night, day, and time.
line 25238-->    Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit,
line 25239-->    And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes,
line 25240-->    I will be brief. Your noble son is mad.
line 25241-->    Mad call I it; for, to define true madness,
line 25242-->    What is't but to be nothing else but mad?
line 25243-->    But let that go.
line 25244-->  Queen. More matter, with less art.
line 25245-->  Pol. Madam, I swear I use no art at all.
line 25246-->    That he is mad, 'tis true: 'tis true 'tis pity;
line 25247-->    And pity 'tis 'tis true. A foolish figure!
line 25248-->    But farewell it, for I will use no art.  
line 25249-->    Mad let us grant him then. And now remains
line 25250-->    That we find out the cause of this effect-
line 25251-->    Or rather say, the cause of this defect,
line 25252-->    For this effect defective comes by cause.
line 25253-->    Thus it remains, and the remainder thus.
line 25254-->    Perpend.
line 25255-->    I have a daughter (have while she is mine),
line 25256-->    Who in her duty and obedience, mark,
line 25257-->    Hath given me this. Now gather, and surmise.
line 25258-->                                             [Reads] the letter.
line 25259-->    'To the celestial, and my soul's idol, the most beautified
line 25260-->      Ophelia,'-
line 25261-->
line 25262-->    That's an ill phrase, a vile phrase; 'beautified' is a vile
line 25263-->      phrase.
line 25264-->    But you shall hear. Thus:
line 25265-->                                                        [Reads.]
line 25266-->    'In her excellent white bosom, these, &c.'
line 25267-->  Queen. Came this from Hamlet to her?
line 25268-->  Pol. Good madam, stay awhile. I will be faithful.     [Reads.]  
line 25269-->
line 25270-->          'Doubt thou the stars are fire;
line 25271-->            Doubt that the sun doth move;
line 25272-->          Doubt truth to be a liar;
line 25273-->            But never doubt I love.
line 25274-->      'O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers; I have not art to
line 25275-->    reckon my groans; but that I love thee best, O most best, believe
line 25276-->    it. Adieu.
line 25277-->      'Thine evermore, most dear lady, whilst this machine is to him,
line 25278-->                                                          HAMLET.'
line 25279-->
line 25280-->    This, in obedience, hath my daughter shown me;
line 25281-->    And more above, hath his solicitings,
line 25282-->    As they fell out by time, by means, and place,
line 25283-->    All given to mine ear.
line 25284-->  King. But how hath she
line 25285-->    Receiv'd his love?
line 25286-->  Pol. What do you think of me?
line 25287-->  King. As of a man faithful and honourable.
line 25288-->  Pol. I would fain prove so. But what might you think,  
line 25289-->    When I had seen this hot love on the wing
line 25290-->    (As I perceiv'd it, I must tell you that,
line 25291-->    Before my daughter told me), what might you,
line 25292-->    Or my dear Majesty your queen here, think,
line 25293-->    If I had play'd the desk or table book,
line 25294-->    Or given my heart a winking, mute and dumb,
line 25295-->    Or look'd upon this love with idle sight?
line 25296-->    What might you think? No, I went round to work
line 25297-->    And my young mistress thus I did bespeak:
line 25298-->    'Lord Hamlet is a prince, out of thy star.
line 25299-->    This must not be.' And then I prescripts gave her,
line 25300-->    That she should lock herself from his resort,
line 25301-->    Admit no messengers, receive no tokens.
line 25302-->    Which done, she took the fruits of my advice,
line 25303-->    And he, repulsed, a short tale to make,
line 25304-->    Fell into a sadness, then into a fast,
line 25305-->    Thence to a watch, thence into a weakness,
line 25306-->    Thence to a lightness, and, by this declension,
line 25307-->    Into the madness wherein now he raves,
line 25308-->    And all we mourn for.  
line 25309-->  King. Do you think 'tis this?
line 25310-->  Queen. it may be, very like.
line 25311-->  Pol. Hath there been such a time- I would fain know that-
line 25312-->    That I have Positively said ''Tis so,'
line 25313-->    When it prov'd otherwise.?
line 25314-->  King. Not that I know.
line 25315-->  Pol. [points to his head and shoulder] Take this from this, if this
line 25316-->      be otherwise.
line 25317-->    If circumstances lead me, I will find
line 25318-->    Where truth is hid, though it were hid indeed
line 25319-->    Within the centre.
line 25320-->  King. How may we try it further?
line 25321-->  Pol. You know sometimes he walks four hours together
line 25322-->    Here in the lobby.
line 25323-->  Queen. So he does indeed.
line 25324-->  Pol. At such a time I'll loose my daughter to him.
line 25325-->    Be you and I behind an arras then.
line 25326-->    Mark the encounter. If he love her not,
line 25327-->    And he not from his reason fall'n thereon
line 25328-->    Let me be no assistant for a state,  
line 25329-->    But keep a farm and carters.
line 25330-->  King. We will try it.
line 25331-->
line 25332-->                 Enter Hamlet, reading on a book.
line 25333-->
line 25334-->  Queen. But look where sadly the poor wretch comes reading.
line 25335-->  Pol. Away, I do beseech you, both away
line 25336-->    I'll board him presently. O, give me leave.
line 25337-->                       Exeunt King and Queen, [with Attendants].
line 25338-->    How does my good Lord Hamlet?
line 25339-->  Ham. Well, God-a-mercy.
line 25340-->  Pol. Do you know me, my lord?
line 25341-->  Ham. Excellent well. You are a fishmonger.
line 25342-->  Pol. Not I, my lord.
line 25343-->  Ham. Then I would you were so honest a man.
line 25344-->  Pol. Honest, my lord?
line 25345-->  Ham. Ay, sir. To be honest, as this world goes, is to be one man
line 25346-->    pick'd out of ten thousand.
line 25347-->  Pol. That's very true, my lord.
line 25348-->  Ham. For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a god  
line 25349-->    kissing carrion- Have you a daughter?
line 25350-->  Pol. I have, my lord.
line 25351-->  Ham. Let her not walk i' th' sun. Conception is a blessing, but not
line 25352-->    as your daughter may conceive. Friend, look to't.
line 25353-->  Pol. [aside] How say you by that? Still harping on my daughter. Yet
line 25354-->    he knew me not at first. He said I was a fishmonger. He is far
line 25355-->    gone, far gone! And truly in my youth I suff'red much extremity
line 25356-->    for love- very near this. I'll speak to him again.- What do you
line 25357-->    read, my lord?
line 25358-->  Ham. Words, words, words.
line 25359-->  Pol. What is the matter, my lord?
line 25360-->  Ham. Between who?
line 25361-->  Pol. I mean, the matter that you read, my lord.
line 25362-->  Ham. Slanders, sir; for the satirical rogue says here that old men
line 25363-->    have grey beards; that their faces are wrinkled; their eyes
line 25364-->    purging thick amber and plum-tree gum; and that they have a
line 25365-->    plentiful lack of wit, together with most weak hams. All which,
line 25366-->    sir, though I most powerfully and potently believe, yet I hold it
line 25367-->    not honesty to have it thus set down; for you yourself, sir,
line 25368-->    should be old as I am if, like a crab, you could go backward.  
line 25369-->  Pol. [aside] Though this be madness, yet there is a method in't.-
line 25370-->   Will You walk out of the air, my lord?
line 25371-->  Ham. Into my grave?
line 25372-->  Pol. Indeed, that is out o' th' air. [Aside] How pregnant sometimes
line 25373-->    his replies are! a happiness that often madness hits on, which
line 25374-->    reason and sanity could not so prosperously be delivered of. I
line 25375-->    will leave him and suddenly contrive the means of meeting between
line 25376-->    him and my daughter.- My honourable lord, I will most humbly take
line 25377-->    my leave of you.
line 25378-->  Ham. You cannot, sir, take from me anything that I will more
line 25379-->    willingly part withal- except my life, except my life, except my
line 25380-->    life,
line 25381-->
line 25382-->                    Enter Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.
line 25383-->
line 25384-->  Pol. Fare you well, my lord.
line 25385-->  Ham. These tedious old fools!
line 25386-->  Pol. You go to seek the Lord Hamlet. There he is.
line 25387-->  Ros. [to Polonius] God save you, sir!
line 25388-->                                                Exit [Polonius].  
line 25389-->  Guil. My honour'd lord!
line 25390-->  Ros. My most dear lord!
line 25391-->  Ham. My excellent good friends! How dost thou, Guildenstern? Ah,
line 25392-->    Rosencrantz! Good lads, how do ye both?
line 25393-->  Ros. As the indifferent children of the earth.
line 25394-->  Guil. Happy in that we are not over-happy.
line 25395-->    On Fortune's cap we are not the very button.
line 25396-->  Ham. Nor the soles of her shoe?
line 25397-->  Ros. Neither, my lord.
line 25398-->  Ham. Then you live about her waist, or in the middle of her
line 25399-->    favours?
line 25400-->  Guil. Faith, her privates we.
line 25401-->  Ham. In the secret parts of Fortune? O! most true! she is a
line 25402-->    strumpet. What news ?
line 25403-->  Ros. None, my lord, but that the world's grown honest.
line 25404-->  Ham. Then is doomsday near! But your news is not true. Let me
line 25405-->    question more in particular. What have you, my good friends,
line 25406-->    deserved at the hands of Fortune that she sends you to prison
line 25407-->    hither?
line 25408-->  Guil. Prison, my lord?  
line 25409-->  Ham. Denmark's a prison.
line 25410-->  Ros. Then is the world one.
line 25411-->  Ham. A goodly one; in which there are many confines, wards, and
line 25412-->    dungeons, Denmark being one o' th' worst.
line 25413-->  Ros. We think not so, my lord.
line 25414-->  Ham. Why, then 'tis none to you; for there is nothing either good
line 25415-->    or bad but thinking makes it so. To me it is a prison.
line 25416-->  Ros. Why, then your ambition makes it one. 'Tis too narrow for your
line 25417-->    mind.
line 25418-->  Ham. O God, I could be bounded in a nutshell and count myself a
line 25419-->    king of infinite space, were it not that I have bad dreams.
line 25420-->  Guil. Which dreams indeed are ambition; for the very substance of
line 25421-->    the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.
line 25422-->  Ham. A dream itself is but a shadow.
line 25423-->  Ros. Truly, and I hold ambition of so airy and light a quality that
line 25424-->    it is but a shadow's shadow.
line 25425-->  Ham. Then are our beggars bodies, and our monarchs and outstretch'd
line 25426-->    heroes the beggars' shadows. Shall we to th' court? for, by my
line 25427-->    fay, I cannot reason.
line 25428-->  Both. We'll wait upon you.  
line 25429-->  Ham. No such matter! I will not sort you with the rest of my
line 25430-->    servants; for, to speak to you like an honest man, I am most
line 25431-->    dreadfully attended. But in the beaten way of friendship, what
line 25432-->    make you at Elsinore?
line 25433-->  Ros. To visit you, my lord; no other occasion.
line 25434-->  Ham. Beggar that I am, I am even poor in thanks; but I thank you;
line 25435-->    and sure, dear friends, my thanks are too dear a halfpenny. Were
line 25436-->    you not sent for? Is it your own inclining? Is it a free
line 25437-->    visitation? Come, deal justly with me. Come, come! Nay, speak.
line 25438-->  Guil. What should we say, my lord?
line 25439-->  Ham. Why, anything- but to th' purpose. You were sent for; and
line 25440-->    there is a kind of confession in your looks, which your modesties
line 25441-->    have not craft enough to colour. I know the good King and Queen
line 25442-->    have sent for you.
line 25443-->  Ros. To what end, my lord?
line 25444-->  Ham. That you must teach me. But let me conjure you by the rights
line 25445-->    of our fellowship, by the consonancy of our youth, by the
line 25446-->    obligation of our ever-preserved love, and by what more dear a
line 25447-->    better proposer could charge you withal, be even and direct with
line 25448-->    me, whether you were sent for or no.  
line 25449-->  Ros. [aside to Guildenstern] What say you?
line 25450-->  Ham. [aside] Nay then, I have an eye of you.- If you love me, hold
line 25451-->    not off.
line 25452-->  Guil. My lord, we were sent for.
line 25453-->  Ham. I will tell you why. So shall my anticipation prevent your
line 25454-->    discovery, and your secrecy to the King and Queen moult no
line 25455-->    feather. I have of late- but wherefore I know not- lost all my
line 25456-->    mirth, forgone all custom of exercises; and indeed, it goes so
line 25457-->    heavily with my disposition that this goodly frame, the earth,
line 25458-->    seems to me a sterile promontory; this most excellent canopy, the
line 25459-->    air, look you, this brave o'erhanging firmament, this majestical
line 25460-->    roof fretted with golden fire- why, it appeareth no other thing
line 25461-->    to me than a foul and pestilent congregation of vapours. What a
line 25462-->    piece of work is a man! how noble in reason! how infinite in
line 25463-->    faculties! in form and moving how express and admirable! in
line 25464-->    action how like an angel! in apprehension how like a god! the
line 25465-->    beauty of the world, the paragon of animals! And yet to me what
line 25466-->    is this quintessence of dust? Man delights not me- no, nor woman
line 25467-->    neither, though by your smiling you seem to say so.
line 25468-->  Ros. My lord, there was no such stuff in my thoughts.  
line 25469-->  Ham. Why did you laugh then, when I said 'Man delights not me'?
line 25470-->  Ros. To think, my lord, if you delight not in man, what lenten
line 25471-->    entertainment the players shall receive from you. We coted them
line 25472-->    on the way, and hither are they coming to offer you service.
line 25473-->  Ham. He that plays the king shall be welcome- his Majesty shall
line 25474-->    have tribute of me; the adventurous knight shall use his foil and
line 25475-->    target; the lover shall not sigh gratis; the humorous man shall
line 25476-->    end his part in peace; the clown shall make those laugh whose
line 25477-->    lungs are tickle o' th' sere; and the lady shall say her mind
line 25478-->    freely, or the blank verse shall halt fort. What players are
line 25479-->    they?
line 25480-->  Ros. Even those you were wont to take such delight in, the
line 25481-->    tragedians of the city.
line 25482-->  Ham. How chances it they travel? Their residence, both in
line 25483-->    reputation and profit, was better both ways.
line 25484-->  Ros. I think their inhibition comes by the means of the late
line 25485-->    innovation.
line 25486-->  Ham. Do they hold the same estimation they did when I was in the
line 25487-->    city? Are they so follow'd?
line 25488-->  Ros. No indeed are they not.  
line 25489-->  Ham. How comes it? Do they grow rusty?
line 25490-->  Ros. Nay, their endeavour keeps in the wonted pace; but there is,
line 25491-->    sir, an eyrie of children, little eyases, that cry out on the top
line 25492-->    of question and are most tyrannically clapp'd fort. These are now
line 25493-->    the fashion, and so berattle the common stages (so they call
line 25494-->    them) that many wearing rapiers are afraid of goosequills and
line 25495-->    dare scarce come thither.
line 25496-->  Ham. What, are they children? Who maintains 'em? How are they
line 25497-->    escoted? Will they pursue the quality no longer than they can
line 25498-->    sing? Will they not say afterwards, if they should grow
line 25499-->    themselves to common players (as it is most like, if their means
line 25500-->    are no better), their writers do them wrong to make them exclaim
line 25501-->    against their own succession.
line 25502-->  Ros. Faith, there has been much to do on both sides; and the nation
line 25503-->    holds it no sin to tarre them to controversy. There was, for a
line 25504-->    while, no money bid for argument unless the poet and the player
line 25505-->    went to cuffs in the question.
line 25506-->  Ham. Is't possible?
line 25507-->  Guil. O, there has been much throwing about of brains.
line 25508-->  Ham. Do the boys carry it away?  
line 25509-->  Ros. Ay, that they do, my lord- Hercules and his load too.
line 25510-->  Ham. It is not very strange; for my uncle is King of Denmark, and
line 25511-->    those that would make mows at him while my father lived give
line 25512-->    twenty, forty, fifty, a hundred ducats apiece for his picture in
line 25513-->    little. 'Sblood, there is something in this more than natural, if
line 25514-->    philosophy could find it out.
line 25515-->
line 25516-->                     Flourish for the Players.
line 25517-->
line 25518-->  Guil. There are the players.
line 25519-->  Ham. Gentlemen, you are welcome to Elsinore. Your hands, come! Th'
line 25520-->    appurtenance of welcome is fashion and ceremony. Let me comply
line 25521-->    with you in this garb,
